headline: Research Scientists to Use Network Much Faster Than Internet
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A series of ultra-high-speed fiber-optic cables will weave a cluster of West Coast university laboratories and supercomputer centers into a network called the Pacific Research Platform as part of a five-year $5 million dollar grant from the National Science Foundation.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Are Artificial Sweeteners Safer Than Sugar?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Inmate’s Suit Over Abortion Denial Ends With Her Decision to Have Child
text: FLORENCE, Ala. — A lawsuit brought by a pregnant Alabama inmate seeking access to an abortion was dismissed by a federal judge on Friday after the woman said she had changed her mind and would carry the child.

headline: Lawmakers on Azerbaijan Trip Cleared
text: The House Ethics Committee announced Friday that it had cleared 10 lawmakers and 32 House employees of any wrongdoing associated with a trip they took in May 2013 to Azerbaijan, even though investigators found inconclusive evidence suggesting that the approximately $200,000 worth of airfare and other bills were improperly paid for by the Azerbaijan government. Six lawmakers were ordered to return rugs and other gifts they received during the trip. And the investigators urged the Department of Justice to examine “possible criminal” efforts to mislead the lawmakers about who actually paid for the travel.

headline: Jerome Kohlberg Jr., Pioneer of the Private Equity Industry, Dies at 90
text: Jerome Kohlberg Jr., a veteran financier who pioneered the $2.6 trillion leveraged-buyout industry but later rejected its hunger for huge and aggressive deals, died on Thursday at his home in Martha’s Vineyard. He was 90.

headline: Food Program Gets Emergency Cash
text: The anti-hunger agency of the United Nations said Friday that it had averted an imminent suspension of food aid to 440,000 Syrian refugees in Jordan after the United States provided a $65 million infusion. In a statement, the agency, the World Food Program, said the American money would enable it to maintain, albeit at a reduced level, food voucher assistance to the refugees, who all live outside camps in Jordan. “This timely contribution has helped us avoid major cuts, but unless other donors step up to the plate, it will be only a matter of months before we face the same situation again,” Muhannad Hadi, the agency’s regional director, said in a statement. The agency, which assists 80 million people in 80 countries, has been vexed by recurring financial travails as humanitarian crises have expanded in the Middle East and Africa.

headline: Maine Court Considers Vetoes by Gov. LePage
text: PORTLAND, Me. — The contentious standoff between Gov. Paul R. LePage of Maine and the State Legislature moved to the courts Friday as the two sides battled over whether the governor vetoed 65 bills within the proper time frame.

headline: For Prisoners, a Path to Society
text: Conservatives and liberals who clash on just about everything else agree that the harsh drug sentencing laws that swept the country starting four decades ago have been wholly counterproductive, driving up prison costs to bankrupting levels, undermining confidence in justice and decimating communities. But as Congress seeks to reform federal sentencing policies, it should revisit other outdated policies that trap people with criminal convictions at the margins of society — and indeed have driven many of them back to jail — by denying them jobs, housing and education.

headline: New York City to Reroute Garbage Truck Ramp Planned on East Side
text: Score one for the neighbors.

headline: Lynn Anderson, Singer of ‘Rose Garden,’ Dies at 67
text: Lynn Anderson, who skyrocketed to country music stardom in 1970 singing her signature song, “(I Never Promised You a) Rose Garden,” died on Thursday in Nashville. She was 67.

headline: Republicans Audition for Big Money
text: A definitive event in the plutocratic spending binge now engulfing presidential politics is taking place in Orange County, Calif., this weekend. The Koch brothers and 450 of their most affluent allies are auditioning a select group of Republican candidates, who are vying to get a share of the whopping $889 million pledged by these donors for the presidential race next year.

headline: Third Person Dies of Legionnaires’ Disease in the Bronx
text: A third person died of Legionnaire’s disease in the Bronx on Friday, health officials said, part of an outbreak of the airborne illness that has emerged during the hottest weeks of the year as many seek relief with air-conditioning systems that help spread the bacteria.

headline: Samuel DuBose’s Death in Cincinnati Points to Off-Campus Power of College Police
text: CINCINNATI — Six years ago, with crime creeping upward in the tree-lined, if slightly downtrodden, neighborhoods encircling the University of Cincinnati campus, the city and the university quietly signed an agreement giving the 72-member campus police force authority to patrol nearby residential streets.

headline: New Meningitis Strain in Africa Brings Call for More Vaccines
text: Meningitis may be poised for a ferocious comeback in Africa, international aid organizations are warning, and vaccine manufacturers must step up production if the outbreak is to be averted.

headline: Contenders Use Late Deals to Pad the Margins of Their Rosters
text: The shelves were not exactly empty for general managers on Friday, but the snazziest items were already gone. The flurry of deals in the final hours before the nonwaiver deadline mostly helped contenders at the margins of their rosters.

headline: The Glow of the Special Olympics
text: Athletes from around the world competed in Los Angeles this week.

headline: Special Olympics and the Burden of Happiness
text: When Special Olympics athletes get their medals — and the competitions are designed so that many, many do — the music swells, they pump their fists and their parents and teammates clap and yell. At the 2015 Special Olympics World Games across Los Angeles this week, the medals ceremonies went on for hours, a cascade of triumphant moments, one after another after another.

headline: Woman Arrested After Jumping Over White House Barricade
text: WASHINGTON — A woman was arrested on Friday evening after she jumped over a barricade in front of the White House fence, a spokesman for the Secret Service said.

headline: Emails Expand on Mosaic of Hillary Clinton’s Days as Secretary of State
text: WASHINGTON — A new batch of emails released on Friday portray Hillary Rodham Clinton when she was secretary of state, dealing with everything from political unrest in Honduras and a freeze on Israeli settlements in the Palestinian territories to minor details of her schedule and even a shipment of apples to her office.

headline: Concern Mixes With Trust Issues for Sheldon Richardson
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The first eight minutes of Coach Todd Bowles’s news conference on Friday were devoted to a subject he had thought he would not have to address again. Willie Colon answered questions about it, as did Brandon Marshall and Damon Harrison.

headline: Should We Charge Patients for Medical Research?
text: A FEW months ago, we got a call from a former oncology professor of ours. He had developed an experimental precision diagnostic test that he thought would be able to determine which chemotherapies would be most effective against a patient’s cancer. He wanted to conduct a research trial to evaluate the effectiveness of the new test. But there was one big problem: The research had no funding.

headline: ‘Super PACs’ Spent Millions Before Candidates Announced, Filings Show
text: Acting as shadow campaigns, the political committees backing the major presidential candidates supported them with tens of millions of dollars in chartered planes, luxury hotel suites, opposition research, high-priced lawyers and more, spending reports showed Friday.

headline: American Pharoah Arrives in New Jersey
text: American Pharoah, the first Triple Crown winner in 37 years, received a warm welcome upon arriving at Monmouth Park in New Jersey. He is preparing to race on Aug. 2 in the Haskell Invitational.

headline: Works of Childlike Simplicity
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — One of the nice things about puzzle constructing is that it can be done by anyone of mostly any age who happens to have the urge to construct and enough masochism to want to pursue it as a hobby (very few people actually make a living at it.)

headline: New York City Questions English, Math and Science Taught at Yeshivas
text: The New York City Department of Education plans to investigate whether roughly three dozen private yeshivas are providing an adequate education in secular subjects like English, math and science, in response to a letter from parents, former students and former teachers expressing concerns, the department said this week.

headline: Cosmopolitan Magazine Covers to Be Shielded by 2 Retailers
text: Is Cosmopolitan so racy it needs to be covered up?

headline: Revenge of the Ideologues: Killing the Export-Import Bank
text: “Idiotic,” sputtered Heidi Heitkamp, the Democratic senator from North Dakota. “Mind-bogglingly idiotic.”

headline: Giants Sign James Jones to Shore Up Receivers
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Coach Tom Coughlin confirmed Friday that the Giants had signed James Jones, the former Green Bay and Oakland wide receiver.

headline: 2022 Olympics Leave China Beaming From Its Growing Clout
text: HONG KONG — Dong Jianguo, 25, a vegetable farmer from the hills outside of Beijing, cannot afford to ski, snowboard, play hockey or luge.

headline: Can China’s Games Help Human Rights?
text: The Times’s Nicholas Kristof, who covered China in the 1980s, explains how Beijing’s Olympic win can also help improve the country’s tarnished human rights record.

headline: Yankees Bypass A-List Trades, Content With Pitchers for Now and Later
text: CHICAGO — For all the hype surrounding the Yankees’ top prospects, the nonwaiver trading deadline was an opportunity to test the patience and resolve of a franchise that has rarely been known for either.

headline: Roddy Piper, a Master Villain of Professional Wrestling, Dies at 61
text: Rowdy Roddy Piper, a professional wrestler whose athleticism and antics in the ring helped raise the profile of World Wrestling Entertainment in the 1980s, has died, his agent said on Friday. He was 61.

headline: Wilmer Flores Swaps Tears for Cheers With Walk-Off Home Run
text: It was around 11 p.m. Friday when Terry Collins predicted the future.

headline: Cover Letter of St. Louis Family Court Report
text: The Justice Department’s Civil Rights Division has completed a 20-month investigation.

headline: Summary of Findings in St. Louis Family Court Report
text: The Justice Department’s report is based on data on nearly 33,000 cases over three years.

headline: Justice Department Report on the St. Louis County Family Court
text: The department said Friday that the juvenile justice system in St. Louis County, Mo., treats black youths far more harshly than whites.

headline: Department of Justice Civil Rights Reforms in Juvenile Justice
text: The Justice Department has released findings in four juvenile justice administration cases.

headline: Justice Department Investigation of St. Louis County Family Court
text: The department said Friday that the juvenile justice system in St. Louis County, Mo., treats black youths far more harshly than whites.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) BIRDMAN OR (THE UNEXPECTED VIRTUE OF IGNORANCE) (2014) Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton, in an Oscar-nominated performance), a washed-up Hollywood superhero, floats down to earth to deliver himself from his past by staging a Broadway adaptation of a Raymond Carver short story. Then a pompous theater actor (Edward Norton) comes along and threatens to steal the show. Riggan’s fresh-from-rehab daughter (Emma Stone) has taken on the role of his assistant. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called this best-picture winner “a funny, frenetic, buoyant and rambunctiously showboating entertainment” in which the director Alejandro G. Iñárritu “himself rises high and then higher still.” Riggan, Mr. Scott added, “isn’t the only man on the move: So is Mr. Iñárritu, who has staged and shot the movie so that it looks like everything that happens, from airborne beginning to end, occurs during one transporting continuous take. The camera doesn’t just move with the story and characters, it also ebbs and flows like water, soars and swoops like a bird, its movement as fluid as a natural element, as animated as a living organism.” Mr. Iñárritu won the Oscar for best director, and Emmanuel Lubezki for cinematography.

headline: Tibetan Who Called for Dalai Lama’s Return Is Said to Be Freed From Chinese Prison
text: BEIJING — A Tibetan man who was imprisoned for eight years after calling for the Dalai Lama’s return to Tibet at a popular festival has been released, according to overseas Tibet advocacy groups.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “But maybe everything that dies someday comes back. Maybe Asbury Park is back?”

headline: Corrections: August 1, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Mark Karpeles, Chief of Bankrupt Bitcoin Exchange, Is Arrested in Tokyo
text: TOKYO — Since the collapse last year of Mt. Gox, the exchange that served as the largest hub for storing and trading the virtual currency Bitcoin, law enforcement officials and angry clients have been asking what happened to nearly half a billion dollars in Bitcoins that the company said had vanished from its computer systems.

headline: Turning Point: Hilary Swift
text: Hilary Swift, a photography intern with The New York Times, has previously worked for the Reno Gazette-Journal in Nevada and The Free Lance-Star in Virginia. Ms. Swift, 22, participated in the 2014 Eddie Adams Workshop and the 2015 New York Portfolio Review. Her conversation with Elijah Walker has been edited.

headline: I’m Not Mad. That’s Just My RBF.
text: I didn’t think much about it at the time: I was appearing in a short television segment and had quickly brushed my hair, then slapped on some concealer. I figured my glasses would cover the circles under my eyes.

headline: My Dinner With Longevity Expert Dan Buettner (No Kale Required)
text: Dan Buettner and I were off to a good start. He approved of coffee.

headline: Censure and Clashes After West Bank Attack
text: JALAZOUN REFUGEE CAMP, West Bank — Palestinian youths clashed with Israeli forces while thousands of Israelis flocked to rallies, all of them protesting an arson attack that killed a Palestinian toddler — a rare instance of mutual shock in a land attuned to bitter violence.

headline: A Late Summer Night’s Dream on Michigan’s Mackinac Island
text: New at Mission Point Resort on Mackinac Island in Michigan will be a Shakespearean-themed two-night package from Aug. 27 to 31 called “Stratford on the Straits.”

headline: 120 Degrees and No Relief? ISIS Takes Back Seat for Iraqis
text: BAGHDAD — In the Iraqi summer, when the temperature rises above 120 degrees Fahrenheit, electricity becomes even more of a political issue than usual. This past week, at the top of Iraqis’ agenda, it has even eclipsed war with the Islamic State.

headline: U.S. Declassifies FISA Court Documents about the Protect America Act
text: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit filed by The New York Times, the Obama administration has declassified and released documents related to the Protect America Act in late 2007 and early 2008. The documents fill in a gap in the historical record regarding the evolution of the Bush administration’s post-9/11 warrantless surveillance program.

headline: Hot Hot Hot
text: TIMES INSIDER — It’s hot outside. You want to be either poolside or, lacking a pool, somewhere in air-conditioning with a cool beverage and a crossword puzzle. So let’s get to it: We have four puzzles that may or may not take your mind off the heat.

headline: When the Super Has a Drinking Problem
text: A Belligerent Superintendent

headline: Joe Biden in 2016: What Would Beau Do?
text: WASHINGTON — A PATTERN of cutting corners, a patina of entitlement and inevitability, has led to this.

headline: New Orleans Hospital Is Replaced, With Hope of Preserving Its Mission
text: NEW ORLEANS — After Hurricane Katrina, the shrunken medical staff of the state-owned Charity Hospital worked out of tents, an abandoned Lord & Taylor department store and eventually a cramped interim hospital with scaled-back services. As best they could, they continued Charity’s centuries-old mission of caring for poor and uninsured residents, mostly black, whom other hospitals typically turned away.

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Review: Twitter Problems
text: We are trying something new. Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, will review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe even a few jokes about the most important developments in the industry.

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — For those of you just joining us, the deal here is that this particular variety puzzle looks like a crossword and it smells like a crossword (seriously; put your nose right against the paper or screen), but it is only a crossword in the sense that it crosses words.

headline: Small Pool of Rich Donors Dominates Election Giving
text: Fewer than four hundred families are responsible for almost half the money raised in the 2016 presidential campaign, a concentration of political donors that is unprecedented in the modern era.

headline: Joel S. Marcus on Taking the Ego Out of Leading
text: This interview with Joel S. Marcus, chief executive of Alexandria Real Estate Equities, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Providing the Soundtrack for Life’s Last Moments
text: I’ve been called an angel more times than I care to admit. That’s what happens when you walk down hospital hallways with a harp and have a job that primarily serves people who are dying.

headline: The Strip
text: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: The Treat That Could Bite Your Dog Back
text: The Haggler chatted recently with a woman named Muriel Mateer, who did something in late July that nearly had disastrous consequences: She gave her dog a bone. Specifically, she gave her dog a Real Ham Bone, a shrink-wrapped canine treat that is, in fact, a real pork femur, made by Dynamic Pet Products of Washington, Mo.

headline: Mets’ Relationship With Yoenis Cespedes? It’s a Rental
text: The Mets’ union with Yoenis Cespedes seems certain to be brief. Cespedes, the slugging outfielder acquired for two prospects on Friday, is a free agent after this season. The Mets have three other outfielders signed for 2016 and an aversion to the kind of lavish deal Cespedes will command.

headline: Dr. Stephen Klasko: Where Einstein, Jobs and Yoda Join Strategy Sessions
text: Dr. Stephen Klasko is the President and C.E.O. of Thomas Jefferson University and Jefferson Health, Philadelphia.

headline: Converse Treads Carefully in Updating Well-Worn Chuck Taylor Brand
text: Nike came out with a new product last Tuesday, an updated and — for my feet — more comfortable version of an old canvas basketball sneaker known as the Converse Chuck Taylor All Star.

headline: Flooding Spurs Disaster Zones in Myanmar
text: YANGON, Myanmar — Myanmar’s president on Friday declared four rural regions to be disaster zones, as floods and landslides continued to cause severe damage and the government faced criticism for its slow response to the emergency.

headline: Former White Sox Organist’s Offbeat Approach Resonated for Decades
text: In 1970, just before she was hired as the organist for the Chicago White Sox, Nancy Faust received a letter from a team official.

headline: Vahé Alaverdian
text: Vahé Alaverdian is a master falconer whose company, Falcon Force, has a staff of more than 30 raptors, which are used to scare off, but not kill, nuisance birds (starlings, gulls, pigeons, etc.) at vineyards, farms, airports, historical sites and amusement parks.

headline: ‘Hamilton’ and the Republican Hopefuls
text: HOW fitting that the Republican presidential candidates will hold their first debate this Thursday on the same night as the Broadway opening of “Hamilton,” the groundbreaking new musical about the founding fathers. At a time when so many American politicians are sanitized, cautious, even boring, the characters on the debate stage and the Broadway stage are remarkably in sync: brazen, unpredictable, even outrageous.

headline: Republican Hypocrisy on Iran
text: The exaggerations and half-truths that some Republicans are using to derail  President Obama‘s important and necessary nuclear deal with Iran are beyond ugly. Invoking the Holocaust, Mike Huckabee, a contender for the Republican presidential nomination, has accused Mr. Obama of marching Israelis “to the door of the oven.” Tom Cotton, a senator from Arkansas, has compared Secretary of State John Kerry, who helped negotiate the deal, to Pontius Pilate.

headline: How to Fight Doping in Sports
text: FEW sports performances are regarded without suspicion these days. Nowhere was this more evident than in the recent Tour de France, where the winner, Chris Froome of the British Team Sky, spent three weeks responding to skeptics about his exceptional performances, which rivaled those of doped champions, including Lance Armstrong.

headline: Is New Orleans Safe?
text: New Orleans — THIS city always had a different rhythm. It was the opposite of New York: After a stevedore was overheard saying, “If you can’t make it in the Big Easy, you can’t make it anywhere,” the phrase “The Big Easy” made its way from the African-American community into Newsweek, and spread. For decades, the city’s ambitious young men and women loved it yet fled, while those who did move here found places for themselves in existing spaces, slipping into its crevices, embracing it.

headline: President Obama’s Racial Renaissance
text: WE finally have the president we thought we elected: one who talks directly and forcefully about race and human rights.

headline: Palm Oil Company Is Accused of Exploiting Liberia’s Ebola Crisis
text: KABADA, Liberia — Standing in his garden, Alex Wloh wistfully cradled a few ears of corn in his hands. A mile or so away, field workers had been planting palm seedlings where he and his fellow villagers used to grow crops like rice, cassava and vegetables.

headline: Congress Should Look Beyond the Gas Tax
text: Lawmakers in Washington are so scared of raising the inadequate federal gas tax that they keep passing short-term bills to move money from other taxes to fund transportation projects. They should develop the kind of courage legislatures in red states like Utah, Nebraska and South Dakota have shown and raise the gas tax.

headline: Why the Economy Is Not Ready for an Interest Rate Increase
text: The Federal Reserve talked up the economy last Wednesday, in a statement that emphasized improvements in employment, housing and consumer spending. Unfortunately, the optimism is misplaced.

headline: A New Abortion Furor
text: Readers discuss the videos of officials at Planned Parenthood discussing fetal tissue.

headline: Joe Biden Said to Be Taking New Look at Presidential Run
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his associates have begun to actively explore a possible presidential campaign, which would upend the Democratic field and deliver a direct threat to Hillary Rodham Clinton, several people who have spoken to Mr. Biden or his closest advisers say.

headline: Our Sex-Crazed Congress
text: TO appreciate the dumbing down of American politics, consider this: Conservative Republicans, indignant about abortion, are trying to destroy a government program that helps prevent 345,000 abortions a year.

headline: The Tortured Tale of Hillary Clinton and The Times
text: The history of the Clintons and The New York Times over the decades is like an airport baggage carousel — with a difference. New pieces keep barreling down the chute, but none of it ever seems to get removed.

headline: The Donald’s Gifts for Jeb Bush
text: THE most important question of the moment, as the Republican Party prepares for the first of 1,162 or so presidential primary debates, isn’t really what Donald Trump will say or do on stage.

headline: Grand Jury Indicts Texas Attorney General, Ken Paxton, on Felony Charges
text: HOUSTON — Ken Paxton, the Republican attorney general of Texas and a former state legislator, has been indicted by a grand jury on charges of securities fraud and of failing to register with the state securities board, officials said.

headline: Giants Undertake Major Renovation Projects on Both Sides of the Ball
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — There are still four Super Bowl trophies in a shimmering case just inside the front door of the Giants’ offices and training complex. Thirty-foot banners commemorating those defining victories dominate the indoor practice grounds.

headline: Taliban Leader Urges Unity, Playing Down Peace Talk
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two days after acknowledging that its supreme commander, Mullah Muhammad Omar, was dead, the Taliban released an audio recording said to be from the group’s new leader.

headline: Ohio State’s Ascent Reinvigorates the Big Ten
text: CHICAGO — In January, the Big Ten felt united as perhaps never before. After years of perceived decline in its signature sport, football, the conference had seen its champion — Ohio State — become the first league team to play for the national title since the 2007 season, and the first to win one since the 2002 season.

headline: Aja Zanova, Top Czech Skater Who Defected to West, Dies at 84
text: Aja Zanova, a world champion figure skater whose defection from Czechoslovakia as a teenager in 1950 made headlines around the world, died on Thursday in Manhattan. She was 84.

headline: In Case You Missed It: Top Articles of the Week
text: Catch up with the most-read sports stories in The New York Times from July 24 to July 30.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Missing the Point in a Biological Controversy

headline: Bronx Residents Anxious After 4th Death From Legionnaires’ Disease
text: The largest outbreak of Legionnaires’ disease in New York City in at least three years has claimed its fourth victim, health officials said on Saturday, reinforcing concerns among some residents and elected leaders that the city had not adequately prepared to combat the airborne illness.

headline: Highly Coordinated
text: When “don’t look down” isn’t an option.

headline: A.& P. Bankruptcy Means New York, Chain’s Birthplace, Will Lose Last Store
text: Linda Fisch stopped at the A.&P. on Riverdale Avenue in the Bronx on Thursday and bought eight prepackaged containers of cottage cheese and fruit. She did not realize the store had become a footnote to history.

headline: In Compromise, Pro Football Hall of Fame Offers to let Junior Seau’s Daughter Speak at Ceremony
text: Sydney Seau may speak after all — sort of.

headline: Inflation Paranoia as a Tribal Marker
text: Derp — views that just keep being repeated in the face of overwhelming contrary evidence — has always been with us, but the derp quotient has really soared since the crisis of 2008, which made nonsense of doctrines too dearly held to be reconsidered. This is especially true of inflation derp: has any prominent figure who warned of runaway inflation from the Fed’s efforts admitted having learned anything from being wrong year after year?

headline: Dr. James Jude, Who Helped Develop Use of CPR, Dies at 87
text: Dr. James Jude, a thoracic surgeon whose recognition that external manual pressure could revive a stalled heart, and who used that insight to help develop the lifesaving technique now known as cardiopulmonary resuscitation, or CPR, died on Tuesday at his home in Coral Gables, Fla. He was 87.

headline: Literally Speaking
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — A very literal puzzle today from Matt Ginsberg, where the circled squares do exactly what the entire phrase describes. I do love an obedient crossword puzzle.

headline: After Deal, Europeans Are Eager to Do Business in Iran
text: PARIS — Before the ink was even dry on the Iran nuclear deal, European leaders and executives were heading to the airport to restart trade with an Iranian market described in almost feverish terms as “an El Dorado” and potential “bonanza.”

headline: Dry Days Bring Ferocious Start to Fire Season
text: WALLA WALLA, Wash. — Another summer of record-breaking drought and heat has seized the West, setting off costly and destructive wildfires from Southern California, where a single blaze burned more than 30,000 acres of national forest east of Los Angeles, to Montana, where a fast-moving fire in Glacier National Park recently forced tourists to flee hotels, campgrounds and vehicles.

headline: Laos, Destination in Illegal Ivory Trade, So Far Eludes Global Crackdown
text: BANGKOK — When the authorities in Thailand recently intercepted huge stashes of ivory stuffed inside shipments of beans and tea leaves, the seizures were described as groundbreaking international police work.

headline: Bay Area’s Disjointed Public Transit Network Inspires a Call for Harmony
text: SAN FRANCISCO — There is much to relish about the Bay Area, from the intoxicating landscape to the blissful lack of humidity.

headline: Inquiry Faults Huma Abedin, Close Aide to Hillary Clinton
text: WASHINGTON — The State Department inspector general has determined that Huma Abedin, the close confidant of Hillary Rodham Clinton, must return more than $9,000 for alleged overpayments made to her during her time working for the department when Mrs. Clinton was secretary of state, according to her lawyer and Senate documents.

headline: Jets Offer Support and Tough Love to Sheldon Richardson
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The first few days of Mike Maccagnan’s first training camp as the Jets’ general manager had been largely quiet — except for Sheldon Richardson’s latest off-the-field infractions, Muhammad Wilkerson’s simmering contract dispute and Devin Smith’s broken ribs.

headline: Medical Marijuana Dispensary Plan in the South Bronx Stirs Anxiety and Hope
text: The Hunts Point neighborhood in the South Bronx has struggled to clean up its act for years. Prostitution is still a problem, but it is far less prevalent, residents say, than it once was.

headline: Enigmatic Cespedes Is Charged With Lighting Up New York Again
text: The first time Yoenis Cespedes walked through the Mets’ clubhouse, he made an impression, intentional or not. He gave firm handshakes, looked his new teammates in the eye and introduced himself. He wore a necklace with a pendant the size of a baseball that showed his number, 52.

headline: Buddy Emmons, Virtuoso of the Steel Guitar, Dies at 78
text: Buddy Emmons, the inventive musician who reimagined and popularized the pedal steel guitar in jazz, country, and western swing bands beginning in the mid-1950s, performing with many of music’s biggest stars, died on July 21 in Hermitage, Tenn., near Nashville. He was 78.

headline: Training Officers to Shoot First, and He Will Answer Questions Later
text: WASHINGTON — The shooting looked bad. But that is when the professor is at his best. A black motorist, pulled to the side of the road for a turn-signal violation, had stuffed his hand into his pocket. The white officer yelled for him to take it out. When the driver started to comply, the officer shot him dead.

headline: Preparing for Debate, Republicans Test Themselves Against Donald Trump
text: Jeb Bush is spending hours in sessions from Florida to Maine preparing policy answers for Thursday’s first Republican debate — but he is also being mindful to avert any display of disdain for the man he will stand beside, Donald J. Trump, who has infuriated Mr. Bush by criticizing Mexican immigrants. (Mr. Bush is married to one.)

headline: Yoenis Cespedes Makes His Presence Felt, Indirectly, in a Win
text: The Citi Field crowd leapt from its seats and threw up its hands and roared in anticipation, watching a screaming line drive jump off Yoenis Cespedes’s bat. The second-largest crowd in the park’s history, 42,996 fans, had come to watch his Mets debut. He had been heralded as their offensive savior, and a home run would tie the score in the sixth inning.

headline: Stepping From Class AAA to Majors, Young Yankees Pitchers Can’t Deliver
text: CHICAGO — When General Manager Brian Cashman decided he did not want to trade his top prospects for the starting pitchers his first-place team needs at the moment, it was a show of faith in the farm system, particularly the pitchers he will be counting on now.

headline: Obama to Unveil Tougher Environmental Plan With His Legacy in Mind
text: WASHINGTON — In the strongest action ever taken in the United States to combat climate change, President Obama will unveil on Monday a set of environmental regulations devised to sharply cut planet-warming greenhouse gas emissions from the nation’s power plants and ultimately transform America’s electricity industry.

headline: Bianca Kaprielian, Deborah Koski
text: Bianca Lynn Kaprielian and Deborah Anne Koski were married Saturday at the Headlands Center for the Arts in Sausalito, Calif. Alison Hurwitz, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Xela Herridge-Meyer,  John Okrent
text: Xela Herridge-Meyer, a daughter of Tamie J. Herridge and Dick L. Meyer of Olympia, Wash., was married Saturday to Dr. John L. Okrent, the son of Rebecca L. Okrent and Daniel Okrent of South Wellfleet, Mass. The bride’s father, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the home of the bride’s friends, Abigail Rueb and Rolland Rueb, on Orcas Island, Wash.

headline: Why Some Start-Ups Are Called Tech Companies and Others Are Not
text: After Charles Lindbergh flew across the Atlantic in 1927, a company called Seaboard Air Line Railroad attracted an unusual amount of attention from investors who thought it was in the aviation business.

headline: Copwatch vs. Cops: After Freddie Gray
text: In a year of violent police encounters, a 25-year-old movement to document law enforcement has new urgency. This is the story of Copwatch as told by Michael Brown’s neighbor and Freddie Gray’s friend.

headline: Six Things Google Remembers About My Parenting That I’d Almost Forgotten
text: I’ve been a parent for six years. That is six short years full of long days. Our children are born tiny, helpless, things, then we blink and they’re fully formed human beings, and we can hardly remember what it was like when they didn’t sleep, pee or pretty much do anything the way we thought they should. Or at least, we can’t remember what it is they used to not do the way we thought they should, because we are so caught up in whatever it is they’re doing or not doing now.

headline: The Rising Cost of Manufacturing
text: A look at the (mostly) rising costs to manufacture goods by country and a breakdown of the cost to make yarn.

text: When Donna Yip, a lawyer who lives in the financial district, went into labor with her second child in June, she had more than just her husband and medical team in her room at NewYork-Presbyterian Morgan Stanley Children’s Hospital.

text: OTTAWA — Prime Minister Stephen Harper of Canada called federal elections on Sunday, hoping to extend his Conservative Party’s decade-long hold on power despite questions about its ethics and a struggling economy.

headline: 1965: Fists Fly in Athens Assembly
text: ATHENS — In its second attempt in three days, Premier George Athanasiades-Novas’s government tonight got the quorum it has been seeking to submit itself to a confidence debate in Parliament. But it did so in a session marked by fist fights and efforts to drag Foreign Minister George Melas down from the rostrum where he had been speaking. Police were called in to protect the minister from anti-government deputies who claimed he had abused one of their members.

headline: Tiny Island of Réunion Awash in Intrigue Over Vanished Malaysian Plane

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
text: 12:30 P.M. (13) LA DONNA DEL LAGO Joyce DiDonato, above, sings Elena, the lady of the lake, and Juan Diego Flórez is Giacomo, the king of Scotland, in Paul Curran’s staging of this Rossini melodrama, based on the poem by Sir Walter Scott and conducted by Michele Mariotti. “The wondrous Ms. DiDonato and Mr. Mariotti, the fast-rising young Italian conductor, seemed almost in competition to see who could make music with more delicacy,” Anthony Tommasini wrote in The New York Times of this production from the Metropolitan Opera and the Santa Fe Opera, presented here by “Great Performances at the Met.” “Ms. DiDonato sang Rossini’s beguiling phrases with soft yet penetrating richness, subtly folding ornaments and runs into the long melodic arcs. And Mr. Mariotti drew hushed gentle and transparent playing from the inspired Met orchestra.”

headline: ‘Poster Child’ for New York’s Paid Sick Leave Law Failed to Follow It
text: Shiv Puri embraced New York City’s paid sick leave law last year and was heralded as a trailblazer among employers. At City Hall, Mayor Bill de Blasio praised him as “a great example to business owners all across the city.”

headline: Animals on the Empire State Building
text: The artists Louie Psihoyos and Travis Threlkel projected digital images of endangered species onto the Empire State Building in an event meant to draw attention to the creatures’ plight.

headline: 2 Proud Daughters of the Bronx Share More Than a Name
text: The sounds of summer drifted through the air on the Bronx side of the High Bridge, from the squeals of children running along sun-dappled paths to the slaps of flip-flops hitting the pavement as boys with towels slung over their shoulders walked to the public swimming pool on the Manhattan side. Two women chatting on a bench stopped midsentence as two other women, smiling and familiar looking, ambled past.

headline: Kerry Warns Egypt Human Rights Abuses Can Hurt Fight Against Terrorism
text: CAIRO — Secretary of State John Kerry told Egyptian officials on Sunday that they would not be able to defeat terrorism at home unless they showed greater respect for human rights.

headline: France and Britain Seek Help on Calais Migrants From E.U.
text: LONDON — In a letter published on Sunday, the interior ministers of Britain and France called on other European Union countries to help solve the underlying causes of the migrant crisis at the port of Calais, where thousands of people have been trying to force their way onto trucks and trains bound for Britain through the tunnel linking the two countries.

headline: Eric Schlosser to Publish Book on American Prison System
text: Eric Schlosser, author of the best-selling exposé of the fast food industry, “Fast Food Nation,” will publish a new book that investigates America’s expanding prison system and explores how rising incarceration rates are intertwined with social factors like growing inequality.

headline: Donald Trump Campaign Fires Adviser Linked to Racially Charged Facebook Posts
text: Donald J. Trump has fired a campaign adviser after racially charged Facebook posts under his name emerged last week, Mr. Trump’s campaign manager said.

headline: Review: ‘The Economics of Inequality,’ by Thomas Piketty
text: Back in 2001 two French economists, Thomas Piketty and Emmanuel Saez, circulated a seminal research paper (formally published two years later) titled “Income inequality in the United States, 1913-1998.” They used data from income tax receipts to do two things that you can’t do with standard data on the distribution of income, which come from household surveys. First, they gave us a portrait of the economic stratosphere — the incomes of the now-famous 1 percent. Second, they gave us historical depth, reaching all the way back to the late Gilded Age.

headline: Freshwater’s Wrong Turn (Wonkish)
text: Paul Romer has been writing a series of posts on the problem he calls “mathiness”, in which economists write down fairly hard-to-understand mathematical models accompanied by verbal claims that don’t actually match what’s going on in the math. Most recently, he has been recounting the pushback he’s getting from freshwater macro types, who seem him as allying himself with evil people like me — whereas he sees them as having turned away from science toward a legalistic, adversarial form of pleading.

headline: Puerto Ricans Brace for Crisis in Health Care
text: MAYAGÜEZ, P.R. — The first visible sign that the health care system in Puerto Rico was seriously in trouble was when a steady stream of doctors — more than 3,000 in five years — began to leave the island for more lucrative, less stressful jobs on the mainland.

text: Uber, the ride-hailing app, seems capable of the impossible: fighting City Hall and winning.

headline: Review: Garth Fagan Dance Honors Geoffrey Holder Along With Carmen de Lavallade
text: The prodigious dancer, choreographer, painter, designer and actor Geoffrey Holder, who died in October — but not before reportedly dancing on his deathbed — would have been 85 on Saturday. Lincoln Center Out of Doors hosted a day of events in his honor, culminating in a performance by Garth Fagan Dance at Damrosch Park, with a prelude by Mr. Holder’s partner of 59 years, Carmen de Lavallade.

headline: Review: Jeremy Denk in a Full-Blooded Performance at Mostly Mozart
text: A Google search for scores written for one hand alone reveals a considerable repertory for each hand. The best-known works are for the left hand, like the concertos by Ravel and Korngold, composed for the pianist Paul Wittgenstein, who lost his right arm in World War I. Injury is often a motivating factor behind such compositions; Scriabin wrote for left hand after an injury to his right. Brahms dedicated his transcription for left hand of the Chaconne in D minor (from Bach’s Partita in D minor for solo violin) to Clara Schumann, who had injured her other hand.

headline: Talking to the Taliban
text: Fledgling peace talks between the Afghan government and the Taliban have been postponed indefinitely.

headline: R-Rated Comedies, ‘Vacation’ Among Them, Continue to Struggle
text: LOS ANGELES — Raunchy comedy is having a rough run at the box office.

headline: Review: Cecilia Bartoli Has Dramatic Depth as ‘Norma’ at Salzburg Festival
text: SALZBURG, Austria — During the mid-1990s, when Cecilia Bartoli was known for scintillating performances of roles like Rossini’s Cenerentola (Cinderella), the suggestion that this light-voiced mezzo-soprano might take on the daunting title role of Bellini’s “Norma” someday would have seemed absurd. Maria Callas had defined the role for late 20th-century audiences as a supreme test for a fiercely intense, formidable soprano. Some powerhouse mezzo-sopranos, like Shirley Verrett and Grace Bumbry, had made the leap. But a perky Cinderella singing Norma? No way.

headline: Review: Karen Oberlin’s ‘His Aim Is True,’ a Tribute to Elvis Costello
text: Karen Oberlin’s extensively researched, beautifully executed tribute to the music of Elvis Costello answers a question that has been gnawing at me for years: Why have so few of Mr. Costello’s songs achieved the status of modern standards? For all this time, I had assumed that his raw, unwelcoming voice, with its strangulated diction, was the reason. Surely, a better-equipped singer could untangle his knotty lyrics and sharpen the melodic profiles of songs that Mr. Costello presented as impassioned downbeat mystery stories.

headline: Review: ‘Significant Mother’ Puts a Son in an Awkward Situation
text: When is progress the opposite of progress? When it’s “Significant Mother,” a new comedy on CW that tried for the cutting edge but ended up dull and dimwitted.

headline: Review: ‘Beats of the Antonov’ Examines Sudan’s Civil Wars
text: In a recent series of opinion columns filed from the Nuba Mountains in southern Sudan, Nicholas Kristof of The New York Times decried the lack of attention paid to the Sudanese government’s brutal daily bombing of its own people. As if in response, on Monday PBS’s “POV” documentary series presents “Beats of the Antonov,” a film shot on the front lines of Sudan’s continuing civil wars.

headline: Seattle Art Fair Receives a Boost From Tech’s Big Spenders
text: SEATTLE — Paul Allen came ready to shop. Mr. Allen, a billionaire co-founder of Microsoft and one of this city’s major cultural patrons, strolled the aisles of the inaugural Seattle Art Fair on Thursday, looking to add to his formidable art collection.

headline: Review: License and Restriction in a Work by La Monte Young at Dia Chelsea
text: Some kind of tension, real or metaphorical, is primary for the life force of any music. La Monte Young’s music can have lots of tension with very few notes, and the performance of one of his early pieces at Dia: Chelsea’s “Dream House” on Friday had it in every aspect of its experience.

headline: Robin Phillips, Director, Dies at 75; Revitalized Canada’s Stratford Festival
text: Robin Phillips, a British theater director who helped rejuvenate Canada’s best-known theater, the Stratford Festival, as artistic director from 1975 to 1980, died on July 25 in Woodstock, Ontario. He was 75.

headline: Finland Unnerved by Trial of Police Detective on Drug Charges
text: Members of Finland’s National Bureau of Investigation were working to crack a drug smuggling ring, when they intercepted phone calls and text messages between a suspected supplier and buyer emanating from Pasila, a district of Helsinki.

headline: American Pharoah Wins Haskell Invitational
text: OCEANPORT, N.J. — Victor Espinoza was curious as he gave American Pharoah his head and let the colt slingshot around the far turn at Monmouth Park, a charming racetrack on the Jersey Shore. Espinoza peeked beneath one shoulder, glanced over the other, then narrowed his eyes between his colt’s ears and stared down the stretch.

headline: Toward the Back of a Ship
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — Ladies and gentlemen, I beg of you: We need to find David Steinberg a girlfriend. Somebody nice, who appreciates a young man who has a way with words. Because if you read his notes, they are infused with an ACHE and a LONGing that, frankly, are starting to make me weep. So if you have a lovely niece or daughter who is single and of college age, please let me know.

headline: A Resurgent Didi Gregorius Helps the Yankees Pound the White Sox
text: CHICAGO — As the baseball season advances further into August, the Yankees’ surprising ascent to the top of the American League East can be primarily traced to the turn-back-the-clock performances of Alex Rodriguez and Mark Teixeira, an offense that has scored the most first-inning runs and a bullpen that is among the most reliable in the majors.

headline: For Rohingya, Fear and Forced Marriages
text: As thousands of Rohingya women flee persecution and peril in Myanmar, many end up trapped by smugglers, vulnerable to exploitation and forced into prostitution and arranged marriages.

headline: Dr. Donald L. Rasmussen, Crusader for Coal Miners’ Health, Dies at 87
text: Dr. Donald L. Rasmussen, who was lured to Appalachia as a fledgling physician by a help-wanted ad and set off a grass-roots movement that won benefits for coal miners afflicted with black lung disease, died on July 23 in Beckley, W.Va. He was 87.

headline: Memphis Police Seek Man in Death of Officer
text: A suspect was being sought Sunday night in the killing of a Memphis police officer who was shot after he interrupted a drug deal the night before, the police said.

headline: John Gibbons, 86, Clinton Science Aide, Dies; Pushed Cooperation in Space

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Aug. 3

Used in jest, it has become Tokashiki’s favorite saying. But another favorite English word is “confidence,” something she has built during her first W.N.B.A. season. Tokashiki has become one of the league’s best rookies and a blooming fan favorite, while hoping to change the perception of women’s basketball in Japan.

headline: In a Sport of Beautiful Animals, Ugliness Is Unavoidable
text: OCEANPORT, N.J. — Outside the paddock before Sunday’s William Hill Haskell Invitational, the crowd angling for an up-close look at American Pharoah was, in some places, more than 20 people deep. The fans held their camera phones high. Some stood on their tiptoes, even if the reward was to catch just a glimpse of the colt’s shiny bay coat.

She worries he won’t write back as he’ll be occupied with “ordering people around, or eating lobster on silver plates or getting a massage, that kind of thing.” But Kim Jong-il responds. He even sends an autographed photo.

headline: Greece’s Market Reopens, European Banks Report Results, and Tesla Announces Earnings
text: The Athens Stock Exchange reopened on Monday after a five-week closure that followed a decision by the Greek authorities to shut Greek banks and impose capital controls. The banks reopened two weeks ago, though restrictions on cash transactions remain in place to avert a run on the banks’ deposits. To prevent capital flight, a mass sell-off of holdings and a market crash, there is a cap on stock fluctuations and restrictions on local traders, though foreign investors will face no constraints when stock trading resumes. The reopening of Greece’s market comes as government officials and representatives of the country’s international creditors enter a second week of difficult negotiations on a multibillion-euro bailout, Greece’s third in five years. —Niki Kitsantonis

headline: Picky Eating in Children Linked to Anxiety, Depression and A.D.H.D.
text: For the last several months, my 3-year-old daughter Annika has been on a steady diet of waffles, yogurt sticks and milk. Before that, she ate mainly hot dogs and milk. And for many months before that, she ate almost nothing but fruit-and-yogurt squeezers and, you guessed it, milk. While I haven’t exactly been thrilled with her eating habits, I recognize that in life, and in parenting, we need to pick our battles. And the food battle is one I had chosen not to fight in full force. I had purposefully avoided putting too much pressure on Annika to eat a wider variety of foods because I thought that might backfire and make things worse. I also figured she would branch out eventually, as my older daughter had. But a new study, published in the journal Pediatrics, made me wonder if I should rethink my strategy.

headline: With Ballpark Rocking, Mets Keep Rolling, Pulling Into a Tie for First

headline: What’s On TV Monday
text: 10 A.M. (TMC) HAPPY-GO-LUCKY (2008) The irrepressible optimism of a 30-year-old London schoolteacher (Sally Hawkins, above) grates on those whose days she’s intent on brightening up — among them, her driving instructor (Eddie Marsan), flamenco teacher (Karina Fernandez) and sister (Caroline Martin) — in this character study directed and written by Mike Leigh, which earned him an Oscar nomination for best original screenplay. Ms. Hawkins’s portrayal is “glorious,” a “gurgling, burbling stream of gasps, giggles and words,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “Mr. Leigh has a documentarian’s eye for unadorned reality — his people and places look equally lived in — and his dialogue has the ebb and flow, the swells and eddies and logjams of ordinary conversation,” she added. “But the dramatist in Mr. Leigh is always hard at work, aligning his characters for maximum narrative effect and emotional pow.”

headline: The Iran Deal’s Dangerous Precedent
text: HAD anyone believed President Obama’s mantra that “all options are on the table” to deal with Iran’s nuclear weapons program, the Vienna agreement might have emerged less advantageously for Tehran. But no one took Mr. Obama’s threat of military force seriously — a credibility gap that Israel still fears and Iran still exploits. Even so, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is still trying to reassure nervous Democrats in Congress that the Vienna agreement does not preclude America’s use of force.

headline: A Health Care Safety Net the Public Loves
text: Recent public surveys show that Americans strongly support Medicare and Medicaid, the twin pillars of the health care safety net, and that approval of the Affordable Care Act, President Obama’s health care reform law, is steadily rising. The popularity of these three government programs is a stiff warning to critics, mostly Republicans, who seek to radically change or demolish them.

Readers shared their own experiences with being told to smile, wondered about RBF’s cultural context and expressed frustration with the inherent sexism of such a term. headline: Patter and Patois
text: I am what you might call a grandchild of Louisiana. My father was born there as were many of his friends and relatives. Most of my neighbors in Los ­Angeles came from there too — black rural folk who had traveled west through southern Texas on their migration to escape the South’s heavy hail of racial hatred. They came to California for the tattered shelter of mocking freedom that the Golden State had to offer people like them, poor people willing to work hard.

headline: Cleaning Up a Legacy of Pollution on an Alaskan Island
text: ST. LAWRENCE ISLAND, Alaska — America’s Far North cherishes its image of wild purity in a landscape so vast it can sometimes seem barely touched by people. But the roughly 600 military installations across Alaska — some dating from World War II, others built during the Cold War — tell a different story, in polluted sites that were never fully cleaned up, and in the related health problems that have lingered and festered.

headline: Pregnancy Is the Best Time for Some Vaccines

headline: Don’t Blame Medicaid for Rise in Health Care Spending
text: Health care spending growth has moderated in recent years, but it’s still putting tremendous strain on state and local governments. A recent analysis by The Pew Charitable Trusts revealed that it consumed 31 percent of state and local government revenue in 2013, nearly doubling from 1987.

headline: Morning Agenda: Health Care Deals Raise Doubts for Consumers
text: HEALTH CARE DEALS RAISE DOUBTS FOR CONSUMERS | The recent frenzy of mergers among health insurers promised big savings, but not everyone is convinced that consumers will see that, Reed Abelson reports in The New York Times. The tie-up between Anthem and Cigna and the deal for Aetna to join its smaller rival Humana would create two behemoths. Along with UnitedHealthGroup, they would control nearly half of the American commercial health insurance market.

headline: Saving Tunisia From ISIS

headline: Cap and Trade and Polarization
text: One of the most obvious facts about the U.S. political scene is also a fact most pundits refuse to acknowledge: the extreme polarization we now experience, the complete disappearance of any kind of political center, is not a two-sided phenomenon. Democrats haven’t moved drastically to the left — if anything they inched right for a couple of decades, and are only now shuffling slightly back toward a more robust liberalism. But Republicans have barreled off to the right.

headline: When Will Fashion Discover Ronda Rousey?
text: For a sector that has suddenly discovered its love of all things “athleisure” (Tory Sport, anyone? Stella McCartney for Adidas? Kering’s Sport & Lifestyle division?) — not to mention its love of all things celebrity — fashion has been extraordinarily slow to embrace female sports stars.

headline: No Sanity Clause
text: Just in case you had any illusions about the state of US governance, and the sanity of the party that now controls Congress, the estimable Stan Collender now tells us that there is a better-than-even chance of a government shutdown this fall. headline: New York Regulator Moves to Suspend Promontory Financial
text: The Promontory Financial Group occupies a position of trust in the global financial system, acting as a consultant to big banks, foreign nations and the Vatican. Its influence has soared over the years, positioning it as a sort of shadow regulator that provides government authorities with a window into bank misconduct. And the firm’s political ties run deep, thanks to its founder and chief executive, Eugene A. Ludwig, a former top banking regulator and a law school friend of Bill Clinton.

When she does talk, she speaks the way she writes: succinctly, with nary a run-on sentence.

headline: In London: Food With a Heaping Side of Gimmick

headline: American Pharoah Steers Clear of Route of Past Triple Crown Winners
text: American Pharoah won the Haskell Invitational with ease Sunday. He was a 1-9 favorite and is the reigning Triple Crown winner, so few were surprised. He may race two or three more times at the most, then he will be retired. Few are surprised by that decision either.

headline: China Seeks Businessman Said to Have Fled to U.S., Further Straining Ties
text: LOOMIS, Calif. — China is demanding that the Obama administration return a wealthy and politically connected businessman who fled to the United States, according to several American officials familiar with the case. Should he seek political asylum, he could become one of the most damaging defectors in the history of the People’s Republic.

headline: Baby Name Change Could Reduce Hospital Errors
text: More than 80 percent of neonatal intensive-care units, or NICUs, use temporary first names for patients — Babygirl Jackson or Babyboy Goldsmith, for example — a convention that may lead to errors in prescribing medicines. A new study has found that a simple change in this procedure can significantly reduce such errors.

headline: Review: ‘Le Nozze Di Figaro’ Gets an Update in Salzburg
text: SALZBURG, Austria — For a director, conductor and cast, it must be intense pressure to present a new production of Mozart’s “Le Nozze di Figaro” amid the high expectations of the Salzburg Festival here in the composer’s hometown. But, if those involved in this summer’s new “Figaro” are feeling burdened, it did not come through during Sunday afternoon’s performance, the second of seven, at the intimate Haus für Mozart.

headline: Kraft Recalls Some Cheese Products Over Choking Concerns
text: The Kraft Heinz Company has recalled some of its individually wrapped cheese products over concerns that the plastic packaging could stick to the slice after being removed and cause a potential choking hazard.

headline: Joe Domanick’s ‘Blue’ Examines the L.A.P.D.
text: Being fired in New York and moving to Los Angeles is usually a smart career move. For William Bratton, the former New York City police commissioner under Mayor Rudy Giuliani, it was a no-brainer.

headline: Kerry Speaks On Iran Deal in Qatar
text: Secretary of State John Kerry spoke on Monday in Doha, Qatar, about the Iran nuclear deal. Mr. Kerry traveled to the Middle East in an attempt to get the Arab states to endorse the accord.

headline: Chilly at Work? Office Formula Was Devised for Men
text: Summers are hot in Omaha, where heat indexes can top 100 degrees. But Molly Mahannah is prepared.

headline: A Day at the Haskell
text: Over 60,000 fans visited Monmouth Park on Sunday to enjoy a sunny day on the Jersey Shore and to see American Pharoah race for the first time since he won the Triple Crown.

headline: Hannah Kirshner of Sweets & Bitters and Her Omelet Pan for the Backyard Bounty
text: “Chickens were always my thing,” said Hannah Kirshner, the founder and editor of Sweets & Bitters, a hybrid magazine-cookbook the size of a personal diary. “And once people know that. …”

headline: John Kerry Wins Gulf States’ Cautious Support for Iran Deal
text: DOHA, Qatar — Persian Gulf monarchies issued a cautious endorsement on Monday of the accord Secretary of State John Kerry negotiated last month to constrain Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: Roger Vivier’s Summer Capsule Collection, a Recipe App with Playlists and a Pinterest Inspired by Jealousy
text: Every week, T rounds up five captivating online destinations you should be visiting often.

headline: John Horton Conway, the Genius at Play
text: Try the famous Look-and-Say puzzle by John Horton Conway, the subject of the new biography “Genius at Play” by Siobhan Roberts.

headline: On the Heat Beat
text: How best to illustrate an impending snowfall or heat wave? The question arises at least once a year in most newsrooms, before a very snowy or a very hot day, and is usually met with a collective groan. Year after year, it gets tougher to come up with new ways to dramatize the story.

headline: What’s Your Greatest GIF Moment?
text: You text, you email, you tweet. We want to know how you use GIFs to communicate.

headline: The Challenges of Fighting Money Laundering
text: The Watergate credo to “follow the money” is the reason for a number of laws that require banks, credit unions and money-transmission businesses to keep track of who their customers are and report suspicious transactions. These financial firms are the first line of defense against money laundering, and recent cases highlight just how difficult it is for the government to police the tidal waves of cash that wash through the banking system.

headline: Trend of New York Gun Violence Has Flattened Out, Police Statistics Show
text: Despite a wild burst of gunfire that wounded nine people at a party in Brooklyn over the weekend, the number of shootings across New York City was sharply lower last week compared with the same week in 2014, bringing the city effectively even with last year in total amount of gunfire.

headline: For Mobile Messaging, GIFs Prove to Be Worth at Least a Thousand Words
text: Lucy Dikeou, a 21-year-old senior at Stanford University, has long used English and the pictorial images known as emoji to text on her iPhone. A few months ago, she started messaging in a third language: GIFs.

headline: Jason Pierre-Paul Is Talk of Giants Training Camp. And He Isn’t Even There.
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Every day since Giants training camp opened last week, the team has printed a roster of players by number, which includes this line: No. 90, Pierre-Paul, Jason, DE, 6 feet 5, 278 pounds.

headline: Celebrating Basque Heritage in Idaho
text: A Basque street party called Jaialdi takes over downtown Boise, celebrating the legacy of Basque immigrants who mostly came as shepherds in the early 20th century.

headline: 1965: Draft Call Is Biggest Since 1951
text: WASHINGTON — The Defense Department, carrying out President Johnson’s military manpower demands, today ordered the highest draft quotas since the Korean war. The new figures were 27,400 for September, all for the Army, and 33,600 men for October, including 4,600 for the Navy. The original draft call for September was 17,000. The September and October quotas were the highest since 80,000 youths were called in March of 1951. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 4, 1965

headline: Auto Sales Jumped in July; G.M. and Fiat Chrysler Were Up 6%
text: The auto industry began the second half of the year with a jolt that totaled more than 1.5 million vehicles sold in July, a 5.3 percent increase from the previous year.

headline: First Came Summer Camp Marriage, Then Came a More Mature Love
text: They met when they were 17 and 19 years old, and a week later, they were married — in a play.

text: Season 1, Episode 2: “The Road Trip: Part 1”

headline: Summery, Sweet-Smelling Hair Perfumes
text: During the summer, it’s tempting to skip the shampoo and go an extra day (or two) without washing one’s hair. But to keep it smelling fresh, there’s hair perfume: small, portable bottles that protect and hydrate hair while serving up a dose of white rose or gardenia. Here, a mix of recent launches and classics.

headline: What Is Our Attention Really Worth?
text: Pay attention!

headline: The Internet of Things and the Future of Farming
text: The Internet of Things — the vision of a world brimming with communicating sensors and digital smarts — occupies the peak of Gartner’s most recent “hype cycle.” And a report released two months ago by the McKinsey Global Institute laid out the potential multitrillion-dollar payoff from the emerging technology.

headline: Investment Consortium Buys Germany’s Tank & Rast
text: LONDON — A group of investors led by the private equity arm of German insurer Allianz agreed to acquire Autobahn Tank & Rast Holding, the German motorway service area operator, its owners said on Monday.

headline: Alpha Natural Resources, a Onetime Coal Giant, Files for Bankruptcy Protection
text: Alpha Natural Resources, once a powerhouse of the American coal industry, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Monday so it may emerge from the grip of a $3 billion debt at a time when utilities are switching to natural gas and coal prices are plummeting.

headline: Theory on Lithium in Stars May Be Confirmed
text: Astronomers believe that the metal lithium was created during the Big Bang 13.8 billion years ago. Yet old stars often have less lithium than might be expected, while young stars seem to have much more. Some scientists have speculated the source of extra lithium in young stars may be stellar explosions, or novae, expelling matter into space. Now lithium has been found in material ejected by the younger star Nova Centauri 2013, which may confirm the theory. The observation was made by telescopes at La Silla Observatory, the European Southern Observatory’s site in Chile, and at the Observatory of the Pontificia Universidad Catolica de Chile near Santiago.

headline: India Blocks 857 Pornography Websites, Defying Supreme Court Decision
text: NEW DELHI — Without warning or explanation, the Indian government this weekend ordered Internet service providers to block access to 857 pornography websites that had been singled out by an anti-pornography activist.

headline: Dispense With the Jokes Now: Pez Candy Gets Its Own Film
text: In what could be viewed as a sign (but almost certainly isn’t) that the era of toy-themed movies is nearing its end, a Hollywood production company announced Monday that it would be making a film about Pez.

headline: Miscelanea NY Brings Mexico to Manhattan
text: Guillaume Guevara considered his options. A restaurant? New York had enough Mexican places. But a market selling chiles, Oaxaca cheese, masa and Mexican sweets may make a difference, he thought. There could be some takeout food, but definitely not more tacos. What was needed, he believed, were tortas (sandwiches), like egg and chorizo. His inventory also tempts with jams infused with tequila and mezcal; paletas (ice pops) from Fany Gerson; coffee; and less common Mexican items like sweet maguey syrup and Mayan clay (for cosmetic use). He also sells lime presses, cookbooks and personal-care products from Mexico. And if he suggests iced coffee with the rice-milk drink horchata, take him up on it, especially when the sidewalk is steaming: Miscelanea NY, 63 East Fourth Street (Bowery), 212-253-0277, miscelaneany.com.

headline: British Government to Begin Partial Sale of R.B.S. Stake
text: LONDON — The British government said on Monday that it would sell a 5.2 percent stake in Royal Bank of Scotland, its first sale since the bank received a huge bailout seven years ago.

headline: Soylent Announces New Version of Its Nutrition Drink
text: The makers of Soylent, the powdered drink that has developed a following in Silicon Valley as an easy meal replacement for busy workers, has created a follow-up version called Soylent 2.0.

headline: Collegiate Chorale, Under a New Name, Is Teaming Up With City Center
text: The Collegiate Chorale, which was founded in 1941 by the conductor Robert Shaw, announced Monday that it was changing its name to MasterVoices and beginning a new partnership with City Center to give concert performances there of operas and operettas in English.

headline: John Kerry Abroad, Malaysia Airlines Investigation and Hiroshima Anniversary
text: What’s going to generate headlines this week in international news? We’re experimenting with offering readers a tip sheet. Let us know if you find it useful or what you’d like to see here. Contact hanna.ingber@nytimes.com.

headline: Massive Sandstorm Hits Jordan’s Capital
text: Flights were disrupted in Amman, Jordan, on Sunday after the city was hit by a sandstorm and strong winds.

headline: Woman’s Death in Mount Vernon, N.Y., Holding Cell Will Be Investigated by State Attorney General
text: The New York State attorney general’s office said on Monday that it would investigate the death of a woman who was found dead in a holding cell in Mount Vernon after she was arrested on shoplifting charges and then fell ill.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Note to His Brother, the President, About BBQ and Tax Cuts
text: It was playful banter between brothers. But these were not just any brothers — and the subject of the joke was not garden variety humor. It was federal taxes.

headline: Live and Kicking: Games to Watch This Week
text: The long international soccer nightmare that is the 10-week Premier League summer break ends this weekend with 10 games. Schedule accordingly.

headline: Wild Uganda Chimpanzees Using Clay as Food
text: Wild chimpanzees in Uganda have begun eating clay, which furnishes dietary minerals to them, a new study reports.

headline: The Promise and Limits of Obama’s ‘Clean Power Plan’ for Limiting Global Warming
text: Over the weekend, in a “Memo to America” and lots of details released to the press, President Obama set the stage for today’s release of the Environmental Protection Agency’s final “Clean Power Plan,” aimed at meeting the administration’s pledges to reduce carbon dioxide emissions.

headline: After Killing of Cecil the Lion, Delta Joins Airline Ban on Game Trophies
text: The recent killing of a popular lion named Cecil by an American dentist in Zimbabwe sparked considerable outrage on social media and elsewhere against safari hunting. The event has also brought to light the role that airlines play in transporting trophy kills as cargo, and may have contributed to changing airline policy.

headline: If You Were the Boss, Would You Raise the Minimum Salary to $70,000?
text: Three months ago, Dan Price, the chief executive of Gravity Payments, a credit card processing company, decided to raise the salary of his lowest paid workers to $70,000. Almost overnight, he represented a swashbuckling blow against income inequality. He also drew no small amount of criticism.

headline: A Baseball Habit Begins to Feel the Pinch
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Most days he is at work at AT&T Park here, Giants pitcher Madison Bumgarner can be seen with a clump of smokeless tobacco lodged in his lower lip. Bumgarner, a World Series hero and the face of the team, grew up in small-town North Carolina, where, he said, nearly all men dipped. He has been doing it since he was in fifth grade.

headline: British Police to Review Sex Abuse Claims Against Ex-Premier Edward Heath
text: LONDON — Britain’s independent police watchdog agency said on Monday that it would investigate an allegation that the police in Wiltshire had dropped a criminal investigation in the 1990s when the subject threatened to go public with accusations that the former Conservative prime minister Edward Heath had sexually abused children.

headline: Canopies and Umbrellas, Gifts That Shelter the Glowing Couple

headline: Chris Christie Softens Tone on Minimum Wage Increases
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has ardently opposed raising the minimum wage in New Jersey, but on Monday he hinted that his opposition might not be absolute.

headline: Obama Takes a Crucial Step on Climate Change
text: President Obama’s Clean Power Plan has rightly been hailed as the most important action any president has taken to address the climate crisis.

headline: Al Sharpton Accepts Apology From Donald Trump Aide Who Was Fired Over Racial Posts
text: The Rev. Al Sharpton is known for his fiery oratory and excoriating those who cross him.

headline: Jury Rejects Mental Illness Argument for James Holmes in Aurora Theater Rampage
text: DENVER — A Colorado jury on Monday moved an important step closer to sentencing James E. Holmes to death for carrying out a massacre inside a suburban movie theater in July 2012, rejecting defense arguments that his mental illness should remove the death penalty from consideration as a potential punishment.

headline: Cranes Collapse on Houses in Netherlands
text: Emergency rescue crews inspected on Monday the area where two cranes carrying a bridge segment collapsed onto houses and stores in a central Dutch town.

headline: Obama Unveils Plan on Climate Change
text: The president formally unveiled on Monday his administration’s plan to cut future carbon emissions from power plants.

headline: Effects of Solitary Confinement
text: Inmates at Pelican Bay State Prison discuss the detrimental effects of long-term solitary confinement.

headline: Solitary Confinement: Punished for Life
text: In 1993, Craig Haney, a social psychologist, interviewed a group of inmates in solitary confinement at Pelican Bay State Prison, California’s toughest penal institution.

headline: Jill Scott Tops Chart With ‘Woman’
text: Jill Scott’s latest album, “Woman,” has opened at the top of the Billboard chart in a slow week of music sales.

headline: Travel Diary
text: Richard Christiansen and Vanessa Holden share images from Marrakesh, the first stop in their three-week trip around the world.

headline: Do Israelis Still Care About Justice?
text: TEL AVIV — “This isn’t everyone,” my son said Saturday as we stood on the steps of the Tel Aviv City Hall, in Rabin Square. “There are more people coming, right?”

headline: Flooding and a Landslide Kill Dozens Amid India Monsoons
text: NEW DELHI — At least 73 people have died in India since Friday amid flooding and a landslide linked to heavy rains in two states in the country’s east, disaster management officials said.

headline: Good Timing for Britain to Shed Its R.B.S. Stake
text: Britain shouldn’t obsess about losing money on its Royal Bank of Scotland stake. George Osborne, the chancellor of the Exchequer, is about to get cracking on reducing the government’s 79 percent holding, which will mean a short-term loss on the 46 billion pounds handed over by taxpayers in 2008 and 2009. That hit needs to be put into perspective.

headline: Pentagon Chief Ashton Carter Adds ‘Secretary of Reassurance’ to His Portfolio
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s defense secretary, Ashton B. Carter, has become the secretary of reassurance.

headline: Move to Fight Obama’s Climate Plan Started Early
text: WASHINGTON — In the early months of 2014, a group of about 30 corporate lawyers, coal lobbyists and Republican political strategists began meeting regularly in the headquarters of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, often, according to some of the participants, in a conference room overlooking the White House. Their task was to start devising a legal strategy for dismantling the climate change regulations they feared were coming from President Obama.

headline: Chuck and Amy Schumer Team Up to Fight Gun Violence
text: The poster evoked a family law practice, or perhaps an Off Broadway act, announcing the gathering’s hosts inside the overstuffed Midtown office of New York’s senior senator.

headline: Puerto Rico Defaults on Bond Payment
text: Puerto Rico defaulted on a $58 million bond payment on Monday, a risky move that seemed to intensify the pressure on creditors for broader debt renegotiation, but might also make future borrowing far more difficult.

headline: Effective Ovarian Cancer Treatment Is Underused, Study Finds
text: In 2006, the National Cancer Institute took the rare step of issuing a “clinical announcement,” a special alert it holds in reserve for advances so important that they should change medical practice.

headline: Review: China Miéville’s ‘Three Moments of an Explosion’
text: Even when he is orbiting somewhere in a galaxy too far away for normal human comprehension, the genre-subverting English novelist China Miéville is dazzling. His latest collection of short stories, “Three Moments of an Explosion,” crowds virtuosity into every sentence.

headline: Wylie Dufresne Is Closing Alder
text: The innovative chef Wylie Dufresne will close his bistro, Alder, in the East Village, at the end of the month. The restaurant confirmed the news, which Mr. Dufresne announced in a message on Twitter that added, “The search for a new home begins.” He did not give a reason for the closing and has not returned calls.

headline: Dr. Forrest Bird, Inventor of Medical Respirators and Ventilators, Dies at 94
text: Dr. Forrest M. Bird, an eccentric aviator and inventor who studied high-altitude breathing problems of World War II pilots and later created medical devices that saved lives and aided thousands of people with respiratory ailments, died on Sunday at his home in Sagle, Idaho. He was 94.

headline: Schumers Launch Push For Gun Control
text: The comedian Amy Schumer is teaming up with her cousin Senator Chuck Schumer, Democrat of New York, to push for new legislation limiting gun access for the mentally ill.

headline: Judge Delays Retrial in Etan Patz Case Until Feb. 22
text: A judge on Monday delayed the retrial of a man accused of murdering Etan Patz until Feb. 22 to give a newly appointed prosecutor more time to prepare in one of the country’s most infamous child-abduction cases.

headline: ‘Hedwig’ Takes a Dip With Taye Diggs in Title Role
text: Taye Diggs is off to a wobbly start in his new heels.

text: Following the unrest in Baltimore after Freddie Gray’s death, I found myself inside the Gilmor Homes housing project there, listening to three men in an impromptu rap battle.

text: Donald J. Trump was trumped.

headline: A Comedy Family in Myanmar
text: With private shows, comics in Myanmar try to avoid crackdowns.

headline: Expert Panel Withholds Support for Early Autism Screening
text: For years experts have urged physicians to screen infants and toddlers for autism in order to begin treatment as early as possible. But now an influential panel of experts has concluded there is not enough evidence to recommend universal autism screening of young children.

headline: Review: In ‘Dear Evan Hansen,’ Teenage Angst Grows Complicated
text: WASHINGTON — The quirks of fate prove both kind and cruel in “Dear Evan Hansen,” a sweet, sad and quite moving new musical making its premiere here at Arena Stage. The title character, a friendless teenager crippled by the depression that only being a friendless teenager can bring, is caught up in the whiplash of web fame when a note he wrote finds its way into the hands of another troubled kid, with complicated consequences.

headline: Hillary Clinton to Appear on Al Sharpton’s Radio Show
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton will appear on the Rev. Al Sharpton’s syndicated radio show on Thursday, the 50th anniversary of the Voting Rights Act and the day of the first widely broadcast Republican debate.

headline: German Officials Suspend Treason Inquiry of Bloggers, but Public Still Seethes
