headline: Review: In ‘Freight,’ a Black Man Follows the Script for Five Incarnations
text: Abel Green arrives out of breath from running for the train. It is the 1910s, and he is an actor hopping a boxcar on his way to a minstrel show. But performing is something he’s done since long before he ever was paid for it.

headline: To Some, Beijing Olympics Song Is Suspiciously Similar to Ballad From Disney’s ‘Frozen’
text: BEIJING — China lacks enough snow for the 2022 Winter Olympic Games, environmentalists said. China is too repressive to hold the Games, detaining hundreds of lawyers just in the past month, rights campaigners said. On Friday, despite those complaints, the International Olympic Committee awarded the Games to Beijing.

headline: Drenchcam

headline: ‘Playing House’ Begins Its Second Season a Little More Grown-Up
text: The USA comedy “Playing House” lived to see a second season only after an extended lobbying effort by its few but vocal fans. With that season beginning on Tuesday night, the almost 100 percent of Americans who didn’t get on board for Season 1 need to ask themselves: Should they give the show a second chance?

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
text: Good evening. Here’s the latest.

headline: What Yahoo Paid for Polyvore: More Than $200 Million
text: It has been some time since Marissa Mayer, chief executive of Yahoo, has spent big to add a promising start-up to her company’s portfolio. On Friday, she broke out the checkbook.

headline: An Extraordinary Humpback Whale Sighting in Alaska
text: The whale, whom the researchers named Old Timer, was first seen in Lynn Canal in southeast Alaska. It is the longest string of sightings of a humpback.

headline: Fragile Burundi Casts a Wary Eye on Rwanda
text: KIGALI, Rwanda — Burundi and Rwanda can seem deceptively like conjoined twins. They share a common history, geography and language, and their populations are divided ethnically between Hutu and Tutsi. Both were devastated by some of the worst mass slaughter of the 20th century.

headline: Boston Symphony Extends Andris Nelsons’s Contract Through 2022
text: LENOX, Mass. — The honeymoon was a success, and the flirtation with a would-be home wrecker from overseas ended without infidelity, so now they are renewing their vows: The Boston Symphony Orchestra  said on Monday that it had extended Andris Nelsons’s contract as its music director through 2022.

headline: Review: Carl Safina’s ‘Beyond Words’ Doesn’t Mince Any on Animal Abilities
text: Given the subtitle of Carl Safina’s fascinating and expansive new book, “Beyond Words: What Animals Think and Feel,” it’s no surprise that Dr. Safina frequently discusses animal cognition.

headline: Great Men (Mostly) Through History
text: Making composite portraits of national leaders — layering dozens of them, sometimes, into a single frame — one photographer explored the “aesthetic of power” and sameness.

headline: ‘Bobby Jones Gospel’ and Its Strongest Voice Prepare to Say Farewell
text: WASHINGTON — Some folks skipped church on Sunday in hopes of getting to BET’s headquarters here in time for the final taping of “Bobby Jones Gospel.” Many were turned away, though, as the studio’s chairs runneth over, filled with gospel stars who trace their careers back to their debuts on the show and retired network executives who did not want to miss the chance to say goodbye to a legend.

headline: Review: ‘The Dreamer Examines His Pillow’ Talks of Love, Lust and Lots More
text: In its current revival by the Attic Theater Company, “The Dreamer Examines His Pillow,”an early John Patrick Shanley work, is an intermissionless 90 minutes, but it’s really a play in three parts. From the audience’s perspective this particular production’s three parts are: “Not buying it,” “Just got more interesting” and, “Ah, now it all makes sense.”

headline: Review: Nação Zumbi Returns to Central Park SummerStage
text: A great band can sound even better when propelled by a great thesis: an endlessly renewable idea big enough to encompass music, history, philosophy, politics and the daily grind.

headline: A Fencer Strives to Crack a Saber Ceiling
text: Daryl Homer secured his spot in United States fencing history last month by becoming the first American man to claim a medal in saber fencing at the world championships, winning silver in Moscow. But for a broader scope of the legacy he has been building, look no further than his home fencing club in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: The Little Orchestra Society Limits Schedule and Aims for Younger Audience

headline: Yankees Pitching Prospect Luis Severino Draws Raves Before Debut Against Red Sox
text: CHICAGO — When Dellin Betances was at the Yankees’ minor league complex in Tampa, Fla., at the end of the 2012 minor league season preparing to head to the instructional league, there were about 20 young pitching prospects working out.

headline: Toy Guns Can Be Dangerous, for Real
text: A toy gun is supposed to look like a toy — not a gun. In New York, it cannot be black, blue or silver. It should have bright neon colors in New York City, and a strip of orange around the barrel in the state. That’s the law. Yet, the office of New York’s Attorney General Eric Schneiderman found that retailers had sold more than 6,400 toy guns to New York families in the last three years that looked all too real.

headline: Vigilante Effort After a Child’s Death Underlines Stark Change in West Bank
text: DUMA, West Bank — Early one recent morning, a few residents of this sleepy hilltop hamlet heard that Jewish settlers were hurling rocks at a house. Almost instantly they started posting messages on Facebook, rousing neighbors — then somebody’s brother called a friend, who called his cousin, who called the Muslim preacher, who rushed to the mosque, flicked on a megaphone rigged to the minaret and shouted:

headline: Runway Report
text: The white button-down shirt.

headline: The Moon, Going Through a Phase
text: Is there such a thing as a half moon?

headline: Review: ‘Turandot’ and ‘Les Contes d’Hoffmann,’ Spectacle and Substance at Bregenz Festival
text: BREGENZ, Austria — Opera at its best has always been spectacle with a brain. And nowhere is that marriage of seriousness and showmanship pursued more openly than at the Bregenz Festival.

headline: Review: ‘Heritage Sunday’ and ‘Ache: Lavagem da Rua’ Maintain Culture Through Dance
text: “Let’s hear it for Congress!”

headline: Garbage In, Garbage Out, Garbage Around
text: O.K., so the compromise is small in the global scheme of things. It is not a two-state solution and it does not involve the sovereignty of tiny islands claimed by China and Japan. But it does loom hugely for citizens of the Upper East Side of Manhattan, where conflicts over land use can – and do – take on geopolitical proportions and urgency.

headline: Pimco May Face S.E.C. Action Over a Fund
text: A Pimco exchange-traded bond fund that once tracked the performance of a much larger fund formerly managed by the firm’s co-founder, William H. Gross, may have violated federal securities laws.

headline: Legionnaires’ Disease Death Toll in Bronx Rises to 7
text: An outbreak of Legionnaires’ disease in the South Bronx has claimed three more lives, bringing the death toll to seven, New York City officials said on Monday amid calls for tighter regulation of water-cooling towers, which are thought to be the origin of the illness.

headline: Planned Parenthood Is Defended as Senate Democrats Block Bill to End Funding
text: WASHINGTON — As president of Planned Parenthood, Cecile Richards tries to keep perspective while the group faces one of its biggest political crises. After all, she said on Monday, the founder, Margaret Sanger, was arrested 99 years ago for pamphleteering about birth control.

headline: Richard S. Schweiker, Former Senator and Reagan Confidant, Dies at 89
text: Richard S. Schweiker, a former United States representative and senator from Pennsylvania who was the secretary of health and human services during the first term of President Ronald Reagan, died on Friday in Pomona, N.J. He was 89.

headline: Bodegas Declining in Manhattan as Rents Rise and Chains Grow
text: José Alvarrado saved for more than a decade to buy 3 Brothers Mini Market, a bodega at 169th Street and Audubon Avenue.

headline: Hitchhiking Robot, Safe in Several Countries, Meets Its End in Philadelphia
text: After an international adventure that included spending a week with a heavy metal band, cruising through the canals of Amsterdam and participating in a wave at a Boston Red Sox game, a hitchhiking robot met a brutal demise in a Philadelphia alley on Saturday. It was 1 year old.

headline: The Failed Attack on Planned Parenthood
text: Senate Republicans’ latest ploy to choke off all federal funding to Planned Parenthood failed, as expected, on Monday afternoon in a 53-46 procedural vote. The measure fell short of the 60 votes needed to move it forward.

headline: Trans-Pacific Partnership Session Ends With Heels Dug In
text: WASHINGTON — Tokyo was ready to extend major concessions on American truck tariffs but was blocked by Mexico, which wanted less competition for its own trucks in the United States market.

headline: Trial Opens for Charlotte Officer Who Fatally Shot Black Motorist Seeking Help
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — A Charlotte police officer fired eight shots at the fallen body of an unarmed former college football player who had knocked on the door of a house in an unfamiliar neighborhood seeking help after a car crash, a prosecutor said in opening arguments Monday in the trial of Officer Randall Kerrick on voluntary manslaughter charges.

headline: Obama Administration Urges States to Cut Health Insurers’ Requests for Big Rate Increases
text: WASHINGTON — Hoping to avoid another political uproar over the Affordable Care Act, the Obama administration is trying to persuade states to cut back big rate increases requested by many health insurance companies for 2016.

headline: Suspect in Memphis Police Officer’s Death Turns Himself In
text: An ex-convict wanted in Tennessee for the murder of a Memphis police officer turned himself in to the authorities on Monday, law enforcement officials said.

headline: United Nations Members Establish 15-Year Global Development Agenda
text: In what the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, described Monday as the organization’s “to-do” list for the next 15 years, its 193 member states have agreed on an agenda for global development that aims to eliminate poverty and hunger, protect the environment from climate change, achieve gender equality and raise living standards. The agreement, known as the  2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, was finalized over the weekend after negotiations that began a few years ago. It will be formally adopted at a United Nations summit meeting next month. The agenda supersedes and broadens the eight Millennium Development Goals set in 2000, which Mr. Ban has credited with helping to raise more than one billion people out of abject poverty.

headline: Kentucky Officer Handcuffs Third Grader
text: The video released by the A.C.L.U. shows a deputy sheriff in Kentucky handcuffing a third grader to a chair. An A.C.L.U. lawyer said the handcuffing was “traumatizing, and in this case illegal.”

headline: A.C.L.U. Sues Over Handcuffing of Boy, 8, and Girl, 9, in Kentucky School
text: WASHINGTON — The American Civil Liberties Union, seeking to spotlight the use of handcuffs to restrain young children who act out in school, filed a federal lawsuit in Covington, Ky., on Monday alleging that a school resource officer there shackled an 8-year-old boy and a 9-year-old girl, both with disabilities, causing the children “pain, fear and emotional trauma.”

headline: A Climate Plan Businesses Can Like
text: WITH the release of President Obama’s Clean Power Plan, a flood of legal challenges will begin. Already, opponents have denounced the new rule limiting carbon pollution as unconstitutional. Behind the rattling sabers, however, there’s a quieter story worth noticing. Many big players in the electric power industry will gain more with the rule in place than if the courts strike it down.

headline: New Polls Show Donald Trump Widening His Lead and John Kasich Holding His Own
text: Less than 24 hours before the candidates’ deadline to qualify for Fox News’s debate, two polls released on Monday show Donald J. Trump with a statistically significant lead over the rest of the field and Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio squeaking into the top ten.

headline: Securities Fraud Charges Bring Texas Attorney General, Ken Paxton, to County Jail
text: McKINNEY, Tex. — Ken Paxton, the Texas attorney general, was arrested on felony charges Monday and booked at the county jail in this Dallas suburb after a grand jury indicted him last week for securities fraud, the start of a criminal case that could complicate and even jeopardize his tenure as the state’s top lawyer.

headline: Syria: U.S. Sets New Sanctions
text: The United States sought to broaden its economic pressure on Syria’s government on Monday, imposing sanctions on a far-flung network of seven overseas companies and four individuals for actions to evade American and European Union restrictions on fuel imports. The Treasury Department’s Office of Foreign Assets Control, which oversees enforcement of American sanctions, said seven commercial ships owned or controlled by one of the newly penalized companies had been blocked by its action, cutting off a potential source of fuel to President Bashar al-Assad’s military. The affected companies operated in Syria, the United Arab Emirates, Turkey, Lebanon, Panama, St. Kitts and Nevis and the Marshall Islands, the Treasury said in a statement, asserting that “many of these entities are front companies that the government of Syria and its supporters have used in an attempt to evade U.S. and E.U. sanctions.” Any sanctioned individuals and entities risk seizure of assets under American jurisdiction, and are barred from commercial dealings with the United States.

headline: Vincent Marotta Sr., a Creator of Mr. Coffee, Dies at 91
text: Vincent Marotta Sr., who as a creator of the Mr. Coffee machine helped send the percolator the way of the one-horse shay, died on Saturday at his home in Pepper Pike, Ohio. He was 91.

headline: David Price Electrifies Toronto’s Fans With Debut for Blue Jays

Price has pitched in the World Series, critical playoff games and even a win-and-get-in 163rd game two years ago.

headline: A Refreshing Cocktail Recipe, Featuring Iceland’s Newest Export
text: “Ever since I had come back from London, I have always been looking for how I could get this stuff,” says barman Matt Piacentini. It’s a sentiment that has continuously informed choices for his bars, from Clyde Common in Downtown Portland to his latest venture, the Up & Up, on New York’s Macdougal Street. “This stuff” is Piacentini’s shorthand for the goods he found easily accessible back in Europe that he wants to bring stateside: everything from William Morris wallpapers and Italian amari to Scandinavian aquavit.

headline: One-Thing Shops: Herbs in Athens
text: Among a generation of young Greeks scattered around the more prosperous cities of Europe, Evangelia Koutsovoulou is an anomaly: an émigré who last year returned to Athens with opportunity on her mind. The sage- and mint-perfumed islands of her Mediterranean homeland are rich in herbs, unchanged and mostly uncultivated since ancient times with a world of unique flavors not found elsewhere, even in her adopted country of Italy. “Greek herbs were something very special but no one else had paid any attention to them,” says the former journalist, who opened her tiny headquarters below the Acropolis in the midst of the country’s economic crisis and created Daphnis and Chloe, a brand of wild-bred culinary herbs named after a second-century Greek tale of predestined love.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
text: 11:40 A.M. (Starz) WHIPLASH (2014) Andrew (Miles Teller), an aspiring jazz drummer at a highly selective Manhattan music school, falls in thrall to Fletcher (J. K. Simmons, in an Oscar-winning portrayal), a charismatic and terrifying instructor whose teaching methods include browbeating, humiliation and cymbal throwing in this second feature from Damien Chazelle. And a blood bath, literal and figurative, ensues. “For all its dexterity and assurance, the movie has its share of false notes and rhythmic stumbles,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “A few plot twists test the limits of credibility. And there is something a little dispiriting — if sadly unsurprising — about the way Mr. Chazelle turns a historically African-American art form into the existential arena for a couple of white guys.” Still, he added, “the battle of master and disciple is exciting and terrifying to witness, and, at its best, the film can feel as wild and spontaneous, as risky and precise, as a live jam session.”

headline: Great Men (Mostly) Through History
text: In the 19th century, eminent smart guys like the Scottish author Thomas Carlyle popularized the Great Man theory, the idea that history was a shapeless wad of ground beef till a great man came along to make a sturdy hamburger of it. Or something like that. Carlyle had his contemporary critics, of course, but confronted with images from “Portraits of Power,” a fine art photo project by Alejandro Almaraz, he might have reconsidered his theory.

headline: Obama’s Flexible Fix to Climate Change
text: For many years, I used to spend at least part of the summer in the gorgeous Laurentides region of Quebec, an hour northwest of Montreal. By the mid-1980s, with each return trip, I could see a growing environmental threat to the area’s beauty: More and more trees were dying. When I asked people what was happening, the answer was simple: “pluie acide,” or acid rain, a form of pollution caused by sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides that were spewing from coal-fired power plants in America.

headline: News Q’s | Wildfires Blaze in California
text: Note: We’ve updated 6 Q’s About the News for the new school year. This feature, now known as News Q’s, will be a daily mini-lesson, with both Before Reading and After Reading questions, and a suggested activity for going further. Let us know what you think.

headline: Walker Percy’s Theory of Hurricanes
text: Walker Percy had a theory about hurricanes. “Though science taught that good environments were better than bad environments, it appeared to him that the opposite was the case,” he wrote of Will Barrett, the semi-autobiographical title character of his second novel, “The Last Gentleman.” “Take hurricanes, for example, certainly a bad environment if ever there was one. It was his impression that not just he but other people felt better in hurricanes.”

headline: ‘The Beautiful Bureaucrat,’ by Helen Phillips
text: In the opening pages of Camus’s “The Stranger,” a nurse warns Meursault to keep a steady pace during his mother’s funeral procession: “If you go slowly,” she says, “you risk getting sunstroke. But if you go too fast, you work up a sweat and then catch a chill inside the church.” Meursault’s response conveys his overwhelming, and baffling, sense of imprisonment: “She was right. There was no way out.” It’s an illustrative moment of the paralysis — damned if I do, damned if I don’t — that characterizes so much of existential literature: Vladimir and Estragon, waiting for a God who never shows; the man from the country in the parable told by the priest in Kafka’s “The Trial,” inert, cursing his fate and praying to fleas, waiting for the doorkeeper to admit him into the Law; Gregor Samsa, trapped between identities, unable to leave his house or return to his human condition. This existential paralysis emerges, in part, from spiritual crisis: If God is dead, what is the individual’s role in an essentially meaningless universe? Are we pawns in the thrall of bureaucratic (Kafka) or totalitarian (Orwell) systems? Or are we, in fact, the ones with ultimate power; the arbiters — even unknowingly — of life and death?

Some handshakes, some smiles, a quick word between the writer and the manager, and a nice picture in the next day’s paper: It was the sort of thing that happened in small towns everywhere.

headline: What It’s Really Like to Be an Airline Pilot
text: Mark Vanhoenacker’s new book, “Skyfaring: A Journey With a Pilot” (Knopf), isn’t exactly a memoir. It’s a meditation on flying, on the physical act of soaring through the air in a giant metal tube, and on the foreign-to-most experiences of the pilot behind the yoke. “I am occasionally asked if I don’t find it boring, to be in the cockpit for so many hours,” he writes. “But I’ve never had the sense that there was any more enjoyable way to spend my working life, that below me existed some other kind of time for which I would trade my hours in the sky.”

headline: The Tough Love of ‘Austerity’
text: Austerity, diet of our lives, girder of our loins. At the moment, the word brings to mind the continuing crisis in Greece and, by extension, the power of the Germans holding the purse strings. ‘‘Austerity’’ has become the catchall word for the cost-cutting a government enacts in order to balance its books: Cut pensions, cut the public payroll, cut social services — cut whatever and wherever. Shrink spending, shrink debt, shrink deficits. The idea is to inspire confidence and make the place more attractive to investors, who prefer a government that’s tough and lean to one that’s marbled and tender.

headline: The Misadventures of Issa Rae
text: Somewhere, during the elaborate chor­eography leading up to my initial meeting with Issa Rae, a miscommunication between her publicist and me led to my asking Rae how the filming of her pilot was going. Rae pressed her chin to her chest and rolled her eyes upward, making the universal face for: ‘‘Are you kidding me?’’ Actually, she explained, the show had no director attached, no pit crew, not even the slightest inkling of a cast. She was nowhere near filming. All she had was a finished script and a charged cellphone.

headline: John Leslie Munro, Last of the World War II ‘Dambuster’ Pilots, Dies at 96
text: On the night of May 16, 1943, a squadron of bombers set out from Britain to conduct strikes against heavily fortified dams in the Ruhr Valley of Germany, using bombs that bounced on the water before exploding. Of the 133 crew members who started the mission, only 77 returned.

headline: Review: ‘Street Poison,’ a Biography of Iceberg Slim, Writer and Pimp
text: In the late 1960s and early ’70s, if you wanted a book by Iceberg Slim, the best-selling black writer in America, you didn’t go to a bookstore. You went to a black-owned barbershop or liquor store or gas station. Maybe you found a copy on a corner table down the block, or being passed around in prison.

headline: Alibaba Names Former Goldman Sachs Executive as President
text: To oversee international expansion, the Alibaba Group is turning to a former Goldman Sachs executive who has long worked with the Chinese Internet giant.

headline: Free Diver Natalia Molchanova Descends for Fun, Then Vanishes
text: Natalia Molchanova, widely regarded as the greatest free diver in history, wore her favorite purple wet suit Sunday on a chartered boat off the coast of Formentera, an island near Ibiza. Only 1.5 millimeters thick, the wet suit was low buoyancy, designed specifically for divers like her who want to go deep on a single breath. It was a Molchanova, the brand she started with her son, Alexey Molchanov.

headline: Israel Detains Meir Kahane’s Grandson, a Scion of Jewish Militancy
text: JERUSALEM — He has the pedigree: Meir Ettinger is a grandson and the namesake of Meir Kahane, the slain American-Israeli rabbi considered the father of far-right Jewish militancy.

headline: ‘Act of God’ Costs, Region by Region
text: In 2014, when the country was hit by a series of natural disasters, the United States footed a $25 billion bill for the economic and insurance damages. Here, we look at the costs.

headline: Slow-Motion Catastrophe
text: California may be known for earthquakes, but the region has a bigger problem right now.

headline: Four Graphs Bolster Bill Gates’s Case for Greatly Boosting Clean-Energy Research
text: A few days before President Obama’s release of the final “Clean Power Plan” restricting greenhouse gas emissions from power plants, Bill Gates posted a Gates Notes essay that helps reinforce an important reality: It will take more than regulation to limit humanity’s growing influence on the climate system.

headline: Mud and Fire
text: Where the landscape is spectacular, the natural disasters can be, too.

headline: Take Cover
text: There is one obvious danger in a wide-open country, and another one you might not expect.

headline: A Little of Everything

headline: Celebrating an Unexpected Heritage in Idaho
text: A Basque street party called Jaialdi takes over downtown Boise, celebrating the legacy of Basque immigrants who mostly came as shepherds in the early 20th century.

headline: A Taste of Basque Paella Amid Idaho’s Potatoes
text: BOISE, Idaho — When the president of the Basques arrived here in Idaho’s capital from Europe late last month, the mayor stepped in to interpret for him into English from Basque, one of the world’s most ancient and difficult languages.

headline: In European Soccer, Usual Suspects Are Expected to Win
text: The European soccer season gets under way in earnest in the days ahead. A look at bookmaker’s odds shows that for the have-nots in the major leagues, the chance of winding up at the top of the table is increasingly close to zero.

headline: An Old Songbook Could Put ‘Happy Birthday’ in the Public Domain
text: It is one of the most beloved and famous of all songs, belted out at countless gatherings for infant and octogenarian alike. Yet “Happy Birthday to You,” far from being as free as a piece of cake at a party, is actually considered private property.

headline: 1915: Peace Mission Fails in Haiti
text: NEW YORK — A special cablegram to the Herald from Port-au-Prince says the mission of the Peace Committee has completely failed. The Cape army refused to fight. Governor Blot and his staff secretly fled during the night aboard a Haitian gunboat, while the population shouted ‘‘Vive Bobo.’’ The garrison of 1,500 was disarmed. Later the American warships Eagle and Nashville landed 250 sailors. Bobo’s army then tried to force the city gates despite the interdiction of the United States naval commanders. The Eagle then shelled the army. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 5, 1915

headline: Donald Trump’s Debate Weapon: Checks Written to His Rivals
text: Favors are not free in business or politics and Donald J. Trump will have his ledger ready if the insults start flying his way at Thursday’s debate.

headline: Solitary Confinement: Reporter’s Notebook
text: A few years ago I visited the security housing unit at California’s Pelican Bay State Prison, where inmates are kept in solitary confinement. The first thing that struck me was how eerily quiet it was.

headline: Protests, and Some Surrenders, as Sun Does Battle With Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — At noon, the light bouncing off the hot concrete seems to bleach everything, like an overexposed photograph. Standing for more than a minute in the sun sets off a full-body sweat.

headline: Family Member on Pakistan Execution
text: Mohammad Altaf, whose nephew, Shafqat Hussain, was executed in Karachi, Pakistan, on Monday, said that it was “cruel” to hang Mr. Hussain 12 years after his arrest.

headline: Romanos Aren’t Just Any Green Beans
text: I will impulsively buy romano beans whenever I see them at a farmers’ market, which is every week right now. The luxurious flat, wide, longish green beans keep well in the crisper, but the beans don’t stay in my refrigerator for long.

headline: Corruption Case Against Julius Malema, a South African Opposition Leader, Is Dismissed
text: JOHANNESBURG — A South African court dismissed a long-running corruption case against the opposition leader Julius Malema on Tuesday, handing a victory to one of President Jacob G. Zuma’s most strident critics.

headline: New Taliban Leader Faces Discord as a Top Official Quits

text: GIFs, the fodder of Internet memes for quite some time, have experienced a recent resurgence, propelled by mobile devices into a more widespread form of instant visual-messaging.

headline: The Marie Kondo Effect: A Closet’s Loss, a Consignor’s Gain
text: When Marie Kondo’s blockbuster book, “The Life-Changing Magic of Tidying Up,” was published in the United States last year, it quickly reached the top of best-seller lists, sold more than three million copies worldwide and extended the global phenomenon that had already swept her native Japan, as well as Europe.

text: NEW ORLEANS — On a brutally humid day almost 10 years ago, Donald Link was a sweaty, desperate man in a respirator mask lugging a rotting pig’s head to the curb.

headline: 1965: Greek Lawmakers Vote
text: ATHENS — Parliament met for a showdown vote on the nation’s political crisis tonight [Aug. 4], with observers giving the three- week-old government only a slim chance of success. Shouts and interruptions rang out across the assembly as soon as debate got under way. A vote of confidence in the administration of Premier George Athanasiades-Novas was expected to be held early tomorrow morning. In the lobbies, the predominant opinion was that Mr. Athanasiades-Novas has little chance of mustering a majority of the 300 deputies. At least 143 deputies belonging to the Center Union party are pledged to support former Premier George Papandreou. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 5, 1965

headline: Lindsey Graham, Hillary Clinton, Monica Lewinsky: A Case Study in Desperation
text: You would think that a struggling (to be charitable) presidential candidate would think about his words on a day when it had just been revealed by the Washington Post that his much bragged-on record in the military reserve was wildly overblown.

headline: Article on Darren Wilson Offers Window on His Life After Ferguson Shooting
text: Darren Wilson, the police officer who fatally shot an unarmed black teenager almost a year ago, now lives on a dead-end street on the outskirts of St. Louis. His name is not on the deed of the house. He wears a hat and sunglasses when he goes outside to greet a reporter, having synced his phone with a security system to tip him off to his visitor’s arrival.

headline: New Polls Give Better View of G.O.P. Debate Field
text: Only a few hours remain for polls to land before Fox determines who’s in the first Republican debate on Thursday in Cleveland. Fox News won’t announce which 10 candidates will be on stage until after today’s 5 p.m. deadline, but three new polls released in the last 24 hours make the field look much more stable than before.

headline: A Belated Look at New York’s Cooling Towers, Prime Suspect in Legionnaires’ Outbreak
text: Since the outbreak that gave Legionnaires’ disease its name nearly four decades ago, water-cooling towers have been identified as prime breeding grounds for the deadly disease.

headline: The Foo Fighters Answer a YouTube Plea: The Band Will Play in Cesena, Italy
text: PARIS — What do you do when you want to convince your favorite band to play in your hometown? Fabio Zaffagnini, an enterprising 39-year-old fan of the Foo Fighters in Cesena, in Northern Italy, had an idea. He organized 1,000 people to play the band’s upbeat anthem “Learn to Fly,” had professionals film it, posted the video to YouTube — and watched it go viral.

headline: Answers About Campus Depression and Suicide Risk Among College Students
text: This week, I wrote about the pressures college students face and the related risk for depression and suicide. The article, “Suicide on Campus and the Pressure for Perfection,” generated numerous comments, and readers also raised important questions about other aspects of mental health.

headline: Aron Johannsson’s Impending Transfer Slows a Talent Leak
text: Aron Johannsson, a striker for the United States men’s national soccer team, is on the verge of a transfer to Werder Bremen of Germany’s Bundesliga, his Dutch club announced Tuesday. The move will make Johannsson, 24, one of the most high-profile American players in Europe, and it stops a migration of top American pros out of the top European leagues, at least temporarily.

headline: Christie and Kasich Appear to Be Probables in Prime-Time Debate
text: The latest round of national polling gives a good clue about who will make the cut for Fox News’s prime-time debate Thursday, with Gov. John Kasich, of Ohio, and Gov. Chris Christie, of New Jersey, very likely to be selected, The Upshot reports.

text: Bad weather can often ruin a vacation, but weather forecasts can also be wrong. With these two thoughts in mind, a new service called WeatherPlanner is hoping to give travelers a better sense of when to book their next trip.

headline: A Creperie, Délice & Sarrasin, Opens
text: Délice & Sarrasin Hunger for authentic French crepes drove Christophe Caron, a model, to open this creperie. Mr. Caron enlisted his mother, Yvette, a chef and former surgeon, and his father, Patrick, an engineer, in the project. Now for the French lesson: The word sarrasin means “buckwheat” and refers to the flour traditionally used for savory crepes, or galettes as they are called in France. (Sweet crepes are made with white flour.) And at this charming little cafe, both varieties are well balanced. None of the filling combinations, including smoked salmon with shrimp, or chocolate and banana, overburden the flavor of the delicate crepe. Pastries, coffee drinks, wine and cider are also served: 20 Christopher Street (Gay Street), 212-243-7200, delicesarrasin.com.

headline: Siebel Institute Seeks to Make the Smart Grid Smarter
text: Companies and governments are investing heavily to digitize much of the world’s power grid with sensors. The worldwide spending estimates range up to $2 trillion over the next decade for everything from so-called smart meters and thermostats in homes to sensors on transformers and power lines. But if power-curbing and cost-saving sense is to be made of all the data flowing from those sensors, something more is needed — intelligent software.

headline: Shire’s Merger Machine Stumbles on Baxalta Bid
text: Shire’s merger machine has taken a gentle knock. Shire, the onetime Irish target for AbbVie, is planning a mega-deal of its own. Unlike the previous combination, Shire’s $30 billion lunge for Baxalta carries a fair slug of industrial logic, as well as tax benefits. Its shareholders, though, still need some persuading.

headline: A Dirt Road in Gaza, Devised by Hamas as a Message to Israel
text: GAZA — The new road known as Jakar Street is a rough dirt expanse that Hamas bulldozers cleared parallel to the fence separating this restive Palestinian strip from Israel. Jakar comes from a slang Arabic term that suggests provocation, stubbornness, an effort to vex or annoy or irritate.

headline: Tips for Shady Gardens
text: Leafy greens grow well in partial shade and will last longer before they bolt, or go to seed, and taste bitter. There is still time to plant seeds of arugula, basil, cilantro, leaf lettuces of many kinds, Asian greens, spinach and kale. They all thrive in cooler early-fall conditions. Here are a few tips for success.

headline: Hair Protection From the Sun, One Spritz (or Pump) at a Time
text: In the summer, protecting one’s hair from the sun isn’t always a top priority, with so much attention and energy paid to safeguarding the skin. But as anyone who’s seen blond turn to brass knows, the sun can do long-lasting damage to one’s locks. Luckily, there are a handful of products on the market to protect against it: Last summer, the Stockholm-based brand Sachajuan launched a leave-in serum that protects the hair from ultraviolet rays; earlier this year, the French colorist Christophe Robin released a treatment (with SPF 6) infused with lavender and plant oils to strengthen it before sun exposure. Elsewhere, Phyto introduced five oils in a single bottle as an after-sun mist to renew hair fibers and Davines relaunched its SU line in a four-product range, all with antioxidant and anti-inflammatory benefits. Even the 58-year-old hair-care company René Furterer added three new products to its already-established sun protection line, Soleil. But our favorite of the bunch is a sun-specific hair-repair shampoo, formulated with jojoba wax, that prevents strands from dehydration.

headline: In Zimbabwe, We Don’t Cry for Lions
text: Winston-Salem, N.C. — MY mind was absorbed by the biochemistry of gene editing when the text messages and Facebook posts distracted me.

headline: On Island of Lesbos, a Microcosm of Greece’s Other Crisis: Migrants
text: LESBOS, Greece — The immigration center here, a cluster of prefabricated buildings surrounded by rows of chain-link and barbed-wire fences, was full again on a recent evening, leaving hundreds of families, some with infants, to find a place among the piles of garbage outside.

headline: Refugee Crisis on the Beach in Greece
text: Refugee camps are always sad, desperate places. I saw a lot of them when I was covering southern Africa for four years. But most were in desolate, poor places, not vacation islands like Lesbos, Greece, where thousands of refugees have been arriving in small inflatable boats, as upscale tourists do their best to unwind.

text: With tomatoes, it’s all about waiting for the vigorous, sometimes-gnarly ones grown outdoors. Shun those impostors at the supermarket. Though there have been early outdoor cherry tomatoes to tease us, now we can really let loose.

text: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York advised the public to be on the lookout for symptoms of Legionnaires’ disease and to immediately seek treatment if symptoms start to appear.

headline: Zucchini Two Ways
text: If you have a vegetable garden, you know the drill. A zucchini plant is prolific. Yesterday’s tiny squash has grown to medium-size seemingly overnight. And there are always a few giants lurking, like big fish that got away. But, if I may say, there is nothing like an unblemished, shiny, just-picked zucchini, whatever the size (well, perhaps not those great, great big ones).

headline: Corn

headline: Beyond Corn on the Cob
text: You may have eaten corn on the cob for the Fourth of July, but now is the time to get your fill. Joining the ranks at the corn stand and rummaging for the best ears (heavy and green, with fresh-looking husks and silk) is a summer ritual. The reward for waiting is blissfully sweet corn, the kind that induces a certain euphoria.

headline: Review: Emerson String Quartet Plays Beethoven, Mozart and Fauré
text: Sometimes there is a moment in a concert when the music-making suddenly comes into focus. During the Emerson String Quartet’s recital at Alice Tully Hall on Monday evening at the Mostly Mozart Festival, it came during the Lento of Beethoven’s String Quartet in F.

headline: Merkel Aide Seeks Dismissal of Prosecutor Who Opened Treason Inquiry
text: MÜNSTER, Germany — The uproar over the decision by Germany’s top prosecutor to investigate two journalists on charges of treason intensified on Tuesday when the justice minister, with the support of Chancellor Angela Merkel, called for the prosecutor to be fired.

headline: Review: ‘Mr. Robinson,’ a Classroom Comedy on NBC

text: A perilous, improbable rail journey that began at the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001, will end Thursday when PATH car No. 745 is welcomed with a parade — bagpipes, dignitaries and all — through the streets of East Haven, Conn.

text: There’s the Jim Gaffigan career path: Work hard on the comedy circuit, amass a huge following and parlay that into a small-screen series loosely inspired by your own life. And then there’s the Julie Klausner career path: Aspire to the Jim Gaffigan career path and then parlay your underachievement into a small-screen series loosely inspired by your own life.

headline: Jeb Bush Causes a Stir on Women’s Health Issues

headline: Zucchini, Tomatoes and Corn: Ripe for the Cooking
text: Tomatoes, corn and zucchini define summer eating for me. It no doubt has something to do with my memories of childhood summers in the Midwest. That’s when we had fresh vegetables; the rest of the year, they came neatly frozen in their little paper boxes, just right for a family of four.

headline: Long Before Patriots Scandal, N.F.L. Was Rocked by High School Ringers

headline: Up for Sale, The Economist Is Unlikely to Alter Its Voice

headline: In ‘Steve: A Docu-Musical,’ Colin Summers Unveils a Mysterious Collaborator

headline: Eating Spicy Food Linked to a Longer Life
text: Eating spicy food is associated with a reduced risk for death, an analysis of dietary data on more than 485,000 people found.

headline: Katie Ledecky Sets Another Record, Then Returns to Pool
text: KAZAN, Russia — Before Katie Ledecky embarked on a mission many onlookers at the swimming world championships Tuesday considered pure madness, she consumed two meals. The first was a plate of pasta with pesto sauce, a mound of rice, a piece of bread and green beans. The second, roughly three hours later, consisted of another plate of pasta.

headline: Review: In This ‘Comedy of Errors,’ Shakespeare Gets a Jersey Accent
text: LENOX, Mass. — She is a magnificent specimen: the hair big and honey blond, the clothes snug and revealing, the jewelry copious and gold. Meticulously manicured, stalking around in screaming-orange sandals with wedge heels that would maim a weaker woman, the aggrieved Adriana is pure Jersey girl — the stereotypical variety.

headline: Riding the Waves
text: A stunt two years in the making.

headline: Russia Stakes New Claim to Expanse in the Arctic
text: MOSCOW — Russia formally staked a claim on Tuesday to a vast area of the Arctic Ocean, including the North Pole.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Remain in Dead Heat in New Hampshire, Poll Shows
text: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont continues to tighten the race with Hillary Rodham Clinton in New Hampshire, according to a poll released on Tuesday.

headline: The Commune
text: Meet some of the residents of rural Cannon County, Tenn., which has become an unlikely refuge for L.G.B.T.Q. noncomformists.

headline: Ebola Cases Fall Sharply, W.H.O. Reports
text: The number of new Ebola diagnoses in Sierra Leone and Guinea reached its lowest point in well over a year last week, according to the World Health Organization, with only one reported case in each country. There were no new cases in Liberia, the third nation most severely affected by the outbreak.

headline: An Exchange in Australia Woos Listings From China
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Just two companies are listed on the Asia Pacific Stock Exchange in Sydney, and it has to rely on its biggest Australian rival to clear and settle trades.

text: Netflix announced on Tuesday that it was starting an unlimited leave policy for new mothers and fathers for the first year after the birth or adoption of a child.

headline: Rise of SoundExchange Shows the Growth of Digital Radio Royalties
text: For a sense of how quickly digital radio outlets like Pandora and SiriusXM have become a major source of revenue for the music industry, look no further than their royalty payments.

headline: Oklahoma Acts to Limit Earthquake Risk at Oil and Gas Wells
text: Oklahoma regulators have told energy companies to sharply reduce underground wastewater disposal across an earthquake-prone stretch of the state, a move that ratchets up a so-far unsuccessful effort to reduce quakes related to oil and gas production.

headline: 330 to Share $21 Million in Abuse Settlement With Milwaukee Archdiocese
text: Leaders of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Milwaukee said Tuesday that they had reached a $21 million settlement with hundreds of victims of sexual abuse by clergy members, though the agreement is still subject to approval by a federal judge.

headline: As Debate Goes On Without Bobby Jindal, Super PAC’s Ad Will Support Him in Iowa
text: The super PAC backing Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana, who was relegated to the second-tier debate panel on Thursday in Cleveland, will broadcast an ad on Fox News in Iowa during the main event.

headline: Puerto Rico Has Another Debt Worry on Horizon
text: While Puerto Rico’s first bond default in its history reverberated through the financial markets on Tuesday, another move by the cash-poor island may provide a clue to where the next trouble spot lies.

headline: Judge Rejects Settlement in American Express Case
text: It sounded like an innocuous message: “Amex negotiation has gotten crazy,” Gary Friedman, representing merchants in a lawsuit against American Express, said in a text message to his friend and fellow lawyer Keila Ravelo two years ago. “Gmailed u the issue.”

headline: U.N. Chief Appeals for More Aid to Support Palestinian Refugees
text: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon of the United Nations beseeched donors on Tuesday to fill an emergency $100 million gap in funding for the agency that aids five million Palestinian refugees in the Middle East. In a statement, Mr. Ban said the shortfall confronting the United Nations Relief and Works Agency was unprecedented and risked disrupting the education of a half-million children. Many United Nations agencies are under severe financial pressure because of emergency efforts to help people displaced by the conflicts in Syria, Iraq and Yemen.

headline: Iraq: Funding Shortfall Deprives Uprooted Iraqis of Health Services
text: Faced with a shortage of funds, international aid agencies have been forced to suspend 84 percent of their health programs in 10 Iraqi provinces, depriving almost three million people of basic medical care, World Health Organization officials said Tuesday. The aid agencies, including the W.H.O., need $60.9 million to operate their health care centers in Iraq but have received only $5.1 million from donors. More than 184 centers serving refugees and other people displaced by violence in Iraq have suspended their operations, the W.H.O. said. The centers were the only health care providers in many parts of Iraq. “This is a country ravaged by conflict,” said Dr. Syed Jaffar Hussain, the W.H.O. representative in Iraq. “Not only do we have innocent civilians being caught in the violence, with so many people fleeing the fighting and living in temporary housing, people are at much higher risk from communicable diseases. Unless additional funding is received, millions more will be deprived of health services they urgently need.” The W.H.O. said it was appealing to international donors and seeking alternative sources of funding.

headline: Catch a Back-to-School Spending Break With Sales-Tax Holidays
text: August is time for back-to-school shopping — and, in many states, that means so-called sales-tax holidays as well.

headline: Friends of Joe Biden Worry a Run for President Could Bruise His Legacy
text: WASHINGTON — Later this month, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will escape for a family retreat to mourn his late son, Beau, but also to mull, as his dying son urged him to do, a campaign for president. Some of Mr. Biden’s friends and allies worry that he will decide it is a good idea.

headline: Luis Severino Carries Hopes of Yankees
text: The Yankees took the field on Tuesday with precisely 600 innings from their starting pitchers this season. Only one winning team in the major leagues, the Kansas City Royals, had fewer. This explains the Yankees’ seemingly daily habit of calling up a fresh bullpen arm from the minors.

headline: Group Plans to Renovate Long-Neglected Areas of Prospect Park
text: When the gleaming Lakeside skating complex opened in Prospect Park’s southeast corner in 2013, it quieted critics who had long said that the park’s east side, which faces grittier neighborhoods, was being neglected.

headline: M.L.B. Advanced Media Joins With N.H.L. in Unusual Intersport Deal
text: In an unusual transaction between two major sports entities, Major League Baseball Advanced Media will pay the National Hockey League $100 million annually starting next year to operate the NHL.com website, and the NHL Network will also distribute out-of-market games online through NHL GameCenter Live and through television providers on NHL Center Ice.

headline: Another Exoneration in Brooklyn Brings Total Since Last Year to 14

headline: Fruit at an Oasis
text: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — If you’ve been reading Wordplay for a while, you will know that I firmly believe that the themes in some of the crosswords published here are subliminal messages from the constructors or, if they’ve been doing this for many years, an occasional cry for help. Today, we have a call for help from Patrick Berry, who has apparently landed himself in prison.

headline: Kentucky: Sheriff Defends Officer Shown Handcuffing Child in Video
text: The county sheriff in Covington on Tuesday defended a school resource officer who was shown on a video restraining an 8-year-old boy with handcuffs last year, saying the officer had acted appropriately while responding to a request from school officials to “de-escalate and defuse a threat to others.” The handcuffing is the subject of a federal lawsuit filed Monday by the American Civil Liberties Union against the Kenton County sheriff’s office, Sheriff Charles L. Korzenborn and the resource officer, Deputy Kevin Sumner; a video shows the boy, who has attention hyperactivity deficit disorder and had been acting out in school, crying as Deputy Sumner holds his arms behind his back and places handcuffs on his biceps. In a statement, Sheriff Korzenborn said the deputy “did what he is sworn to do and in conformity with all constitutional and law enforcement standards.”

headline: New York City Task Force Targets Cheating by Teachers and Principals
text: The New York City Department of Education said on Tuesday that it would establish a task force to root out cheating by teachers and administrators in city schools, responding to recent episodes and allegations of grade inflation, forged test answers and the passing of students who rarely attended class.

headline: Cilla Black, Top Pop Star in Swinging Sixties Britain, Dies at 72
text: Cilla Black, who rose from a job checking coats in a Liverpool nightclub to become Britain’s top female vocalist of the 1960s, died on Saturday at her villa in Estepona, Spain. She was 72.

headline: Mets, Well Aware of Status as Leaders, Rally to Fifth Straight Win
text: MIAMI — Terry Collins was trying to ignore the widespread attention the Mets were receiving as they surged into first place in the National League East with an invigorated offense and stout pitching.

headline: Yankees’ Surging Offense Makes Up for Imperfections in Rout of Red Sox
text: The way the Yankees are swinging the bats, pounding pitchers and racking up runs, as they did again Tuesday night in a 13-3 win over the Boston Red Sox, they do more than overwhelm opponents.

headline: Alan Cheuse, Late-Blooming Author and NPR Book Critic, Dies at 75
text: Alan Cheuse, a late-blooming author who published his first short story just before his 40th birthday and went on to write two dozen books, but who became even better known as a longtime book critic for NPR, died on July 31 in San Jose, Calif. He was 75.

headline: A B.Y.O.B. Peking Duck Feast With Some of New York’s Top Sommeliers
text: Last Thursday, Chinatown blazed in a noontime swelter as some of the city’s top sommeliers filed into the Peking Duck House on Mott Street. Each had a thing or two tucked under his or her arm — bottles of wine from their personal collections. Michael Madrigale, Bar Boulud’s head sommelier, entered with a 2007 Albert Boxler Riesling Grand Cru Brand ($50). Ashley Santoro, the wine director at Narcissa, came with a 1974 Francesco Rinaldi & Figli Barolo from Piedmont, Italy (about $115 retail). Patrick Cappiello was waiting for the sommeliers — eight, in all — with a magnum of Savart Premier Cru L’Accomplie Brut Champagne ($80). As the wine director for Rebelle and Pearl & Ash, sister restaurants on Bowery, Cappiello convenes these impromptu lunches about once a month, whenever the time allows. There are only two rules: Bring an intriguing bottle of wine; and keep it to around $100 each.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday
text: 3:40 P.M. (HBO Signature) FOUR WEDDINGS AND A FUNERAL (1994) Hugh Grant portrays an Englishman with a fear of commitment who happens to be a favored best man among the marrying kind of his circle in this comedy, directed by Mike Newell and written by Richard Curtis. Andie MacDowell is the American beauty who just may change his mind — if only his friends (played by Kristin Scott Thomas, Simon Callow, James Fleet, John Hannah and Charlotte Coleman, among others) would stop getting in his way. Writing in The New York Times, Janet Maslin compared this “multitiered confection with a romantic spirit and an enchantingly pretty veneer” to a wedding cake, adding that it was “elegant, festive and very, very funny.”

headline: Photography in Cuba: It’s Not Easy
text: If you spend enough time talking with people in Cuba, there is a phrase you are sure to hear: No es fácil — it’s not easy. Those three words attest to a hard-earned wisdom, of learning how to survive challenges big and small, ideological and practical, without getting caught in the middle or, worse, on the wrong side.

headline: A Judge’s Rebuke of Immigration Detention
text: Children do not belong in prison. The mass detention of families offends American values, a lesson this country learned long ago at Manzanar, Tule Lake, Heart Mountain and the other Japanese-American internment camps of World War II.

headline: My Question for the Republican Presidential Debate
text: If I got to ask one question of the presidential aspirants at Thursday’s Fox Republican debate, it would be this: “As part of a 1982 transportation bill, President Ronald Reagan agreed to boost the then 4-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax to 9 cents, saying, ‘When we first built our highways, we paid for them with a gas tax,’ adding, ‘It was a fair concept then, and it is today.’ Do you believe Reagan was right then, and would you agree to raise the gasoline tax by 5 cents a gallon today so we can pay for our highway bill, which is now stalled in Congress over funding?”

headline: Where Should a Poor Family Live?
text: If its goal is to move up the ladder, where should a poor family live? Should federal dollars go toward affordable housing within high-poverty neighborhoods, or should subsidies be used to move residents of impoverished communities into more upscale – and more resistant — sections of cities and suburbs with better schools and job opportunities?

headline: How to Really Defend Planned Parenthood
text: WHY does the pro-choice movement so often find itself in a defensive crouch?

headline: The Voting Rights Act at 50
text: For the first 48 years of its existence, the Voting Rights Act — signed by President Lyndon Johnson 50 years ago this week — was one of the most popular and effective civil rights laws in American history. Centuries of slavery, segregation and officially sanctioned discrimination had kept African-Americans from having any real voice in the nation’s politics. Under the aggressive new law, black voter registration and turnout soared, as did the number of black elected officials.

headline: Who Will Fund the M.T.A.?
text: New York State’s Metropolitan Transportation Authority has said that it needs $29.8 billion in capital spending over the next five years if the nation’s largest mass transit system — the network of trains, buses and subways that supports New York City and its suburbs and serves 15.2 million people — has any real hope of improvement. The question, as always, is where this money will come from.

headline: ‘Verbatim: The Ferguson Case’
text: By now, most Americans have heard of Ferguson, Mo.: on Aug. 9, 2014, a white police officer, Darren Wilson, shot an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown, on a street in that suburb of St. Louis. One year later, the word “Ferguson” has become indelibly linked to the charged conversation about racial justice in the United States. Like many Americans, I followed the case and ensuing protests, absorbing a barrage of commentary from news sources and my social networks. And yet as the months wore on, and the officer was not indicted, I realized that I (perhaps like many others), was never clear on the details: What exactly happened in Ferguson the day Mr. Brown was shot?

headline: Verbatim: The Ferguson Case
text: This short video juxtaposes the reenacted testimony of two key witnesses in the shooting of the unarmed black teenager Michael Brown by a police officer in Ferguson, MO.

headline: News Q’s | With Halo 5, Microsoft Seeks to Lure E-Sports Players Back
text: Note: We’ve updated 6 Q’s About the News for the new school year. This feature, now known as News Q’s, will be a daily mini-lesson, with both Before Reading and After Reading questions, and a suggested activity for going further. Let us know what you think.

headline: Réunion Debris Is Almost Surely From Flight 370, Officials Say
text: PARIS — Investigators and the families of those who were aboard Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 now have what they have sought for more than a year — the first tangible trace of the vanished airplane.

headline: Living in the Financial District
text: The neighborhood is undeniably crowded during rush hour and around tourist hubs, but quiet corners can be found.

headline: The Financial District: A Neighborhood With Two Faces
text: Sara Benda remembers when the Financial District didn’t feel like a neighborhood. That was eight years ago, when she moved there shortly before giving birth to twins.

headline: Gary Rivlin’s ‘Katrina: After the Flood’
text: New Orleanians have been hearing it for 10 years now: How’s New Orleans doing? Is it back? Is the Lower Ninth Ward . . . O.K.? The questioner takes the tentative, commiserating tone one might use to inquire about a friend’s infirm grandmother who, at last report, had been moved to hospice. The local, sighing, responds tersely: New Orleans is doing terrifically and terribly. It’s back but different and currently undergoing a furious transformation. Much of the Lower Ninth Ward is not O.K. But each of these answers requires a book-length footnote. If you really want to know how New Orleans is doing, you have to ask different questions.

headline: ‘We’re Still Here Ya Bastards,’ by Roberta Brandes Gratz
text: When I first lived in New Orleans, during the spring of 2005, the unfinished work of Reconstruction was much on my mind. An obelisk near the ­Mississippi River commemorates a revolt against the Reconstruction government led by former Confederate soldiers. Half a mile away, where Canal Street meets North Rampart, I’d wait at a bus stop among people going home post-shift — hotel chambermaids and kitchen workers in their black-and-white checkered pants — waiting to be carried away from the city’s hallucinatory core to the New Orleans that lay beyond, a city whose racialized inequality was so entrenched it masqueraded as the natural order of things. During a public forum on gentrification at the historic St. Augustine Church, people spoke of being under siege. A neighbor told me, “If you cut the ground here, it will bleed black.”

headline: How to Vacation Like It’s 1999
text: Let’s take a road trip back in time to, say, 1999.

headline: In Sea of Memorial Patches, a Former Mets Owner Sinks From Sight
text: When Nelson Doubleday Jr. died in mid-June, the Mets honored him with a short statement and a moment of silence.

headline: The Kansas Experiment
text: When I think of my uncle Gene, I think of a man who, late into the night at a particularly boisterous family wedding, would flatten his palms against the dance floor, extend his body parallel to the ground and then begin to undulate his legs and torso in a move known as the worm. Or I think of how, even later that same evening, he would agitate for a midnight meal at a diner in west Wichita, Kan., called the Golden Bell. Or of how, in his more abstemious workaday life, he left the family business — a small bank based in Colwich, a town of about 1,000 people in south-central Kansas, where he grew up alongside my father and 11 other siblings — so that he could expand a chain of pizzerias, which grew to include 48 franchises in five states.

headline: Real Estate Investment Aided by Ponzi Scheme Could Recoup Victims’ Money
text: MONTAUK, N.Y. — With the ocean roaring in front of them, guests relaxed under white umbrellas on a recent summer afternoon here. Stacked against a hill behind them were the villas and cottages of the Panoramic View, the beneficiary of one of the most audacious frauds in Long Island history.

headline: Push for Retribution in Egypt Frays Muslim Brotherhood

headline: A Year Later, Ferguson Sees Change, but Asks if It’s Real
text: FERGUSON, Mo. — Brianna West stepped before the judge as her daughter Morgan, 3, fidgeted beside her. Ms. West had waited weeks to get this case behind her, facing citations that included failure to comply with a police officer. She worried about steep fines, even jail time, on charges she felt were baseless. But the hearing brought relief.

headline: Ungrounded
text: When I was 14, my family moved into a house that was basically a big wooden box perched on the side of a mountain. At my new school, I became The Girl in the House on Stilts. Despite this minor celebrity, there were certain perils to living in a house that didn’t touch the ground, the foremost being its sway in a powerful storm.

headline: Today in Politics: Commotion Over Ad-Libbed Remarks Fills Divide Between Two Jebs
text: Good Wednesday morning from Washington, where all eyes are on Thursday’s Republican debate now that the lineup has been finalized. Jeb Bush is among those who made the cut, but on Tuesday, he rekindled some concerns about his propensity for off-the-cuff remarks that often require subsequent clarification.

headline: Wedding in Berlin Finally Has Its Moment
text: At a Berlin dinner party, few punch lines used to be as reliable as naming the city’s Wedding neighborhood as the next big thing. This working-class area has been trumpeted as up-and-coming since the Berlin Wall came down 26 years ago. But at last this 3.5-square-mile district is showing signs of delivering on that promise.

headline: The Cost of Natural Disasters
text: Every year, natural disasters cost the United States billions in insured losses. In 2014, the figure reached $25 billion. Which disasters are the most common, and what do they cost?

headline: Is It Wrong If a Friend Sells My Hand-Me-Downs?
text: I have two small children and am frequently divesting our household of toys, clothes and other child supplies. I sell the larger items, but I typically give the smaller items away to a neighborhood parent or leave them in a box in front of my house to be taken for free. A friend on my block recently indicated that she takes much of what we leave out, and I’ve since offered her first pick before leaving the remaining items outside. I was happy to do so, as she has two children a bit younger than mine, and I considered it a worthwhile gesture to share what we no longer need with her, despite the fact that she is of similar economic status and likely doesn’t need our castoffs. She recently held a stoop sale, and I recognized a very large number of the items that were formerly ours on display for sale. Am I wrong to see this as somehow inappropriate? I recognize that a gift means I’m not free to question what the receiver does with it, but this has changed the way I feel about her and the prospect of putting out other items in the future. Am I wrong to feel that she should have passed on these items to others? NAME WITHHELD, BROOKLYN

headline: Assessing Tom Brady’s Stock in the Fashion World
text: If we accept as a given in the fashion/celebrity complex that public figures sell clothes (and cars and cookies) — that their carefully constructed image transfers itself to the stuff that surrounds them, along the way suggesting that if we get that stuff, too, we might be more like them — does it then follow that the obverse is true? That the tarnishing of public figures tarnishes that which is associated with them, too?

headline: A Mess of Clams
text: ‘‘The hard-shell is the king of the clams,’’ a clam merchant named Archie M. Clock told the New Yorker writer Joseph Mitchell in 1939. They were sitting on Clock’s battered old sloop, the Jennie Tucker, out on the wind-ruffled waters of the Great South Bay, off Islip and Babylon, on Long Island. Mitchell was there to report on the harvest of the hard-shell littleneck and cherrystone clams that then dominated the shellfish sections of New York restaurant menus.

headline: What’s Left of the Voting Rights Act?
text: My cover story in the Aug. 2 magazine details the half-century-long arc of the Voting Rights Act, from its passage as a signal accomplishment of the civil rights movement to the ultimately successful campaign to eradicate its strongest provisions at the Supreme Court in 2013. During my reporting I became particularly interested in the federal court challenge to North Carolina’s sweeping new voting law, which showed how the Supreme Court’s decision gutting key provisions of the law had immediate consequences in some states.

headline: Zimbabwe Court Postpones Trial of Guide in Killing of Cecil the Lion

headline: Barrel Bombs, Not ISIS, Are the Greatest Threat to Syrians
text: GAZIANTEP, Turkey — As the self-proclaimed Islamic State, or ISIS, commits horrendous videotaped executions, it might seem to pose the greatest threat to Syrian civilians. In fact, that ignoble distinction belongs to the barrel bombs being dropped by the military of Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad. The Islamic State has distracted us from this deadly reality.

headline: What You Get for… $2,000,000

headline: Halsey, With ‘Badlands,’ Is Moving Fast to Share a Secret Language
text: It was one thing for Ashley Nicolette Frangipane, a kid from New Jersey, to have 14,000 friends on MySpace at age 14 and 16,000 subscribers on YouTube at 18. But it’s quite another for Halsey, Ms. Frangipane’s pop-star alter ego, to have taken that innate 21st-century talent for self-presentation — not to mention songwriting — from her bedroom to arena stages in a mere year since signing with a record label.

headline: A Five-Bedroom 1927 Townhouse in a Suburb of Brussels

headline: Daily Report: E-Sports Continues to Reshape Gaming Landscape
text: Video games used to be such a simple business. You bought a console (say, an Xbox), you bought a game at your local big-box retailer ($46 for Halo: Combat Evolved at Wal-Mart), and you went on your merry way — spending hundreds of hours glued to a TV screen, blasting away at the bad guys.

headline: Morning Agenda: Puerto Rico’s Next Debt Problem
text: PUERTO RICO’S NEXT DEBT PROBLEM | The Puerto Rican government quietly disclosed on Monday afternoon that it had stopped making contributions of $92 million a month into a fund used to make payments on $13 billion in bond debt, Mary Williams Walsh writes in DealBook. A small payment from the fund is due on Sept. 1 and unlike the bond payments that went into default on Monday, these are general obligation bonds. Puerto Rico had issued such bonds over the years to raise money for government projects, with a guarantee in the island’s constitution that the bonds would be paid.

headline: There is No Pro-Life Case For Planned Parenthood
text: I’m hoping to do something broader about the abortion issue in this space soon, given the prominence that the debate over Planned Parenthood funding has suddenly assumed. But for this week a word (well, a few words) on the argument in this Dana Milbank column, which was also basically the argument in this earlier Milbank column, which is also roughly the argument in this Ruth Marcus column, which is also the argument in this Damon Linker column, which is also a case that Slate’s Will Saletan has made repeatedly in the past, which … well, you get the idea. The claim they’re all making, in different ways, is that even though Planned Parenthood performs hundreds of thousands of abortions every year (while lobbying constantly against any restriction on the practice), to oppose channeling public dollars to its family planning operations is to be objectively pro-abortion, because those operations objectively prevent many more abortions still.

headline: ‘Right to Be Forgotten’ Online Could Spread
text: More than a year ago, in a decision that stunned many American Internet companies, Europe’s highest court ruled that search engines were required to grant an unusual right — the “right to be forgotten.” Privacy advocates cheered the decision by the European Court of Justice, which seemed to offer citizens some recourse to what had become a growing menace of modern life: The Internet never forgets, and, in its robotic zeal to collect and organize every scrap of data about everyone, it was beginning to wreak havoc on personal privacy.

headline: Tim Blanks Joins the Industry Website The Business of Fashion
text: Fashion’s never-ending game of musical chairs, a nonstop roundelay of personnel moves, tends to confine itself to those who create, rather than observe, fashion. Designers shuffle; those who file into the stands season after season to see their shows, less so.

headline: Review: ‘Let’s Be Less Stupid,’ a Distracted Meditation on Absent-Mindedness
text: When you need something short and funny to read, it helps to have a few old journalistic favorites on standby. Mine include Dave Barry’s seminal Miami Herald piece “Can New York Save Itself?” and a Guardian article from 2002 in which the writer, Tim Dowling, was forced by his editors to spend a night in a trench in his backyard.

headline: No, Giving More People Health Insurance Doesn’t Save Money
text: In 2014, an estimated  nine million people became newly insured thanks to Obamacare.

headline: Floyd Mayweather’s Choice of Andre Berto Excites Few
text: Floyd Mayweather Jr. has named the final opponent in his storied career. But the general reaction to his announcement has been resigned disappointment.

headline: Report Finds Wide Diversity Gap Among 2014’s Top-Grossing Films
text: The numbers are stunning: From 2007 through 2014, women made up only 30.2 percent of all speaking or named characters in the 100 top-grossing fictional films released in the United States. That’s bad enough to repeat: For every 2.3 male characters who say “Dude,” there is just one woman saying, “Hello?!”

headline: 1890: Push for President to Resign
text: BUENOS AYRES, Aug. 5 — Having failed to obtain a single Opposition Minister, President Celman has offered the city all kinds of privileges, including practical autonomy. The populace, sullen and menacing, refuse everything except the President’s resignation. The officers of the regiments that recently fought on opposite sides have fraternized and declare that in future the troops will not fight against each other. The naval opposition officers have been quietly permitted to resume their commands in the fleet. The situation here is unprecedented and almost incredible. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 6, 1890

headline: Jeb Bush on Funding for Women’s Health
text: Jeb Bush, the Republican presidential candidate, said on Tuesday that he would cut off federal funding for Planned Parenthood if elected to the White House.

headline: A Spread of Spanish Snacks at Despaña
text: Despaña Brand Foods, in Jackson Heights, Queens, ships its chorizo all over the world. On Saturdays, it sets out samples of sausage and cheese for customers.

headline: Britain Charges Anjem Choudary, Radical Preacher, With Aiding ISIS
text: LONDON — The radical preacher Anjem Choudary, some of whose followers have joined the Islamic State, was charged by the British authorities on Wednesday with inciting support for the organization.

headline: Travel Diary

headline: Staging Passion Play for 200 Years, Italians Become More Than Merely Players
text: SORDEVOLO, Italy — The horses were skittish. The microphones occasionally went silent or screeched shrilly. Phones in the audience trilled a little too often.

headline: From a Spanish Shop in Queens, Chorizo That’s Out of This World
text: It is true that there’s a SoHo branch of Despaña Brand Foods, a chic and airy boutique on Broome Street. But to get the full sense of Despaña, you have to visit the original outlet in Queens, where the chorizo has been made for four decades.

headline: Kids in the Kitchen: No-Knead Bread for All Ages
text: Who wouldn’t want children who can be independent in the kitchen, able to prepare a few healthy meals and snacks and with the confidence to tackle a new recipe or task? In our Kids in the Kitchen series, Motherlode’s KJ Dell’Antonia and Cooking’s Margaux Laskey work toward that long term goal with their very differently aged families. Margaux finds ways for her 3-year-old and toddler to help cook, while KJ stands back and coaches her two 9-year-olds and her 11 and 14-year-olds in cooking on their own. This week, both families tried simple bread-making.

headline: Summer in Iraq: Beneath the Heat and Abaya and a Flak Jacket Too
text: BAGHDAD – It was August 2004 in Najaf, in southern Iraq. Off to the west past the edge of town, the desert shimmered like a sea. In the streets, mud brick and cinder block magnified the heat. I was too busy to check the temperature, but at midafternoon, it was likely heading toward 120 degrees Fahrenheit.

headline: Egypt’s President Leads Celebration of ‘New’ Suez Canal
text: CAIRO — An image of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt triumphantly piloting a ship full of smiling Egyptians appears Wednesday on the cover of the state-owned newspaper Al Akhbar al Youm to mark the successful excavation of what he has called a new Suez Canal. Really, it is a new channel, parallel to about a third of the existing canal, intended to reduce shipping bottlenecks.

headline: Turkey’s Push Into War Is Seen as Erdogan’s Political Strategy
text: ISTANBUL — Confronted with widespread protests two summers ago, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan ordered a harsh police crackdown and tarnished the demonstrators as traitors and spies. Faced with a corruption inquiry focused on his inner circle, he responded by purging the police and judiciary.

headline: Shanice Williams to Play Dorothy in NBC’s Live Version of ‘The Wiz’
text: Shanice Williams will have some big silver shoes to fill. NBC announced Wednesday that she will play the lead role of Dorothy, made famous by Diana Ross in a 1978 film, in the network’s live version of “The Wiz.” Following on the heels of NBC’s live “The Sound of Music” in 2013 and “Peter Pan” in 2014, “The Wiz” will air Dec. 3.

headline: A New Action Camera, Born From a Cycling Crash
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In 2012, a Brazilian software engineer named Bruno Gregory and a friend went for a bicycle ride in the hills of the East Bay, where Mr. Gregory was living. With a GoPro camera on one of their bikes recording the ride, a car mowed into the two cyclists, sending them hurtling to the pavement.

headline: Spotify’s Content Chief Moves to Online Video Start-Up Pluto TV

headline: 1965: U.S. Jobless Rate at New Low
text: WASHINGTON — The unemployment rate dropped to an eight-year low in July and President Johnson pledged today that his administration would try to cut it further. The Labor Department announced that unemployment fell to 4.5 percent of the working force last month from 4.7 percent in June. It attributed the drop to the heavy hiring of teenagers, young men, and adult women. Employment jumped sharply to a record high of 74,854,000. There were 1.1 million more at work in July than in June and 2.4 million more than in July a year ago. Mr. Johnson said he was ‘‘extremely pleased.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 6, 1965

headline: James Lecesne of the Trevor Project, Inhabiting Lives and Saving Them
text: Late in the first episode of Caitlyn Jenner’s documentary series “I Am Cait,” Ms. Jenner visits the family of Kyler Prescott, a 14-year-old transgender boy who committed suicide in May. “It’s so hard for young people,” Ms. Jenner says. “They can’t see the future, and because of that they become extraordinarily desperate and suicide becomes an option. We have to do something about that.”

text: Q. I never use the built-in webcam on my PC laptop. Is there a way to deactivate it in case I ever get infected with any malware that tries to use the camera?

headline: Guerrilla Girls, Going and Going …
text: Thirty years after the feminist activists began, the Guerrilla Girls are still going. Their identities remain a secret but their fight for equality in the art world still attracts legions of fans.

headline: Cheryl Boone Isaacs Re-Elected President of Motion Picture Academy
text: LOS ANGELES — Cheryl Boone Isaacs was elected to a third one-year term as president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on Tuesday, the Academy said. Academy presidents may serve up to four consecutive years under the group’s rules, and have typically been re-elected by its governors if they choose to return.

headline: Style, Substance, and The Donald
text: Just about the entire political commentariat has been caught completely flatfooted by Donald Trump’s durable front-runner status; he was supposed to collapse after being nasty to St. John McCain, but nothing of the sort happened.

headline: The Guerrilla Girls, After 3 Decades, Still Rattling Art World Cages
text: When you’ve spent 30 years wearing a gorilla mask, as the women known by the aliases Frida Kahlo and Käthe Kollwitz have, certain behavior becomes second nature. So there were Kahlo and Kollwitz, two of the pseudonymous founding members of the Guerrilla Girls, the activist, feminist art collective, preening and posing at their 30th anniversary party and retrospective in May. They sipped prosecco through straws (their gorilla lips wouldn’t allow much more) at the Abrons Arts Center on the Lower East Side, while guests gazed at walls lined with the posters protesting elitism and bias that first shook the art world in the 1980s. “Do Women Have to Be Naked to Get Into the Met Museum?” one provocatively asked. The Guerrillas’ name tags identified them as pioneering dead female artists (like Alice Neel, the portraitist, or Zubeida Agha, the Pakistani modernist) whose legacies they hope to continue.

headline: S.E.C. Approves Rule on C.E.O. Pay Ratio
text: The chief executive of General Electric raked in a $37.3 million pay package last year, a large sum by any standard.

headline: A Virtual Reality Film Festival Becomes a Reality
text: Would you like to be in a movie? How about inside a movie? A new film festival focused solely on virtual reality projects will give audiences that opportunity. The inaugural Kaleidoscope VR Film Festival, announced by organizers on Wednesday, will go on a 10-city tour and will feature a variety of virtual reality films by independent filmmakers. It will start Aug. 22 in Portland, Ore., and move on to San Francisco and Los Angeles, among other cities. It comes to New York on Oct. 6.
