headline: Three Reasons to (Still) Visit Puerto Rico
text: Puerto Rico faces a potentially crippling financial crisis that is drawing comparisons with Greece. We’ve asked travel experts to share their perspective on how the crisis will affect the island’s $7 billion tourism industry. headline: 36 Hours in Provence
text: Exploring Provence’s vast, rugged sprawl can be exhilarating — and daunting. From the salt marshes of the Camargue to storybook hilltop villages like Gordes to the lively Mediterranean city of Marseille, the famously picturesque French region offers an array of landscapes and experiences that could take months to uncover. Where to start? Arles and Avignon. Just 20 minutes apart by train, the Roman-era town of Arles and the medieval walled city of Avignon enfold a dense mix of architectural beauty, world-class art, sun-soaked Provençal gastronomy and Unesco World Heritage sites. Toss in ambitious new cultural spaces, a hint of urban cool and a high-speed rail link with Paris (about three hours away), and the result is a southern French smorgasbord that can be devoured in a weekend.

headline: Bank of America Starts to Pull Clients’ Money Out of a Paulson Fund
text: John A. Paulson, the billionaire investor who rose to fame betting against the housing market bubble, is having a rocky 2015. And at least one major investor may have had enough.

headline: Revisiting Ferguson
text: The strangest thing about returning to write about Ferguson, Mo., almost a year after the death of Michael Brown, the black teenager who was fatally shot by a white police officer, was how ordinary the place looked.

headline: The Key Numbers in the California Wildfires
text: Dozens of wildfires have burned tens of thousands of acres in California and prompted the evacuation of entire communities. The fires are part of a regional phenomenon of severe drought and heat that has gripped the West.

headline: Departing German Prosecutor Defends Treason Inquiry Against Bloggers

headline: A New Throwback Joint From the Cabin Down Below’s Jesse Malin
text: The East Village nightlife entrepreneur and musician Jesse Malin has a fondness for the neighborhood’s bygone, coarser days. Now, the area is filled with rising rents and Pilates studios, but the little empire of hip haunts Malin has helped to build below 14th Street — Black Market, the Bowery Electric, Niagara, Lovers of Today, Dream Baby and the Cabin Down Below, the intimate clubhouse-like bar just off Tompkins Square Park — pay homage to the neighborhood of 40 years ago. And Malin’s obsessive interest in creating auras of New York authenticity (or, at least, the closest approximation 2015 can offer) is likewise demonstrated in Berlin, the small club he opened last Tuesday on Avenue A.

headline: Days of Selling Popular College Players’ Jerseys Seem Numbered

headline: The Proms, BBC’s Classical Music Festival, Is All the More Important as Austerity Looms

That music festival, dating to 1895, has been under the BBC’s stewardship ever since, barring a brief wartime interlude.

headline: A Woman on the $10 or the $20 Bill?

headline: Temporary Tattoos, Now for Grown-Ups, Too

But the art that drew the most fuss from the collectors was free: temporary tattoos that echoed the paintings for sale, including demons by a follower of Hieronymus Bosch and the monogram-like signature of Albrecht Dürer.

headline: A George Benjamin Exacting Storm in Opera Comes to Mostly Mozart

headline: Donald Trump and Bill Clinton Chatted by Phone Before Trump Announced Candidacy
text: Shortly before Donald J. Trump kicked off his presidential campaign, he had a genial phone conversation with former President Bill Clinton, but the two apparently did not discuss the race itself or Hillary Rodham Clinton’s bid for the Democratic nomination.

headline: Hiroshima Atomic Bomb Survivors Pass Their Stories to a New Generation
text: HIROSHIMA, Japan — Hiromi Hasai was being trained to make machine gun bullets when the flash from the atomic bomb that destroyed his city lit up the already bright morning sky. Just 14, he had been pulled from school a week before to help Japan’s failing war effort.

headline: Best Is Still to Come in Pearson Breakup
text: The best chapter of Pearson’s breakup is yet to be written. Selling a 47 percent stake in the book publisher Penguin Random House to the co-owner Bertelsmann might generate twice as much as The Financial Times, which the British company sold to Japan’s Nikkei for 844 million pounds ($1.3 billion) last month. Pearson’s chief executive, John Fallon, can unshackle himself from the publisher of “Fifty Shades of Grey” as early as October, when a lockup ends. Yet it makes sense to wait.

headline: Texas ID Law Called Breach of Voting Rights Act
text: A federal appeals panel ruled Wednesday that a strict voter identification law in Texas discriminated against blacks and Hispanics and violated the Voting Rights Act of 1965 — a decision that election experts called an important step toward defining the reach of the landmark law.

headline: Value of Iran Sanctions Relief Is Hard to Measure
text: A principal argument opponents raise against the nuclear agreement with Iran is that it would release at least $100 billion in impounded funds that Tehran could then use for attacks against the West and others. But exactly how much money the Iranians would actually receive and how they would use it, should the accord survive, remain difficult and unresolved questions.

headline: At Glimmerglass Festival, ‘The Magic Flute’ Is Among the Reimagined
text: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — No, Vivaldi’s “Cato in Utica” is set not in Utica, N.Y., some 40 miles to the north of here, but in the ancient North African city of that name. Mozart’s “The Magic Flute,” on the other hand, is set in the woods virtually next door.

headline: Reddit Sets New Content Policy, Banning Some Racist Communities
text: Reddit, the popular community news site, formalized a new set of guidelines that aim to restrict some of the risqué and potentially offensive content posted to the site.

headline: Spain Says Banker’s Seized Picasso Will Head Back Home
text: PARIS — To the Spanish authorities, Picasso’s 1906 “Head of a Young Woman” is a unique painting, the only example in Spain from a pivotal period in the artist’s life. Because of that status, the courts labeled it a “national treasure” that should not be sold outside the country.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
text: Good evening. Here’s the latest.

headline: Tesla Motors Trims Delivery Outlook, Sending Stock Down
text: Even as Tesla Motors painted a better-than-expected financial picture in announcing its second-quarter earnings on Wednesday, it warned of fewer car deliveries for the year, sending the stock tumbling.

headline: Review: Joshua Beamish Takes On Challenges Within Couples, in 4 Takes
text: Do major ballet companies commission new works by committee, or does it just seem that way? Depending on the year, certain choreographers — lately Liam Scarlett and Justin Peck — are suddenly everywhere. But what about all the others plugging away? The Joyce Theater plays host to several in its two-week Ballet Festival, which began Tuesday with Joshua Beamish’s MOVE: the company.

headline: Review: ‘Swing That Music,’ Effortless Fun in a Tribute to Jazz Forerunners
text: The secret of serious fun is not to take it too seriously, especially if it involves playing jazz. That attitude is something that the easygoing singer and saxophonist Danny Bacher, who appeared with a small swing band at the Metropolitan Room on Tuesday evening, knows in his bones. It is about making hot music but staying cool, about cutting up while maintaining effortless self-control, about having a blast with friends. And at his performance of “Swing That Music,” a homage to the era of jumpin’ jive with a dollop of Dixieland, Mr. Bacher conflated the music of three Louises — Armstrong, Jordan and Prima — in a concert revealing him to be a prodigiously talented musical preservationist.

headline: Los Angeles Agrees to Overhaul Jails to Care for Mentally Ill and Curb Abuse
text: LOS ANGELES — After disclosures of routine prisoner abuse by the Los Angeles County Sheriff’s Department — where jailers were found to break prisoners’ bones and sexually humiliate them — a settlement was announced Wednesday with the Justice Department in which the county will submit to sweeping reforms of its jail system, with the goals of improving the care of mentally ill inmates and curtailing abuse by deputies.

headline: Review: Vail International Dance Festival Celebrates Meter
text: VAIL, Colo. — Every August, the Vail International Dance Festival, high in the Rockies here, presents an impressive collection of world premieres: ballet, modern dance and other genres. While there’s no scenery (except the mountains), most performances are accompanied by live music. And most of the dancers and choreographers are well known — often from New York.

headline: Yahoo Tweaks Email to Make Search More Personal

headline: When Architecture Meets Pop Culture (Kanye West Included)

headline: Ex-Detective Going to Jail for Role in Manhattan Biker Assault
text: An undercover New York police detective who joined a gang of motorcyclists as they attacked a driver and his family in Upper Manhattan was sentenced to two years in jail on Wednesday.

headline: Midcentury Chic at Loosie Rouge, in Williamsburg’s South Side
text: For longtime Williamsburg denizens, the area’s North Side now feels like a grim “Mad Max” wasteland patrolled by clean-cut conquistadors in hipster Halloween costumes. Seeking cooler climes, the neighborhood’s holdouts now huddle in a South Side oasis along Broadway, just south of the Williamsburg Bridge, where new spots like Loosie Rouge have cropped up around the stately century-old street.

text: Long before “RuPaul’s Drag Race” made cross-dressing a televised form of mainstream entertainment, there was the drag boom of the 1980s and ’90s, when a burgeoning New York club scene was filled with drag performers who perfected the art form.

A quick flight and a few phone calls to surf schools and hotels will put you on the best waves of your life. Listed here are the greatest quick hits for an endless summer.

headline: Shopping Events and Sales Happening This Week in New York
text: What’s up, Doc? This week, Moschino opens a New York boutique in SoHo. There you’ll find all manner of Looney Tunes-themed items from the designer Jeremy Scott’s fall collection, like a Bugs Bunny sweater dress ($895), a Tweety Bird bucket bag ($950) and a Daffy Duck iPhone 6 case ($75) to celebrate your inner child. At 73 Wooster Street.

headline: Bill Plympton Lends His Animation Skills to ‘Kahlil Gibran’s The Prophet’
text: Since the late 1970s, Bill Plympton has been creating shorts and features that use hand-drawn animation to explore adult themes, like  relationships and sexuality. That was the case with his recent film “Cheatin’ ” which looked at difficulties in a relationship with a fever-dream kind of style. He has also collaborated with recording artists including Kanye West on music videos and has drawn some of the opening couch gags for “Simpsons” episodes. His contributions to anthology projects included a segment in the film “The ABCs of Death 2″ and “The Animation Show,” a compilation  put together by Don Hertzfeldt and Mike Judge.

headline: Fox, Topping Projections, Reports a Tough Quarter
text: LOS ANGELES — Reporting its first quarterly results since Rupert Murdoch stepped aside as chief executive, 21st Century Fox revealed a mixed picture on Wednesday: Profits beat expectations, but were down nonetheless, as broadcasting trouble, lower movie revenue and higher sports costs cut into cable-affiliate growth.

headline: New Hampshire: A Vote Against Planned Parenthood
text: Officials  on Wednesday voted against funding  health centers operated by Planned Parenthood of Northern New England. New Hampshire’s Executive Council voted, 3 to 2, to reject contracts that would have provided the organization’s centers in the state with about $638,000 over two years, roughly one-third of the public funding for the centers, which is primarily federal.  Planned Parenthood, whose centers  provides reproductive health services that sometimes include abortion, has been under fire after an abortion opponent released undercover videos showing its officials discussing fees for fetal tissue donation. Lawmakers elsewhere have also called for funding cuts. On Monday, Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana announced that his state would terminate its Medicaid contract with the organization. On Wednesday, the councilors in New Hampshire approved contracts for three other reproductive health service providers.

headline: Charles Goldstein, Lawyer Who Helped Find Looted Art, Dies at 78
text: Charles Goldstein, a high-stakes New York real estate lawyer who transformed himself into a tenacious advocate for recovering art looted from Holocaust victims, died on July 30 in Manhattan. He was 78.

headline: Jon Stewart, Sarcastic Critic of Politics and Media, Is Signing Off
text: On Thursday night 10 presidential candidates will spill onto a stage in Cleveland, and the already crowded Republican primary race will begin in earnest with the first day of debates, live on Fox News.

headline: Red Sox Quickly Go From Lifting Trophy to Raising Doubts
text: Another member of the brotherhood left the family just before game time on Wednesday. Daniel Nava, an outfielder on the Boston Red Sox’ 2013 championship team, was claimed on waivers by Tampa Bay. The Red Sox cut him last week, when he was hitting .152.

headline: High Diving, a Crowd-Pleasing Sport, Pursues an Olympic Platform
text: KAZAN, Russia — It makes no sense that the International Olympic Committee voted Beijing, a city devoid of snow, to be a Winter Games host but has resisted inviting high diving into the Summer Olympics. The men’s high diving event on Wednesday at the FINA world championships, won by Britain’s Gary Hunt, was more entertaining than puppy videos on YouTube.

headline: Bronx Man’s Death From Legionnaires’ Disease Gives Family Cause to Worry
text: Carmelo Quiles was a man of routine. He did not live with his wife anymore, but he rode two buses every day to see her. No later than 9 a.m., he would knock on the door of her brick house in the South Bronx and call her name through the window to let her know he had arrived for his daily visit.

headline: Bob Timmons, 91, a Demanding Coach Who Developed a Star Runner, Is Dead

headline: Cybersecurity Bill Is Latest to Be Delayed in Senate

headline: Senate Report Cites I.R.S. Mismanagement in Targeting of Tea Party Groups
text: WASHINGTON — A Senate committee on Wednesday closed a two-year investigation with unanimous agreement that mismanagement at the Internal Revenue Service led it to improperly target conservative groups seeking tax-exempt status. But a report by the panel did not suggest that any laws were broken, and Republicans and Democrats were divided over whether White House politics was behind the problems.

headline: Louis Sokoloff, Pioneer of PET Scan, Dies at 93

text: A majority of Americans support South Carolina’s decision to remove the Confederate battle flag from its State House grounds, while a third of Americans oppose the move, according to a national survey released on Wednesday.

headline: Mexicans Aren’t Buying Official Account of ‘El Chapo’ Escape
text: MEXICO CITY — When Mexico’s most powerful drug lord, Joaquín Guzmán Loera, escaped from prison last month, he walked out of captivity and straight into the conspiracy-obsessed imaginations of his countrymen, who are willing, it seems, to believe almost anything except what their government tells them.

headline: Marlins Erupt, With Six Runs in Final Inning, but the Mets Avert a Meltdown
text: MIAMI — The Mets entered the bottom of the ninth inning Wednesday with an 8-0 lead. Matt Harvey had just put in a sterling performance: six strikeouts, two hits and no runs in seven efficient innings. Their offense, powered by recent additions, had hammered the Marlins’ pitching for 12 hits. The Mets were an inning away from a day off, nine strikes from their second straight series sweep.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
text: 6:25 P.M. (Flix) FLIRTING WITH DISASTER (1996) Mel Coplin (Ben Stiller), a worker at the American Museum of Natural History and a new father, goes in search of his biological parents with the help of Tina (Téa Leoni), an adoption agency employee, and encounters a succession of oddballs in this comedy from David O. Russell. Patricia Arquette (above right, with, from left, Josh Brolin, Ms. Leoni, Mr. Stiller and Richard Jenkins) plays Mel’s wife, who is just getting her sexual footing back after the birth of their son and doesn’t like Tina’s flirty ways. Mary Tyler Moore plays the mother who raised Mel. She nags a lot and likes to show off her body. “I want you to consider my age and ask yourself how I maintain this,” she declares, lifting her sweater. Writing in The Times, Janet Maslin called the film a “wonderfully mad odyssey of a movie,” adding that “thanks to this filmmaker’s fine comic acumen, the payoff is always there.” In “The Secret Life of Walter Mitty” (2013), at 8 on Cinemax, Mr. Stiller, who also directed this adaptation of the James Thurber short story, stars as Walter, a dutiful drone in the photography department of Life magazine, who finds himself in a caper beyond his wildest imagination when the negative for the publication’s final print edition goes missing. Kristen Wiig plays the crinkly-nosed co-worker on whom Walter has a crush; Adam Scott is the leader of the new tech-jerk bosses who have Walter’s job on the line; and Sean Penn is the mysterious photographer behind Walter’s travels to Iceland, Afghanistan and other stunning far-off places. “Though it is a celebration of modesty, there is also quite a lot of vanity in ‘The Secret Life of Walter Mitty,’ ” A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. There is also a contradiction: “An ordinary fellow should not have to be quite so special to win our admiration.”

headline: Free Puerto Rico, America’s Colony
text: PUERTO RICO has begun to default on its bond payments, for the first time since it became part of the United States, 117 years ago. If it fails to make interest payments on its $72 billion public debt, pension funds across the United States may be unable to meet their payment obligations. But if it were allowed to file for Chapter 9 bankruptcy protection, as cities and counties have done, every state will want that right.

headline: Making Life Harder for Pimps
text: In the long struggle against sex trafficking, we finally have a breakthrough!

headline: Howard Schultz: America Deserves a Servant Leader
text: FROM the earliest days of Starbucks, I’ve been captivated by the art of leadership. I was mentored over three decades by Warren G. Bennis, the eminent professor and scholar on leadership. I’ve gathered insights from peers, and I’ve drawn inspiration from our 300,000 employees. But nothing I’ve read or heard in the past few years has rivaled the power of the image I viewed on my cellphone a few years ago: Pope Francis, shortly after his election, kneeling and washing the feet of a dozen prisoners in Rome, one of them a young Muslim woman, in a pre-Easter ritual.

headline: Why the Voting Rights Act Is Once Again Under Threat
text: IN his opinion for the majority in the Supreme Court’s 2013 Shelby County decision, which struck down a major section of the Voting Rights Act, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. wrote that “history did not end in 1965.” But the sad truth is that voter-suppression efforts did not end, either.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Gap on Race and Juries
text: There are so many troubling issues surrounding race and the criminal justice system these days that it is easy to forget a longstanding problem: the exclusion of African-Americans from juries. After all, it was nearly three decades ago that the Supreme Court took what was seen then as a major step toward solving that problem. In Batson v. Kentucky, decided in April 1986, the court ruled that prosecutors could be required to provide a race neutral explanation when their use of peremptory challenges to strike black potential jurors raised an inference of discrimination.

headline: A Long Time Coming, Sunlight on the Executive Pay Gap
text: After years of delay, the Securities and Exchange Commission approved a sensible final rule on Wednesday  that will force publicly traded companies to reveal how the pay of chief executives compares with that of typical employees.

headline: Greece’s Refugee Crisis and Europe’s Failure
text: As if Greece didn’t have enough on its hands after its European creditors forced it to accept a damaging bailout deal last month, it is also trying to cope with more refugees crossing the Mediterranean to its shores than to any other country in Europe. It is unconscionable for Europe to expect Greece to shoulder this burden, yet that is exactly what is happening.

headline: State Department Cautions Americans Considering Travel to Iran

headline: Albino Sea Cucumbers, a Delicacy, Could Become a Lot Less Rare
text: Sea cucumbers, sluglike creatures that hug the seafloor, have long been a prized delicacy at Chinese banquets, the mark of a special occasion. And no variety of sea cucumber is more valued, or costlier, than the exceedingly rare albino. Just a few years ago, five white sea cucumbers sold at auction in the city of Jinan for 160,000 renminbi, or nearly $26,000 at today’s exchange rate.

headline: A Brooklyn Rental for Sisters and Their Families
text: Four years ago, Lisbeth Kaiser and Alex Rappaport bought a condo with two bedrooms, two baths and almost 1,000 square feet on Fourth Avenue, the busy thoroughfare on the edge of lively Park Slope, Brooklyn. For $640,000, they got a terrace, a washer-dryer, a roof deck, a storage unit and even a parking spot.

headline: June’s Book Club Pick: ‘The Fifth Season,’ by N.K. ­Jemisin
text: Fantasy novels often provide a degree of escapism: a good thing, for any reader who has something worth escaping. Too often, though, that escape comes through a fictional world that erases rather than solves the more complex problems of our own, reducing difficulty to the level of personal struggle and heroism, turning all obstacles to monsters we can see and touch and kill with a sword. But N.K. ­Jemisin’s intricate and extraordinary world-­building starts with oppression: Her universes begin by asking who is oppressing whom, what they are gaining, what they fear. Systems of power stalk her protagonists, often embodied as gods and primeval forces, so vast that resistance seems impossible even to contemplate. When escape comes in her novels, it is not a merely personal victory, or the restoration of a sketchy and soft-lit status quo. Her heroes achieve escape velocity, smashing through oppressive systems and leaving them behind like shed skins.

headline: Ursula K. Le Guin: By the Book
text: The author, most recently, of the updated “Steering the Craft: A 21st-Century Guide to Sailing the Sea of Story,” avoids “fiction about dysfunctional urban middle-class people written in the present tense.”

headline: The Tale of an Anxious Economic Recovery, Told by a Revived Textile Mill
text: Founded 150 years ago, the Faribault Woolen Mill in Minnesota survived the Great War and the Great Depression, not to mention World War II. But it almost did not make it through the Great Recession.

headline: As Coaches Come and Go, Arsène Wenger of Arsenal Just Keeps Going
text: LONDON — It is often said that no job in sports is less secure than that of an N.F.L. player. With no guaranteed contracts, incredible pressure for immediate results, a steady influx of new talent from college football and the constant threat of serious injury, it is hardly surprising that the average player’s career lasts about three years.

headline: Cuban Youth Wait for Change to Filter Down to Their Lives

So after a California woman asked Phillip Injeian, a violinmaker and dealer, to appraise the instrument, he met her at a Manhattan hotel in late June and examined every inch of it, from its nicks to the somewhat pointy curve of its F-holes to its distinctive wood grain, before delivering his verdict.

text: Good morning on this sparkling Thursday.

headline: Did Jon Stewart Have a Serious Lesson for Journalists?
text: Can mainstream journalists learn anything from Jon Stewart’s approach, or from comedic news shows in general?

headline: Search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 to Continue Off Australia
text: SYDNEY, Australia — The search for a missing Malaysian jet in waters off Australia’s western coast will continue as planned, Australia’s prime minister said on Thursday, hours after his Malaysian counterpart announced that a wing part found thousands of miles away was the first confirmed debris from the Boeing 777.

headline: U.S. and Russia to Back U.N. Vote on Chemical Attacks in Syria
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — The United States and Russia will support a United Nations Security Council resolution to identify the perpetrators of attacks using chlorine and other chemical agents in Syria, Secretary of State John Kerry said Thursday.

headline: Morning Agenda: Activist Investors Build Their Stakes
text: ACTIVIST INVESTORS BUILD THEIR STAKES | William A. Ackman has built up a $5.5 billion stake in Mondelez International, the maker of Oreo cookies and Cadbury chocolate, Alexandra Stevenson reports in DealBook. His $20 billion hedge fund, Pershing Square Capital Management, is betting on consolidation in the food industry with its 7.5 percent stake.

headline: Today in Politics: Republicans Gather Under the Lights to Talk Amongst Themselves
text: Good Thursday morning from Washington as Cleveland bustles with preparations for the first debates of the 2016 election season. Fox News moderators are looking to keep the top 10 candidates on their toes as they wrangle in prime-time, while the seven other candidates will have their say hours earlier. For each group, the preseason is over.

headline: Major Issues for Chinese Leaders to Tackle in Beidaihe, if They Meet
text: Read in Chinese | 点击查看本文中文版

headline: Ice Cube Might Have Dinner With the President
text: In a trailer for ‘‘Straight Outta Compton,’’ the N.W.A. biopic that you co-produced, you say a lot of people don’t realize that your music was a form of nonviolent protest. Is that because the nonviolent part wasn’t very clear? I think it’s very clear. We put our frustrations on a record, and we were creative. We didn’t make a Molotov cocktail; we didn’t loot no buildings or burn ’em down or none of that. All we did was make music.

headline: Suez Canal Upgrade May Not Ease Egypt’s Economic Journey
text: CAIRO — “Egypt Rejoices,” the television networks and newspapers declared, announcing “Egypt’s gift to the world.” Businesses were closed, the streets of Cairo were empty, and the airwaves were full of patriotic songs and music videos — all featuring adoring images of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi interspersed with footage of cargo sailing toward the sea.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: ‘The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock’
text: My first hours with the spiky words of T.S. Eliot’s ‘‘The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock’’ are fixed in a precise location: the cluttered space of my teenage bedroom floor. It’s 1982. The light is low. The parquet tiles are coming unglued. Album covers — Talking Heads, David Bowie, the Clash — fan out around me, and an array of paperbacks sprawl among a week’s discarded clothes. I begin to read: ‘‘Let us go then, you and I,/When the evening is spread out against the sky/Like a patient etherized upon a table’’ — and, with a 17-year-old’s sense of imminent upheaval, feel the stirrings of a new language in me, connected to my own language but having passed through fire. I can’t say whether the voice the poem puts in my head as it extends its opening invitation is stiffly formal, smarmy or seductive. ‘‘Spread yourself out on the floor,’’ it seems to whisper, ‘‘and prepare to be turned inside-out.’’

headline: Out of the Woods
text: Several years ago, David Withers, a zoologist with the Tennessee Department of Environment and Conservation, was digging for crayfish in some creek beds on the edge of DeKalb County, in an area that can plausibly be described as nowhere at all, when he spotted an unmarked road. He had never noticed it and decided to see where it led; after a short drive, he found himself amid a strange encampment. Withers stepped out of his truck and looked around. Cheerful, rickety houses sprouted from the ground like unclassified fungi, or something dreamed up by Lewis Carroll, but what appealed to him most was the barn; on the side, in large yellow letters, someone had written ‘‘Welcome Home.’’ Withers walked up to a shack that appeared to be inhabited and — overtaken by curiosity — he knocked. The woman who came out looked surprised. She told him that he was on a commune for gay, lesbian and transgender people and suggested politely that he leave. Later, Withers called his friend Neal Appelbaum, the openly gay director of the arts center in neighboring Cannon County, and told him about what he saw. Appelbaum explained that Withers had stumbled into Ida, a commune for queer vegetarians; the entire region was home to maybe a dozen rural planned communities for L.G.B.T.Q. people, a kind of sexually nonconforming Amish country. He also pointed out that the fading sign on the barn didn’t say ‘‘Welcome Home.’’ The last letter was not an ‘‘e’’ but an ‘‘o.’’

headline: Victims of Hiroshima Bombing Honored
text: Cicadas shrilled and a peace bell rang as a crowd near the Peace Memorial remembered those who died after the atomic bombing of the city 70 years ago.

headline: CF Industries to Acquire Businesses From OCI for $8 Billion
text: LONDON — The American fertilizer maker CF Industries said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire several European and North American operations and a global distribution business from OCI of the Netherlands for $8 billion, including debt.

headline: 4 Palestinians Are Killed by Leftover Explosive in Gaza War’s Rubble
text: GAZA CITY — Four Palestinians from one extended family were killed and more than 40 others were wounded on Thursday after military ordnance exploded in Gaza as residents cleared the rubble of their homes a year after the war with Israel.

headline: Review: ‘The Gift,’ a Stalker Thriller That Isn’t What It Seems
text: Even if “The Gift,” the Australian director Joel Edgerton’s creepy stalker thriller, didn’t make a dramatic U-turn at around the halfway point, it would still rank as a superior specimen. This movie doesn’t foam at the mouth like “Fatal Attraction.” No bunnies are boiled. But fish are poisoned, a family dog goes missing and the soundtrack is tricked out with the sudden jolts dear to the genre. Any revenge is more pitiable than cathartic.

headline: At Katmai National Park in Alaska, Bears Rule
text: Katmai National Park sprawls over four million acres in southern Alaska. So why does its only established campground allow for just 60 people per night — a limit that leads to an online booking fray every January? The answer is also one of the park’s main draws, and its primary claim to national fame: bears. Lots of them — about 2,200 at the National Park Service’s last count, with 60 or so regulars that hang around Brooks Camp every summer. In theory, you can camp elsewhere in Katmai, but the campground has an electric fence and constant activity, making it an unlikely place to find a bear too close to your tent for sleeping comfort.

headline: 1965: Voting Rights Act Passed
text: WASHINGTON — President Johnson today [Aug. 6] signed into law federal voting rights legislation which he said will ‘‘fuse and blend … the Negro story and the American story.’’ He said his administration will move immediately to enforce it in the Deep South. After his address, Mr. Johnson walked to the ornate ‘‘President’s Room’’ in the Senate, where 104 years ago Abraham Lincoln signed a law freeing slaves impressed into war service by the Confederacy. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 7, 1965

headline: Broadcasting From the Bedroom
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Three Coca-Cola Bottlers in Europe Agree to Merger
text: LONDON — Three Coca-Cola bottlers in Europe said on Thursday that they had agreed to combine their businesses to form the world’s largest independent bottler of Coca-Cola products.

headline: New York Times Co. Reports $16 Million Profit
text: The New York Times Company reported net income of more than $16 million for the second quarter on slightly lower revenue, as digital growth and cost declines offset a continued drop in print advertising across the industry.

headline: Malaysia’s Declarations on Flight 370 and Plane Debris Further Dent Its Credibility
text: HONG KONG — Malaysia’s handling of the discovery of a wing part that apparently came from the missing Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777 has worsened frictions with its partners in the investigation, rekindled frustrations among the families of people who were aboard the plane and further dented the country’s battered credibility.

headline: At Least 15 Die at Saudi Mosque from Suicide Bomber
text: ISTANBUL — A suicide bomber killed at least 15 people on Thursday, including 12 members of a Saudi police force, when he detonated explosives in a mosque in southern Saudi Arabia, the state news agency there reported.

headline: Press Play
text: Press Play is the place where The New York Times debuts noteworthy new music.

headline: The Uber-ization of Activism
text: The nasty battle between Uber and the administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio over New York City’s proposed cap on livery vehicles has ended, at least for now, with the city and the ride-hailing giant agreeing to postpone a decision pending a “traffic study.” There’s no doubt who won, though. The mayor underestimated his opponent and was forced to retreat.

headline: A Small Kansas Town Relishes Its History
text: Families return to Nicodemus each year to reconnect with their ancestors and with one another, in a town established by freed slaves in 1877.

headline: Descendants Keep Alive Legacy of 1877 Black Settlement in Kansas
text: NICODEMUS, Kan. — Riding a red lawn mower down Washington Avenue in her hometown’s annual parade, Bertha Carter, 82, shielded herself from the sun with a white cowboy hat, and dispatched giant mosquitoes with an electronic swatter.

headline: WME-IMG Unveils a New York Fashion Week Makeover
text: It’s going to be logos-a-gogo at New York Fashion Week come September.

headline: Johanna Quandt, Matriarch of Family That Controls BMW, Dies at 89
text: FRANKFURT — Johanna Quandt, the matriarch of the family that controls the automaker BMW and one of the wealthiest people in Germany, died on Monday in Bad Homburg, Germany. She was 89.

headline: Young Conservatives Press Republican Presidential Debaters on Energy Policy
text: A few hundred yards from the Cleveland arena where Fox News invited the top-ranked Republican presidential candidates to debate, several hundred young conservatives will gather for an unusual party — “an epic Republican evening” celebrating and promoting energy policy reforms that are anathema to most of those who’ll be onstage.

headline: Afghan Army Helicopter Crashes, Killing All 17 Aboard
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — An Afghan National Army helicopter crashed in southern Afghanistan on Thursday, killing all 17 people aboard, government officials said.

headline: Daily Report: Google and the Spread of the ‘Right to Be Forgotten’
text: If you thought the so-called right to be forgotten was limited to Europe, think again.

headline: Everyone Wants to Hit Something
text: People are boxing for fitness — without ever taking a punch — in increasing numbers. Follow three men through their workouts at three New York City gyms.

headline: The New Workout: Boxing Without the Bruises
text: For the last two years, Raymond Wilburg, 27, has been training hard at Gleason’s Gym in Brooklyn. At first, it was for fitness. “It’s therapeutic,” he said. “All of the world’s problems, whatever I have outside of the boxing gym, it just falls away.”

headline: No Comment Necessary: A Debate and an Anniversary
text: On August 6, 1965, Lyndon Johnson signed the Voting Rights Act, which barred states from enacting any provision aimed at restricting citizens’ right to vote on the basis of race.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: A Knife in the Ear
text: The Challenge: Can you figure out why a middle aged man developed an earache and pupils of different sizes?

headline: Jon Stewart, From Parody to Politics
text: As Mr. Stewart nears the end of his 16-year tenure on the “Daily Show,” here is a look back at how he has transformed it into a satirical mainstay that is now part of the political establishment.

headline: Sisi Unveils Suez Canal Extension
text: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt traveled on the Suez Canal on Thursday to the city of Ismailia, where he unveiled a new extension to the canal.

headline: At Hiroshima’s 70th Anniversary, Japan Again Mourns Dawn of Atomic Age
text: HIROSHIMA, Japan — Every year on Aug. 6, Hiroshima becomes a city of mourning. And one full of reminders — some delivered politely, some pointedly — of the most extreme dangers of modern warfare.

headline: The Choreographer Matthew Neenan of BalletX Nears the Stratosphere
text: PHILADELPHIA — A few weeks back, the lobby of the Wilma Theater here took on the aspect of a cheap Hawaiian resort. Polynesian music twanged from speakers. Everyone who entered was offered a paper-flower lei. This was not a visit from a hula troupe. This was a gala performance of the Wilma’s resident contemporary ballet company, BalletX. And yet the atmosphere made complete sense, if only in combination with a more incongruous fact: The ballet on the program was about a signal incident in the history of airmail.

headline: Teenagers Leading Happy, Connected Lives Online
text: Where is the doom and gloom?

headline: Relaxed Parisian Style
text: Select pieces from the brand Cristasaya.

headline: Cinemark Rejects Paramount’s Plan to Rush Movie Releases
text: LOS ANGELES — Paramount Pictures has failed to get two of the nation’s three largest theater chains on board with an effort to shorten the length of time it takes for new wide-release movies to become available to watch at home.

headline: Bartenders Whip Up Fringe Cocktails
text: Del Pedro, the managing partner of Tooker Alley, a bar in Brooklyn, pours an ounce and a half of tequila into a glass. He follows that with some genever, the malty Dutch gin. Then it really gets weird.

headline: What to Do This Weekend
text: Looking for something fun to do?

headline: Stage Scenes: Sherie Rene Scott
text: A look at some of the actress’s past stage roles, from “Rent” to “Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown.”

headline: In ‘Whorl Inside a Loop,’ Prisoners’ Fingerprints in Tales of Inmate Lives
text: In the spring of 2011, the librettist Dick Scanlan and the Broadway actress Sherie Rene Scott woke up early and drove a few hours upstate to the Woodbourne Correctional Facility in New York, a medium-security prison in Sullivan County. They’d already been fingerprinted and tested for tuberculosis. They’d selected clothing that wouldn’t trigger the metal detectors.

headline: Apple Music Attracts 11 Million Users in Trial Period, Executive Says
text: Apple Music, the company’s new streaming service, attracted 11 million people for its trial period in a little more than a month, a top executive said.

headline: Teenagers Keep and Make Friends Online, Pew Says
text: Researchers say they have discovered something that teenagers already know: Young people use the Internet to maintain friendships made at school or work, but also to forge entirely new ones with peers they meet while browsing social networks like Instagram or playing a game like Call of Duty.

headline: Czech Company, Pressing Hits for Years on Vinyl, Finds It Has Become One
text: LODENICE, Czech Republic — He was a businessman, not a clairvoyant. Zdenek Pelc did not really foresee, a generation ago, that vinyl records would one day make a return from near extinction.

headline: Among the States, Self-Driving Cars Have Ignited a Gold Rush
text: Whether it is fuel savings, safer commutes or freed-up time behind the wheel, motorists have many reasons to embrace self-driving cars.

headline: Making Every Vote Count
text: The Voting Rights Act, which marks its 50th anniversary this week, was meant to end one of the quieter ways black people have been held back from equal participation in American life. If half a century later, new laws are still being passed intended to create arcane impediments to their voting, it’s still a landmark of the civil rights movement worth celebrating – and one that’s still vitally important to explain to children. Two new picture books do that through moving narratives of an older generation’s struggles.

headline: Detroit Boy, 11, Charged With Manslaughter in Shooting of 3-Year-Old
text: An 11-year-old Detroit boy has been charged with manslaughter in the fatal shooting of a 3-year-old, the first such case that a prosecutor could recall involving a suspect so young.

headline: 1940: Ministers Ponder Actor’s Trip
text: LONDON — Parliament today [Aug. 6] buckled down to discussing Noel Coward and Miss Gracie Fields and how they got away to America. Coward, actor and all-round entertainer, was the subject of a question put by a Conservative. On what mission, he asked, was Mr. Coward engaged by his majesty’s government? Harold Nicolson, Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Information, replied that Coward had gone with the approval of Prime Minister Winston Churchill. Another member said feeling was rising that ‘‘if a man has a certain amount of publicity value and money he can get out of this country when the country is going through a period of great stress and anxiety?’’ — New York Herald Tribune, August 7, 1940

headline: Brooklyn Getting a New Jazz Festival at BRIC House
text: A new jazz festival will take root in downtown Brooklyn this fall. The first BRIC JazzFest will take place Oct. 11 to 16 at BRIC House, the recently renovated contemporary arts center in Fort Greene. The festival will be a highlight of fall programming for BRIC, which also presents Celebrate Brooklyn! at the Prospect Park Bandshell.

headline: A Parisian Lifestyle Brand That Combines Art With Slouchy Sweaters
text: “We are against the fashion system … we were bored with fashion and trends and the change every season,” says Cristina Casini, co-founder of the Parisian lifestyle brand CristaSeya. Instead, Casini and her partner, Keiko Seya, release “editions” — of 12 to 15 items — every six months. “We wanted to do something that would be timeless, using the best materials — pieces that you can keep for a long time,” Casini says.

headline: Tougher Standards Set for U.S. Visa Waivers, Citing Militant Threat
text: WASHINGTON — The Department of Homeland Security has toughened air travel requirements on foreign governments in response to what it believes is the growing threat from fighters who have gone to Syria and Iraq to join the Islamic State and other groups, senior American officials said Thursday.

headline: Police Video From N. Carolina Shooting
text: A portion of the dashboard camera video released by the Charlotte Police Department on Wednesday shows Jonathan Ferrell moments before he was shot by Officer Randall Kerrick.

headline: IBM Adds Medical Images to Watson, Buying Merge Healthcare for $1 Billion
text: IBM is adding medical images to the health data its Watson artificial-intelligence can mine to help doctors make diagnoses.

headline: Natalia Molchanova Was Teaching Divers When She Vanished, Son Says
text: The champion free diver Natalia Molchanova was giving private instruction to at least two inexperienced divers Sunday when she failed to surface from a dive, her son said Thursday.

headline: The Weitz Brothers Help Each Other Through Hollywood Hits and Misses
text: LOS ANGELES — The filmmaking brothers Paul and Chris Weitz, who have had their movie hits and misses since breaking through with the blockbuster 1999 teen sex comedy “American Pie,” had childhoods that resemble something out of a movie made by their friend Wes Anderson.

headline: Pennsylvania Attorney General, Kathleen Kane, Charged in Leak Case
text: A prosecutor filed criminal charges on Thursday against Pennsylvania’s attorney general, Kathleen G. Kane, in a convoluted tale of political maneuvering and retribution that threatens the career of an official who was seen until recently as one of her state’s rising stars.

headline: What’s That Bubble? A Dying Star’s Glowing Remains
text: A new picture of the Southern Owl Nebula was captured by the Very Large Telescope in Chile.

headline: Viacom’s Weak Results Pile On More Bad News for TV Industry
text: It is no more than a coincidence that Viacom announced weak earnings and suffered a sharp plunge in its stock on the same day that one of its biggest stars, Jon Stewart, exited the stage.

headline: Texas Watchdog Group Calls Another Political Titan to Account
text: McKINNEY, Tex. — When Attorney General Ken Paxton of Texas was booked at the county jail here Monday on felony fraud charges, he joined some pretty high-powered company, including Tom DeLay, the former House majority leader, and former Gov. Rick Perry, as powerful Texas officials indicted while in office over the last decade.

headline: Review: In ‘The Diary of a Teenage Girl,’ a Hormone Bomb Waiting to Explode
text: Minnie Goetze, the 15-year-old heroine of “The Diary of a Teenage Girl,” is a would-be cartoonist who, despite her first name, is closer in lusty spirit and scratchy pen to Robert Crumb than to Walt Disney. When, partway through this gutsy, exhilarating movie, she draws her first cartoon, it’s of a bodacious female colossus striding across San Francisco. As this inky giant keeps on trucking, she evokes the 50-foot-woman of cult film fame, if one that has received a Crumb makeover, with thighs as mighty as giant sequoias and a bottom that rolls like a ship in a storm.

headline: What We Learned From German Prisons
text: EARLIER this summer, we led a delegation of people concerned about the United States criminal justice system to visit some prisons in Germany and observe their conditions. What we saw was astonishing.

headline: Russia Destroys Piles of Banned Western Food
text: MOSCOW — Ramping up enforcement of a ban on European food imports, the Russian authorities on Thursday destroyed hundreds of tons of foodstuffs they said violated the proscription, instituted a year ago in retaliation for Western sanctions over Ukraine.

headline: Form for Drug Dealers to Snitch on Competitors Results in an Arrest
text: When the sheriff in Franklin County, Ky., posted a flier on Facebook asking local drug dealers to snitch on their competition, the response was more than a little incredulous.

headline: Salesforce Ventures and Microsoft Join Informatica Buyout
text: SAN FRANCISCO — As Informatica closes its $5.3 billion sale to private equity on Thursday, the enterprise software maker will count two of its big technology partners as new investors as well.

headline: Hiplife, a Sound Imported From Ghana, Arrives on a New York Stage
text: When Evans Appiah moved to the Bronx from Ghana at age 8, he was teased for his accent. As a way of fitting in, he learned to rap. By the time he got to Middle School 391 on Webster Avenue, his friends were calling him “Lighter” because he rapped so fast and furious in English that it sounded as if he were spitting fire.

headline: A Millennial’s Guide to Kissing
text: After a stranger on an international flight delivers the perfect kiss, a college student weighs the possibilities of romance.

headline: As China Reduces Local Spending, Cities Woo Private Investors
text: HONG KONG — The wide new boulevards that cut across parts of Weifang in eastern China are largely free of traffic, a quiet reminder of the coastal city’s big ambitions.

headline: Charges Announced Against Kathleen Kane
text: Risa Vetri Ferman, the district attorney for Montgomery county, Pa., said on Thursday that the state’s attorney general, Kathleen G. Kane, is being charged with leaking information to the media.

headline: Welcome, Small Pigs
text: Demonstrating once again that the only things more appealing than charismatic megafauna are miniature charismatic megafauna, the Prospect Park Zoo has added three adorable faces to its menagerie.

headline: Facebook Joins the Live-Streaming Crowd With a Service for Celebrities
text: Facebook has joined the live-stream-video scene — but so far, it’s only for famous people.

headline: What Dad Should Do About the Brat Pack
text: I am a 65-year-old man, vigorous and still working. I divorced 20 years ago when I came out as a gay man. After years of dating, I find myself in love with a man in his early 20s who loves me back. We have been dating for a couple of years. I do not support him financially; he is not in my will. But my three adult children, all married, find the age difference impossible to accept. I was their primary caretaker, and we have always been close. I don’t want a rift. How to proceed?

headline: California Burning: Photographer’s Notebook
text: The Rocky fire is the largest of several fires currently burning in California. It has consumed 68,000 acres, or an area of a little more than 106 square miles, forcing thousands of residents from their homes. It has burned 91 structures including 39 homes in a very rural area near Clearlake that encompasses parts of Lake, Yolo and Colusa Counties. Since the fire began last Wednesday, about 3,500 firefighters have battled it. As of 7 a.m. on Aug. 6, it was 40 percent contained and the cause of the blaze was unknown.

headline: For Vaccines Needed in an Epidemic, Timing Is Everything
text: Last year, scientists launched a trial of an experimental vaccine against Ebola in Guinea. On Friday, they reported great news: The vaccine works well, providing remarkable protection just 10 days after injection.

headline: Fox Failed Statistics in Explaining Its G.O.P. Debate Decision
text: Will Rick Perry miss the main Republican debate Thursday night because he’s unpopular or because he’s unlucky? This turns out to be a far more difficult question that you might realize, and it’s one that apparently eludes the Fox News decision desk.

headline: Jemera Rone, Investigator Who Bared Human Rights Abuses, Dies at 71
text: Jemera Rone, who abandoned a legal career on Wall Street in her 40s to focus instead on exposing and redressing human rights violations in El Salvador and Sudan, died on July 29 in Washington. She was 71.

headline: The Hosts Are Wild, So Keep Your Distance
text: About 2,200 bears reside at Katmai National Park in Alaska, with 60 or so regulars that hang around Brooks Camp every summer.

headline: Ledecky Gains Relay Gold; Lochte Wins 200 I.M.
text: KAZAN, Russia — For four days at the world championships, Katie Ledecky hauled the weight of the United States’ sterling swimming reputation by herself. While New Zealand, Chile, Jamaica and Iceland put athletes in individual finals, the American team, which had won 182 gold medals in the previous 15 world championship meets, saw only Ledecky rise to the very top.

headline: The Speech That Defined the Fight for Voting Rights in Congress
text: Fifty years ago today, on Aug. 6, 1965, President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Voting Rights Act, which effectively ended centuries of black disenfranchisement by banning barriers to minority voting like the poll tax and the poll test, as I detailed in the magazine’s Aug. 2 cover story. At the signing ceremony, Johnson called the Voting Rights Act “a triumph for freedom as huge as any victory that has ever been won on the battlefield.”

headline: Follow Debate Day Coverage on The Times’s Live Blog
text: Times reporters are posting on the Republican debates and the runup to the events on the live blog.

headline: Does America Still Believe in Diplomacy?
text: President Obama has never seemed so sure-footed on foreign policy as now, when he is battling against determined opponents to persuade the American public and Congress on the merits of the Iran nuclear deal.

headline: Lively Morgue Tumblr 549 — 553
text: Lively Morgue Tumblr 549 — 553

headline: King Coal, Long Besieged, Is Deposed by the Market
text: In April 2005, President George W. Bush hailed “clean coal” as a key to “greater energy independence,” pledging $2 billion in research funds that promised a new golden age for America’s most abundant energy resource.

headline: Rebuilding Around Tina Charles Puts Liberty in Playoff Hunt
text: A Liberty season that began with an off-court to-do over the hiring of Isiah Thomas as team president has turned into a great one on the basketball court. The Liberty sit on top of the W.N.B.A.’s Eastern Conference at 13-6. If the team maintains that .684 winning percentage over its final 15 games, it will finish with the best record in franchise history.

headline: Review: ‘Fantastic Four,’ the Reboot (Wanted or Not)
text: The opening scenes of “Fantastic Four” — 20th Century Fox’s reboot of its Marvel superhero franchise — take place in 2007, which happens to be the year that the second movie in the prerebooted franchise (“Rise of the Silver Surfer”) was released. Ben Grimm and Reed Richards (played as children by Evan Hannemann and Owen Judge, later by Jamie Bell and Miles Teller) don’t mention that fact, because if they did the cinematic universe would collapse on itself and all light would be extinguished from the cosmos. Also, the thoughtful people at Fox probably don’t want to remind anyone of those earlier movies.

headline: Soul-Searching in Israel After Bias Attacks on Gays and Arabs
text: JERUSALEM — On one edge of the Zion Square gathering, an Orthodox yeshiva student was in heated debate with a secular couple over the hierarchy of sin. On the other, young men wearing skullcaps rocked back and forth, reciting the evening prayer. In between, people sat cross-legged on the cobblestones amid an array of memorial candles and banners decrying violence, promoting love, demanding change.

headline: In South Sinai With One-third of Three as Four
text: The Israel-born designer Adi Gil remembers family trips to South Sinai in the ’70s, before Egypt secured the area. Recently, she’s started spending time there again — though the present-day peninsula bears little resemblance to the crowded South Sinai from her childhood photo albums. Still, it remains “beautiful and surreal,” says Gil, one-third of the brand Three as Four. “It all depends on how you look at it — and who is looking at it. When it comes to the Middle East, sometimes I feel that the media likes to magnify the negative. We know there are issues in North Sinai. But next door there is beauty, and no one is talking about that.”

headline: Video Is Released From 2013 North Carolina Police Shooting of Jonathan Ferrell
text: A police dashboard camera video from the shooting death of a black man in North Carolina in 2013 has been made public as part of the trial of the police officer accused of killing him.

headline: 18-Year-Old Sentenced to Five Years for Robbing Man, 84, She Met on Dating Site
text: A teenager who with her twin sister robbed an octogenarian they met on an Internet dating site was sentenced on Thursday to five years in prison.

headline: In North Dakota, Boom, Bust and Oil
text: On U.S. 2 in North Dakota, just west of the turnoff for Tioga, you will spot two little brown highway signs pointing left:

headline: Chenin Blanc Makes an Audacious U.S. Return
text: After 20 years in which the repertoire of American winemakers seemed to have dwindled to a half-dozen grapes, endlessly repeated, the last decade has been one of intrepid exploration. Myriad grapes once deemed unworthy or too esoteric have been rediscovered and revived by winemakers seeking to make fresh, lively wines that are simply delicious to drink nightly, rather than ponderous wines aiming for trophies.

headline: Boom, Bust and Oil
text: On the byways of northwest North Dakota, a richly historic past meets the oil-fueled present.

headline: Review: ‘We Believe the Children,’ on Child Abuse Hysteria in the 1980s
text: From 1987 to 1990, in the longest criminal trial in American history, prosecutors tried to prove that Virginia McMartin, who owned a preschool in Manhattan Beach, Calif., and other school employees, including her daughter and grandson, had raped or abused 13 children, taken pornographic pictures of them and forced them to watch the mutilation of animals.

headline: Macedonia Arrests 9 Suspected of Having Ties to ISIS
text: SKOPJE, Macedonia — Macedonian officials announced Thursday that nine people had been arrested and that 27 more were being sought in a crackdown on citizens who traveled to the Middle East to fight alongside the Islamic State group or who helped recruit fighters for it.

headline: In Chicago, Lincoln, Copernicus and Shakespeare Have Something to Say to You
text: If a public sculpture in a large American city could talk, what would it say, besides complaining about pigeons and benign neglect? In Chicago, beginning Thursday, residents are finding out with the help of prominent writers and performers, as part of a program started by the British arts organization Sing London, and supported in Chicago by the Richard H. Driehaus Foundation.

headline: Humpty Dumpty Deal-Making
text: Some of the finest minds in finance seem to have missed the lesson of the nursery rhyme “Humpty Dumpty”: All the king’s horses and all the king’s men couldn’t put that character together again.

headline: Pakistan Army Helicopter Crashes, Killing 12
text: PAKISTAN — At least 12 people aboard a Pakistani Army helicopter were killed Thursday in northwestern Pakistan, a military spokesman said. They included a team of army doctors, paramedics, two pilots and crew. Officials said they were trying to determine the cause of the crash and suspected weather conditions to be responsible. The helicopter, carrying medical supplies, took off from Rawalpindi and was headed toward Gilgit, which has been affected recently by floods.

headline: ‘Crucible’ Revival, With Whishaw and Okonedo, Sets Broadway Opening
text: As the 100th anniversary of Arthur Miller’s birth approaches, Broadway is doubling down on two of his most produced plays this season.

headline: In Papua, Indonesia, a Visit to the Welcoming Dani People
text: The thatched-roof homes of Wesagalep lay at cloud level, high above the Baliem Valley in Papua, the Indonesian side of the island of New Guinea. They are built on about six terraced levels of the mountain, with startling views of the valley and down to the rushing river below.

headline: With Deadline Deals, Blue Jays Load Up on Optimism
text: TORONTO — Paul Molitor rounded the bases just ahead of Joe Carter on that electrifying night of Oct. 23, 1993. He felt the roar that pulsated inside the Skydome when he scored the winning run on Carter’s homer, giving the Toronto Blue Jays their second consecutive World Series title.

headline: Creator and Fans Hit It Lucky With ‘Hamilton’
text: Three hours before the 5 p.m. Broadway opening night of his hip-hop musical “Hamilton,” Lin-Manuel Miranda paid emotional tribute to the biography, and the life, that inspired his work.

headline: A Home of One’s Own in Notting Hill
text: The West London district of Notting Hill famously attracts visitors to its pastel-colored rows of houses, sprawling Portobello Road Antiques Market and Europe’s biggest street festival — and yet has always, until now, lacked sumptuous places to stay. On the south side of the secluded Pembridge Gardens, just seconds from Notting Hill Gate station (and a mere 15-minute hop to the hubbub of Soho), a row of five stucco Victorian mansions have recently been transformed into what is now the Laslett hotel.

headline: New York Ordering Tests of Water-Cooling Towers Amid Legionnaires’ Outbreak
text: New York City buildings with water-cooling towers must assess and disinfect the units within the next two weeks under an order issued on Thursday by health officials in response to the outbreak of Legionnaires’ disease in the South Bronx.

headline: Syrian Official’s Visit to Oman May Signal a Diplomatic Opening
text: Syria’s government sent a high-level delegation on Thursday to Oman, the Persian Gulf state that historically has helped broker negotiations in regional conflicts.

headline: Wait, He Plays for Them Now?
text: While Arsène Wenger never seems to go anywhere — he will begin his 20th season at Arsenal on Sunday — a host of prominent players joined, left or switched Premier League teams over the summer. Among the more notable moves you will notice starting this weekend:

headline: Top Hillary Clinton Donor Comes Out Against Iran Deal
text: A top donor to Hillary Rodham Clinton expressed his opposition Thursday to the Obama administration’s agreement with Iran to curtail its nuclear program, calling it a “very bad deal.”

headline: For Mets Fans, First Is a Surprise. For Yankees Fans, It’s About Time.
text: After three emotion-filled days with the Mets at Citi Field last weekend, I was looking forward to going to the Bronx this week and watching the first-place Yankees during a six-game homestand against Boston and Toronto.

headline: Living With Cancer: Alone and Ghosted
text: When my husband, incapacitated by knee surgery, was placed in a rehabilitation facility, I lost my caregiver. Don can no longer drive me to the cancer center or undertake the chores he used to do for both of us, and he must consider his own overriding physical problems, not mine. With the good luck of my relatively stable physical condition, I struggle to meet our basic needs. However, an unluckier member of my support group found herself in dire circumstances after her partner traveled overseas on a business trip.

headline: 1945 | Witnessing the A-Bomb, but Forbidden to File
text: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

text: Joel Edgerton narrates a sequence from “The Gift,” featuring Rebecca Hall and Jason Bateman.

headline: ‘The Gift’ (With Movie Trailer): Joel Edgerton Narrates a Scene
text: For the “The Gift,” the actor Joel Edgerton goes behind the camera to direct a twist on the thriller genre, while also using some of its conventions. Jason Bateman and Rebecca Hall play Simon and Robin, a couple who have moved to a new town and are greeted and befriended by Gordo (Mr. Edgerton), an old classmate of Simon’s. The relationship the couple maintains with Gordo is uncomfortable at best.

headline: Shipping News
text: An old canal gets a new channel.

headline: The Coolest Look This Season: All That Came Before
text: From ’70s floral-print suits to ’40s-era net hats, from oversize shearlings to logo sweatshirts, the current, decade-spanning style of today alludes to the past.

headline: Things to Do in Westchester, Aug. 9 to 15, 2015

headline: Reducing Skyscraper Sway
text: Mass dampers are added to slender skyscrapers to reduce their sway in high winds.

headline: An N.W.A. Biopic Heads Straight Into Mainstream
text: N.W.A., the group that brought gangster rap to the mainstream, angering conservatives and the F.B.I. along the way, burned hot and fast. The core group as it’s remembered today — Dr. Dre, Ice Cube, Eazy-E, MC Ren, DJ Yella — was together for only about two years, and in total the group lasted for maybe five, from the late 1980s to early ’90s.

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: Aug. 7
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images of a projection on the Empire State Building, closing parishes and a wet walk with dry cleaning.

text: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews “The Fantastic Four.”

text: Elegant classics, a capsule collection from Nick Wooster, a minimalist bathing suit and more.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, Aug. 9 to 15, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Revisiting Ferguson and the Death of Michael Brown
text: Whitney Curtis returned to Ferguson, Mo., to see what has changed, and hasn’t, since police shot the teenager, setting off vigils and volatility.

headline: An Ecuadorean Horseman at Bemelmans Bar
text: Luis Serrano grew up in Ecuador with a love for horses and the idea that he would become a veterinarian. He ended up wearing the crisp red jacket at Bemelmans Bar, the Carlyle hotel’s elegant drinking spot on the Upper East Side, where he is currently the longest-tenured bartender, having served drinks there for 22 years.

headline: Review: ‘Holden’ Explores the Distance That Killing Requires
text: “Holden,” a new play written and directed by Anisa George, occupies a claustrophobic realm: a one-room cabin into which four intense men are crammed, bounded by slowly growing walls of chopped firewood.

headline: Review: In ‘Sneaky Pete’ and ‘Casanova,’ a Fast Talker and a Smooth Talker
text: Judging “Sneaky Pete,” which stars Giovanni Ribisi as a con man and recent ex-con hiding out in upstate New York, has a lot to do with context. As an Amazon pilot — it’s one of two, along with “Casanova,” going up on Friday — it looks kind of ordinary, surprisingly like a broadcast network drama. Semi-episodic, slightly procedural, light dusting of dark humor.

headline: Isabella Rossellini on Her Mother Ingrid Bergman’s Enduring Style
text: “This is how I look, take it or leave it,” said the Swedish film star Ingrid Bergman, perhaps the first natural actress of the Golden Era. (When the film producer David Selznick suggested a Hollywood makeover — change her name, pluck her eyebrows and fix her teeth — right before her debut in 1939, she refused.) This year, Bergman’s legacy will be honored in a centennial celebration opening at the Museum of Modern Art on her bittersweet birthday, Aug. 29, which is also the day she died at age 67 in 1982. The 14-film retrospective spans Bergman’s 50-year career, including her starring roles in “Casablanca” and Hitchcock’s “Notorious.”

headline: Why ‘Hamilton’ Has Heat
text: What’s the story behind a show that’s become a Broadway must-see with no marquee names, no special effects and almost no white actors? Erik Piepenburg explains, in six snapshots, why “Hamilton” has become such a big deal.

headline: Short Game
text: Whether they’re Boy Scout cargo-style or fashion-designer formal, nothing exposes a man to more judgment and ridicule than wearing shorts.

headline: Why Putting a Number to C.E.O. Pay Might Bring Change
text: It is a confounding truth about outsize executive pay — all past attempts to rein it in have failed.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Disorderly Conduct
text: James Draplin­‘s favorite things.

headline: ‘By the Sea’ Trailer Is Released, Featuring Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie Pitt
text: In the new Angelina Jolie Pitt film, there seems to be a lot less combat, but still plenty of suffering. After directing two tense movies set in wartime, Ms. Pitt has now written and directed the drama “By the Sea,” for which the teaser trailer was released today. She stars in it with her husband, Brad Pitt — their first on-screen pairing since “Mr. and Mrs. Smith” in 2007.

headline: The Jeter of Yankee Stadium Cameramen
text: As soon as Eric Capstick appeared in an upper deck of Yankee Stadium, camera on his shoulder, the fans began clamoring as if Derek Jeter had suddenly returned from retirement.

text: Aaron James Draplin

text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
text: Good evening. Here’s the latest.

headline: Studies of Nepal Quake Raise Concern About Skyscrapers
text: In April, as email alerts ricocheted with the news that a large earthquake had shaken Nepal near its capital, Kathmandu, experts somberly expected a toll comparable to the roughly 85,000 who died in 2005 when a smaller earthquake struck a more sparsely populated area in the Kashmir region.

headline: Review: ‘Ricki and the Flash’ Puts Meryl Streep Behind a Telecaster
text: “Ricki and the Flash,” a gentle-hearted baby boomer guilt-trip family drama directed by Jonathan Demme and written by Diablo Cody, is bookended by two musical performances from the rock ’n’ roll bar band that gives the movie its name. It would be a spoiler to say too much about the number that ends the movie, a Bruce Springsteen cover, but the opener, sung to a sparse, appreciative audience at a scruffy club in Tarzana, Calif., is a competent version of an old hit by Tom Petty. (If that name doesn’t ring a bell, go ask your dad.) Ricki, the lead singer, sporting a blue Telecaster, heavy eyeliner and half of Bo Derek’s haircut from “10” (ask your dad about that too), belts out the lyrics with perfect credibility, landing somewhere between Chrissie Hynde and Bonnie Raitt on the spectrum of available reference points.

headline: A Steve Jobs Opera Is Up Next for the Santa Fe Company
text: SANTA FE, N.M. — Just don’t call it iOpera. The Santa Fe Opera has announced that its next commissioned work will be “The (R)evolution of Steve Jobs,” with music by Mason Bates, known for combining electronic sounds and traditional instruments, and a libretto by Mark Campbell.

headline: Review: ‘Cold Mountain,’ at Santa Fe Opera, Recounts a Separated Lover’s Arduous Journey
text: SANTA FE, N.M. — It’s quite a ways from here to western North Carolina, where Charles Frazier set his 1997 novel, “Cold Mountain.” And it’s quite a different landscape out there, too.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Ricki and the Flash’
text: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews “Ricki and the Flash.”

text: France and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Brooks Brothers Discontinuing Black Fleece Collection
text: Devotees of Black Fleece, Thom Browne’s collection for Brooks Brothers, should hurry to stores to stock up. Claudio Del Vecchio, the Brooks Brothers chief executive, confirmed in a phone interview on Thursday that the Black Fleece line will be discontinued following the fall 2015 season, though he did not rule out the option of reviving it, potentially without Mr. Browne, in the future.

headline: August 6, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from France, United States, Macedonia and El Salvador.

headline: This Week’s Movies | August 7, 2015
text: The New York Times film critics review “Ricki and the Flash,” “Diary of a Teenage Girl” and “Fantastic Four.”

headline: Review: ‘Drawing Waves’ and ‘Borne Frieze,’ a Robin Rhode Twofer
text: For the South African artist Robin Rhode, drawing is never enough. He draws on gallery walls, then throws his body against the images he’s made, or drags his hands through the fresh chalk or charcoal. He draws in public places, in choreographed acts or in improvised, highly physical exertions. Drawing is not a stand-alone artistic medium; it forms part of a constellation of techniques, from performance to photography and video, which in turn informs a larger cluster of concerns, from his own childhood to the politics of urban space.

headline: A Facebook for Watch Geeks
text: Kevin Rose, the Digg founder and Silicon Valley wunderkind, remembers the pushback he got in young-tech circles when he started wearing his late father’s Rolex a few years ago.

headline: At Givenchy in Paris, Toughness and Light
text: The Givenchy men’s store in Paris shows off its mix of haute history and sharp detailing.

headline: 25 Years After Gardner Museum Heist, Video Raises Questions
text: BOSTON — In 1990, Richard Abath was a 23-year-old self-described hippie and guitarist for a rock band named Ukiah who, while moonlighting as a security guard, allowed two thieves posing as police officers to enter the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum here.

headline: ‘How Cats Took Over the Internet’ at the Museum of the Moving Image
text: WHILE it’s not true that 15 percent of all Internet traffic is cat-related, as the Friskies cat food company asserted in 2013, it does make a convincing urban legend.

headline: Review: Paintings by George Stubbs Travel to the Met
text: New York should be grateful that the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven is closed for renovations. As a result, eight canvases by the inimitable English painter George Stubbs, one of the great artists of the 18th century, have been lent to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Works by Stubbs are scarce in this town: The Met has one painting, and there’s a drawing at the Frick Collection. This makes “Paintings by George Stubbs From the Yale Center for British Art” a rare and thrilling treat.

headline: Elaine de Kooning and Andreas Gursky in Close-Up in the Hamptons
text: Decades before the East End in Long Island became a crowded mecca for summertime vacationers, the Hamptons and their neighboring villages were quiet, rural getaways for artists, from the American Impressionists of the late 19th and early 20th centuries to the Pop artists of the ’60s. Visual art still has a lively presence in the area, as viewers can discover at two of the region’s pre-eminent destinations.

headline: Heavy on Top
text: To keep skinny skyscrapers from swaying when high winds blow, giant counterweights are placed at the top. To get an idea of how much heft is required, consider the following equivalents.

headline: Review: ‘Call Me Lucky,’ About the Comedian-Activist Barry Crimmins
text: “Call Me Lucky,” Bobcat Goldthwait’s documentary portrait of his professional mentor, the political comedian Barry Crimmins, is an earnest homage that also honors Mr. Crimmins’s crusade to drive child pornography off the Internet.

headline: Review: Mostly Mozart, Highlighted by Sol Gabetta’s Haunting Vocalise
text: It was a good night Wednesday for avid followers of the Mostly Mozart festival. The main event was the concert of the festival orchestra in Avery Fisher Hall, featuring the New York debut of the young German conductor Cornelius Meister and the Mostly Mozart debut of the Argentine cellist Sol Gabetta. It was preceded by a recital from the piano duo Anderson & Roe in the hall and followed by a Little Night Music recital in the Kaplan Penthouse, performed by Ms. Gabetta and the pianist Ilya Yakushev.

headline: Daily Show Fans on Jon Stewart’s Legacy
text: Fans of the Daily Show waiting for the taping of Jon Stewart’s final episode share their thoughts on the host’s 16 years, and the legacy he leaves.

headline: As Egypt Unveils Its ‘New Suez Canal,’ Dissenters Make Voices Heard Online
text: As Egypt’s government congratulated itself on Thursday at the very grand opening of a new side channel to the Suez Canal, the reaction on social networks to the televised pageantry was divided between praise for President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi from his supporters and jeers from his critics.

headline: At Givenchy’s Men’s Shop in Paris, the Two Sides of Riccardo Tisci
text: There is a certain, redoubtable logic to fishing where the fish are. Thus, the Marais — Paris’s gay mecca, the rough equivalent in demography (if not style) of New York’s Chelsea or West Hollywood in Los Angeles — has lately been filling with designer stores catering to the stylish men who fill its streets. Along the Rue des Archives are men’s boutiques from Gucci, Fendi, Moncler and, at No. 13, Givenchy.

headline: Review: In ‘Cop Car,’ a Joyride by 2 Runaway Boys Takes a Wrong Turn
text: When the 10-year-old heroes of “Cop Car” first see the cruiser in question, it’s parked unattended in a field, ready to be plucked like a daisy. Travis (James Freedson-Jackson) and Harrison (Hays Wellford) make a fine pair of pipsqueaks, and they’re on a great journey when they find the car, having run away from home that same day. They have no real reason or complaint or plans, just a single piece of beef jerky and a boy’s own sense of adventure.

A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.★ Ben Allison Quintet (Tuesday through Aug. 15) Mr. Allison is a resourceful bassist, bandleader and composer, and for this run he celebrates the great jazz guitarist Jim Hall, who died in 2013. He’ll have excellent personnel for the task: the guitarist Steve Cardenas, the trumpeter Jeremy Pelt, the pianist Frank Kimbrough and the drummer Rudy Royston. At 8:30 and 11 p.m., Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, 212-581-3080, birdlandjazz.com. (Nate Chinen)

headline: Review: ‘Kahlil Gibran’s The Prophet’ Turns Essays Into a Family Movie
text: The burning question during my freshman year in college was whether “The Prophet,” a slim volume of poetic essays by the early-20th-century Lebanese writer and artist Kahlil Gibran, was more spiritually profound than Captain Beefheart’s seminal album, “Trout Mask Replica.” I still haven’t decided.

text: There are four audiences for the G.O.P. debate Thursday night — voters, donors, party leaders, media members — and they are not equal in importance.

text: 106 YEARS AGO
