headline: Great Jazz on the Great Hill, and Club Fare in Harlem and the Village
text: Jazz is as synonymous with New York City as the Empire State Building or the Statue of Liberty. On any given night, live jazz options abound for nearly all preferences and budgets.

headline: Review: ‘God Bless the Child’ Follows Neglected Siblings at Play
text: Directed by Robert Machoian and Rodrigo Ojeda-Beck, “God Bless the Child” poignantly illustrates what busy, tired parents have told bored offspring for years: You have to make your own fun. This extraordinary movie immerses us in the playtime of five California siblings abandoned to their own devices.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Aug. 7-13
text: Captain Mary’s Story Hour

headline: The ‘Green Book’ Legacy, a Beacon for Black Travelers
text: Starting in 1936, Victor Hugo Green, a letter carrier who lived in Manhattan, published the “Negro Motorist Green Book,” listing hotels, restaurants and other businesses where African-Americans would not only be welcome but also safe. The “Green Book” series rather diplomatically described Jim Crow-era experiences with racist business owners as “painful embarrassments suffered which ruined a vacation or business trip.”

headline: Antique Lacquered Furniture’s Odd Ingredients
text: Scientists have detected some surprising ingredients in pieces of lacquered furniture that will soon go on view at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston and the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam.

headline: Before Main Republican Debate, Bottom 7 Contenders Put On Brave Faces
text: CLEVELAND — They called it the undercard. The kiddie table. The happy hour debate.

headline: Buccaneers Offer Women a Modern N.F.L. Lesson Out of the ’50s
text: Well, this must be a relief for all the women out there who lose sleep during football season wondering, “What delicious snack can I whip up for this weekend’s N.F.L. games, and what is the appropriate (and possibly color-coordinated) handmade centerpiece to accompany it?”

headline: Review: ‘Homme Less’ Follows a Homeless Middle-Age Model-Photographer
text: Poignancy and pathos distinguish Thomas Wirthensohn’s polished documentary, “Homme Less,” a portrait of Mark Reay, a former model struggling as a photographer. The New Jersey-born Mr. Reay had a moment more than 20 years ago, posing for shoots in Europe. Now in his 50s, he entreats Marc Jacobs for work by leaving a photo of the designer at his office; talks women into posing for him on the street; and works as a day player on movie sets. But the title derives from Mr. Reay’s nightly shelter: an East Village rooftop, where he sleeps under a tarpaulin.

headline: Final Biker Is Sentenced in Assault on S.U.V. Driver
text: A state judge sentenced the last of the motorcyclists convicted of attacking a driver in Upper Manhattan to three and a half years in prison on Thursday after the defendant gave a tearful apology in court.

headline: The Washington Hostess Who Nurtured Warhol
text: Ina Ginsburg, the Washington patron of the arts and fund-raiser who died in November at 98, befriended some of the most powerful politicians and celebrities of her era. Famously, in 1975, she held a dinner for Andy Warhol at her house in Washington, despite warnings from some of her friends.

headline: Review: ‘The Runner’ Stars Nicolas Cage as a Politician After an Oil Spill
text: In “The Runner,” a political drama without much drama, Nicolas Cage plays a Louisiana congressman, Colin Pryce, whose personal choices — too much alcohol, an affinity for extramarital affairs — make him thoroughly unlikable and a walking cliché. It’s difficult to feel the sympathy for him that Austin Stark, who wrote and directed, wants us to feel.

headline: ‘Hamilton’
text: Scenes from the Broadway musical about the founding fathers.

headline: Review: ‘Assassination,’ With Twists and Hired Guns in 1930s Seoul and Shanghai
text: ASSASSINATION

headline: Review: In ‘Sneakerheadz,’ an Obsession Over Something More Than Footwear
text: Footwear enthusiasts left wanting by “The Rise of Sneaker Culture,” an exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum this summer, can continue exploring that snug niche in “Sneakerheadz,” an unrelated, fans-only documentary.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Hamilton’
text: The cast of the Broadway musical performing the number “The Schuyler Sisters.”

headline: Review: ‘Hamilton,’ Young Rebels Changing History and Theater
text: Yes, it really is that good.

headline: Missouri Governor Calls for Improved Police Training
text: Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri called on Thursday for improved training for law enforcement officers in his state, including more education on “fair and impartial policing” and helping mentally ill residents.

headline: Ackman Bets on Mondelez Going on Sale
text: By putting $5.5 billion into Mondelez International, a hedge fund billionaire is wagering that the company, which makes Oreos, Cadbury chocolates and Trident gum, could be prodded into selling itself.

headline: ‘On the Town’ to Close on Broadway
text: The Tony Award-nominated revival of the musical “On the Town” will end its Broadway run at the Lyric Theater on Sept. 6, the producers of the show announced on Thursday. The musical will go out with a big ballet bang: the ballerina Misty Copeland, who this summer became the first African-American woman to be named a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, will make her Broadway debut in the show for two weeks beginning on Aug. 25, replacing Megan Fairchild, for 12 performances through Sept. 6.

headline: 200 Migrants Are Believed Drowned in Capsizing Off Libya
text: CAIRO — About 200 migrants are believed to have drowned off the coast of Libya when their boat capsized, the United Nations refugee agency said Thursday.

headline: The Never-Ending Lawsuit Against 2 Former A.I.G. Executives
text: Charles Dickens invented the interminable estate dispute Jarndyce v. Jarndyce for “Bleak House,” his 1853 novel. In real life, the Federal Trade Commission once took 16 years to force Carter’s Little Liver Pills to drop the word “Liver.” And antitrust regulators spent 13 years on a case against IBM before the Reagan administration dropped it abruptly.

headline: As Temperatures Rise in Phoenix, Hikers Embrace Heat on a Grueling Ascent
text: PHOENIX — Summer has a smothering presence here, with its punishing triple-digit temperatures that turn parked cars into ovens so hot one can bake cookies on the dashboard. (Yes, it happens.) It triggers a modified hibernation — it is heat that keeps people indoors.

headline: George Cole, 90, British TV Star, Dies; Played a Young Scrooge in ’51 Film
text: George Cole, a British actor who as the young Scrooge foreshadowed Alastair Sim’s aging, coldhearted moneylender in a celebrated film version of “A Christmas Carol,” and who later developed a following as British television’s favorite rogue, died on Wednesday in Reading, England. He was 90.

headline: Letters: The Rediscovered Manuscript
text: To the Editor:

headline: Life or Death for Colorado Theater Gunman Now in Jurors’ Hands
text: CENTENNIAL, Colo. — After 15 weeks in court and testimony from more than 300 witnesses, lawyers in the trial of James E. Holmes rested their cases on Thursday. A jury will now decide whether to sentence him to death or to send him to life in prison without the possibility of parole.

headline: President Reflects on Voting Rights Act
text: At a White House event commemorating the 50th anniversary of the Voting Rights Act, President Obama said there were still “too many ways in which people are discouraged from voting.”

headline: Obama Urges Restoring Voting Rights Provisions
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama used the 50th anniversary of the Voting Rights Act on Thursday to urge Congress to restore key elements of the law, arguing that court decisions and state statutes that discourage “certain kinds of folks” from voting are threatening to erode the fundamental promise of the civil rights-era bulwark.

headline: A Troubled Jockey’s Full Legacy Is on Display
text: Natalie Jowett Antley does not know what she will say about her late husband, Chris Antley, when she speaks at the National Museum of Racing’s Hall of Fame on Friday. She has been worried more about how her daughter will hold up when the father who died before she was born will be recognized as one of the greatest jockeys of all time.

headline: $25,000 Fine Proposed in Taxi Driver’s Snub of Black Family
text: The taxi lurched away from the curb in Midtown Manhattan, leaving behind a black family of three who had flagged it down on their way to a birthday dinner 10 blocks away. The driver, Baqir Raza, told them he had to go off duty to use the bathroom, the family said, and then picked up two white women nearby and drove away.

headline: Connecticut to Require All 11th Graders to Take the SAT

headline: From an Unfussy New Orleans Cafe, a Summer Cobbler
text: Back in 2003, the Southern-born pastry chef Kelly Fields approached her boss, the beloved blue-eyed New Orleans chef and James Beard Award-winner John Besh, about opening a bakery. Then Hurricane Katrina hit, putting Fields’s plans on hold while the city picked itself back up again. At Besh’s urging, she traveled the world in the meantime, gathering culinary inspiration in Italy, Egypt and throughout the Middle East before settling back in New Orleans and holding the title of executive pastry chef at his culinary empire there. And finally this week, over a decade after she first conceived it, Fields opened the doors to Willa Jean, an unfussy corner bakery and cafe in the up-and-coming South Market District.

headline: Jon Stewart Signs Off From ‘Daily Show’ With Wit and Sincerity
text: After 16 years of taking satirical aim at the hypocrisy of politics and the fatuousness of the news media, Jon Stewart said goodbye to “The Daily Show” on Thursday evening with a farewell broadcast that mixed wry parting shots with earnest displays of emotion and with a passionate speech urging his audience not to accept falsehoods and misinformation in their lives.

headline: What’s On TV Friday
text: 10 P.M. (Starz Edge) FROZEN (2013) Warm up your vocal cords: This Disney movie musical produced “Let It Go,” the Oscar-winning power anthem written by the married songwriters Kristen Anderson-Lopez and Robert Lopez. Chris Buck and Jennifer Lee directed this fable about Elsa, above (the voice of Idina Menzel), an ice princess cursed with a frigid touch, and Anna (Kristen Bell), her younger sister and best friend. When Anna falls for a prince (Santino Fontana), Elsa forbids them to marry, casting their Scandinavian kingdom into eternal winter with a wave of her hand. Horrified, she retreats to an ice palace, but sibling love sends Anna plowing through drifts and up glacial ridges in search of Elsa, confident that she can reverse the spell. “Allegorically, ‘Frozen’ lacks the purity and elemental power of a classic myth like ‘Beauty and the Beast,’ but at least its storytelling is fairly coherent, and its gleaming dream world of snow and ice is one of the most visually captivating environments to be found in a Disney animated film,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times about this blockbuster, inspired by Hans Christian Andersen’s “The Snow Queen.”

headline: How to Project Power
text: ‘‘Keep your limbs away from your body,’’ says Deborah H Gruenfeld, a social psychologist who teaches at Stanford University. Some research shows that people posed in expansive postures feel more powerful, exhibit higher testosterone levels and have lower levels of the stress hormone cortisol — all characteristics of high-ranking social status. Make eye contact while you’re talking, but feel free to look away when others do. This is what scientists call having a high ‘‘look-speak to look-listen ratio,’’ which is common for dominant members of groups.

headline: ‘Written by Himself’
text: There is so much to pay attention to in this poem: the rich and varied allusions; the use of repetition at the beginnings and endings of its sentences; the rhythm in the making and breaking of its pattern; and the idea of a personal mythology, a song of the self that, in its expansiveness, might stand for us all.

headline: He’s Got Legs
text: Up above the hems of a proper pair of trousers — above the ankle-­baring ends of high-­waters and clam-­diggers, above the shin-­skimming edges of pants named for the isle of Capri and for the gauchos of the Pampas — are the knees. Bared by shorts, they point us toward a few truths about social standards. Women’s legs are tangled in their own sex-­segregated history of social control and gender politics; shorts are, first off, short pants, and it was not so very long ago that women were told wearing pants of any length was prima facie evidence of moral turpitude. The man in shorts, meanwhile, occupies a space that is more subtly strange. Year after year, as surely as tender spring yields to scalding summer, a season of dress-­code controversies gives way to a running conversation about the unwritten rules of urban spaces, with arbiters of taste cringing at men’s legs in shorts as if wincing at a comedy of embarrassment.

headline: Starring Vermouth
text: A few years ago, my brother asked me where I would like to spend my 40th birthday. I chose Spain, and he generously presented me with a plane ticket to Barcelona. I booked a sunny apartment with an abundance of colorful tiles. I got a ticket for an FC Barcelona match at Camp Nou. But in the weeks leading up to my birthday, my mother’s health declined precipitously. I couldn’t leave New York under the circumstances, and canceled the trip.

headline: Off the Road
text: I never thought I was a car guy until the day my little blue Toyota truck died. In fact, on some level, I had contempt for guys who cared too much about what they drove. Proof that I didn’t share their affliction, in my mind, was the fact that I had been driving the same beat-up base model Toyota pickup, with camper shell, for 23 years, ever since my father sold it to me for $4,000 in 1992.

headline: Yankees’ C. C. Sabathia Grows Older, Wiser and, at Least for a Night, Stronger
text: In his first few years with the Yankees, when his fastball hummed as reliably as it did on Thursday against the Boston Red Sox, C. C. Sabathia made pitching sound so easy. All he did, he would say after starts, was pound the zone.

headline: A Call to ‘Cry Out’ Against Cross Removals in China
text: Over the past year and a half, the government of Zhejiang Province has forcibly removed hundreds of crosses from churches, part of a campaign by the local authorities to lower the profile of Christianity in a region where it has made deep inroads. The campaign has long met with protests by parishioners, but now it is also being denounced by government-approved Christian organizations. In early July, official Protestant and Catholic associations issued open letters questioning the campaign’s legality.

headline: Presidential Debate Fashions: Windows Into a Candidacy
text: On Thursday night voters got their first look at the 10 current leading Republican candidates in comparison to one another — literally. Ever since Richard Nixon met John F. Kennedy on the small screen in 1960, there’s been little doubt that while it’s the substance of presidential debates that matters most, image and appearance can play a potentially significant role in swaying voter opinion (consciously or not). As a result, different schools of thoughts have developed on the best approach to the situation. The two most popular were on view last night, and like the candidates themselves, proved to have varying degrees of success.

headline: 1890: Electrical Execution Botched
text: NEW YORK — From one end of the country to the other there is nothing but expressions of indignation and horror at the method of Kemmler’s execution and a demand from all classes that it should be the last scene of such horrors. Two curious points have been developed. It is supposed that 1,700 volts were applied to Kemmler, but twenty incandescent test lamps were by mistake left burning, consuming fifty volts each, leaving only 700 volts for the death of Kemmler, which was not enough to cause instant death.

headline: In Katie Ledecky’s Amazing Feats, Echoes of a Swimmer From the 1970s
text: KAZAN, Russia — The 5-foot-11 teenage freestyler with the reserved personality and the swimming range of an albatross won every final at the world championships from the 200 meters through the 1,500, thrilling the crowds inside the stadium while gun-toting soldiers patrolled outside.

headline: The Republican Scrum Begins
text: My fantasy of the 2016 G.O.P. primary debate, regular readers may remember, involved a serious clash of ideas between Marco Rubio and Rand Paul, the two candidates who seemed — as of six months ago, at least — to be charting the most creative and interesting paths forward for a Republican Party that’s lost the popular vote in five of the last six presidential contests. My worst-case scenario, on the other hand, basically involved a replay of 2012 — an establishment candidate playing it as safe as possible while a group of would-be populists fought one another noisily but emptily for the chance to finish second.

headline: The Doorman’s Dilemma: What to Do With All Those Packages?
text: As president of the board of his Midtown East co-op, Dennis Paget has reason to walk a little faster when a particular fellow resident comes into view. To do otherwise would mean enduring yet another stern lecture about the building’s supposedly dilatory parcel delivery service.

headline: ‘Kitchens of the Great Midwest,’ by J. Ryan Stradal
text: “Larger than life” is usually a cliché, but in the case of Eva Thorvald — the 6-foot-2 mighty Aphrodite who strides through the pages of J. Ryan Stradal’s appealing first novel — the description is literally as well as metaphorically accurate. Born with a “once-in-a-generation palate,” Eva is a food prodigy. At 3½ months old, she destroys a vegetable stand in pursuit of a perfect heirloom tomato; at 10, she runs a cottage industry from her bedroom closet, growing chocolate habanero peppers so incendiary that her client, the city’s best Mexican restaurant, is forced to post a warning label on the menu; at 11, she earns extra cash from bar bets by consuming quantities of blistering chili and “Circle of Hell” chicken wings. Yet despite a life pockmarked by poverty and other adversities, Eva has an equally outsize heart. A warring mass of desires, talents and imperfections, she’s an attractively flawed, completely likable demigoddess.

headline: What Steve Jobs Taught Me About Being a Son and a Father
text: A couple of months ago, right after my first son was born, I thought about the lessons I wanted to pass along to him that I had learned a little late in life. Among the morals I scribbled down in my mind one that stood out began with a story involving Steve Jobs and ended with the serving of my mother’s last meal.

Cohen’s “Folk City.” This handsome book, which includes rarely seen photographs, reminiscences of participants and a lively narrative, adds depth to an exhibition of the same name on view at the Museum of the City of New York until January.

headline: Why a Boring Jobs Report Is Great News for the Fed

headline: Hugh Thomas’s ‘World Without End: Spain, Philip II, and the First Global Empire’
text: When did the modern age begin? There is no shortage of contenders — from the fall of Constantinople to Columbus’s arrival in the Americas to (my candidate) Vasco da Gama’s projection of European power into Asia. In “World Without End,” Hugh Thomas stakes a claim for one more: an obscure 1559 peace treaty between Philip II, the Hapsburg king of Spain, and Henry II, the Valois king of France, that concluded a decades-old struggle for control of Italy.

headline: Inside the List
text: Carbon Footprints: The thriller writer C.J. Box (whose initials stand for Charles James, dashing your hopes that his full name was Cracker Jack Box) is best known for his series of gritty mysteries about the Wyoming game warden Joe Pickett. But in “Badlands,” a stand-alone suspense thriller new at No. 5 on the hardcover fiction list, Box shifts his attention to North Dakota and the fracking boom; the book, set in the fictional oil town of Grimstad, N.D., is about a 12-year-old boy who witnesses a car accident on his paper route and makes off with the bundle of drugs and money he finds at the scene. As a child, Box had relatives who worked blue-collar jobs in the energy industry — “The house I grew up in didn’t have a single bookcase except mine,” he once told a website devoted to crime fiction — and in this novel he pokes some fun at journalists who reflexively condemn big oil. “They fly all the way here from the East Coast burning up jet fuel,” the town sheriff grouses at one point, “then rent cars and fill ’em with gasoline to drive all the way to Grimstad just so they can trot me out to say, ‘Oil is bad.’ I won’t play their game anymore.” Box has observed reporters up close: He used to be one. “My first job was working for a small Wyoming weekly newspaper,” he told the same website, The Rap Sheet, in 2010. “In retrospect, it was spectacular training in ‘the real world’ for what was to come. I learned so much, and met so many people in all walks of life. Much of what I’ve since written came from those days as a starving reporter.”

headline: ‘Sea Lovers: Selected Stories,’ by Valerie Martin
text: Among the many potent themes that weave in and out of the stories in “Sea Lovers” — the stark realities of the artist’s path; the proximity of death to life; the complexities of the relationship between humans and animals — are a number of seemingly ordinary yet revelatory ­images. For Valerie Martin’s characters, something as simple as drinking a glass of water can yield a moment of reflection and clarity.

headline: ‘All That Followed,’ by Gabriel Urza
text: Stories are shape-shifters in “All That Followed,” Gabriel Urza’s strange and ambitious debut novel. Set in Spain’s Basque Country, the book revolves around the assassination of Councilman José Antonio Torres, as recounted by three characters: Mariana, his dubiously grieving widow; the American teacher Joni Garrett, who came to Muriga in 1951 and wound up staying for his entire life; and Iker Abarzuza, serving time for murder in an island prison, where he listens to the cries of shorebirds and receives the occasional letter from Mariana.

headline: Opposing Iran Nuclear Deal, Chuck Schumer Rattles Democratic Firewall
text: WASHINGTON — The decision by Senator Chuck Schumer of New York to oppose the Iran nuclear deal has rattled the Democratic bulwark around the accord, emboldened the deal’s opponents in both parties, and set off a wave of condemnation from liberals for the man who hopes to lead Senate Democrats in the next Congress.

headline: In a First, a Sudanese Migrant Nearly Crosses the English Channel on Foot
text: LONDON — For one African migrant, there was nothing left to lose.

headline: ‘Crooked Heart,’ by Lissa Evans
text: Show of hands: Was anybody here an odd-looking, precocious, misunderstood child? Oh. . . . Everybody? Maybe that’s why so many of the novels we love most, from Brontë’s “Jane Eyre” to Rowling’s Harry Potter series, feature some version of this small person. We are gutted not by Scout or Jem in “To Kill a Mockingbird,” but by Dill, the fatherless fantabulist; we may admire Sara Crewe when she’s a kind little heiress, but she’s truly a princess when she loses both her money and her dad. I’ll read anything that features an invisible, unloved child, an orphan either in reality or spirit, more resourceful than any wee one should have to be. Bonus points if the child finds ways to skirt the law. (I’m looking at you, Addie Pray.)

headline: ‘Joy: Poet, Seeker, and the Woman Who Captivated C.S. Lewis’
text: Even if “Joy,” Abigail Santamaria’s life of C.S. Lewis’s wife, were a bad book, Lewis’s zealous admirers would read it, eager for another way to finger his shroud. Joy Davidman married Lewis, author of the beloved “Chronicles of Narnia,” at 41, and her late entrance into his bachelor existence is a cherished part of his legend. She soon died of bone cancer, but she had made him a husband and stepfather, adding an intimate touch to the genial but distant self-portrait that emerges from his grown-up books, tracts like “Mere Christianity.” Her death was also the subject of “A Grief Observed,” his classic book on mourning and how faith can survive it.

headline: The Economy Vanishes
text: There was almost no discussion of the economy in last night’s debate, which is actually weird if you consider the Republican self-image. These guys portray themselves as high priests of growth, the people who know how to bring prosperity. And remember all the crowing about how Obama was presiding over the worst recovery ever?

headline: Robin Williams’s Underrated Roles Help Illustrate His Major Talents
text: This summer brings in close proximity two sad milestones for fans of Robin Williams: July 21 would have been the 64th birthday of this inventive comedian and Academy Award-winning actor, and Aug. 11 is the one-year anniversary of his death. It is a bittersweet occasion to reflect on the range of work that Williams created, as he bounded from classically trained stage actor to stand-up comedian, and from a star of sitcoms to a leading man in movies. While a full consideration of Williams’s career would naturally gravitate toward his sympathetic serio-comic roles in films like “Good Morning Vietnam,” “Dead Poets Society” and “Good Will Hunting,” these performances overshadow other, more idiosyncratic but equally vivid efforts — some from a time when his on-screen persona hadn’t completely coalesced, and others he was able to sneak in once his fame was assured. Here are five of Williams’s less celebrated performances.

headline: Marco Rubio Clarifies His Position on Abortion
text: Senator Marco Rubio surprised some viewers on Thursday night when he said that he never supported exceptions that would allow for abortions if conception occurred from rape or incest.

headline: The Man Who Gave Air Force One Its Aura
text: Next time you see an image of Air Force One taking off, think Coca-Cola and Lucky Strike. The look of today’s presidential plane, emblazoned with “United States of America” on the blue-and-white fuselage, originated with a quiet collaboration between President John F. Kennedy and Raymond Loewy, who was perhaps the most accomplished commercial image and design expert of the post-World War II era.

headline: Donald Trump’s Remarks Feed Into Charges of Sexism
text: Donald J. Trump kept his vow to remain unbeholden to political correctness after Thursday night’s debate, continuing to criticize the Fox News anchor Megyn Kelly for asking him questions that were too tough while he was on stage.

headline: The Next G.O.P. Phenom
text: If recent history of Republican presidential campaigns continues, a couple of different candidates will have a few weeks or months to shine.

headline: A Product of Tunisia’s 1960s Resistance Continues to Protest
text: TUNIS — WhenFathi Ben Haj Yahia seeks to explain Tunisia’s troubled transition since its revolution overthrew nearly 60 years of dictatorship four years ago, he offers a parable.

headline: She Answered His Ad for a Roommate, Moved In and Never Left
text: Kerry Ryan needed a new place to live; her crazy Yugoslavian roommate had become unbearable. So, as people did in 1991 in New York City, she turned to the classified ads in The Village Voice.

headline: How to Approach the Generation Gap in the Workplace
text: A generation gap is widening in the workplace. As baby boomers (ages 51 to 69 or so) express reluctance about retiring, so-called millennials (roughly ages 18 to 34) have become the single largest demographic in the American labor force. Because of this, more older workers have found themselves being hired and managed by people much younger than they are.

headline: Stuff We Liked: How Cats Took Over the Internet
text: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: Don Brown’s ‘Drowned City,’ and More
text: Ten years have passed since Americans were glued to their televisions, watching the catastrophic results of Hurricane Katrina. Yet much of the drama happened after the storm pummeled New Orleans. For readers too young to remember, three new books revisit those troubled days and offer a clear view of that notorious storm’s impact.

headline: ‘The Little Brother,’ by Victoria Patterson
text: Victoria Patterson is a capable and ­canny writer, and she would have to be to take on the subject of her newest novel, “The Little Brother,” and produce so arresting and haunting an experience. To say the book is about a rape is true, but that’s only part of it — in many ways, the least interesting part. The real subject is the conditions that allow that rape to happen.

headline: A Missed Opportunity: G.O.P. Debate Avoids Family Policy Issues
text: I watched the first 2016 Republican debate with four children, aged 14, 11, 9 and 9. That meant juggling pizza off the grill while juggling questions about immigration (“But why does it matter if they come here? We’re all on the same continent.”); foreign policy (We have enemies? Who? China?); and Donald Trump’s hair. It meant introducing my oldest son to Politifact and its Pants on Fire GIF and teaching my suddenly very worried youngest daughter (“America is under attack?”) about the concept of exaggerating for dramatic affect (“just like your sister does”).

headline: Lauren Fox’s ‘Days of Awe’
text: What’s wonderful about reading a novelist’s books in back-to-back sequence is that you witness the writer grow not gradually, but seemingly overnight. In Lauren Fox’s first novel, “Still Life With Husband,” an unhappily married woman who works for a journal called Male Reproduction (complete with, yes, a boss named Dick) satisfies her seven-year itch with a hunky but sensitive writer she meets in a cafe. Fox furthers these themes with a more mature voice in her delightful “Friends Like Us” — a story of relationships made all kinds of confused when the protagonist’s best friend as an adult falls for her best friend from adolescence.

headline: Paperback Row
text: PANIC IN A SUITCASE, by Yelena Akhtiorskaya. (Riverhead, $16.) The boundaries between the Old and New Worlds blur in this debut novel, which follows a Ukrainian family adjusting to Brighton Beach, Brooklyn. Spanning 15 years of their lives, the resulting story is, as Karolina Waclawiak wrote here, a “rewarding biography of displacement, where those left behind are often as disconnected as those who flee for an elusive better life elsewhere.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: LET ME TELL YOU: New Stories, Essays, and Other Writings, by Shirley Jackson. Edited by Laurence Jackson Hyman and Sarah Hyman DeWitt. (Random House, $30.) Insights into the vagaries of Jackson’s ruminant, generous mind.

headline: Men and Women Team Up and Face Off in New Mixed Relays
text: KAZAN, Russia — The gun went off for the medley relay final at the swimming world championships, and it quickly seemed that Russia was in deep trouble. Its backstroker rapidly fell behind the other seven swimmers and, by the end of the leg, was more than seven seconds behind the leader and nearly six seconds behind the next slowest swimmer.

headline: After the Storm
text: SHOTS ON THE BRIDGEPolice Violence and Cover-Up in the Wake of KatrinaBy Ronnie Greene240 pp. Beacon, $24.95.

headline: Most Railroads Won’t Meet Deadline for Safety Controls, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — A majority of freight railroads and passenger trains will not be able to meet a year-end deadline to install technology that prevents trains from exceeding speed limits and helps avoid collisions, the Federal Railroad Administration said Friday in a report to Congress.

headline: Navigating Tougher I.R.S. Rules for Family Partnerships
text: THE Internal Revenue Service is about to toughen the rules on a type of investment vehicle that has been abused by some very wealthy families to avoid millions of dollars in taxes.

headline: Readers on Cecil the Lion
text: The first time #CeciltheLion popped up on Twitter, I wondered, “Who would name a lion after Cecil John Rhodes?”, the colonial founder of Rhodesia, now Zimbabwe.

headline: Swiss Identify Remains of Japanese Climbers Missing for 45 Years
text: Two Japanese mountain climbers caught in a snowstorm and buried under nearly half a century of Alpine ice have been identified, the police in Switzerland announced this week.

headline: Political Scandal Consumes Malaysia at Time of Flight 370 Inquiry
text: HONG KONG — It was a breakthrough in one of the biggest mysteries in aviation history. When a wing part belonging to a Boeing 777 was found last week on the remote Indian Ocean island of Réunion, the world took notice, echoing the intense news media coverage that followed the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 on March 8, 2014.

headline: Busy September Looms for Obama, but First: Two Weeks of Golf
text: EDGARTOWN, Mass. — President Obama slipped out of Washington on Friday afternoon for his annual Martha’s Vineyard vacation, just in time for the political spotlight to swing firmly away from the White House and toward the 2016 presidential campaign after the first Republican debate on Thursday night.

headline: 1940: Stewardess Says Man Hit Her
text: A mysterious attack on a pretty twenty-two-year-old stewardess on a New York to Dallas, Tex., sleeper plane was being investigated yesterday by American Airlines officials. The girl swallowed a baggage compartment key after she was struck by an unidentified man thirty minutes before the plane landed at 11:40 p.m. Wednesday at Nashville, Tenn. The stewardess, Miss Rosemary Olive Griffith, who was taken to a hospital in Nashville after the plane landed, suffering from a bruised head and scratches on her legs and arms, told the story of the assault to C.R. Smith, president of the American Airlines, yesterday from her hospital bed. She was struck on the head just after entering the women’s lounge to get her bag, and fell to the floor unconscious after first swallowing the key which the intruder had demanded. — New York Herald Tribune, August 8, 1940

headline: Success or Excess: What’s Behind Manhattan’s New Residential Sales Record?
text: The average price for a residence was reported to have hit $1.7 million, proof that the real estate market has bounced back from the 2008 recession.

headline: Duck in Summertime, Spicy and Fruity
text: You don’t have to go to a restaurant to have duck for dinner. Many home cooks leave duck cooking to the professionals, but once you know the technique, cooking a large Muscovy duck breast is no more difficult than cooking a steak.

headline: Review: A Divisive ‘Fidelio’ Draws Boos at Salzburg
text: SALZBURG, Austria — What’s a summer at the Salzburg Festival without at least one opera production that provokes vociferous booing on its opening night? That requisite rite took place here on Tuesday, at a new staging of Beethoven’s “Fidelio,” when the German director Claus Guth and his production team appeared during curtain calls at the Grosses Festspielhaus.

headline: Army Ranger School a Test for Women in Combat Roles
text: CAMP JAMES E. RUDDER, Fla. — Wearing a cap, sunglasses and a 75-pound rucksack and carrying a 17-pound machine gun, the young, buzz-cut Army officer quickly traversed a muddy river, pulling on a rope stretched between trees on either bank.

headline: SoulCycle: You Say ‘Cult.’ I Say ‘Loyal Customer Base.’
text: When young, trendy companies prepare for initial public offerings, their financial statements often show rapid growth but little profit. Investors are expected to take a leap of faith and bet that today’s expanding popularity will lead to sustainable earnings down the road.

headline: Potash Corporation Again Approaches K&S About Takeover
text: LONDON — K&S, the German potash and salt mining company that owns Morton Salt, said on Friday that the Potash Corporation had made another unsolicited takeover approach for the company.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Katrina: After the Flood’
text: This week, Gary Rivlin discusses “Katrina: After the Flood”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Joe Domanick talks about “Blue: The LAPD and the Battle to Redeem American Policing”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: The Long Shadow of Bill Gross
text: Pimco may not have emerged from the shadow of its larger-than-life co-founder Bill Gross, who left the world’s biggest bond fund abruptly in September 2014. But Allianz, its German owner, can take Pimco’s fall from grace in its stride. The company’s half-year results suggest its insurance division and a growing in-house asset manager are taking up the slack.

headline: Norwegian Youths Return to Camp on Utoya, the Site of a 2011 Massacre
text: UTOYA, Norway — With songs, volleyball games and defiant displays of summer languor, more than 1,000 Norwegian youths on Friday joined the secretary general of NATO and other dignitaries on the island of Utoya, reclaiming the bucolic summer retreat from the horrors of a 2011 attack by a right-wing extremist that killed 69 people.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Katrina: After the Flood’
text: This week, Gary Rivlin and Joe Domanick.

headline: Activist Protests Fourth Blogger’s Death
text: Imran H Sarker, head of the Blogger and Online Activist Network in Bangladesh, spoke out against the killing of Niladri Chaterjee in Dhaka on Friday. Mr. Chaterjee, who wrote under the name Niloy Neel, became the fourth secular blogger slain in the country this year.

headline: Six Days in North Korea
text: Six Days in North Korea

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: This week’s properties are located on the Upper East Side, in Midtown East and Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.

text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in the New York region:

headline: Drake’s Bully Pulpit
text: Jon Caramanica, Minya Oh and Rawiya Kameir discuss Drake and OVO Fest.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
text: This week’s properties include five-bedroom homes in Montville, N.J., and Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

headline: Bad Decision by Senator Schumer
text: New York’s senior senator, Chuck Schumer, has cast his lot with Republican presidential candidates, other hardliners and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in declaring his opposition to the nuclear agreement that President Obama and five other world leaders negotiated with Iran. Given Mr. Schumer’s wrong-headed and irresponsible decision, Democrats may want to reconsider whether he is the best candidate to be their next leader in the Senate, a job he desperately wants.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘Katrina: After the Flood’
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Nathaniel Rich reviews Gary Rivlin’s “Katrina: After the Flood.” Mr. Rich writes:

headline: Lee Daniels: ‘Empire’ Spinoff Coming ‘Without Question’
text: “Empire” fans know Cookie Lyon is an outsize character. Now it appears that she’s become too big for one show to contain her.

headline: Lenny Kravitz-Gate, a Zoolander 2 Teaser and Idris Elba’s Cover
text: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Fried Eggplant With Chickpeas
text: In this gently spiced vegetable dish, baby eggplant slices are first fried until golden, then braised with chickpeas, tomatoes and garam masala until soft, velvety and richly flavored.

headline: The Great Eggplant Question: To Fry or Not to Fry?
text: To fry or not to fry?

headline: Trump Sells His Penthouse for $21.38 Million
text: Donald J. Trump, the real estate developer and presidential hopeful, sold one of the two penthouses he owned at the Trump Park Avenue to the founder of the Fresh Market, a supermarket chain, for $21,383,250, a transaction that was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Big Ticket | 502 Park Avenue
text: Donald J. Trump sold his full-floor penthouse on the 24th floor of the Trump Park Avenue.

headline: China Philharmonic Orchestra to Play in Tehran
text: As the world focuses on the accord to limit Iran’s nuclear capabilities that was reached last month, the China Philharmonic Orchestra, a major ensemble from one of the six nations that negotiated the deal, is planning to play two concerts in Tehran next week.

headline: We Need Brain: Songify the G.O.P. Debate
text: The Gregory Brothers present a musical mash-up video of the first Republican presidential debate of 2016.

headline: Colin Quinn: A Most Charming Complainer
text: The comedian’s recent successes have not prevented him from offering amused resignation about the state of the world.

headline: Psychologists Approve Ban on Role in National Security Interrogations
text: TORONTO — The American Psychological Association on Friday overwhelmingly approved a new ban on any involvement by psychologists in national security interrogations conducted by the United States government, even noncoercive interrogations now conducted by the Obama administration.

headline: Colin Quinn Can Find the Dark Cloud in a Silver Lining
text: The comedian Colin Quinn, it turns out, likes to bicker and complain. A lot.

headline: Capitalists, Arise: We Need to Deal With Income Inequality
text: I’M scared. The billionaire hedge funder Paul Tudor Jones is scared. My friend Ken Langone, a founder of the Home Depot, is scared. So are many other chief executives. Not of Al Qaeda, or the vicious Islamic State or some other evolving radical group from the Middle East, Africa or Asia. We are afraid where income inequality will lead.

headline: Britain, Consumed by Sex Scandals, Focuses on Inquiries
text: Since 2012, Britain has been consumed by scandals about sexual predations and child sexual abuse by elite politicians and entertainers dating back to the 1960s. Here are some of the most prominent among them.

headline: In Britain, Edward Heath Case Intensifies Debate Over Validity of Sex Abuse Claims
text: LONDON — Accusations of child sexual abuse against some prominent figures of Britain’s recent past have proved true. Allegations of similar wrongdoing by others, dating back decades, surface regularly now in the hothouse British press, as does talk of cover-ups by some of the nation’s most powerful institutions.

headline: ‘We Need Brain: Songify the G.O.P. Debate’
text: As we hunkered down at Gregory Brothers headquarters in Brooklyn to songify the first debate of the 2016 election season, word broke that the Fox News team, inspired by their broadcast from Quicken Loans Arena, was considering using the Cleveland Cavaliers’ N.B.A. shot-clock buzzer to alert candidates that their allotted time was up. We were crestfallen when, at the first such transgression, we instead heard a polite “ding.” The Cavaliers’ claxon would have been perfect for a debate field so large it could have filled two basketball teams, qualifying in number if not by height.

headline: Shooting of Unarmed White Teenager, Zachary Hammond, Enters National Debate
text: Zachary Hammond, a white teenager, pulled up to a drive-through window last week at a Hardee’s restaurant in Seneca, S.C. A sting operation was underway, with police officers suspecting a possible drug deal.

headline: Another Secular Blogger in Bangladesh Is Killed
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — A group of men on Friday slit the throat of Niladri Chaterjee, an activist whose social media posts were often critical of Islam, in the fourth fatal attack this year against secular bloggers, the police said.

headline: Headstrong Filly Will Skip Undercard and Take on Colts in Hambletonian
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Money was relatively low on the list of priorities when the owners of Mission Brief, a record-setting filly, decided to test her against males in the $1.2 million Hambletonian. They had loftier aims.

headline: Biweekly Mortgage Payment Problems
text: Many lenders promote biweekly payment plans as a way to pay down mortgages more quickly. But the programs can sometimes be costly, and, as federal regulators recently found, may promise borrowers more than they actually deliver.

headline: Greta Gerwig, Illustrated
text: The actress sketches her responses to personal questions.

headline: Officials in Turf Fight Over Response to Legionnaires’ Outbreak in Bronx
text: An outbreak of Legionnaires’ disease in the South Bronx appeared to be ebbing on Friday, even as city and state officials jockeyed to show how they were responding to the airborne illness.

headline: Kerry Speaks on Human Rights in Vietnam
text: Secretary of State John Kerry delivered a speech on Friday in Hanoi recognizing the 20th anniversary of the restoration of diplomatic ties between the United States and Vietnam.

headline: Popcast: Drake’s Bully Pulpit
text: For the last five years, the annual OVO Fest in Toronto has been Drake’s hometown pulpit. Earlier this week, at its sixth annual installment, he turned it into a bully pulpit. After two weeks of squabbling with Meek Mill – over the ethics of ghostwriting, or maybe something deeper – Drake orchestrated an elaborate takedown that seemed to secure the victory that was already pretty plainly his.

headline: Map: Marin County
text: Here’s where to eat, sleep and shop in San Francisco’s neighbor to the north.

headline: Map: Marin County
text: Here’s where to eat, sleep and shop in San Francisco’s neighbor to the north.

headline: Eye Shape May Help Distinguish Predator From Prey
text: Why do the eyes of some animals, including goats, have horizontal-shaped pupils, while others, such as rattlesnakes and domestic cats, have vertical slits?

headline: 20 Years After Honeymoon, a Return Trip to Amsterdam
text: Twenty years ago, I traveled with my husband, Wendell, on our honeymoon to Amsterdam, where we walked hand in hand along 17th-century canals, visited museums, ate an obscene amount of cheese, and then blew a big black hole into the middle of our trip by eating hash-laced space cakes.

headline: 6 Strategies to Extend Savings Without Working Longer
text: Karen Arndt, 60, has tinkered with several retirement calculators, and they all generate the same finger-wagging advice: Keep working, they seem to warn. You’re not even close.

headline: Female Visibility Matters
text: A few weeks ago, I taught a social-justice workshop for African-American teenage girls from Chicago’s West Side. They all attend school in North Lawndale, one of the city’s most impoverished neighborhoods, and many of them have experienced hostile or violent interactions with the police. But because they are girls, not boys, they’ve told me, most people in their community do not take those interactions seriously.

headline: Republican Debate Draws 24 Million Viewers
text: Fox News’s telecast of Thursday night’s Republican debate drew a staggering 23.9 million viewers, making it the highest-rated presidential primary debate ever and among the most-viewed events in cable TV history.

headline: ‘I Am Cait’ Ratings Drop Nearly 50 Percent
text: Ratings for the second episode of “I Am Cait,” E!’s reality series about Caitlyn Jenner, fell almost by half from its July 26 premiere. The second show drew 2.1 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s live-plus-three-days data, which accounts for delayed viewing; 3.9 million total viewers watched the first episode of “I Am Cait” within three days of its first airing.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch to End On-Call Shifts for Workers
text: Abercrombie & Fitch said on Friday that it would no longer require workers to be on call for shifts that may be canceled with little notice, after a regulator’s inquiry into the practice.

headline: Jets’ Dee Milliner Expected to Miss 6 to 8 Weeks With Wrist Injury
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — A week into training camp, the Jets have already endured injuries to four prominent players. The latest came Thursday, when cornerback Dee Milliner hurt a tendon in his right wrist.

headline: On the Campaign Trail With Hillary Clinton
text: Amy Chozick, a politics reporter, has been covering Hillary Rodham Clinton for years. Some people have called her obsessed.

headline: Debate Was Highest-Rated Program Ever for Fox News
text: Fox News’s telecast of Thursday night’s Republican debate drew 23.9 million viewers, making it the highest-rated program ever for Fox News and among the most-viewed events in cable TV history.

headline: Out on the Prairie
text: A group of six high school students from New York City won grants to visit the American Prairie Reserve in Montana, where they met bison and learned how to roast marshmallows.

headline: New York High School Students Trade Skyscrapers for Big Sky
text: MALTA, Mont. — On a late July day 2,000 miles west of the Bronx, Vaughn Minott, a tall and soft-spoken aspiring biochemist who was born in Jamaica, bounced with five other New York teenagers in the bed of a 4X4 pickup through a Montana bison range as vast as the bright dome of sky above.

headline: Sparks Flew: Assessing the Republican Debate
text: To the Editor:

headline: Activist Hedge Fund Takes Significant Stake in American Express
text: ValueAct Capital Management, a prominent activist hedge fund, has taken a significant stake in American Express, which is grappling with a number of recent challenges.

headline: Lessons of Yonkers From David Simon’s ‘Show Me a Hero’
text: In the second hour of “Show Me a Hero,” David Simon’s long-awaited HBO miniseries about a crisis of race and class that erupted in Yonkers in the 1980s and reverberated for years, a crazed mob floods City Hall to denounce a plan, mandated by a federal court, to residentially desegregate the city. Yonkers is vertically divided by the Saw Mill River Parkway: The east side had traditionally been home to white middle-income earners, many of whom were Italian-American; the west side was poor, and black and Hispanic. In 1988, close to 98 percent of Yonkers’s public housing stock was located in the southwest section, which contained 81 percent of the city’s minority population.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: A Knife in the Ear Solved!
text: On Thursday we challenged Well readers to solve the mystery of a 39-year-old man with an earache and asymmetrical pupils. More than 200 of you wrote in with your thoughts on his diagnosis, but only a handful got the two part answer completely right.

headline: Brazil’s Vice President Sees Influence Grow as Scandal Engulfs Dilma Rousseff
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Few Brazilians gave much thought until recently to their vice president, a 74-year-old scholar of constitutional law with a bearing so formal that a political rival once compared him to “a butler from a horror movie.”

headline: 49ers Release Star Defender Aldon Smith, Adding to Their Recent Turmoil
text: The San Francisco 49ers released linebacker Aldon Smith on Friday after his arrest on accusations of hit and run, driving under the influence and vandalism, a move that continues the extraordinary foundering of an organization that reached the Super Bowl just three seasons ago.

headline: Factors Unrelated to Driving Can Affect Car Insurance
text: ARE you married or single? Have you been widowed or divorced? Is your credit history less than stellar? Your answers to those questions can affect the rates you pay for car insurance.

headline: Roots of Reaganolatry
text: Noah Smith suggests that Reagan worship reflects a misunderstanding of how the economy works — that those who idolize Reagan believe in the Green Lantern theory of presidential power, that presidents can make stuff happen, in the economy and elsewhere, though sheer force of will.

headline: Scene City: ‘Hamilton’ Opens on Broadway
text: Jake Gyllenhaal, Anna Wintour, Susan Sarandon, Sarah Jessica Parker and other stars attend the Broadway opening.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Playing With Light
text: Abandon all worries, ye who enter here.

headline: The Exclusive | 24 West 71st Street
text: A townhouse on an historic Upper West Side block is about to enter the market at $29 million.

headline: Upper West Side Townhouse for $29 Million
text: A historically significant granite-and-iron-spot-brick townhouse with fanciful terra-cotta embellishments and distinctive interior millwork is poised to enter the market at $29 million.

headline: Jon Stewart Signs Off With Second-Most-Watched Episode in ‘The Daily Show’ History
text: Jon Stewart’s final appearance as host of “The Daily Show” on Thursday drew 3.5 million viewers, making it the second-most-watched episode in the series’ history.

headline: Shenanigans, Heartache and a Lot of Laughter
text: The July 18 marriage of Andrew Gregory, a comedian, and Casey McIntyre, an associate publisher, followed a courtship with, of course, a lot of laughter — but a few tears as well.

headline: Court Forbids F.D.A. From Blocking Truthful Promotion of Drug
text: A federal judge said on Friday that the Food and Drug Administration could not prohibit the truthful promotion of a drug for unapproved uses because doing so would violate the protection of free speech.

headline: Candidates Continue to Plead Their Cases After First Republican Debate
text: The stage lights have dimmed, the spin room has been shuttered, but for Republican presidential candidates, the debate goes on.

headline: A Once-Flourishing Pima Cotton Industry Withers in an Arid California
text: FRESNO, Calif. — Up and down the San Joaquin Valley, vast fields that once grew cotton lie fallow, remnants of a boom and bust fueled by a worldwide demand for premium T-shirts and linens.

headline: Life Sentence for James Holmes, Aurora Theater Gunman
text: CENTENNIAL, Colo. — In a decision that surprised many in this community, a jury sentenced James E. Holmes on Friday to life in prison with no chance of parole, rejecting the death penalty for the man who carried out a 2012 shooting rampage that killed 12 people in a Colorado movie theater.

headline: Court Says 4 Catholic Nonprofits Must Allow Workers Access to Contraception
text: Four Roman Catholic nonprofits in New York must allow employees access to contraception, a federal appeals court panel ruled on Friday, reversing a decision by a lower court that allowed the organizations to get around a requirement in the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Afghanistan and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: August 7, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Afghanistan, Taiwan, France and Ukraine.

headline: Italian Police Charge 5 in Shipwreck That Killed Migrants
text: ROME — The Italian police arrested two Libyans, two Algerians and a Tunisian on Friday in connection with a shipwreck that left at least 25 confirmed deaths and probably as many as 200.

headline: Linda Sarsour Is a Brooklyn Homegirl in a Hijab
text: Behind schedule as usual, Linda Sarsour rushed into the Times Square office of the civil rights group the Gathering for Justice last month, 40 minutes late for a meeting with its founder, Harry Belafonte. On the way in from Brooklyn, the Uber driver she had hired made a wrong turn and wound up in New Jersey. Now, wearing her head scarf and hungry from fasting for Ramadan, Ms. Sarsour scurried into an auditorium packed with some of the city’s most prominent social-justice warriors.

headline: A Republican Broadside on Immigrants
text: Latinos of America, there you have it. The Republican presidential campaign has nothing good to offer you on immigration.

headline: Jon Stewart, Patron Saint of Liberal Smugness
text: IT shows how gifted Jon Stewart is that his best moment happened on someone else’s show. He appeared in 2004 on “Crossfire,” a CNN yelling program, and asked the hosts to take seriously their responsibility to public understanding by having useful conversations instead of shouting matches.

headline: What I Love | John Miller
text: John Miller, a bass player who assembles musicians for theater productions, lives with his wife, Constance Barron, on the Upper West Side.

headline: For ‘Public Morals,’ Edward Burns Exhumes the ’60s From Manhattan Streets
text: Tourists walking in New York look up at the skyscrapers and blinding billboards. Locals look down to avoid stepping in gum or whatever. Edward Burns lately has been looking here, there and everywhere when he strolls the city: at stoops, windows, cornices, railings. He has been looking for the 1960s.

headline: The Best Paternity Leave Policies
text: Here’s our working list of the United States employers that offer at least 10 weeks of paid parental leave to new fathers.

headline: Bringing Paternity Leave Into the Mainstream
text: This week, two companies joined in an unfolding race to provide ever more generous paid parental leave. Netflix said it planned to offer unlimited leave in the first year after a child’s arrival to many (though not all) of its employees, while Microsoft said it would substantially increase the paid leave that it will provide.

headline: A Musician on the Upper West Side
text: “I think every home should have an upright bass,” said John Miller, walking into his music room and nodding at the instrument in the corner. “It adds a certain je ne sais quoi. The shape of the bass, the contours, the gestalt of the bass only adds to a room.”

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: New Releases From La Luz, Chelsea Wolfe and Ossia
text: La Luz

headline: Bernie Sanders, After Call From Obama, Announces Support for Iran Deal
text: A day after Senator Chuck Schumer of New York announced his decision to vote against President Obama’s deal to curtail Iran’s nuclear program, he and the president each placed a call to Bernie Sanders.

headline: The Week in Political Pictures
text: The first debate of the 2016 presidential campaign, lobster rolls, jello, a Brooklyn beer hall and more in this week’s political pictures.

headline: Mostly Mozart’s Big Tent Embraces George Benjamin, Dai Fujikura and More
text: The big news this week at Mostly Mozart is George Benjamin’s opera “Written on Skin,” to be performed Tuesday Thursday and Saturday. But there’s also plenty of interest elsewhere at the festival.

headline: Ebola Survivors Face Lingering Pain, Fatigue and Depression
text: The Ebola outbreak that started more than a year ago seems to be waning at last. But now, West Africa faces another difficulty: More than 13,000 people survived the virus, and many have lingering health problems, psychological troubles like depression and post-traumatic stress disorder, and worries about returning to work to feed themselves and what is left of their families.

headline: Drive East Festival Spins to a Bigger Stage at La MaMa
text: This year Drive East, the South Asian performing arts festival, has grown up or, rather, into La MaMa’s largest space, the Ellen Stewart Theater, where it will host more than 20 programs of Indian music and dance. Presented by the organization Navatman, performances include Archana Joglekar, an esteemed dancer and actress who specializes in Kathak, and Ashwini Ramaswamy, of Ragmala Dance Company, in a Bharatanatyam solo featuring music by an all-female orchestra.

headline: German TV Anchor Denounces Online Hate
text: In a commentary broadcast on public television in Germany, Anja Reschke, a journalist, blamed a recent spate of “hateful Internet tirades” for inciting real-world violence against foreigners.

headline: Van Halen and Mötley Crüe, Stylists of Hair Metal, Play Area Shows
text: Here was one thrilling route to whiplash in the 1980s: Mötley Crüe, “Too Fast for Love” (1981); Van Halen, “Diver Down” (1982); Mötley Crüe, “Shout at the Devil” (1983); Van Halen, “1984” (1984); Mötley Crüe, “Theatre of Pain” (1985); Van Halen, “5150” (1986); Mötley Crüe, “Girls, Girls, Girls” (1987); Van Halen, “OU812” (1988); Mötley Crüe, “Dr. Feelgood” (1989). It was a rich decade for headbanger decadence, toggling between Mötley Crüe’s devil-may-care Dionysian pop-metal and Van Halen’s howling blue-collar arena aerobics — competing approaches, both demanding copious amounts of hair spray.

headline: At Sea With Joseph Conrad
text: THE tall ship Corwith Cramer stumbled into the Celtic Sea, engine roaring, 7,500 square feet of sail furled up mute. Its two masts ticked against the horizon like a metronome set to allegro. I joined a row of pallid sailors crouched at the leeward rail. Foam-lathered swell swung for my face, then reeled abruptly away. By the third time I threw up over the side, the “wine-dark sea” of Homer’s poetry just looked like the basin of a billion vomits.

headline: In ‘Shared Dining,’ a Table of Heroines at the Brooklyn Museum
text: “The Dinner Party,” Judy Chicago’s sumptuous, vulva-themed table with places for 39 historical female figures (Susan B. Anthony to Mary Wollstonecraft), has been permanently set at the Brooklyn Museum since 2007. Through Sept. 13, it will be joined in the museum by another women’s table, inspired by Ms. Chicago’s but made under far different circumstances.

headline: On ‘Kevin From Work,’ an Office Romance Built for One
text: Kevin (Noah Reid), an earnest young office worker, finally gets to quit the worst job in history. Every bit of it stinks, except for the colleague with whom he has shared a cubicle wall for three years: Audrey (Paige Spara), perpetually backlit, her hair tousled by a magical breeze and the wings of the animated bluebirds that suddenly appear every time she is near. And like them, Kevin longs to be close to her. If only she didn’t have a lunk of a boyfriend — which is why Kevin has banished himself and his shredded heart to Italy, but not before pouring his passion into a love letter and mailing it. After all, he’s never going to see her again.

headline: T City Guides: Milan
text: Five leaders in creative fields share their favorite places to eat, drink, shop and play.

headline: ‘The Three Musketeers,’ the Richard Lester Treatment
text: Countless directors have taken on Alexandre Dumas’s “The Three Musketeers,” but none have matched Richard Lester’s adaptation, so rambunctious it took “The Three Musketeers” (1973) and “The Four Musketeers” (1974) to contain it. The Film Society at Lincoln Center screens both Sunday and Tuesday. (Also on Sunday: Mr. Lester’s “The Return of the Musketeers,” from 1989.) The novel’s action and humor play to Mr. Lester’s gifts for the same, and working from George Macdonald Fraser’s script, the director attracted an unsurpassable cast, including Faye Dunaway as the lethal Milady de Winter; Christopher Lee as an eyepatched Rochefort; Raquel Welch as Constance; Michael York as D’Artagnan; Oliver Reed as Athos; and a peerless Charlton Heston as Cardinal Richelieu.

headline: How Mitchell J. Silver, New York City Parks Commissioner, Spends His Sundays
text: A lot of New Yorkers spend their weekends frolicking in the city’s 1,700 parks, but Mitchell J. Silver takes his visits more seriously than most. As the New York City parks commissioner, Mr. Silver picks a different borough every Sunday, packs his beloved camera and sets off to observe and document how a select few parks are being used and how they could be improved. A born-and-bred New Yorker, the 55-year-old urban planner recently returned to the city after serving for nearly a decade in North Carolina as the planning director for its capital city, Raleigh. Mr. Silver lives with his wife, Mary, 48, an administrator for the nonprofit Brooklyn Community Services, and his daughter, Rachel, 17, in Downtown Brooklyn.

headline: New York Review of Books Fills a Niche by Reviving Forgotten Works
text: In 1882, the writer Anton Chekhov, just 22 and beginning his literary career, submitted a dozen short stories to Czar Alexander III’s censors, who discerned a subversive intent and promptly forbade publication of the collection, called “The Prank.” The satirical tales then languished in official archives for more than 130 years — until last week, when they were finally published, in English, by New York Review Books.

headline: Hillary Clinton Has Her Own Celebrity Moment After Debate
text: Just as one reality television star upended the first debate of the Republican presidential race in Cleveland, another posed for a selfie with Hillary Rodham Clinton in Los Angeles.

headline: Frances Oldham Kelsey, Who Saved U.S. Babies From Thalidomide, Dies at 101
text: The sedative was Kevadon, and the application to market it in America reached the new medical officer at the Food and Drug Administration in September 1960. The drug had already been sold to pregnant women in Europe for morning sickness, and the application seemed routine, ready for the rubber stamp.

headline: Revenue Down Slightly at Sotheby’s, a House in Transition
text: Sotheby’s, the upscale auction house that appointed a new chief executive in March, reported weaker results on Friday than analysts had expected.

headline: The Great Victorian Weather Wars
text: THE history of today’s climate change debate may have begun on Feb. 7, 1861. That day, an Irish physicist named John Tyndall, a professor of natural philosophy, delivered the annual Bakerian Lecture to the Royal Society in London.

headline: Slide Show: Scene City: ‘Hamilton’ Opens on Broadway
text: Jake Gyllenhaal, Anna Wintour, Susan Sarandon, Sarah Jessica Parker and other stars attend the Broadway opening.

headline: Ferguson One Year Later
text: The Times revisited the community to see what has and has not changed in the year since Michael Brown was killed.

headline: Rapper and Model Chynna Rogers Straddles Two Worlds With Ease
text: The star of DKNY’s spring 2015 ad campaign is working on her debut album.

headline: Returning to a Rebuilding Nepal
text: As soon as Kevin Bubriski learned of the earthquake that devastated Nepal, he knew he had to return to the land he has documented since 1975.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
text: The first debate of the 2016 presidential campaign, lobster rolls, jello, a Brooklyn beer hall and more in this week’s political pictures.

headline: Friday Night Music: San Fermin, Parasites
text: One of the pleasures I wasn’t expecting back when I discovered, to my surprise, that I liked a lot of indie music was that of following the progress of favorite bands. In general, when I become aware of them — often, I have to say, via Bob Boilen’s Tiny Desk concerts — they already have a following but are still playing to small venues and haven’t fully worked out their persona. Over time, however, they visibly develop.

headline: Celebrities Flock to ‘Hamilton’ Broadway Opening and Party
text: It was a big night for American politics and entertainment.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: A Debate With Substance. No, Not That Debate.
text: Last night, I watched a really interesting political debate, in which the candidates engaged one another substantively about their vision for the country’s future.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
text: Good evening. Here’s the latest.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Park Avenue on Wheels
text: The annual closing of Park Avenue to automobiles brings New Yorkers on in-line skates, bikes, scooters, CitiBike unicycles and everything you can think of.

headline: Evening Hours | An Elegant Affair
text: Several hundred guests attended Southampton Hospital’s 57th annual summer party.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Park Avenue on Wheels
text: The annual closing of Park Avenue to automobiles brings New Yorkers on in-line skates, bikes, scooters, CitiBike unicycles and everything you can think of.

headline: Common Yellowthroat Warbler: A Bandit in the Bramble
text: Though tiny, the common yellowthroat warbler is no church mouse. Unlike many of their beautiful warbler relatives, these birds shun the treetops for a life amid the tangled brambles and vines of wetland edges and dense thickets. Highly inquisitive — even aggressive while protecting a breeding territory — the birds are animated subjects for anyone with even a passing interest in bird-watching. A lengthy view of the three- to four-inch warbler is measured in seconds.

headline: The Hole in the Middle of the Jobs Report
text: The jobs report for July, released on Friday, showed steady if unspectacular job growth. The economy created 215,000 jobs, in line with average job creation so far this year.

headline: Mussolini Slept Here: Unearthing a Roman Villa’s Uneasy Past
text: ROME — Deep beneath the historic Villa Torlonia, where Benito Mussolini lived for nearly two decades, a wine cellar repurposed in 1941 as a bunker to protect the Fascist leader was recently opened to the public. Even in a city stratified with centuries of history, where archaeologists are digging up the remains of an ancient empire, the damp underground space is a telling sign of how deeply Italy’s relatively recent past can stay buried.

headline: The Clash of New York’s Irish and Italians, and the City’s First Black Firefighter
text: “Among the most overlooked racial problems in the country,” the columnist Jimmy Breslin wrote in 1970, “is the division between Irish and Italians.”

headline: The Week on Instagram
text: Photos posted on @nytimes this week took us from Rand Paul’s campaign headquarters to the cockpit of a Boeing 747.

headline: An Influential Debate? Not if You Trust Prediction Markets
text: Thursday night’s Republican primary debate was watched by a record-shattering 24 million people, and some pundits lauded it as the “best, classiest debate ever.” But for all the fireworks, nothing seems to have changed.

headline: Review: Santa Fe Opera Offers ‘The Daughter of the Regiment,’ ‘Rigoletto’ and ‘Salome’
text: SANTA FE, N.M. — The appeal of the Santa Fe Opera, with its history of presenting the most distinguished American summer festival of its kind, is obvious. Taking in the mountain vistas from the terraces before performances may alone be worth the price of admission, though perhaps not at a top rate of $300 on weekends.

headline: The Bobbed-Hair Bandit of Brooklyn
text: Q. My stepdaughter, a hairdresser who is interested in old styles, was telling me about a young woman in the 1920s known as the Bobbed Hair Bandit. Can you tell me more?

headline: Photographs of Train Riders’ Idle Hands, on Way to Work
text: For a project called “Strangers in Common,” Alvaro Keding has discreetly captured images of New Yorkers on their commutes.

headline: A Photographer Puts Subway Riders’ Idle Hands to Work
text: A young man’s puffy coat on an overstuffed No. 4 train. The slick semi-oasis of an empty seat. The distressing warm patch of a vertical pole — which fellow traveler made it so, and what is his recent medical history? — tethering riders to their transit fate.

headline: Falling All Over Trump
text: There was a moment at the Republican debate in Cleveland on Thursday night — actually, there were several moments, but this one in particular lingered, and lingers, as an illuminating episode. You’ll never guess who was in the middle of it: starts with T and ends with “rump.”

headline: Review: In ‘Pimm’s Mission,’ Seeking Clues to a Deadly Blast
text: “Pimm’s Mission” takes place on a Sunday afternoon in an empty bar across the street from the Manhattan headquarters of a Big Pharma company, Zincorp, where an explosion has just killed 15 people. F.B.I. agents are questioning Robert Pimm, a Brit who was outside the building when the blast went off, and is nursing a head injury.

headline: Colorado: Heavy Metals Spill Into River
text: Environmental officials are working to clean up one million gallons of wastewater containing heavy metals that spilled from an abandoned mine, turning an adjoining river a mustard yellow. The Environmental Protection Agency caused the spill on Wednesday while it was investigating a leak at the Gold King Mine. The wastewater flowed into Cement Creek, a tributary of the Animas River in southwestern Colorado, and snaked through the river toward New Mexico. E.P.A. officials said the wastewater included lead and arsenic, but said it was too early to know whether there was a health risk. The river was closed for recreational and other uses, but officials said water sources should be safe. “The orange color is alarming to people, but that is not an indication in any way of a health risk,” said Joan Card, an official with the E.P.A. Testing continues, she said.

headline: Vice Media Staff Latest to Choose Unionizing
text: Some staff members at Vice Media have voted to unionize, according to two people familiar with the matter, joining other digital media outlets that have recently moved to organize.

headline: Prince Plans to Make New Album a Tidal Exclusive
text: Prince announced on Friday that he had signed an exclusive deal with the music-streaming service Tidal to release his new album, HITNRUN. A longtime advocate for artists’ rights, Prince recently began removing his music from most streaming services. But he has left his music on Tidal, the subscription service owned by Jay Z and more than a dozen other artists (Prince is not thought to be among them). Last month, Prince released a new single, “Stare,” on Spotify, another streaming service.

headline: Her Son Was Safe Behind Bars, but Then He Came Home
text: The wall had been covered in photographs of smiling children and grandchildren. Now there were gaps where pictures of a son used to hang, leaving behind bare nails.

headline: Judge Rules New York Teacher Exam Did Not Discriminate Against Minorities
text: A federal judge on Friday ruled that a new licensing exam for teachers given by New York State did not discriminate against minorities, saying that even though they tended to score poorly, the test evaluated skills necessary to do the job.

headline: German Journalist Wades Into Online War Over Refugees
text: Given two minutes to air her views on Germany’s response to the refugee crisis in Europe during a newscast on Wednesday night, Anja Reschke, a respected broadcaster, blamed a recent spate of what she called “hateful Internet tirades” for inciting real-world violence against foreigners, and she called on the public to speak up in favor of “decency.”

headline: Nuns of a New Generation Forge Their Own Path
text: Mechanical bulls, rock-climbing walls, bounce houses, go-karts: Before becoming a nun, Sister Virginia Joy helped insure them all.

headline: Brazilian Implicated in FIFA Case Remains Free, Unlike Many Others
text: Some are sitting in jail in Switzerland, while others are under house arrest in places including New York and Asunción, Paraguay. But of the 14 people indicted in May in a far-reaching corruption case within world soccer, only one remains a free man.

headline: Murder of Brazilian Journalist Furthers Alarming Trend
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Gleydson Carvalho’s radio program was on the air in the provincial beach city of Camocim when two gunmen burst into his studio. During a musical interval, they subdued the receptionist and told a technician to stay quiet. Then they did their work, unloading three rounds and killing Mr. Carvalho, a journalist known for crusading against political corruption.

headline: Guantánamo Hunger Striker’s Petition Divides Officials
text: WASHINGTON — Obama administration officials are divided over what to do about a detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, who has been on a hunger strike since February 2007 and now weighs less than 75 pounds, according to officials familiar with internal deliberations.

headline: Jon Stewart’s Legacy
text: It seems unfair, cruel even, that Jon Stewart would end his tenure as a national court jester the very night the absurdist circus kicks off Indecision 2016.

headline: Blackhawks’ Patrick Kane Facing Criminal Investigation
text: BUFFALO — The police in nearby Hamburg, N.Y., confirmed Friday that Patrick Kane, one of the N.H.L.’s most high-profile players, was under criminal investigation.

headline: Day After Debates, Carly Fiorina Finds Receptive Audience
text: ATLANTA — The final question to the candidate was from Diane: “What can people in this room who like what they’re hearing do to help the campaign?”

headline: Peace Activists Descend on Los Alamos, but Residents Remain Indifferent
text: LOS ALAMOS, N.M. — Ellie Voutselas, 78, pulled from a cardboard box the sacks she had fashioned into ponchos, slicing holes in the burlap for the head and arms. Cayla Turain, 22, grabbed hers, smudged ashes on her face, and joined a silent march for peace.

headline: Coleen Gray, Who Played Film Noir Naïfs, Dies at 92
text: Coleen Gray, an actress who dreamed of playing femmes fatales but was repeatedly cast as innocents in noir films like Stanley Kubrick’s “The Killing,” died on Monday at her home in the Bel Air neighborhood of Los Angeles. She was 92.

headline: The Perils of Probation
text: To the Editor:

headline: Shackling of Children
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ecuador’s Progress
text: To the Editor:

headline: Refugees on Greek Shores
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fears of Lasting Rift as Obama Battles Pro-Israel Group on Iran
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama had a tough message for the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, or Aipac, the powerful pro-Israel group that is furiously campaigning against the Iran nuclear accord, when he met with two of its leaders at the White House this week. The president accused Aipac of spending millions of dollars in advertising against the deal and spreading false claims about it, people in the meeting recalled.

headline: Louise Suggs, Golf Pioneer, Dies at 91; Helped Found the Women’s Pro Tour
text: Louise Suggs, a Georgia-born founder of the women’s professional golf tour and one of its most successful and outspoken players, died on Friday in Sarasota, Fla. She was 91.

headline: Dozens of Syrian Christians Missing From Town Attacked by ISIS
text: ISTANBUL — Dozens of Christian civilians are missing and are believed to be captives of the Islamic State extremist group after it seized their town in central Syria this week, according to conflict-monitoring groups and the Syrian Orthodox Church.

headline: Children Caught in a Racist System
text: The Justice Department cast the St. Louis County, Mo., law enforcement system in a harrowing light in March when it documented entrenched racism and unconstitutional policing in the town of Ferguson, which erupted in riots last year after a white police officer killed Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager.

headline: A Stronger Web of Care for the Mentally Ill in New York
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced a plan on Thursday for a coordinated attack on mental illness, violence and homelessness. It involves having more caseworkers, clinicians and police officers working in shelters and on the streets, and having the mental health and criminal justice systems work together more closely to find and protect people who might pose a danger to themselves or others.

headline: Remembering Hiroshima, and How It Changed the World
