text: After 70 years, the memory may be fading. Survivors are in their 80s, and many young Japanese can no longer give the dates when American atomic bombs incinerated Hiroshima and Nagasaki. But at every anniversary the debates resurface, as impassioned and complex as ever.

headline: Jury Reads Holmes Verdict
text: James Holmes was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole in a Colorado courtroom Friday. The jury was unable to reach the unanimous verdict required for the death penalty.

headline: Cuomo Rejects Federal Offer to Lend Money for New Hudson River Tunnels
text: When it comes to paying for new train tunnels under the Hudson River, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo wants the federal government to send, not lend, money to New York.

headline: Nagasaki, the Forgotten City
text: ON Aug. 9, 1945, the United States dropped a nuclear bomb on Nagasaki, situated on a long, narrow bay on Japan’s southernmost main island, Kyushu.

headline: The Other Mushroom Clouds
text: Hundreds of atomic bombs have been tested since the one dropped on Nagasaki on Aug. 9, 1945.

headline: Some Parisian
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Let’s just put our grids on the table and say it: People are scared of the Saturday puzzle, and with good reason. It’s hard.

headline: Producer Acquitted of Top Sexual Assault Charge; Mistrial on Other Counts
text: A former producer for the Wu Tang Clan hip-hop group who served as his own lawyer was acquitted on Friday of the top sexual assault charge he faced, but the judge declared a mistrial on several other counts on which a jury said it was deadlocked.

headline: When Jon Stewart Took Down CNBC’s Jim Cramer
text: It began, you’ll perhaps recall, with the Santelli rant.

headline: Wastewater Spill in Colorado Turns a River Yellow
text: Environmental officials in Colorado are working to clean up one million gallons of wastewater containing heavy metals that spilled from an abandoned mine, turning an adjoining river a murky, mustard shade of yellow.

headline: Fear That Debate Could Hurt G.O.P. in Women’s Eyes
text: After Senator Marco Rubio of Florida insisted at the Republican presidential debate that rape and incest victims should carry pregnancies to term, aides to Hillary Rodham Clinton could barely contain their delight at his unyielding stance, rushing to tell reporters at her headquarters that those remarks would hurt Mr. Rubio with female voters.

headline: Blue Jays Draw First Blood in ‘Most Meaningful’ Series
text: Toronto Manager John Gibbons said he considered it “the most meaningful series” the Blue Jays have played at Yankee Stadium in 20 years. But the atmosphere in the visitors’ clubhouse before Friday’s game hardly attested to that proclamation.

headline: Wilmer Flores Again Shows Flair for Theater in Comeback Victory
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The rookie and the folk hero are from different countries, speak different first languages and stood on opposite sides of the clubhouse on Friday. One is an outfielder; the other plays the infield. One just completed his third series in the major leagues; the other is playing in his third season.

headline: How to Save a Sinking Coast? Katrina Created a Laboratory
text: NEW ORLEANS — Ten years ago, the neighborhood hard by the 17th Street canal in this city was water-blasted. The surges from Hurricane Katrina swept into the canal, broke through its flood walls and forced homes off their foundations. Much of New Orleans remained steeped in brackish filth for weeks until the sodden city could be drained.

headline: A Look Back at the Outcry in Ferguson
text: A retrospective on the events that put Ferguson, Mo., in the national spotlight and spurred discussion on race relations nationwide.

headline: Ferguson: A Shooting That Caused the Nation to Shudder
text: For days after the shooting death of Michael Brown on Aug. 9, 2014, protesters faced off with the police as racially charged demonstrations gripped the streets of Ferguson, Mo. Protesters knelt with their arms raised, signifying “hands up, don’t shoot,” which became their plea for justice and change. Other residents, however, just wanted their neighborhood to return to normal.

headline: Rebuilding Nature in Wake of Katrina
text: Several projects have been undertaken to restore wetlands in Louisiana to provide flood protection and wildlife habitat.

headline: How the 14 Indicted FIFA Defendants Currently Stand
text: Updating the legal status of the 14 soccer and sports marketing officials charged in the FIFA corruption case.

headline: What Is Nature Worth to You?
text: THE United States government recently announced an $18.7 billion settlement of claims against the oil giant BP in connection with the Deepwater Horizon oil rig explosion in April 2010, which dumped millions of barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico. Though some of the settlement funds are to compensate the region for economic harm, most will go to environmental restoration in affected states.

headline: What’s On TV Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE HOBBIT: THE BATTLE OF THE FIVE ARMIES (2014) In Peter Jackson’s conclusion to the tale of Bilbo Baggins (Martin Freeman, above), the hobbit and his companions become mired in a war that threatens to destroy Middle-earth. Ian McKellen returns as Gandalf, who finds himself at the heart of the story after his imprisonment; Richard Armitage is Thorin Oakenshield, the headstrong leader with a lust for treasure; Evangeline Lilly is the elf Tauriel, who pursues a forbidden love; and Benedict Cumberbatch lends his voice to the dragon Smaug. “What this adaptation of ‘The Hobbit’ can’t avoid by its final installment is its predictability and hollow foundations,” Nicolas Rapold wrote in The New York Times. “It’s been said before, but Mr. Jackson himself is still haunted by the past.” He added: “It’s especially a shame since Mr. Jackson’s original knack for world building (not to mention the sense of humor in his early films) is often missing in the ever-proliferating superhero-franchise worlds that his own vastly successful endeavors no doubt helped encourage. Bilbo may fully learn a sense of friendship and duty, and have quite a story to tell, but somewhere along the way, Mr. Jackson loses much of the magic.”

headline: Corrections: August 8, 2015
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “There’s a difference between pandering and vote-courting: Thursday night, G.O.P. candidates did neither for women weary of the Republican brand.”

headline: Father of Palestinian Toddler Killed in West Bank Arson Attack Dies in Hospital
text: DUMA, West Bank — The severely burned father of a Palestinian toddler who was killed in an arson attack died of his wounds early Saturday, and thousands of Palestinians came to bury him in this West Bank village gripped by grief, anger and fear.

headline: Chinese Human Rights Lawyer Is Unexpectedly Freed a Day After Being Detained
text: PINGYAO, China — A Beijing human rights lawyer said Saturday that he had been released from police custody, a day after being detained in a raid on his apartment.

headline: Andrew Gregory and Casey McIntyre: A YouTube Comedy Star and the Woman Who Keeps Him Laughing
text: In love, as in comedy, impeccable timing is everything. Yet there is something to be said for the offbeat, and even the missed beat, when it comes to great romance.

headline: Conservative Forum Rescinds Donald Trump’s Invitation Over Remark About Megyn Kelly
text: ATLANTA – Donald J. Trump’s suggestion that a Fox News journalist who questioned him during the Republican debate was aggressive because she was menstruating led a conservative group on Friday night to disinvite the real estate mogul from a prominent conservative forum.

headline: I’m Too Old for This
text: There is a lot that is annoying, and even terrible, about aging. The creakiness of the body; the drifting of the memory; the reprising of personal history ad nauseam, with only yourself to listen.

headline: A Master’s Degree in ... Masculinity?
text: Michael Kimmel stood in front of a classroom in bluejeans and a blazer with a pen to a whiteboard. “What does it mean,” the 64-year-old sociology professor asked the group, most of them undergraduates, “to be a good man?”

headline: Typhoon Soudelor Kills 6 in Taiwan and Leaves Millions Without Power
text: HONG KONG — A powerful typhoon dumped rain on China on Sunday, a day after it pummeled Taiwan, toppling trees and leaving millions without electricity as strong winds ripped across the island.

headline: City Tours Becoming More Children-Friendly
text: Adults might find organized city tours interesting and informative, but for children they can be yawn inducing. Fortunately, for hard-to-please young travelers, companies are creating interactive and entertaining versions for those between the ages of 6 and 12.

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Review: Netflix’s Not So ‘Unlimited’ Benefits
text: We are trying something new. Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the industry.

headline: Twisting Words to Make ‘Sharing’ Apps Seem Selfless
text: I have trouble with the sharing economy. Ditto the peer economy, the people economy and the collaborative economy.

headline: Dealing With a Possible Hoarder
text: A Bad Odor Next Door

headline: Hand-Wringing in G.O.P. After Donald Trump’s Remarks on Megyn Kelly
text: Donald J. Trump’s suggestion that a Fox News journalist had questioned him forcefully at the Republican presidential debate because she was menstruating cost him a speaking slot Saturday night at an influential gathering of conservatives in Atlanta. It also raised new questions about how much longer Republican Party leaders would have to contend with Mr. Trump’s disruptive presence in the primary field.

headline: Mornings in America
text: Just a further thought about Reaganolatry: consider the track of unemployment under two presidents. One is lauded as the ultimate economic hero and savior; the other reviled as an economic failure, who killed jobs by being nice to poor people and insulting job creators. The chart compares their records.

headline: Kevin E. Lofton of Catholic Health Initiatives: Designate a Devil’s Advocate
text: This interview with Kevin E. Lofton, chief executive of Catholic Health Initiatives, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: 29 U.S. Scientists Praise Iran Nuclear Deal in Letter to Obama
text: Twenty-nine of the nation’s top scientists — including Nobel laureates, veteran makers of nuclear arms and former White House science advisers — wrote to President Obama on Saturday to praise the Iran deal, calling it innovative and stringent.

headline: 4 Years After Fukushima Nuclear Calamity, Japanese Divided on Whether to Return
text: IITATE, Japan — For four years, an eerie quiet has pervaded the clusters of farmhouses and terraced rice paddies of this mountainous village, emptied of people after the disaster at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, 25 miles away, spewed radiation over a wide swath of northeastern Japan.

headline: Variety: A Flighty Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — If you happen to be a BIRDWATCHER, you will like this acrostic. Even if you’re not, it’s still an excellent puzzle, because it’s by Cox and Rathvon.

headline: Katie Ledecky Wins 800 in Record Time, Completing World Championships Sweep
text: KAZAN, Russia — Ask Katie Ledecky to name what she believes is the most amazing athletic feat in her lifetime, and she will talk about Michael Phelps’s eight-gold-medal performance at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, helped along by the anchor leg that Jason Lezak unleashed in the 4x100-meter freestyle relay to deliver Phelps his second gold.

headline: California Effort to Issue Driver’s Licenses to Immigrants Receives Surge of Applicants
text: LOS ANGELES — When Alberto Fraire drives past a police car these days, he no longer worries about steep fines, or perhaps being hauled to jail and tangling with the immigration system. When California began issuing driver’s licenses to undocumented immigrants this year, he was one of the first in line.

headline: Conservative Forum’s Leader Says Donald Trump’s Language Will Lose G.O.P. the White House
text: ATLANTA – After rescinding an invitation to Donald J. Trump over his misogynistic comments about a Fox News reporter, the leader of a conservative conference said on Saturday morning that his email box filled with vitriolic messages.

headline: Dick Costolo Is Said to Plan Departure From Twitter’s Board
text: Dick Costolo, the former chief executive of Twitter, plans to leave the company’s board of directors by the end of the year or when a new chief executive is appointed, according to two people familiar with Mr. Costolo’s plans.

headline: Many Minority Families Stuck in Poor Neighborhoods Despite Housing Voucher Program
text: Where families receiving housing choice voucher live.

headline: A Year After Ferguson, Housing Segregation Defies Tools to Erase It
text: ST. LOUIS — When she tore open the manila envelope on a sweltering morning in early June, Crystal Wade thought she had unlocked her ticket to freedom.

headline: In Handling Barrage of Attacks, Afghan Forces Show Training Is Paying Off
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The unprecedented wave of attacks here — three major bombings in less than 24 hours that killed at least 65 people and wounded hundreds of others — was arguably a major victory for Taliban forces, who proved they could mount simultaneous operations with devastating effect, including on an American military base.

headline: Pain of Puerto Rico’s Debt Crisis Is Weighing on the Little Guy, Too
text: To Lev Steinberg, it seemed like a good place to park his nest egg.

headline: For the Cubs and the Mets, a Whiff of the Past and a Tantalizing Glimpse of the Future
text: CHICAGO — It was a let’s-play-two jewel of an evening at Wrigley Field, the shadows of summer long and sharp as the Cubs and the Giants gathered for a showdown.

headline: Andrew Zirm: An Astrophysicist With a Down-to-Earth Calling
text: Andrew Zirm, 41, is a data scientist at Greenhouse Software in New York.

headline: Regulators Should Develop Rules to Protect Cars From Hackers
text: The recent revelation that hackers have found ways to remotely take control of cars made by Fiat Chrysler and Tesla is alarming. This is a danger that most drivers had not even imagined. And it comes on the heels of the recalls of millions of cars for dangerous defects.

headline: Exposing Abuse on the Factory Farm
text: While most Americans enjoy eating meat, it is hard to stomach the often sadistic treatment of factory-farmed cows, pigs and chickens.

headline: Is India Selling Out Its Tigers?
text: The Modi government is diluting environmental protections.

headline: Africa’s Scramble for Europe
text: THIS summer, a striking, often tragic story has been playing itself out on the outskirts of Calais in France, at the entrance to the tunnel that connects the European mainland to Great Britain. Thousands of migrants, African and Middle Eastern, have been trying to sneak onto the trucks and trains that traverse the tunnel, cutting through wire fences and evading the police along the way. Ten have died, but enough have succeeded for many more to keep trying, while politicians on both sides of the Channel point fingers and a refugee camp outside Calais remains swollen with would-be subjects of Elizabeth II.

headline: Congress and Obama Are Too Timid on Marijuana Reform
text: Even as support for ending marijuana prohibition is building around the country, Congress and the Obama administration remain far too timid about the need for change.

headline: Suicide on Campus
text: Responses to an Education Life article about pressure on students and the rising rate of suicide on college campuses.

headline: Trump the Disrupter
text: Washington — I’VE been hesitant to start writing about Donald Trump.

headline: U.S.A., Land of Limitations?
text: YAMHILL, Ore. — We like to boast of America as the “land of opportunity,” and historically there is truth to that.

headline: A Prudent College Path
text: EVERY year the frenzy to get into highly selective colleges seems to intensify, and every year the news media finds and fawns over the rare students offered admission to all eight Ivy League schools. This year Ronald Nelson, from the Memphis area, was one of those who sopped up that adulation.

headline: Do the Amazon’s Last Isolated Tribes Have a Future?
text: HIS name is Shuri, but everyone calls him Epa, which means father in the indigenous Pano language family. His wizened face and bare, gnomish feet are familiar to the villagers who live along the Curanja River, which flows through some of the densest rain forest of Peru’s vast Amazon region.

headline: A Cheer and a Half for Cheap Commodities
text: Commodities markets have taken a beating this summer. Oil, coal, coffee, soybeans, copper, iron and nearly every other commodity has fallen sharply in price, upending currency markets and inflicting pain in large parts of the world economy.

headline: Afghan Forces Display Effectiveness in Fending Off Attacks
text: Officials noted that in none of the three bombings on Friday, scattered across Kabul, did the insurgents manage to breach their targets’ inner defenses.

headline: What Do the Poor Need? Try Asking Them
text: FOR decades, policy makers have treated poverty as a sign of helplessness and ineptitude. The worse off the neighborhood — the higher the rate of poverty, crime, and juvenile delinquency — the less influence it would have over its future. Social service agencies conducted “needs assessments” rather than asking residents what would strengthen their community. Government agencies or private entrepreneurs then delivered brick-and-mortar solutions — a new school, medical clinic or housing.

headline: Congolese See No End to President’s Final Term
text: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo — To take the political pulse of this sprawling, mineral-rich country, head to the busiest stretch of Lumumba Boulevard, one of the capital’s main roads. On weekdays, a large crowd gathers here to peer at the newspapers posted on an eight-foot-high wall and loudly trade opinions on the news of the day.

headline: Giants Can’t Give Big Hits for Now, and That Hurts, Some Players Say
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In 2011, a new N.F.L. labor agreement did away with a staple of summer pro football workouts since the 1950s. Gone was the punishing two-a-day practice regimen.

headline: What Selfie Sticks Really Tell Us About Ourselves
text: CREMATED remains, xylophones and lawn chairs are not allowed in the Magic Kingdom, and now selfie sticks aren’t either. Disneyland banned the so-called narcisticks this summer following similar prohibitions at the Roman Colosseum, Palace of Versailles and Sydney Opera House. The cited reason was public safety concerns as well as basic propriety.

headline: Margrethe Vestager
text: Margrethe Vestager is a Danish politician who last year was appointed the European Union’s commissioner for competition and promptly took to task several powerful interests including Google, Russia’s gas behemoth Gazprom and European Union countries’ state-owned utilities.

headline: Key Events in the Hillary Clinton Email Controversy
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton's email account has become a significant early chapter in her presidential run, and a new stroke in the portrait of the Democrats' leading candidate.

headline: Hillary Clinton Emails Take Long Path to Controversy
text: WASHINGTON — Earlier this summer, the inspector general of the nation’s intelligence agencies contacted the longtime lawyer for Hillary and Bill Clinton with a pointed question. Classified information had been found in a small sample of 30,000 messages from the former secretary of state’s private email account. The inspector general, I. Charles McCullough III, wanted to know from the lawyer, David E. Kendall, where copies of the message collection might still be stored.

headline: Caregiving: A Burden So Heavy, Until It’s Gone
text: “Marry an orphan,” my mother used to say, “and you can always come home for Christmas.” What she should have said was: “Marry an orphan, or you’ll have four parents to nurse through every torment life doles out on the long, long path to the grave.”

headline: Kazan, a Russian Cultural Hub, Finds It’s Good at Sports
text: KAZAN, Russia — In his first trip abroad, Michael Weiss visited a place he had a hard time locating on a map. Was Kazan a sports destination or an exclamation popularized by the television character Gomer Pyle?

headline: Mother Is Charged With Murder After Infant’s Fall From a Window in Queens
text: The mother of a 3-week-old boy who died after plummeting from a fourth-floor window in Queens was charged on Saturday with intentionally killing her child.

headline: A Minor League Home Run King Without Major Fanfare
text: When Mike Hessman entered professional baseball, as a 15th-round draft choice in 1996, he fixed his mind on reaching an annual statistical benchmark.

headline: The Strip
text: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Australian Brothers Cherish Their Reunion at P.G.A. Championship
text: The last time that Matt and Brett Jones played a competitive round in the same field was nearly a decade ago at the Jacob’s Creek Open Championship in Adelaide, Australia, a regular stop on the PGA Tour of Australasia. The event was “co-sanctioned” by the Nationwide Tour in the United States, meaning that those who finished in the money had a chance to move up to the PGA Tour.

headline: Scientists’ Letter to Obama on Iran Nuclear Deal
text: Twenty-nine of the nation’s top scientists wrote to President Obama on Saturday in support of the deal, which calls for Iran to curb its nuclear program and allow inspections in return for an end to sanctions.

headline: Iris DeMent Returns, Via Russia
text: Iris DeMent, a songwriter and singer of country and gospel music, emerged in the 1990s. And if you listened a lot to the New York City radio station WFUV back then, you could hear her voice every day, plaintive and joyous, lonely and quite unforgettable, singing tunes that felt brand new and many generations old.

headline: Manuel Contreras, Chilean Spy Chief Under Pinochet, Dies at 86
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — Gen. Manuel Contreras, Chile’s intelligence chief during the military dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, died on Friday in the military hospital in Santiago while serving 526 years of multiple prison terms for human rights violations. He was 86.

headline: Ditching Honky-Tonk for Chic
text: It’s a sign of the times: Baron’s Cove, for many years a mainstay among local family motels, reopened this spring as an upscale resort and restaurant. The old space had grown a little honky-tonk over the years, and the results of the upgrade — overseen by the hotelier, Curtis Bashaw, and his designer sister, Colleen Bashaw — are ravishing.

headline: With Seventh Straight Win, Blue Jays Creep Closer to Yankees
text: Taped to David Price’s locker was a self-written message on yellow notebook paper, pronouncing in all capital letters, “If You Don’t Like It, Pitch Better,” with the last two words underlined three times for emphasis.

headline: Restaurant Review: Charritos in Weehawken Is a Family Affair
text: One ideal place to be this summer is the slender terrace overlooking Manhattan at Charritos, a restaurant in Weehawken specializing in the colorful dishes of Oaxaca, a region in southern Mexico. For those unfamiliar with Oaxacan cuisine, it is known for chocolate-infused moles, which Charritos does serve, and grasshoppers, which it does not.

headline: Amid an Inquiry, Patrick Kane Cancels Stanley Cup Events
text: BUFFALO — Under increasing scrutiny as the subject of a criminal investigation, Patrick Kane, one of the N.H.L.’s highest-profile players, kept a low profile here in his hometown Saturday rather than celebrate publicly with the Stanley Cup, as he had in the past.

headline: Hanoi Through a Parisian Lens
text: The vision for Everett and Linda Reid’s new restaurant began, like so many dreams, over a meal in Paris. But it was not a traditional French cafe that sparked the couple’s imagination, during that visit more than 20 years ago. Rather, it was the City of Light’s most famous Vietnamese eatery, Tan Dinh, still a fixture on the Seventh Arrondissement’s Rue de Verneuil.

headline: Everything for a Summer Picnic at Westchester County Markets
text: August, in my book, is picnic month. As summer and mosquitoes wane, a simple meal spread over a checkered cloth among tall grasses and Queen Anne’s lace reminds us that we are part of the natural order of things.

headline: A Duo, in Jazz and in Love
text: By her own account, Carla Bley was operating outside her comfort zone when at a ceremony honoring her and three other new National Endowment for the Arts jazz masters in April, she was obliged to deliver an acceptance speech to a packed house at Lincoln Center.

headline: Douglas LeVien, New York Detective Who Infiltrated the Mafia, Dies at 68
text: Douglas A. LeVien Jr., a former undercover police detective who in 1972 infiltrated the meeting ground used by New York’s five Mafia families, a landmark operation that produced scores of convictions, died on July 30 while vacationing in Saratoga, N.Y. He was 68.

headline: Documentary Explores Struggle of New Jersey’s Ramapough Tribe
text: Corey Bobker was an accomplished 30-something adult when he took his first drive into the Ramapo Mountains in 2010. But the 12-year-old version of him still had knots in his stomach.

headline: Cecil’s Kin?
text: What a tour group saw.

headline: Review: ‘The Cottage’ in Northport Is a Saucy Farce
text: “The Cottage,” a saucy farce about infidelity set in 1923 England, was written — contrary to any expectations that description might conjure — very recently by Sandy Rustin, a young American playwright who lives in Maplewood, N.J. Compounding its lack of British pedigree, the play was first produced at the Astoria Performing Arts Center in 2013 before spawning regional productions in Colorado, Massachusetts and Arizona. In 2014, the Astoria production enjoyed another run in the borough where it had its world premiere, this time at Queens Theater in the Park.

headline: 299 Connecticut Museums and One Special Child
text: When Steve Wood arrived at the Ukrainian Museum and Library of Stamford on a recent Sunday afternoon, in his head were the number 299 and a sense of uncertainty.

headline: Help Wanted
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE —If a HELP WANTED ad ran for test crossword-puzzle solvers, what do you think it might say?

headline: Benton Becker, Ford Aide, Dies at 77; Negotiated Nixon Pardon
text: Benton L. Becker, who as President Gerald R. Ford’s personal emissary negotiated the pardon of Richard M. Nixon in 1974 and preserved his White House papers and tapes from what Mr. Becker predicted would have otherwise been “a hell of a bonfire in San Clemente,” where Nixon lived, died on Aug. 2 in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 77.

headline: India Warns TV Stations Over Criticism of Hanging
text: NEW DELHI — India’s government on Friday accused three television networks of violating broadcasting regulations by showing interviews that criticized the execution of Yakub Memon, hanged last month for bombings that killed 257 people in Mumbai in 1993.

headline: Did Roger Stone Jump, or Was He Pushed From Donald Trump’s Campaign?
text: Both Donald J. Trump and political strategist Roger Stone agree they have parted ways. What they don’t agree on is when and how they did it.

headline: On the Defensive, the S.E.C. Quietly Pursues High-Profile Cases
text: Wall Street’s chief regulator, the Securities and Exchange Commission, appears to some to be in need of a makeover.

headline: Poor E.U. Migrants Test Limits of Swedish Tolerance
text: STOCKHOLM — After begging through the night outside bars and nightclubs, Gheorghe Rancu, a homeless migrant from Romania, was asleep one morning this summer in a Stockholm park when he woke with a start and felt a sharp pain on his face.

headline: Medicare, Reversing Itself, Will Pay More for an Expensive New Cancer Drug
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has decided that Medicare will pay for one of the newest, most expensive cancer medications, which costs about $178,000 for a standard course of treatment.

headline: 70 Years After Nagasaki Bombing, Atomic Debate Yields Little Consensus
text: Did the United States have to drop the bomb?

headline: Daughter Honors Seau Onstage at a Celebration Under a Cloud
text: CANTON, Ohio — At a dinner and ceremony Thursday night as part of the Pro Football Hall of Fame induction weekend, Sydney Seau received a standing ovation after Roger Goodell, the N.F.L. commissioner, presented her with a gift honoring her father, Junior, one of the game’s most celebrated linebackers.

headline: A Year On, Ferguson Killing Is Recalled
text: FERGUSON, Mo. — As demonstrators shouted, “Hands up, don’t shoot,” and marched toward West Florissant Avenue, the scene here on Saturday morning looked in many ways like a flashback to the protests that followed the police killing of Michael Brown a year ago.

headline: Man Dies After Being Shocked With a Taser by a Hartford Police Officer
text: The Connecticut State Police are investigating the death of a man who was shocked with a Taser by a Hartford police officer after a call for medical assistance.

headline: Final Hearing for Reporter Held in Iran Is Scheduled for Monday
text: The final hearing in Iran’s espionage trial of Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post correspondent whose yearlong incarceration has helped worsen tensions with the United States, has been scheduled for Monday, the newspaper’s executive editor and Mr. Rezaian’s brother said Saturday.

headline: Marco Rubio: Won’t Comment on Everything Donald Trump Says
text: Senator Marco Rubio praised Megyn Kelly, the Fox News debate moderator who has come under fire from Donald J. Trump, but said he was not going to comment on Mr. Trump’s latest remarks.

headline: Tom Coughlin Finds Little New in a Talk With Jason Pierre-Paul
text: Giants Coach Tom Coughlin had a telephone conversation Friday afternoon with Jason Pierre-Paul, the Giants’ defensive end who has stayed away from the team’s training camp after a serious fireworks accident on the Fourth of July weekend. Coughlin said Pierre-Paul, whose right index finger was amputated, did not indicate when he planned to rejoin the team, but it did not sound as if it would be soon.

headline: Jeb Bush Gets Applause at Conservative Forum
text: ATLANTA — Jeb Bush, who has fought the perception of conservatives that he is not one of them, journeyed into the lion’s den on Saturday. While he may not have converted every skeptic at the RedState Gathering, a conclave of anti-establishment Republicans, he persuaded more than a few to give him a second look.

headline: Jefferson-Jackson Dinner Will Be Renamed
text: An Iowa Democratic Party panel voted on Saturday to change the name of the popular Jefferson-Jackson dinner, joining several state parties in distancing itself from the legacies of the two former slave-owning presidents for whom the dinner is named.

headline: Measuring the Legacy of Ferguson: Readers Respond
text: Reflections on the legacy of the fatal shooting of Michael Brown by a police officer last year in Ferguson, Mo., that set off protest movements and sparked a nationwide conversation about race.

headline: Officials Expand Efforts to End Legionnaires’ Disease Outbreak
text: New York City and state officials continued to step up efforts on Saturday to thwart the spread of Legionnaires’ disease, even as an outbreak of the airborne illness in the South Bronx appeared to be waning.

headline: An Excerpt From Sydney Seau’s Speech
text: Before his suicide, Junior Seau told his daughter to speak on his behalf if he entered the Hall of Fame. But she was not allowed to give the speech. Here’s an excerpt from Sydney’s speech.

headline: The Hall of Fame Speech You Didn’t Hear
text: Before his suicide, Junior Seau told his daughter to speak on his behalf if he entered the Hall of Fame. But the Hall didn’t allow her to speak at the ceremony. Here’s what Sydney would have said.

headline: The Hall of Fame Speech Junior Seau’s Daughter Couldn’t Give
text: In his 20-year N.F.L. career, Junior Seau established himself as one of the game’s greatest linebackers. He committed suicide in 2012 at age 43 and was subsequently found to have had a degenerative brain condition linked to repeated hits to the head. Before his death, Seau told his daughter Sydney that she should speak on his behalf if he made it into the Pro Football Hall of Fame. But the Hall, citing a five-year-old policy of not letting others give full speeches for deceased inductees, did not allow Sydney to deliver her speech.

headline: Noah Syndergaard Struggles as Rays End Mets’ 7-Game Winning Streak
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Amid the clang of cowbells, Noah Syndergaard stalked off the mound, his face buried in his glove and hanging toward the ground.

headline: A Moscow of Dancing Feet, Under an Iron Fist
text: MOSCOW — Russia’s capital city has worn many outfits since the fall of the Soviet Union.

headline: Answers Sought in Police Shooting of Unarmed Christian Taylor
text: The police in Arlington, Tex., asked the F.B.I. to help investigate the shooting death of an unarmed black college student who was killed by a police trainee early Friday morning inside a car dealership.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Sunday, August 9, 2015
text: “It’s not the end of the world; she didn’t give away the crown jewels. But this is not how things are supposed to be done.”

headline: Nicole Gill and Robert Ottaway Jr.: Grandma Knows Best. Both of Them.
text: Nicole Marie Gill, a daughter of Patricia Dunsmore Gill and Robert L. Gill of Jackson, Wyo., was married there Saturday to Robert Flinn Ottaway Jr., a son of Anne Galvin Scruggs of Cashiers, N.C., and Mr. Ottaway of Birmingham, Mich. The Rev. Carl Beavers, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the home of the bride’s parents.

headline: Frances Middleton, Michael Fields
text: Frances Baird Middleton, a daughter of Leigh P. Middleton and John S. Middleton of Bryn Mawr, Pa., was married Saturday to Michael David Fields, a son of Barbara Y. Fields and Bryan J. Fields of Atlanta, at the Winterthur Museum, Garden & Library in Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Dr. Eugene Bay, a Presbyterian minister, officiated, with Rabbi Philip Kranz assisting. The bride will take her husband’s name.

headline: Emily Chang and Michael Wong
text: Emily C. Chang and Michael Wai-Yin Wong were married Saturday at the Bardessono Hotel and Spa in Yountville, Calif. The Rev. Charles Grande, a minister of the American Catholic Church in the United States, officiated.

headline: Riva Anand and Harman Narula
text: Riva Kaur Anand, a daughter of Narvin K. Anand and Taranjit Singh of Westport, Conn., was married Saturday to Harman Singh Narula, a son of Priti K. Narula and Dr. Amarjot S. Narula of Mahwah, N.J. Granthi Surjit Singh performed a Sikh ceremony at the Glen Rock Gurudwara, a Sikh temple in Glen Rock, N.J.

headline: Brittany Mosely and Derrick Barker Jr.
text: Brittany Elise Elizabeth Mosely and Derrick Gerhard Barker Jr. were married Saturday at the Hilton Garden Inn in Cleveland. The Rev. Colin Jones officiated with his wife, the Rev. Imani Jones, both of whom are ministers of the United Church of Christ.

headline: Molly O’Donnell,  Hao Meng
text: Mary Catherine Molly O’Donnell, a daughter of Kitty Ryan O’Donnell and Tim J. O’Donnell of Skaneateles, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Hao Meng, the son of Yi Jiang and Dr. Gang Meng of Brooklyn. The Rev. Janet M. Shortall, a Unitarian Universalist minister, is to officiate at the John Joseph Inn in Groton, N.Y.

headline: Jaime Donate, Michael Schulman
text: Jaime Luis Donate and Michael Jared Schulman were married Saturday evening at the Pebble Beach at Brooklyn Bridge Park in Brooklyn. Ellen R. Birnbaum, a friend of Mr. Schulman’s family who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Elizabeth Schmidt,  Andrew Malcolm
text: Elizabeth Joanna Schmidt, a daughter of Susan D. Schmidt of Evanston, Ill., and the late Willard F. Schmidt, was married Saturday to Andrew Leland Malcolm, the son of Lisa S. Malcolm and John F. Malcolm of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The Rev. Jo Forrest, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Kenilworth Union Church in Kenilworth, Ill.

headline: Sarah Molinoff,  Scott Rosenthal
text: Sarah Esther Molinoff, a daughter of Kati Van Lierde and Dr. Arthur Molinoff of Ashtabula, Ohio, was married Saturday evening to Scott Edward Rosenthal, a son of Marti E. Rosenthal and John C. Rosenthal of Portland, Ore. Rabbi Michael Cahana performed the ceremony at Congregation Beth Israel in Portland, with Cantor Ida Rae Cahana participating.

headline: Gail Becker,  Stuart Smith
text: Gail Frances Becker and Stuart James Smith were married Saturday. Rabbi Yoshi Zweiback officiated at Saddlerock Ranch in Malibu, Calif.

headline: Madelyn Morris,  Daniel Goldberg
text: Madelyn Alexandra Morris and Daniel Lewis Goldberg were married Saturday evening at the Bridgeport Arts Center in Chicago. Rabbi Steven S. Lowenstein officiated.

headline: Tamar Winters,  Avi Nussbaum
text: Dr. Tamar Sophia Winters, a daughter of Rachelle R. Winters and Dr. Stephen L. Winters of Parsippany, N.J., is to be married Sunday to Avi Yedidiah Nussbaum, the son of Dr. Myrna K. Nussbaum and Dr. Monte J. Nussbaum of Oceanside, N.Y. Rabbi Andrew Scheer is to officiate at the Sheraton Parsippany.

headline: Tryn Collins and Matthew Kaelin
text: Kathryn McManmon Collins and Matthew Eugene Kaelin were married Saturday at the Weekapaug Chapel in Weekapaug, R.I. David Collins, an uncle of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Victoria King, Brian Frommer
text: Victoria Elise King, a daughter of Patricia A. King and David C. King of Wilton, Conn., was married Saturday evening to Brian Lloyd Frommer, a son of Sandy Y. Greene and Alan G. Frommer of Scarsdale, N.Y. Linda Gates, a justice of the peace in Westport, Conn., officiated at Rolling Hills Country Club in Wilton.

headline: Mackenzie Condon, Alexander Roussos
text: Mackenzie Wilson Condon and Alexander Daley Roussos were married Saturday at Maritime Gloucester, a museum in Gloucester, Mass. The officiant was Frederick M. Daley III, an uncle of the groom who received a one-day designation to officiate from Massachusetts.

headline: Darla Murray,  Matthew Zander
text: Darla Michelle Murray and Matthew Louis Zander were married Saturday evening at the Museum of Vancouver in British Columbia. Rabbi Dina-Hasida Mercy officiated.

headline: Elizabeth Hendee,  James Canner
text: Elizabeth Gregg Hendee and James Hart Canner were married Saturday in Stonington, Conn. The Rev. Ryan Fleenor, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Calvary Church.

headline: Sara Lipka and Alberto Behar
text: Sara Lynn Lipka, the daughter of Ellen R. Lipka and George S. Lipka of Framingham, Mass., is to be married Sunday to Alberto Behar, a son of Marta Behar and Leon Behar of Cape Town. Rabbi Donald M. Splansky is to perform the ceremony at the Sixth & I Historic Synagogue in Washington.

headline: Annie Karni, Ted Mann
text: Annie Karni and Ted Mann were married Saturday. Ryan Downer, a childhood friend of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the Brooklyn Masonic Temple.

headline: Emily Mollenkopf, Scott Moschella
text: Emily Gerson Mollenkopf, the daughter of Kathleen Gerson and John H. Mollenkopf of Brooklyn, was married Saturday to Scott David Moschella, a son of Marie M. Moschella and Salvatore A. Moschella of Englewood, Fla. Ruth Horowitz, a friend of the bride’s mother who is a Universal Life minister, officiated at Campovida, a farm and vineyard in Hopland, Calif.

headline: Saul Olyan,  Frederik Schockaert
text: Saul Mitchell Olyan and Frederik Schockaert are to be married Sunday at their vacation home in Fitzwilliam, N.H. Daniel T. Moran, a celebrant of the American Humanist Association, is to officiate.

headline: Christine Binder,  Brian Chu
text: Christine Ann Binder and Brian Francis Chu were married on Saturday at Judson Memorial Church in Manhattan. The Rev. Dr. Donna Schaper, the senior minister at Judson Memorial, performed the ceremony.

headline: Alexandra Gaudiani and Tracy Bjelland
text: Alexandra Lynn Gaudiani and Tracy Alexandra Bjelland were married Saturday. Canon Elizabeth S. Berman, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Harvard Memorial Church in Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Leah Zimmerman and Peter Lord: A Cardboard Walrus Delivers
text: Leah Marie Zimmerman and Peter Wesley Lord were married Friday evening at the Greenpoint Loft, a warehouse space in Brooklyn. The officiant was the Rev. Tyler C. Staton, who was ordained by Trinity Grace Church, where he is pastor of the Williamsburg parish.

headline: Emelyn Northway,  Ely Kahn IV
text: Emelyn Claire Northway and Ely Jacques Kahn IV were married Saturday evening at Liberty National Golf Club in Jersey City by Matthew Mitchell, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion.

headline: Marie Aberger,  Andrew Nesi
text: Marie Elizabeth Aberger and Andrew William Nesi were married Saturday afternoon at St. Augustin's Catholic Church in Newport, R.I. The Rev. Christopher M. Rehagen, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Di Hu,  Adam Webb
text: Di Hu and Adam Kempton Webb were married Saturday at the Church of Our Lady in Upton Pyne, Devon, England. Canon Michael A. Hall, an Anglican priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Priya Sethi,  Nimish Verma
text: Priya Sethi and Nimish Dev Verma were married Saturday. Pandit Dwejendra Doobay performed a Hindu ceremony at the Hyatt Regency in Princeton, N.J.

headline: Rebecca Levine,  Barry Eisenberg
text: Rebecca Shari Levine and Barry Mitchell Eisenberg were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Joshua Goldstein at the Brooklyn Winery in Brooklyn.

headline: Nora Murphy, Robert Massimi
text: Nora Barnard Murphy, the daughter of Laura Barnard Murphy and Raymond G. Murphy of Rockville, Md., was married Saturday to Robert Frank Massimi, a son of Maria G. Massimi and Frank A. Massimi of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Scott R. Pilarz performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Dahlgren Chapel of the Sacred Heart at Georgetown University in Washington.

headline: Rose Weiner, Marc Held
text: Dr. Rose Heather Weiner, a daughter of Lois M. Weiner and Dr. William A. Weiner of East Rockaway, N.Y. , is to be married Sunday to Marc Ari Held, the son of Suzanne Held of Lynbrook, N.Y., and Bruce C. Held of Wellington, Fla. Rabbi Sholom Stern is to officiate at Oheka Castle, a hotel and estate in Huntington, N.Y.

headline: Nicole Teibel, Taylor Boyd
text: Nicole Marie Teibel, a daughter of Gail M. Teibel and Mitchell C. Teibel of Wilmington, N.C., was married Friday to Taylor Leslie Boyd, a son of Cynthia S. Boyd and Frank L. Boyd of Raleigh, N.C. The Rev. Kate Dunn performed the ceremony at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

headline: Emily Fabre,  Robert Gomez
text: Emily Sarah Fabre and Robert Alexander Gomez were married Saturday at the Central Park Conservatory Garden in New York. The officiant was Judge Barbara S. Jones, formerly of the United States District Court of the Southern District of New York, for whom the groom was previously a law clerk.

headline: Analisa Andry,  Heriberto Rodriguez
text: Analisa Andry and Heriberto Rodriguez were married Friday. The Rev. Paul M. Ybarra performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Basilica of the Sacred Heart in Notre Dame, Ind.

headline: Jessica Tannenbaum and Jeffrey Berger: Hey Sis, He Likes Me (Not You)
text: Jessica Kara Tannenbaum and Jeffrey Scott Berger were married Saturday. Rabbi Benjamin H. Spratt officiated at the JW Marriott Essex House in New York.

headline: In Case You Missed It: Top Articles of the Week
text: Catch up with the most-read sports stories in The New York Times from July 31 to Aug. 6.

headline: Corrections: August 9, 2015
text: MAGAZINE

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know to start your week.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
text: Here are the week’s top stories.

headline: ‘I Love to Watch You Play’ but Not Every Game
text: I couldn’t help but be a little relieved when the thunder rolled in. Baseball was canceled, one of five games scheduled in a nine-day span. The weekday games are precisely at dinnertime, and I have two other children and a husband with a commute.

headline: Similarities Aside, Bernie Sanders Isn’t Rerunning Howard Dean’s 2004 Race
text: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa — It was a summer Friday night in Iowa, and a high school auditorium here was overflowing, as more than 1,000 people, holding signs and collecting names, spilled out into the lobby and onto the sidewalk. Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont strolled onstage — tieless, his white hair askew, his shoulders stooped — and stopped at the sight in front of him.

headline: Teacher Shortages Spur a Nationwide Hiring Scramble (Credentials Optional)
text: ROHNERT PARK, Calif. — In a stark about-face from just a few years ago, school districts have gone from handing out pink slips to scrambling to hire teachers.

headline: Do You Have Change for a Bowie? The Advent of Artisanal Cash
text: LONDON — Though paper money here typically bears the visage of Queen Elizabeth, the Brixton district of the city last month released a new 5-pound note designed by Jeremy Deller, an artist who won the prestigious Turner Prize in 2004. It features a fuzzy, psychedelic image of an androgynous face surrounded by rainbow clouds and coruscating, swirling etchings.

headline: More Cohesive Australian Team Shows a Harder Edge
text: Any notion that Australia would not be a serious threat at the Rugby World Cup was dispelled as the Wallabies underlined their credentials with a 27-19 victory over New Zealand in Sydney on Saturday night.

headline: 1890: Power Struggle in Guatemala
text: NEW YORK — Despatches to the HERALD from Guatemala say that conspiracies are breaking out in all quarters. Senor Sobrol, Minister of Foreign Relations, suspected of being a traitor, is confined in the penitentiary and the imprisonment of other prominent men is expected.

headline: ‘True Detective’ Season 2, Unexplained
text: Fans of the HBO television show “True Detective” attempt to explain what the second season of the series is about.

headline: African-American Stage Stars to Join Audra McDonald in ‘Shuffle Along’
text: Four of the American theater’s leading African-American singer-actors will join Audra McDonald next spring in a musical that seeks to reintroduce one of the first all-black shows on Broadway.

headline: Lollapuzzoola 8: On a Saturday in August
text: Administrivial Lollapuzzoola Alert! We are thrilled to have Oliver Roeder of FiveThirtyEight.com as our guest blogger covering Lollapuzzoola 8, the most fun you can have with a sharp pencil on a Saturday in August. Warning: If you are playing the Home version of the game, you might want to avert your eyes until you submit your answers. We have taken precautions, using power tools and advanced chemistry, not to spoil any of the answers, but you never know what could spill out of Oliver’s mouth. That’s how much fun he had.

headline: Premier Haider al-Abadi, Facing Protests, Proposes Iraqi Government Overhaul
text: BAGHDAD — Facing widespread protests against government corruption and poor services, as well as a crucial call for change from the country’s top Shiite cleric, Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi proposed on Sunday to radically reshape the dysfunctional political system of Iraq that has been entrenched since the American-led invasion in 2003.

headline: Email Requesting Another Date for Taking Sergeant’s Exam
text: Police Officer Akema Thompson sent an email to the Department of Citywide Administrative Services requesting other options for taking the test because Oct. 19, 2013 was the same day as her due date.

headline: Email Details Make-Up Exam Date Guidelines
text: An officer giving birth or recovering from childbirth on the exam date is not among the instances in which an individual can reschedule taking the sergeant’s exam.

headline: Pregnant Officer Denied Chance to Take Sergeant’s Exam Fights Back
text: Police Officer Akema Thompson felt the energy in the air the moment she walked into the Manhattan precinct station. And as soon as she stepped into the women’s locker room, she knew why.

headline: Shots Are Fired as Anniversary Is Marked in Ferguson
text: FERGUSON, Mo. — A day of peaceful protest commemorating the killing of Michael Brown, an unarmed black 18-year-old, by a white police officer one year ago ended in gunfire late Sunday as multiple shots rang out on West Florissant Avenue, the commercial district hit by rioting last summer.

headline: ‘Hannibal’ Recap: Did He Who Made the Lamb Make Thee?
text: Season 3, Episode 10: “And the Woman Clothed in Sun”

headline: Knitting History (Trivial)
text: Via Brad DeLong, a great history of socks. But somehow it misses the economic geography story, where there once was a great hosiery center in Cohoes, near Albany, thanks to one Egbert Egberts, who invented the first power knitting frame. In England the comparable complex was in Nottingham.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
text: 7 P.M. (Travel) AMERICA. THE BEAUTIFUL. Robert Redford narrates this exploration of some of the country’s most breathtaking landscapes in advance of the National Park Service’s centennial celebration in 2016. The journey begins in California, as the pilots Chris Bolfing and John Heiney, above, hang glide through Yosemite; the arborist Chad Brey climbs 200 feet into the branches in Redwoods National Park; and the marine biologist Alana Osaki dives into kelp that can grow 90 feet tall in the Channel Islands. At 7:30, the series moves to Utah, where the adventurers Faith Dickey and Andy Lewis slack-line in Mineral Canyon, and Heidi Redd herds cattle in Indian Creek Canyon.

headline: Donald Trump Remains Defiant on News Programs Amid G.O.P. Backlash
text: A defiant Donald J. Trump suggested on Sunday that he had been singled out for attacks by the hosts of last week’s widely watched Republican presidential debate and again threatened a third-party White House bid if he was not treated “reasonably fairly” by party leaders.

headline: 1965: Friction Between Singapore and Malaysia Intensifies
text: SINGAPORE — The bitter friction between Singapore’s government and the predominantly Malay federal government intensified during recent weeks and led to predictions that the federation would be torn apart by racial and political bitterness. But no one expected it to happen so soon, with so little warning.

headline: 29 Are Killed in Afghanistan as Bombing Targets Militia
text: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan — At least 29 people were killed and 19 others wounded in a suicide bombing targeting a militia in the northern province of Kunduz, Afghan officials said Sunday.

headline: A Hive of Activity Atop the Barclays Center
text: “We have a bee,” Ashley Cotton said, in a we-have-liftoff voice.

headline: Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway Said to Be Near Deal to Buy Precision Castparts
text: Warren E. Buffett has long spoken about his “elephant gun,” the huge pile of cash at Berkshire Hathaway that is reserved for big deals, and his itchy trigger finger.

headline: Man Charged After 8 Members of Texas Family Are Found Dead
text: Eight members of a Texas family, including six children, were shot to death over the weekend and the mother’s former domestic partner was arrested and charged with the murders on Sunday, the authorities said.

headline: Change in Militant Tactics Puts Tunisians on Edge
text: MONASTIR, Tunisia — A dozen police officers, one with an assault rifle across his knees, guard the presidential mausoleum in this seaside resort, easily outnumbering the foreign visitors on a recent morning.

headline: ‘Rocky Horror’ at Lincoln Center, With Headphones
text: It is a cinematic ritual that unconventional film fans have shared in for nearly 40 years, but it has probably never been presented quite so unconventionally.

headline: After Sydney Seau, Football Hall of Fame Policy Will Be Tested Again
text: When Sydney Seau spoke briefly Saturday at the Pro Football Hall of Fame induction for her late father, Junior, she proved emphatically that the relatives of deceased inductees deserved to deliver full speeches at their enshrinement ceremonies. Who would have thought otherwise?

headline: Frank Gifford, Star for Giants and in the Broadcast Booth, Dies at 84
text: Frank Gifford, a gleaming hero of sports and television in an era when such things were possible, who moved seamlessly from stardom in the Giants’ offense to celebrity in the broadcast booth of “Monday Night Football,” died on Sunday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 84.

headline: ‘Fantastic Four’ Lacks Superpowers at Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES — 20th Century Fox’s big-budget “Fantastic Four” went down in flames at the weekend box office, adding to fears about superhero fatigue and calling into question Hollywood’s willingness to hire novice directors for major films.

headline: After Nokia Layoffs, Tech Workers in Finland Regroup and Refocus
text: Kimmo Kalliola knows the feeling that thousands of Finns have been dealing with over the last couple of years. He spent more than a decade working on geolocation positioning at Nokia, a highly technical job, but the Finnish tech giant hit hard times. In late 2012, Mr. Kalliola and 10,000 others at the company were laid off.

headline: As South Korean Villages Empty, More Primary Schools Face Closings
text: NOGOK, South Korea — The post office pulled up stakes and moved away years ago. The police station is long gone. And so is the bank. Over the years, the residents of Nogok have watched almost every major institution disappear, victims of an exodus of young people that is emptying villages and towns across much of rural South Korea.

headline: Behold the Deep Bench
text: NBC has the first post-debate poll; it’s an online poll, but using a methodology that worked very well in the midterm elections. And it does not, it turns out, show the predicted Trump collapse and rise of the establishment candidates.

headline: Mets Lose Early Lead and Fall to Rays
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — On his final pitch of Sunday’s game, Tampa Bay starter Chris Archer threw an 88-mile-an-hour slider to Wilmer Flores. Flores swung and missed. Archer, the Rays’ young All-Star pitcher, pumped his arms, let out a yell and strutted off the mound. He had allowed three runs and four hits while striking out 10 in six innings.

headline: Malaysia’s Prime Minister and 1MDB
text: The Prime Minister of Malaysia, Najib Razak, is mired in a scandal over billions of dollars that his critics say are missing from a sovereign wealth fund 1Malaysia Development Berhad, known as 1MDB.

headline: Yankees Shut Out by Blue Jays for Second Day in Row
text: Of the three hits that Masahiro Tanaka allowed in six innings Sunday, two were home runs. The damage was minimal, but it supplied the Toronto Blue Jays with just enough offense to send the Yankees off winless in this important three-game series between teams jockeying for supremacy in the American League East.

headline: Abrons Announces Premieres for New Season
text: Seven world-premiere theater pieces are in store for the coming season at Abrons Arts Center, the 100-year-old home to avant-garde theater and dance at the Henry Street Settlement.

headline: KCON
text: Scenes from the festival of K-Pop music.

headline: At Salzburg Festival, Musicians Tap Their Inner Mozarts and Schuberts
text: SALZBURG, Austria — The six-week calendar of this summer’s Salzburg Festival is, as usual, packed. Among the offerings are seven staged opera productions (three of them new), and three operas in concert, as well as dozens of programs by the Vienna Philharmonic, nine guest orchestras, chamber groups, contemporary ensembles and more.

headline: Coca-Cola Funds Scientists Who Shift Blame for Obesity Away From Bad Diets
text: Coca-Cola, the world’s largest producer of sugary beverages, is backing a new “science-based” solution to the obesity crisis: To maintain a healthy weight, get more exercise and worry less about cutting calories.

headline: It’s Not the First Time Donald Trump Has Flirted With a Third-Party Run
text: Over nearly two decades, Donald J. Trump has given more than a little thought to a third-party presidential candidacy. How serious he is about it for 2016 is about to be tested.

headline: Review: In ‘Delirium’s Daughters,’ Dad Wrestles Daughters’ Suitors, One Dead
text: Things turn complex and lovely when the ghost appears in “Delirium’s Daughters.” It’s not a real ghost. Giovio isn’t dead; he has cleverly faked his own demise so that everyone will think kindly of him, especially his girlfriend’s father, who has rejected him as a prospective son-in-law. So he visits the man in the middle of the night.

headline: Israel Continues Crackdown on Jewish Extremist Network in West Bank
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli authorities on Sunday continued their crackdown against the young Jewish zealots believed to be associated with the Revolt, a shadowy network described by its members as an anarchistic vision of redemption.

headline: Review: Stately Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra, a Brave Danish String Quartet
text: In recent summer seasons, Jane Moss, the artistic director of Lincoln Center, has successfully transformed the Mostly Mozart Festival. What was once a stodgy diet of Classical-era hits and occasional novelties has become a varied festival that includes a valuable platform for contemporary music. This week, for example, the festival presents the American stage premiere of George Benjamin’s acclaimed opera “Written on Skin,” with Alan Gilbert conducting the Mahler Chamber Orchestra, a major event.

headline: Review: Steven Osborne Is Joined by 2 Collaborators at Kaplan Penthouse
text: One of the most attractive innovations of the Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center in recent decades has been A Little Night Music, a series of intimate concerts in a nightclub atmosphere (with free wine) at the Kaplan Penthouse. The 10 o’clock start typically allows patrons a leisurely stroll from the evening’s orchestral concert, where, as often as not, they will have heard some of the same performers.

headline: Widespread Child Sexual Abuse Case Rocks Pakistan
text: HUSSAIN KHAN WALA, Pakistan — Pakistani officials have initiated an investigation into allegations that a gang of men sexually abused more than 200 children and sold videos of the abuse.

headline: New York, Combating Worker Abuse, Requires Salon Owners to Secure Wage Bonds
text: For nearly six years, Silvia Gonzalez opened the doors of Romy’s Nails in Brooklyn at about 8:45 a.m. and left more than 12 hours later, six days a week. She performed manicures and pedicures with no lunch break, making $55 a day, or about $4.50 an hour. After Ms. Gonzalez had worked there four years, her pay increased to $80 a day, which was still below minimum wage. She recalled hearing her employer often proclaim to workers, many of whom were working illegally in the country, that no one could win against him in court.

headline: Another Sunday Dominated by Donald Trump
text: Donald J. Trump may have found himself on the defensive this weekend for his remarks criticizing the moderators of Thursday’s Republican presidential debate. But even under attack, Mr. Trump seems to be dominating the Republican primary campaign.

headline: Review: In ‘A Moon for the Misbegotten,’ Audra McDonald Is Front and Center
text: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. — She may be wild-eyed, dusty and barefoot, and wearing a dress that looks like it doubles as a heavy-duty cleaning rag. But from the moment you set eyes on her at the beginning of the Williamstown Theater Festival’s production of Eugene O’Neill’s “A Moon for the Misbegotten,” you never for a second doubt the supreme, comforting competence of the rowdy farm gal named Josie Hogan.

headline: K-Pop Fans Swoon During East Coast KCON
text: NEWARK — The tears began as soon as Teen Top waved hello.

headline: Review: Celebrating Partnership, Mostly Apart, in ‘Solo for Two’
text: On Friday, the Russian dynamos Natalia Osipova and Ivan Vasiliev zipped into City Center for “Solo for Two,” a program intended to highlight an artistic partnership that was once personal as well as professional.

headline: Smile!
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — Even on a Monday, there has to be a mental separation between the solving of a puzzle and the full understanding of the theme. That gap is where your brain takes all of the theme clues, digests them and then delivers that “Aha!” moment that we all know and love. The gap can’t be too short, because that would mean that the theme is too obvious, and that’s no fun. It can’t be too long, because then it wouldn’t be a Monday puzzle. It’s an art to get it just right.

headline: Scenes From Ferguson’s Protests
text: A year after the death of Michael Brown, protesters marched in Ferguson to mark the anniversary of the shooting of the black teenager by a white police officer.

headline: Instagram Takes on Growing Role in the Art Market
text: Anyone in the art market who was not already paying attention to the social media platform Instagram had to sit up and take notice in April after the actor Pierce Brosnan visited the showroom of Phillips auction house in London. Mr. Brosnan snapped a selfie in front of a work he admired: the “Lockheed Lounge,” a space-age aluminum chaise longue by the industrial designer Marc Newson. Then he added the words “let the bidding commence,” and posted it to the 164,000 followers of his Instagram feed.

headline: Harper Lee and Truman Capote: A Collaboration in Mischief
text: One summer about 85 years ago in a small Alabama town, a scrappy tomboy named Nelle met her new next door neighbor, Tru, a bookish, dapper dresser with a high-pitched voice and a mischievous streak.

headline: Review: ‘On Writing,’ a Charles Bukowski Collection of Rants and Musings in Letters
text: Charles Bukowski’s 95th birthday would have been this Sunday. And, inevitably, here comes “On Writing,” a selection of letters, and a scattering of drawings, by that prolific and bellicosely opinionated author, from 1945 to 1993. According to the news release from Ecco, the book is “the first in a series of at least three Bukowski anthologies.” Batten down the hatches, folks — as surely everyone must know by now, this wasn’t a man inclined to edit himself.

headline: Frank Gifford, Giants Icon and Broadcaster, Dies at 84
text: Gifford personified the Giants’ glory years of the late 1950s and early ’60s, then became the low-key play-by-play voice of “Monday Night Football” on ABC.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Aug. 10
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Tyler Drumheller, Ex-C.I.A. Official Who Disputed Bush, Dies at 63
text: Tyler S. Drumheller, a former senior American intelligence official who publicly asserted that President George W. Bush’s administration had knowingly hyped fabricated evidence of Iraq’s arsenal of biological weapons to justify the 2003 invasion, died on Aug. 2 in Falls Church, Va. He was 63.

headline: Vogue Ads Skip a Step, Linking Readers to Target
text: Iconic images from the pages of Vogue are getting a makeover, courtesy of Target.

headline: Carolyn Kaelin, Breast Cancer Surgeon, Patient Advocate and Patient, Dies at 54
text: Dr. Carolyn M. Kaelin, a breast cancer surgeon who continued her research and advocacy for patients after her own diagnosis of breast cancer ended her surgical career, died on July 28 at her home in Charlestown, Mass. She was 54.

headline: ‘Black Lives Matter’ and the G.O.P.
text: Only one candidate in last week’s Republican presidential debate was asked to directly address the Black Lives Matter movement and that candidate was Gov. Scott Walker.

headline: Chobani’s Founder Sees Opportunity in a Coffee Insurgent
text: Having shaken up the yogurt world, Hamdi Ulukaya, the founder of Chobani, now has his sights on a much tougher target — coffee.

headline: N.F.L. to Weigh Three Teams’ Proposals on Moving to Los Angeles
text: SAN DIEGO — For two decades, N.F.L. owners in search of public funding for their stadiums have often played a trump card: threatening to move to Los Angeles. In a few months, that ultimatum may ring hollow.

headline: Will It Rain? Umbrella Man Knows When
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Sean Price, Rapper With Deep Brooklyn Roots, Dies at 43
text: Sean Price, a rapper who for two decades embodied the rugged essence of peak-era Brooklyn hip-hop, died in his sleep on Saturday morning at his home in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. He was 43.

headline: Argentines Vote in Presidential Primary
text: BUENOS AIRES — Argentines voted to select presidential nominees on Sunday in a primary election that will gauge the nation’s desire for change after 12 years of the current president’s governing party.

headline: Department Store Earnings, Alibaba’s Results and July Retail Sales
text: The Department of Labor will hold four days of public hearings this week to discuss its proposed rule that would require a broader group of financial professionals to put their clients’ interests ahead of their own when handling the clients’ retirement money. The hearings will be held from Monday through Thursday. The White House has estimated that the lack of consumer protection costs investors as much as $17 billion annually, or 1 percent of their assets, and perhaps more. But the rule has faced strong and well-funded opponents in the financial services industry. Those stakeholders, along with consumer advocates including AARP, will have the opportunity to make their arguments to regulators this week. —Tara Siegel Bernard

headline: Cuomo Says Hudson Tunnels Need Grants, Not Loans to States, From U.S.
text: Two weeks after the federal government’s top transportation official urged the governors of New York and New Jersey to meet with him about how to solve the problems plaguing rail service between their states, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York said on Sunday that such a meeting would be pointless unless federal officials offered grants, not loans, to finance new tunnels under the Hudson River.

headline: Fan Throws Back Homer, Leaving Brett Gardner Welted
text: Jose Bautista’s deep home run in the fourth inning of Sunday’s game came back to hurt the Yankees in more ways than one.

headline: Mtime Helps Hollywood Clear China’s Marketing Hurdles and Reach Fans
text: LOS ANGELES — Now that Hollywood has mostly figured out how to get its biggest movies approved for release in China, studio marketers here are grappling with a new puzzle: What is the best way to woo China’s ticket buyers?

headline: Vainglory Breaks Through in E-Sports on a Tablet
text: Under everyone’s noses, the competitive video game scene has gotten huge, with more than 113 million fans globally by some estimates.

headline: A 12-Year-Old Girl, a Rape and a Bronx Neighborhood Left Unsettled
text: In the chill of a February evening, he pulled on a hat that matched his dark blue coat and approached the girl on the Bronx sidewalk caked in snow. She was 12 and, it appeared, not much younger than he was.

headline: Jets Hope Brandon Marshall’s Catches Fix a Snag
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — It was second-and-goal, and the Jets had the ball at the 1-yard line. Lined up to the outside was their hulking new receiver, Brandon Marshall, who feinted right and then broke inside, beating his defender. Quarterback Geno Smith rifled a quick slant, and Marshall grabbed the ball in the end zone.

headline: Investors Find Ways to Indirectly Profit From Valuable Start-Ups
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Airbnb’s valuation has ballooned over the last few years as large financial firms like Fidelity Investments and T. Rowe Price have rushed to invest in the start-up. But a small San Francisco-based hedge fund called Pier 88 Investment Partners has decided that the fervor for Airbnb shares creates a different kind of opportunity.

headline: Rethinking an Olympic Format in Light of Katie Ledecky’s 1,500 Feat
text: KAZAN, Russia — On the eighth day, Katie Ledecky was supposed to rest. So the text message she sent in the hours after her fifth gold-medal swim of the 16th world championships caught its recipient, Scott Leightman, by surprise.

headline: Winning Mantra of ‘I’m Not Sick’ Propels Victoria Duval
text: When Victoria Duval learned last year that she had cancer, the only thing she knew to do was win.

headline: Yankees’ New Look: Over Their Shoulders
text: First, there were no expectations for the Yankees.

headline: Frantic Struggle Leaves Unfamiliar Name, Shane Lowry, Atop Leaderboard
text: AKRON, Ohio — The final round of the Bridgestone Invitational was supposed to unfold as a spirited duel between Jim Furyk and Justin Rose, playing partners who entered the day tied for the lead. Instead, a humid afternoon at Firestone Country Club devolved into a frantic scramble at the top.

headline: Celebrating Dominican Pride
text: The annual Dominican Day Parade made its way through Manhattan on Sunday.

headline: U.S. Air Power and Kurdish Fighters Team Up to Inflict Losses on ISIS
text: But Turkey is nervous about the coordination between the United States and the Kurds, who are seeking autonomy in parts of Turkey and elsewhere.

headline: 3 Men Are in Custody in a String of Rapes and Robberies
text: All three women had placed ads online looking to exchange sex for money, and had arranged to meet with an interested party this summer. Each reported afterward that she had been raped and robbed by three men.

headline: An Eviction to Make Way for an Ex-Convict’s Return
text: For the last three and a half years, Tomoko Watabe, 49, has made Apartment 1C at 46 Downing Street in Manhattan her home, and it shows.

headline: Prostitution Charge Dropped in Case an Albany Journalist Called Retaliation
text: ALBANY — In March 2012, just blocks from the State Capitol, several law enforcement officers stormed into a second-floor spa and arrested a woman, accusing her of soliciting money for sexual acts. An invasive strip search was done, thousands of dollars were seized and the woman, Min Liu, was soon charged with prostitution.

headline: ‘Masters of Sex’ Recap: Bill Waxes On About Love, but Does He Sound Believable?
text: Season 3, Episode 5: “III-A”

headline: Red Bulls Finish Season Sweep of New Rival New York City F.C.
text: HARRISON, N.J. — Just before kickoff at Red Bull Arena on Sunday night, an enormous banner rose above a cloud of red smoke in the stands. On it were caricatures of Frank Lampard and Andrea Pirlo, the veteran international superstars who joined the expansion club New York City F.C. halfway through the M.L.S. season.

headline: One Year After Michael Brown’s Death
text: Protesters returned to the spot where Michael Brown Jr., an unarmed 18-year-old, was killed by a white police officer, setting off local unrest and a national debate on race and policing.

headline: For a Villa Full of Artists, a French Chef Masters His Italian
text: While many Parisians travel to Tuscany in August to enjoy their requisite monthlong holiday, chef Guillaume Rouxel, the former head chef at Inaki Aizpitarte’s smart 11th Arrondissement bistro Le Dauphin, has packed up his cooking knives and traveled to Italy to work. Rouxel has taken on a chef residency at the hip hotel and artist retreat Villa Lena, a sprawling 500-hectare estate perched high up in the hills, just a 50-minute drive from Pisa.

headline: A Sculptor’s Assistant Whose Canvas Is Cake
text: Georgia-Rose Fairman makes desserts that are delicious, beautiful and a little gross: a miniature human figure fashioned after the bold, imperfect beauty of a Lucian Freud nude; a fruits de mer banquet commissioned by the French fashion label Carven. So convincing — and tasty — was the flower-festooned pig’s head that she made for the restaurant critic A. A. Gill’s 60th birthday party, that the chef Heston Blumenthal jokingly threatened to dismiss his own pastry chef. Fairman, an assistant to the sculptor Phyllida Barlow, started baking two years ago in her London studio, when she decided to make something for her boyfriend’s birthday. Rather than the usual chocolate gateau, she got ambitious, precision-carving blocks of marzipan-covered sponge cake before painting them with edible watercolors to create what looked exactly like a roast chicken complete with carrots, potatoes and peas. “It’s a weird cross between food and sculpture,” she says. “The main thing for me is that they look like still-life paintings.”

text: egotistical • \ˈe-gə-ˈtis-ti-kəl\ • adjective

headline: Study of Ad-Blocking Software Suggests Wide Use
text: Guillermo Beltrà spends a lot of time surfing the web.

headline: Hillary Clinton to Offer Plan on Paying College Tuition Without Needing Loans
text: With Americans shouldering $1.2 trillion in student loan debt, and about eight million of them in default, Hillary Rodham Clinton on Monday will propose major new spending by the federal government that would help undergraduates pay tuition at public colleges without needing loans.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
text: 6 A.M. (Animal Planet) WORLD LION DAY In remembrance of Cecil (above), who was illegally killed last month in Zimbabwe, and others, Animal Planet presents some of its most memorable lion programming, starting with “Last Lion of Liuwa,” about the sole survivor of a massacre that destroyed the rest of the pride. The lineup continues with “Big Cat Diary,” which tracks lions, cheetahs and leopards roaming the Masai Mara National Reserve in Kenya, at 7; “Into the Lion’s Den,” which follows Dave Salmoni, a large-predator expert, into lion territory as he tries to prove that the creatures are more likely to accept people than attack them, at 10; “Into the Pride,” in which Mr. Salmoni works to save rogue lions from elimination, at noon; and “A Lion Called Christian,” about the story behind the Internet phenomenon depicting the emotional reunion between two men and their 300-pound captive lion a year after it was released into the wild, at 5 p.m. Nat Geo Wild also commemorates big-cat conservation from noon through 8 p.m.

headline: Top 10 Fantasy Football Quarterbacks
text: Jason and Justin Sablich, who provide fantasy football analysis for The New York Times, pick their 10 favorite quarterbacks for 2015.

headline: 2015 Fantasy Football: Quarterback Preview and Rankings
text: For anyone who played fantasy football last season, it should be no secret that the quarterback position is deep and loaded with value ripe for the picking.

headline: South Korea Accuses the North After Land Mines Maim Two Soldiers in DMZ
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korean soldiers sneaked across the heavily guarded border with South Korea and planted land mines near one of the South’s military guard posts, and two southern soldiers were maimed after stepping on them, the South Korean Defense Ministry said Monday.
