headline: Marco Rubio, Amid Soaring Moments, Sticks to Steady Course
text: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida earned glowing praise and predictions about how formidable a contender he would be when he announced his run for the White House in April. Then he disappeared on a two-month fund-raising trip.

headline: Data on Use of Force by Police Across U.S. Proves Almost Useless
text: WASHINGTON — When the Justice Department surveyed police departments nationwide in 2013, officials included for the first time a series of questions about how often officers used force.

headline: 1940: British Fight Off 400 Raiders
text: LONDON — Out of a cloud-checked Sabbath sky over the English Channel, 400 Nazi warplanes struck yesterday at the British south coast naval bases of Portland and Weymouth, at balloon defense on the southeast coast in Kent and at a convoy. Two hundred German craft attacked Portland and Weymouth at one time. At 11:30 p.m., the Air Ministry said reports received up to 9 p.m. showed that sixty enemy planes had been shot down, five of them by anti-aircraft fire. The Ministry also raised the total of British losses from its first report of nineteen fighter planes lost to twenty-six, but said the pilots of two were saved. — New York Herald Tribune, August 12, 1940

headline: Workers Stage Strike at National Gallery in London
text: LONDON — Around 200 staff members at the National Gallery here went on an indefinite strike Tuesday in a dispute over the gallery’s plans to privatize some of its services.

headline: S.E.C. Complaint in Hacker-Insider Trading Case
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission said that defendants made trades based on illegally obtained information and reaped over $100 million in unlawful profits.

headline: NBC ‘Nightly News’ Holds Lead in Fight for Viewers
text: Six months after Brian Williams was suspended without pay from his position as the anchor of NBC’s “Nightly News” show, the broadcast has held its lead in the fierce battle for viewers.

headline: Grilled Halloumi for a Light Summer Meal
text: Halloumi is a firm, white, brined cheese traditionally made from a mixture of goat’s and sheep’s milk. (Though today, cow’s milk is often used.) Like other low-fat cheeses, it is perfect for grilling. It sears and colors quickly when it hits the hot grill. The interior softens, but the cheese doesn’t melt; it just warms up invitingly.

headline: From Underarm Hair to Summer Turtlenecks, Styles Trends Are Hot
text: At the end of last year, I published a list of what I would like to see happen at The Times in 2015. Because I was having a little fun with the listicle format, which seems to require an odd, preferably prime, number in its title, I called it “17 Hopes and Dreams for The Times in the New Year.”

headline: Seth Meyers Decides to Take a Seat to Deliver His ‘Late Night’ Monologue
text: When audience members at Monday’s broadcast of “Late Night” finished applauding and took their seats, the host Seth Meyers did something unusual: He sat down, too.

headline: Geno Smith Is Sucker-Punched in the Latest Bizarre Blow to the Jets
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — It had been nearly two weeks since absurdity befell the Jets, an epoch in their tormented history.

headline: China’s Currency Dilemma
text: China’s decision to devalue its currency, the renminbi, by 2 percent against the dollar on Tuesday is intended to give its slowing economy a boost. But the decision is likely to be seen by lawmakers in the United States and elsewhere as currency manipulation to increase Chinese exports at the expense of producers in other countries.

headline: Palestinian Prisoner’s Case Tests Israeli Force-Feeding Law
text: ASHKELON, Israel — The first Palestinian prisoner who could be forced to stay alive under a new Israeli law lies shackled to a hospital bed, vomiting bile and blood after 57 days of drinking only water to protest his indefinite incarceration without charges.

headline: Competitiveness and Class Warfare
text: For reasons not entirely clear to me, recently I found myself thinking about Lester Thurow’s Head to Head: The Coming Economic Battle Among Japan, Europe, and America. For those too young, or who don’t remember, Thurow’s book was a monster best-seller in the early 1990s; it resonated with many people who feared that America was losing its economic edge, that Japan was an unstoppable juggernaut, and so on. And it also played into the general notion of global economics as a struggle for competitive advantage, which is a perennial popular favorite.

headline: Leaf Bar and Lounge Joins the Asian Rush in Flushing
text: Leaf Bar and Lounge Flushing, Queens, is already chockablock with Asian restaurants and bars, but this new rooftop enclave is notable for its inventive drinks, like a chrysanthemum old-fashioned. Leaf Bar and Lounge, which opens Wednesday, is on top of a Hyatt hotel at One Fulton Square. It is the latest in the growing collection of Asian restaurants in this new multistory complex. The bar offers a menu of small plates like pork-belly buns, yellowtail collar, dumplings and popcorn chicken. The chef is Henry Lin, a Taiwan native. Already open at One Fulton Square are the Coop, a bar and restaurant specializing in Korean fried chicken; Good Harvest, a branch of a big hot-pot chain in China; Rong Restaurant, for Chinese regional cuisine; and Iki, a Japanese restaurant with a variety of dishes and wagashi sweets: One Fulton Square, 39-16 Prince Street, (Roosevelt Avenue), Flushing, Queens, onefultonsquareflushing.com.

headline: The Latest Snapchat Update, Explained
text: Snapchat released its newest update for Android and iPhone. Here’s a review of the new features. Find us on Snapchat, username: thenytimes

headline: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week 7 | On ‘Why Is It So Hard to Get a Great Bagel in California?’
text: Every week, a rotating group of judges helps choose our Summer Reading Contest winner, runners-up and honorable mentions. A few of the judges, however, have now been on the panel all seven weeks, and they agree that this week’s crop of essays was, overall, the strongest yet.

headline: Amnesty International Votes for Policy Calling for Decriminalization of Prostitution
text: PARIS — After days of emotional debates and intense lobbying, delegates from Amnesty International voted on Tuesday to support a policy that calls for decriminalization of the sex trade, including prostitution, payment for sex and brothel ownership.

headline: Ikemefuna Enemkpali, the Backup Who Broke Geno Smith’s Jaw
text: With one punch, Ikemefuna Enemkpali transformed himself from a little known third-string linebacker into a figure of infamy for the Jets.

headline: Easiest Vanilla Ice Cream
text: Julia Moskin makes Philadelphia-style vanilla ice cream.

headline: Homemade Ice Cream, Without All the Heat
text: Here’s what most people say when you brag to them about your recipe for no-cook ice cream:

headline: After 2 Killers Fled, New York Prisoners Say, Beatings Were Next
text: Night had fallen at the Clinton Correctional Facility in far northern New York when the prison guards came for Patrick Alexander. They handcuffed him and took him into a broom closet for questioning. Then, Mr. Alexander said in an interview last week, the beatings began.

headline: Showtime To Produce Series Based on Patti Smith’s ‘Just Kids’
text: LOS ANGELES — Showtime announced Tuesday that it had acquired the rights to Patti Smith’s memoir, “Just Kids” and would adapt it into a limited TV series.

headline: Why Misleading Americans About Climate Change Is Dangerous
text: Even as the Pope and some conservatives call for action on climate change, it remains common among Republican politicians to claim that the science on the issue is murky or inconclusive. The latest to take this position is Gov. John Kasich of Ohio.

headline: Labour Party, Leaning Left, Looks to Outsider Jeremy Corbyn
text: LONDON — “A working-class hero,” John Lennon wrote in 1970, “is something to be.”

headline: Ted Cruz Gets a Boost in Mississippi From a Tea Party Stalwart
text: OLIVE BRANCH, Miss. – Perched on a barstool at Sweetpea’s Table here was a Tea Party favorite whose political rise alarmed the Republican leadership last year. And pacing the stage in front of him and delivering a rousing speech was Senator Ted Cruz.

headline: Swing House Seat in New Hampshire May Have Another Rematch
text: New Hampshire’s First Congressional District is one of the nation’s dwindling number of genuine swing districts — and, in recent elections, it has bounced back and forth between the same two candidates, with the incumbent losing each time.

headline: Colorado Governor Visits Polluted River
text: Governor John Hickenlooper of Colorado announced that the Animas River is beginning to improve after an accidental spill of toxic wastewater by Environmental Protection Agency workers.

headline: Tracy Morgan Crash Largely Result of Truck Driver’s Fatigue, Regulators Say
text: Federal transportation regulators on Tuesday cited a Walmart truck driver’s fatigue as the chief cause of a crash last year that killed the comedian James McNair and critically injured Tracy Morgan, a star of the television series “30 Rock.”

headline: You’ll Love What We’re Doing With the Place
text: SPECIAL POST — Human nature loves a routine, but sometimes change is necessary. Change can bring vast improvements to how you get your crossword puzzle, from keeping track of streaks and statistics to easily accessing the more than 8,000 crossword puzzles in our Archive. You’ve given us your feedback and we listened.

headline: Tech Breakups Show Bigger Is Not Necessarily Better
text: Symantec is revealing the truth about tech mergers and acquisitions. Offloading its data storage and recovery business Veritas for $8 billion to the buyout firm Carlyle and GIC of Singapore ends a decade-long disaster of a deal. Like Hewlett-Packard, Microsoft and others, Symantec discovered that it can be harder to buy than to build. The resulting carve-ups and write-downs, though, have a tendency to perpetuate the problem.

headline: Kickstarter Campaign Aims to Fund ‘Kids’ Documentary
text: LOS ANGELES – Some of Larry Clark’s “Kids” became stars. Others committed suicide or died of drug overdoses. A couple more, 20 years later, are still trying to make sense of a movie, a place, a time and themselves.

headline: Liftoff
text: Flight time: 10 seconds.

headline: Mystery Over Jury Notes in Manhattan Psychic’s Trial Is Solved
text: A mystery over two jury notes sent during a 2013 larceny trial of a Manhattan psychic has been resolved, dampening the hopes of the psychic, who has appealed her conviction.

headline: Buying Car Insurance for Teenagers Can Be a Balancing Act
text: Adding a teenager to a family’s auto insurance policy is a sure way to raise the premiums, but it’s usually less expensive than buying a separate policy, according to new research.

headline: Philosophers Jürgen Habermas and Charles Taylor to Share $1.5 Million Prize
text: The German philosopher Jürgen Habermas and the Canadian philosopher Charles Taylor will share this year’s $1.5 million John W. Kluge Prize for Achievement in the Study of Humanity. The prize, inaugurated in 2003 and awarded by the Library of Congress, is intended to recognize work in disciplines not covered by the Nobel prizes.

headline: Review: Clarice Lispector’s ‘The Complete Stories’ Sees Life With Existential Dread
text: On the very first page of the Brazilian writer Clarice Lispector’s “The Complete Stories,” she signals that hers was never an ordinary sensibility, but one capable of perceiving anxiety and menace in even the most routine phenomena. The story in question was her debut as a writer, published in 1940 when she was just 19. Called “The Triumph,” it begins with a woman awakening to a “bright stain of sunlight” that leaves her motionless in bed, “crucified by lassitude.”

headline: Review: Archana Joglekar Presents a Dazzling Solo at Drive East
text: In the last couple of years, the Drive East festival, a celebration of classical Indian music and dance, has packed the small First Floor Theater at La MaMa. Opening night of the third edition, on Monday, seemed more sparsely attended than usual, perhaps because there were more seats to fill. This year’s festival has moved to the cavernous Ellen Stewart Theater, and the Kathak dancer Archana Joglekar, in a vibrant solo program, made the extra space work to her advantage.

headline: In El Salvador, Gangs Hold on to Power
text: Murder rates have soared as the government has struggled to rein in criminal organizations.

headline: El Salvador Cracks Down on Crime, but Gangs Remain Unbowed
text: SAN SALVADOR — Seven bus drivers are killed in four days. A morgue worker slowly counts 224 stab wounds on a murder victim. Police officers post memorials to slain comrades and photographs of “eliminated” suspects on Facebook.

headline: New York City’s Responsible Banking Act Is Unconstitutional, a Judge Rules
text: A law passed by New York City three years ago that required banks to make public their efforts to be socially responsible, particularly in low-income neighborhoods, is unconstitutional, according to a federal court ruling.

headline: Birdland Club to Open a Theater Next Spring
text: The Birdland jazz club announced that the Birdland Theater, a 100-seat space that will occupy the lower level of the club at 315 West 44th Street in Manhattan, would open in the spring. The programming will include cabaret, jazz, dance, burlesque and comedy.

headline: Are Times Readers Smarter Than a 3rd Grader?
text: You might remember the reading passage about an anthropomorphic pineapple that appeared on New York State’s eighth-grade tests a few years ago. Some of the accompanying questions were so confusing that the state decided not to count the answers in students’ scores.

headline: Kodak’s First Digital Moment
text: In the mid-1970s a young engineer invented the digital photographic process. Some of his bosses were not impressed. His employer? Eastman Kodak.

headline: Review: ‘How to Smell a Rose,’ Ricky Leacock at His French Farmhouse
text: Through its subject and its maker, “How to Smell a Rose” puts us in the vibrant presence of documentary history. Ricky Leacock — the film’s twinkly man of the hour — helped pioneer the documentary approach called direct cinema in the 1960s, using portable cameras and synchronized sound to record everyone from John F. Kennedy to a mother of quintuplets. But in his nine decades on earth, Mr. Leacock also apprenticed with Robert J. Flaherty, director of the silent classic documentary “Nanook of the North”; shot combat photography in World War II; taught rising filmmakers at M.I.T.; and embraced shooting on video.

headline: Plaxico Burress’s Game-Winning Super Bowl Catch
text: Arlo White calls Plaxico Burress’s touchdown catch that won Super Bowl XLII for the Giants against the Patriots.

headline: David Tyree’s Memorable Super Bowl Catch
text: Arlo White calls the David Tyree’s catch that helped the Giants win Super Bowl XLII.

headline: Curiae Veteres Sanctuary in Rome Attracts the Curious
text: ROME — Archaeologists working on the Palatine Hill here this summer excavated parts of sixth-century B.C. foundations connected to a sanctuary of a cult that ancient sources trace back to Romulus, Rome’s mythic founder — a rare find from such an early period.

headline: Facts & Figures: Change Could Keep Thousands of Kansans From Voting
text: A proposal by Secretary of State Kris Kobach of Kansas could cancel the voter registration applications of over 30,000 Kansans who haven’t yet provided proof of citizenship. Under current regulations, they have until Election Day to do so — the new proposal would void their applications if they don’t provide the necessary documents within 90 days.

headline: Review: UP’s ‘Ties That Bind’
text: Many have tried, but when it comes to making television that is both family- and faith-friendly, few have produced anything other than unwatchable mush. The UP network, though, has shown signs of being the exception, and its first original scripted series, which begins on Wednesday night, is another respectable offering.

headline: Classical Playlist: ‘Siegfried Idyll,’ Rachmaninoff and ‘I Have Set My Hert So Hy’
text: ‘SIEGFRIED IDYLL’Works by Liszt, Wagner and Brahms; David Deveau, pianist (Steinway & Sons)

headline: Jets Coach Todd Bowles on Fight
text: Coach Bowles of the Jets said Tuesday that the quarterback Geno Smith will be out six to 10 weeks after a punch from a teammate left him with a broken jaw.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Trading Scheme Tied to Ukraine
text: Paul J. Fishman, the United States attorney for New Jersey, said that nine people were charged after stealing corporate news releases and using the information to make over $100 million.

headline: Why This Movie Now? Planning Release Dates, From ‘Straight Outta Compton’ to ‘Meru’
text: Each week brings with it dozens of new cinematic offerings, and this one is no different.

headline: An ‘Apollo’ Debut and a Balanchine Celebration at Vail International Dance Festival
text: VAIL, Colo. — The Vail festival spoils dancegoers. We start to feel that every theater should be surrounded by pine-clad mountains and approached by a path featuring a rushing river (and at least one hummingbird).

headline: Five Difficult Characters that Delight Billy Eichner
text: The comedian famous for yelling at people on the street rounds up five misanthropic characters he adores abhorring.

headline: China’s Currency Move Clouds Its Policy Goals
text: HONG KONG — As President Xi Jinping of China prepares for a state visit to Washington next month to smooth over troubled relations, his government has just turned the spotlight back on a recurring issue: the value of his country’s currency.

headline: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
text: Good evening. Here’s the latest.

text: Greece and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: August 11, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Greece, Myanmar, Portugal and Germany.

text: Here’s what you need to know.

headline: Is the New Google More Like Berkshire Hathaway, General Electric or AT&T?
text: Google’s decision to restructure is the strongest signal yet that it intends to be a 21st-century innovator, a bold creator of new products, not simply a harvester of profits from its lucrative search engine business.

headline: A Conversation With John C. Tashjian
text: Mr. Tashjian, 45, is a founder and principal of Centurion Real Estate Partners, a New York-based company that develops, acquires and manages commercial property. Centurion’s most recent project is River & Warren, a condominium conversion it is developing in partnership with Five Mile Capital Partners.

headline: How China Is Trying to Stabilize Its Economy
text: China’s devaluation of the renminbi was the latest in a series of moves over the past two months to help boost the slowing Chinese economy.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
text: RECENT SALE

headline: Heck of a Class Project: An ‘Affordable, Robust, Compact’ Fusion Reactor Design, Buildable in a Decade
text: It’s a sure bet that the best known “arc reactor” in the world is the glowing energy source in the chest of Tony Stark, the inventor with a superhero complex at the heart of the “Iron Man” film franchise.

headline: A Milestone in Africa: No Polio Cases in a Year
text: It has been one full year since polio was detected anywhere in Africa, a significant milestone in global health that has left health experts around the world quietly celebrating.

headline: Moments Before Ferguson Shooting
text: St. Louis County investigators posted a surveillance video on Tuesday that they say shows Tyrone Harris pulling out a handgun. The man, wearing a white shirt, appears near the end of the video.

headline: G.E. Continues Sell-Off With Health Care Lending Business
text: General Electric continued its campaign to shrink its huge finance arm, announcing on Tuesday that it will sell its health care lending business to Capital One for about $9 billion.

headline: ‘King Lear With Sheep.’ Yes, Sheep.
text: LONDON — A new adaptation of “King Lear,” will open at the Courtyard Theater here on Wednesday.

headline: Arlington, Tex., Officer Is Fired in Fatal Shooting of Christian Taylor
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — A white rookie police officer who shot and killed an unarmed black college football player after the youth had broken into a car dealership in this Dallas suburb was fired on Tuesday for “inappropriate judgment” in his handling of the situation, officials said.

headline: Showtime Reveals ‘Twin Peaks’ Details
text: LOS ANGELES — Showtime’s revival of “Twin Peaks” is back on track  after a dispute over the show’s budget this spring between the network and the co-creator of the series, David Lynch, led to uncertainty over its return.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,346 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: How Hackers Made $1 Million by Stealing One News Release
text: A scheme, announced by federal authorities on Tuesday, to hack into three news wire services to steal copies of corporate news releases went on for years, and required a good deal of patience and persistence. For a while, it seemed to pay off.

headline: One Year Later, ‘Bouncy Bridge’ in Brooklyn Remains Closed
text: After missing a number of reopening dates, the so-called bouncy bridge of Brooklyn Heights reached a dubious milestone on Tuesday: It has now been closed for repairs for exactly one year.

headline: John Riggi, Who Led New Jersey Crime Family, Dies at 90
text: John Riggi, a convicted New Jersey labor racketeer who was often mistakenly cited as an inspiration for the acclaimed HBO series “The Sopranos,” died on Aug. 3 at his home in Edison, N.J. He was 90.

headline: Google Goal in Restructuring as Alphabet: Autonomy
text: SAN FRANCISCO — For a glimpse of how Larry Page might envision the way a newly restructured Google will work, take a look at Nest Labs, the company’s Internet-connected thermostat business.

headline: Newlyweds Are Accused of Planning to Join ISIS
text: A newlywed Mississippi couple who were arrested on the way to the airport for a trip to Syria to join the Islamic State were ordered held without bail on Tuesday.

headline: Serena Williams Recovers After Another Middling Start
text: TORONTO — Given its beginning, Serena Williams’s hardcourt season may well look like the clay and grass-court campaigns that preceded it. And her march toward a calendar-year Grand Slam will most likely require stepping into potholes along the way.

headline: Global Selling Shows Concerns About China’s Weakness
text: After China shocked investors on Tuesday by devaluing the country’s currency, a wave of selling swept the globe. The price of oil plunged, the currencies of other countries tumbled and stock markets skidded on every continent.

headline: Ann McGovern, Author, Is Dead at 85; She Made ‘Stone Soup’ a School Staple
text: Ann McGovern, a prolific author for children whose work ranged over women’s history, adaptations of folk tales and her own exploits as a globe-trotting adventurer, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 85.

headline: Donald Trump Defines His Style: Deal-Making Flexibility
text: BIRCH RUN, Mich. — Donald J. Trump’s plan to combat the Islamic State? “We go in, we knock the hell out of ’em, we take the oil,” he told Fox News on Tuesday.

headline: New Diplomacy Seen on U.S.-Russian Efforts to End Syrian Civil War
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — With President Bashar al-Assad of Syria facing battlefield setbacks, diplomats from Russia, the United States and several Middle Eastern powers are engaged in a burst of diplomatic activity, trying to head off a deeper collapse of the country that could further strengthen the militant group Islamic State.

headline: Schumer Says Corporation Should Oversee Hudson Tunnels Project
text: Senator Chuck Schumer, seeking an end to the standoff over financing new Hudson River rail tunnels, proposed on Tuesday creating a nonprofit corporation to oversee the project and to assemble the billions of dollars needed to build new tunnels.

headline: Any Sexual Abuse by Guards May Violate Inmates’ Rights, Court Says
text: Any malicious sexual contact by prison guards against inmates may amount to a constitutional violation, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday, noting how standards of decency have changed in the past two decades.

headline: Head of Group Opposing Iran Accord Quits Post, Saying He Backs Deal
text: WASHINGTON — When the bipartisan advocacy group United Against Nuclear Iran decided last week to mobilize opposition against the nuclear deal with Tehran, Gary Samore knew he could no longer serve as its president.

headline: E.P.A. Treating Toxic Water From Abandoned Colorado Mine After Accident
text: DENVER — Nearly a week after the Environmental Protection Agency accidentally breached a store of chemical-laced water from an abandoned mine in southwest Colorado, toxic water continues to spill at a rate of 500 to 700 gallons a minute, E.P.A. officials said Tuesday.

headline: Puerto Rico to Issue $750 Million in Revenue Bonds for Construction
text: Eight days after it defaulted on bond payments for the first time, the government of Puerto Rico said on Tuesday that it planned to issue $750 million more in bonds for an array of construction and maintenance projects.

headline: Hillary Clinton Directs Aides to Give Email Server and Thumb Drive to the Justice Department
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton has directed her aides to give the Justice Department an email server that housed the personal account that she used exclusively while secretary of state, along with a thumb drive that contained copies of the emails, her presidential campaign said on Tuesday.

headline: Jeb Bush Blames Hillary Clinton and Obama for Iraq’s Decline
text: SIMI VALLEY, Calif. — The war in Iraq, which dominated American presidential politics in 2004 and 2008, has returned as an issue in 2016. This time, the argument is not over whether the United States should have gone to war, but rather how the Obama administration sought to end it.

headline: Handling of Donald Trump Puts Fox News on the Spot
text: It started with Megyn Kelly’s interrogation of Donald J. Trump at Thursday night’s debate on Fox News. Mr. Trump wasted no time responding, in less than presidential terms. The network’s chief executive, Roger E. Ailes, intervened, placating Mr. Trump while also defending his star anchor, Ms. Kelly.

headline: An Aging Nomad, Jose Reyes Longs for a Team in the Hunt
text: It was around midnight, and Jose Reyes was sleeping in his Toronto home when his wife received a call from a Toronto Blue Jays trainer summoning him to the ballpark. Reyes had spent the off day mostly hanging around the house. At 32, he needed ample rest and recovery.

headline: In Former Hummer Plant in Indiana, Mercedes Turns Out S.U.V.s for China
text: MISHAWAKA, Ind. — The steady comeback of the American auto industry has brought new life to underused factories, as carmakers across the country add shifts of workers to meet growing demand for new vehicles.

headline: Police Officer With U.N. Force in Central African Republic Is Accused of Rape
text: UNITED NATIONS — In the latest allegation of child sexual abuse by peacekeepers in the Central African Republic, a United Nations police officer is accused of raping a 12-year-old girl in the capital, Bangui, during a nighttime house-to-house search, according to Amnesty International.

headline: Questions of Focus Hover Over Tiger Woods
text: HAVEN, Wis. — Tiger Woods’s new, and first, sports bar and restaurant opened Monday night in Jupiter, Fla. About 18 hours later, Woods was on the practice range at Whistling Straits, preparing for his 18th P.G.A. Championship.

headline: Straight Outta History, the Rage That Makes Movies
text: LOS ANGELES — Universal Pictures took on one of its more delicate challenges on Tuesday: making sure that the studio’s film “Straight Outta Compton” heals more wounds than it reopens.

headline: Review: In ‘John,’ Pondering Life’s Mysteries From Gettysburg
text: If chintz could speak, I’m sure it would sound like Georgia Engel, whose girlish purr must be the most comforting voice possessed by man or woman. The comparison springs to mind because Ms. Engel is presiding over a virtual museum of chintz — and cute tchotchkes, and stuffed animals, and dainty figurines — in the new Annie Baker play, “John,” which opened on Tuesday night at the Signature Center.

headline: Glaxo Closes Plant After Legionnaires’ Bacterium Is Found
text: GlaxoSmithKline temporarily shut down a major pharmaceutical manufacturing plant in North Carolina on Tuesday after the bacterium that causes Legionnaires’ disease was discovered in a cooling tower.

headline: Looking Within
text: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — When there are starred clues in a puzzle, I immediately scan the list to see if there is a revealer that will help me guess the theme. It’s not always successful, but occasionally it pays off. Today was not one of those days, but that’s on me: I forgot that Tom McCoy tends to see things through a mathematical lens.

headline: Carmelo Anthony Takes Step in Test of Knee
text: Carmelo Anthony took part in a light, noncontact workout on Tuesday in Las Vegas, where U.S.A. Basketball convened a three-day training camp this week involving more than 30 N.B.A. players. It was a small but noteworthy step for Anthony, 31, who has not played basketball since February, when he underwent surgery to repair a damaged tendon in his left knee.

headline: Matt Harvey Proves Stellar in Shutout as Mets Defeat the Rockies
text: On Tuesday, with about eight weeks remaining in the season, the Mets sent their season-ticket holders directions for buying tickets for potential postseason games at Citi Field. As part of the package, the Mets were selling hypothetical seats to the World Series — and it was not a cruel joke.

headline: Donald Trump Lashes Out at Bush
text: While speaking at a campaign event in Michigan Tuesday, the Republican presidential candidate called Jeb Bush’s comments on women’s health issues a “disaster.”

headline: Rikers Inmate Has Legionnaires’ Disease; Officials Find No Link to Outbreak
text: A Rikers Island inmate has Legionnaires’ disease, New York City officials said on Tuesday, quickly adding that it was unlikely the case was connected to an outbreak in the South Bronx that has killed 12 people since early July.

headline: Arlington Police Chief Addresses Media
text: Will D. Johnson, the Arlington, Tex., police chief, said the officer who fatally shot an unarmed black teenager at a Dallas-area car dealership had been fired.

headline: China Weakens Its Currency Further
text: HONG KONG — China weakened its currency, the renminbi, for a second straight day on Wednesday, jolting markets across Asia and raising concerns about the path of the giant economy.

headline: Own a Piece of Le Corbusier’s Tree
text: At Le Corbusier’s Villa Le Lac near Geneva — one of the architect’s first projects, which he designed for his parents in 1924 — a felled giant Paulownia tree has been turned into a series of collectible objects by the Spanish designer Jaime Hayon. In partnership with the Italian furniture manufacturer Cassina, Hayon has fashioned birds, birdhouses and swing-shaped shelves from the wood of the ancient tree, whose branches once created a canopy over the property’s waterfront terrace.

headline: A New Tuscan Spa in a Centuries-Old Granary
text: Tucked away in the Siena region of central Tuscany, the idyllic Hotel Monteverdi has opened a heavenly new spa in partnership with Santa Maria Novella, the cult skin-care and fragrance label (and one of the most storied apothecaries in the world). Housed in a centuries-old granary, the space offers an extensive menu of treatments including olive- and grapeseed-oil massages and outdoor mineral baths overlooking the rolling countryside.

headline: The Art of the Sculpturally Unfinished Updo
text: On the fall runways, hair was elaborate but undone — like your grandmother’s hair, only crazier.

headline: Camilla Guinness and the Importance of Not Being Earnest
text: From troll dolls to the queen, the interior designer blends Old World elegance and British charm.

headline: Number of Uninsured Has Declined by 15 Million Since 2013, Administration Says
text: WASHINGTON — The number of people without health insurance continues to decline and has dropped by 15.8 million, or one-third, since 2013, the Obama administration said Tuesday.

headline: Word of the Day | pigment
text: pigment • \ˈpig-mənt\ • noun and verb

headline: ‘The Girl on the Train’ Chugs Past 3 Million in Sales
text: When Riverhead Books acquired a thriller from an unknown British novelist last year, it seemed like a bit of a gamble. Foreign suspense novels don’t always resonate with American readers, and the author, Paula Hawkins, was new to writing crime fiction. But the book had a lot going for it, mainly a mesmerizing plot fueled by three unreliable narrators, and Riverhead planned a healthy first print run of 40,000 copies.

headline: Yankees’ Loss in 16th Shrinks Their Lead to Half a Game
text: CLEVELAND — After last weekend, when simply pushing a runner across home plate seemed like such a monumental task for the Yankees, the sight of much-maligned Stephen Drew hitting a home run that ended a 31-inning scoreless streak inspired a sigh of relief Tuesday night.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday
text: 8 P.M. (ABC Family) KEVIN FROM WORK Kevin (Noah Reid), an earnest young office worker, finally gets to quit the worst job in history. Every bit of it stinks, except for the colleague with whom he has shared a cubicle wall for three years: Audrey (Paige Spara), perpetually backlit, her hair tousled by a magical breeze and the wings of the animated bluebirds that suddenly appear every time she is near. And like them, Kevin longs to be close to her. If only she didn’t have a lunk of a boyfriend — which is why Kevin has banished himself and his shredded heart to Italy, but not before pouring his passion into a love letter and mailing it. After all, he’s never going to see her again, right? With a whisper of “(500) Days of Summer” in its DNA — those bluebirds again, and a younger sister (Jordan Hinson) to inflict pain — “Kevin From Work” heralds the return of the single-camera comedy to ABC Family. It also packs a secret weapon in Amy Sedaris, as Kevin’s monster of a boss.

headline: Kodak’s First Digital Moment
text: Imagine a world where photography is a slow process that is impossible to master without years of study or apprenticeship. A world without iPhones or Instagram, where one company reigned supreme. Such a world existed in 1973, when Steven Sasson, a young engineer, went to work for Eastman Kodak.

headline: Keep the Tax on High-End Health Plans
text: Congress is under pressure to repeal an impending tax on the so-called Cadillac health plans offered by many employers. Scores of legislators from each party have endorsed separate bills to repeal it, and candidates for office, pressed by lobbyists from labor unions, business groups and insurers, may join the call for repeal. The tax should probably be adjusted by Congress to eliminate inequities, but outright repeal would be a mistake that would undermine the viability of the Affordable Care Act.

headline: New Dorp, Staten Island: Still Recovering From Sandy
text: Its name comes from the Dutch words for “new village.” But today, New Dorp, a middle-class area on Staten Island’s eastern shore, exudes a spirit that seems to have more to do with the past than anything contemporary or trendy.

headline: President Obama’s Letter to the Editor
text: For the cover story of our Aug. 2 issue, Jim Rutenberg wrote about efforts over the last 50 years to dismantle the protections in the Voting Rights Act of 1965, the landmark piece of legislation that cleared barriers between black voters and the ballot. The story surveyed a broad sweep of history and characters, from United States Chief Justice John Roberts to ordinary citizens like 94-year-old Rosanell Eaton, a plaintiff in the current North Carolina case arguing to repeal voting restrictions enacted in 2013. The magazine received an unusual volume of responses to this article, most notably from President Barack Obama.

headline: Obama Urges Defense of Voting Rights in Letter to the Editor
text: President Obama wrote on Wednesday that voting rights must be “vigorously defended” and called on Congress to restore the Voting Rights Act in the wake of a Supreme Court ruling that invalidated central parts of the historic 1965 law.

headline: Nine Years Ago, Republicans Favored Voting Rights. What Happened?
text: On July 20, 2006, the United States Senate voted to renew the Voting Rights Act for 25 more years. The vote was unanimous, 98 to 0. That followed an overwhelmingly bipartisan vote in the House of Representatives, which passed it by a vote of 390 to 33. President George Bush signed the renewal with apparent enthusiasm a few days later.

headline: Jane Lynch Can’t Resist the Call of the Stage
text: Jane Lynch was holding it in.

headline: As Drug Kingpins Fall in Mexico, Cartels Fracture and Violence Surges
text: CHILAPA, Mexico — For nearly a week, gun-toting masked men loyal to a local drug gang overran this small city along a key smuggling route. Police officers and soldiers stood by as the gunmen patrolled the streets, searching for rivals and hauling off at least 14 men who have not been seen since.

headline: Soccer Broadcaster Pairs Proper English Accent With Unbridled American Verve
text: LEICESTER, England — The voice of English soccer in the United States did not hesitate — not even for a second — when asked for his favorite broadcasting memory.

text: Fighter jets from the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt are supporting Iraqi troops approaching Ramadi, a city overrun by the Islamic State.

headline: U.S. Jets Meet Limit as Iraqi Ground Fight Against ISIS Plods On
text: ABOARD U.S.S. THEODORE ROOSEVELT, in the Persian Gulf — Navy fighter jets roar off this nuclear-powered aircraft carrier in support of Iraqi troops approaching Ramadi, a city in Anbar Province overrun by Islamic State fighters in one of the worst defeats for the American-led coalition.

text: A small amount of exercise may improve our ability to think as we age, but more may not be better, according to a new study of exercise and cognition.

headline: Reporting From Iran, Jewish Paper Sees No Plot to Destroy Israel
text: The first journalist from an American Jewish pro-Israel publication to be given an Iranian visa since 1979 reported Wednesday that he had found little evidence to suggest that Iran wanted to destroy Israel, as widely asserted by critics of the Iranian nuclear agreement.

headline: British Regulator Approves Sale of K-Y to Reckitt Benckiser
text: LONDON — A British regulator on Wednesday signed off on the consumer goods maker Reckitt Benckiser’s planned acquisition of the K-Y brand of personal lubricants, but said it would require the company to license the brand to a competitor in Britain for a period of eight years.

headline: Today in Politics: Jeb Bush Opens New Front in Attack on Hillary Clinton’s Foreign Policy Record
text: Good Wednesday morning from what scientists now say is a dying universe and where Donald J. Trump remains the leader in Republican polls. But while he dabbled in policy discussions and held a large rally in Michigan on Tuesday, one of his major rivals, Jeb Bush, regained some of the spotlight by attacking Hillary Rodham Clinton over the Obama administration’s policies in the Middle East.

headline: What a $15 Minimum Wage Would Mean for Your City
text: As the campaign for a $15 minimum wage has gained strength this year, even supporters of large minimum-wage increases have wondered how high the wage floor can rise before it reduces employment and hurts the economy.

headline: Beijing Hotels to Benefit From Olympic Boom
text: After hosting the Summer Olympics in 2008, Beijing was recently picked for the 2022 Winter Games, the first city to organize both events. The last games fueled a major construction boom and offered the Chinese capital a chance to build world-class hotels. Since then, the pace of construction has not slowed much and, despite the recent economic slowdown, more hotels are planned ahead of the Winter Games.

headline: In Ireland, All Yeats, All Year
text: Celebrations of poets tend to revolve, fittingly, around poetry readings. But on a cool evening in May, the main auditorium of the Abbey, the national theater of Ireland, was filled with enthusiasts of W. B. Yeats who had gathered for a contemporary dance performance inspired in part by his poem “Sailing to Byzantium.” The venue was particularly apt: Yeats co-founded the theater in 1904.

headline: How Do I Handle the Towel Saga Next Door?
text: On Easter Sunday, we always have an egg hunt for our neighbors and the children of our Hispanic housekeeper and yard man. This past Easter, our next-door neighbor invited the kids to swim in their pool afterward. In July, a full three months later, we received an email from our neighbor stating: ‘‘Would you mind reminding your housekeeper that they have a large portion of my swimming towels, I was terribly short this weekend. Hope you had a great Fourth of July.’’ This was the first we heard of missing towels. We did not want our housekeeper to think that we or our neighbor thought the children had taken towels that did not belong to them, so we made the decision to purchase 12 towels and give them to our neighbor. We wrapped them up and left them with a note — ‘‘A little surprise for your generosity.’’ A week later, we found the box of towels with a note back at our door — ‘‘I cannot accept these towels and cannot keep them because it is morally as wrong for me to take your towels as it was for your housekeeper’s children to keep my towels.’’ We do not think the children were morally wrong in intent; they simply did what kids do when getting out of the pool — dry off and then wrap in a towel before piling into cars to go home. Had we known about the towels, we would have collected them at the time, but three months after the fact changes how we think the towels should be regarded. The cost of the towels is not really an issue for us or our neighbors. Should we have tried to retrieve the towels from several families before buying new ones? We are almost certain that our housekeeper was not even aware the children were given towels, as she was at our house the entire swim time cleaning up from the meal. Our effort to replace the towels was meant to defuse the situation, not continue into a towel saga. NAME WITHHELD

headline: The Pleasure of a Steak at Home
text: After staring at the bill for a ridiculously overpriced and not very good rib-eye at a famous steakhouse in Chicago — replete with a sauce so banal it may as well have been ketchup, and served with attitude, too — I remembered I could do better at home. I went to my local butcher (which in my neighborhood just happens to be called the Local Butcher Shop) and paid $60 for a glorious, two-inch thick, fat-laden rib-eye. The plan was to blow the minds of three guests with a piece of meat so good it needed no sauce — and then pair it with sauces that were irresistible on their own.

headline: Morning Agenda: China Weakens Currency Again
text: CHINA WEAKENS CURRENCY AGAIN | The People’s Bank of China set the official midpoint for the renminbi 1.6 percent lower than the day before, at 6.33 per dollar, Neil Gough reports in The New York Times. The second-largest one-day drop since China’s modern foreign exchange system began came directly after a 2 percent devaluation on Tuesday.

headline: Lin-Manuel Miranda, Creator and Star of ‘Hamilton,’ Grew Up on Hip-Hop and Show Tunes
text: His parents own hundreds of Broadway cast albums; his mother blasted “Camelot” in the car and his father is obsessed with “The Unsinkable Molly Brown.”

headline: Perfectly Reasonable Question: Why Not Identify Cornel West in Front-Page Caption?
text: The lead photograph in the print edition of Tuesday’s Times showed protesters marching in St. Louis as part of the commemoration of Michael Brown’s killing last year. In the middle of the frame was a famous face: that of Cornel West, the prominent activist and academic. But the caption, a single sentence, was general and did not identify him.

headline: Tinder Doesn’t Contribute to Hookup Culture (Says Tinder)
text: Like a person scorned after a bad date, the tech company Tinder went a little bit crazy on social media on Tuesday after Vanity Fair published an article blaming technology for the death of dating.

headline: Kids in the Kitchen: Outdoor Fish Fry
text: The master plan? Raising children who can be independent in the kitchen, able to prepare a few healthy meals and snacks and with the confidence to tackle a new recipe or task. In our Kids in the Kitchen series, Motherlode’s KJ Dell’Antonia and Cooking’s Margaux Laskey move their very differently aged families toward that goal. Margaux finds ways for her 3-year-old and toddler to help cook, while KJ stands back and coaches her two 9-year-olds and her 11- and 14-year-olds in cooking on their own.

headline: Alibaba Revenue Misses Expectations; $4 Billion Stock Buyback Is Planned
text: HONG KONG — A year ago, executives of the Chinese e-commerce company Alibaba were preparing a roadshow that paved the way for one of the biggest initial public offerings of stock in history.

headline: Indonesia’s President Replaces Ministers Amid Economic Slowdown
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Less than 10 months into his term, President Joko Widodo of Indonesia on Wednesday fired four cabinet ministers, including crucial members of his economic team, in a much-anticipated reshuffle that reflected growing frustration with his government’s struggles to improve the country’s sluggish economy.

headline: Afghan Panel to Call for Retrial in Death of Farkhunda, a Female Scholar
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A panel of lawyers appointed by Afghanistan’s president to review the murder of Farkhunda, a female Islamic scholar who was killed by a mob of men, plans to recommend that those accused in her death be retried, the group’s leader said on Wednesday.

headline: 1915: Cotton Seen as Key to Peace
text: LONDON — ‘‘If cotton had been declared contraband, the war would have been over last March.’’ Sir Charles Macara and Sir William Ramsay repeated that statement (which they have made before) at the meeting over which Sir Charles presided last night in Queen’s Hall. ‘‘If we stop cotton,’’ Sir William declared, emphatically, ‘‘then we stop this war.’’ (Applause.) ‘‘Cotton is the only substance which the Germans cannot furnish themselves with for ammunition,’’ said Sir William. Wood, hemp, straw, anything that contained wood fibre, was available to make nitric cellulose, but none of these fibres had the ballistic power of cotton. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 13, 1915

headline: Playlist: The Sounds That Shaped ‘Hamilton’
text: He grew up hearing KRS-One and “Cats,” went on to freestyle and to act, and now has created a hit musical, “Hamilton,” that stands out for its successful confection of hip-hop show tunes. How did Lin-Manuel Miranda’s musical aesthetic develop? The New York Times talked with him about how the soundtrack of his life shaped the songs of “Hamilton.” You can read the story here, and below are some of the tunes that helped inform his thinking about music, lyrics, and storytelling through song.

headline: Fidelity National Information Services to Buy Software Maker SunGard
text: Fidelity National Information Services, a large service provider for banks, said on Wednesday that it had agreed to buy SunGard in a cash-and-stock deal that values the financial software company at about $9.1 billion, including debt.

text: CAIRO — A deadly insurgency in Egypt that has been directed largely at soldiers and police officers took a dangerous new turn on Wednesday, as a militant group affiliated with the Islamic State said it had beheaded a Croatian expatriate worker who was kidnapped on the outskirts of Cairo last month.

headline: What the West Gets Wrong About Russia
text: SOFIA, Bulgaria — WHEN George Kennan wrote his famous “Long Telegram,” his 1946 letter to Secretary of State James F. Byrnes that laid the foundation for America’s containment policy against the Soviet Union, he mentioned Joseph Stalin just three times — despite the fact that, by then, the Russian leader ran his country like an emperor.

text: Thom Yorke wrote “Exit Music (for a Film)” in 1996; now he has written exit music, and more, for a play. The Radiohead frontman is composing an original score for the Roundabout Theater Company’s production of Harold Pinter’s “Old Times,” which will open in October at the American Airlines Theater in New York.

text: The history of brawling New York teammates is a long one, with bouts including Jorge Posada-Orlando Hernandez (2002), Darryl Strawberry-Keith Hernandez (1989, on team picture day) and even Billy Martin-Ed Whitson (1985).

text: A United States Army helicopter crashed on Wednesday off the southern Japanese island of Okinawa, injuring seven people on board, officials said.

headline: Mississippi Ban on Adoptions by Same-Sex Couples Is Challenged
text: When Mississippi adopted a one-sentence law forbidding adoptions by same-sex couples in 2000, it was not so surprising: For decades, gay men and lesbians in several states had run into roadblocks when they sought to adopt or foster children.

headline: Bernie Sanders in Statistical Tie With Hillary Clinton in New Hampshire Poll
text: Senator Bernie Sanders is making significant inroads against Hillary Rodham Clinton in New Hampshire, with a new poll showing him in a statistical tie with Mrs. Clinton in the state.

headline: The More China’s Currency Falls, the More It Looks Like a ‘Currency War’
text: There were two stories for why China allowed the value of its currency to fall beginning on Tuesday, one of which makes the government look shortsighted and the other farsighted: It is looking to boost its export sector to combat a weakening economy or it is trying to liberalize its financial system as it ascends the global financial stage.

headline: Love Grows
text: They do not wear wedding rings, or celebrate anniversaries. Their story does not involve a proposal on bended knee. But holding hands in the park? Naturally.

headline: Many Long Walks in Prospect Park, on Duty, Then a Kiss
text: The lowly black walnut nearly ended their romance before it began.

headline: Haruki Murakami’s ‘Wind/Pinball’
text: More than anyone, Haruki Murakami invented 21st-century fiction, which says as much about the 21st century as it does about Murakami. He is the novelist of our mash-up epoch and the subversive who, by intent or not, lit the fuse to whatever “canon” of the previous century anybody still takes seriously. Unless some aging secret master clandestinely labors away at the center of the Tokyo labyrinth, Murakami is the first major Japanese author born in the radioactive white light of the modern age that commenced in the zero-years of 1945, with nuclear decimation by the United States, and, even more traumatically, 1946, with the emperor’s admission to the Japanese public that he wasn’t divine.

headline: ‘A Manual for Cleaning Women,’ by Lucia Berlin
text: Some short story writers — ­Chekhov, Alice Munro, William Trevor — sidle up and tap you gently on the shoulder: Come, they murmur, sit down, listen to what I have to say. Lucia Berlin spins you around, knocks you down and grinds your face into the dirt. You will listen to me if I have to force you, her stories growl. But why would you make me do that, darlin’?

headline: The Peronist Roots of Pope Francis’ Politics
text: BUENOS AIRES — “I wish to join my voice to yours in calling for land, lodging and labor for all our brothers and sisters. I said it and I repeat it: These are sacred rights. It is important, it is well worth fighting for them.” The combative-sounding message of Pope Francis last month on his South American tour resonated deeply in a region where poverty continues to be the most pressing concern.

headline: Six Years After Murder, Guinea-Bissau Autocrat Makes a Posthumous Comeback
text: BISSAU, Guinea-Bissau — A mystery has hung over this sweltering West African capital for six years, but not because no one could solve it. Many people have an answer, though they will not say so in public: Who killed Nino?

headline: Greece Rounds Up Migrants on Kos, Locking Them in Stadium Overnight
text: ATHENS — About a thousand refugees have been locked in a stadium on the Greek island of Kos overnight without food and with very little water, as Greek authorities struggle to contain the rising tide of migrants from war-torn countries, a spokeswoman for Doctors Without Borders said Wednesday.

headline: 1965: Johnson on U.S. Vietnam Role
text: WASHINGTON — President Johnson said today that the United States would not be making sacrifices in South Vietnam ‘‘if its help were not wanted and requested.’’ Mr. Johnson’s remarks, at the swearing in of Henry Cabot Lodge as U.S. ambassador to South Vietnam, were significant in light of reports that Mr. Lodge had told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee July 27 that the United States would keep its forces in South Vietnam even if the Saigon government asked them to leave. Spokesmen insisted yesterday that these reports were inaccurate. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 13, 1965

headline: Pro-Choice Questions, Pro-Life Answers
text: Last week I turned a little bit intemperate in arguing about abortion with members of the conflicted center-left. Now I’m going to try to be a little calmer in pursuing a conversation with the not-at-all-conflicted pro-abortion left, by answering some of the questions that Katha Pollitt posed to her pro-life opponents last fall. I wanted to write a response at the time (she wrote up some of the answers she did receive here), but it slipped by the wayside; now that we’re in the throes of the ongoing Planned Parenthood controversy, it seems like an appropriate time to take her challenge up. So here are the first four of Pollitt’s (meaty) questions, in italics, with my (prolix) responses following; I’ll try to handle the remaining five by this time next week.

headline: Why Turkey Is Fighting the Kurds Who Are Fighting ISIS
text: While the United States has long sought Turkey’s help in fighting ISIS, getting its help has revealed a tangle of diverging interests in the region.

headline: Jon Watts, Director of ‘Cop Car,’ Rocketing to Hollywood From a Viral Video
text: To hear the director Jon Watts talk about his film career, you might think much of it happened by chance. His first feature came about because of a prank video that went viral. His second feature, the new thriller “Cop Car,” was based on a recurring dream and written for fun, but the script drew interest from Kevin Bacon, who stars as the not-so-kind Sheriff Kretzer. And now, Mr. Watts, at 34, has already been tapped for a superhero franchise, the latest “Spider-Man” reboot.

headline: New Releases From Nicholas Payton, Robyn & La Bagatelle Magique and Others
text: Robyn & La Bagatelle Magique

headline: 20% of New York State Students Opted Out of Standardized Tests This Year
text: More than 200,000 third through eighth graders sat out New York’s standardized tests this year, education officials said on Wednesday, in a sign of increasing resistance to testing as more states make them harder to pass.

headline: ‘Évocateur’ on CNN Revisits the Bullying and Bluster of Morton Downey Jr.
text: Between what went on in the first Republican presidential debate and what goes on daily on social media, it sometimes seems that browbeating, not baseball, is America’s pastime. Morton Downey Jr. certainly didn’t invent public nastiness. For verification, see the campaign posters from presidential contests of a century or a century and a half ago. But his nationally syndicated talk show in the 1980s gave bullying and bluster a new prominence. “The Morton Downey Jr. Show” didn’t last long, but others soon picked up the banner and continue to carry it today.

headline: Jets Are a Franchise as Broken as Their Quarterback’s Jaw
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — A dejected Calvin Pace stood outside the Jets’ training complex on Tuesday evening, valiantly trying to make sense of how another black cloud had suddenly appeared over the team.

headline: Battery Dance Festival Offers World and Harbor Views
text: The Battery Dance Festival, which runs from Aug. 15-21, offers a panoramic view of world dance on an outdoor stage with panoramic views of New York harbor. On Monday night the Polish Dance Theater makes its American debut with Takako Matsuda’s “Thousand Colors” and “It’s Already Dusk,” in which Ewa Wycichowska, the company’s director, depicts a symbolic contest between life and death. (It’s inspired by Ingmar Bergman; death, on stilts, looms above everyone.) Enzo Celli and Elisabetta Minutoli’s “Zònton,” for Mr. Celli’s Rome-based VIVO Ballet, takes its title from an ancient Greek word for “living.” Although Kate Thomas’s Ballet Neo is a New York group, her “Fellini’s Dream” evokes the sentimental and grotesque Italy imagined by the film director Federico Fellini. It’s all free, views included. (6:30 p.m., Robert F. Wagner Jr. Park, Battery City, 212-219-3910)

headline: When Online Loan Applications Lead to Unauthorized Bank Account Debits
text: Thousands of cash-strapped Americans who filled out applications for payday loans on sites with names like paymeloans.com instead found their financial details had been used to make unauthorized debits or credit card charges, according to an investigation by federal regulators.

headline: The Afropunk Festival in Brooklyn Explores All the Angles
text: Afropunk, the annual outdoor festival of alternative black music, is an evolving argument against category. This year’s edition, on Aug. 22 and 23 in Brooklyn, includes varying takes on the long and wide R&B tradition from Kelis, SZA and Ms. Lauryn Hill; progressive-pop virtuosity from the bassist Thundercat; enigmatic rapping from Danny Brown; metallic and noisy heaviness from Suicidal Tendencies and Death Grips; futuristic folk from Raury; traditional or mainstream blues and rock from Gary Clark Jr. and Lenny Kravitz.

headline: George Benjamin Reimagines the Pied Piper in ‘Into the Little Hill’
text: George Benjamin’s brilliant opera “Written on Skin” was rightly heralded as the highlight of this summer’s Mostly Mozart Festival. If you weren’t able to snag a ticket, try Sunday’s performance of Mr. Benjamin’s “Into the Little Hill.” This 40-minute chamber opera is a darkly inventive reimagining of the tale of the Pied Piper of Hamelin as a political allegory, with a text by Martin Crimp, the poet behind the astonishingly original libretto to “Written on Skin.” The soprano Hila Plitmann and the mezzo Susan Bickley take on a host of characters, and many of the 15 musicians from the International Contemporary Ensemble multitask, too — watch for unusual instruments including bass flute, cimbalom, banjo and basset-horns.

headline: Met Opens Asian Art Exhibitions Featuring Dynasties’ Silk and Gold
text: The 100th anniversary celebration of the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Asian Art department continues this month with the opening of exhibitions on Chinese lacquer and textiles.

headline: Bigger Is Brighter at the Museum of the Moving Image
text: Table the tablet, shut down the smartphone. From outdoor movies to Imax blockbusters, summer seems built for living large. In that seasonal spirit, the Museum of the Moving Image’s intermittent series “See It Big!” has scheduled a program through Aug. 30 of features shot using 70-millimeter film for images that are brighter and sound that is richer than 35 millimeter can hope to provide. This week alone includes David Lean’s classic “Lawrence of Arabia” and the greatest New York musical, Jerome Robbins and Robert Wise’s “West Side Story.”

headline: A.R. Gurney’s ‘Love & Money’: Wealth, a Widow and Complications
text: The playwright A. R. Gurney may have mused about retirement in the past, but he isn’t going anywhere. In his mid-80s, Mr. Gurney, the longtime chronicler of the white Anglo-Saxon Protestant experience, seems to have a play opening every week. Last season brought a revival of “Love Letters” on Broadway and two productions at the Signature Theater. A revival of his popular comedy “Sylvia” comes to Broadway in September. And his new “Love & Money,” now in previews for an Aug. 24 opening at the Signature, examines the late-in-life introspection of a wealthy widow named Cornelia Cunningham (played by Maureen Anderman) determined to give away all her worldly possessions. The plan of Ms. Cunningham, who is white, hits a snag when an African-American man (Gabriel Brown) arrives at her home saying that he is the child of her dead daughter, putting into question issues of inheritance. (Pershing Square Signature Theater, 212-244-7529, signaturetheatre.org.)

headline: Uggie, Co-Star of ‘The Artist,’ Dies at 13
text: Uggie, the plucky Jack Russell whose co-starring performance in “The Artist” (2011) earned him the Palm Dog and Golden Collar awards, died in Los Angeles on Friday after a battle with a prostate cancer. He was 13.

headline: Want to Shop for a Surprise? Try a Subscription Box
text: Need a monthly delivery of doomsday prepping supplies? How about treats for your pet rabbit, or only-available-in-Japan snacks like Umashi Oasi Cheetos?

headline: Through the Keyholes, Reporting on Prisons
text: Mike Winerip and I have been reporting on New York jails and prisons for more than a year. Doing so is like looking through a keyhole: It is very difficult to get reliable information about what is going on inside a corrections facility.

headline: Sam Elliott, a Leading Man Again at 71, No Cowboy Hat Required
text: MALIBU, Calif. — Not too long ago, the actor Sam Elliott, who has spent much of his 46-year career alternately fighting and embracing habitual typecasting as America’s cowboy, was referred to as a “male ingénue.”

headline: The Quay Twins: Spinning Magic From Marginalia
text: For more than 30 years, identical twins Stephen and Timothy Quay have gradually coaxed life from a baffling combination of everyday objects and handcrafted puppets and sets.

headline: Donald Trump Takes On China After Devaluation
text: When Donald J. Trump announced his run for president in June, much of the focus was on his explosive comments about Mexican immigrants. But he also had another target: China, which he mentioned at least a dozen times, saying, “They’re killing us” economically and that “China comes over and they dump all their stuff” on American markets.

headline: Janet Baker’s Voice, a Singular Instrument, Lingers Like No Other
text: Dance was not the first love of my life among the arts. Growing up in the English countryside, I lived for hours on end in books and beside the gramophone; the first performing art to obsess me was opera. When I first attended opera, at 17, it immediately proved addictive.

headline: For ‘Mistress America,’ Noah Baumbach and Greta Gerwig Serve Screwball With a Whiff of Menace
text: Both of Noah Baumbach’s parents reviewed movies when he was growing up in Brooklyn — his father, Jonathan Baumbach, for Partisan Review, and his mother, Georgia Brown, for The Village Voice. So it may not be a surprise that Mr. Baumbach, 45, became a writer-director whose films often pay homage to screen influences like Woody Allen and Hal Ashby.

headline: International Money Mania
text: China is claiming that it’s not devaluing the renminbi to gain competitive advantage, it’s adding flexibility to prepare for the yuan as an international reserve currency, becoming part of the basket in the IMF’s SDRs and all that. That’s highly implausible as a story about what’s happening right now; but it may be true that China’s urge to loosen capital controls is driven in part by its global-currency ambitions.

headline: Paying for College: Election Edition
text: The Editorial Board recently pointed out that the Democratic presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders have announced plans to make college more affordable, while the only rumbling from the Republican camp so far is Senator Marco Rubio’s support for linking loan repayments to borrowers’ incomes.

headline: Hailee Steinfeld’s Tough, Perforated Leather Skirt
text: The Star: Hailee Steinfeld

headline: F.D.A. Warns Company Over Kardashian Instagram Marketing
text: “OMG. Have you heard about this?”

headline: Excerpt: ‘Show Me a Hero’
text: Oscar Isaac stars as an embattled Yonkers politician in the HBO mini-series.

headline: David Simon and Cory Booker on ‘Show Me a Hero’ and the Future of Cities
text: When the elevator door at the housing project opens onto two men seemingly dealing drugs, a young mother, loaded down with groceries, wordlessly opts to lead her small children lugging backpacks up the decrepit stairs. Across town, an all-white mob fumes before an all-white city council, which eggs it on. Later, a man spits on the mayor, who defies the angry crowd.

headline: U.N. Official Resigns Amid Accusations of Sex Abuse by Peacekeepers
text: UNITED NATIONS — In an exceptional move, the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, on Wednesday ousted his top official in the Central African Republic after repeated accusations that peacekeepers there committed what Mr. Ban called “terrible crimes of sexual violence” against civilians, including children.

headline: Devaluation Hints at China’s Rising Distress Over Economy
text: HONG KONG — Whenever China’s economy swooned in recent downturns, its currency never buckled. It held steady, or strengthened, even as China’s neighbors or trading partners scrambled to cut the value of their own currencies to deal with the fallout.

headline: Filling a Reservoir With ‘Shade Balls’
text: A municipal district in California has been filling its reservoirs with thousands of black balls in an effort to reduce evaporation and deter birds.

headline: Bayreuth Festival, the House That Wagner Built, Stays on Course but Changes
text: BAYREUTH, Germany — Audience members headed to the Bayreuth Festival weren’t happy. The train route from Nuremberg, the principal way to reach this small town in northern Bavaria, was suspended because of construction. They would have to take a bus instead. It would be slow. It would be uncomfortable.

headline: New York Hospitals Group Requests Ban on TV Filming
text: The association that represents nearly all major New York City hospitals has asked its members not to allow patients to be filmed for entertainment purposes without their consent, joining a chorus of disapproval of a practice that patients’ families have said breached their privacy during their most vulnerable moments.

headline: Teatro Colón in Buenos Aires Aims to Reclaim Glory Days with a New Direction
text: BUENOS AIRES — The Teatro Colón, a stately Belle Époque building, presides over the Avenida 9 de Julio here like a grande dame, elegant and imposing. The century-old building fills a city block, rising four stories and extending three stories below ground, with studios and workshops beneath the avenue and the Plaza del Vaticano. It is one of this city’s most important landmarks, a reminder of a more prosperous era, when artists like Toscanini, Caruso and the Ballets Russes routinely performed there.

headline: New School Technology for Class and the Quad
text: It is almost time for teachers and students to head back to campus, and many of them will arrive with the newest technology in things like headphones and storage devices. Here are some notable gadgets that will enhance your back-to-school experience:

headline: Spielberg-Coens Drama ‘Bridge of Spies’ Gets New York Film Festival Premiere
text: “Bridge of Spies,” the Steven Spielberg-Coen brothers Cold War drama, will get its world premiere at the New York Film Festival, organizers announced Wednesday as they released details of a diverse main slate featuring movies from Asia, Europe and North America.

headline: Guggenheim, With Eye on Asian Art, Hires Two New Curators
text: The Guggenheim Museum, which has delved more deeply into Asian art than any other American museum in recent years, announced Wednesday that it had hired two curators to focus on exhibitions that will feature the work of artists born in mainland China, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau.

headline: A Less Defiant Germany Seems Prepared to Clear a Path for a Third Greek Bailout
text: BERLIN — Germany softened its resistance to a third bailout package for Greece on Wednesday, raising the chances that a draft plan could be approved in time for the country to make a crucial debt payment next week.

headline: Facial Recognition Software Moves From Overseas Wars to Local Police
text: SAN DIEGO — Facial recognition software, which American military and intelligence agencies used for years in Iraq and Afghanistan to identify potential terrorists, is being eagerly adopted by dozens of police departments around the country to pursue drug dealers, prostitutes and other conventional criminal suspects. But because it is being used with few guidelines and with little oversight or public disclosure, it is raising questions of privacy and concerns about potential misuse.

headline: Fury 325
text: Fury 325 at Carowinds is the newest addition to the giga coaster family, and is the tallest of the group. It traverses the North Carolina-South Carolina state line.

headline: Tianjin, a Port in China, Is Rocked by Explosions That Killed Dozens
text: TIANJIN, China — Thunderous, fiery explosions at a warehouse containing hazardous goods traumatized this northeast port city late Wednesday, killing at least 44 people, injuring at least 400, shattering glass on scores of high-rise buildings and causing other extensive damage.

headline: Pennsylvania Attorney General, Kathleen Kane, Denies Charges
text: HARRISBURG, Pa. — Attorney General Kathleen G. Kane defended herself against criminal charges on Wednesday, saying she was the victim of retaliation against her own investigation into pornographic emails that were exchanged between some officials in the previous state administration.

headline: Pope Urges Work-Life Balance
text: Pope Francis, during his weekly general address at the Vatican, urged his followers not to become “slaves to work.”

headline: 36 Hours in Berlin
text: Berlin bursts with a creative spirit that is on full display in cutting-edge restaurants, performance spots and art, both on and off the street.

headline: SunGard Sale Has a Bright Side for Owners
text: At first glance, it would appear that the $9.1 billion sale, including debt, of the financial software maker SunGard to Fidelity National Information Services would be a disappointment to the private equity firms that paid nearly $11 billion for Sungard.

headline: 36 Hours in Berlin
text: There are few cities in the world that transform themselves as profoundly from season to season as Berlin. The purgatorial winter, with its lightless days and frigid nights, gives way to four months of balmy intoxication. Cafe and gallery culture spills out into graffitied alleyways; the parks fill with techno D.J.s, nudists and picnicking families; and young people arrive by the planeload from Brooklyn, Copenhagen and East London to take part in an open-air night-life scene that is equal parts “Paris Is Burning” and “A Midsummer Night’s Dream.” But even as the hype of the last decade has made the city a magnet for tourists, Berlin remains a place for the strange and libertine, where the radical left still nips at the heels of neoliberalism, where snapping photos in public is often more taboo than smoking a joint, and where people seldom ask what it is you “do.”

headline: Review: In ‘Up Here,’ Boy (and All His Inner Demons and Angels) Meets Girl
text: SAN DIEGO, Calif. — Geek meets girl. Geek’s neuroses drive him batty. Geek loses girl.

headline: Pajamas: From the Sheets to the Streets
text: This season, try a silky, structured pantsuit.

headline: An Unusual Octopus Gets a Second Look
text: The larger Pacific striped octopus has an unusual way of mating, and hunts with a “slow bounce” style.

headline: App Smart | Start-Up 101

headline: Video Feature: Inexpensive Apps for Entrepreneurs and Start-Ups
text: WHEN you’re starting a company, speed and efficiency are priorities. Luckily, there are plenty of apps for your smartphone or tablet that can help people collaborate and make quicker decisions.

headline: Vertical Video on the Small Screen? Not a Crime
text: In 2012, Vincent Bova and Damien Eckhardt-Jacobi, two puppeteers who host a YouTube series called Glove and Boots, created a public service announcement to warn viewers about what they considered a modern scourge: People keep shooting videos while holding their phones vertically.

headline: In California, Millions of ‘Shade Balls’ Combat a Nagging Drought
text: Facing a long-term water crisis, officials concerned with preserving a reservoir in Los Angeles hatched a plan: They would combat four years of drought with 96 million plastic balls.

headline: Pennsylvania Attorney General on Charges
text: Kathleen G. Kane, Pennsylvania’s attorney general, denied all charges against her on Wednesday, saying that the accusations came out of an incomplete investigation into pornographic emails.

headline: Carly Fiorina Emerges as a G.O.P. Weapon Against ‘War on Women’ Charge
text: This week, Donald J. Trump said that listening to Carly Fiorina, the only woman competing for the Republican presidential nomination, gave him “a massive headache.”

headline: Alibaba’s Slump May Test Investors’ Good Will
text: The golden-child status of the Chinese e-commerce group Alibaba hangs by a thread.

headline: Judge Prods N.F.L. at Hearing on Tom Brady’s Suspension
text: After seven months of accusations, recriminations and bluster, the N.F.L. and New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady faced off in federal court before a skeptical judge who grilled both sides about Brady’s four-game suspension for his role in the deflation of footballs used in a playoff game.

headline: Where to Watch the Perseid Meteor Shower in the New York Area
text: A harmonic convergence of cosmic dust, lunar phase and fair weather on Wednesday is shaping up to make the Perseid meteor shower this year the most spectacular since at least 2008.

headline: Texas Officer Who Killed Unarmed Man Made Mistakes, Police Experts Say
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — When Officer Brad Miller, a trainee in the Arlington Police Department, walked through the shattered glass in an automobile showroom here in pursuit of a suspected burglar, he had already violated several basic principles of modern-day policing, according to law enforcement veterans: Wait for backup, establish a perimeter, have a plan.

headline: Tianjin Blast Caught on Video
text: Cellphone video captured the moment an explosion tore through a warehouse in China’s northeast port city of Tianjin late Wednesday.

headline: Siri, Tell Me a Joke. No, a Funny One.

headline: Time Is Running Out on Part of Assange Sex Assault Investigation
text: LONDON — Time is running out for Swedish prosecutors investigating accusations of sexual assault against Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, who has been holed up in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London since he walked into the building in 2012 and requested asylum.

headline: Pistol Packing in the Kansas Statehouse
text: The citizens’ right to bear arms in Kansas is now flourishing at the very heart of government — the Statehouse in Topeka. New laissez faire laws championed by the gun lobby allow visitors to routinely carry concealed loaded handguns into the building, and they no longer need a state permit and safety training to do so.

headline: NBCUniversal Invests $200 Million in Vox Media
text: Vox Media, a publishing house for the digital age, has landed a $200 million strategic investment from the entertainment group NBCUniversal, forming a partnership between the new and old media companies to collaborate on programming, advertising and technology.

text: Snapping on a playsuit in the heat of a New York City summer.

headline: Bipartisan Group of Ex-Senators to Run Ads Against Iran Deal
text: A bipartisan group of former senators and veterans is unveiling a multimillion advertising campaign aimed at derailing President Obama’s nuclear agreement with Iran.

headline: Former President Jimmy Carter Says He Has Cancer
text: ATLANTA — Former President Jimmy Carter announced on Wednesday that he had been given a diagnosis of a spreading cancer that was detected by recent liver surgery.

headline: Scandals in Brazil Prompt Fears of a Return to Turmoil
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — The president is battling calls for her impeachment. The speaker of Brazil’s lower house is grappling with accusations that he pocketed a $5 million bribe. The former treasurer of the governing Workers Party is in jail.

headline: Sandra Lee Is Released From Hospital After Surgery for Infection
text: Sandra Lee, the television host and longtime companion of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, was released from the hospital on Wednesday, her spokeswoman said, after undergoing surgery meant to address a lingering infection, several months after she had a double mastectomy for breast cancer.

headline: The Perils of Ever-Changing Work Schedules Extend to Children’s Well-Being
text: WASHINGTON — Abercrombie & Fitch announced last week that it would stop requiring workers to be on call for shifts that could be canceled with little notice, making it the latest retailer to pull back from such scheduling practices.

headline: Iran’s Foreign Minister Visits Syria for Talks With Assad
text: ANTAKYA, Turkey — The foreign minister of Iran arrived in Damascus, Syria, on Wednesday to discuss the civil war in Syria with President Bashar al-Assad, while rebel shelling and government airstrikes killed more than 30 people nearby.
