headline: Review: Ashwini Ramaswamy Goes Solo at the Drive East Festival
text: Dancers are like anyone else: Sometimes they get the urge to leave the nest. Ashwini Ramaswamy, a soloist with the much-admired Ragamala Dance Company, struck out on her own on Tuesday night at Drive East, the excellent festival of Indian music and dance playing through Sunday at the Ellen Stewart Theater at La MaMa.

headline: Conservatives Need to Redefine Themselves as More Caring, John Kasich Says
text: DERRY, N.H. – It was the last question at Gov. John R. Kasich’s town-hall-style meeting here on Wednesday, and it also was perhaps the bluntest.

headline: Review: Enrique Vila-Matas Plots His Own Awakening in ‘The Illogic of Kassel’
text: Imagine you’re a 60-something Spanish writer with several substantial international prizes under your belt. You’re prone to feeling anxiety and dread come nightfall, and famously decline invitations that keep you out late. But, one day, you receive an invitation to act as an installation piece at Documenta, the quinquennial contemporary-art exhibition in Kassel, Germany. You think, What would a writer like me do in a place like that?

headline: The ‘Shopping List’ of Rogue Traders
text: A group of men, who were recently indicted, would sometimes submit “shopping lists” to hackers with the names of the companies whose press releases they wanted to obtain illegally from news services like BusinessWire and PR Newswire. This is one of those lists.

headline: Fashion’s Favorite Yoga Trainers Tell You What and What Not to Wear to Class
text: Plus: A line of rubber-soled shoes made of neoprene that dries in the sun in just 10 minutes; a new e-commerce site with the goal to make gold and gold-plated jewelry affordable and a pop-up store with walls painted by the Instagram phenomenon @drawbertson.

headline: Trump Weighs In on China
text: Speaking at a campaign event in Michigan, the Republican presidential candidate Donald J. Trump criticized the Chinese government for devaluing its currency, calling the move a “disgrace.”

headline: 7 La Guardia Cab Dispatchers Accused of Taking Bribes From Drivers
text: It might feel like forever, standing in line outside an airport terminal, luggage in tow, waiting for a taxi. But when cabdrivers obey the rules, it is likely that they have waited just as long, if not longer — idling in a lot, awaiting the go-ahead from a dispatcher.

headline: Tom Brady Sketch Artist, Panned Online, Apologizes
text: “This courtroom sketch of Tom Brady will haunt your dreams,” Fusion declared.

headline: Review: In ‘Written on Skin,’ George Benjamin Creates an Unusual Love Triangle
text: In the first scene of the British composer George Benjamin’s extraordinary opera “Written on Skin,” a group of modern-day angels bustle about in an upstairs room on a two-tiered set. It could be a kind of laboratory, or maybe the fitting room of a celestial opera house. That’s the way it looks in this haunting production by the director Katie Mitchell, which opened a three-performance run at the David H. Koch Theater on Tuesday, receiving an enormous ovation. The production comes from the Aix-en-Provence Festival in France, where the opera had its premiere in 2012. In an ambitious venture, the Mostly Mozart festival is presenting the American stage premiere at Lincoln Center.

headline: N.S.A. Used Phone Records Program to Seek Iran Operatives
text: WASHINGTON — The National Security Agency has used its bulk domestic phone records program to search for operatives from the government of Iran and “associated terrorist organizations” — not just Al Qaeda and its allies — according to a document obtained by The New York Times.

headline: N.S.A. Inspector General’s Reports About Bulk Phone Records Program Are Released
text: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit by The New York Times, the Justice Department has provided these reports by the National Security Agency’s inspector general about the once-secret bulk phone records program. The release includes an unredacted letter showing the full name of an order from the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court about the program, which usually is redacted. It lists phone company names and discloses that the program can be used to search for operatives of the government of Iran and associated terrorist groups, not just Al Qaeda and its allies.

headline: How Olivia Kim Is Teaching Nordstrom to Think Small
text: The woman coaxing the $13 billion fashion retailer to think small has a “Babes in Toyland” squeak, intermittently bleach-blond hair and the letters S-I-C-K tattooed across her knuckles.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
text: Greece and More — Photos of the Day

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
text: Good evening. Here’s the latest.

headline: Review: ‘Sunset, o639 Hours’ by BalletX at the Joyce Theater
text: A plane crash may seem like unusual fodder for a story ballet, though the longer you spend with Matthew Neenan’s “Sunset, o639 Hours,” the more related ballet and aviation appear to be: twin forms of flight and propulsion through space. This two-act work for Philadelphia’s terrific BalletX, presented as part of the Joyce Theater’s Ballet Festival on Tuesday, revolves around the American pilot Edwin Musick, who in 1938 manned the first airmail flight from New Zealand to Hawaii. The Samoan Clipper, as his aircraft was known, went down on its return trip, just off the Samoan coast.

headline: The Slave Quarters at Joseph Lloyd Manor
text: Joseph McGill, founder of the Slave Dwelling Project, is sleeping in former slave quarters on Long Island, N.Y.

headline: Slavery at Sylvester Manor
text: Joseph McGill, founder of the Slave Dwelling Project, is sleeping in former slave quarters on Long Island, N.Y.

headline: Confronting Slavery at Long Island’s Oldest Estates
text: Joseph McGill first unrolled bedding in a former slave cabin in 1999. He was participating in a documentary about Civil War re-enactors and the controversy over the Confederate battle flag, and the producers asked Mr. McGill — an African-American museum professional from South Carolina who dresses in the Union blue — if he could add some spice to a scene being filmed at a plantation near Charleston.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know.

headline: Opponents of Iran Deal Try to Reach Young Voters on Snapchat
text: Speaking in favor of the international arms control agreement with Iran last week in Washington, President Obama warned that opponents of the deal would flood the airwaves with “tens of millions of dollars in advertising,” ahead of a congressional vote in September. He failed, however, to advise citizens who want to tune out the debate entirely to avoid not just their televisions but also Snapchat, the social messaging service popular with teenagers.

headline: Rex Ryan and Bills Sign Ikemefuna Enemkpali
text: A day after punching Jets quarterback Geno Smith in the face, Ikemefuna Enemkpali found a new home — with the former Jets coach Rex Ryan.

headline: Review: Matthias Goerne Captures the Mood at the Mostly Mozart Festival
text: What was notable about the concert of the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra on Tuesday evening in Avery Fisher Hall, apart from its excellence, was that the program was mostly Mozart, or at least more than half. Jane Moss, as artistic director of the festival since 1992, continues to take it in so many new and stimulating directions that Mozart can sometimes seem like an endangered species there.

headline: Review: Mario Diaz de Leon Plays Selections From ‘The Soul Is the Arena’
text: A handful of listeners sat in almost total darkness at the late show at the Stone on Tuesday evening, as the composer Mario Diaz de Leon used a laptop to perform electronic works he described as his “most extreme music,” written while an undergraduate at Oberlin.

headline: HAY Mini Market Comes to New York
text: Here are some items that are sold at the store.

headline: August 12, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Greece, India, South Korea and India.

headline: HAY Mini Market Hits New York
text: The Danish furniture company HAY has a loyal following in Europe but is virtually unknown in the United States. Think of it as the COS of couches: a brand that style insiders shop when they travel abroad and show off to their friends back home. What’s usually brought back from Copenhagen or Oslo is carry-on-size accessories, like HAY’s colorful trays, decorative textiles and stationery.

headline: U.S. Appeals Ruling That A.I.G. Bailout Terms Were Too Harsh
text: In a move that starts a new chapter in the battle over the bailout of the American International Group during the financial crisis, the Justice Department formally appealed a court ruling on Wednesday that said the government’s terms for saving the company had been too harsh.

headline: After Colorado Waste Spill, E.P.A. Halts Field Investigations
text: DENVER — After a contractor for the Environmental Protection Agency accidentally caused a mine to burst during a field investigation — releasing more than three million gallons of toxic waste — the agency’s top official said Wednesday that she had halted all similar investigations until further notice.

headline: Ticks: Summer’s Unwanted Guests
text: At a recent dinner party in Greenwich, Conn., Topic A was not stock futures or boarding school, but something decidedly less tony: ticks.

headline: Common Core Test Results
text: The New York State Education Department released the results of the Common Core English and math tests for students in third through eighth grades.

headline: Gloria Allred Challenges Cosby Lawyer to Debate as 3 More Women Surface with Accusations
text: LOS ANGELES — The lawyer Gloria Allred introduced three women with new accusations against Bill Cosby on Wednesday at a news conference here and challenged a lawyer for Mr. Cosby, Monique Pressley, to debate the raft of sexual allegations leveled by dozens of women against the entertainer.

headline: Capitalists, Arise!: Q. & A. With Peter Georgescu
text: In a Sunday Review article last weekend, “Capitalists, Arise!,” Peter Georgescu, the chairman emeritus of Young & Rubicam, argued that if we don’t deal with income inequality, we’ll face intolerable taxes or social unrest. Readers rose up, posting more than a thousand comments on Facebook and The Times’s site challenging and applauding his ideas. Here, Mr. Georgescu addresses a few of their comments.

headline: How Are Those Walleye Biting? On Minnesota Lake, They’re Not
text: GARRISON, Minn. — Along the rocky shore of Mille Lacs Lake on a recent morning, flat-bottomed fishing boats were idle in their docks. No customers wandered into a bait shop selling night crawlers, minnows and jumbo leeches. The restaurant at Twin Pines Resort was hushed and nearly empty, despite the postcard-perfect views of the vast, sparkling lake it offers from the patio.

headline: Cuba: Reliving Memories of Communism
text: When Yana Paskova visited Cuba, her eyes — and heart — were attuned to details that summoned her childhood in Communist Bulgaria.

headline: New N.B.A. Schedule Gives Players More Breaks
text: The N.B.A. released its 2015-16 schedule on Wednesday, trumpeting an effort to make the season more physically forgiving for players by building in more days off between games.

headline: Money Ills Raise Doubts on Plan to Take SFX Entertainment Private
text: SFX Entertainment brought dance music to Wall Street, but lately the party — at least when it comes to the company’s stock price — has been a bit of a downer.

headline: Blue Bell Is Shipping Ice Cream Again After a Listeria Outbreak
text: Back in April, employees at H-E-B’s grocery stores were scrambling to pull Blue Bell ice cream from their shelves. Come September, they may be rushing to put it back.

headline: The Marines Who Took Down the American Flag in Havana
text: Around noon on Jan. 4, 1961, after spending hours feeding mounds of government documents into an incinerator, three American Marines assigned to the embassy guard force in Havana turned their attention to a solemn task: lowering the American flag.

headline: 22-Year Term for Nigerian Who Joined Al Qaeda and Then Denounced It
text: From one perspective, Lawal Babafemi was a propagandist for Al Qaeda who traversed several countries to join in jihad, and was plotting to carry out an important mission when he was arrested in 2011.

headline: Ted Cruz Looks South
text: On a road trip full of sweet tea, biscuits and gravy, the Republican presidential hopeful tried hard to prove his bonafides in Dixie.

headline: Evoking Donald Trump, Ted Cruz Grabs for the Limelight During Southern Tour
text: FRANKLIN, Tenn. — The sweet tea was mostly gone, the homemade coffee cakes picked over by the more than 2,000 who showed up here to hear Senator Ted Cruz deliver a blistering indictment of the direction the country is headed in and of the man who is now leading it.

headline: Prosecutors Ask to Deny Bail to 5 Accused in Insider Trading Ring
text: Federal prosecutors have asked the courts to refuse bail to all five men arrested in connection with a scheme that enabled securities traders to benefit from confidential corporate information in news releases stolen by hackers in Ukraine before the documents were made public.

headline: Yankees Surrender Division Lead as Their Offense Continues to Sputter
text: CLEVELAND — Buried in the detritus of 16 innings of baseball on Tuesday night, an extraordinary event occurred: Brett Gardner tried to steal a base.

headline: U.S. Says Iranian Military Figure’s Visit to Russia Violates U.N. Ban
text: WASHINGTON — The State Department said Wednesday that a recent visit to Moscow by the head of Iran’s paramilitary Quds force had violated a United Nations travel ban that has been imposed because of concerns about Tehran’s nuclear and ballistic missile programs.

headline: The Growing Strength of New York’s “Opt Out” Movement
text: An analysis of where students are opting out of New York’s standardized tests.

headline: Donors Descend on Schumer and Others in Debate on Iran
text: In the weeks before Senator Chuck Schumer’s decision to oppose the Iran nuclear accord, John Shapiro, a New York financier and a leader of the American Jewish Committee, had his ear, plying him with reasons to oppose it.

headline: Nigeria: Boko Haram Is Said to Have a New Leader
text: The leader of Boko Haram, the Islamist militant group that has traumatized Nigeria and expanded its attacks in three neighboring countries, has been wounded and replaced, the president of Chad said in a state radio broadcast Wednesday. President Idriss Déby, whose forces have been collaborating with their counterparts in Nigeria, Cameroon and Niger to battle Boko Haram, said its leader, Abubakar Shekau, had ceded control to another militant identified as Mahamoud Daoud. Mr. Déby did not elaborate on the source of this information, which could not be confirmed independently. But he asserted that Boko Haram’s capabilities had been crushed by the four-country military campaign against the group and that it would be finished as a fighting force by year’s end.

headline: Ivo Karlovic, King of Aces, Closes In on a Record
text: MONTREAL — When Ivo Karlovic was a lanky teenager, his daily routine took him to the Salata tennis club in Zagreb, Croatia, where he would fire hundreds of serves into an empty court.

headline: Former Met Museum Official to Lead Roosevelt House

headline: Scott Walker Approves Public Funding of Basketball Arena
text: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin approved $250 million in public financing for a new arena for the Milwaukee Bucks basketball team on Wednesday, a deal exposing him to charges of corporate welfare as he seeks the Republican nomination as a fiscal conservative.

headline: J. Wallace LaPrade, New York F.B.I. Chief in ’70s, Dies at 89

Wallace LaPrade, who oversaw the safe return of several celebrity kidnapping victims and was later fired as the Federal Bureau of Investigation’s New York chief, accused of not being forthcoming about the bureau’s role in illegally investigating radical groups in the 1970s, died on July 31 in Lexington, Va. He was 89.

headline: Fred Otnes, Illustrator and Collage Artist, Dies at 89

headline: A New Role for Lagares as the Mets Keep Rolling

headline: California: Grand Juries Are Barred From Deciding Cases Involving Police
text: The state has banned the use of grand juries to determine whether to prosecute a law enforcement officer in the death of a member of the public. The law, which Gov. Jerry Brown signed on Tuesday, comes a year after the death of Michael Brown by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo., sparked nationwide protests. A grand jury in Missouri did not indict the officer, Darren Wilson. Experts said that the use of grand juries in criminal cases already was relatively rare in California. But now prosecutors will no longer have the option of sending difficult cases to grand juries: they will have to decide whether to indict police officers. Because grand jury testimony is often held in secret, Holly Mitchell, the author of the law, said that the change would increase trust in police officers and transparency in government.

headline: Meat Without Meat, Courtesy of Herbivorous Butcher
text: Kale and Aubry Walch launched the Herbivorous Butcher, a line of small-batch meat alternatives, last year, after recognizing a demand for vegan food that doesn’t taste like vegan food. When the brother-sister duo from Minneapolis, Minn., first brought their locally sourced, protein-rich products — smoky BBQ ribs, maple-glazed bacon, spicy chorizo, all made from creative blends of wheat gluten, beans and flavorings — to the local farmer’s market, they caused a small sensation. “One person said, ‘I’m a food scientist, and I swear I can taste fat marbling in that sausage,’ ” recalls Aubry. After appearing at a series of pop-ups across the Midwest, they’re now opening a brick-and-mortar location in their hometown. Says the aptly named Kale, “Our goal is to fool people into saving the planet.”

Many of them were adorned with a cryptic hashtag bearing a new word: “cuckservative.”

headline: What’s On TV Thursday
text: 1:20 P.M. (Starz Cinema) THE INVISIBLE WOMAN (2013) A young actress (Felicity Jones, above with John Kavanagh) becomes the clandestine lover of Charles Dickens (Ralph Fiennes) in this recounting of Dickens’s longtime affair with Nelly Ternan, who was 18 to his 45 when they met. Mr. Fiennes also directed the film, which was written by Abi Morgan (“The Iron Lady,” “Shame”). “You may become impatient with the leisurely pace of ‘The Invisible Woman’ and its occasional narrative vagueness, but its open spaces leave room for some of the strongest acting of any contemporary film,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times, adding, “Ms. Jones gives a performance of extraordinary subtlety and delicacy.” And Mr. Fiennes “gives his warmest, most full-bodied screen performance as Dickens, an irresistibly charismatic, tirelessly energetic celebrity who was the life of every party he attended.”

headline: Review: In ‘Straight Outta Compton,’ Upstarts Who Became the Establishment
text: “Straight Outta Compton,” an exultant rap-to-riches story about the group N.W.A., opens with a blast of action-film braggadocio. It’s night sometime in 1986, and the group’s future headliner and fly in the ointment, Eazy-E (Jason Mitchell), is taking care of shady business. With the camera dogging his steps so closely that you half expect him to shout “Heel,” he hotfoots it into a cramped, bleak house that has been prepped for maximum horror-film suggestiveness, with lighting as dark as a dungeon, a Welcome Wagon of tough-guy scowls and a she-devil who’s soon holding a shotgun next to a bare leg, her gat and her gam each loaded and lethal.

headline: Rescuing Wildlife Is Futile, and Necessary
text: In a plastic dishpan on Judith Wakelam’s kitchen table, six huge, dark eyes gaze up at me from a huddle of pale-fringed faces and dusty black feathers, bladelike wings projecting outward at a variety of unlikely angles. These are baby common swifts, insectivorous birds so exquisitely aerial that they eat, sleep and mate on the wing and spend the first two or three years of their lives migrating between Europe and Africa in continuous flight.

headline: Tyra Banks Isn’t Running a Democracy Here
text: You’ve been hosting ‘‘America’s Next Top Model’’ for more than a decade. It gives you a unique vantage point on how reality television has influenced the people who consume it. How are the young people who audition for the show today different from those of 10 years ago? In terms of the audition process, people sometimes come in and are like, ‘‘I’m gonna be the weird one!’’ or ‘‘I’m gonna be the overly sexual one!’’ They’ve grown up with reality television and know that producers are looking for strong archetypes. I’d like to think that we can see through that.

headline: Personal (Search) History
text: One afternoon, riding the bus in downtown Montreal, Madelyne Beckles swiped open her phone to browse the web. She caught sight of her most recent mobile searches — ‘‘Snooki diet,’’ ‘‘Miley Cyrus’ sex tape,’’ ‘‘Bruno Mars songs’’ — and found this collection to be absurd but unexpectedly poignant: an unvarnished glimpse into the meanderings of her mind. Beckles, a 23-year-old visual artist whose work explores her relationship to technology, took a screen grab and shared the image on Instagram. This became the genesis of her newest project, called Herstory: Every so often, Beckles pulls up her mobile search history and saves it with a screen shot. In one image, ‘‘Labiaplasty’’ is listed right above ‘‘Bethenny Frankel Instagram.’’ In another, ‘‘Dirty martini’’ appears a few searches before ‘‘Who owns the Mona Lisa.’’ (To preserve the integrity of the project, she says she deletes only items with typos.) Some of the images appeared in a recent art book called ‘‘Babe’’; the rest will appear, in the form of large poster-size prints, as part of a show in a Toronto gallery called Autumn later this month.

headline: Bounce, Launch, Splash! The Joy of the Diving Board

After a preliminary bounce on the diving board at the pool at the Tony Dapolito Recreation Center, he took three steps, paused and started his signature move, a lofty dive with a midflight spin that ended with his slicing effortlessly into the water.

headline: The Bail Trap
text: On the morning of Nov. 20 last year, Tyrone Tomlin sat in the cage of one of the Brooklyn criminal courthouse’s interview rooms, a bare white cinder-block cell about the size of an office cubicle. Hardly visible through the heavy steel screen in front of him was Alison Stocking, the public defender who had just been assigned to his case. Tomlin, exhausted and frustrated, was trying to explain how he came to be arrested the afternoon before. It wasn’t entirely clear to Tomlin himself. Still in his work clothes, his boots encrusted with concrete dust, he recounted what had happened.

headline: 1940: Britain May Lift Blockade

Earlier reports of Mr. Hoover’s statement were taken to indicate that Britain was, in effect, being asked to raise her blockade to allow American foodstuffs to get through to peoples recently taken under the German wing. — New York Herald Tribune, August 14, 1940

headline: Doctors Fail to Address Patients’ Spiritual Needs
text: My patient, a woman in her 20s with cancer, was doing poorly on chemotherapy. The disease had spread throughout her body. We were doing everything we could to help her, but didn’t know how long she would live – probably only a few months, at most. Her mother came regularly to visit, and sat by her side. Around their necks, they both wore gold crosses on tiny gold chains. Taped on the wall, near the foot of her bed, was a greeting card with a picture of Jesus, in a red cloak with pointy gold beams radiating from his head.

text: The singer-songwriter Sara Bareilles has sold more than two million albums and served as a celebrity judge on the NBC a cappella competition show “The Sing-Off.” Next spring, she will add Broadway composer to her list of credits when the new show “Waitress” opens at the Brooks Atkinson Theater.

headline: Team From New York Education Dept. to Study Troubled East Ramapo Schools
text: After the Legislature rejected a move to give the New York State Education Department enhanced powers over the troubled East Ramapo school system in Rockland County, the department is taking a more modest step: It has appointed three experts to study the district’s operations and offer recommendations to the school board and the Board of Regents, the agency said on Thursday.

headline: Jeans Made for Walking Down Memory Lane
text: Seventies fashion again feels of the moment, with denim styles as loose and freeing as they were in the disco era. For inspiration, look no further than to three stylish women of the period.

headline: Turkish Coalition Talks End Fruitlessly, Making New Elections Likely
text: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s two largest political parties ended talks on Thursday without agreeing to form a coalition government, setting the stage for likely new elections and threatening further political instability.

headline: Reaching Back
text: Vu Tran, whose novel “Dragonfish” is reviewed this week, was born in Saigon in 1975 and escaped the country in 1980. He is one of a number of writers in his generation with Vietnamese roots, including Viet Thanh Nguyen and Nam Le, who have recently met with literary success.

headline: For Evolving Brains, a ‘Paleo’ Diet of Carbs
text: You are what you eat, and so were your ancient ancestors. But figuring out what they actually dined on has been no easy task.

headline: Emery LeCrone in the Studio
text: The 28-year-old choreographer debuts new work at the Ballet Festival this week.

headline: Wayne Brady Will Step Into ‘Kinky Boots’
text: Billy Porter, who won a Tony Award for playing Lola in Cyndi Lauper and Harvey Fierstein’s hit musical “Kinky Boots,” will leave the production on Nov. 20, and be succeeded by the actor and comedian Wayne Brady, producers announced Thursday.

headline: Can a Hotel Robot Read a ‘Do Not Disturb’ Sign?
text: Giving a new meaning to “robotic service,” several hotels and at least one cruise ship have been experimenting with machines that can handle guest check-in, store bags, deliver extra towels or mix a drink at the bar.

headline: Letters: ‘The Conservative Heart’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Review: ‘Show Me a Hero’ Focuses on a Mayor in the Maelstrom of Desegregation
text: You can see why the tale of Nick Wasicsko and the decades-long battle to desegregate Yonkers, in which he played a short but crucial role, would appeal to David Simon. Like Baltimore in “The Wire” and New Orleans in “Treme,” Yonkers symbolizes the tortured metamorphosis of the post-industrial American city. And in Wasicsko, elected mayor at 28 and caught in a vortex of racism and fear, it would seem to have a classic tragic hero: an impetuous young man who grows into leadership, is cast out and doesn’t live to see the full fruit of the seeds he planted.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | Man From U.N.C.L.E.
text: Guy Ritchie narrates a sequence from “The Man From U.N.C.L.E.”

headline: How a Kitten Eased My Partner’s Depression
text: When his depression was at its worst, my partner, Joe, would wake up in the morning engulfed in a fog so palpable that its presence would sometimes startle me awake, as if I had smelled something burning.

headline: Pouilly-Fuissés With an Identity Crisis
text: The Mâconnais, a tranquil, hilly, picturesque region near the southern end of Burgundy, just to the north of Beaujolais, has long been a source for inexpensive white wines. Like almost all white Burgundies, they are made of chardonnay. And, as has been true all over the wine-producing world, the last 20 years have been incredibly exciting because of the tremendous rise in quality from the Mâconnais.

headline: A World War and Clashing Architecture Foil a German Arts District
text: BERLIN — Twenty-five years after German reunification, the capital is still trying to fill the lingering gaps in its urban fabric as it vies to be considered alongside Paris and Rome as one of Europe’s pre-eminent cultural centers.

headline: HBO, Brought to You by ‘Sesame Street’
text: Starting this fall, new episodes of the children’s television series “Sesame Street” will appear exclusively on the cable network HBO and its streaming outlets. After nine months, the episodes will be available free on PBS, the show’s longtime home.

headline: The Man From U.N.C.L.E. (With Movie Trailer): Guy Ritchie Narrates a Scene
text: The 1960s television spy series “The Man From U.N.C.L.E.” gets a big screen update from the director Guy Ritchie. Henry Cavill and Armie Hammer take the lead roles of Napoleon Solo and Illya Kuryakin, CIA and KGB agents forced to join forces, with an assist from Alicia Vikander. This early scene pits the two against each another in a divided Berlin. In an interview, Mr. Ritchie spoke about the sequence and ideas for the movie. Following are excerpts from that conversation.

headline: Review: ‘The Man From U.N.C.L.E.’ Resurrects a Glossy, Action-Packed ’60s
text: Guy Ritchie makes the kind of enjoyably disreputable movies that are fun to watch until they’re not. He’s a talented flimflam artist and, for the industry, I imagine, a useful one because of how he glosses up schlocky, sketchy projects (his “Sherlock Holmes” movies and other hyperkinetic baubles), making them seem as if there’s more to their slick surfaces than naked commercialism, agency fees and facile pleasure. It works for him (he keeps getting hired), and sometimes also for us. Pleasure is, after all, rarely overrated, including in the often mind-bludgeoning arena of franchise cinema, and there’s a lot to be said for watching beautiful people doing very silly stuff on screen.

headline: Families of Virginia Tech Massacre Victims Start Program to Improve Campus Safety
text: Eight years after the Virginia Tech massacre, survivors and families announced a program on Thursday intended to make colleges and universities safer, hoping it will serve as a legacy for the 32 people killed.

headline: Drone Videos Show Ancient Peruvian Sites
text: Peru’s Ministry of Culture is using drones to survey the country’s archeological sites as part of conservation efforts.

headline: Connecticut Death Penalty Law Is Unconstitutional, Court Rules
text: Casting the death penalty as an outdated tool of justice at odds with today’s societal values, Connecticut’s highest court on Thursday spared the lives of 11 men on death row by ruling that capital punishment violated the State Constitution.

headline: Exploring the Dolomites in Italy
text: In summer, hiking trails through forests and flower-filled meadows beckon, and enticing meals are never far away.

headline: Adam Johnson’s ‘Fortune Smiles’
text: Late one night not long ago, when I was losing an ugly bout with insomnia and everyone in my family was snoring in syncopated swing, I read a story in Harper’s Magazine that made me wake my husband up and insist that he read it, no, read it right now. The story is from the point of view of a very sick woman, the wife of a writer, and it speaks about family love and grief and jealousy and guilt and rage and illness with a power that took my breath away. That story, “Interesting Facts,” has now been published with five others, all of them so long they could almost be called novellas, in a new collection titled “Fortune Smiles.” Its author is Adam Johnson, who won the 2013 Pulitzer Prize for his novel about North Korea, “The Orphan Master’s Son.”

headline: Lindsey Vonn Fractures Ankle While Training
text: Lindsey Vonn crashed while training on Coronet Peak in New Zealand on Thursday and sustained an ankle fracture that forced her to fly back to the United States for treatment, the United States Ski Team said. Vonn first announced the injury on her social media accounts.

headline: Toronto Film Festival Announces First TV Lineup
text: Keith Richards, French zombies and a quirky set of siblings are among the subjects to be explored in a new television section of the Toronto International Film Festival.

headline: Bookshelf: Board Book Treats for Toddlers
text: New books include a chunky guide to dinosaurs and some big laughs in small packages.

headline: For ‘Mercury Fur’ Writer Philip Ridley, a Macabre Vision Takes Many Forms
text: When Philip Ridley was a child he suffered from severe asthma. When he wasn’t in the hospital, he was often kept at home. Alone in his bedroom, in a tower block in London’s East End, he would draw pictures and write stories, make up poems and sing songs. He would disappear into a world of his own making.

headline: Colorado Court Rules Against Baker Who Refused to Serve Same-Sex Couples
text: A state appeals court in Colorado ruled Thursday that a baker could not cite religious beliefs in refusing to make wedding cakes for same-sex couples.

headline: China’s Central Bank Backs Currency
text: Officials for the People’s Bank of China insist that the yuan remains strong, despite the recent currency devaluation.

headline: 1965: Dr. King to Appeal for Peace
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — The Rev Martin Luther King Jr. will appeal personally to North Vietnamese President Ho Chi Minh to carry the war in Vietnam to the conference table, he said last night. The Negro integration leader said he would send a letter to the North Vietnamese leader as well as to those of South Vietnam, Russia and the United States. Dr. King told his Southern Christian Leadership Conference convention that each side must end the ‘‘cycle of mistrust, violence and war.’’ Dr. King suggested that the United States seriously consider halting its bombings. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 14, 1965

headline: Sky Lights
text: Last night’s Perseid meteor shower was one of the most spectacular in years.

headline: The Heat Is On to Score the Next Big Summer Song
text: It was still spring when the ultimate New York summer song was written.

headline: Top Hillary Clinton Donor Clarifies Stance on Iran Nuclear Deal
text: Haim Saban, a top donor to Hillary Rodham Clinton who came out last week against the nuclear agreement between Iran and six world powers, says his comments about the deal were taken “out of context.”

headline: Mary Jo Heath Will Be New Radio Host for Metropolitan Opera
text: There have been many voices at the Metropolitan Opera, but only a few voices of the Metropolitan Opera. Now the mantle, or microphone, is being passed to Mary Jo Heath: she will become the fourth full-time radio host in the company’s history in September.

headline: After Ferguson, California Orders Police Shooting Cases Into Open Court
text: After a tumultuous year of nationwide protest, California has become the first state to ban the use of grand juries to decide whether a police officer should face criminal charges in using deadly force against civilians. Criticism of the secret grand jury process has become a flash point in a series of civilian deaths at the hands of police that began with the shooting of Michael Brown, a black teenager in Ferguson, Mo., last summer.

headline: Sir Kensington’s, Condiments Maker, Receives $8.5 Million Investment
text: Sir Kensington’s, a small but growing company in the condiments business, has received a $8.5 million from some individual investors and Verlinvest, the family-owned private equity group that is snapping up stakes in some of America’s most popular new food companies.

headline: P.G.A. Championship 2015: Dustin Johnson Is Calm Before Storming to the Top
text: HAVEN, Wis. — Dustin Johnson started his first round of the 2015 P.G.A. Championship on the 10th hole, a short, downhill 361-yard par 4. Most players in the field Thursday used irons off the tee, strategically positioning themselves on a serpentine fairway so they could be aggressive with their second shots.

headline: Narcotic Drugs Can Be Coaxed From Yeast
text: In a widely expected advance that has opened a fierce debate about “home-brewed heroin,” scientists at Stanford have created strains of yeast that can produce narcotic drugs.

headline: What to Do This Weekend
text: Looking for something fun to do?

headline: Shinzo Abe’s Bid to Redefine Japan and Its Military Has Echoes of Family History
text: In a famous photograph from his childhood, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan is seen perched on the knee of his smiling grandfather, Nobusuke Kishi, the influential postwar prime minister. There is no sign of the turmoil just outside the family home, where thousands were protesting Mr. Kishi’s plan to extend Japan’s military alliance with the United States.

headline: El Niño May Bring Record Heat, and Rain for California
text: This year’s El Niño weather pattern could be the most powerful on record, federal forecasters said, while warning that the effects of the weather system are never certain.

headline: Japan’s Apologies for World War II
text: Here is a look at major statements on Japan’s war legacy by monarchs and senior officials since its defeat in 1945.

headline: Donald Trump Is Officially Off ‘The Celebrity Apprentice’
text: LOS ANGELES — “The Celebrity Apprentice” will return to NBC’s lineup at some point in the 2016-17 television season, but Donald J. Trump will not.

headline: Age-Defying Athletes
text: In masters track and field, athletes 35 and older compete in various divisions. At the World Masters Championships in France, competitors in the top age groups provided many of the highlights.

headline: Mets Overcome Shaky Start and Complete Sweep of Rockies
text: Noah Syndergaard gritted his teeth and punched his glove, watching a solo home run sail over Yoenis Cespedes’s head in center field. Five pitches later, there was another home run to left. It was only the first inning, and the unimpressive Colorado Rockies were the opponent, but, still, Syndergaard looked vulnerable.

headline: Venezuela Releases Two Prominent Government Critics From Prison
text: Venezuela released two prominent government critics from prison this week, including a former defense minister who had been a confidant of President Hugo Chávez.

headline: Donald Trump Video Juxtaposes Obama Playing Golf With ISIS Violence
text: Donald J. Trump may be new to politics, but he has already demonstrated a mastery of the dark art of creating haunting campaign videos packed with imagery of violence and war.

headline: Works Sighted: Iranian Life Under Sanctions
text: As a vote on the nuclear deal that would lift sanctions against Iran approaches in Congress, Pedestrian, an Iranian writer, offers a look at what those sanctions mean to Iranians’ day-to-day lives. Via Vox:

headline: U.N. Faces Scrutiny Over Unpaid Intern Who Slept in a Tent in Geneva
text: United Nations officials are facing pressure to revisit their unpaid internship policy after an intern who had been living in a tent near Lake Geneva resigned and called for “interns all over the world” to unite in a fight for their rights.

headline: The Roller Rink Origins of N.W.A.
text: Craig Schweisinger opened the doors to Skateland U.S.A. on Saturday, Nov. 16, 1984. High schoolers mingled with gangbangers and roller skaters who took their choreography seriously. A sign reading NO CAPS — NO COLORS greeted attendees at the door.

headline: 'Everyone Just Stood Around in Horror': Readers React to Moms at Bachelorette Parties
text: Readers discuss inter-generational partying, helicopter parenting and ageism.

headline: States With High Gun Ownership See More Officers Killed
text: The higher the rate of gun ownership in a state, the higher the likelihood of a law enforcement officer being killed, a new study has found.

headline: For Lenovo, Cost-Cutting Is Not Enough to Stem Losses
text: Lenovo’s turnaround will take more than cost-cutting. The PC and smartphone maker will slash $1.35 billion from annual expenses after earnings fell 51 percent in the second quarter. Revamping may halt losses at the Motorola handset unit that Lenovo bought last year. But any return to growth depends on a demand pickup.

headline: The High Price of Rejecting the Iran Deal
text: WASHINGTON — THE Iran nuclear deal offers a long-term solution to one of the most urgent threats of our time. Without this deal, Iran, the world’s leading state sponsor of terrorism, would be less than 90 days away from having enough fissile material to make a nuclear bomb. This deal greatly reduces the threat of Iran’s nuclear program, making Iran’s breakout time four times as long, securing unprecedented access to ensure that we will know if Iran cheats and giving us the leverage to hold it to its commitments.

headline: John A. Nerud, Hall of Fame Thoroughbred Trainer, Dies at 102
text: John A. Nerud, a Hall of Fame trainer of thoroughbreds who named his greatest horse, Dr. Fager, after the Boston neurosurgeon who saved his life, died on Thursday at his home in Old Brookville, N.Y. He was 102.

headline: Google Unveils New Chrome Operating System for Business Customers
text: Google figured out something important: You can sell businesses the future, but they’ll show up with lots of the past.

headline: Review: ‘One & Two’ Exposes Dangers of Trying to Control Teenagers
text: In “One & Two,” an isolated family of four is about to go nuclear. Dad (Grant Bowler) runs a very tight ship on a very tidy homestead in a rural paradise, walled off from the outside world and apparently lacking any technology more recent than kerosene lamps. Mom (Elizabeth Reaser) pretty much goes along, except to try to soothe her husband when he rages about their teenagers, Zac (Timothée Chalamet) and Eva (Kiernan Shipka). They have powers, you see, that must be shunned.

headline: On View
text: Auto Body’s sixth art exhibition of the season, “Scapes,” opened this past Saturday.

headline: Review: In ‘Return to Sender,’ Rosamund Pike Connects With Her Attacker
text: For most of the way, “Return to Sender” merges creepy and sexy to good effect, thanks to a close-to-the-vest performance by Rosamund Pike, the missing wife of “Gone Girl.” The story works an old and distasteful trope — the rape victim who falls for the attacker — but the treatment is restrained rather than salacious.

headline: China’s Renminbi Devaluation May Initiate New Phase in Global Currency War
text: For years, China looked like the principled noncombatant. As other countries, seeking to secure an economic advantage, let the value of their currencies slide on international markets, China held firm on the value of its money.

headline: Review: ‘Rosenwald,’ on a Philanthropist Who Created Schools for Blacks in the Jim Crow South
text: In the first half of the 20th century, Julius Rosenwald was not only a leading businessman — the chairman of Sears, Roebuck & Company, one of the country’s wealthiest men — but a leading philanthropist and civil rights advocate as well. With challenge grants, he spurred the building of Y.M.C.A.s that would accept blacks as residents; his Rosenwald Fund dispensed fellowships for a who’s who of black artists and academics, from W. E. B. Du Bois to James Baldwin.

headline: Copy of Postal Service Audit Shows Extent of Mail Surveillance
text: WASHINGTON — In what experts say is the first acknowledgment of how the United States Postal Service’s mail surveillance program for national security investigations is used, the service’s internal watchdog found that inspectors failed to follow key safeguards in the gathering and handling of classified information.

headline: Why You Can’t Get There From La Guardia
text: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is reconsidering a longstanding rule that limits flights in and out of La Guardia Airport in Queens to a 1,500-mile radius. The authority should repeal the anachronistic policy, which was introduced decades ago to force airlines and travelers to use Kennedy Airport.

headline: Second Stage Adds ‘Dear Evan Hansen’ To Spring Season
text: A new musical about suicide, social media and a group of angsty high school students will be presented at Second Stage Theater next spring after a production at Arena Stage in Washington received strong reviews.

headline: Emery LeCrone’s Intimate (and Often Emotional) Dance
text: “You haven’t said anything yet,” the choreographer Emery LeCrone tells the dancers Shane Ohmer and Izabela Szylinska in rehearsal. They face each other, each with a hand on the other’s shoulder, and move closer. LeCrone pauses. “Now you have the conversation.” It’s the intensity of this movement — a silent yet intimate exchange between the dancers — that is emblematic of LeCrone’s choreographic style. While working within the classical vocabulary, LeCrone incorporates pedestrian movements — touching hands, hugging — that are strikingly tender. The steps look like ballet, but they’re less formal, more rugged and athletic — and her dancers are certainly not afraid of the floor. “When you go to a big theater and watch 20 dancers on a huge stage, it can feel very distant,” says LeCrone. “But ballet doesn’t have to be that way. It can be more approachable and emotional, less stark and refined.”

headline: Review: In ‘Air,’ Norman Reedus and Djimon Hounsou Keep Hope, and Themselves, Alive
text: “We can’t just decide who lives and who dies!” one character says in “Air.”

headline: Review: In ‘Big Sky,’ Starring Bella Thorne, Mortal Fears Collide
text: The actress Bella Thorne (“The Duff”; MTV’s “Scream”) dips her toes into grown-up desert noir with “Big Sky,” a lean exercise that leaves her over her head. Ms. Thorne plays Hazel, a teenager with acute agoraphobia and obsessive-compulsive disorder. Her lonely, mildly disheveled mother, Dee (Kyra Sedgwick), is accompanying her to a treatment center when the van carrying Hazel, Dee and four others is violently ambushed in a sandy wasteland. (The film was shot in New Mexico.) Their assailants are kidnappers (Aaron Tveit and Frank Grillo) who believe they have killed all the passengers save their quarry (Jodi Lynn Thomas), whom they stick in a car trunk. But Dee, though shot, is still alive, and Hazel, who has witnessed the carnage from a concealed spot, must surmount her fears to seek help in the wilderness.

headline: Review: ‘Fort Tilden,’ a Comic Odyssey to the Beach
text: Take the potty-mouthed, woman-centric millennial sensibility of HBO’s “Girls,” turn down the drama and turn up the comic amorality, and you have “Fort Tilden,” the highly amusing debut feature from Sarah-Violet Bliss and Charles Rogers. Rarely has a movie so humorously illustrated the meaning of “frenemy.”

headline: Mike Huckabee Offers 6 Percent Economic Growth, and Food Tips, at Iowa State Fair
text: DES MOINES – As the first of more than a dozen presidential candidates to drop by the Iowa State Fair, Mike Huckabee mixed the serious with the jovial on Thursday, promising economic growth of 6 percent if elected president, but beginning a speech with a culinary tip.

headline: Review: ‘Ten Thousand Saints,’ a Coming of Age in the East Village, Circa 1980s
text: If you are one of those people who romanticize the East Village in New York when it was at its grungiest, “Ten Thousand Saints” might be the movie of your dreams. Even if you’re not, it’s still a very fine film, full of quietly impressive performances and young characters who register as authentic.

headline: Viewfinder
text: Portraits by Delphine Diaw Diallo.

headline: Message Believed to Be From Qaeda Leader Pledges Support for Taliban
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The leader of Al Qaeda, Ayman al-Zawahri, broke nearly a year of radio silence on Thursday to pledge allegiance to the new leader of the Taliban, but his audio message made no mention of the Taliban’s two-year delay in acknowledging that their former leader was dead.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
text: Good evening. Here’s the latest.

headline: Review: ‘Tango Negro’ Explores the Roots of a Dance and Musical Genre
text: An interesting idea is overexplained in the documentary “Tango Negro: The African Roots of Tango.” Here, theories that are worth voicing are apparently worth repeating, and beats that sound catchy are sure to be replayed many times.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, Aug. 16 to 22, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: Sarasota Ballet, With Ashton as the Beating Heart of a Triple Bill
text: BECKET, Mass. — There is just one place I visit in America that seems a true dance-only haven: Jacob’s Pillow. People don’t come here to see theater or attend concerts, but hundreds drive every day to this secluded spot to attend performances of dance, dance, dance. Their interest in an extremely wide range of work makes the atmosphere one of singularly generous appreciation.

headline: In China, Single Women Live by Their Own Rules
text: Single women past a certain age are called “leftover women,” though some are pushing back against such traditional Chinese strictures.

headline: Review: In Sophie Hannah’s ‘Woman With a Secret,’ Mysteries Multiply
text: If anyone in Sophie Hannah’s latest book deserves to die, it’s Damon Blundy, a repellent British tabloid columnist who cannot write a sentence without making an enemy. And while his murder is annoyingly nasty — he is bound and gagged, a knife taped across his mouth — an intriguing clue lingers on the wall behind him, daubed in lurid red paint resembling blood: “HE IS NO LESS DEAD.”

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

text: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: In ‘People Places Things,’ Jemaine Clement Navigates Life as a Newly Single Dad
text: The fleeting pleasures of “People Places Things,” Jim Strouse’s winsome trifle of a comedy, derive almost entirely from the charm of its star, Jemaine Clement, the New Zealand-born actor best known in America as one-half of the musical comedy duo Flight of the Conchords.

headline: On Long Island, an Artists’ Collective Takes Shape
text: The common good may seem like an elusive political ideal — or a naive one. But for a group of eight young creatives on Long Island, banding together to form a collective to promote the arts has revitalized a small, sleepy surf town. Auto Body, as both the crew and its community space are known, formed last summer when sisters Georgia and Claire Read (whose father, Howard, founded the blue-chip gallery Cheim & Read) and their photographer friend Johnny Knapp “pushed our way,” as Claire puts it, into a vacant auto body shop (hence the name) in Bellport, N.Y. “The space came first, in a way,” she explains. “We knew it had been vacant for years and years, and we wanted to exhibit art and design and hold events, create a space for everyone in the village, bring a creative energy to Main Street, because it was lacking before.”

text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

text: This weekend, women who surf will step into the spotlight in Far Rockaway, Queens.

headline: Finding the Other, Cheaper Side of Bali
text: It was about five miles from the Kudesa Homestay guesthouse in Kemenuh village to the Gianyar Night Market, on the Indonesian island of Bali. So I asked my host, Mangku, whether I could make it on the bike he had available for rent. No problem, he said, he knew people who do it all the time.

text: Company executives discussed the addition of two Galaxy phones, the Note 5 and S6 Edge Plus.

headline: Review: ‘Meru’ Follows an Expedition Up Shark’s Fin Peak in the Himalayas
text: To dedicated mountaineers, an unconquered — and believed unconquerable — peak is an irresistible, insistent taunt on their to-do lists. “Meru” is the story of one such peak, the notorious Shark’s Fin atop Mount Meru in India and the pea beneath the mattress of the climber Conrad Anker.

text: Photos from China, Greece, India and Taiwan.
