text: Museums and Sites

headline: Love for Jimmy Carter in Plains, Ga., Where He Stands Tall
text: PLAINS, Ga. — Here, just beyond the welcome signs with the presidential seal, people still call him “Mr. Jimmy.”

headline: Review: Galactic, Paying Tribute to New Orleans and Its Sounds
text: For its encore at Brooklyn Bowl on Wednesday night, Galactic dug into “Africa,” a flag-waving funk classic recorded by the Meters just over 40 years ago. That song choice suggested a genuflection; an acknowledgment of influence, if not a pledge of allegiance.

headline: Review: ‘We Come as Friends’ Explores Potential Exploitation of South Sudan
text: In “Darwin’s Nightmare” (2005), a searing Oscar-nominated documentary about economic exploitation in Tanzania, the director Hubert Sauper found a perfect microcosm for colonialism in the invasive Nile perch. The fish was artificially introduced into Lake Victoria in the 1950s and ’60s, ate all the other fish and then was exported as food for Europe and Japan. In the meantime, Tanzania suffered from a famine, and as the film repeatedly sought to demonstrate, the planes arriving to pick up the fish sometimes brought in weapons for use in the continent’s civil wars.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Aug. 14-20
text: International Contemporary Circus Festival

headline: NBC Extends Jimmy Fallon’s ‘Tonight Show’ Contract Into 2021
text: LOS ANGELES — A few weeks before NBC faces a new challenge in late night, the network is doubling down on Jimmy Fallon as the host of the “Tonight” show.

headline: Review: In ‘Prince,’ a Restless Teenager’s Risky Bid for Acceptance
text: For a boy of a certain age and income, the most potent instrument of seduction may well be a pair of ultramarine Zanotti shoes. They can carry him toward his dreams of joining the royal family of the streets, conquering the thugs who torment him and winning the heart of Laura (Sigrid ten Napel), the fairest of the girls at the Dutch housing project where he and his posse dwell.

headline: Study Links Polluted Air in China to 1.6 Million Deaths a Year
text: BEIJING — Outdoor air pollution contributes to the deaths of an estimated 1.6 million people in China every year, or about 4,400 people a day, according to a newly released scientific paper.

headline: Take a Ride on a SeaGlass Carousel
text: A carousel designed as an underwater garden teeming with fish is opening in Lower Manhattan.

headline: New York’s New Carousel Puts You in a Whirling School of Mechanized Fish
text: COME with me to the Battery, to the tip of Manhattan, where the sea meets the city, where the sea once was, where the sea may be again someday.

headline: Christie’s to Sell Collection of Arthur and Anita Kahn Beginning This Fall
text: There was a Calder sculpture on a tabletop, a Calder on a bookcase, and a Calder mobile hung from the ceiling.

headline: Even in the New Alphabet, Google Keeps Its Capital G
text: G is for Google, as the company’s chief executive, Larry Page, put it this week in a blog post introducing Alphabet, Google’s new corporate name.

headline: Review: In ‘The Great Man,’ Friendship and Politics in a War Zone
text: A pocket-size pleasure, the French movie “The Great Man” opens with a fairy-tale flourish as a child narrator winds up the once-upon-a-time. The movie then takes a break in a war zone, where a monster with glowing eyes briefly sends it into fantasy and a wounded soldier yanks it back to terra firma. Not long after, swells of emotion seep in like low-rolling fog and suddenly you are watching a drama about real people wrestling with life blow by blow.

headline: Photos That Celebrate — and Challenge — Feminine Ideals
text: The photographer Delphine Diaw Diallo’s “Highness” series originated a few years ago as a collaboration with the hairstylist Joanne Petit Frere, who creates fantastical, sculptural styles with real hair. Frere asked Diallo, a graduate of the Academie Charpentier of Visual Arts in Paris, to photograph her work, and the two started working together on a series of increasingly revealing portraits. Diallo, who was born to a Senegalese father and a French mother in Paris, was attracted to the idea of women recreating themselves — and wanted to challenge traditional notions of femininity and eminence. “What kind of queen can I create?” she says. “How can I redefine what highness means to a woman’s experience?” To her, the true “highnesses” are warriors.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, Aug. 16 to 22, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: ‘Robert Seydel: The Eye in Matter’ Looks at an Artist’s Traces
text: Robert Seydel is growing on me. This artist, who rarely exhibited during his lifetime, but worked as a curator and taught photography and film at Hampshire College in Amherst, Mass., died at 50 in 2011. He left behind an odd body of work — mostly notebooks, little collages and drawings — that are now on view in “Robert Seydel: The Eye in Matter” at the Queens Museum.

headline: With $350 Billion Plan, Hillary Clinton Prods Rivals on Student Debt
text: When Hillary Rodham Clinton unveiled her plan this week to make higher education more affordable, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida promptly dismissed it as “Obamacare for college.” Jeb Bush, the former Florida governor, asserted that she would burden taxpayers by throwing more federal money at the problem.

headline: Review: Bada Shanren, Chinese Art Superstar, Takes a Bow at the Freer
text: WASHINGTON — Beginning in January, the Freer Gallery of Art here will go dark for a year and a half while its 1923 building gets an overhaul. Some museums might take a shutdown as an opportunity to send its collection on the road, to generate institutional advertising and earn rental fees. But the Freer doesn’t have that option.

headline: Dan Flavin’s ‘Icon’ Constructions on Display in Bridgehampton
text: Dan Flavin’s early works have come home again.

headline: Review: In ‘A Rare Earth Magnet’ at Derek Eller, a Focus on Repurposed Materials
text: ‘A RARE EARTH MAGNET’

headline: Review: In ‘The Architectural Impulse,’ Art Aspires
text: ‘THE ARCHITECTURAL IMPULSE’

headline: For Fitz Henry Lane and Other 19th-Century Painters, Catalogues Raisonnés Go Digital
text: New technology and fresh perspectives are jumpstarting efforts to assemble exhaustive lists of works by 19th-century American painters, sometimes in progress for decades. Next month a consortium of museums interested in the Massachusetts maritime painter Fitz Henry Lane (1804-65) will introduce a website, fitzhenrylaneonline.org, documenting about 320 paintings, drawings and prints at various institutions. Much of the material is being drawn from the Cape Ann Museum, in Mr. Lane’s hometown, Gloucester, Mass., and images on the website will be linked to infrared paint analyses, biographies of Mr. Lane’s clients, newspaper ads for his suppliers, maps of harbors where he sketched and portraits of owners of the ships moored there.

headline: Mastodons Remembered at Staten Island Show
text: Mastodons, while tramping around what is now New York, shed teeth and tusks, and dinosaurs, wandering along riverfronts in Massachusetts, left footprints in mud that hardened into sandstone. Remnants of these prehistoric creatures and artifacts from the Americans who discovered them are heading to museum galleries in the region.

headline: Review: The Writer Raymond Roussel and His Legacy, at Galerie Buchholz
text: RAYMOND ROUSSEL

headline: Review: Cy Gavin Employs Unusual Canvas Ingredients in ‘Overture’
text: CY GAVIN

headline: Review: ‘Mistress America,’ a Noah Baumbach Comedy on Getting By in a Backbiting World
text: Noah Baumbach’s “Mistress America” advertises itself as a screwball comedy. But this smart, fast-paced film is not really the zany, lighter-than-air divertissement that the term usually conjures. There are scattered sharp one-liners, but not enough to infuse the movie with a sustained bonhomie. It’s fair to say that “Mistress America” revises and subverts this most buoyant of genres with a steady undertow of anxiety, dread and anger.

headline: Review: In ‘Tom at the Farm,’ Psychosexual Games Down at the Farm
text: “Tom at the Farm,” the fourth film from the 26-year-old French Canadian wunderkind Xavier Dolan, is a teasing exercise in unfettered narcissism that sticks its out tongue out and goes, “Nyah, nyah, nyah” as if it were a 5-year-old running wild on a sugar high. I should add that the movie, completed in 2013 and just now being released, is wildly entertaining, sexy and beautifully shot in the Canadian heartland.

headline: One Year Later, Fringe Festival Shows Measure Their Success
text: A Fringe festival can be a real boon for theatergoers, offering the chance to binge on a variety of new plays, musicals and other performances. Best of all, in most cases you can gluttonously feed your theater addiction without spending a ton of money: Tickets for shows at the forthcoming New York International Fringe Festival, for example, are just $18.

headline: 10 Shows to Watch for at This Year’s New York Fringe Festival
text: Will participants in the 2015 New York International Fringe Festival be glad they performed, once this year’s frenzy is over? First they need audiences. Using methods mostly instinctual, editors and writers for The New York Times put their heads together for a list of 10 shows they’re anticipating among the 200 productions. (Dates, times and sites are at fringenyc.org.)

headline: ‘Outsider Art’ Under One Roof at Katonah Museum of Art
text: In the almost 70 years since the term was first coined, “outsider art” — a somewhat dismissive designation for the work of self-taught artists — has been steadily finding its way inside the mainstream art world. These days, it is no longer unusual to see pieces by artists with no formal training displayed in even the most prestigious venues; just the past two years have seen such works included in exhibitions mounted by the Venice Biennale, the Museum of Modern Art, the Philadelphia Museum of Art and the Brooklyn Museum, among others.

headline: Tiger Woods Blames His Putting After a Disappointing 75
text: HAVEN, Wis. — Tiger Woods’s first-round score at the P.G.A. Championship on Thursday was a disappointing three-over-par 75. But in a measure of how far Woods has fallen, it was his second-best result in the opening round of a major championship this year.

headline: Missing Historical Marker Resurrects Debate Over Photographer’s Birthplace
text: JOHNSBURG, N.Y. — Publicity surrounding the mysterious disappearance, last August, of a sign commemorating a famed Civil War photographer, Mathew B. Brady, has generated more than enough money for its replacement.

headline: Theater Listings for Aug. 14-20
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: A Review of ‘Misalliance’ at the Shakespeare Theater in Madison
text: The setting for “Misalliance,” which depicts an elegant conservatory in a baronial country house in England, may briefly mislead some theatergoers into expecting a genteel comedy. But its ever-devilish author, George Bernard Shaw, packs plenty of craziness into this 1909 play, now receiving a very smart revival by the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey in Madison.

headline: Review of ‘La Cage aux Folles’ at Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam
text: Just what makes the campy musical “La Cage aux Folles” work so well? (As it does, delightfully, in the production now deep into a run at the Goodspeed Opera House.) I was moved to ponder that question after overhearing a couple of intermission conversations, both of which used this phrase:

headline: Goldman Expands Retail Banking by Taking On GE Capital’s Deposits
text: Goldman Sachs is broadening its effort to offer banking services to people with a wider array of incomes than it has traditionally served.

headline: Restaurant Review: Regulars Say R.S.V.P. Does Everything Wrong, Except for the Food
text: R.S.V.P., in West Cornwall, offers one of the most unusual dining experiences in the Northeast. So unusual, in fact, that some of the restaurant’s regular customers have accused it of doing everything wrong. Everything, that is, except for the food.

headline: Restaurant Review: At Picnic on the Square in Ridgewood, Balancing Rich and Light
text: When Christine E. Nunn, the executive chef and co-owner of Picnic on the Square in Ridgewood, was 16 years old, her boyfriend made fun of her for burning a pot of Campbell’s soup and told her she didn’t know how to cook.

headline: Review: Lilly’s in White Plains Finds Room for Chandeliers and Sundaes
text: Mamaroneck Avenue in White Plains can be something of a scene, with restaurants competing for wandering singles with thumping music and standard pub fare. When I first entered Lilly’s, which opened in April, I feared I had found another example of the trend. Pop music was blasting and, despite the airy, attractive space, I braced myself for an uncomfortable meal with little conversation because no one could hear anyone speak.

headline: A Reading of “Later in the Garden” by Sandra Lim
text: The poet reads her verse on Adam and Eve.

headline: Review: A Classically Italian Menu at Restaurant Joanina in Huntington
text: Was this downtown Huntington or a town in Tuscany? I counted nine restaurants with outdoor seating within a one-block radius. One of the most appealing spots was Restaurant Joanina. While most of the competition had sidewalk seating in front of a noisy street, Joanina faced a parking lot (a slight improvement) and its tables were separated from that lot by planters overflowing with flowers.

headline: Colorado: Water Near Mine at Pre-Spill Toxicity
text: The water just below a Colorado mine that poured three million gallons of toxic waste into nearby waterways has returned to pre-spill levels of toxicity, officials said Thursday. The Environmental Protection Agency is still analyzing water farther along the spill’s path — in New Mexico, the Navajo Nation and Utah. Officials in Utah said waste from the mine had probably reached Lake Powell, a major water storage facility for the region. E.P.A. officials have said they will have to monitor the spill’s path for years to understand its full effect. The Gold King Mine, near Silverton, burst on Aug. 5 while workers contracted by the E.P.A. were conducting a field investigation of the mine, which had leaked for years. The agency has said it was responsible for the spill. Levels of metals including arsenic and lead jumped in local waterways as the contamination flowed down the Animas River and into the San Juan, angering many who use these rivers for drinking, irrigation and recreational activities. Colorado, New Mexico, Utah and the Navajo Nation declared states of emergency. The rivers remained closed Thursday.

headline: Bangladeshi Women, Isolated in New York City, Need More Support, Advocates Say
text: A 3-week-old baby ended up dead in the courtyard of an apartment building in Queens. The police arrested the mother, Rashida Chowdhury, a 21-year-old Bangladeshi immigrant, on charges of second-degree murder. They said she confessed to throwing the baby out the bathroom window of her fourth-floor apartment because she thought the child was possessed by an evil spirit.

headline: Former Editor of Time Inc. to Lead Yahoo Magazines
text: Martha Nelson, a former editor in chief of Time Inc., will join Yahoo as its global editor in chief, the company said Thursday, overseeing its portfolio of digital magazines. Ms. Nelson, the founding editor of InStyle and a former editor of People magazine, had taken the top editorial job at Time Inc. in 2013. But she left later that year in a shake-up that eliminated her position and had editors of the company’s 21 magazines reporting to the business side. She will be based in New York when she starts her new job next week, Yahoo said, and will focus on developing Yahoo’s 13 domestic digital magazines and 30 international magazines.

headline: Tom Brady Unexpectedly Starts for Patriots
text: A day after the N.F.L. and Tom Brady faced off in federal court over his suspension for his role in the deflation of footballs used in last season’s A.F.C. championship game, he started in the New England Patriots’ preseason opener Thursday against the Green Bay Packers.

headline: New York Council Passes Bill Aimed at Limiting Future Legionnaires’ Outbreaks
text: With New York City’s largest ever outbreak of Legionnaires’ disease apparently waning, the City Council passed a bill on Thursday intended to thwart future spread of the illness.

headline: Biff Liff, Broadway Manager and Powerhouse Agent, Dies at 96
text: When “My Fair Lady” opened on Broadway in 1956, there was Alan Jay Lerner’s book, and there was Biff Liff’s book. Mr. Liff’s book, the log he kept as the production stage manager, swelled to several volumes over the show’s long run, and the entries were not just about each performance.

headline: Washington State Faces $100,000-a-Day Fine Until Schools Plan Is Reached
text: SEATTLE — Washington State’s highest court, which has threatened, cajoled and pleaded with the state Legislature and governor for years to close the gap in spending between rich and poor schools, said on Thursday that it had finally lost its patience. In a unanimous decision, the nine-member Supreme Court imposed a fine of $100,000 a day on the state until a plan to reduce the gap was accepted, and in a written order “encouraged” Gov. Jay Inslee to call the Legislature into a special session.

headline: Freddie Mac Yields
text: Average for some Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. securities.

headline: In Good Times or Bad, Brazil Banks Profit
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Political parties whose symbol is a red star tend to be unfavorable for bankers, but Brazil’s ruling party has been a lucrative exception.

headline: In Latin America, Quiet Diplomacy Bears Fruit
text: Nearly seven years ago, President Evo Morales of Bolivia expelled the American ambassador, denouncing him for “conspiring against democracy and seeking the division of Bolivia.” Months later, Mr. Morales’s government kicked the Drug Enforcement Administration out of La Paz, in a rebuke of Washington’s approach to counternarcotics in the region. In 2013, Bolivia ejected the American government’s international aid agency, which Mr. Morales accused of working secretly to destabilize his government.

headline: U.S. and Turkey Face Questions in Anti-ISIS Effort
text: GAZIANTEP, Turkey — The United States and Turkey have taken preliminary steps to carry out a plan to push the extremists of the Islamic State from the last strip of Syrian territory along the Turkish border controlled by the jihadist group.

headline: Joe Biden Wades Further Into 2016 Bid
text: WASHINGTON — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is vacationing on Kiawah Island off South Carolina’s coast, riding bikes and walking the beaches with his family. But on Wednesday night, he called one of his most outspoken political supporters and wrestled with the question looming over his future: Should he run for president?

headline: Breakdown at BP Refinery Strains Midwest Gas Prices
text: A breakdown at a BP refinery outside Chicago is sending jolts across the energy markets of the Midwest and Canada, pushing up gasoline prices even as oil prices over all reached a six-year low.

headline: The End of Prison Days, the Start of Something New
text: Rudolph Norris, 58, is out of prison and trying to piece together a new life after his sentence for drug offenses was commuted by President Obama.

headline: They Look to the Sky
text: People gathered in Inwood Hill Park in Upper Manhattan on Wednesday for an unobstructed view of the Perseid meteor shower, an annual occurrence during which burning specks of cosmic dust race zoom through the heavens at 36 miles per second. The meteor activity is expected to drop sharply after this weekend.

headline: Stores Suffer From a Shift of Behavior in Buyers
text: As Americans spend more money on doing things, not buying things, department stores are losing out.

headline: The Yen, Won and Renminbi: A Triangular Guide to the East Asian Currency Wars
text: These charts show the relative currency strength of East Asia’s three largest economies over the last 15 years.

headline: A Secretive Path to Raising U.S. Flag in Cuba
text: WASHINGTON — Before the United States and Cuba could seal a historic diplomatic rapprochement brokered in 18 months of secret talks, they first had to hide a pregnancy.

headline: Marco Rubio Frustrates Those Taking a Zero-Abortion Stand
text: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida surprised some Democrats and moderate Republicans last week when he said during the Republican presidential debate that he opposed abortion even in cases where rape or incest were involved: He had previously backed legislation allowing those exceptions. Though many abortion opponents applauded the bill, some groups were frustrated with Mr. Rubio for what they saw as compromised values.

headline: Rory McIlroy Returns, and Is Tested Immediately
text: HAVEN, Wis. — The next great rivalry in golf broke slowly out of the gates Thursday, which just shows the folly of treating golfers as if they are heavyweight boxers or world champion sprinters. Rory McIlroy and Jordan Spieth may have shared a tee time in the first round of the 97th P.G.A. Championship, but they were not each other’s main adversary.

headline: Story’s Opening
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — The Jewish Association Serving the Aging, or J.A.S.A. as it’s popularly known, provides services for people age 55 and up in new York City, and one of the classes taught there is the fine art of crossword puzzle construction. The class has been taught by a variety of familiar constructor names, including Ian Livengood, Finn Vigeland and now Natan Last and, if the puzzle passes muster, it is published in The New York Times. If you live in New York City and would like to join the constructing class, the Fall 2015 catalog can be downloaded here.

headline: Before Texas Killing, Officer Took Unusual Path to Police Work
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Officer James Bradley Miller was not a typical rookie in the Police Department here. At 49, he was six years older than the chief. He discovered law enforcement relatively late in life, after struggling for decades in an array of jobs and careers.

headline: Egypt: 2 Groups Handled Hostage, Croatia Says
text: A Croatian expatriate worker believed to have been beheaded by the Islamic State’s Egyptian affiliate was initially abducted by a different group that demanded a ransom, Croatia’s foreign minister said Thursday. The worker, Tomislav Salopek, 30, was kidnapped on July 22 on the outskirts of Cairo, and on Wednesday, the affiliate, Sinai Province, released a picture of what it claimed was Mr. Salopek’s body. Foreign Minister Vesna Pusic said it was “very likely” that “two separate organizations” were involved in Mr. Salopek’s abduction, “one which kidnapped and the other which presented itself as ISIS, Sinai Province.” Sinai Province released a video of Mr. Salopek on Aug. 5, in which he conveyed the militants’ threat to kill him if Muslim women were not released from Egyptian jails. Ms. Pusic said that Egypt and Croatia had not yet been able to confirm Mr. Salopek’s death.

headline: Smelly Visit to New York’s Sewer System Ends With 3 Men Under Arrest
text: The sewer system of New York — the more than 7,500 miles of it — exists to move the slush left behind in a city of millions. Still, for a branch of infrastructure, it has done a remarkable job of inspiring the public’s imagination into believing it is so much more.

headline: Man Killed in a Shooting in Brooklyn
text: One man was killed and two more were injured in a shooting in Brooklyn on Thursday night, the police said.

headline: Ryan Fitzpatrick’s First Start for Jets Is Brief, but He’s Happy
text: DETROIT — The Jets did something normal on Thursday: They played a football game without incident or swirling drama. Alas, they opened the preseason in underwhelming fashion, losing by 23-3 to the Lions at Ford Field.

headline: Obama Is Set to Discuss Rights Issues With China
text: WASHINGTON — A top State Department official said Thursday that there was a “growing sense of alarm in the United States about human rights developments in China,” vowing that the issue would feature prominently in summit talks between President Xi Jinping of China and President Obama in Washington next month.

headline: New York Schools With Many Opting Out of Tests May Be Penalized
text: A drastic increase this year in the number of students sitting out New York’s standardized exams has created another kind of test, one for state and federal education officials who must decide whether to punish school districts with low participation rates.

headline: Fresh Face Arrives, and Yankees’ Bats Awake From a Slumber
text: CLEVELAND — In the movie “Major League,” the first baseman for the Cleveland Indians, a character named Pedro Cerrano, makes offerings to Jobu, his voodoo totem, to drive the fear out of his bats. A cup of rum is the preferred sacrament, though sacrificing a chicken is also a consideration.

headline: The Illustrated Interview: Greta Gerwig
text: In this series for T, notables from the worlds of fashion, art, design and entertainment sketch their responses to a brief questionnaire.

headline: Imagining Life After Eden
text: For T’s ongoing series, the poet Sandra Lim and the artist Lionel Estève consider life for Adam and Eve after the fall, as a banal reality begins to crystallize.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Michael Stipe
text: For his new bookshop installation, One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next installment in the series comes from Michael Stipe, the artist and former frontman of the band R.E.M., who shares his picks exclusively with T.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | bombastic
text: bombastic • \bäm-ˈbas-tik\ • adjective

headline: Indonesia Frees 2 Educators After Court Overturns Sex Abuse Convictions
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Two educators at a prestigious international school in Indonesia were freed from prison on Friday after an appeals court overturned their convictions and 10-year prison sentences on charges of sexually assaulting kindergartners, in a case that the school said was fabricated and that led to international concern about the competence of the country’s judicial system.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
text: 9:15 A.M. (Cinemax) SWEENEY TODD: THE DEMON BARBER OF FLEET STREET (2007) Johnny Depp, his skin pale and his eyes odd, stars as the vengeful barber (and earned a best actor Oscar nomination) in Tim Burton’s film of the Stephen Sondheim-Hugh Wheeler musical. Helena Bonham Carter is Mrs. Lovett, the pie maker who disposes of Sweeney’s victims. And Alan Rickman is the malevolent judge who had Sweeney transported to Australia, stole his wife (Laura Michelle Kelly) and now has guardianship of his teenage daughter. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called the film “as dark and terrifying as any motion picture in recent memory, not excluding the bloody installments in the ‘Saw’ franchise,” adding, “It is also something close to a masterpiece, a work of extreme — I am tempted to say evil — genius.” In “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory” (2005), Mr. Burton’s sugar-rush adaptation of the Roald Dahl book, at 8 p.m. on ABC Family, Mr. Depp portrays an oddly sinister candy maker, and Freddie Highmore is a boy who wants nothing more than to swim in chocolate. Well, who wouldn’t? Despite burdening Willy Wonka with a psychological back story, “there is simply too much pleasure to be found in Wonka’s world to get too hung up about his relationship with his dad,” A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. “The real lesson of ‘Charlie and the Chocolate Factory’ is — or should be — that pleasure and curiosity are their own rewards.”

headline: Quotation of the Day: August 14, 2015
text: “He said that raping me is his prayer to God. I said to him, ‘What you’re doing to me is wrong, and it will not bring you closer to God.’”

headline: Corrections: August 14, 2015
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: China’s Currency Stabilizes After 3-Day Slide
text: HONG KONG — China’s currency stabilized on Friday, ending a three-day plunge that shook markets globally during the renminbi’s steepest devaluation in decades.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Trump’s Economic Muddle
text: DONALD TRUMP’S economic views may not have garnered as much attention as his misogynistic statements, but they are equally unpalatable, evincing a lack of understanding of basic economics that is startling for a billionaire businessman.

headline: Coke Tries to Sugarcoat the Truth on Calories
text: The Coca-Cola Company, which has suffered a large decline in consumption of sugary sodas as consumers worry about obesity, has formed a new organization to emphasize exercise as the best way to control obesity and to play down the importance of cutting calories.

headline: A Multiple-Choice Question: Which Answer Is Correct?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bungling Beijing’s Stock Markets
text: China is ruled by a party that calls itself Communist, but its economic reality is one of rapacious crony capitalism. And everyone has been assuming that the nation’s leaders are in on the joke, that they know better than to take their occasional socialist rhetoric seriously.

headline: Liberals, Conservatives and Jon Stewart
text: To the Editor:

headline: This Week’s Movies | August 14, 2015
text: The New York Times film critics review “Straight Outta Compton,” “Mistress America” and “The Man From U.N.C.L.E.”

headline: Zen and the Art of Dying Well
text: What is the “right” way to die? We’re experiencing a zeitgeist moment about that. “Being Mortal: Medicine and What Matters in the End,” by Atul Gawande, is a best-selling book. Videos by Brittany Maynard, a 29-year-old who wanted to die in a way of her own choosing, went viral last year. And in more than 20 countries, thousands of people have dined and discussed dying through a project called “Death Over Dinner.”

headline: As Greek Bailout Deal Passes, Alexis Tsipras Faces Rebellion
text: ATHENS — The Greek Parliament and eurozone ministers approved an international loan deal on Friday that the Greek government needs to avoid defaulting on a debt payment next week. But an all-night debate required in Greece, and a growing rebellion within Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras’s leftist Syriza party, seemed to have pushed his coalition closer to spinning apart.

headline: Summer in the City: Some Like It Loud
text: Every Sunday morning at 10:30, Ingrid Erickson comes to rapt attention as the choir at Macedonia Baptist Church in Hamilton Heights launches into full-throated renditions of “Glory to His Name,” “Lift Him Up” and “Hold to God’s Unchanging Hand.”

headline: Kerry Strikes Delicate Balance in Havana Trip for Embassy Flag-Raising
text: HAVANA — John Kerry, the first secretary of state to visit Cuba in 70 years, said on Friday that the Cuban government could not expect the United States to lift its trade embargo unless it moved to improve its record on human rights.

headline: With a Letter From the President, a New Day for Rudolph Norris
text: Mr. Norris, who was granted clemency by President Obama along with several other prisoners, has the potential to turn his life around. He responded to the president with gratitude and a promise, writing that “it feels as if the chains that I have been wearing for a long time have suddenly been released.”

headline: With Clemency From Obama, Drug Offender Embraces Second Chance
text: MORGANTOWN, W.Va. — Rudolph Norris walked out of Morgantown federal prison two weeks ago carrying a duffel bag like no other. First, he had spent six months hand-stitching it himself from dozens of mottled leather scraps, symbolizing the shards of his life he longed to piece back together. Then he unzipped it and pulled out his invitation to try.

headline: Decades After Pearl Harbor, a Mission to Honor ‘the Unknowns’ Gains Urgency
text: HONOLULU — As the sun broke from behind the billowy clouds hanging over Oahu’s Koolau mountains, a seven-member detail of military personnel transferred five coffins one recent morning, disinterred from two grave sites marked “unknown,” at the Punchbowl, the National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific here in the shallow crater of an extinct volcano.

headline: Nick Symmonds, a Sidelined Track Star, Continues to Break From the Pack
text: SEATTLE — Nick Symmonds sat at a desk in his modest apartment, equipped with a laptop, a printer, a scanner, a cellphone and caffeine-infused gum. If he could not run at the world track and field championships, at least he could talk nonstop about why he was not running.

headline: A New Style for a New Havana
text: The dandies of the Cuban capital embrace a reggaeton-inspired look.

headline: Forget Retro. The Men of Havana Embrace the Reggaeton Look.
text: HAVANA — On a recent evening, tourists in banded hats and guayabera shirts climbed out of pink 1950s-era American cars to puff cigars, drink mojitos and listen to Buena Vista Social Club classics at the Hotel Nacional. It was one of those frozen-in-time Havana scenes that Americans, enticed by their flag once again flying over the U.S. embassy and the promised easing of a 50-year embargo, can’t wait to witness.

headline: News Q’s | A Museum Exhibit on Cats and the Internet
text: Note: We’ve updated 6 Q’s About the News for the new school year. Let us know what you think.

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: Aug. 14
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images of summer love, the Dominican Day Parade and meteor watchers.

headline: Donald Trump, Moderate Republican
text: Donald Trump may be the “post-policy candidate,” but when you strip away the bluster and the outrageous commentary that have defined his campaign to find his occasional, substantive statements about public policy, a surprising fact emerges: Mr. Trump is a moderate Republican.

headline: 读者评论区: 日本投降70周年
text: 你认为日本对二战中的侵略行为是否做出了足够有诚意的道歉？请与我们分享您有关这一话题的想法。

text: Our weekday morning digest that includes information about outdoor activities and events, with deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.

headline: A Grief So Deep It Won’t Die
text: She had taken care of her husband for the last eight years of his life, through his blindness, through cancer and heart failure. After he died in 2002, she sold the Long Island house they’d loved and shared, finding it too filled with memories, and moved to their country home in upstate New York.

headline: New York Today: A Starry Show
text: Good morning on this warmer Friday.

headline: Eurozone Finance Ministers Approve Greek Bailout
text: BRUSSELS — Eurozone finance ministers on Friday backed a Greek bailout plan approved earlier in the day by lawmakers in Athens, overcoming months of bitterness.

headline: Statement by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan
text: On the 70th anniversary of the end of the war, we must calmly reflect upon the road to war, the path we have taken since it ended, and the era of the 20th century. We must learn from the lessons of history the wisdom for our future.

headline: Today in Politics: Democrats Gather for Chicken Wings in Shadow of Iowa State Fair
text: Good Friday morning, as the United States reopens its embassy in Cuba and Senator Marco Rubio of Florida travels to New York to condemn the move. But most of the campaigns are in Iowa, where the State Fair offers soapboxes to speak from, and where the Democrats will gather to chow down as they press the flesh.

headline: The 8.2.15 Issue
text: Readers respond.

headline: How to Brush a Gorilla’s Teeth
text: Even 400-pound silverbacks will fear a toothbrush. ‘‘You have to desensitize them,’’ says Jodi Carrigan, the lead keeper of primates at Zoo Atlanta, which is home to the largest collection of gorillas in North America. At first, place the toothbrush at a safe distance, somewhere out of reach but visible. Every day, inch it closer until you can hold the brush in your hand while you teach the gorilla to open its mouth. To do this, reward it with grapes, slices of apple, popcorn or juice (Crystal Light is an ape favorite). The first time an animal completes the desired behavior, ‘‘jackpot’’ it, offering 10 grapes instead of one. ‘‘Then they’re like, ‘Oh, whatever I just did I should do it again,’ ’’ Carrigan says.

headline: ‘More Than Once’
text: So much depends on the precision of language. In this seemingly plain-spoken poem, ‘‘tears’’ suggests not only a literal image but also an abstract one. In that trick the eye plays on the mind, I see at once the rips in the fence and a glimpse at the emotion such a crossing — ‘‘a little dangerous’’ — can engender.

headline: The Island of Decades Before
text: Our first family vacation in 33 years began with a suicide.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Uzbek
text: Four years ago, the federal government paid me a large sum — a year of graduate-school tuition, plus a stipend — to study Uzbek at the University of Chicago. Uzbek is among the least commonly taught of the so-called Less Commonly Taught Languages, or L.C.T.L.s. So uncommonly is it taught, in fact, that without federal largess it would hardly be taught at all. Because I happened to speak decent Turkish, a cousin of Uzbek, and because I spent a week in Uzbekistan when I was 22, and because life is nothing if not a sequence of odd choices vaguely considered, for two years I sat in a room with two other students and produced some extremely literal translations.

headline: Why Did He Feel Like a Knife Was Stabbing His Head?
text: A patient worries about his painful earaches and asymmetrical pupils.

headline: Ramiro Gomez’s Domestic Disturbances
text: I first noticed the work of the young Los Angeles artist Ramiro Gomez across a series of recent art fairs, on account of those Hockneys of his: that is, paintings that were dead ringers for Hockneys — same scale, same colors, same composition — except that something was always just slightly off. Take Gomez’s large-scale version of Hockney’s iconic ‘‘American Collectors’’ double portrait, for example, which Gomez’s Los Angeles dealer, Charlie James, exhibited at the most recent Expo Chicago. It looks almost exactly like the original portrait of the couple in question, clenched in a grim rictus amid the sculptures in their backyard garden, except that Gomez replaced the two collector protagonists with a pair of dark-skinned gardeners of the sort who regularly do the actual tending of such gardens. Into another Hockney, of one of those nondescript West Los Angeles apartment buildings with its wide front lawn, Gomez slotted a groundskeeper, rake extended. That was the genius of the whole series: how in much the same way that, back in the ’60s, the English transplant Hockney first opened our eyes to so much that we had previously overlooked in Los Angeles, rendering all sorts of things visible to us as if for the first time (those boxy apartment buildings, the distinctive street signs, the moderne furniture, that light), so Gomez seemed to be allowing us, indeed forcing us, to notice the very groundskeepers and housemaids and pool cleaners who make that look, the look of Los Angeles, possible, rendering visible a whole world of people, our fellow humans, who often go unseen (and who, for that matter, because they are sometimes ‘‘illegal,’’ often strive not to be seen).

headline: Taliban Present Gentler Face but Wield Iron Fist in Afghan District
text: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan — As they have captured more territory in Afghanistan this year, the Taliban have twinned their military offensive with a publicity push. Their pitch goes something like this: We’ve learned the lessons from our time in power, and we’re ready to moderate a bit.

headline: Morning Agenda: A New Global Currency War
text: A NEW GLOBAL CURRENCY WAR | China held firm on the value of its money for years, as other countries tried to secure an economic advantage by letting the value of their currencies slide on international markets. Some analysts see its jump into the fray as a new phase in a long-raging global currency war, Peter Eavis writes in DealBook. The plunge paused on Friday, but the renminbi was still down 4.4 percent against the dollar this week, a huge drop for China and the steepest drop since the country’s modern exchange system was set up, Neil Gough reports in The New York Times. The move could leave the United States exposed and undermine efforts to pull the world economy out of the doldrums.

headline: Searching for Missing After China Blast
text: Friends and relatives hoped to find their loved ones in a local hospital after a warehouse blast killed at least 50 in Tianjin.

headline: Death Toll in Chinese Fire Rises, Along With Anger at Apparent Safety Lapses
text: BEIJING — The high-rise apartment complex closest to Tianjin’s toxic chemical storage inferno was only 2,000 feet away, despite Chinese laws requiring a 3,200-foot minimum distance from hazardous sites.

text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea denied on Friday planting land mines that maimed two South Korean soldiers near their guard post last week.

text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — A Palestinian prisoner on a hunger strike for 60 days was placed on an artificial respirator and given fluids intravenously on Friday after his lungs stopped working and he had seizures.

text: NEW DELHI — Two men suspected of belonging to the extremist Islamic group Ansarullah Bangla Team have been arrested in Bangladesh in connection with the murder of a secular blogger this month, the police said on Friday.

headline: What Eating 40 Teaspoons of Sugar a Day Can Do to You
text: Soda has been a major target in the debate over sugar and its role in the obesity crisis. But high levels of added sugars can be found in many seemingly healthful foods, from yogurts to energy bars and even whole-grain bread.

text: Even as AT&T has been busy expanding its wireless empire into other markets, like cars and home security, it remains at its heart a phone carrier. The company said Friday that it made some minor revisions to some of its most popular phone plans, offering more mobile data per buck.

text: You are lucky enough to have some money to give away: It could be $100 or $1 million. Whether you are prepared to make a small donation or a big one, you would like to accomplish something good with it.

headline: Florida Legislators Deny Gerrymandering as They Slouch Back to the Drawing Board
text: In 2010, 63 percent of Florida voters approved a “Fair Districts” amendment to the state constitution designed to end the partisan dirty pool that is as old as Congress itself — the gerrymandering of congressional boundaries to favor one party over the other. Patrick Henry tried it first in Virginia in 1788, having lines drawn to block James Madison from a congressional seat, but Madison prevailed before the voters.

headline: 1940: France Gets a 2nd Guillotine
text: VICHY — The partition of France into two zones, occupied and unoccupied, has had the unfortunate consequence of depriving the French government of the services of the official executioner, known as ‘‘Monsieur Paris,’’ who is in Paris. So the civil authorities have had to call on ‘‘Monsieur Algeria,’’ who in civilian life goes by the name of Henri Roch, to behead criminals guilty of capital offenses. ‘‘Monsieur Algeria’’ has arrived in Nimes from North Africa with three assistants and a guillotine. There he will discharge the duties of his gruesome office until the French government is permitted by the Germans to return to Paris. — New York Herald Tribune, August 15, 1940

headline: British Trader Charged in ‘Flash Crash’ Released After Bail Reduction
text: LONDON — Navinder Singh Sarao, the British futures trader charged by United States authorities with contributing to a sudden plunge in American stock markets five years ago, was assigned a reduced bail at a court hearing on Friday, allowing him to be released from custody.

text: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “Straight Outta Compton,” “Mistress America” and “The Man From U.N.C.L.E.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: An Ode to Diving Boards
text: Remember the summertime thrill of leaping off a diving board? Since the 1970s it has gotten harder to find in New York, as diving boards have steadily disappeared from the city’s pools.

headline: Readers Share Back-to-School Tips for Incoming Freshmen
text: Freshman year can be a challenge. Between choosing the right classes, meeting new people and navigating tricky roommate relationships, there’s plenty of room for error.

headline: First Draft Focus: It’s Heigh-Ho, Come to the (Iowa) Fair!
text: Every presidential election cycle, candidates face a big test at the Iowa State Fair: Can they fit in with the locals at the ultimate down-home event in the state with the first nominating contest? Knowing what to eat is part of the challenge: corn dogs, fried butter, and apple pie on a stick are just some of the cholesterol-filled favorites.

headline: ‘Eileen,’ by Ottessa Moshfegh
text: “I looked like a girl you’d expect to see on a city bus,” begins “Eileen,” Ottessa Moshfegh’s seductive novel, “reading some clothbound book from the library about plants or geography, perhaps wearing a net over my light brown hair.” This is the eponymous Eileen, and we quickly learn that any assumptions we might make about her from her appearance would be dead wrong. “I didn’t really read books about flowers or home economics,” she tells us a few pages later. “I liked books about awful things — murder, illness, death.”

headline: Why We Need Fetal Tissue Research
text: Hidden-camera videos showing Planned Parenthood staffers discussing fetal tissue donations have led not just to efforts to defund the organization, but to calls for an end to the use of fetal tissue in research. In an article in The New England Journal of Medicine, the law and bioethics professor R. Alta Charo explains why these calls are misguided.

headline: The 19th Century in Fiction
text: A SLANT OF LIGHTBy Jeffrey Lent357 pp. Bloomsbury, $27.

headline: ‘Make Your Home Among Strangers,’ by Jennine Capó Crucet
text: Elián González, the 6-year-old boy at the heated center of the international custody battle that tore apart Miami and the Cuban-American community in 2000, has resurfaced in the news. Fifteen years after the predawn raid by American agents that led to his return to his father in Cuba, he has announced that he would like to visit the United States again. With the thaw in relations between the two countries, the times are vastly different. But as we are expansively reminded in “Make Your Home Among Strangers,” Jennine Capó Crucet’s heartfelt first novel about a Cuban-American family entangled in a fictionalized account of the González affair, no amount of change erases the past. With history onboard, Crucet shows us how journeys between cultures are almost impossible to navigate and family relationships are bound to dump us in choppy waters.

headline: ‘The Pope’s Daughter,’ by Dario Fo
text: Last year, at the venerable age of 88, the Italian comic Dario Fo took on a new creative challenge. The veteran of more than 60 years as an actor, painter, director, stage designer and playwright (as well as the recipient of the 1997 Nobel Prize in Literature), he had in recent years begun to deliver delightful public lectures on artists — Giotto, Leonardo, Raphael, Caravaggio, Picasso — and architecture, including the Romanesque cathedral of Modena. But up to 2014, he had never written a novel. That changed with “The Pope’s Daughter,” now translated into English, although needless to say for this wild man of the theater, the word “novel” is not quite enough to encompass his lightly fictional labor of love for, of all people, Lucrezia Borgia. “The Pope’s Daughter” is also a picture book, illustrated with some of Fo’s own colorful paintings, most based on Renaissance originals. It has since become a full-blown theatrical script. (Meanwhile, Fo has finished a second illustrated novel, inspired by an 18th-century Danish prince, Christian VII.)

headline: ‘The Marriage of Opposites,’ by Alice Hoffman
text: For a period of her young life, Virginia Woolf wrote while standing at an elevated desk poised near her sister Vanessa’s easel. The writing table’s curious height enabled Virginia to peer at the world from the same viewpoint as her artist sister, to witness all at once the world itself, the world transcribed in ink and the world brushed onto a canvas. Later, when Woolf created the character of the painter Lily Briscoe in “To the Lighthouse,” she knew the mix of delicacy and passion that collide to create a great work, and she was schooled in the fine craft of transforming daubs of paint into strings of words.

headline: Mystery of ‘Baby Doe’ Troubles Massachusetts Investigators
text: For nearly eight weeks, investigators in Massachusetts have been struggling to solve a mystery: the identity of a little girl whose remains were found on a Boston Harbor shoreline.

headline: ‘Brief Loves That Live Forever’ and ‘A Woman Loved,’ by Andrei Makine
text: As a child growing up in a Soviet orphanage, the narrator of Andrei Makine’s memoiristic novel “Brief Loves That Live Forever” recalls being completely in thrall to the idea of a “dazzlingly white city” where everything would be abundant and free, and people would help themselves only to as much as they needed. The harsh realities of daily life under Communism being what they are, disillusionment sets in quickly. Even so, the novel’s dreamy and impressionistic linked episodes, which take the narrator from his boyhood under Brezhnev to his adulthood, offer up this essential truth: Fleeting moments of beauty and love are to be treasured above all else. Carved out of even the most dreary and oppressive circumstances, they’re the sum of a life, a means of triumphing over brutality, a more powerful form of resistance than “dissident whisperings.”

headline: Jeff Bartsch’s ‘Two Across’
text: Right before college-age Vera Baxter disappears from Stanley Owens’s life for the second time, she wakes up in the middle of the night, wondering whether she should leave him. “Maybe,” she thinks, “it was better to make important decisions in the misty neverland of a tired mind, when she might be closer to her real desires, than using all the well-rested but suspect might of logic.” It’s one of many moments in Jeff Bartsch’s new novel, “Two Across,” where we’re reminded that brainpower can be vastly overrated, especially in matters of the heart.

headline: ‘The Dust That Falls From Dreams,’ by Louis de Bernières
text: Enviously noting the insatiable public appetite for television dramas like “Downton Abbey,” writers often lament the prospects for their historical novels, which have faint hopes of attracting anything resembling such sizable audiences. Not Louis de Bernières, who charges straight at them with “The Dust That Falls From Dreams,” a sprawling story about the members of a wealthy English family and the neighbors, friends and servants who constellate around them at their grand house in London during the first few decades of the 20th century.

headline: ‘Sophie and the Sibyl,’ by Patricia Duncker
text: In 1863, George Eliot received the largest advance that had yet been offered for a novel; the £7,000 paid for “Romola” were well-earned. Her previous books had captured a zeitgeist. They received rave reviews, sold enviably well and were even quoted in debates in Parliament. Her stories were much talked about, but Eliot’s authorship and life were also subjects of gossip and speculation; writing under a pen name, the journalist and translator Marian Evans was also scandalously cohabiting with a married man. Evans was a social pariah, but Eliot was now a success.

headline: ‘The Dressmaker,’ by Rosalie Ham
text: Rosalie Ham’s novel “The Dressmaker” was published in Australia in 2000 and later this year will be presented as a movie starring Kate Winslet. What’s surprising is that a film version took so long to appear. From the moment the book opens, with a long shot of “wheat-yellow plains” around the “dark blot” of a hill in the small country town of Dungatar, we sense that we’re on our way to quirky-indie-movie land; and once the camera closes in on the “tumbling brown house” of Mad ­Molly, “leaning provocatively on the grassy curve,” it’s clear we’re visiting a small 1950s town not of history but as imagined by Tim Burton: the gothic, polarized world of “Edward Scissorhands.”

headline: Inside the List
text: The Dolphin Whisperer: One of the more entertaining figures in “Voices in the Ocean,” Susan Casey’s look at dolphin intelligence — new at No. 13 on the hardcover nonfiction list — is the neurophysiologist John C. Lilly, who before his death in 2001 did as much as anyone to promote the image of dolphins as a nearly alien superspecies that might speak English someday. In the 1960s, Lilly’s unfettered enthusiasm caught on big with a certain segment of the public, but his fellow scientists were less enthralled: As Casey notes, the trade reviews of his 1961 book, “Man and Dolphin,” were scathing. “Scientifically unsound and naïve,” Natural History fumed, judging the book a perfect example of “how not to do scientific research.” The biologist E.O. Wilson called it “borderline irresponsible,” and a Navy researcher snarked: “I find Dr. Lilly’s work very interesting. I like Dr. Seuss, too.” Not that the reviews hurt the book’s prospects: “Man and Dolphin” hit the New York Times best-seller list at No. 15. But Lilly’s reputation as a scientist never quite recovered. “Lilly is so fascinating because he’s so polarizing,” Casey told “Fresh Air” this month. “He was pretty freewheeling about the things he did and the things he said.” Or, as she clarifies in “Voices in the Ocean,”  “The real damage occurred when Lilly began a run of experiments that involved LSD and interspecies sex.”

headline: Mom, I Know You’re Doing that ‘Gift of Failure’ Thing, But Could You Please Just Not?
text: In an earlier post, Six Things Parents Need to Send Kids Back to School (That We Can’t Buy), I mentioned that I needed time to read, because books like “The Gift of Failure” by Jessica Lahey are inspiring me to push my children, not toward conventional school and other successes, but toward the kind of independence that leads them to find their own way.

headline: ‘In Another Country,’ by David Constantine
text: More than a century ago, in England during the late-Victorian and Edwardian eras, the god Pan made something of a comeback. In “The Wind in the Willows,” the Mole and the Water Rat encountered him piping at the gates of dawn. E.M. Forster located him in the Italian countryside in “The Story of a Panic,” and presiding over a secluded English pond in “A Room With a View.” Arthur Machen’s brilliant novella “The Great God Pan” emphasized the orgiastic horror as well as the freedom associated with the deity. And Peter Pan himself, that eminent Edwardian, recalled the god both in his name and in his occasional habit of blowing on the panpipes.

headline: Yes, Succotash Has a Luxurious Side
text: Succotash, that savory mélange of corn and beans, is a noble dish with a long history. We have 17th-century Native Americans to thank for it; they introduced the stew to the struggling colonial immigrants. Composed of ingredients unknown in Europe at the time, it gradually became a standard meal in the settlers’ kitchens.

headline: Fumbling in the Dark
text: There are authors who keep writing the same book, over and over. Michael Koryta is not one of those authors. An inventive storyteller who’s also a skilled stylist, he’s constantly experimenting, which explains why his private eye novel LAST WORDS (Little, Brown, $26) doesn’t read like one. Mark Novak conducts investigative work for a team of Florida defense lawyers who take on pro bono cases for clients on death row. But he’s been unraveling for more than a year, ever since his wife, who worked for the same firm, was murdered. With his job hanging by a thread, Mark is given the mercy assignment of investigating a cold case in Garrison, Ind., noteworthy because Ridley Barnes, the man who has asked for help, was never charged but has been condemned by the whole town.

headline: José Mourinho Says Chelsea Doctor Won’t Be on Bench This Week, but May Return
text: Chelsea Manager José Mourinho pivoted on Friday under persistent criticism of his demotion of the club’s team doctor this week, confirming that the doctor would miss Sunday’s match against Manchester City but leaving open the possibility of her return to the bench.

headline: How California Is Winning the Drought
text: FOR California, there hasn’t ever been a summer quite like the summer of 2015. The state and its 39 million residents are about to enter the fifth year of a drought. It has been the driest four-year period in California history — and the hottest, too.

headline: Iowa Democratic Leader: Complaints on Debate Timing Have a Point
text: The chairwoman of the Iowa Democratic Party appeared to acknowledge this week that complaints about the party’s compressed presidential debate calendar from candidates trailing in the polls are understandable.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE MAGICIAN’S LAND, by Lev Grossman. (Plume, $16.) At the outset of Grossman’s novel, a satisfying end to his Magicians trilogy, Quentin Coldwater has been exiled from Fillory, the enchanted land he once helped rule, and dismissed from his teaching post at Brakebills College, where he first learned magic. Charting Quentin’s growth as both a magician and a man, the book “considers complex questions about identity and selfhood as profound as they are entertaining,” our reviewer, Edan Lepucki, wrote.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: KATRINA: After the Flood, by Gary Rivlin. (Simon & Schuster, $27.) A former Times reporter examines the personalities and process behind New Orleans’s reconstruction, including the often corrupt horse trading of the early days.

headline: Greek Parliament Approves Bailout Deal
text: Greek lawmakers spoke on Friday after its parliament approved the country’s third bailout in a vote relying on opposition party support.

headline: Versatile White Button-Downs
text: The season’s ubiquitous staple is a sartorial blank canvas.

headline: Remembering Beatlemania, 50 Years On
text: “The Beatles, those four engaging Englishmen, whose rock ’n’ roll singing and long hair have stirred strong emotions in youngsters, proved yesterday that their mere presence in town can create more commotion along the Avenue of the Americas than the months of subway construction,” read the lead of a Times article about the group’s arrival in New York City.

headline: Kerry Speaks as Flag Is Raised in Havana
text: Secretary of State John Kerry spoke in Havana on Friday before the American flag was raised over the recently reopened American Embassy in Cuba.

headline: With an Eye to Impact, Investing Through a ‘Gender Lens’
text: ELLEN REMMER had wanted to align her investments with her values for years, seeking to put her money into stocks and bonds that would have an impact beyond the returns. For her, this meant investing in organizations that either improved the lot of women and girls or helped the environment.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York City:

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Vu Tran’s ‘Dragonfish’
text: This week, Vu Tran discusses his debut novel, “Dragonfish”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Ruth Franklin talks about Lucia Berlin’s stories; listeners share what they’ve been reading; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: The Downside of Labor Mobility
text: The theory of optimum currency areas is one of those old-fashioned pieces of macroeconomics — like IS-LM, the concept of the liquidity trap, and the theory of secular stagnation — that has turned out to be extremely relevant and useful to the world since 2008. So this is a version of Mark Thoma’s dictum that new economic thinking involves reading old books (or in this case articles). Still, we do learn some new things. And what we’ve learned lately, I’d argue, is that labor mobility — which was supposed to be good, and a prerequisite for currency union — is actually much more problematic than we knew.

headline: The Listener
text: Don Kent, the blues scholar and founder of more than one obscure yet influential record label, died last week of cancer at the age of 71. For anyone who knew the man or cared at all about prewar American music, the loss is palpable. Last year, when I was working on “The Ballad of Geeshie and Elvie” — a story about recovering the identities and lives of two lost singers from that early period — Kent proved the most illuminating and generous of sources. He was, to borrow a Barry Hannah line, “a hell of a sweet genius guy.”

headline: The Junk Politics of 2015

headline: Oliver Sacks: Sabbath
text: MY mother and her 17 brothers and sisters had an Orthodox upbringing — all photographs of their father show him wearing a yarmulke, and I was told that he woke up if it fell off during the night. My father, too, came from an Orthodox background. Both my parents were very conscious of the Fourth Commandment (“Remember the Sabbath day, to keep it holy”), and the Sabbath (Shabbos, as we called it in our Litvak way) was entirely different from the rest of the week. No work was allowed, no driving, no use of the telephone; it was forbidden to switch on a light or a stove. Being physicians, my parents made exceptions. They could not take the phone off the hook or completely avoid driving; they had to be available, if necessary, to see patients, or operate, or deliver babies.

headline: Popcast: ‘Straight Outta Compton’
text: The N.W.A. biopic “Straight Outta Compton” arrives in theaters Friday. In some ways, it’s the final symbol of the success N.W.A. had in redefining hip-hop, and over time, the shape of American pop culture. That’s true in terms of music, and also in terms of politics: the tales N.W.A. specialized in ended up being the stories that would define the news cycle, both in its era and for decades to come.

headline: A New Vodka Distillery That Subsidizes Artists
text: Whether it’s a flute of champagne above the High Line or a can of medium-cold beer in Bushwick, beverages play an essential role in the social ritual of art consumption. Plenty of brands have cashed in on this association, commissioning elaborate bottle labels and other decorative schemes from artists — often with the effect of watering down their profiles. Enter a new vodka distillery called Material, expressly founded on flipping the script and diverting boozy profit margins back to makers.

headline: President Obama’s Eleventh-Hour Conservation Efforts
text: Shortly before leaving town for the summer, Congress approved – and President Obama happily signed into law – three bills that, taken together, will preserve as permanent wilderness roughly 275,000 acres of spectacular mountain terrain in Idaho known as  Boulder-White Clouds.  This was a rare moment for a Congress that has been far more interested in  party infighting than environmental stewardship, and a tribute to the perseverance of one person, Congressman Mike Simpson, Republican of Idaho, who spent years engaging with local officials, ranchers,  hunters, tribes, off-road vehicle enthusiasts and other stakeholders.

headline: How Jesse Eisenberg Makes Cup of Noodles a Weapon in ‘American Ultra’
text: Weed is not the only thing that is smoked in the violent action-comedy “American Ultra,” due Friday. Jesse Eisenberg plays Mike Howell, a stoner who works at a convenience store and who has, without his knowledge, been programmed by the C.I.A. to be a lethal sleeper agent. His dormant killer instincts are activated in the middle of a government operation, letting Mike transform whatever items he has at hand into weapons. An early scene, from which this frame is taken, shows Mike’s skills when, in a 10-second burst of action, he takes down two men sent to kill him by using a cup of noodles, a spoon and the gun they pull on him. It’s a quick but energetic scene that will probably shock the viewer as much as it does the character. Here is a closer look at that scene with commentary from the film’s director, Nima Nourizadeh, and its stunt coordinator, Robert Alonzo.

headline: At Iowa’s State Fair, Candidates Brave Cholesterol and Hecklers
text: DES MOINES — There are 75 foods on a stick, including apple pie and gluten-free corn dogs. There is a cow sculpted from butter. And there are 18 presidential candidates in a bipartisan stampede to the Iowa State Fair — bringing their stump speeches, of course, but more important, aiming to prove their common touch in the ultimate venue for retail campaigning.

headline: How John Hatfield, Executive Director of Socrates Sculpture Park, Spends His Sundays
text: As the executive director of Socrates Sculpture Park, a public art space in Long Island City, Queens, John Hatfield keeps an eye on the weather: The clearer the skies and the warmer the temperature, the busier he is. “Late spring, summer, early fall — we have so many events,” Mr. Hatfield said. The schedule often keeps him away from his family’s TriBeCa apartment, so on Sundays, Mr. Hatfield, 51, focuses on spending time at home — taking in art with his wife, Amy Wolf, 57, an art dealer; catching up with their son, Otis, 18; and caring for the family’s new puppy, Babs Kramer.

Litvinenko and the murder of the human rights activist Natalya Estemirova.

headline: From the Vault of the Museum of Sex: Macaura’s Pulsocon
text: For 15 years, the Museum of Sex, at 233 Fifth Avenue (an address, appropriately enough, near the former site of an early-20th-century red-light district known to vice enthusiasts as the Tenderloin), has been educating, by way of titillating, age-appropriate tourists and locals alike. While those who visit for a bit of blushing will no doubt find an array of X-rated artifacts capable of getting the job done, the true lessons to be learned from the one act with which every culture is consumed are many. And, oftentimes, a little gross.

headline: Post-Katrina, Vietnamese Success
text: IT has been 10 years since Hurricane Katrina struck New Orleans, and in the Vietnamese enclave of Village de l’Est, a neighborhood in a remote eastern corner of the city that was extensively flooded, there are now bustling restaurants, tidy homes with well-tended lawns and brisk street traffic. Much of the surrounding area, by contrast, still seems to be struggling.

text: It’s mid-August in New York City and suddenly everyone is in black, white or gray.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Summer Madness
text: It’s mid-August and suddenly everyone is in black, white or gray. The glittering skyline is full of dreams and the Holly Golightlys are having breakfast at Tiffany’s. A poodle pranced by in a pearl necklace. These scenes capture the exuberance and the magic of the city at the end of summer.

headline: U.S. Is Poised to Oppose Freeing Guantánamo Hunger Striker
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has decided for now to fight any court-ordered release of a detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, who has been on a hunger strike since February 2007 and now weighs less than 75 pounds, according to officials familiar with internal deliberations.

headline: Chinese Independent Filmmakers Look to Locarno Festival
text: LOCARNO, Switzerland — Thanks largely to financing by a university teacher, Bi Gan was able to make his first feature film, “Kaili Blues,” an elliptical story about a man’s family relationships and his journey through the lush rural hilltowns of Guizhou Province in China. He even received approval from official censors. But its art house techniques and narrative style guarantee a minuscule Chinese audience.

headline: F.B.I. Tracking Path of Classified Email From State Dept. to Hillary Clinton
text: WASHINGTON — F.B.I. agents investigating Hillary Rodham Clinton’s private email server are seeking to determine who at the State Department passed highly classified information from secure networks to Mrs. Clinton’s personal account, according to law enforcement and diplomatic officials and others briefed on the investigation.

headline: Jukely App Offers ‘Unlimited’ Concert Tickets, With Limits
text: The term “pivot” has become almost as much of a cliché in tech circles as “disrupt.” It describes the way that many young start-ups change their approach to business, recycling elements of an initial idea and using them to pursue something new. Pivoting often suggests a last-ditch attempt to salvage a failing start-up. But sometimes, the strategy can turn a business that’s simply chugging along into one with more staying power.

headline: Mo Rocca Finds Calm in the Kitchen in ‘My Grandmother’s Ravioli’
text: It’s a frenetic time on the culinary TV front. On Wednesday, the Food Network rolled out “Camp Cutthroat,” a “Cutthroat Kitchen” spinoff competition show advertised with the tagline “This time, we’re playing with campfire.” On Thursday, Destination America’s “BBQ Pit Wars” reached the finale of a grueling season of cross-country grilling. Next Tuesday, the Season 2 premiere of the amusing truTV show “Hack My Life” has a segment on cooking lasagna in a dishwasher.

headline: 1896 | ‘Without Fear or Favor’
text: Political madness has surely gripped the nation when a Fox News journalist publicly embraces a 119-year-old guiding principle of The New York Times, as Megyn Kelly did this week by vowing — Donald Trump’s taunts notwithstanding — to “continue doing my job without fear or favor.”

headline: Mozzarella for Big Cheeses at an East Hampton Market
text: Unlike other East Hampton haunts treasured by affluent summer people for their beachy, low-key vibe, Red Horse Market bustles with productivity. The produce is arranged like a Flemish still life, women in equestrian garb demand to know the provenance of the grass in the grass-fed beef, and the Kardashian sisters once fought on camera in this small shop. Its patrons are a devoted lot.

headline: Mylan’s Bid to Buy Perrigo Is Complicated by Opposing Declarations
text: Mylan appeared on Friday morning to hit a significant hurdle in its quest to buy a fellow drug maker, Perrigo, when an influential advisory firm recommended that investors vote down the pursuit.

headline: Quenching a Thirst for Tacos in the Rockaways
text: It looked at one point that the Rockaways, the beachy peninsula in southern Queens, home to firefighters, midlevel Wall Street guys and armies of sun-seeking Brooklyn hipsters, was headed toward a taco-less summer. Late in March, the news slipped out that Andrew Field and David Selig, the co-owners of Rockaway Taco, had parted ways over business plans and that their ramshackle joint on Beach 96th Street would not return this season. But then, Mr. Selig decided to take a food-truck version of Rockaway Taco across the country, and Mr. Field made plans to move his own new venture, Tacoway Beach, onto the premises of the Rockaway Beach Surf Club on Beach 87th Street. Showing no sign of the hostilities, Tacoway Beach was booming recently, filled with a ruddy, beer-drinking crowd that included two newlywed (or newlywed-ish) couples.

headline: Aug. 14, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photographs from Cuba, China, Japan and Greece.

headline: Review: From La Otra Orilla, Flamenco Without Flounces at Jacob’s Pillow
text: BECKET, Mass. — For about 10 fairly good minutes of “Moi & Les Autres,” the four performers of La Otra Orilla (The Other Coast) share the stage in equal measure and at close quarters: the dancer Myriam Allard, the guitarist Caroline Planté, the percussionist Miguel Medina and the vocalist Hedi Graja. Flamenco rhythms and sonorities pour forth.

headline: Orbitz Offers Vacation Packages by App
text: Reflecting a major shift in travel planning, Orbitz.com, the web-based travel company, now offers vacation packages in its mobile application. With a few taps, users can purchase combined flight and hotel packages on the app and view their total savings before they complete any sale.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Period Pieces
text: On Mr. Cunningham’s Evening Hours page this week, a weekend of vintage dancing that took place at Nahant, Mass.

headline: Evening Hours | Period Pieces
text: A weekend of vintage dancing took place at Nahant, Mass. The three-day event, which benefited the Nahant Historical Society, was originally created 25 years ago as a Viennese dance by Katy and Ben Bishop at the urging of Ms. Bishop’s mother, the Viennese-born Olli Heil. RoAnn Costin lent her family’s 1867 seaside home for the gala and the Edwardian tea dance. Most guests wore period clothes for the dance at the Costin house, which has a ballroom and billiards room.

headline: Efforts to Preserve Henry Varnum Poor’s House and Its History Have Stalled
text: CLARKSTOWN, N.Y. — The rambling stone cottage here where the artist Henry Varnum Poor created his ceramics and his paintings and other artworks now held at major museums around the country is called Crow House, perhaps because of the birds that circled overhead when Poor designed and built it, by hand, nearly 100 years ago.

headline: Paul Kalkbrenner, a Techno Star, Rises From Berlin’s Clubs
text: The German techno producer Paul Kalkbrenner is not just a famous musician in his home country — he’s also a movie star (“Berlin Calling,” 2008) and a folk hero, having taken his minimal electronic compositions from the Berlin underground to a performance last year for a half-million people at the 25th anniversary of the Berlin Wall’s crumbling.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
text: Good evening. Here’s the latest.

headline: Review: ‘Mother of the Maid,’ a Lesson on Raising a Teenage Saint
text: LENOX, Mass. — Teenage saints — and yes, religious history records the existence of such improbable phenomena — are apparently not so unlike other teenagers. They’re moody, rebellious, impulsive and prone to intense crushes on glamorous, inaccessible idols. They also love, loathe and are deeply embarrassed by their parents, who spend sleepless nights fretting over their wayward and baffling progeny.

headline: A South Bronx Graffiti Walkabout
text: For the first @nytimes Instameet, a group of photographers descended upon Hunts Point to see bold murals and hidden gems.

headline: U.S.-Led Air Campaign Is Linked to Civilian Deaths in Syria
text: ANTAKYA, Turkey — An airstrike by the American-led military coalition in northern Syria this week killed eight civilians, including two women and five children, according to neighbors and relatives of the dead.

headline: Mail Theft, With a Milk Carton and Some Glue
text: The young man approached a mailbox on a dark corner in the Bronx. It was a Tuesday in November 2013, almost 4 a.m. He carried two tools: a milk crate and a crushed milk carton on a string. The carton was very sticky, covered in glue from rattraps.

headline: The Mystery of San Marzano
text: Beware the tomato that masquerades as a true Italian.

headline: Internet Hoax on Downing of Malaysian Jet Spreads in Russia
text: In the immediate aftermath of the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 over rebel-held, eastern Ukraine last year, Ukraine’s intelligence agency released what it said was audio from intercepted phone calls between separatist leaders and Russian military intelligence officers, in which the militants appeared to acknowledge shooting down a civilian plane by mistake.

headline: Yankees to Honor Alex Rodriguez’s 3,000th Hit With a Ceremony in September
text: TORONTO — The once frigid relationship between Alex Rodriguez and the Yankees has turned downright cuddly. The latest example came Friday when the team announced it would celebrate Rodriguez reaching the 3,000-hit plateau by holding a day in his honor at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Abandoned Cars Are a New York Memory
text: Abandoned cars were a fixture on the New York landscape from the ’60s to the early ’90s. A look back in The New York Times photo archive shows a city all but gone from memory.

headline: Volkswagen and Mazda Recall Over 600,000 Vehicles
text: Volkswagen and Mazda are recalling about 613,000 vehicles, several years after the automakers changed parts on new vehicles to fix the possible loss of steering or failure of airbags, according to documents filed with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. The automakers decided on a recall after the federal regulators opened investigations this year. The automakers said they were not aware of any accidents or injuries related to the problems. Volkswagen’s recall covers about 420,000 vehicles because the driver’s-side airbag may not deploy properly in a crash. They are the 2010-13 Eos and Jetta, the 2011-14 Golf GTI, the 2010-14 Passat and Tiguan and the 2010-14 CC. Mazda is recalling 2007-14 CX-9 family vans in some states because rust on a front suspension part could cause the loss of steering.

headline: Man Is Released After 34 Years in Prison; Murder Conviction Is Thrown Out
text: A man who served 34 years in prison for the rape and murder of a teenager in Pennsylvania has been freed after new DNA analysis led a judge to vacate his murder conviction.

headline: Brazil: Police Suspected in Killings of 18
text: The authorities in São Paulo said Friday that they were investigating whether police officers were involved in a series of execution-style killings that left at least 18 people dead. The shootings were carried out by gunmen wearing balaclavas during a span of about three hours on Thursday night in the metropolitan area of São Paulo, Brazil’s largest city, according to video images captured on security cameras and witness accounts. “When we get to the suspects, whether they are police or not, we’ll act quickly to detain them,” Alexandre de Moraes, the top security official in São Paulo State, told reporters. He said investigators were examining whether the killings were reprisals for the recent shooting deaths of two police officers. The killings added to concern among human rights groups over a spate of similar episodes in Brazil that have left dozens dead in other cities, including Manaus and Belém. Police officers killed at least 2,212 people in Brazil in 2013, though the actual number of such killings around the country is thought to be much higher because some states do not report them.

headline: Richard S. Ross, Johns Hopkins Dean and Watergate Walk-On, Dies at 91
text: Dr. Richard S. Ross, an innovative cardiologist and medical school dean who encouraged prospective doctors to pursue broader undergraduate education, and who earlier had the distinction of examining Richard M. Nixon during the Watergate investigation, died on Tuesday at his home in Baltimore. He was 91.
