headline: Hedge Funds Shed Shares in Alibaba and Baidu in Second Quarter
text: As China’s stock market took a free fall earlier this summer, big money managers looked to sell shares of two of the largest Chinese tech companies listed in the United States — Alibaba and Baidu — during the second quarter.

headline: ISIS Is Suspected of a Chemical Attack Against Kurds in Syria
text: WASHINGTON — The Islamic State is suspected of using chemical agents — said by some American officials to be mustard gas — in an attack on Kurdish fighters in northern Syria two weeks ago, United States officials said Friday.

headline: Betting on a Smooth Ride, Investors Flock to Tesla
text: Tesla Motors has seemingly defied the law of financial gravity on Wall Street ever since the company began proving that electric cars could be sporty, powerful and trendy — not just green.

headline: Connecticut Death Penalty Ruling Stirs Painful Memories of 3 Grisly Killings
text: CHESHIRE, Conn. — Celine Bonilla was only 11 when she looked out her first-floor window and saw police officers pinning a man down on her front lawn. It was 2007, and that man and an accomplice had just killed two of her friends and their mother, dousing them with gasoline and burning them alive in their home in what became known as one of the grisliest crimes in Connecticut history.

headline: In Familiar Fashion, Giants Stumble in Preseason Opener
text: CINCINNATI — After an off-season of strategic renovations designed to restore their proud franchise, the Giants opened the preseason in a familiar bumbling manner on Friday.

headline: Most Health Insurance Co-ops Are Losing Money, Federal Audit Finds
text: WASHINGTON — Most federal insurance cooperatives created under the Affordable Care Act are losing money and could have difficulty repaying millions of dollars in federal loans, an internal government audit has found, prompting the Obama administration to step up supervision of the carriers.

headline: Edward Thomas, Policing Pioneer Who Wore a Burden Stoically, Dies at 95
text: When Edward Thomas joined the Houston Police Department in 1948, he could not report for work through the front door.

headline: Jordan Spieth Is an Approachable Star on the Course
text: HAVEN, Wis. — Walking up a stone stairway halfway through his round on Friday, Jordan Spieth lifted his head to see his father, Shawn, waiting in his path.

headline: ISIS Held Kayla Mueller, U.S. Aid Worker, as Sex Slave Before Fatal Airstrike
text: DOHUK, Iraq — Somewhere in territory controlled by the Islamic State, Kayla Mueller, an American aid worker, was chained in a room with other female captives. The leader of the Islamic State, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, would regularly enter and lead Ms. Mueller away, her parents say.

headline: Many Sailors Are Not Put Off by Rio de Janeiro’s Polluted Waters
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Putting aside concerns over health risks to athletes, about 339 sailors from 52 countries will begin racing here Saturday on the picturesque and polluted Guanabara Bay in the second official test race ahead of next year’s Summer Olympics.

headline: Donald Trump Called to Jury Duty in Manhattan
text: Donald J. Trump, whose bid for the Republican presidential nomination has shaken up the race, will participate in a more common civic activity next week: jury duty.

headline: The Affluent Ante Up for the Presidency
text: When the Republican candidates for president expounded on what they would do for ordinary Americans in their debate this month, they neglected to mention that more than half the money underpinning their campaigns has been coming from just 130 big-spending families and the businesses they run. These families are determined to influence the election with six- and seven-figure checks.

headline: Opting Out of Standardized Tests Isn’t the Answer
text: An alarming 200,000, or 20 percent, of the students in grades three through eight in New York State public schools this year refused to take the state’s standardized tests in reading and math that are supposed to measure progress in meeting national academic standards.

headline: Hillary Clinton Jokes About Emails at Fund-Raiser
text: — Hillary Rodham Clinton at the Annual Wing Ding Dinner in Clear Lake, Iowa, a Democratic fund-raising event.

headline: Brooklyn Man Accused of Supporting ISIS Pleads Guilty
text: A Brooklyn man accused this year of trying to join the Islamic State pleaded guilty on Friday to conspiring to provide material support to the terrorist organization.

headline: Redemption as a Mark of Public Service
text: After 33 years in public office in Albany and New York City, Oliver Koppell is finally admitting to himself that the one achievement likely to be featured in his obituary is a humble state law known as the bottle bill. This was a 1982 measure that introduced 5-cent redemptions on empty beverage cans and bottles. It thereby created an unintended subculture of midnight garbage gleaners — down-and-out citizens who quietly pick bottles and cans from curbside refuse collections and cash them in for sustenance.

headline: New Monitoring Program Aims to Keep Youths Out of Rikers Island
text: Youths accused of felonies will be tracked and monitored with smartphones and electronic bracelets instead of awaiting trial in jail under a new program created by the Manhattan district attorney’s office.

headline: Hiroshi Iwata Ties a Record, Then Takes a Star Turn
text: HAVEN, Wis. — After signing his scorecard on Friday, Hiroshi Iwata started walking toward the clubhouse. He looked surprised when he was redirected to the media center. Iwata, who is making his first major start in the United States, did not draw much notice during his opening five-over-par 77, but in the second round of the P.G.A. Championship he came tantalizingly close to making history.

headline: Let Older Americans Keep Working
text: BOSTON — EVERY day, 10,000 baby boomers — Americans born from 1946 to 1964 — leave the work force. Most of them have not saved enough for retirement; at least one-fifth have basically no retirement savings. Our economy has a shortage of skilled workers.

headline: The Painful Lessons of the Yonkers Housing Crisis
text: “IS that what all the trouble was about? Just that?” a young actor asked me, sweeping her hand toward a row of cream-shingled townhouses on a leafy residential street in Yonkers.

headline: Bank of America Stiffs Shareholders
text: The year 2009 was rough for the Bank of America and its chairman and chief executive, Ken Lewis. On Jan. 1, the bank closed its $50 billion purchase of Merrill Lynch, a deal Lewis had hastily negotiated the previous September, as the financial world appeared close to collapse.

headline: Iconoclast Stiflers
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Ironically, the very entry that Jeff Chen found hard to fill at 20 Down was one of the last entries that went in for me, and that was only because I am so used to using “click”-type ballpoint pens. I can’t remember the last time I used a pen with a cap, but that’s on me. I might have been more likely to be the back-of-the-head recipient of a flying PEN CAP in school, not that I’m bitter, Mr. Chen. But thanks for being “that guy.”

headline: Test-Refusal Movement’s Success Hampers Analysis of New York State Exam Results
text: With 20 percent of eligible students sitting out the New York state standardized tests this year, even some central organizers of the “opt out” movement were surprised at their own success.

headline: Disney Announces Its Coming Slate of Animated Films at D23 Expo
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — John Lasseter, the Walt Disney Company’s top animation executive, jogged onto a stage at a sprawling Disney fan convention here on Friday and started throwing red meat to the masses.

headline: Brooklyn Man Awarded $4 Million After 2009 Rooftop Fall in Police Chase
text: The impact from the fall, on Aug. 22, 2009, was undeniable: A Brooklyn man, Brian D. Martin, fell more than 30 feet to the ground, fracturing his back in several spots and shattering his left heel.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Woo Democrats at Iowa Dinner
text: CLEAR LAKE, Iowa — The annual Wing Ding Dinner here delivered on its name Friday night, with no shortage of thrown elbows and plenty of baked ones, as four Democratic presidential candidates tried to excite a crowd of Iowa voters by attacking their Republican counterparts.

headline: Raised to Be Respectful, Ikemefuna Enemkpali Lets a Dispute Get the Better of Him
text: His parents expected him to work hard, show respect and always be a man of his word, and Ikemefuna Enemkpali tried to uphold their teachings, partly rooted in their Nigerian upbringing, as he rose from high school football star to budding linebacker with the Jets.

headline: Carlos Beltran Propels Yankees Past Blue Jays
text: TORONTO — If, at age 38, Carlos Beltran is not the player he once was, he does not think of himself as anything other than an everyday player. He sticks to the same routine before each game, 25 or so batting practice cuts from each side of the plate, just enough to keep his swing finely tuned but not so many as to wear himself out.

headline: Mets Face a Truer Measuring Stick in the Pirates, and Fall Short
text: At a news conference Friday afternoon, hours before the Mets and the Pittsburgh Pirates were to begin a three-game series at Citi Field, Mets Manager Terry Collins was asked to characterize what was at stake. He made no effort to mask or minimize the significance of the weekend.

headline: Showtime’s Spotlight Shifts at South Bend
text: The Houston Texans are being tailed at training camp by HBO Sports and NFL Films cameras for the 10th edition of the “Hard Knocks” series.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE THEORY OF EVERYTHING (2014) Eddie Redmayne won an Oscar for his portrayal of the British theoretical physicist Stephen Hawking, who, as a graduate student at Cambridge intent on fathoming the origins of the universe and locating the beginning of time, learned he had amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. Felicity Jones, who earned a nomination, plays his first wife, Jane Hawking, whose memoir, “Traveling to Infinity: My Life With Stephen,” is the main source for James Marsh’s portrait of a marriage. “Mr. Redmayne, hunched into a wheelchair, the muscles of his face spread into what looks like a permanent smile, must communicate his character’s feelings almost entirely with his eyes, which are remarkably expressive, conveying Stephen’s mischievous wit as well as his intelligence,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this best picture nominee. “But it is in showing the application of that intelligence that ‘The Theory of Everything’ tumbles into a black hole of biopic banality.” The film’s historical and scientific lapses have been enumerated, but “taking liberties with facts is a prerogative of storytelling,” he said. The greater failing is that Mr. Marsh seems “unable to capture the spirit and energy of scientific inquiry.”

headline: South Korean Leader Marks Anniversary of War’s End With Warnings to North Korea

headline: How Video Killed the Family Vacation
text: Like most parents, I imagine, I keep a running list of things I’ve done well and things I’ve flubbed. Help our children get lots of sleep? Check. Play fun, stimulating games at dinner? Score. Have peaceful, stress-free mornings when everyone goes into the day uplifted and on time? Hardly. Produce handsome scrapbooks with carefully captioned memories? Not a one. (We do have a few boxes labeled “keepsakes.”)

headline: G.O.P. Is Vague on Using Power Abroad
text: If the diverse group of candidates competing for the Republican presidential nomination agree on one thing when describing how they would engage with the world if they made it to the White House, it is this: If only the United States were stronger, and more feared, the country would not feel threatened by the Islamic State, manipulated by Iran or challenged by a rising China.

headline: Tiger Woods Misses Cut at P.G.A. Championship, His Season Fizzling
text: HAVEN, Wis. — Only a handful of people occupied the Kohler skybox near the 18th green before 8 a.m. Saturday, but the public grandstand opposite it was full. No matter how ragged his game, Tiger Woods, like any headliner worth his marquee billing, can still command a crowd of everyday fans.

headline: Locked in Solitary at 14: Adult Jails Isolate Youths Despite Risk
text: HATTIESBURG, Miss. — The prisoner spent a fitful August night trying to tune out the howls and moans of inmates in adjoining cells. He did not stir from his thin sleep mat until well after 1 p.m. A breakfast of cold grits waited in a slot in the reinforced steel door.

headline: Newly Disclosed N.S.A. Files Detail Partnerships With AT&T and Verizon
text: These National Security Agency documents shed new light on the agency’s relationship through the years with American telecommunications companies. They show how the agency’s partnership with AT&T has been particularly important, enabling it to conduct surveillance, under several different legal rules, of international and foreign-to-foreign Internet communications that passed through network hubs on American soil.

headline: AT&T Helped U.S. Spy on Internet on a Vast Scale
text: The National Security Agency’s ability to spy on vast quantities of Internet traffic passing through the United States has relied on its extraordinary, decades-long partnership with a single company: the telecom giant AT&T.

headline: Why Starbucks Prices Went Up as Coffee Beans Got Cheaper

headline: A ‘Price Is Right’ Winner’s Showcase Letdown
text: People are constantly praising the Haggler’s willingness to fight for consumers. By “constantly,” the Haggler means “about twice a year.” Actually, that might be an exaggeration. It’s probably happened. Once. Don’t ask for specifics, though.

headline: Red Cross Offers Workshops in International Law to Hamas
text: GAZA CITY — A new training regimen for fighters in Hamas’s armed wing employs slide presentations and a whiteboard rather than Kalashnikov rifles and grenades. The young men wear polo shirts instead of fatigues and black masks. They do not chant anti-Israel slogans, but discuss how the Geneva Conventions governing armed conflict dovetail with Islamic principles.

headline: For French-Algerians and Algerian-French, No Place to Truly Call Home
text: CAP FALCON, Algeria — The fishermen of Cap Falcon, a peaceful beach on Algeria’s western Mediterranean coast, swear they can see the Spanish mountaintops when the weather is clear. So tantalizingly close is Europe, the beach is a favorite launching point for the “harragas,” as illegal migrants are known here.

headline: Emperor Akihito Expresses ‘Deep Remorse’ for Japan’s Role in World War II
text: TOKYO — Emperor Akihito, whose father announced his exhausted country’s surrender in World War II, expressed “deep remorse” for the conflict on Saturday at a memorial service on the 70th anniversary of the war’s end.

headline: The Galloping Gourmet
text: Tim Kellogg is a cowboy and a chocolatier, with a store in Meeteetse, Wyo.

headline: P.G.A. Championship Course a Site of Intense Rounds, for Gunners and Golfers
text: HAVEN, Wis. — Before Whistling Straits was a golf course, all the shots fired on the property plummeted to the bottom of adjacent Lake Michigan. Antiaircraft guns, machine guns and tanks fired at targets high above the water, part of artillery exercises at Camp Haven, a military base from 1949 to 1959 that was transformed into the setting for the P.G.A. Championship.

headline: David Raff
text: David Raff is the science integrity officer for the United States Bureau of Reclamation, the nation’s largest water wholesaler, which is currently struggling to manage competing demands for a dwindling resource.

text: A month before the Mexican photojournalist Rubén Espinosa was murdered in Mexico City in late July, the governor of Veracruz, the province Mr. Espinosa had fled fearing for his life, gave other journalists a warning.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Got This
text: HER favorable ratings have fallen. The investigation into her private email server is tightening. Bernie Sanders is drawing huge crowds. Joe Biden is considering one last White House bid. Al Gore has advisers who have friends who’ve told reporters that they might have heard about conversations spitballing about a possible Gore run.

headline: Ugly Attacks on Refugees in Europe
text: It is one of the tragedies of the European refugee crisis that the country with the fewest means, Greece, is the one coping with the greatest number of migrants fleeing tumult and poverty in the Middle East and Africa.

headline: Sex Offenders Locked Up on a Hunch
text: The essence of the American criminal justice system is reactive, not predictive: You are punished for the crime you committed. You can’t be punished simply because you might commit one someday. You certainly can’t be held indefinitely to prevent that possibility.

headline: Kale, With Fudge on Top
text: “Americans’ eating habits have begun changing for the better.”

headline: Mom Plans, God Laughs
text: EVERY May, I start fantasizing about lazy, long days at the pool. I order a sundress from Athleta and picture myself wearing it while carrying a cheerful melamine platter of snacks and lemonade to my sweaty trio of children in the backyard. In June, I get a pedicure, bring the beach towels up from the basement, and compose a list of day trips we’ll embark on as soon as school gets out. This summer, my dream itinerary featured a spectrum of activities, ranging from rafting and boogie boarding to visiting a science museum and an aquarium. I imagined my family picking blueberries outside a tiny house in the Berkshires.

headline: The Frontier Chocolatier
text: Meeteetse, Wyo. — IN the arid hills that rim this remote town of just 327 people, Tim Kellogg spent countless hours with cattle: feeding them, herding them, even helping them give birth. He was a cowboy through and through.

headline: Vacation in Rome? Or on That Oil Rig?
text: ON A PLATFORM IN THE CELEBES SEA — IN the next several years, thousands of offshore oil and gas drilling rigs, many of them built during a global construction boom in the 1970s and ’80s, will reach retirement age and require decommissioning. Countries will have to decide whether to sink, remove or repurpose them.

headline: Introducing Donald Trump, Diplomat
text: DONALD TRUMP gives me his Grumpy Cat look.

headline: Lightning Round With Donald Trump
text: Maureen Dowd shares some of Trump’s rapid-fire impressions about his rivals and other boldfaced names.

headline: Looking for a Breakthrough? Study Says to Make Time for Tedium
text: Innovation isn’t all about eureka moments. In fact, the road to creative breakthroughs is paved with mundane, workaday tasks. That’s the message of a recent study that might as well be titled “In Praise of Tedium.”

headline: Hometown Is a Picture of Texas Tradition
text: Ikemefuna Enemkpali, the linebacker who punched Geno Smith, is the product of the Austin suburb Pflugerville, where he was raised by his parents from Nigeria.

headline: Times Reaches Online Milestone, but Many Challenges Await
text: LAST spring, Mark Thompson, chief executive of The New York Times Company, said The Times would soon boast of one million digital-only subscribers. Early this month, his prediction came to pass.

headline: The V.A.’s Woman Problem
text: ON Sept. 11, 2001, Desma Brooks was a single mother in her mid-20s who served part-time in the Indiana Army National Guard. Watching the attack on TV, she wondered if she might be called up. She had three kids, so maybe she would be assigned to some kind of support role on the home front. Instead, she served two yearlong deployments, the first to Afghanistan, the second to Iraq. During the second, while driving a military vehicle that was guarding a supply convoy, she hit a roadside bomb. Ms. Brooks returned home with a mild case of traumatic brain injury and a serious case of post-traumatic stress disorder.

headline: EnChroma’s Accidental Spectacles Find Niche Among the Colorblind
text: An inventor of lenses invented to aid surgeons found that they could also help the colorblind, leading him to start a company that sells glasses.

headline: No Matter How Terry Collins Orders It, Mets’ Offense Is Producing
text: The trade was met with little fanfare at the time, but on July 24, when the Mets acquired Juan Uribe and Kelly Johnson from the Atlanta Braves, Manager Terry Collins was given two versatile players for a team that had been mostly devoid of offense. But perhaps more important to the way Collins tends to run his team, it allowed him to start tinkering with the lineup in hope of finding the combination that worked best.

headline: Jessica Jones: Sizing Up the Latest Fashions
text: Jessica Jones, 31, is a fit model with True Model Management in New York.

headline: The Teacher Shortage
text: Educators cite low pay, lack of respect and support, and high-stakes tests as causes.

headline: When You’re in Charge, Your Whisper May Feel Like a Shout
text: “Gail, I need to talk with you about something this afternoon. Can you come by my office at 3 p.m.?” I didn’t think much about my seemingly innocuous words, spoken to one of my department’s doctoral students one morning back when I was an assistant professor.

headline: A Last Splash of Summer
text: Photographs of the water slide in Foley Square on the last day of Summer Streets.

headline: A Fashion Trailblazer’s Stylish Leap From Touch to Touch Screen
text: In a small house in South London, five executives of the high-end fashion retailer MatchesFashion.com sat around an oval conference table, discussing a coming event. From outside, the house looked like any sweet two-story London cottage, with a cobblestone courtyard and small balcony, but inside, it was all white and open plan — more Silicon Valley than Staffordshire.

headline: Puzzling Through My Fiction
text: When I was growing up, crossword puzzles were — along with watching Ken Burns movies and eating lox — among the unfathomable pleasures of grown-ups. My grandmother would sit in her den for hours, the puzzle in her lap, looking blankly around the room as if she had just read a piece of news whose enormity she could scarcely comprehend. Other adults would periodically drift by to offer their condolences (“A nine-letter religious figure, hmm…”) and I would stare from the rug in disbelieving boredom.

headline: Now With the Mets, It’s All Come Into Focus for Tyler Clippard
text: Tyler Clippard cannot remember the exact moment when he decided to see the eye doctor. He might have been standing on a mound in Columbus, Ohio, squinting at the sign in the shadows between the catcher’s legs. That happened often during the summer of 2008. Clippard also squinted when he was in the clubhouse, or looking at the television. His teammates teased him endlessly.

headline: After Protests for Racial Justice, Activists Ask: What Next?
text: FERGUSON, Mo. — Leaning on a chain-link fence, Charles Mayo surveyed what was transpiring before him with a heavy dose of skepticism.

headline: The Greek Debt Deal’s Missing Piece
text: At long last, European creditor nations and Greece have reached an agreement on a third bailout in five years.

headline: California Town, United by Drought, Is Split Over New Water Park
text: DUBLIN, Calif. — On a typical hard-hat tour of a major municipal construction project, city officials extol the venture’s expansiveness and rave about how many citizens will benefit. But this city has taken a different approach to a nearly $44 million recreational complex underway: Officials boast how small it is and how few people are expected to use it.

headline: Yankees Resist Toll of Dog Days, Rebuilding Division Lead Over Toronto
text: TORONTO — These can be the miserable days of a baseball season, with the finish line still not quite in sight and the daily grind taking its toll on the body and the mind. They are called the dog days for a reason.

headline: Hillary Clinton Fires Back Against Jeb Bush on Rise of ISIS
text: DES MOINES – Hillary Rodham Clinton hit back at Jeb Bush on Saturday over his accusation that the Obama administration’s handling of the withdrawal of 10,000 troops in Iraq had facilitated the rise of the Islamic State now sweeping violently through Syria and Iraq.

headline: As N.F.L. Prepares for Longer Extra Points, C.F.L. Offers a Preview
text: MONTREAL — Boris Bede, the rookie kicker of the Montreal Alouettes in the Canadian Football League, made league history on June 25 when he launched the first rule-mandated 32-yard extra point.

headline: ‘Key & Peele’ Ends While Nation Could Still Use a Laugh

headline: Jerome G. Miller, 83, Dies; Emptied Reformatories to Better Juvenile Justice
text: Jerome G. Miller, who inspired a revolution in America’s juvenile justice system by virtually emptying Massachusetts’s reformatories in the early 1970s, died on Aug. 7 at his home in Woodstock, Va. He was 83.

headline: Susan Newhouse, Who Guided Fresh Air Fund, Dies at 80

headline: Technical Problem Suspends Flights Along East Coast

headline: Bernard d’Espagnat, 93, Physicist, Dies; Sought Implications of Quantum Theory
text: Bernard d’Espagnat, a French physicist and philosopher whose writings explored the philosophical implications of the paradoxical laws that govern the subatomic realm, died on Aug. 1 in Paris. He was 93.

headline: Obama Power Foursome Hits Links Before Vernon Jordan Soiree

Jordan Jr. and Ron Kirk, America’s former trade representative.

headline: Wolves, Resurgent and Protected, Vex Swedish Farmers
text: OLMHULT, Sweden — Electric fences surround his sheep, two large dogs stand guard and a neighbor monitors the adjacent forest from a security camera.

headline: 40 Migrants Found Dead in Sea Rescue
text: ROME — The crew of an Italian Navy ship that responded to a distress call on Saturday morning from a boat carrying hundreds of migrants discovered the bodies of more than 20 people piled on top of one another in the boat’s hold, Italian officials said. It was another ghastly reminder of the perils faced by migrants crossing the Mediterranean in overcrowded and unsafe vessels.

headline: Disney Bulks Up Theme Parks, as Universal Gains Ground

headline: Clinton and Trump at the Iowa State Fair

headline: Excess in Iowa: 90°, a Butter Cow and Rides on Donald Trump’s Helicopter
text: DES MOINES, Iowa — Hillary Rodham Clinton denounced Jeb Bush and discussed the rise of the Islamic State. Bernie Sanders held forth on Social Security. But at the Iowa State Fair, where a life-size butter cow rules and fairgoers devour stick-impaled delicacies, it is the candidacy of Donald J. Trump that perhaps best captures the air of raucous excess.

headline: Jason Day Leads a P.G.A. Championship Round Filled With Zany Shots
text: HAVEN, Wis. — No sequence exemplified the madcap, can-you-top-this personality of the third round at the P.G.A. Championship as perfectly as Matt Jones’s shot from the blue carpet of a hospitality tent.

headline: A 6-Under Round for Phil Mickelson Bolsters His Presidents Cup Bid
text: HAVEN, Wis. — Phil Mickelson has never depended on the kindness of Team USA captains, and he does not intend to start now. That is why his six-under 66 in the P.G.A. Championship on Saturday mattered. Mickelson’s first subpar round of the week not only catapulted him up the leaderboard into a tie for 24th from 61st, but also gave him hope that the payoff for all his hard work would come in time for him to make the United States team for the Presidents Cup in South Korea in October.

headline: Three Killed and Eight Injured in Crash on Taconic State Parkway

headline: Exclusion of Blacks From Juries Raises Renewed Scrutiny
text: SHREVEPORT, La. — Here are some reasons prosecutors have offered for excluding blacks from juries: They were young or old, single or divorced, religious or not, failed to make eye contact, lived in a poor part of town, had served in the military, had a hyphenated last name, displayed bad posture, were sullen, disrespectful or talkative, had long hair, wore a beard.

headline: Hamid Gul, 78, Dies; Backed Militants in Leading Pakistan Spy Agency
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Hamid Gul, an influential and contentious three-star general who served as the head of Inter-Services Intelligence, Pakistan’s spy agency, from 1987 to 1989 and was deeply involved in the country’s policy toward neighboring Afghanistan when Soviet troops were withdrawing, died on Saturday in Muree, a hill station near Islamabad, the capital of Pakistan. He was 78.

headline: Provincial Minister in Pakistan Is Killed in Suicide Bombing
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A senior provincial minister in Pakistan who was at the forefront of the country’s fight against militants and banned sectarian groups was killed in a suicide bomb attack on Sunday, officials said. At least 10 other people were also said to have been killed in the bombing, and several were reported wounded.

headline: Indonesian Plane Carrying 54 Is Declared Missing in Papua
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Rescue teams were searching Monday for the wreckage of an Indonesian commercial aircraft carrying 54 people that was believed to have crashed on Sunday amid inclement weather in the eastern region of Papua.

headline: 1915: M. Venizelos Scores Triumph in Greek Chamber Election
text: ATHENS — The Greek Chamber met at Athens yesterday for the first time after the elections, and M. Zavitsanos, the Venizelist candidate, was elected President of the Chamber by a clear majority of 58 votes. The Chamber was opened with the customary ceremonial. M. Venizelos will be summoned by King Constantine to-morrow. So soon as he has made known his programme, the King will give him his decision.

text: Betsy Pinover Schiff realized she no longer recognized New York, and that made her happy. It made her happier than she was in 1997 or 1998, when, she said, book publishers scorned the idea she was championing: gardens in the city.

headline: Messes Pile Up for de Blasio in 2nd Year

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) SHOW ME A HERO Nick Wasicsko (Oscar Isaac, above, with Carla Quevedo), a young Yonkers mayor, tries to get the city to abide by a federal judge’s desegregation order, despite savage opposition — and destroys his future in the process — in David Simon’s mini-series, based on a nonfiction book by Lisa Belkin, a former reporter for The New York Times. The cast includes Alfred Molina as a machine politician, Bob Balaban as the judge, and Terry Kinney, Clarke Peters and Catherine Keener. “What Mr. Simon and his ‘Wire’ collaborator William F. Zorzi have written, and Paul Haggis (‘Crash’) has directed, is many things: meticulously and cleverly assembled, wonderfully coherent, often moving and funny, painstaking in its evocation of a midsize, tired city in the late 1980s and early ’90s,” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. “In its later episodes, as the first black and Latino residents move into their new homes in formerly all-white neighborhoods of east Yonkers, it has a real (if modest) emotional punch. But, ultimately, it’s a show to be admired, not loved.”

headline: One Dead in Crash of Small Plane on Long Island
text: One person was killed and another was injured on Sunday when a small plane crashed on Long Island, leaving debris scattered across the tracks of the Long Island Rail Road near Hicksville and disrupting commuter service throughout the day, the authorities said.

headline: ‘Straight Outta Compton’ Tops Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES — The N.W.A. biopic “Straight Outta Compton,” backed by a sophisticated marketing campaign, touched a cultural nerve over the weekend, taking in $56.1 million at the domestic box office, an astounding total for an R-rated drama.

headline: 1965: U.S. Drops Effort to make Russia Pay UN Debts
text: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. — The United States today said it would bow to the will of the majority and permit the UN General Assembly to resume normal operations without a confrontation over Soviet voting rights. U.S. Ambassador Arthur J. Goldberg, in his first UN speech, told the 33-nation Committee on Peace-Keeping Operations that the United States had regretfully concluded, ‘‘on ample evidence, that at this stage in the history of the United Nations, the General Assembly is not prepared to carry out the relevant provisions of the Charter in the context of the present situation.

headline: Obama Administration Warns Beijing About Covert Agents Operating in U.S.
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has delivered a warning to Beijing about the presence of Chinese government agents operating secretly in the United States to pressure prominent expatriates — some wanted in China on charges of corruption — to return home immediately, according to American officials.

headline: Donald Trump Releases Plan to Combat Illegal Immigration
text: After staking his early campaign on caustic and contentious remarks about undocumented immigrants, Donald J. Trump on Sunday outlined his plan to fix the country’s immigration system and deal with people who are in the country illegally.

headline: Yankees Fall to Blue Jays, Tightening A.L. East Race Again
text: TORONTO — Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman walked out on a ledge near the top of CN Tower late Saturday afternoon, tethered only by a harness, which was stronger than his nerves.

headline: Review: Lars Vogt Presents Late-Career Beethoven and Schubert at Mostly Mozart
text: The word “muscular” often came to mind while listening to the German pianist Lars Vogt perform Beethoven’s Piano Concerto No. 4 at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday evening. Mr. Vogt balanced a powerful touch that stopped just short of harsh in forte passages, particularly in the piano’s upper register, with a limpid delicacy, control and poise that proved striking in intimate sections.

headline: Review: Erasing Borders Festival of Indian Dance, a Showcase of Dizzying Movement
text: Now that the weeklong Battery Dance Festival — an August perennial — has settled on a stage in Robert F. Wagner Jr. Park, it has the best backdrop in New York. The audience sees, behind the dancers, the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island. Sailboats, cruise boats and yachts pass. Airplanes pass silently above. The drawback is that audience members, at 6:30 p.m., have the early-evening sun in their eyes. Baseball caps or dark sunglasses are advised.

headline: An Ex-Player at the Center of the N.F.L. Concussion Settlement Dispute
text: MIRAMAR, Fla. — During his nine years in the N.F.L., Shawn Wooden was a steady, if unspectacular, presence on the field. Selected in the sixth round of the 1996 draft by the Miami Dolphins, he never made it to the Super Bowl, and in all likelihood, he will never be elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

headline: Review: Emery LeCrone Dance and Amy Seiwert’s Imagery Balance Elements
text: It’s not news that female choreographers are underrepresented within major ballet companies. Take the coming season at New York City Ballet, which includes 58 works, among them seven new commissions, and not one by a woman. In the midst of this landscape, the emphasis on female choreographers at the Joyce Theater’s recent Ballet Festival — where four out of the six engagements were produced and/or choreographed by women — was probably not incidental, an effort to counter that imbalance. And it made for a nice change of pace.

headline: New Dr. Dre Album Serves as a Test for Apple Music
text: When Apple introduced its new streaming service, Apple Music, at the end of June, one of the big questions hanging over it was whether it could compete with outlets like Spotify to deliver blockbuster results for big new albums.

headline: Review: Lynn Nottage’s ‘Sweat’ Examines Lives Unraveling by Industry’s Demise
text: ASHLAND, Ore. — “Sweat,” the title of Lynn Nottage’s scorching new play, refers to the hard labor that its characters have put in for decades, only to find their modest livelihoods threatened by the evaporation of manufacturing jobs in America. But members of the audience may find themselves getting a little moist with anxiety as this extraordinarily moving drama hurtles toward its conclusion with the awful inevitability of Greek tragedy.

headline: On China’s Economy
text: Is it time to panic?

headline: Janelle Monáe, and Other Wondaland Artists, Step Back in Time at the Highline Ballroom
text: Janelle Monáe is on her third, maybe fourth life, a striking fact given that she’s been an avowed futurist from the very start. For almost a decade, she’s been treating R&B and funk as technologies badly in need of updating, planning for their cyborg future and waiting for everyone else to catch up.

headline: Lucia Berlin’s Roving, Rowdy Life Is Reflected in a Book of Her Stories
text: “In order to write about life, first you must live it.” That’s often attributed to Hemingway, and he would have applauded Lucia Berlin, who made fiction from her life and had a surplus of raw material. Born in Alaska in 1936 to a father who was a mining engineer, Ms. Berlin lived all over the American West and in Chile, New York City and Mexico. She survived childhood abuse and adult alcoholism, an addiction that sent her, in her words, to “jails, hospitals, psych wards.” She hung out with poets and musicians (marrying two jazz players). By her early 30s, she had been divorced three times and had four sons. She worked as a house cleaner, a substitute teacher and a hospital clerk. She put much of her roving, rowdy life onto the page in vivid stories that garnered the respect of a modest audience and now could be on the verge of making her posthumously famous.

headline: Review: In Susan Barker’s ‘The Incarnations,’ Lives of Despair (Past and Present) in China
text: Trying to spruce up its public image before the 2008 Summer Olympics, China embarked on a program of enforced self-improvement in which citizens were meant to change their ways on the spot. No more spitting; no more queue-jumping. No more risible translation of signs, either: In one fell swoop, the Dongda Anus Hospital, a much-photographed Beijing tourist attraction, became the Dongda Proctology Hospital.

headline: Catch Charlie Barnett and Other Rising Stand-Up Stars Who Never Hit the Top
text: I was walking through Central Park last year when I came across a comic on a bench selling jokes for a dollar. After I bought a punch line, we started talking comedy. “My dream,” he said, “is to be like Charlie Barnett.”

headline: Marc Quinn’s ‘The Toxic Sublime’ Shows a Provocateur and Social Observer

headline: Q. and A.: Qiu Xiaolong on His Novel ‘Shanghai Redemption’
text: In Qiu Xiaolong’s new novel, “Shanghai Redemption,” Inspector Chen Cao of the Shanghai police finds himself once again enmeshed in elite political struggles inside the Chinese Communist Party, but it is now harder than ever for him to navigate the conflicts. This latest installment in the Inspector Chen series was published in March in France, and an English-language edition is set for release in the United States in September. In an interview, Mr. Qiu, a Shanghai native who now lives in St. Louis, discussed how the 2012 downfall of Bo Xilai, the ambitious party chief of Chongqing and Politburo member, influenced the novel. Mr. Bo’s purge from the party and criminal trial on corruption charges were precipitated by the flight of his former police chief, Wang Lijun, to the United States Consulate in Chengdu, where Mr. Wang told American officials that Mr. Bo’s wife, Gu Kailai, had killed a British businessman with poison.

headline: Retailer Earnings, Fed Minutes and Greek Debt

Walmart has invested heavily in its stores, as well as in its online business and work force, as part of a bid to overcome a prolonged decline in sales and market share. Still, analysts do not expect big results soon. On the other hand, Home Depot, the home improvement retailer, has been riding a recovery in the housing market to sales gains, and analysts expect it to book a solid quarter. Also reporting this week are TJX on Tuesday; Staples, Lowe’s and American Eagle Outfitters on Wednesday; and Foot Locker on Friday. —Hiroko Tabuchi

headline: What’s On TV Monday

(HBO) TASHI AND THE MONK (2015) In 2006, Lobsang Phuntsok, a Buddhist monk who trained under the Dalai Lama, felt called to leave his life as a spiritual teacher in the United States and return to his homeland with the mission of rescuing unwanted children. This documentary, directed by Andrew Hinton and Johnny Burke, follows Mr. Phuntsok into the foothills of the Indian Himalayas, where he has created a community called Jhamtse Gatsal (translation: “the garden of love and compassion”) that offers a home and education to 85 children who have been orphaned or abandoned — among them Tashi, above, a 5-year-old girl with an alcoholic father who, at the time of filming, was the newest and youngest resident, and perhaps the most challenging.

headline: Mario Vargas Llosa’s ‘Notes on the Death of Culture’
text: I call it the newspaper problem: About a decade ago I wrote an essay on contemporary poetry for a newspaper that will remain nameless, and had the occasion to quote a line by “Eliot.” The editor sent back many changes, the most telling of which was that the quotation was now attributed to “the English poet T.S. Eliot.” Vaguely piqued, I asked what the editor was trying to clarify: Was he afraid readers wouldn’t realize the quotation came from a poem? Or was he afraid readers might confuse the Eliot who wrote it with, say, George Eliot, the pseudonymous author of “Middlemarch”? Anyway, I noted that the English qualifier was misleading: Though T.S. Eliot had taken British citizenship, he had been born in America. The editor, then, sent on another suggestion: “the American-born English poet T.S. Eliot.” I, having lost all the patience I had as a 24-year-old, replied by modifying that tag to: “the American-born, British-­citizen English-language poet, essayist, dramatist, teacher, publisher and bank teller Thomas Stearns Eliot (1888-1965),” after which the editor finally got the point and canceled the assignment.

headline: ‘NeuroTribes,’ by Steve Silberman
text: The history of science is studded with stories of simultaneous discovery, in which two imaginative souls (or more!) turn out to have been digging tunnels to the same unspoiled destination. The most fabled example is calculus, developed independently in two different countries by Isaac Newton and Gottfried Wilhelm von Leibniz, but the list stretches back centuries and unfurls right into the present. One can add to it sunspots, evolution, platinum, chloroform . . . and now autism, as the science journalist Steve Silberman informs us, identified separately by Leo Kanner and Hans Asperger. The crucial difference is that Kanner had the fortune to publish his work in Baltimore, while Asperger had the misfortune to publish his in Nazi-controlled Vienna, and this accident of geopolitics lies at the tragic core of Silberman’s ambitious, meticulous and largehearted (if occasionally long-winded) history, “NeuroTribes: The Legacy of Autism and the Future of ­Neurodiversity.”

headline: Voting Underway In Sri Lankan Election
text: Residents including Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe and former President Mahinda Rajapaksa cast their ballots in Sri Lanka’s parliamentary election.

headline: International Designation Is Sweet Victory for Burgundy
text: VOSNE-ROMANÉE, France — Aubert de Villaine gently lowered a long glass tube into an oak barrel and filled it with a rare liquid: Romanée-Conti Burgundy from the 2014 harvest.

headline: Music Can Help Recovery From Surgery
text: Surgical patients who listen to music — even while they are under general anesthesia — have less anxiety and need less pain medication during recovery than those who do not, a large review of studies has found.

headline: An Expat in Berlin for 36 Hours
text: While I was backpacking alone through Europe in 2006, people kept telling me to check out Berlin. Though I originally had no intention of moving here, I was immediately enamored of the city: its energy; its fascinating, devastating history; the freedom it seemed to offer.

headline: John Lansing Named as New Chief of Broadcasting Board of Governors
text: WASHINGTON — John Lansing, a retired cable television executive, was named Monday as the new chief executive of the Broadcasting Board of Governors, the agency that oversees United States government-supported, civilian international news media such as Voice of America and Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty.

headline: N.L.R.B. Rejects Northwestern Football Players’ Union Bid
text: The National Labor Relations Board on Monday dismissed a petition by Northwestern football players who were seeking to unionize, effectively denying their claim that they are university employees and should be allowed to collectively bargain. In a unanimous decision that was a clear victory for the college sports establishment, the five-member board declined to exert its jurisdiction in the case and preserved, for now, one of the N.C.A.A.’s core principles: that college athletes are primarily students.

headline: Naoki Inaba’s Area Maze Puzzle
text: This week’s challenge is an original suggested by Naoki Inaba, and is the second in a series by this ingenuous and remarkably prolific Japanese puzzle designer. (In case you missed it, check out Predator and Prey.) This week we take on Menseki Meiro, or “Area Maze,” referring to the labyrinthine process involved in finding the target — the area of a rectangle. Area Maze is already a hit in Japan. Will it have the same addictive potential in the United States as it does in Japan? Let’s give it a try. Here’s Mr. Inaba presenting five challenges in ascending difficulty:

headline: Gearing Up for Turner Prize, Art Exhibition Will Roam Scotland
text: LONDON — A roving art exhibition featuring work by Scottish Turner Prize winners and nominees will go on the road this fall in the lead-up to the Dec. 7 announcement of this year’s award winner in Glasgow.

headline: Where to Eat and Shop at the Barlow in Sebastopol
text: A fire pit, bocce courts and public lawns invite visitors to linger at a development called the Barlow in Sonoma County.

headline: Teen Choice Awards
text: Britney Spears had tie-dye hair, Jussie Smollett sported a hat, Zendaya rocked a high waist skirt and more style choices from the show.

headline: Marijuana: Uncertain Medicine
text: Marijuana’s effects can vary from person to person, and scientists are not quite sure what to make of the common distinction users and growers make between cannabis sativa and cannabis indica.

headline: The Beatles Awaken a New Sensation
text: I think I had my first orgasm at a Beatles concert — then again, how would I have known? When you’re preteen, prepubescent and pretty much pre-everything, “I Want to Hold Your Hand” seems the height of erotic ambition. And that was especially true in 1964, before the sexual revolution and the Internet made that kind of ignorance unimaginable.

headline: Stay Focused on Your Own Spending, Not the Other Person’s
text: The CrossFit Park City gym is right across the parking lot from my office. I used to love going there early in the morning to get my daily dose of intensity and to spend time with other people dedicated to the same thing. But a few years ago, I made a mistake. Instead of staying focused on my goals, I got a little too focused on beating other people, and I injured my shoulder.

headline: Accomable: Lessons From an Inspiring Start-Up
text: Srin Madipalli and Martyn Sibley, like many entrepreneurs, got the idea for their start-up from their everyday experience, seeing a problem to solve.

headline: An Instagram Walkabout in the Bronx
text: What’s the best way to connect with our readers? Meet them face-to-face.

headline: Looks from the Blue Carpet at the Teen Choice Awards
text: The 2015 Teen Choice Awards on Sunday evening brought together a bevy of stars, including Zendaya, Britney Spears and Shay Mitchell.

headline: Tracy Morgan to Host ‘Saturday Night Live’ in First Performance Since Accident
text: More than a year after he was critically injured in an automobile accident, Tracy Morgan will return to host “Saturday Night Live” in his first announced performance since the accident. NBC said on Monday that Mr. Morgan, an alumnus of “Saturday Night Live” and the comedy series “30 Rock,” is scheduled to host “S.N.L.” on Oct. 17 in one of its first new episodes of the fall season. He has been recovering since he was injured in a crash on the New Jersey Turnpike in June 2014, when a luxury van he was riding in was struck from behind by a Walmart tractor-trailer. Mr. Morgan said in an interview on NBC’s “Today” show in June that he hoped to return to comedy when he was able, adding, “When I’m there, you’ll know it. I’ll get back to making you laugh. I promise you.”

headline: Russia Burns Dutch Flowers Amid Netherlands’ Inquiry Into Malaysia Airlines Crash
text: MOSCOW — In recent years, trade relations between Russia and the Netherlands have at times blossomed and at times wilted. This summer they went up in smoke.

headline: Lobbying Fight Over Iran Nuclear Deal Centers on Democrats
text: WASHINGTON — From his rented vacation home on Martha’s Vineyard with sweeping views of the Atlantic Ocean, President Obama has been making phone calls to Democratic members of Congress, trying to rally support for the nuclear deal with Iran that faces a vote next month.

headline: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch This Week
text: That music you hear when you close your eyes is this season’s first true stirrings of the Champions League anthem. The final playoff rounds begin this week, with hope still alive for scrappy little challengers like ... wait, is that Manchester United over there?

headline: Donald Trump Arrives for Jury Duty
text: Mr. Trump, a Republican presidential candidate, reported for jury duty at State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

headline: Stalled Train and Burning Car Create Another Bad Commute for N.J. Transit
text: New Jersey Transit riders faced another morning of difficult delays on Monday after a car caught fire inside the Lincoln Tunnel and a train stalled in one of the Hudson River rail tunnels.

headline: 2015 Fantasy Football: Running Back Preview and Rankings
text: Any fantasy football owner with the No. 1 overall draft pick this season will not have an easy decision, as there is no clear consensus on which player is the safest choice, though based on average draft position, at least most drafters agree that the selection should be a running back.

headline: Chris Christie Assails Donald Trump’s Immigration Plan
text: Donald J. Trump’s immigration plan has been panned by many Democrats as an extreme measure, but some of his Republican rivals also have their doubts.

headline: Exposures Puerto Rico
text: Summary TK

headline: 1915: U.S. Angered by German Plots
text: LONDON — According to the New York correspondent of the ‘‘Daily Express,’’ the revelations concerning the great German plot in the United States have caused a nation-wide sensation, and the Government is considering whether formal action can be taken against the conspirators. The New York ‘‘World’’ to-day prints a memorandum on a project to obtain possession of all the liquid chlorine in America in order to prevent its exportation to the Allies for the manufacture of asphyxiating gases. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 18, 1915

headline: Bedtime Stories for Young Brains
text: A little more than a year ago, the American Academy of Pediatrics issued a policy statement saying that all pediatric primary care should include literacy promotion, starting at birth.

headline: Facing Money Gap, Hillary Clinton Slowly Warms to ‘Super PAC’ Gifts
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton recently spent four days straight scurrying across the Western United States, mingling for hours at a time with hundreds of Democratic donors from the Rockies to Portland, Ore., from Southern California to the southern tip of Texas, and everywhere seeking the maximum primary campaign contribution allowed by law: $2,700.

headline: Scott Walker Is Heckled in Iowa State Fair Appearance
text: DES MOINES – They sported Wisconsin cheese hats but the impression that Gov. Scott Walker had brought a home-state cheering section was demolished when catcalls began as soon as he started speaking Monday morning.

headline: A Mouthwash Rinse May Predict Throat Cancer Recurrence
text: A simple mouthwash rinse may be able to predict the dangerous recurrence of a kind of throat cancer that is rapidly increasing in heterosexual men, according to a new study.

headline: Paul Smith’s College Will Get $20 Million, if It Changes Its Name
text: PAUL SMITHS, N.Y. — To administrators of the financially troubled college here, Joan Weill’s appearance on campus more than 20 years ago may have seemed like the arrival of a fairy godmother.

headline: Communicating Through Whistling
text: Two men arrange to meet at a cafe by whistling across a valley about 765 yards wide in Kuşköy, Turkey.

headline: David Denson, Gay Minor Leaguer, Has Power but Faces Long Odds
text: Stepping into the batter’s box at Marlins Park in Miami three years ago, David Denson, 17, looked as if he might have a future in the big leagues when he mashed a 515-foot drive off the scoreboard in a home run competition, breaking the distance record by 12 feet.

headline: Sorry I’m Late Again, Boss…
text: Anybody trying to cross the Hudson River by tunnel between New Jersey and New York on Monday morning probably had to rely on a reserve of patience, good humor and an understanding boss.

headline: Hacking Case Raises Question on Securities Fraud
text: The elaborate scheme described by the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission last week, which involved breaking into computer servers to obtain confidential information about impending corporate announcements, certainly looks like a classic case of insider trading. The defendants are accused of making millions of dollars in profits by using information to trade profitably.

headline: Batches of Root Beer Generate a Noticeable Buzz
text: Hard root beer is flying off the shelves. Not Your Father’s Root Beer, an ale fermented with spices, made by Small Town Brewery in Wauconda, Ill., landed in New York and elsewhere late last month. The taste, like soda fountain root beer with less sweetness, does not hide the gentle kick from 5.9 percent alcohol. Coney Island Brewing, which opened recently, also has a hard root beer. It is 5.8 percent alcohol and a tad sweeter and fizzier than the competition. The flavor is less earthy with more vanilla and coffee in the flavor notes. Coney Island’s main backer is Boston Beer, the parent company of Sam Adams. The root beer is being made at a Boston Beer plant, not in Brooklyn. Now you can turn that root beer float into a nightcap: Not Your Father’s Root Beer, $10.99 for a six-pack at Fairway markets; Coney Island Hard Root Beer, $2.50 a bottle at Malt & Mold, maltandmold.com.

headline: Ayatollah Khamenei Says Talk of U.S. Influences in Iran Is ‘Hollow Fantasy’
text: TEHRAN — Iran’s highest leader lashed out at the United States on Monday, saying talk that American influences would pour into the country on a wave of positive feelings over the nuclear deal is nothing more than a “hollow fantasy.”

headline: A Woman’s Tweed
text: The traditional men’s wear fabric has been nipped and tucked to new feminine proportions.

headline: In Tianjin Blasts, a Heavy Toll for Unsuspecting Firefighters
text: BEIJING — The young firefighters, their thin frames puffed up by insulated coveralls, some of them barely old enough to shave, rushed to the scene of a modest warehouse blaze in the port city of Tianjin on Wednesday night with little idea of the danger that awaited them.

headline: South Sudan’s President Lets Deadline for Signing a Peace Deal Pass
text: UNITED NATIONS — Bucking the threat of international sanctions, the president of South Sudan, Salva Kiir, refused to sign a peace deal to halt the nation’s civil war on Monday, the deadline for a final accord mediated by African leaders.

headline: Whistled Form of Turkish Is One of a Kind
text: Unlike all other spoken languages, a whistled form of Turkish requires that speakers rely as heavily on the right side of their brain as on the left.

headline: What Would You Pay for This Meal?
text: How often have you bought something you felt wasn’t worth the money?

headline: Katherine Sorensen, Patrick Hebert
text: Katherine Kelly Sorensen and Patrick Daniel Hebert were married Saturday at the Castle Hill Inn in Newport, R.I. Matan Ariel, a friend of the couple who became a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Breast-Feeding’s Heart Benefits
text: Breast-feeding has many benefits. Now a new study found it may reduce a woman’s risk for cardiovascular disease later in life.

headline: Citigroup to Pay $180 Million Over Collapsed Hedge Funds
text: Citigroup has agreed to pay $180 million to settle charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission that the bank concealed problems at two of its now-defunct hedge funds, while taking in additional investments in the months before the financial crisis.

headline: A Chinese Drought Weather Report Written on Cave Walls
text: Writings on the walls of a cave in China record the effects of droughts over the last 500 years, researchers have found.

headline: Neighbors Surprised by New York Attack
text: Residents of the Washington Heights area of New York responded with shock to the stabbing death of E’Dena Hines, the granddaughter of the actor Morgan Freeman’s former wife.

headline: U.S. Budgets Cash to Treat Heroin Abuse in Northeast
text: CHILMARK, Mass. — Faced with a surge in heroin abuse in recent years, especially in the Northeast, the White House on Monday announced a program aimed at improving the government’s response to the drug across 15 states in that region.

headline: Summer Vacation: Goodbye Restaurants, Hello Kitchen
text: There are people who plan their vacations around restaurant reservations that have to be secured months in advance. I am not one of them. When I need to get away from it all, competing for a table is one of the main things I’m getting away from. That, and meals longer than a filibuster, and hearing that “Chef” would like me to eat this particular taste in one bite while rubbing my stomach and patting my head.

headline: The Butterfly, the Ant and the Oregano
text: It may be hard to imagine a ménage à trois, satisfactory to all parties, in which one member tries to dislodge another with a toxic gas and a third eats the offspring of the other two. But such an arrangement exists, and one of its members may even be sitting quietly in your kitchen’s spice rack.

headline: 1940: Electroshock Therapy
text: “Insanity Treated By Electric Shock” read the headline of an article published on July 6, 1940, in The New York Times. The article described “a new method, introduced in Italy, of treating certain types of mental disorders by sending an electric shock through the brain.”

headline: Egypt Widens Government Power With New Anti-Terrorism Law
text: CAIRO — President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt has issued a counterterrorism law that gives state security officers wider immunity from prosecution, expands the government’s surveillance powers and penalizes journalists for contradicting official accounts of militant attacks.

headline: Thai Police Statement on Explosion
text: Officials provided an update about the deadly blast at the Erawan Shrine in Bangkok.

headline: Ted Cruz Megadonor Identified as Cellphone Executive
text: A New York cellphone executive has emerged as a mystery megadonor behind the presidential campaign of Senator Ted Cruz of Texas.

headline: Warren Braren, 82, Dies; Urged Ban on Broadcast Tobacco Ads
text: Warren Braren, a reformed smoker who helped trigger a congressional ban on tobacco advertising on television and radio in 1970 by blowing the whistle on broadcasters’ lax self-regulation, died on Thursday at his home in New Milford, Conn. He was 82.

headline: Palestinian Man Fatally Shot in Confrontation With Israeli Police
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — A Palestinian man wearing jeans, a black shirt and sneakers approached two heavily armed Israeli police officers at a West Bank checkpoint in Nablus on Monday, claiming he was sick and needed medical assistance. It was a ruse, according to an Israeli police spokeswoman, who said the man tried to stab the border officers before they shot him dead.

headline: Daily Coffee May Boost Colon Cancer Survival
text: Colon cancer patients who were heavy coffee drinkers had a far lower risk of dying or having their cancer return than those who did not drink coffee, with significant benefits starting at two to three cups a day, a new study found. Patients who drank four cups of caffeinated coffee or more a day had half the rate of recurrence or death than noncoffee drinkers.

headline: Luke Bryan Tops Dr. Dre in Album Sales
text: On the music charts this week, the country star Luke Bryan beat Dr. Dre for the No. 1 album, as expected, while OMI’s “Cheerleader” returns as the top single.

headline: Police Officers Are Killed at a Checkpoint in Afghanistan’s South
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — At least five Afghan police officers were poisoned and then shot to death in the southern province of Helmand late on Sunday, according to Afghan officials, who said the attack was the third of its kind in the province in less than two weeks.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, Greece, Thailand and Bulgaria.

headline: August 17, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photographs from Ukraine, Greece, Thailand and Bulgaria.

headline: ‘Hamilton’ Shows Its Muscle on Broadway
text: It was a big week at the box office for the founding fathers and a pair of magicians, according to data released on Monday by the Broadway League, a trade group for theater owners and producers.

headline: Jury Duty for Donald Trump: ‘Amazing,’ ‘Really Good’ and Done in a Day
text: The prospective juror emerged from his stretch limousine at 9:07 a.m. He spoke briefly to the waiting media horde, walked a gantlet of photographers and climbed the steps of State Supreme Court in Lower Manhattan.

headline: As Winning Majors Gets Tougher, Losing Them Is Easier to Stomach
text: HAVEN, Wis. — Can we agree that it has never been harder to win a major in men’s professional golf? Consider the case of Justin Rose, who produced 72-hole scores of 14 under par at the Masters and the P.G.A. Championship only to lose by a combined 10 strokes. In golf’s four showcase events, Rose was 34 under, the fourth-lowest cumulative total in history.

headline: Off the Coast of Iran, a High-Stakes Version of Spy Versus Spy
text: MANAMA, Bahrain — The commander of the Navy’s Fifth Fleet was in his office on the afternoon of July 25 when he got the phone call: An Iranian Navy frigate in the Gulf of Aden had approached a ship where an American military helicopter had just landed.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the editor:

headline: Negotiators on South Sudan Peace Accord
text: Officials in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, commented on the failure of the South Sudanese president, Salva Kiir, to sign the peace agreement that was reached on Monday.

headline: Hamptons Night at the Apollo
text: Christina Aguilera, Jamie Foxx, Jimmy Fallon, Smokey Robinson and others perform at Ron Perelman’s fund-raiser for the Apollo.

headline: Stevie Wonder Performs Free D.C. Concert
text: Mr. Wonder surprised fans with a free concert on the Armory Mall in Washington on Monday, before heading to perform free shows in Philadelphia and New York.

headline: Petco Files for an I.P.O.
text: Only months after one of the country’s big retailers of dog food and catnip went private, another is planning a return to the public markets.

headline: Hamptons Night at the Apollo
text: It has become of one of the Hamptons’ most glamorous galas: Ron Perelman hosted a Saturday night gala for the Apollo Theater at his East Hampton estate. Performers included Jamie Foxx and Jimmy Fallon, who, it turns out, does an uncanny impression of Mick Jagger. See the photos.

headline: Lifetime Commits to ‘Unauthorized’ Movie Franchise
text: Critics panned it. Fans skewered it. Ratings were middling. But in the end it didn’t really matter what anyone thought about Lifetime’s “The Unauthorized Saved by the Bell Story” when it ran over Labor Day weekend last year. It did the job.

headline: A Double Dose of Divine, and Other Reports From the Fringe Festival
text: On Saturday night, I stood in a basement space in the East Village, holding hands with a man who was attempting to regurgitate a bean, possibly cannellini. The bean, he promised, would have a number on it that matched a slip of paper I’d chosen from a plastic bag. The man was red-faced, groaning and coughing and retching. (I’m still not sure why he had to hold my hand.) Finally, he ejected the numbered bean from an unlikely orifice. Everyone applauded.

headline: Review: In ‘Unity (1918),’ a Town Blindsided by Spanish Influenza
text: So much for genteel images of the 1918 Spanish flu. Kevin Kerr’s “Unity (1918)” can make any “Upstairs Downstairs” fan forget the tasteful expiration of James Bellamy’s febrile young wife in a grand bedroom at Eaton Place. “Unity,” having its United States premiere at the Gene Frankel Theater, is much more like a horror story. The flu killed an estimated 50 million people worldwide in less than two years. (AIDS has killed around 39 million, but over 34 years.)

headline: Review: ‘The Last Love Song,’ a Biography of Joan Didion
text: Loss, nostalgia for a vanished past and “the unspeakable peril of the everyday” represented by “swimming pools, high-tension wires, lye under the sink, aspirin in the medicine cabinet” — these are the themes that have animated Joan Didion’s work, since “Slouching Towards Bethlehem” established her as one of America’s most distinctive and acute literary voices almost five decades ago.

headline: Review: In ‘Head Over Heels,’ Jukebox Musical Meets Elizabethan Romance
text: ASHLAND, Ore. — One ancient and venerable theatrical genre, the jukebox musical, is merrily mashed up with another, the Elizabethan romance, in “Head Over Heels,” having its premiere at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival here. In this funny and frolicsome concoction, the back catalog of the Go-Go’s, the new wave girl group that made a splash in ye olde 1980s, is wedded to a book by Jeff Whitty (“Avenue Q”) that pays winking homage to Sir Philip Sidney’s prose poem “The Arcadia,” from way back in the late 16th century.

headline: Review: George Benjamin, at Mostly Mozart, Shows Depth as a Conductor
text: Last week, during a discussion onstage after the opening-night performance of George Benjamin’s haunting opera “Written on Skin,” Mr. Benjamin, who has conducted the piece many times, lavished praise on the textured, exciting performance Alan Gilbert had just led.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
text: Good evening. Here’s the latest.

headline: ‘This Looks Like a National Strategy’
text: On the 50th anniversary of the signing of the Voting Rights Act earlier this month, Ari Berman, a contributing writer for The Nation, published “Give Us the Ballot,” a book about the decades-long political battle over minority voting rights that followed the act’s passage, which I also wrote about recently in the magazine. I caught up with Berman to discuss his book, the voting rights fights of the past and those that are to come.

headline: Of Camera Work and Fine Art
text: In Camera Work, Alfred Stieglitz sought to promote photography as fine art. To this day, some collectors have gone as far as to mount individual gravures from the fabled publication.

headline: Claren Road Investors Seek to Pull Out Nearly $2 Billion
text: Investors in Claren Road Asset Management may think the hedge fund has come to the end of the road.

headline: Shake-Up in Moscow as Railways Chief, a Putin Friend, Is Reported Ousted
text: MOSCOW — Vladimir I. Yakunin, the director of Russia’s national railway company and a longtime associate of President Vladimir V. Putin, has reportedly been ousted in one of the most significant shake-ups in domestic politics since the Russian economy slipped into recession last year.

headline: Major Flaws Found in Inquiry That Led to Suspension of Public-School Therapist
text: For sheer bureaucratic folly, it would be hard to top the suspension last year of a devoted occupational therapist in the public school system who showed children in wheelchairs how to get places.

headline: Why Amazon May Take a Page From Walmart’s Labor Playbook
text: Amazon’s latest results were so superb that they catapulted the online retailer’s market value beyond that of Walmart Stores for the first time. Now, the $250 billion goliath led by Jeff Bezos finds itself in another spot that its bricks-and-mortar rival will more happily cede: defending labor practices.

headline: Ta-Nehisi Coates’s ‘Between the World and Me’
text: For the past several years, I’ve greeted Ta-Nehisi Coates’s essays and blog posts for The Atlantic with nothing short of gratitude. As an African-American, he makes me proud. There is no other way to put it. I do not always agree with him, but it hardly matters. In a media world populated with pundits, so-called experts and public intellectuals driven by ego and familiar agendas, Coates’s voice stands nearly alone — a black man raised in the streets of Baltimore who narrowly escaped the violence that lurked around every corner and dodged the clutches of the prisons and jails that were built for him, and who now speaks unpopular, unconventional and sometimes even radical truths in his own voice, unfiltered. He is invariably humble, yet subtly defiant. And people listen.

headline: Hacking of Tax Returns More Extensive Than First Reported, I.R.S. Says
text: WASHINGTON — The Internal Revenue Service said Monday that hackers had gained access to the tax returns of more than 300,000 people, a far higher number than the agency had reported previously.

headline: As Scott Walker Struggles in Iowa, His Campaign Reaches Out to a Strategist
text: A consultant to Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin’s presidential campaign telephoned a Georgia-based Republican strategist last week to sound him out about working for Mr. Walker, a sign that he is considering staff changes at a moment when his campaign has been eclipsed by Donald J. Trump.

headline: Syrian State TV Edits Out Criticism From Visiting U.N. Official
text: Wrapping up a three-day visit to Syria on Monday, the new emergency relief coordinator of the United Nations, Stephen O’Brien, told reporters he was “absolutely horrified by the total disregard for civilian life by all parties in this conflict.”

headline: John Malone’s Big Bet on Online Shopping
text: John C. Malone is taking home shopping over the top.

headline: Messy Music at Berserktown Festival
text: This provocative three-day festival of various extremes of punk, noise, metal and D.I.Y. culture featured over 100 acts in Santa Ana, Calif.

headline: Berserktown Festival Offers a Chance to Meet Lesser Known Bands
text: SANTA ANA, Calif. — “We are not all born equal,” announced Victoria Ruiz, the singer of Downtown Boys, on Sunday afternoon at the Berserktown festival here, in a voice usually reserved for megaphones at protests.

headline: Former Goldman Executive Is Chosen to Lead Dallas Fed
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas on Monday chose for its new president Robert Steven Kaplan, a former Goldman Sachs executive.

headline: Iraq: Monitoring Group to Investigate Possible Chemical Weapons Use by ISIS
text: The group responsible for monitoring adherence to the global ban on chemical weapons said Monday that it had contacted Iraq over reports of the possible use of such munitions there. A statement by the group, the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, based in The Hague, came a few days after United States officials said Islamic State militants appeared to have used such munitions, possibly mustard gas, on Kurdish fighters in Iraq. If confirmed, it would be the first known use of the weapons by the Islamic State, which occupies parts of Syria and Iraq. The monitoring group called such reports “a matter of serious concern,” and its director, Ahmet Uzumcu, said it would “examine any substantive reports it receives including pertinent information that might be shared” by other signers of the chemical weapons ban, which appeared to be a reference to both Iraq and Syria. Iraq, where hundreds of old, corroded mustard artillery shells remained after the 2003 American invasion, signed the chemical weapons ban in 2009. Syria joined in 2013 after having promised to destroy its chemical stockpile, although the monitoring organization said this year that chlorine bombs had been used in the Syrian conflict. On Aug. 7, the United Nations Security Council passed a resolution authorizing an inquiry into who was responsible for the chlorine attacks.

headline: Starter’s Injury Tempers Yankees’ Extra-Inning Win Over Twins
text: In a frightening scene at Yankee Stadium on Monday night, Yankees starter Bryan Mitchell was hit in the face with a line drive off the bat of Eduardo Nunez, a right-handed hitter for the Minnesota Twins, in the second inning of an 8-7, 10-inning Yankees victory. In 2013, when Nunez was an infielder with the Yankees and on a rehab assignment with Class A Tampa, he and Mitchell were teammates for three games.

headline: Shell Wins Final Permission for Arctic Oil and Gas Drilling
text: The Obama administration on Monday issued a final permit for Shell to start drilling for oil and gas in the Arctic Ocean. The Interior Department gave conditional approval in May for the company’s long-delayed application to drill in the untouched waters of the Chukchi Sea off Alaska’s northwest coast. In July, the administration issued a permit that would allow Shell to start drilling at the top of the seabed but would not allow the drill to penetrate into the oil reserves until Shell had quick access to a “capping stack,” which is used to shut down wells in case of emergency spills. The ship carrying that capping stack arrived at the drilling site last week. Environmentalists have criticized Mr. Obama for moving forward with the drilling.

headline: Many Black Lawyers Navigate a Rocky, Lonely Road to Partner
text: Jimmie L. McMillian’s path to partnership in an Indianapolis law firm might seem unexceptional — except for a few telling details.

headline: Bob Johnston, 83, Dies; Produced Bob Dylan and Johnny Cash Albums
text: Bob Johnston, who produced a string of classic albums in the 1960s and ’70s including Bob Dylan’s “Highway 61 Revisited” and “Blonde on Blonde” and Johnny Cash’s “At Folsom Prison,” died on Friday in Gallatin, Tenn. He was 83.

headline: Amazon Chief’s Message to Employees
text: After the weekend publication of an article in The New York Times about his company’s management practices, Jeff Bezos, chief executive of Amazon, sent this message to all employees, linking to the Times article and a counterpoint written on LinkedIn:

headline: U.N. Finds Its Voice on Syria’s ‘Transition’
text: UNITED NATIONS — For four years, the United Nations Security Council has been unable to agree on what to say — let alone what to do — to stop the civil war in Syria.

headline: Mormon Leader Joseph Smith’s 34 Wives Inspire Utah Artist
text: SALT LAKE CITY — In Leslie O. Peterson’s mind, Fanny Alger’s almond-shaped face, with its soulful green eyes and rosebud mouth, is framed by close-cropped brown hair and perched atop a long, slender neck.

headline: Yankees’ C. C. Sabathia Is Contrite After Scuffle Outside Club
text: C.C. Sabathia acknowledged having used poor judgment in confronting a heckler outside a Toronto nightclub over the weekend after video of the incident was released Monday on the celebrity website TMZ.

headline: States Move to Cut Funds for Planned Parenthood

headline: Two Female Soldiers Poised to Graduate From Ranger School
text: Two female soldiers will graduate this week from Ranger School in Fort Benning, Ga., the first women to have made it through the Army’s premier leadership course and one of the most challenging and exhausting training programs in the military, Army officials said on Monday.

headline: Union Ruling Underlines N.C.A.A.’s Evolution
text: Among the more notable features of Monday’s landmark decision by the National Labor Relations Board declining to recognize Northwestern football players’ unionization efforts was the time it took to make it. A petition was filed in January 2014. An N.L.R.B. regional director recognized its legitimacy in March 2014, prompting an appeal to the federal board. But before Monday, it had been more than a year since anything appeared on the case’s docket.

headline: Yankees Game Turns Grisly in an Instant as Bryan Mitchell Is Hit

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
text: 8:20 A.M. (Encore) BLUE JASMINE (2013) Cate Blanchett won an Oscar for her role as Jasmine French, a Park Avenue matron fallen on hard times after her husband, Hal (Alec Baldwin), lands in prison for bilking his clients, leaving her with little more than her pearls, Chanel jacket, Hermès bag and Louis Vuitton luggage. Destitute, in a manner of speaking, Jasmine flies first-class to San Francisco to begin life anew with her sister, Ginger (Sally Hawkins), whose scrappy existence and brutish men Jasmine can barely stomach without self-medicating with vodka and Xanax. Then she meets a diplomatic type (Peter Sarsgaard) with an appreciation for her decorating talents and designer threads and starts to see light at the end of her dark tunnel. With intimations of Ruth Madoff and Blanche DuBois, this shattered woman is “brilliantly brought to quivering life by Ms. Blanchett,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, in Woody Allen’s “most sustained, satisfying and resonant film since ‘Match Point.’ ”

headline: Of Camera Work and Fine Art
text: “The hand camera has come to stay — its importance is acknowledged,” Alfred Stieglitz begrudgingly declared at the end of an 1897 essay about Eastman Kodak’s campaign “You Press the Button, We Do the Rest.” For Stieglitz, this meant that “Every Tom, Dick and Harry could, without trouble, learn how to get something or other on a sensitive plate, and this is what the public wanted — no work and lots of fun.”
