headline: Trump and the Charisma Premium
text: Having used my Sunday column to double down on one 2016 prediction — that Hillary’s still a mortal lock to be the Democratic nominee — let me use this post to quickly hedge a more recent bet: Namely, that the rise of Donald Trump might be a much-needed gift to Jeb Bush’s struggling “frontrunner” campaign. I offered various arguments three weeks ago for why this might be so, and most of them might yet be vindicated once we leave the preliminary phase of the campaign, Jeb starts spending ad dollars in earnest, the establishment field gets winnowed and voters get serious about the nominating process. But here’s one passage from my column that I want to revisit, because I’m not sure the first debate was kind to it:

headline: Police: More Suspects in Bangkok Bombing
text: Thailand’s national police chief said on Wednesday that there is likely more than one person involved in the fatal explosion at a Bangkok shrine on Monday.

headline: Uber Raises $100 Million From Tata of India
text: Uber has picked up another strategic investor.

headline: Pension-cutters and Privatizers, Oh My
text: I wrote Monday about the strange phenomenon of Republicans lining up to propose cuts to Social Security, a deeply unpopular policy that is, however, also a really bad idea. How unpopular? Lee Drutman has the data: only 6 percent of American voters support Social Security cuts, while a majority want it increased. I argued that this apparent act of political self-destructiveness probably reflected an attempt to curry favor with wealthy donors, who are very much at odds with the general public on this issue:

headline: Bombs at 3 Churches in Las Cruces, New Mexico, Confound the Authorities
text: LAS CRUCES, N.M. — Two homemade bombs exploded early this month during busy Sunday services at Roman Catholic and Baptist churches here, while a third, undetonated explosive was discovered on Friday near a leaking sprinkler valve at a Presbyterian church, fueling unease in this placid city in southern New Mexico, the second largest in the state.

headline: Alongside a Doctor’s Care, a Dose of Traditional Healing
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — The first thing Manuel Lincovil does is take a look at the urine. A machi, or spiritual leader and healer of the indigenous Mapuche people, he watches the liquid settle as he shakes the glass jar, learning of his patient’s experiences, ailments and sorrows.

headline: Cécile McLorin Salvant, With Refined Power, Performs at the Jazz Standard
text: When Cécile McLorin Salvant released her sanguine debut album, “Woman Child” (Mack Avenue), she represented something new in jazz singing, even in those moments (and they were many) when newness seemed to be the furthest thing from her mind. That was two years ago, and she has only strengthened her art since, growing more expressive with her vocal gift and more beguiling in her handling of an audience.

headline: A Dance-Theater Work Explores the Life of Pearl S. Buck
text: Come fall, you can expect an avalanche of biopics jockeying for awards consideration; Hollywood loves dramatic life stories. Dance, on the other hand, has never been particularly interested in biographical narrative. So “Pearl,” an ambitious dance-theater work exploring the life of the Nobel- and Pulitzer Prize-winning writer Pearl S. Buck, is a rare breed in both form and content. Buck was born in West Virginia and spent decades in China. She was a prolific writer (best known for the 1931 novel “The Good Earth”), an adoption advocate and a feminist — an intriguing muse for a dance spectacle.

headline: From Holding a Clipboard to Carrying a Franchise’s Hopes
text: N.F.L. teams are completing their depth charts, but for the most part, they know who will be the starting quarterback, the most important slot.

headline: A Pianist Returns to Le Poisson Rouge, and LoftOpera Heads to Brooklyn
text: Playing with suavity and nuance, Taka Kigawa took the stage at Le Poisson Rouge last August with a daunting program: all of Pierre Boulez’s works for piano solo. On Aug. 24, Mr. Kigawa returns to the same space with pieces in the Boulez orbit, by one of his great precursors and by two who’ve been influenced by him. The concert includes both books of Debussy’s “Images” alongside Marco Stroppa’s “Traiettoria ... deviata” for piano and live electronics and Tristan Murail’s “Territoires de l’oubli.” (7:30 p.m., lepoissonrouge.com.)

headline: The Imperfect Wim Wenders: Touring Films by the German Director
text: The German director Wim Wenders has a pile of awards from Cannes and other festivals as well as three Oscar nominations, but American moviegoers who stick to blockbusters probably remain unfamiliar with him. Perhaps a touring retrospective organized by Janus Films that begins a monthlong run on Aug. 28 at the IFC Center will serve as a small corrective. It features 12 of his films, including early works and some of his better-known movies from the 1980s. Among those is the haunting “Wings of Desire,” a fantasy about angels who eavesdrop on and sometimes comfort inhabitants of Berlin.

headline: ‘On the Town’ Is Pulling Up Anchor Soon
text: New York won’t be quite the same helluva town after Sept. 6.

headline: In TNT’s ‘Public Morals,’ Ed Burns Is on the Vice Beat in ’60s New York
text: Prostitution, gambling, after-hours clubs, gay bars — you name it, residents crave it. And everything is against the law in the 1960s. But who wants to make arrests for crimes that aren’t really hurting anyone? Not Terry Muldoon, an officer with the New York Police Department’s public morals division. “So, then, what exactly do we do here?” asks Jimmy Shea, the handsome newcomer. “We do what has been done for the last hundred years: We manage it for the city,” Muldoon says. “Think of us as the landlords, and if you want to be in business, you got to pay your rent. Do you understand what I am telling you?” Shea does. “Now I’m only going to ask you this this one time,” Muldoon says. “Are you in?”

headline: Target Reports Stronger Earnings After Cost Cuts and Job Losses
text: In a season dotted with notable earnings misses among retailers, Target bucked the industry trends by reporting strong earnings on Wednesday, its bottom line lifted by brisk sales of apparel and home goods as well as intensive cost-cutting.

headline: Pimp C in a Journalist’s Back Pages
text: I can tell you about the moment I heard Pimp C was dead — Dec. 4, 2007; at work in my office at Vibe; nervously refreshing TMZ, which had broken the news; feeling nauseous. The room hummed with the white noise that takes over when you no longer register what’s happening around you. Minutes later, a colleague knocked on my door, disrupting the quiet, and we looked at each other wordlessly, our jaws quivering but holding firm. My boss came by to ask if I was all right. I wasn’t.

headline: Destroyer Takes Another Sharp Turn Toward the Fringe
text: Dan Bejar is proudly, defiantly out of touch.

headline: Spinning Heartache Into Humor: Tig Notaro on Cancer, Her HBO Special and Going Topless
text: Next time you have a terrible year, feel free to call it a Tig Year. Because the comedian Tig Notaro’s 2012 was one for the ages.

headline: In Jerusalem, Mike Huckabee Calls West Bank Part of Israel
text: JERUSALEM – Staking out the most extreme position on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict in the crowded field of Republican candidates – one to the right of even Israel’s conservative government – former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas said Wednesday that the entire occupied West Bank was part of Israel, leaving no room for a Palestinian state there.

headline: Watch Your Language
text: “But why is it a bad word?” That’s a question parents reliably face as a former toddler enters the world of bigger kids, where a curse word can fly into the room like some confused baby bat, thrilling the kids and rattling the grownups. Curses are one of the great mysteries of human society, a testament to the weird and wonderful power of language. Hearing a small child cuss can be extremely funny but also, I suspect even for the most “relaxed” and mellow parent, unsettling.

headline: Assemble: Making Things Happen
text: For this renegade architecture collective, what goes on in and around a space is just as important as the space itself.

headline: Obama to Visit New Orleans for Hurricane Katrina Anniversary
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will travel to New Orleans next week for the 10th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, one of the costliest disasters in United States history.

headline: What I Learned From a Disgraced Art Show on Harlem
text: Some first-time art encounters are life-changers, and you know it instantly. They zap you, cast a spell, send you back out with your eyes and mind rewired. Other encounters are just as deep, but don’t seem to be, because you’re not ready for them. You don’t know what you’re looking at, though some day you will, and you’ll wish you could be back there again, equipped with all you’ve learned. “Harlem on My Mind” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art was that kind of show for me.

headline: 1965: Okinawa Visit Prompts Riot
text: NAHA, Okinawa — Nightlong leftist demonstrations tore this Pacific Island capital today and forced visiting Japanese Prime Minister Eisaku Sato to take refuge in a U.S. military camp. Mr. Sato came to emphasize Japanese ties with the Ryukyu Islands. Two thousand rioters fought with sticks and bottles against club-wielding, steel-helmeted police. Police said 17 demonstrators, mostly students and unionists, were hurt. The leftist mobs oppose Mr. Sato’s support of U.S. Vietnam policy, and his lukewarm position on reversion of Okinawa and the Ryukyu islands to Japan. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 20, 1965

headline: Hillary Clinton Asks to Have Donors Pay for Food and Drinks at Her Fund-Raisers
text: All those pigs-in-a-blanket can get pricey.

headline: Hard Climb Awaits Sebastian Coe, New President of I.A.A.F.
text: PARIS — If Sebastian Coe thinks beating Steve Ovett to the finish line or running a successful London Olympics was tough, he is now about to embark on something that looks a great deal more daunting.

headline: Watch Live: Trevor Noah on Race and Identity
text: Trevor Noah shares his perspectives on race and identity with John Eligon, a New York Times reporter, and an audience of students.

headline: Gun Laws Associated With Lower Suicide Rates
text: A new study has found that four gun laws are significantly associated with lower rates of firearm suicide.

headline: The Big Picture on the Mini-Movie in ‘Sinister 2’ and Others
text: Somewhere in an alternate universe, a multiplex is playing a curious slate of motion pictures: “The Dogwalker,” “Habeas Corpus,” “Mant!” and “Camp Bloodbath.” If you don’t recognize any of these titles, there’s a good reason: All of them are imaginary films that pop up in actual movies. We catch a glimpse of these fake flicks when characters watch them in “Trainwreck,” “The Player,” “Matinee” and “The Final Girls.”

headline: Carly Rae Jepsen Moves on From ‘Call Me Maybe’
text: Joe Coscarelli and Jon Caramanica discuss Ms. Jepsen’s new album on this week’s Popcast.

headline: Mexican Worker in Trump Hotel Criticizes Donald Trump’s Views, on Video
text: Ricardo Aca knew he could be fired. But he wanted the camera to roll anyway.

headline: In Clintons’ Town, a Call to Move a Prom Over Donald Trump’s Politics
text: First there was Univision and the beauty queens, then NBC, then the top chefs. Now, in the heart of Clintonland, another one of Donald J. Trump’s business interests is under pressure because of his remarks about Mexican immigrants: his Westchester County golf club, which hosts high school proms.

headline: David Ortiz Not an Easy Choice for the Hall of Fame
text: David Ortiz has often seemed like a giant among men. His larger-than-life personality, his reputation for significant home runs, his three World Series rings with Boston (after more than 80 years of Red Sox futility) and his nickname (Big Papi) have made him an integral part of baseball’s narrative over the last 13 seasons.

headline: Kasich Discusses His Record on Education
text: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio, a presidential candidate, attended a Republican summit meeting on education in New Hampshire on Wednesday.

headline: Mike Huckabee Misses the Point of Black Lives Matter
text: When dominant racial, ethnic or religious groups are challenged by minorities who still suffer from discrimination, intolerance, hatred and violence, those dominant groups sometimes respond by saying that everyone’s rights should be respected and that it breeds division to single out the treatment of specific groups.

headline: Verbatim: John Kasich Takes On Teachers’ Attitudes
text: — Gov. John Kasich of Ohio, a Republican presidential candidate, discussing fear-mongering done by teachers’ unions at an education forum in New Hampshire.

headline: No Suspension of Arguments as Tom Brady Case Becomes a Test of Wills
text: Tom Brady appeared to get the upper hand in his seven-month dispute with the N.F.L. on Wednesday when a judge peppered a lawyer for the league with questions at a hearing.

headline: Jared Fogle’s Guilty Plea
text: Mr. Fogle, who is best known as a Subway spokesman, pleaded guilty to “distributing and receiving visual depictions of minors engaging in sexually explicit conduct.”

headline: George Pataki, in Presidential Bid, Fights to Jog Voters’ Memories
text: WINDHAM, N.H. — As former Gov. George E. Pataki of New York strolled through the luncheon for seniors, bending his 6-foot-5 frame downward to make small talk over a soundtrack of square-dance music, he earned a rare smile of recognition. A retired high school teacher, Raymond Harmacinski, began to praise Mr. Pataki’s record when a note of uncertainty crept into his voice.

headline: Making the New East Village Old Again in ‘Ten Thousand Saints’
text: The East Village ain’t what it used to be. It’s a lament heard from many New Yorkers who knew the neighborhood in the 1980s, before gentrification replaced abandoned storefronts and artists’ squats with luxury condos and banks.

headline: Robert Menendez Offers Unrealistic Plan for Iran
text: It was disappointing, although not unexpected, that Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey, the senior Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, has declared his opposition to the Iran nuclear deal. He has been skeptical, bordering on hostile, from the start.

headline: La Monte Young Is Still Patiently Working on a Glacial Scale
text: “The question is, who decides what music should be?” the composer La Monte Young asked during a recent interview. “What is music, and why is it music, and how did music start?” Sitting in his cluttered loft in TriBeCa, Mr. Young had just been ruminating on the creation myths of Indian music, and continued on to briefly address marches, bagpipes and Dizzy Gillespie before arriving at the conclusion to this circuitous historical trajectory: his own Trio for Strings, from 1958.

headline: China’s Carbon Dioxide Emissions May Have Been Overstated by More Than 10%
text: HONG KONG — Scientists may have been overestimating China’s emissions of carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas driving global warming, by more than 10 percent, because of inaccurate assumptions about the country’s coal-burning, according to a study published on Wednesday.

headline: Chromebooks Gaining on iPads in School Sector
text: As school districts across the country increasingly invest in technology for their students, the volume of personal computers in the classroom is surging.

headline: Wall Street Journal Criticizes Iranian Reports on Its Reporter
text: The Wall Street Journal on Wednesday criticized what it described as false Iranian state media reports that accused the newspaper and one of its veteran correspondents of conspiring against Iran’s government.

headline: Jeb Bush Uses Caution on Dicey Subject of School Standards
text: Common Core is Jeb Bush’s Achilles’ heel when it comes to courting many conservatives, and on Wednesday the former Florida governor treaded carefully over the subject.

headline: How to Style Fall’s Victorian Look for 21st-Century Girls
text: If high-neck collars and loads of ruffles and black lace smack of period drama, consider that the Old World look is easily styled for this fall. Here’s how.

headline: Pastis Plans to Open in Gansevoort Market in 2017
text: Keith McNally’s crowd-pleasing brasserie-style restaurant Pastis, which anchored the meatpacking district from 1999 and closed last year because of building construction, has found a new home in the Gansevoort Market, a collection of stands selling foods that opened about a year ago at 52 Gansevoort Street, near the new Whitney Museum.

headline: Trump in a Box
text: As pundits are discovering to their horror, there’s probably more to the Trump phenomenon than mere celebrity. The fact is that the central planks of modern conservatism — slashing taxes on the rich and benefits for the public at large — are deeply unpopular. Republicans have won elections only by wrapping these policies in other stuff; it’s about cutting benefits for welfare queens and “strapping young bucks” (that’s a Reaganism, in case you’re wondering) buying T-bone steaks with food stamps. And this in turn means that there is a sort of empty box in U.S. politics waiting to be filled.

headline: Low-Income Housing Goals Set for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
text: The federal agency that regulates the mortgage finance companies Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac on Wednesday set goals for the next two years to nudge them to provide mortgages to more low-income borrowers and to landlords who offer low rents to poor people.

headline: Bill de Blasio Addresses ‘Outrageous’ Remarks by Donald Trump
text: Oil and water, meet de Blasio and Trump.

headline: Fed Minutes Show Caution in Discussion on Rates
text: WASHINGTON — Federal Reserve officials are struggling to get comfortable with the persistent sluggishness of price inflation as they move toward raising interest rates later this year.

headline: Soaring Along With the World’s Tallest Roller Coasters
text: I have been intrigued by roller coasters since riding the Mini Mine Train at Six Flags Over Texas as a child. What started out as a fear turned into a discovery and then a passion. These days, I regularly seek out the tallest, fastest and most innovative thrills at parks around the country.

headline: Crash in Southern New Jersey Kills Boy, 2, and Injures 3 Others
text: A car struck a young woman and a group of children on a road in southern New Jersey this week, killing a 2-year-old boy riding in a red wagon, the New Jersey State Police said.

headline: Health Officials Investigating Second Plague Case in California
text: For the second time this summer, health officials in California are investigating a case of plague that a camper most likely contracted while visiting Yosemite National Park.

headline: Germany Announces Plan to Cope with Migrant Influx
text: BERLIN — Germany expects as many as 800,000 asylum seekers or refugees this year, four times the number who came last year, Interior Minister Thomas de Maizière said on Wednesday in announcing new actions to cope with the biggest influx since the aftermath of World War II.

headline: App Smart | Golf Like a Pro
text: Apps can improve your golf game, from helping you understand the rules of the game to factoring the wind into a swing.

headline: Video Feature: Golfing Apps That Improve Play From Tee to Green
text: HERE’S a conversation topic for you and your golfing buddies as you kick back at the 19th hole on a summer’s evening and look back over your day on the course: all the apps that can help with your golfing game.

headline: Conquering Android’s Stagefright Bug
text: Conquering

headline: The Alternatives: Designers Subverting Fashion’s Status Quo
text: As high fashion becomes an increasingly commercial business, a group of rebellious young designers has emerged, challenging the unwritten codes of design, from gender stereotypes to what’s even considered clothing.

headline: Elisabeth Egan’s ‘A Window Opens’ Has Echoes of Her Amazon Odyssey
text: “I’m an oversharer,” Elisabeth Egan said before an interview had even begun.

headline: 36 Hours in Burlington
text: Burlington has long embodied the earthy progressivism and can-do independence that define the state’s spirit. Lately that ethos has taken on a sophisticated sheen.

headline: Social Security Benefits in Limbo for Some Same-Sex Couples
text: Same-sex couples may have won marriage equality, but some gay and lesbian individuals have been left wondering if their unions are still less than equal in the eyes of the government.

headline: 36 Hours in Burlington, Vermont
text: Burlington, home of the University of Vermont and the birthplace of Phish, Ben and Jerry’s and Seventh Generation, has long embodied the earthy progressivism and can-do independence that define the state’s spirit. Lately that ethos has taken on a sophisticated sheen, as chefs apply Vermont’s longtime obsession with local ingredients in exciting new directions. There are still plenty of Birkenstocks about; they’re just parked under tables spread with confit duck poutine, braised leek crepes and crisp, complex Vermont craft brews like Alchemist’s Heady Topper, a beer of near-mythic reputation among hops aficionados.

headline: In Girl’s Account, Rite at St. Paul’s Boarding School Turned Into Rape
text: CONCORD, N.H. — The 16-year-old girl sat on the witness stand, her hair pulled back. She tried to speak steadily as she told a jury about the night when a ritual at St. Paul’s — an elite boarding school here — turned into what she described as a shocking sexual assault.

headline: Louis Stokes, Congressman From Ohio and Champion of the Poor, Dies at 90
text: Louis Stokes, who as the first African-American congressman from Ohio helped focus federal attention on the nation’s poor and led a special House investigation into the assassinations of President John F. Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., died on Tuesday at his home in a Cleveland suburb. He was 90.

headline: In Bribery Law, a New Tool to Scrutinize Wall Street
text: If you want to succeed on Wall Street, you have to build relationships. So firms will do almost anything to please clients, catering to their wishes in the hope of winning the next underwriting assignment or new assets to manage.

headline: First Draft Focus: Striking Up the Band in New Hampshire
text: The Marching Lancers from Londonderry High School opened an education policy forum in Londonderry, N.H.

headline: Time Warner Promotes Priya Dogra to Deals Chief
text: Time Warner announced Wednesday that it had elevated Priya Dogra to lead the media conglomerate’s global deal activity as its new senior vice president for mergers and acquisitions.

headline: Scott Walker on His Education Reforms
text: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin defended his education reforms at a Republican education summit meeting in Londonderry, N.H.

headline: 2007 Case Against Kenyan Leader Is Under Scrutiny
text: PARIS — The failed case against President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya moved into the spotlight again on Wednesday when judges demanded a fresh inquiry into whether the Nairobi government obstructed access to crucial evidence against him.

headline: Jared Fogle Guilty in Child Sex Charges
text: Mr. Fogle, the former pitchman for Subway sandwich restaurants, pleaded guilty to sex acts with minors and to distributing child pornography.

headline: Food Matters
text: Lunch with the Four Horsemen’s family and friends.

headline: London Theater Journal: Maximally Minimal
text: LONDON – Even fictional holidays, it seems, are subject to shrinkage in these days of austerity measures and arts cuts, subjects much on the minds of pundits (and taxpayers and theatergoers) here. On my first night in London this summer, I found myself spending only “Three Days in the Country,” as opposed to the usual full month, at the National Theater.

headline: Kids in the Kitchen: Broiled Fish With Chermoula
text: The master plan? Raising children who can be independent in the kitchen, able to prepare a few healthy meals and snacks and with the confidence to tackle a new recipe or task. In our Kids in the Kitchen series, Motherlode’s KJ Dell’Antonia and Cooking’s Margaux Laskey move their very differently aged families toward that goal. Margaux finds ways for her 3-year-old and toddler to help cook, while KJ stands back and coaches her two 9-year-olds and her 11- and 14-year-olds in cooking on their own.

headline: Bobby Jindal on Louisiana Schools
text: Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana appeared at a Republican education summit to discuss reforms to the school systems in New Orleans and throughout the state.

headline: Glencore Tripped Up by Faith in Rational Markets
text: Glencore’s shtick has long been that it is the master of the commodity markets. It knows when to take risks, it can shift supply to where it’s most wanted and it tweaks its own mines to maximise profit. Or at least it can do all that when everyone else behaves rationally. That thinking has come unstuck, and the British-Swiss commodities trader’s earnings have gone with it. They halved in the first six months of 2015.

headline: How Trump Might Help Reform Conservatives
text: We haven’t been talking very much about intra-conservative policy debates since the G.O.P. primary campaign, and especially the Trump boom, began in earnest. Over at Bloomberg Politics, Peter Gosselin has a piece up quoting some members of my own “reform conservative” tribe expressing dismay at this, and particularly at the way that Trump is killing off serious policy arguments and turning the G.O.P. primary into an exercise in substance-free showmanship. “To one degree or another,” Gosselin writes, “virtually everyone in [the reformocon] circle of mostly 30-something conservatives interviewed in recent days expressed apprehension that the Republican contest could degenerate into the negative, policy-light brawl of four years ago, something party officials and policy advocates had sought to avoid.”

headline: ‘Simpsons’ Memorabilia to Be Auctioned From Sam Simon Collection
text: This fall ardent fans of “The Simpsons” can buy a Simpsons pinball machine at Sotheby’s. (Bart’s voice will berate you, “Hey, man, I’m an underachiever, too.” Homer’s taunts: “Don’t you know how to use the flippers?”)

headline: With an Eye on Fintech, Andreessen Horowitz Adds a New General Partner
text: The leaders of Andreessen Horowitz believe that experience is the best teacher. So the best venture capitalists are ones with first-hand experience founding companies, people who have “been through the war,” as Marc Andreessen puts it.

headline: Yankees’ Greg Bird Steps In for a Slugger and Breaks Into a Trot, Twice
text: When Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman made inquiries into acquiring a starting pitcher before the July 31 trading deadline, he told his counterparts on other teams that three prospects were off-limits: pitcher Luis Severino, outfielder Aaron Judge and first baseman Greg Bird.

headline: Tattoos on and off the Runway
text: Twelve models and their tattoos.

headline: Opening Statements in N.H. Rape Case
text: Lawyers for the prosecution and the defense made their opening statements in the trial of Owen Labrie, a graduate of the St. Paul’s School who is accused of raping a freshman girl.

headline: A Variety Show for the Apollo in the Hamptons
text: Captains of industry arrived in Maseratis and Porsches. The East Hampton lawn was filled with artworks by Robert Indiana, Anish Kapoor and Richard Serra. And celebrities like Christina Aguilera, Jamie Foxx and Jimmy Fallon were there not only as guests, but also as performers.

headline: Rare Sand Kittens Born in Israeli Zoo
text: A sand cat at the Ramat Gan Safari Park became pregnant after a mate was brought in from Sweden. The cats were previously considered extinct in Israel.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Thailand, North Korea and Elsewhere
text: France, Bulgaria, Thailand and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Vintage Looks at Morphew Offer Fresh Take on Fashion
text: “We’re every designer’s dirtiest secret,” said Jason Lyon, while sitting on a leather ottoman in the Midtown Manhattan showroom of Morphew, a vintage clothing archive for which he is a co-owner.

headline: August 19, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photographs from Thailand, North Korea, South Korea and France.

headline: Treasure Discovered From 1715 Shipwreck
text: A treasure-hunting crew found $4.5 million worth of gold coins off Florida’s coast in July. The site is known as the resting place of a fleet of Spanish ships that sank in a hurricane 300 years ago.

headline: A Hawaii Food Festival Goes Local
text: The fifth annual Hawaii Food & Wine Festival runs from Aug. 29 to Sept. 13 on the islands of Hawaii, Maui and Oahu.

headline: Two-Headed Calf Born in Peru
text: The rare calf was born in northern Peru on Tuesday at Edward Villegas Rubio’s stable in the country’s Cajamarca region.

headline: An Itsy Bitsy Teenie Bikini? This Year. Maybe Not.
text: It was almost a decade ago that Nora Ephron famously instructed “anyone young” to go put on a bikini and not take it off until age 34.

headline: Baby Boomers Ready to Sell Businesses to the Next Generation
text: Dan Bizzarro and Bill Jordan were still in college when they went to work at the Bimac Corporation, a castings manufacturer in Dayton, Ohio. After graduation, they joined full time as manufacturing and engineering executives. And eventually they teamed with a third employee to buy the business.

headline: Panti Bliss, the Accidental Activist of Ireland
text: How does a once-conservative Catholic country embrace not only equal rights for gays, but an outspoken H.I.V.-positive drag queen as a national icon?

headline: Ballet Life, Unfiltered and Uploaded to Instagram
text: Deformed toenails, eating disorders and backstabbing jealousy — that’s a quick survey of ballet stereotypes. But with Instagram, dancers have found a way to break through the tulle and tiaras by presenting backstage life on their terms.

headline: Home is Where the Work Takes Him
text: The Pioneer Works art space in Brooklyn has Gabriel Florenz tied up for the moment.

headline: Justice Dept. Presses Civil Rights Agenda in Local Courts
text: WASHINGTON — Burlington, Wash., was a small city fighting what seemed like a local lawsuit. Three poor people said that their public lawyers were too overworked to adequately represent them in municipal court cases. The dispute went mostly unnoticed for two years, until the Obama administration became involved.

headline: Ex-Executive Pleads Guilty in Toxic Spill in West Virginia
text: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — The former president of a company whose toxic chemical spill contaminated the drinking water of more than 300,000 people last year pleaded guilty Wednesday to environmental crimes.

headline: Review: The Battery Dance Festival Evokes Courtship Rituals Amid Flying Hats
text: The Battery Dance Festival, presented by the Battery Dance Company in Lower Manhattan for 34 years, has become known for its international roster. This year artists from India, Norway and Poland are among those appearing along the Hudson River — routinely backed by stunning, if blinding, sunsets — at Robert F. Wagner Jr. Park in Battery Park City.

headline: Review: At Mostly Mozart, Joshua Bell Plays a Rejiggered Bach Novelty
text: Increasingly, classical artists are realizing that audiences appreciate hearing performers speak about a piece they are about to play. Of course, the performer had better be personable and have something helpful to say.

headline: Review: ‘Everybody Rise,’ Stephanie Clifford’s Debut Novel, Features That Old-Money Scent
text: At an Ivy League varsity team dinner in a college dining hall, I was once chastised by a teammate for not passing the pepper along with the salt. The rule was familiar to me, but the insistence on it in these raucous surroundings surprised me. Oh, but that was just the point, said my Miss Manners; in her circle these rules mattered always and everywhere. Having nothing to do with actual courtesy or consideration, a ritual like this one was, it seemed to me, part of a code by which people were meant to recognize one another as belonging.

headline: Chris Christie on a Teaching Revolution
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey appeared at a Republican education summit meeting on Wednesday and said that if there were to be a revolution in teaching, the revolutionaries should be better armed.

headline: A Hoarder’s Tale of Redemption
text: Barry Yourgrau collects shopping bags and stationery from grand hotels, cocktail napkins and coasters from European cafes and more esoteric souvenirs like sponge shoe polishers, a calendar put out by Italian policemen, a tissue paper Day of the Dead banner tucked inside a Mexican newspaper, soccer club scarves. His girlfriend, Anya von Bremzen, is a food writer who travels half the year for her work and Mr. Yourgrau, a fiction writer and performer, accompanies her on all her trips, so he’s been able to feed his collection with a constant stream of new treasures.

headline: Martin O’Malley Calls Hillary Clinton Email Issue a ‘Huge Distraction’
text: Standing in front of a hotel emblazoned with Donald J. Trump’s name in Las Vegas, Martin O’Malley on Wednesday said that the constant questions about Hillary Rodham Clinton’s email use was a distraction for the entire Democratic Party.

headline: ‘Jane the Virgin’ Narrator on His Role and His Emmy Nomination
text: When nominations for this year’s Emmy Awards were announced in late July, CW’s “Jane the Virgin,” one of the most warmly received shows of the 2014-15 TV season, was nearly absent. Despite raves for its star Gina Rodriguez and expectations that it would vie for best comedy, the freshman series was the recipient of only a single nomination.

headline: Beyoncé Is Seen but Not Heard
text: The biggest Vogue of the year, the vaunted September issue (832 pages, four pounds, three ounces), is now on the stands. On its cover is arguably the biggest star of the moment, Beyoncé.

headline: The Artists Behind the Exhibitions
text: The Contemporary Arts Center and the New Orleans Museum of Art put on shows tied to Hurricane Katrina, 10 years after the storm.

headline: Ten Years After Katrina, New Orleans Museums Reckon With Recovery
text: NEW ORLEANS — How well do you remember the last days of August 10 years ago? Asked that question, a 23-year-old New Orleanian writes of seeing a dead alligator on the highway, having nowhere to sleep and crying every night. This anonymous recollection, printed neatly on a card, is part of a growing number pinned to the basement walls of the Ogden Museum of Southern Art here.

headline: Shopping Events and Sales Happening This Week in New York

Shoppers can enjoy free tailoring and the help of an Intermix stylist to pick the perfect pair of on-trend jeans, like very ’70s J Brand velvet kick flares ($298) and Frame high-waist denim trousers ($250). At 125 Fifth Avenue.

headline: The Instagram Archive of Celebrity Summers
text: Celebrities and fashion folk have been having a grand old summer this year. For those who don’t keep up by turning to the usual methods — tabloids, gossip websites and blogs — there’s Instagram, where many well-known users post personal photos from their adventures in locales near and far.

text: And how has your summer been so far?

headline: Russia Sentences Estonian to 15 Years in Disputed Spy Case
text: MOSCOW — A Russian court convicted an Estonian security police officer of espionage on Wednesday and sentenced him to 15 years of hard labor in a case highlighting tensions between Russia and its Baltic neighbors, which have escalated along with the conflict in Ukraine.

headline: Eli Manning Disputes Report That He Wants to Be N.F.L.’s Highest-Paid Player
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In a rare display of annoyance, Eli Manning on Wednesday disputed a report that he wanted to be the N.F.L.’s highest-paid player. Manning, who is negotiating a new contract with the Giants, said that neither he nor his agent had made such a demand.

headline: Researchers Link Longer Work Hours and Stroke Risk
text: People who work 55 hours or more per week have a 33 percent greater risk of stroke and a 13 percent greater risk of coronary heart disease than those working standard hours, researchers reported on Wednesday in the Lancet.

headline: Cornel West: The Fire of a New Generation
text: This is the 15th in a series of interviews on race that I am conducting for The Stone. This week’s discussion is with Cornel West, one of the most prominent and provocative intellectuals in public life. He is a professor of philosophy and Christian practice at Union Theological Seminary and professor emeritus at Princeton University. He is the author and editor of more than 30 books, including “Black Prophetic Fire” and “The Radical King.” — George Yancy

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Grandma’
text: Paul Weitz narrates a sequence from his film “Grandma,” featuring Lily Tomlin and Sam Elliott.

headline: Paul Weitz Narrates a Scene From ‘Grandma’
text: A woman visits an old flame to ask for a favor, and a fire burns. That’s the crux of this scene from “Grandma,” written and directed by Paul Weitz and featuring Lily Tomlin.

headline: Review: In ‘Grandma,’ Lily Tomlin Energizes an Intergenerational Road Trip
text: In need of cash — we’ll get to why in a minute — Elle Reid, a poet and sometime professor in her 70s, decides to sell some precious old books. She figures that even though they’re a bit worse for wear, her first editions of Betty Friedan and Simone de Beauvoir should fetch a few hundred dollars at the local feminist bookstore-cafe. Her outrage when she’s grudgingly offered a lot less than that compounds her dismay at her teenage granddaughter’s cluelessness about the authors of “The Feminine Mystique” and “The Second Sex.” What’s wrong with the world these days?

headline: The Icelandic Composer Anna Thorvaldsdottir, Searching for Beauty Amid Brokenness
text: Listening to a recent album of Icelandic music from the chamber ensemble Nordic Affect is a bit like driving across the country from which its composers hail: The terrain changes radically every few minutes, but a sense of the uncanny unifies the landscape. “Clockworking,” released last month on the Sono Luminus label, forms an absorbing and persuasively performed snapshot of Icelandic composition today. The album brims with compellingly quizzical sounds, from Thuridur Jonsdottir’s “INNI” — in which electronic samples of a babbling baby accompany a shimmering Baroque violin — to Hafdis Bjarnadottir’s “From Beacon to Beacon,” which draws on recordings made at lighthouses to create twitchy grooves.

headline: Russia’s Pitch to Vacationers: Crimea Is for Patriots
text: SAKI, Crimea — Tamara Tsetlayana stood on a narrow stretch of gray beach, rinsing off a thick layer of the black, ostensibly therapeutic mud that has drawn visitors to the salty lake here for more than a century.

headline: Lebanese Police Beat ‘You Stink’ Activists in Beirut
text: Simmering tensions between protesters and the authorities over Lebanon’s continuing trash crisis erupted into violence on Wednesday as the police used force on demonstrators rallying outside the seat of government in Beirut.

headline: Early Prison Release Delayed for Oscar Pistorius
text: South Africa’s justice minister on Wednesday intervened to delay the early release of Oscar Pistorius, the imprisoned Olympic athlete convicted of killing his girlfriend — 48 hours before he was scheduled to begin serving the rest of his five-year term under house arrest.

headline: Oil Companies Sit on Hands at Auction for Leases

headline: British Study Says Electronic Cigarettes Curb Smoking Risks
text: British health officials on Wednesday reported the results of a government-funded study concluding that the use of electronic cigarettes can reduce the health risks of smoking by 95 percent and may also help smokers quit the habit.

headline: Arkansas Governor Wants to Keep Medicaid Expansion, but With Changes

Asa Hutchinson of Arkansas on Wednesday told an advisory group weighing the future of the state’s alternative Medicaid expansion that he favored keeping it — but only if the federal government allowed changes that seemed intended to appeal to conservative legislators who continue to oppose the program.

headline: Jets Sign Matt Flynn, Adding Experience to Backups at Quarterback

headline: City Council Stands in Way of Carriage Horse Ban, de Blasio Tells Activists

headline: 3 Peacekeepers Accused of Rape in Central African Republic
text: UNITED NATIONS — In the latest in a series of sexual abuse allegations against United Nations peacekeepers in the Central African Republic, the families of two women and one girl under the age of 18 have accused three peacekeepers of rape, the United Nations announced Wednesday.

headline: Syria: Typhoid Threatens Refugees
text: A typhoid outbreak is threatening displaced Palestinian residents from the Yarmouk refugee camp outside Damascus, Syria, the United Nations reported Wednesday. Christopher Gunness, a spokesman for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, said that medical teams had confirmed six typhoid cases on Tuesday among Palestinians in the Yalda district near Yarmouk, and that five more cases had been confirmed on Wednesday. “We fear this is the tip of the iceberg,” Mr. Gunness said. The agency has been unable to gain access to Yarmouk since March 28, just before Islamic State militants seized control of part of it, but has been able to help some residents who have fled.

headline: The Ashley Madison Data Dump, Explained
text: The release of stolen data from Ashley Madison, a dating website marketed at would-be adulterers, promises to roil the marital lives of its members.

text: McDonald’s long ago went global. Lately, the anti-McDonald’s campaign has started following it around the world.

headline: Activists Confront Hillary Clinton
text: A newly released video from Good magazine, showing Hillary Clinton in a meeting being confronted by young activists from the Black Lives Matter movement, thrilled me to no end. It also depressed me just as much.

headline: G.O.P. Hopefuls Display Differences on Education

headline: Oh, the Stories He Could Tell
text: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic — Ever since Pedro Martinez entered the Baseball Hall of Fame in July, Emilio Cordova, the Dominican Republic’s most celebrated baseball historian, has been carrying copies of stat sheets with him all over town. On one side of the pages are Martinez’s career numbers; on the other are those of Juan Marichal, the country’s other legendary pitcher.

headline: Momentum Slipping Away in Iowa, Scott Walker Adopts a Trump-Like Stance
text: DES MOINES — On a three-day tour of Iowa after declaring his candidacy for president last month, Scott Walker wore the same rolled-sleeves uniform, told the same sports joke and answered questions with verbatim passages from his announcement speech, whether he was in Davenport, Cedar Rapids or Sioux City.

headline: Review: In Philip Ridley’s ‘Mercury Fur,’ It’s the World’s End, and the Party’s Here
text: Even those who binge on apocalyptic splatter movies are going to be rattled by “Mercury Fur,” Philip Ridley’s pitch-dark portrait of the day after tomorrow in the big city. Granted, this blistering production from the New Group, which opened on Wednesday night at the Pershing Square Signature Center, doesn’t have the big-screen special effects associated with cinematic gore fests about the end of the world.

headline: Gas Station Supply
text: THURSDAY PUZZLE — This may sound odd, but I have nostalgic feelings for the COMPRESSED AIR machines at gas stations. For most, reinflating one’s tires is a mundane chore, but for me, it’s a symbol of personal growth. Stay with me on this one.

He leaned against a wall and swung his legs.

headline: John Henry Holland, Who Computerized Evolution, Dies at 86
text: John Henry Holland, a computer scientist whose seminal work on genetic algorithms, or computer codes that mimic sexually reproducing organisms, proved crucial in the study of complex adaptive systems, a field he helped create, died on Aug. 9 at his home in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 86.

headline: What’s On TV Thursday
text: 10:50 A.M. (Starz) MR. TURNER (2014) A growling, sputtering Timothy Spall, above, stars as J. M. W. Turner (1775-1851), the man the Victorian critic John Ruskin called “the greatest painter of all time.” Mike Leigh’s biographical masterpiece juxtaposes the vexing genius of Turner’s later years and his ramshackle personal life. Turner the painter divined luminously stormy seascapes and placid river scenes that inspired the praise of critics and the envy of colleagues — until his work fell out of fashion. Turner the man lived with his father (Paul Jesson), copulated with his longtime housekeeper (Dorothy Atkinson) and ignored his daughters by his semi-estranged wife (Ruth Sheen) while keeping company with a kindhearted widow (Marion Bailey) whose last name he adopts. “ ‘Mr. Turner’ is a mighty work of critical imagination, a loving, unsentimental portrait of a rare creative soul,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of this Oscar nominee in cinematography, costume and production design, and original score. “But even as it celebrates a glorious painter and illuminates the sources of his pictures with startling clarity and insight, the movie patiently and thoroughly demolishes more than a century’s worth of mythology about what art is and how artists work.” He added, “It might be risking Ruskinesque folly to take ‘Mr. Turner’ as a self-portrait of its director, but Turner shares with Mr. Leigh an ability to travel the circuit between the sublime and the ordinary, to bring into view aspects of reality that had been somehow invisible in plain sight.”

headline: Rude Boy Style Can’t Fail
text: At the heyday of colonial conquest, Charles Baudelaire, the French poet and lover of the Haitian-born artist Jeanne Duval, wrote that “dandyism is a setting sun; like the declining star, it is magnificent, without heat and full of melancholy.” Diasporic Africans, whose bodies were reduced to mere commodities for centuries, have long used “stylin’ out” to subvert racial order, perform their identities far from a lost homeland, and “redefine blackness and cosmopolitanism,” as the historian Monica Miller noted in “Slaves to Fashion: Black Dandyism and the Styling of Black Diasporic Identity.”

headline: Mr. Cuomo Should Get on Board
text: After thousands of irate New Jersey commuters were again delayed in their morning commutes this week, Gov. Chris Christie finally got serious about doing something to help them. On Tuesday, the governor sat down with the secretary of transportation, Anthony Foxx, and a group of New Jersey officials to address what has become a major issue not only for commuters but also for the regional economy: the alarming deterioration of the existing rail tunnel under the Hudson River and the urgent need to build a new one.

headline: How Not to Think About Bears
text: Amicalola Falls State Park, Ga. — I’VE been vacationing in western North Carolina and northern Georgia since I was a kid. I arrive, marvel at the mountains and put on an unconvincing Southern drawl. In recent summers I’ve brought my own kids, too (picture tiny people saying “y’all” in a faintly French accent).

headline: What Donald Trump Could Learn From the Korean DMZ
text: Durham, N.C. — DONALD J. TRUMP has built much of his lead in the Republican primary race on his tough stance on immigration, the centerpiece of which is the demand that America wall off its border with Mexico to stanch the flow of “rapists” and other undesirables.

headline: Talking About the Death Penalty, Court to Court
text: The Connecticut Supreme Court could have taken an easy route to finding the state’s death penalty unconstitutional in the decision it issued last week. The State Legislature repealed the death penalty in 2012, but it made the repeal prospective, leaving 11 men on death row. The reason for the prospective-only repeal was obvious to all: Two of the death-row inmates, Joshua Komisarjevsky and Steven Hayes, had committed a horrific home-invasion triple murder that shocked the state in 2007, and the prospect of barring their execution was unpalatable to Connecticut politicians and many members of the public.

headline: G.O.P. Candidates Follow Trump to the Bottom on Immigration

headline: A Regulator’s Deal With Promontory Skirts a Big Problem
text: New York State’s Department of Financial Services announced this week that Promontory Financial Group, a top bank consultant, would pay $15 million to settle allegations that it purposely obscured evidence of wrongdoing it uncovered at Standard Chartered, the big British bank penalized for money laundering in 2012.

headline: When a River Runs Orange
text: Durango, Colo. — THE recent mining pollution spill in my corner of Colorado — La Plata County — is making national news for all the wrong reasons. Beyond the spill and its impact on everyone downstream, the underlying causes are far more worrisome and dangerous than just a mistake made by the Environmental Protection Agency.

headline: Abandoning the Work I Hated
text: I was the envy of my 30-something friends in Palo Alto, Calif. I had my own law office right on California Avenue. People charged with crimes handed me cash, in advance, over a big oak desk. Occasionally, I’d make a couple of grand in an afternoon.

headline: The Upper West Side for a Lifestyle Change
text: Gail Reiken Tuzman grew up in Canarsie, Brooklyn, but spent most of her adult life in Montclair, N.J. That’s where she and her husband reared their two sons, in a three-story four-bedroom colonial-style house.

headline: ‘Shadows of Sherwood: A Robyn Hoodlum Adventure,’ by Kekla Magoon
text: Modernizing legends can be a tricky business. One must find the resonance between ancient and contemporary, blending incongruous elements in a way that seems not only right but inevitable: telling the story of a founding father with hip-hop lyrics, as in “Hamilton,” or presenting the myth of Theseus in the milieu of reality television as in “The Hunger Games.” Kekla Magoon manages a similar feat of legerdemain in “Shadows of Sherwood,” her compelling reboot of the Robin Hood myth.

headline: In Kosovo, a Thirst for Progress, and Beer, Too
text: On weekends, Kosovo’s millennials dance to Smiths and New Order songs from the 1980s as if they were hearing them for the first time at the new Irish pub Miqt (facebook.com/MIQT.NET) in Pristina. The bar is by turns trendy and louche and hidden down one of the many bumpy, half-paved roads in Kosovo’s capital.

headline: ‘The Road Not Taken,’ by David Orr
text: David Orr has written the best popular explanation to date of the most popular poem in American history.

headline: In Indonesia, Many Islands and Many Faces
text: In the second grade, I spent many hours with a World Book Encyclopedia, an opaque projector and a vast stretch of butcher paper tacked to the classroom wall. My goal was to trace a map of Indonesia. It was for a report, which probably mentioned that Indonesia was the world’s fourth most-populous country and the one with the most Muslims, and that it was covered in rice paddies and exports oil. But what I remember was the map itself: There were so many islands that even a professional tracer would have found the job taxing.

headline: Crackdown in Niger Fails to Deter Migrant Smugglers

Lives last long enough now for the reality of change to be manifest. The world is not what it was when much of existence drifted by in a disconnected state and productivity had not taken a 24/7 hold.

text: Good Thursday morning. The debate over immigration continues to intensify on the campaign trail, but some Republicans are trying to keep things low-key. headline: Federal Intervention in Schools? It Happens Less Than Critics Think
text: Congress is entering final negotiations over the biggest piece of federal education legislation in over a decade. The House and Senate have both passed new versions of the No Child Left Behind Act of 2001, the controversial law that mandated standards, testing and accountability in public schools nationwide. In the coming weeks, lawmakers will try to forge a compromise that can pass the fractious House without drawing a veto from President Obama.

headline: Canadian Maple Syrup ‘Rebels’ Clash With Law
text: The scenic and narrow lane that leads to Robert Hodge’s sugar camp is surrounded by a cat’s cradle of plastic piping that draws sap from 12,000 trees. At the end of the lane, a ramshackle hut contains reverse osmosis pumps to concentrate the harvest. A stainless steel evaporator, about the size of a truck, finishes the conversion into maple syrup.

headline: Baseball’s Last Cuban Escapees
text: For foreign baseball players hoping to make it in America, just about every conceivable journey — the 1,300 miles from Venezuela, the 5,000 miles from Japan, the 7,000 miles from Australia — has been easier than the 90 short miles from Cuba. That trip, over the last 50 years, has involved almost mythic hardships: improvised rafts, drug lords, ransoms, death threats, forgery, machine guns on the high seas. And yet the Cuban players have come, drawn by the promise of freedom, glory and outrageous capitalist paydays.
