text: New data collected by Stericycle, a company that handles recalls for businesses, shows a sharp jump in the number of recalls of organic food products.

headline: R. L. Stine: By the Book
text: The author of the Goosebumps and Fear Street series avoids nonfiction: “I never read it. I hate anything real.”

headline: Minnesota Theaters Embrace New Leaders, and Others May Follow
text: MINNEAPOLIS — At about the same time that Joseph Haj, the new artistic director of the Guthrie Theater, was getting a first panoramic glimpse of the Mississippi River from his office last month, new leaders were settling into the long-occupied bosses’ chairs at a handful of other significant theaters in the Twin Cities.

headline: Review: ‘Fear the Walking Dead,’ a Show About a Plague’s Start (What Zombies?)
text: It’s either surprising or completely logical that “The Walking Dead” has become the most popular drama on television (by some measures) while also being one of the most unusual. The all-bets-are-off gore and violence made possible by its post-zombie-apocalypse scenario set it apart, of course. But even more distinctive are its dawdling rhythms, laconic performances and willingness to turn down the sound. Few shows, if any, are as quiet as “The Walking Dead.”

headline: A Barrier Breaker in the Steward’s Room
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — Erinn Higgins is a racetracker, and this is home. She is the daughter of a thoroughbred trainer and an exercise rider. Her childhood memories are of being lifted onto a pony on the backside of this historic racetrack and playing touch football outside the barn of the Hall of Fame trainer Allen Jerkens, who died in March.

headline: California Drought Is Made Worse by Global Warming, Scientists Say
text: Global warming caused by human emissions has most likely intensified the drought in California by 15 to 20 percent, scientists said on Thursday, warning that future dry spells in the state are almost certain to be worse than this one as the world continues to heat up.

headline: Times Regrets ‘Slave Mistress’ in Julian Bond’s Obituary
text: After Julian Bond’s death on Saturday, The Times published a lengthy and well-written obituary summing up the life and work of the civil rights champion. But many readers were bothered by a single sentence in the front-page article:

headline: Israel’s Other Existential Threat Comes From Within
text: It used to be said by some in Israel that “only the right can bring peace.” But the brave, pragmatic Zionist right of Menachem Begin is gone.

headline: Maker of Addyi, ‘Female Viagra’ Drug, Being Sold to Valeant for $1 Billion
text: Sprout Pharmaceuticals, which on Tuesday won regulatory approval for the first pill to aid a woman’s sex drive, will be acquired by Valeant Pharmaceuticals International for about $1 billion in cash.

headline: France and Britain to Unveil Calais Plan
text: The French interior minister, Bernard Cazeneuve, and the British home secretary, Theresa May, visited the Channel Tunnel site and are to announce measures later Thursday to stem the flow of migrants.

headline: Discussing Immigration, Donald Trump and Jeb Bush Use an Offensive Term
text: Donald J. Trump continues to overheat the Republican Party’s speech on immigration.

headline: Education at the Post Office
text: Dear Diary:

headline: The Ashley Madison Hack Shows We’re Too Dumb to Cheat
text: America. We used to bestride the world like a colossus, a leader among nations, smarter, faster, braver, more forward-thinking than our rivals. Once, we were great, inventive and nimble, always pressing fearlessly ahead in the name of progress. Eradicating polio, inventing the airplane, the chicken nugget, the music video. Going to the moon.

headline: Egyptians Adapt as Cairo Is Redefined by a String of Bomb Attacks
text: CAIRO — Neighbors are growing more suspicious of strangers asking questions or taking pictures. Blast walls and other barriers are crowding the streets. Commuters say they have grown accustomed to changing their routes to avoid traffic snarled by the inevitable security cordons after each new explosion.

headline: Gloria Steinem Marches On
text: A journalist from Ohio who once went undercover at Hugh Hefner’s Playboy Club for a story, Gloria Steinem emerged in the ’70s as the aviator-shaded face — and de facto voice — of the women’s movement. Her magazine, Ms., which she co-founded in 1971, was notable for being owned and operated entirely by women, and was one of the first mainstream publications to directly address the issues of reproductive rights and domestic violence. And while many of her detractors (Richard Nixon, Rush Limbaugh) have fallen by the wayside, Steinem remains relevant. Her forthcoming memoir, ‘‘My Life on the Road,’’ documents her travels as an activist, and, at 81, she is an icon for a new wave of celebrity feminists that includes Lena Dunham and Emma Watson. Here, a front-line look at Steinem’s legacy.

headline: New Concerns in Tianjin Blast After Dead Fish Are Found
text: TIANJIN, China — Officials grappling with the toxic fallout from a series of deadly explosions that rocked this northern port city last week found themselves struggling on Thursday to explain thousands of dead fish that washed up on a riverbank less than four miles away from the blast site.

headline: 3 Killed in Drive-By Shooting in Rochester
text: Three people were shot and killed after a basketball game at a Boys and Girls Club in Rochester late Wednesday night, according to the police.

headline: Daily Report: There’s No Tech News If There’s No Uber News
text: Uber, the ride-hailing service, has become one of the tech industry’s newsmakers of the moment. This week is no exception.

headline: Facts & Figures: Immigration Crackdown Actually Keeps Immigrants In
text: Increased border enforcement in recent decades has had the unintended effect of keeping unauthorized immigrants in the United States when they might otherwise have left, a recent study has found.

headline: Handball Courtship
text: It was all about the ball. And then it was all about each other, and the ball.

headline: He Carried Her Off the Handball Court, but Didn’t Quite Sweep Her Off Her Feet
text: The story of Albert and Dori began with a challenge match, a spectacle that became part first date, part first aid.

headline: 1940: Stocking-Tearless Seat Tested
text: The Board of Transportation has taken the first step toward eliminating the unspeakable feminine disaster of runs in stockings caused by frayed strands and slivers in the woven rattan covering of subway seats, it was learned yesterday [Aug. 20]. A new type of seat, made of spongy plastic material that cannot fray, has been installed experimentally on car 1,208 of the Independent subway, and if it proves successful it may be used in all new subway cars and installed in old cars whenever they are reconditioned. — New York Herald Tribune, August 21, 1940

headline: Daily News Sale Is Taken Off the Table by Zuckerman
text: After months of exploring a sale, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the owner of The Daily News in New York, has decided to keep the newspaper, he said in a memo to staff members on Thursday.

headline: From Papua to Bali, Beauty and Intimacy
text: Exploring the many islands and faces of Indonesia.

headline: Migrant Influx Prompts Macedonia, Britain and France to Increase Security
text: BERLIN — Europe’s migration crisis took on new dimensions Thursday as at least three countries announced added security measures to address the biggest movement of refugees and migrants seen here since the aftermath of World War II.

headline: Sinkhole Opens Up Again in Florida
text: Aerial footage from the Hillsborough County sheriff’s office in Seffner, Fla., revealed a sinkhole that had reopened in the spot where a man was killed by one in 2013.

headline: Verbatim: For George Bush, It’s 5 O’Clock Somewhere
text: — Jeb Bush on his father, former President George Bush, 91, who is slowly recovering from a broken vertebra after falling at his Maine home this summer.

headline: Carter Discusses Cancer Diagnosis
text: The former president Jimmy Carter publicly talked about his health at a news conference in Atlanta on Thursday, eight days after he said that he had cancer.

headline: Toné-Café
text: A Georgian feast emerges from a tiny takeout window near Gramercy Park.

headline: Toné-Café Brings Georgian Cuisine to Gramercy Park
text: In Georgian, supra is the word for both a feast and the tablecloth that vanishes under it, every inch colonized by dishes that only increase in number, hour after hour. (A proper supra may last three days.)

headline: ’Bama vs. Gators
text: BAY MINETTE, Ala. — When alligator season began last Thursday night in Alabama, those lucky enough to receive one of the state’s 260 prized hunting permits wondered if they might do what Mandy Stokes did last year. She and four others captured and killed the largest American alligator on record.

headline: Trump Hotel Goes Up, and His Latino Views Barely Raise Eyebrows
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — The Peruvian Nobel laureate Mario Vargas Llosa calls Donald J. Trump a “racist imbecile.” In Mexico, people are gleefully bashing Trump piñatas after his caustic remarks about Latino immigrants in the United States. In Guatemala, a liquor company is putting up posters of Mr. Trump using a term that, when translated charitably, describes him as a jackass.

headline: Doubt Is Raised Over Value of Surgery for Breast Lesion at Earliest Stage
text: As many as 60,000 American women each year are told they have a very early stage of breast cancer — Stage 0, as it is commonly known — a possible precursor to what could be a deadly tumor. And almost every one of the women has either a lumpectomy or a mastectomy, and often a double mastectomy, removing a healthy breast as well.

headline: What to Do This Weekend
text: Looking for something fun to do?

headline: The Rise and Fall of Shooting-Star Candidates
text: The G.O.P. presidential contest, barely a few weeks old, has been described in dizzying fashion. In Rolling Stone, Matt Taibbi called it “Western civilization’s very own car wreck.” Roger Simon, writing for Politico, described it as Donald Trump mooning America while the “Republican clown car” careens around the country with no driver. And in The New York Times, Ross Douthat hoped the “antics” would produce more than just “crazy cable-news entertainment.”

headline: Cafe Carlyle Kicks Off Season With Brian Stokes Mitchell
text: Café Carlyle, the venerable cabaret in the Carlyle Hotel, has announced its fall season. It starts on Sept. 15 with the Broadway baritone Brian Stokes Mitchell, who is returning to nightclub performance in an all-new show. His residency, through Sept. 26, will be his first appearance in the room.

headline: Inside The Times’ Political Coverage
text: Washington Bureau Chief and Political Editor Carolyn Ryan talks with Times Insider about the paper’s campaign coverage. Susan Lehman is host.

headline: A Beating in Boston, Said to Be Inspired by Donald Trump’s Immigrant Comments
text: After a Hispanic man was beaten Wednesday by two Boston men, one of whom told the police that he was inspired by Donald J. Trump’s anti-immigrant message, Mr. Trump told reporters that his supporters were “passionate.”

headline: Reporter Joins Reddit Conversation on Prison Beating
text: The article Michael Winerip and I wrote this week about the death of an inmate at Fishkill Correctional Facility had a huge following on social media. For a while on Tuesday it was the top item on the Reddit home page, which I’m told is a very big deal. It was another indication of how closely people pay attention to criminal justice issues these days.

headline: Wondering If I Hastened a Patient’s Death
text: In my outpatient exam room, we had arrived at that moment of silence that often marks the crossroads of unwelcome news and a difficult decision.

headline: Jamie Barton to Pinch-Hit at the Met in ‘Anna Bolena’
text: Jamie Barton, the acclaimed young mezzo-soprano, will return to the Metropolitan Opera in September as Giovanna Seymour in Donizetti’s “Anna Bolena,” the company announced Thursday.

headline: As Chase Utley Departs for Dodgers, a Look at the Phillies’ Fall
text: Not long ago, the Philadelphia Phillies were a formidable team. In 2008, they won their first World Series in 28 years and made the playoffs the next three seasons as well. They had power hitters, slick fielders and a strong rotation.

headline: Brooklyn Man Convicted of 2003 Murder of Fairfield Student Will Get a New Hearing
text: John Giuca, the Brooklyn man convicted of the 2003 murder of a college football player, will receive a hearing in which prosecutors and his lawyers can revisit the evidence in the case, a judge ruled Thursday.

headline: David Sweat, New York Prison Escapee, Is Arraigned
text: PLATTSBURGH, N.Y. — A New York prison escapee who was at the center of a three-week manhunt faced charges on Thursday in his first public appearance since his capture.

headline: Banksy’s Latest: ‘Dismaland’ Theme Park
text: LONDON — The graffiti artist Banksy has unveiled his latest exhibition, a haunted, anti-theme park called “Dismaland,” featuring his art and works by about 60 other artists.

headline: Alexis Tsipras, Greek Prime Minister, Calls for New Elections
text: ATHENS — Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece called Thursday for new national elections in a bid to consolidate his power and press ahead with the 86 billion euro bailout plan he agreed to with European creditors.

headline: Can Black Art Ever Escape the Politics of Race?
text: For 18 months, the writer Richard Wright, late of Harlem and Biloxi, Miss., lay sick, then convalescent, then sick again, then dying, in France, writing thousands of haiku. This lasted from 1959 to 1960, years of chaos and promise and growth around the world, especially in Africa, where nation after nation threw off its colonial oppressors.

headline: Thwarted in Russia, ‘Gross Indecency: The Three Trials of Oscar Wilde’ Will Be Read at a Benefit in New York
text: Efforts to stage a gay-themed play about Oscar Wilde in Moscow foundered in June on the Russian government’s hostility toward homosexuality and the use of foreign funds for artistic productions. Now, the New York-based theater company that was partnering in that project will hold a one-night-only, impressively cast benefit reading of the play in October in Manhattan to focus attention on what it calls Russia’s suppression of the rights of gays and lesbians.

headline: 1965: Auschwitz Judge Weeps
text: FRANKFURT — Twenty months to the day after it started, Germany’s marathon Auschwitz trial came to an end this afternoon in a highly emotional heart-gripping tone.

headline: David Bailey’s Latest Muse: a Tod’s Handbag
text: The prolific photographer David Bailey, known for capturing the likes of the Beatles and Andy Warhol in the ’60s, turned his lens recently to an inanimate subject: the classic leather Tod’s Cape Bag. “Tod’s asked me to imagine the bag in whatever way I wanted,” says Bailey, whose summer photo exhibition, “Stardust,” was sponsored by the Italian house. “For the first time in my career, a bag is the lead character in my work. It’s not a fashion shoot, and it’s not editorial. It’s really a portrait.” Above is an exclusive first look at one of Bailey’s images, which he says “show a woman’s intimate and profound connection with this very special object.” The rest will debut online at tods.com beginning Aug. 31.

headline: Uncertainty Looms Over The Undefeated, ESPN’s Site on Sports and Race
text: More than two years into the gestation of The Undefeated, ESPN’s website about sports and race, the site exists in digital limbo.

headline: Viewfinder
text: Markus Brunetti’s painstakingly assembled photos of sacred spaces.

headline: The Learning Network Offers Topical Crossword Puzzles For Students
text: SPECIAL POST — The Learning Network, a free blog about teaching and learning with The New York Times, has updated their student crosswords section. Teachers who have a subscription to the New York Times Crossword will enjoy sharing these topical puzzles, made by veteran Times constructor Frank Longo, with their students.

headline: Jeffrey Ubben Buys Minority Stake in United Talent Agency
text: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood’s third-largest talent agency has sold a minority stake to the activist hedge fund operator Jeffrey Ubben and will use the money for expansion, including the immediate acquisition of a music agency.

headline: Birmingham Bounce: Raising the Minimum Wage in the South
text: By a vote of 7 to 0 with one abstention, the city council of Birmingham, Ala. adopted a citywide minimum wage this week of $10.10 by 2017, with increases for inflation every year after that.

headline: Nail Salon Sweeps Continue as Violations Are Found in Queens
text: The four investigators holding clipboards and clad in navy New York State jerseys descended on Lyn’s Nail Salon I on Thursday morning. The owner, Andy No Tran, scrambled to show his papers, and stammered when explaining just how many employees he had.

headline: Overcoming Love Addiction: One Apple Martini at a Time
text: I appeared as a love addict on a live morning television talk show in Detroit in the late 1980s, when I was 28. The producer, whom I knew through my job as a New York City book publicist, arranged for me to fly out to be a guest, along with an author who had written a book on love addiction.

headline: An Ashley Madison Recession? Or an Ashley Madison Stimulus?
text: The revelation of who opened accounts on the Ashley Madison site for adulterers got the attention of curiousity seekers and suspicious spouses. Josh Barro and Justin Wolfers had a different impulse. They wondered whether a surge in marital trouble resulting from the Ashley Madison hack could hurt the economy — or even, surprisingly, make it grow faster.

headline: Two Sisters, Two Weddings, Too Much
text: My sister and I have both been in long-term relationships. She got engaged in February, and I in May. We are both planning weddings for next year. She picked her date, then I picked one two months before it. She is unhappy about this. She told me I should not get married within three months of her date, before or after, which blocks out six months of the year. But my fiancé and I want the time of year we chose. Shouldn’t more happy events make people happier?

headline: Female Soldiers in Combat
text: What factors should the secretary of defense consider in deciding which positions, if any, should be kept off limits to women in the military?

headline: Britain to Reopen Embassy in Iran, Nearly 4 Years After It Was Ransacked
text: LONDON — In a significant indication of warming Western relations with Iran after a deal limiting its nuclear program, Foreign Secretary Philip Hammond will reopen Britain’s embassy in Tehran, probably on Sunday, British officials said Thursday.

headline: Tesla Stations at Airbnb Locations
text: Airbnb and Tesla Motors are starting a partnership to bring Tesla car charging stations to 30 Airbnb properties along the West Coast in cities such as Los Angeles, Palm Springs and Healdsburg, Calif. Tesla has donated and installed the stations that are meant to give travelers freedom on their road trips, according to Chip Conley, head of global hospitality and strategy at Airbnb. “When considering accommodations, Tesla drivers are limited by how far they can get on their car’s battery charge, but this partnership alleviates that constraint,” he said.

headline: 1895: Churchill in Cuba
text: This feature looks at some of the earliest mentions of famous names or terms in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Leave a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: Escaped Prisoner Appears at Arraignment
text: David Sweat, an inmate who escaped in June, appeared in court on Thursday, charged with two counts of escape in the first degree, and one count of promoting prison contraband in the first degree.

headline: Painstakingly Assembled Images of Sacred Spaces
text: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: A Day in the Life | Neville Jacobs
text: Marc Jacobs’s bull terrier spends a day at the office, where he goes on set with the stylist Carlyne Cerf de Dudzeele and works out with his French bulldog pal Charlie.

headline: Accuser in St. Paul’s Rape Case Defends Account in Cross-Examination
text: CONCORD, N.H. — The day’s cross-examination began with questions about oral sex, emails and uncomfortable laughter.

headline: Marco Rubio Gives Hillary Clinton Staunch Challenge in Bellwether States, Poll Shows
text: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida could be the toughest Republican challenger for Hillary Rodham Clinton in three crucial swing states if the two were to face off in the general election, a new poll from Quinnipiac University has found.

headline: Hytner and Starr’s London Theater Company Chooses Site on the Thames for Its Home
text: LONDON — The London Theater Company — a commercial venture by Nicholas Hytner and Nick Starr, the former artistic director and executive director of the National Theater here —  will open in the spring of 2017 in a 900-seat venue on London’s south bank, the company announced Thursday.

headline: Who Is Marc Jacobs?
text: HI, I’M MARC,” says a smiling, shortish, muscular man in a very white shirt and black trousers with even whiter socks. He has a housekeeper (“This is Reisa”) and a personal chef (“This is Lauren”), but he answers the door of his West Village townhouse himself, at least when reporters come over. He looks 38 or 39 and is definitely Jewish, but maybe he could also be Greek. “I thought it was so strange this morning,” says Marc, who is not going to say anything stranger than the fact that he’s actually 52, “but Nick said, ‘I left you a folder with Sarah, a picture of Sarah,’ and I was like, ‘Why, so I wouldn’t let someone else in the building?’ But no, the press office just did it. They put a picture of you, and like, who you wrote for. Like, as if that would change anything.”

headline: Can You Spot the Mimic?
text: Many species in nature mimic other organisms or features of their environment. Can you figure out which is the original and which is the mimic?

headline: Evolving a Defense, Mimics Save Themselves
text: The Canadian tiger swallowtail caterpillar is a plump green creature that spends all its time munching leaves. It ought to be an easy meal for a bird, yet many birds pass it by.

headline: Neither Rain Nor Snow Nor Gloom of Night Stays Amazon Deliveries
text: The giant e-marketeer Amazon may not have delivery drones in the air yet, but it does have letter carriers from local post offices busy delivering its packages to customers. In an innovative venture into e-commerce by the hard-pressed United States Postal Service, letter carriers in major cities have been making deliveries since October not only of the usual Amazon products but also of fresh milk, eggs, fish and other perishable commodities as Amazon continues its insatiable spread into the nation’s commercial aisles.

headline: Universal Conquers the Box Office, Without a Superhero
text: “No capes.”

headline: Palestinian Ends Hunger Strike, and His Condition Improves
text: A Palestinian hunger striker whose deteriorating health has posed a challenge to Israel’s policy of indefinite incarceration has agreed to give up his fast, one of his lawyers said Thursday as doctors said his condition had improved significantly.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Raises Prospect of Removing Times Square Pedestrian Plazas
text: When New York City installed pedestrian plazas in Times Square six years ago, replacing traffic-choked streets with beach chairs and picnic tables, the move prompted civic controversy, late-night monologue jokes and, eventually, widespread praise as an influential innovation in urban design.

headline: London Theater Journal: A Nonstop Carnival of Culpability
text: LONDON – Wine was very much on the menu on the third night of my summer visit to this city. Not for me. (I’m still sticking to my anti-jetlag regimen of gallons of water and coffee.) But the juice of the grape was being extolled as absolutely essential to our daily diet at the Almeida Theater in Islington, where a riveting production of Euripides’s “Bakkhai” was hypnotizing a packed house.

headline: Jean-Marie Le Pen, Co-Founder of National Front, Is Ousted From French Far-Right Party
text: NANTERRE, France — Jean-Marie Le Pen, a co-founder of France’s far-right National Front, was expelled from the party on Thursday after he repeatedly angered its current leader, his daughter Marine, by reviving the party’s anti-Semitic past, which she is eager to shed.

headline: Once Voters Get the ‘Narrative,’ Jeb Bush Says, They’ll Turn to Him Over Donald Trump
text: KEENE, N.H. — The day after dueling New Hampshire town-hall-style meetings left Jeb Bush the recipient of snide attacks from Donald J. Trump, Mr. Bush offered some not-so-friendly fire of his own.

headline: Airstrikes Kill 43 Militants in Northwestern Pakistan, Military Says
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani military said Thursday that its ground troops had begun moving into Shawal, the last area in the North Waziristan tribal region to feel the force of the military’s offensive against militants.

headline: Exploring Assisi in Italy
text: A new kind of tourist is being drawn by the same mystical essence that more traditional religious pilgrims believe can be felt in the woods around Francis’ hometown.

headline: Bad Singing and Fire Eating: Actors on Their ‘Special Skills’
text: Look past the eyes, hair and height. Keep scanning down, after the college “Hamlet” and the regional “Little Shop of Horrors.” There, at the bottom of almost any actor’s résumé, in small letters, is a list of tricks that reads like an especially manic night at “The Ed Sullivan Show.” Acrobatics, martial arts, hula hoop: just some of the unusual and quirky kinds of expertise found under the category of Special Skills.

headline: Request for Grand Jury Records in Eric Garner Case Is Rejected
text: A Staten Island judge on Thursday rejected a request from the Civilian Complaint Review Board for grand jury records related to the case of Eric Garner, who died last year after a police officer used a chokehold while trying to arrest him on suspicion of selling loose cigarettes.

headline: Jeb Bush Cites Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio in Defending Birthright Citizenship
text: NEW LONDON, N.H. — Jeb Bush invoked the names of two rivals for the Republican presidential nomination as he waded into the debate over birthright citizenship and immigration on Thursday, saying that Senators Ted Cruz of Texas and Marco Rubio of Florida might not be able to run for president if some in the conservative wing of the Republican Party had their way.

headline: Coca-Cola to Disclose Its Spending on Research Into Soft Drinks and Health
text: Coca-Cola says it will begin disclosing its investments in scientific research and advocacy about the impact sugary soft drinks have on public health.

headline: Drought Brings Soul-Searching to California Winemaking
text: St. HELENA, Calif. — At the rustic Smith-Madrone Vineyards high up on Spring Mountain, nobody has been thinking about the drought, which has absorbed so much of the conversation about California this year.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Grandma’
text: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews “Grandma.”

headline: Seventeen Transgender Killings Contrast With Growing Visibility
text: The brutal death of a 36-year-old transgender woman in Kansas City, Mo., is the latest in what activists are calling an alarming rise in anti-transgender violence.

headline: Pictures of the Day: The United States and Elsewhere
text: The United States and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: August 20, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photographs from The United States, Indonesia, Egypt and Spain.

headline: Daughter-in-Law of Senator Skelos Is Arrested in Domestic Dispute on Long Island
text: The family of State Senator Dean G. Skelos, who was arrested on federal corruption charges in May with his son Adam, has some new legal troubles, though of a different order of magnitude.

headline: Top 15 Fantasy Football Running Backs
text: Jason and Justin Sablich, who provide fantasy football analysis for The New York Times, pick their 15 favorite running backs for 2015.

headline: Tracking a Rare Nautilus in Papua New Guinea
text: These ancient creatures with big shells are so good at hiding from researchers that they went decades without a definitive sighting.

headline: Investors Hope to Ride Swell of SoulCycle Fever in Coming I.P.O.
text: Early on a summer morning in Manhattan’s Upper East Side, dozens of mostly young, svelte women file into a quiet, candlelit studio where they mount gleaming stationary bikes. Soft clicks can be heard as they fasten their shoes to the pedals.

headline: Spokesman for Hillary Clinton Offers New Take on Email Issue
text: As Brian Fallon, Hillary Rodham Clinton’s press secretary, defended her on Wednesday during a conference call about her email use, he made a novel argument that got lost in the haze of questions.

headline: Recipes From the Four Horsemen’s One-Month Anniversary Staff Meal
text: Earlier this summer, at noon on what may have been the hottest day of the year, the buzzy new Brooklyn restaurant and wine bar the Four Horsemen hadn’t yet opened its doors for service — they usually serve from the late afternoon until late at night — but three tables had been pushed together and were being set for a feast. The restaurant, which debuted in June, is a collaboration between the consultant Justin Chearno and partners Randy Moon, Christina Topsoe and her husband, the musician James Murphy — who invited the rest of their staff and collaborators to celebrate something of a milestone: making it past the one-month mark and finally having a moment to breathe.

headline: Breast Cancer Treatment and D.C.I.S.: Answers to Questions About New Findings
text: Q. What is D.C.I.S.?

headline: HP Profit Falls in Last Report Before Company Splits
text: Hewlett-Packard said on Thursday that its profit fell 13 percent in the third quarter, a reminder of the grim challenges prompting a breakup of the company in the coming months.

headline: Greek Prime Minister Resigns
text: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece announced Thursday that he would resign after less than a year in office and that new elections would be called.

headline: Review: In ‘Guidance,’ a High School Counselor as a Rotten Role Model
text: “Stay out of the sun,” a doctor warns David (Pat Mills) early in “Guidance,” a ferociously black comedy about growing older without growing up. On the heels of a diagnosis of Stage 3 melanoma, David makes a beeline for the tanning salon, cigarette in hand. He’s not in shock, he’s in denial.

headline: ‘Royal Hawaiian Featherwork,’ a Glimpse at Island Splendors
text: Since at least the 15th century, collectors have competed for feathers sewn and glued onto fabrics, jewelry, fans and statues. New books and exhibitions have reunited widely scattered feathered objects made in Latin America and the Pacific islands, and growing archival evidence shows that the birds used for raw materials were treated relatively well — that is, plucked sustainably.

headline: A Rich Lode of American Ceramics Discoveries
text: The Industrial Revolution drove countless American ceramics workshops out of business. Traces of these wares, whether well-preserved porcelain cups or smashed storage jars, are inspiring lectures and exhibitions.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: Aaron Flint Jamison’s Craft of Technology
text: AARON FLINT JAMISON

headline: Review: ‘Portraiture Now,’ a Group Show of Latino Artists
text: ‘PORTRAITURE NOW’

headline: Cadillac Has New Boss, New Address and Big Plans
text: Can a South African-born former Audi executive, who recently spurned Japanese masters in Hong Kong, lead a Detroit luxury brand back to greatness — and from a new base in Manhattan?

headline: Review: ‘Empty House Casa Vazia’ Highlights Brazilian Artists
text: ‘EMPTY HOUSE CASA VAZIA’

headline: Review: Tamuna Sirbiladze Combines Art and Decoration at Half Gallery
text: TAMUNA SIRBILADZE

headline: FanFest, for Yankees Stalwarts of All Ages
text: The Yankees are taking over Little Italy. And not just on TV screens in bars and restaurants. Mulberry Street, from Canal to Broome Streets, will become a pop-up village for Yankees devotees as part of the annual FanFest, presented by the radio station WFAN.

headline: Podcast: Inside The Times’s Political Coverage
text: What presidential candidates warrant what kind of coverage?

headline: Review: Faile Mines the Dark Depths of Modern Youth With Two Exhibitions
text: The title of an exhibition by the two-artist team Faile at the Brooklyn Museum is certainly promising: “Savage/Sacred Young Minds.” Considering American society’s neurotic preoccupation with youth and the hugely profitable exploitation of that obsession by a vast array of commercial enterprises, it’s a potentially rich vein for imaginative mining. In recent decades, artists like Mike Kelley and Jim Shaw have fruitfully excavated the weird, dark side of adolescent consciousness to reveal its narcissism, hypersexuality, grandiosity, and penchants for magical thinking and instant gratification.

headline: First Draft Focus: Throwback Thursday, With Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter
text: Jimmy Carter and his wife, Rosalynn, on Nov. 2, 1976, the night he was elected president.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, Aug. 23 to 29, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, Aug. 23 to 29, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Coming Up Red
text: A 1908 exhibition series introduced the Cincinnati Reds to its first class of baseball players from Cuba, and the team has had an eye for the island’s talent ever since.

headline: Western Wildfires Consume Manpower and Acreage
text: CHELAN, Wash. — Firefighters often talk about wildfires as living things, each one different in its inherently dangerous behavior and fickle shifts of temper. They are so unpredictable that even a seemingly mundane part of the day — getting to the job — can turn deadly.

headline: Jets’ Reserve Lineman Suspended One Game
text: Oday Aboushi, a reserve offensive lineman for the Jets, was suspended one game for violating the N.F.L.’s substance-abuse policy and program. He was the second member of the team to receive a drug-related ban, joining Sheldon Richardson, who was docked four games after testing positive at least twice for marijuana.

headline: Review: In ‘Sinister 2,’ a Murderous Being Returns for More Mayhem
text: In “Sinister,” from 2012, a true-crime writer (Ethan Hawke) moved his family into a house that had been the site of a multiple murder. In the attic he discovered grainy home-movie-like films of other killings. He also met a pagan entity, Bughuul, who in whisking the souls of children to a nether realm, creates minions who do his homicidal bidding.

headline: Review: L.A. Dance Project’s Tale of Murder, Sprightly and With Sneakers
text: BECKET, Mass. — L.A. Dance Project came east to Jacob’s Pillow here on Wednesday with three works in tow and a new associate artistic director: the exceptional, recently retired Pacific Northwest Ballet principal Carla Körbes. The company’s Pillow performance also coincided with the final appearances of another esteemed dancer, Charlie Hodges, who served as the group’s rehearsal director.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Sinister 2’
text: The Times critic Andrew Webster reviews “Sinister 2.”

headline: Egon Bahr, Who Laid Groundwork for German Reunification, Dies at 93
text: Egon Bahr, a prominent Social Democrat whose efforts to improve West Germany’s relations with the Soviet bloc helped pave the way for German reunification 45 years after World War II, has died, the party announced on Thursday. He was 93.

headline: Credit Scores Are Rising, and Becoming More Visible
text: Consumers appear to be better these days at managing their use of credit: Average scores have reached new highs and delinquent payments have dropped.

headline: Afropunk Festival Brings Music, Dancing and Haute Street Fashion to Brooklyn
text: Eleven years in, Afropunk Fest, Brooklyn’s weekend-long blowout celebration of the diaspora of black music and culture, is more wide-ranging than ever. It’s now possible to imagine the skate kids and fashion bloggers who populate the scene coming with their parents to catch headliners including Grace Jones, Lenny Kravitz and Gary Clark Jr. Up-and-coming acts like Raury, rap stars (Danny Brown) and punkers (Death Grips) are also on the bill for the festival, with doors opening Saturday at noon at Commodore Barry Park in Fort Greene; expect food trucks, on-site mural painting, interactive art and a dance-friendly D.J. stage.

headline: Review: Kamasi Washington and the West Coast Get Down Are Blowing Through Town
text: WOODSTOCK, N.Y. — Kamasi Washington blew his tenor saxophone in heavy gusts — rangy and intemperate, or clipped and urgent — throughout the exultant sprawl of his concert at the Bearsville Theater here on Wednesday night. His sound assumed an almost tactile force in the room, an extension of his burly and stoic presence onstage. And yet that sound wasn’t the most impressive facet of the performance, which ran a little over two hours, with an intuitive, almost constant ebb and flow. What really drove the agenda was the smart, hurtling fury of Mr. Washington’s band, the West Coast Get Down, a Los Angeles demolition crew partway through its first tour. Among the remaining dates are two at the Blue Note in New York City, on Monday and Tuesday.

headline: Review: In ‘American Ultra,’ Jesse Eisenberg Is a Stoner and a Target
text: Some of the many, many promotional spots for “American Ultra” make it seem like more of a comedy than it is. That’s not said as a criticism, just a warning. If you go, expect a diverting summer action adventure with occasional laughs, not a diverting stoner comedy with occasional action.

headline: In His First New York Show in Five Years, Shepard Fairey Is Still Questioning Everything
text: On Sept. 18, the street artist Shepard Fairey will open his first solo show in New York since 2010’s “Mayday” — the suitably colossal closing exhibition at the now-defunct Deitch Projects. Fairey’s latest offering, a series of new mixed-media paintings titled “On Our Hands,” will serve as his inaugural exhibition at Jacob Lewis Gallery, effectively consummating a 10-year friendship between the artist and Mr. Lewis, the gallery’s owner and the first director of the influential Pace Prints in Chelsea. “Jacob looks at every aspect of what the artist is doing, not just the genre, the price or how in fashion you are,” notes Fairey from his studio in Los Angeles, where he continues to finalize the collection. “If you look at the other artists he’s worked with, whether it’s Ryan McGinness or How and Nosm, they’re the only people doing what they do.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘American Ultra’
text: The Times critic Neil Genzlinger reviews “American Ultra.”

headline: A German Artist Colony, Suspended in Time, Stakes a Place in the Contemporary Scene
text: “How large the eyes become here! They want at all times to possess the whole sky,” wrote the young poet Rainer Maria Rilke in 1900. He had just arrived at Worpswede, the fabled artist colony on a stretch of German moorland so flat it becomes almost round as the view curves along the earth’s surface with scarcely a foothill, mountain or other perpendicular obstruction in sight.

headline: Review: ‘Can I Go Now?,’ a Biography of the Hollywood Agent Sue Mengers
text: The biographer Brian Kellow, whose last subject was Pauline Kael, writes in “Can I Go Now?” that even he had doubts about whether the Hollywood agent Sue Mengers would make a good subject. The idea of doing a book about her came from his agent. And even allowing for any prejudices an agent might have about how interesting agents are, it was still a stretch. Ms. Mengers may have been the most glam, powerful, status-conscious, star-snuggling Hollywood power broker of the 1970s, but both she and her way of doing business had gone the way of the dinosaurs by the end of that decade. Now she is Sue Who? to the world at large.

headline: This Week’s Movies | August 21, 2015
text: The New York Times film critics review “American Ultra,” “Grandma” and “Sinister 2.”

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, Aug. 23 to 29, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Theater Listings for Aug. 21-27
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: One Wall, Two Germanys
text: Before the fall of the Berlin Wall, Rudi Meisel spent a decade photographing East and West Germany with a subtle take that made it hard sometimes to tell one side from the other.

headline: New Surge of MERS Infections Hits Saudi Arabia
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Saudi Arabia is facing a new surge in cases of Middle East respiratory syndrome, a viral disease that has infected more than 1,100 people and killed more than 480 in the kingdom since it appeared in 2012.

headline: Things to Do on Long Island, Aug. 23 to 29, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Migrants in Kos Inspire Both Hospitality and Anger in Greeks
text: KOS, Greece — Dawn was breaking over a beach near Kos harbor, and the first swimmers threaded their way between orange beach umbrellas into the sea.

headline: 2 Graduating Rangers, Aware of Their Burden
text: FORT BENNING, Ga. — First Lt. Shaye Haver, an Apache attack helicopter pilot who on Friday will be one of the first women to graduate from the Army’s elite Ranger School, wants to remain an aviator. But she takes away weighty lessons from her grueling Ranger training: “Your mind can take a whole lot more than your body,” she said.

headline: Classical & Opera Listings for Aug. 21-27
text: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for Aug. 21-27
text: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: A Place to Nap After Wine Tasting
text: Visitors to Italian vineyards are often treated to lavish wine-tastings, four-course lunches and, sometimes, a walk around 15th-century grounds. But soon after a big meal, one is faced with a challenge: How to drive back to the hotel? Now, three famous vineyards in Tuscany and Abruzzo have solved this quandary by opening hotel rooms — newly refurbished, and often little-advertised — on the vineyard grounds.

headline: Jazz Listings for Aug. 21-27
text: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: ‘Digging for Fire,’ a Comedy by Joe Swanberg
text: “Digging for Fire,” Joe Swanberg’s new feature is, like many of his previous movies, a case study in heterosexual ethics. Its scope is narrow and, the title notwithstanding, it plumbs no great depths. But like Mr. Swanberg’s “Drinking Buddies” and “Happy Christmas,” the film has an appealing honesty and an enjoyably low-key comic style.

headline: Nature’s Lesson on Understanding Ellsworth Kelly
text: Ellsworth Kelly, renowned maker of abstract, odd-shaped monochromatic paintings, has said that he developed his eye for color and form as a bird watcher when he was a child in rural New Jersey. You can see evidence of this history: in the indigo bunting blue of “Blue Panel I” from 1977; in the pointed angles, like crests on northern cardinals, of “Red-Orange Panel” from 1980; and in the snowy span, like egret wings, of “Memorial” from 1993. Or at least you can start to see it once you’ve come to grips with other, more obvious features of Mr. Kelly’s art: its radical simplicity, its merger of painting and sculpture, its romance with architecture, its contribution to the history of modernism. But all of this absorbing takes time, the way bird watching does.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
text: Good evening. Here’s the latest.

headline: Comedy Listings for Aug. 21-27
text: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: New York Police Sergeant Commits Suicide After Sex-Crime Charges
text: A New York police sergeant who was arrested this month on charges that he had sex with an underage girl he met online committed suicide on Thursday, the police said.

headline: Bronx Legionnaires’ Outbreak Is Over, Health Officials Say
text: New York City health officials on Thursday declared an outbreak of Legionnaires’ disease in the South Bronx officially over, saying that no new cases had been reported since Aug. 3.

headline: Movie Listings for Aug. 21-27
text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Review: Rupert Friend and Zachary Quinto in a Pas de Bullets, ‘Hitman: Agent 47’
text: Dumb as dirt and just as generic, “Hitman: Agent 47” trades brains for bullets and characters for windup toys. So it’s all the more shocking that honest-to-goodness actors like Zachary Quinto and Rupert Friend have signed on to play the film’s two leads; maybe the director, Aleksander Bach, told them they could have a lifetime supply of their smoking-hot suits.

headline: Dance Listings for Aug. 21-27
text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for Aug. 21-27
text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Spare Times for Aug. 21-27
text: Museums and Sites

headline: Spare Times for Children for Aug. 21-27
text: 239th Anniversary of the Battle of Brooklyn

headline: First Female Ranger School Graduates
text: First Lt. Shaye Haver and Capt. Kristen Griest attended a news conference alongside fellow students who will graduate from the Army’s grueling Ranger School.

headline: Judge Says Hillary Clinton Didn’t Follow Government Email Policies
text: A federal judge on Thursday said that Hillary Rodham Clinton did not comply with government policies in her exclusive use of a personal email account while she was secretary of state, challenging her longstanding position that she abided by the rules.

headline: ‘Force Majeure’ Explores Couples’ Expectations as Gender Roles Shift
text: The ever-shifting expectations of husbands and wives has rarely been explored with more depth than in the Swedish director Ruben Ostlund’s scalding, satirically edged 2014 film, “Force Majeure.” In this drama of marital disruption during a luxurious ski vacation in the French Alps, the fragile male ego is subjected to relentless microscopic examination.

headline: The Merode Altarpiece at the Cloisters Represents Time Immemorial
text: The Merode Altarpiece,  a triptych at the Cloisters, ranks among the world’s most beautiful paintings. Produced in the South Netherlands workshop of Robert Campin between 1427 and 1432, it’s also a time machine that shuttles the mind across millenniums while orchestrating a convergence of the natural and the supernatural.

headline: Review: ‘The Iron Ministry’ Uses Train Passengers to Tell China’s Story
text: If a pop culture web publication ever asked me to make a list of the most cinematic forms of transportation, the train would be at the top, probably followed by the horse. Car chases are cool and everything, but the very first publicly shown movie (at least according to legend) was about a train. Trains on film are both sublime and intimate: The camera can trace the muscular movement of railway cars across the land or venture inside to observe the complicated actions of people in motion.

headline: Vintage Sax Solo Improves With (Listener’s) Age
text: Charlie Parker, the matchless alto saxophonist and bebop exemplar, had few better days in a recording studio than March 28, 1946. He was in Hollywood, leading his first session under an exclusive contract with Dial Records. His handpicked sidemen included the well-seasoned tenor saxophonist Lucky Thompson and a young trumpeter named Miles Davis, and by the end of the date they had recorded several of Parker’s most canonical tracks, including “A Night in Tunisia” and “Yardbird Suite.”

headline: A Shakespeare for All Seasons
text: For many theatergoers, summer is the season of Shakespeare, in the way it’s the season of corn and tomatoes for those who want these foods fresh from the garden. Like such comestibles, Shakespeare can be devoured in hearty single sittings — and often alfresco — what with a crop of productions that present the theatrical equivalent of a jolly picnic. For New Yorkers, an abundance of movable feasts is available, from city parks and parking lots to more sylvan environs upstate. (On my August schedule: yet another “Hamlet,” this one starring Benedict Cumberbatch, in London.)

headline: Frederick Wiseman’s Documentaries Defy Straightforward Plot
text: The closer it hews to the conventions of journalism, the more documentary filmmaking becomes an art of compression and acceleration. You know the drill. A social problem is explored, a famous or obscure person’s life story is told, a historical episode is illuminated, in a familiar rhythm and pace. Talking-head interviews alternate with archival clips or re-enactments, all in the service of an argument or a plot. Usually it’s all over in about 90 minutes, and you take away a neat little package of outrage, empathy or enlightenment. Even long-form documentaries, like “The Jinx,” Andrew Jarecki’s mini-series on the alleged crimes of Robert Durst, follow this formula, in that they depend on the quickening of the viewer’s attention.

headline: Holding Off Emily Dickinson’s ‘Complete Poems’
text: I’m embarrassed by how long I resisted Emily Dickinson’s “Complete Poems,” and I’m struck by how much my copy means to me now. As a daft young punk I too often sought out reckless emotion and vulgar effects, the same way one sometimes wants, when callow and feckless, to date a person with obvious physical attributes. Dickinson’s famous line — “I’m nobody! Who are you?” — is not what you want to hear when you are younger than 30, or, in my delayed maturity, closer to 40. It should have helped, but did not, when one of my favorite high school English teachers, Donald Glancy, explained that you could sing nearly all of Dickinson’s verse to the tune of “The Yellow Rose of Texas.”

headline: Eliane Radigue, Mining Wisdom From 11th-Century Buddhism
text: I came pretty late to “Jetsun Mila,” by the French composer Eliane Radigue, but it may be one of those things a lot of people will feel fine about coming to pretty late. Turn it on, and it just keeps teaching.

headline: Awakening to the Joys of ‘The Sleeping Beauty’
text: At the age of 35, I tried counting. I found I’d seen the ballet “The Sleeping Beauty” 200 times. That was 1990, precisely a century after the composer Tchaikovsky and the choreographer Marius Petipa had first presented it in St. Petersburg. Since then, I’ve watched it on many more occasions — 10 so far in 2015 alone.

headline: Another Definition for Extended Play
text: I like a short show. A 90-minute play means more time to write, more time to relax, a chance to see my husband before he goes to sleep, no tedious intermission. But I also have a sneaking fondness for longer plays. Much, much, much longer ones.

headline: Mondrian’s Paintings and Their Pulsating Intricacy
text: The longer I look at Mondrian’s paintings, the more I see in them. This applies to lots of art, but I think Mondrian built real time into his paintings. They unfold with unusual deliberation in a semblance of symmetry and order that is actually precarious, even volatile. This is especially true of his mature works from the late 1920s to the early 1940s, with their tensile fusions of glowing white backgrounds, black scaffoldings and blocks of bright primaries. Everything about them, the tiniest decision, is evident and has visual repercussions.

headline: Revisiting ‘The X-Files,’ a Series Worth Another Watch
text: Television is not an art of slow contemplation. Watching it in real time is more or less a requirement. (My DVR offers slow-motion playback, which has its uses, but they’re not artistic.)

headline: ‘It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia’ Converts a Skeptic
text: For years I was put off by the unrelenting crudeness of the television comedy “It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia.” In 2011 I wrote a minute-by-minute comparison of its Season 7 premiere with the Season 3 premiere of another crass show, “Blue Mountain State,” assessing which was more vulgar. It was a tongue-in-cheek article, but the tsk-tsking undertone was undeniable.

headline: For Bruckner’s Seventh Symphony, a Long Delayed Appreciation
text: By the time I was a music major in college, with all the composers of the past competing for my attention, I had decided I could take a pass on Anton Bruckner. Many great artists, including the conductor Bruno Walter, whom I idolized, championed Bruckner (1824-1896) as a master Austrian symphonist. But from my impatient samplings of those symphonies, Bruckner struck me as a kind of ponderously monumental Brahms, or an inert and stretched-out Mahler.

headline: Running the Alps
text: A Swiss mountain guide crossed five 4,000-meter peaks in less than eight hours this month.

headline: Review: ‘Learning to Drive’ Charts a Culture-Bridging Friendship
text: Among the charms of “Learning to Drive,” a small, observant dual portrait of a New York book critic and her Indian-American driving instructor, are the detailed, lived-in performances of its stars, Patricia Clarkson and Ben Kingsley. The film belongs to a school of grown-up, low-drama two-handers, of which the most famous example is “Driving Miss Daisy,” but “Learning to Drive” isn’t half as sentimental. As this movie, directed by Isabel Coixet, tracks the deepening friendship between people from different cultures and backgrounds, it acquires an unforced metaphorical resonance.

headline: Kazakhstan’s Currency Plunges
text: MOSCOW — Kazakhstan’s currency, the tenge, plunged by about a quarter on Thursday after the central bank stopped managing the exchange rate, prompting fears that a wider emerging market currency rout could be coming.

headline: Review: Hapless Brothers and Their Lovers Intersect in ‘The Mend’
text: Funny, rugged and raw, “The Mend” fits its story together from rough patches in the lives of two nose-diving New York brothers. Mat (Josh Lucas) is a freeloader (and sometime jerk) who is thrown out of the house by his girlfriend, Andrea (Lucy Owen). The slow-burning Alan (Stephen Plunkett) is treading water with his girlfriend, Farrah (Mickey Sumner), and hopes to take a big step when they are on a planned trip together. Directing his first feature after some shorts, John Magary digs into his characters with fresh eyes and a sly sense of adventure.

headline: The Art of Slow
text: Cultural critics of The New York Times suggest works that reward long and leisurely contemplation.

headline: Writer’s Room: Jeanette Winterson
text: Inside the novelist’s rustic writing studio in Glouchestershire, England.

headline: ‘Female Viagra’ Poses Challenges for Buyer Valeant
text: Valeant Pharmaceuticals is popping a risky $1 billion libido pill.

headline: Review: ‘She’s Funny That Way’ Offers Tomfoolery Amid the Floodlights
text: If only the title of “She’s Funny That Way” were true, then maybe this creaky throwback padded with Hollywood names and fake accents could be forgiven its many failings. But there’s barely a whiz-bang punch line or smoothly executed setup to be found in a movie that longs to be a sparkling bedroom comedy and winds up a tortured, fizz-free farce.

headline: Gay Couples Are Eligible for Social Security Benefits, U.S. Decides
text: Same-sex married couples who were living in states that did not recognize their unions and who previously filed claims for Social Security benefits will be able to collect those payments, the government said on Thursday.

headline: Review of Saltbox Restaurant & Bar in Montauk, in the O’Murphy’s Pub Space
text: At first glance, Saltbox Restaurant & Bar in Montauk would seem to be an easy target for local skeptics.

headline: ‘Ornithology,’ From ‘The Complete Dial Modern Jazz Sessions’
text: A track including a tenor saxophone solo by Lucky Thompson.

headline: ‘Human Resources’: Reality TV About a Recycling Company
text: If viewers who tuned into the second season of the workplace reality show “Human Resources” on Pivot this month came away feeling vindicated for Tony Rossi, the new guy who proved himself on trivia night, or relieved for Dan Harris, the sales director who scored an important new account, Tom Szaky, their boss, wouldn’t mind.

headline: Jarryd Hayne, Australian Rugby Star, Gives 49ers a Needed Jolt of Optimism
text: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — For a franchise in need of distraction, the Australian Jarryd Hayne arrived just in time.

headline: New York Schools With Many Students Who Skipped Tests Won’t Lose Money
text: School districts will not be penalized for having large numbers of students refuse to sit for the New York State standardized tests this year, education officials said on Thursday, ending months of uncertainty over how they would respond to a growing antitesting movement.

headline: Review: Axia Taverna in Tenafly Is Home to Old-School Greek Dishes
text: The scene at Axia Taverna is so lively that it’s easy to forget that the mood in Greece — the country that inspired the restaurant’s cuisine and relaxed, joyous atmosphere — is probably more strained because of the current economic crisis. Everyone at Axia, including staff members, many of whom are from the Mediterranean country, seems to be in celebration mode. The crowds of regulars coming through the oversize wooden front door and the lively traditional music add to the energy.

headline: Brazil: House Speaker Is Charged
text: Prosecutors on Thursday filed corruption charges against Eduardo Cunha, the speaker of the lower house of Congress and one of Brazil’s most powerful political figures. Investigators said that Mr. Cunha, 56, a conservative evangelical Christian radio commentator who broke from President Dilma Rousseff’s governing coalition, was involved in a money-laundering operation that was part of a graft scheme at Petrobras, the national oil company. His problems intensified in July when a consultant for a Petrobras contractor testified that Mr. Cunha had solicited and accepted a $5 million bribe. Mr. Cunha says that he is innocent and that he will remain in his post. The Supreme Court will decide whether he will stand trial.

headline: The Painted Ladies of Times Square Are Part of an Old New York Tradition
text: One Saturday afternoon this past winter, when my family and I were having lunch at the Metropolitan Museum of Art during a ritual viewing of mummies and armor with our 5-year-old son, I noticed a young man a few tables away staring at us. He had a notebook and began to sketch; he drew intensely and quickly. I was flattered and vaguely unsettled; he looked like someone in a Todd Solondz movie perhaps up to something not entirely sane.

headline: Two New Cosby Accusers Step Forward in New York
text: Two new accusers came forward on Thursday to add their names to the list of women with allegations of drugging or sexual assault against the entertainer Bill Cosby. They spoke at a news conference in New York held by the lawyer Gloria Allred, who is representing more than 20 other Cosby accusers.

headline: Review: ‘Some Kind of Beautiful’ Stars Pierce Brosnan as a Serial Seducer
text: The execrable romantic comedy “Some Kind of Beautiful” is the kind of embarrassment a studio dumps into the market in August while hoping no one will notice. Directed by Tom Vaughan from a screenplay by Matthew Newman, this witless, offensively sexist farrago stars a flabby Pierce Brosnan as Richard Haig, a self-satisfied professor of English romantic poetry at Cambridge and a serial womanizer who sleeps with his students. When his latest girlfriend, Kate (Jessica Alba), an American, informs him she’s pregnant, he promptly throws up.

headline: George Houser, Freedom Rides Pioneer and a Founder of CORE, Dies at 99
text: The Rev. George M. Houser, a founder of the Congress of Racial Equality who was believed to be the last living member of the inaugural Freedom Ride — the volatile, sometimes violent bus trip through the South by a racially mixed group in 1947 — died on Wednesday in Santa Rosa, Calif. He was 99.

headline: The Scene of a Nail Salon Sweep
text: Investigators from a New York State task force went through nail salons checking for health, safety and wage violations.

headline: Review: In ‘Youth,’ Strains of Family and Country Fall on Brothers’ Shoulders
text: Yaki and Shaul Cooper, teenage siblings played by the brothers David and Eitan Cunio in the Israeli film “Youth” look almost identical but for the fact that the 18-year-old Yaki, the older of the two, has scruffy facial hair. Their bond is so primal that when embracing, they resemble wrestlers standing head-to-head before trying to throw each other to the floor. You have the eerie sense of observing two halves of a severed whole struggling to reunite and break apart at the same time.

headline: Review: A Despairing Librarian Is Ready to Check Out in ‘After Words’
text: In September, television viewers will have a chance to see Marcia Gay Harden play a brusque, decisive, rule-bending doctor in the new CBS drama “Code Black.” Anyone who wants to see her play more or less the polar opposite of that character is hereby referred to “After Words,” a romance novel of a movie featuring the world’s most stereotypical librarian.

headline: Review: ‘Being Evel’ Examines the Life of a Notorious Stuntman
text: There’s something fundamentally American about the stunt motorcyclist Evel Knievel, as this latest informative documentary by Daniel Junge (a director of the Oscar-winning “Saving Face”) demonstrates. Robert Craig Knievel (1938-2007) — police officers tired of his persistent minor offenses created his nickname when he was growing up in Butte, Mont. — was determined to transcend humble origins.

headline: Nelson Peltz Picks Up Seats on Sysco’s Board Days After Buying a Stake
text: Less than a week after emerging as a big investor in Sysco, the activist investor Nelson Peltz has gained seats on the food service company’s board.

headline: Review: In ‘The Boy,’ an Unnerving 9-Year-Old Makes His Move
text: There are engrossing elements in Craig William Macneill’s “The Boy,” the tale of a creepy motel (no, it’s not “Psycho”) and a child sociopath (no, not “The Bad Seed”). Building on their Sundance short “Henley,” Mr. Macneill and his co-screenwriter, Clay McLeod Chapman, have developed a feature stunning to behold if somewhat unpersuasive in narrative.

headline: In Letter, Obama Tells Congress U.S. Will Still Press Iran
text: WASHINGTON — In his most comprehensive effort to assure wavering Democrats, President Obama wrote in a letter to Congress that the United States would unilaterally maintain economic pressure and deploy military options if needed to deter Iranian aggression, both during and beyond the proposed nuclear accord.

headline: China Woes Send Stocks Into Tailspin
text: Stock markets around the world plummeted on Thursday, signaling that investors have not gotten over the shock of China’s devaluation last week and remain nervous about the health of the global economy.

headline: ‘Searching for Home,’ a Cross-Generational Look at Military Veterans
text: The oddest thing about “Searching for Home: Coming Back From War” is how often the military men interviewed talk about having been surprised that real war wasn’t like the movies. They make a Korean War veteran seem like a master of emotional distance and control when he sticks to real-life parallels in a speech about his memories.

headline: Frederick Payne, Decorated Fighter Ace in the Pacific, Dies at 104
text: Frederick Payne, a retired Marine Corps brigadier general who was honored for his exploits as a fighter pilot in the Pacific in World War II, died on Aug. 6 at his home in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 104 and the oldest of America’s surviving fighter aces.

headline: Dropping Mild Tone, Jeb Bush Assails Donald Trump as Leaning Democratic
text: KEENE, N.H. — After weeks of parrying Donald J. Trump’s derisive thrusts with elliptical, indirect and sparing responses, Jeb Bush aggressively attacked Mr. Trump here on Thursday, portraying him as a Democratic-leaning poseur in the Republican field and expressing confidence that voters would come to the same conclusion.

headline: Responding to Rocket Fire, Israeli Forces Carry Out Strikes in Syria

headline: U.N. Details Sexual Abuse Claims Against Troops
text: The United Nations disclosed new details on Thursday about a series of sexual abuse allegations against its peacekeepers in the Central African Republic, saying that nine of the 13 cases reported in the past year involved children as young as 11 and that no one had yet been convicted.

headline: B&H Dairy in the East Village Reopens After Months of Red Tape
text: At lunchtime Thursday, there wasn’t an empty stool or seat to be had at B&H Dairy, a venerable 400-square-foot restaurant in the East Village that survived the Second Avenue gas explosion in March but appeared doomed when it was bound and gagged in red tape. The place managed to reopen a few days ago, and everyone has come back. To go from the front door to the back, you had to walk sideways.

headline: Gas Line Explodes During Construction at a Manhattan High School
text: A gas line exploded during construction at John F. Kennedy High School in the Marble Hill section of Manhattan on Thursday night, critically injuring three workers and heavily damaging three floors, the authorities said.

headline: Concussion Deal Is Challenged in Court as Insufficient

headline: Trial of Testosterone Supplements Sought
text: The Food and Drug Administration called on Thursday for drug makers to conduct a clinical trial of testosterone products marketed to older men to combat diminished levels of the hormone. While marketers call the often-normal decrease “low T”; the F.D.A. calls it “age-related hypogonadism” and describes it as controversial. In a commentary in The New England Journal of Medicine, agency officials cited concerns over cardiovascular risks of testosterone treatment and suggested that the benefits claimed in ads are unsupported by substantial evidence. The supplements are approved by the F.D.A. for treating classic hypogonadism, which includes well-recognized medical conditions like testicular damage. But most men prescribed testosterone do not appear to have this condition, agency officials wrote, calling the trend troubling. To date, no randomized, controlled trials have been designed to evaluate cardiovascular outcomes in men taking supplemental testosterone.

headline: Seven Die as Planes Carrying Parachutists Collide Over Slovakia
text: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia — Two small planes collided over western Slovakia on Thursday, killing seven people, while 31 were able to parachute to safety.

headline: Military Prisons Considered for Guantánamo Detainees
text: Secretary of Defense Ashton Carter said on Thursday that the Obama administration was assessing two military bases that have prisons — Fort Leavenworth in Kansas and Joint Base Charleston in South Carolina — as possible places to bring detainees from the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. Since 2009, when the Obama administration first began trying to close the Guantánamo prison, the executive branch has studied the logistical capacity of several bases to handle such prisoners. President Obama wants to close Guantánamo Bay before he leaves office in January 2017. Of the 116 detainees remaining there, 52 are recommended for transfer if security conditions can be met in the receiving country. But even if all of those lower-level detainees can be resettled, the United States would be left with 64 prisoners who are not approved for release.

headline: What’s On TV Friday
text: 9 P.M. (13) NATIONAL GALLERY (2014) In his 39th documentary, Frederick Wiseman tours the National Gallery in London (above). Docents decode the work of Leonardo, Rembrandt and Turner; restorers use magnifying glasses, eyedroppers, scalpels and cotton swabs to repair a tiny chip in a painting; senior executives politely battle younger ones, who believe the museum is too stodgy; and connoisseurs discuss the underpinnings of masterpieces by Vermeer, Caravaggio, Titian, Velázquez, Pissarro and Rubens. Mr. Wiseman also makes the point that art is the story of human relationships — in labor, commerce, patronage and even the exploitation of bodies. “Mr. Wiseman’s touch is deft but light here, and the experience of watching ‘National Gallery’ is pleasurable and immersive because he’s a wonderful storyteller,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this three-hour movie. “It is also unexpectedly moving. Because his other great theme is how art speaks to us, one he brilliantly expresses in the relay of gazes that finds us looking at museumgoers looking at portraits that look right back — at artists, art lovers and moviegoers — even as Mr. Wiseman, that sly old master, looks at all of us in turn.”

headline: ‘Little Pink Pill’ for Women Comes With Risks

We will probably never know whether the agency made a purely scientific judgment or whether it was unduly influenced by a campaign, partly financed by the manufacturer and organized with the help of one of its consultants, to depict the agency as gender-biased for never having approved a drug to treat sexual dysfunction in women while approving numerous drugs for men.

headline: Putin vs. Parmesan
text: In the Soviet era, the political joke was the first line of defense against the machinery of repression. The jokes are cropping up again, many over Vladimir Putin’s zany crackdown on European flowers and food imports, like the satirical video “Death of a Parmesan,” in which the destruction of foreign cheeses becomes a ballad about a heroic military campaign. “This song is about the unusual stupidity of today’s Russia,” reads the caption.

headline: Can Our Transit System Get Any Worse?
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — THIS has been a tough season for commuters in the New York region: the Amtrak crash in May, trains stuck in Hudson River tunnels in June, subway service disrupted by never-ending summer construction. Still, more than 5.6 million people take the subway each weekday, the most since 1949; New Jersey Transit’s ridership into the city has risen 75 percent in the past 15 years, and Amtrak’s Northeast Corridor carried a record of nearly 12 million riders last year.

headline: ‘Beaux Arts’
text: It’s a delight to see the way that poems (and poets) engage in conversation with other works of art. Chana Bloch’s poem is layered in its ekphrastic references, not only to a painting but also to “Musée des Beaux Arts,” a poem by W.H. Auden that has long been one of my favorites. Echoing the language of Auden’s poem (“About suffering they were never wrong,/The Old Masters: how well they understood”), “Beaux Arts” extends the meditation on art, myth and the representation of human emotion.

headline: At Las Cabras in Santiago, Pedigree Is All
text: The fuente de soda is Chile’s particular take on the soda fountain, a culinary institution along the lines of the American diner — friendly, familiar, old-fashioned. You go to one to tuck your tie into your shirt and wolf down a churrasco completo (imagine a comically large hamburger, but made with sliced meat, mashed avocado, tomatoes and mayonnaise). Throw back a freshly made juice or a beer and you’re ready to get back to work.

headline: Kevyn Aucoin’s ‘Making Faces’
text: I was 14 when I discovered I have an oval face. I learned this from reading Kevyn Aucoin’s ‘‘Making Faces,’’ a glossy volume published in 1997 that quickly became a kind of sacred text among teenage girls. We all trekked to the Borders at Winrock mall in Albuquerque to buy a copy, using the savings we had built up by babysitting or halfheartedly frothing lattes for minimum wage. We lugged the book home (all 160 oversize pages of it) to commune in private with its thick, creamy paperstock full of wisdom about lip shapes, brow bleaching and false eyelashes. We propped it against the bathroom sink as we mashed our fingers into our cheekbones, feeling for deep bone structure. We pored over close-ups of celebrity pores, eager to claim affinity with the actress or supermodel whose skin most matched our own. The girls who learned from Aucoin that they had heart-­shaped faces let everyone at school know about it in the nasal braggadocio common to a certain breed of adolescent queen bee. They were special; the rest of us could only dream of possessing jawlines that ended in a point like valentines.

headline: Fairy Tales
text: Brad DeLong is searching for the origins of the phrase “confidence fairy”. I’m pretty sure — you can never be completely sure, because things can stick in your mind — that it was an original coinage on my part, a snappy way to characterize the deep implausibility of the Alesina-Ardagna stuff that was sweeping Brussels and other corridors of power in 2010. Since then, a lot of further evidence has come in — and all of it confirms the original critique.

headline: Paperback Row
text: WHAT IS VISIBLE, by Kimberly Elkins. (Twelve, $15.) As a young child in the 1830s, Laura Bridgman suffered a bout of scarlet fever that left her without sight, hearing, taste or smell. She rose to prominence after learning language, despite being both deaf and blind, at the institute that Annie Sullivan and Helen Keller would later attend. Her story is the basis of Elkins’s biographical novel, which imagines Bridgman’s inner life.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: EILEEN, by Ottessa Moshfegh. (Penguin Press, $25.95.) Through her fascinatingly twisted heroine, Moshfegh explores a woman’s relationship to her body — the disconnection, the cultural claims, the male prerogative.

headline: ‘Machines of Loving Grace,’ by John Markoff
text: Technologists rarely question technology in public. Yet last fall Tesla’s chief executive, Elon Musk, suggested we might need to regulate the development of artificial intelligence “just to make sure that we don’t do something very foolish.”

headline: ‘Everybody Rise,’ by Stephanie Clifford
text: A quarter-century ago, Harper’s published an essay by Tom Wolfe titled “Stalking the Billion-Footed Beast: A ­Literary Manifesto for the New Social Novel.” Wolfe, whose best seller “The Bonfire of the Vanities” had been published two years earlier, called for a revival of the sort of novel that emerged during the 19th century: realist fiction that was wide in its scope and accurate in its detail, grounded in the kind of reporting that journalistic nonfiction demands.

headline: ‘The Shape of the New,’ by Scott L. Montgomery and Daniel Chirot
text: The world has been horrified but also puzzled by the rise of ISIS. How does one comprehend its brutality and success? What is its likely path? In March 2015, The Atlantic offered an answer, in an analysis by Graeme Wood that quickly became the most widely read essay in the magazine’s 158-year history. Titled “What ISIS Really Wants,” it focused on the ideology that animates the group. Understand its ideas, Wood suggested, and you will understand the phenomenon and how to fight it. Many other, more polemical explanations of jihadi terrorism today — from Bill Maher to Sam Harris — also shine a spotlight on the ideas behind the mayhem.

headline: ‘Young Eliot,’ by Robert Crawford
text: In an unheroic age, T.S. Eliot was ­poetry’s ideal antihero. Shy, indecisive, gangly, he essayed the Parnassian heights not baroquely turbaned like a Byron but buttoned down and gray-flanneled like a Walter Mitty. By day, he was a Lloyds banker in “a four-piece suit,” as Virginia Woolf reportedly described him; by night, a visionary poet, whose lyric fragments harmonized with the malaise troubling Europe after World War I. The Scottish poet Robert Crawford’s assiduous “Young Eliot” follows “Tom” from his earliest poetic finger exercises to the “ineradicably insinuating music” of “The Waste Land” (1922), in which April cruelly breeds lilacs as well as a bramble of textual notes.

headline: ‘Palimpsest: A History of the Written Word,’ by Matthew Battles
text: When an author assigns himself the task of compiling “a history of the written word,” a reader is likely to wonder: How well written is it? “Palimpsest” is a serious, well-researched book. Matthew Battles evokes the flexibility of human consciousness and the ability of the written word to absorb and deploy new technologies even though, as he explains, writing has always had its supposed shallows, from “penny dreadfuls” to propaganda and pornography. However, “Palimpsest” puts up a dull defense of its subject. It’s elliptically organized and full of workmanlike, hackneyed prose. It’s a history of the written word, but it’s also a repository of literary missteps.

headline: ‘Faith Ed.,’ by Linda K. Wertheimer
text: What should you do in a house of worship of another faith? This is a question that vexes many who write about religion and many who do not. Should non-Jewish men don kipas in synagogues? Should non-Muslim women cover their heads in a mosque? Should non-Catholics kneel during Mass? When everyone at an evangelical church holds hands and prays, should I keep mine by my side? Does not participating imply rudeness or does it simply say, I respect your faith enough not to pretend I am a part of it?

headline: ‘We Believe the Children,’ by Richard Beck
text: In the summer of 1983, a California woman named Judy Johnson took her 3-year-old son Matthew to a hospital near her home in Manhattan Beach. She pointed the doctor’s attention to her child’s anus, which, she said, looked redder than it had that morning, before he had gone to his day care center.
