Whether out of genuine concern about foul play or to salve a worried mother, the doctor filed a suspected child abuse report. Johnson, who later received a diagnosis of paranoid schizophrenia, took her own suspicions to the police, who soon alerted parents whose children attended the McMartin Preschool to a possible abuser in their midst.

headline: Whose Side Are You On?
text: When I was 15, I was playing with my 2-year-old sister and our 19-month-old cousin by a fountain in Amherst, Mass. Someone smiled and said, “They’re yours?” and I was shocked. Even if I’d had them in middle school, it was mathematically impossible to have given birth to both of them.

headline: What Alexis Tsipras’s Announcement Means for Greece
text: A tumultuous summer in Greece could lead to an uncertain autumn as voters may have to decide who would best navigate the next phase of the country’s financial struggle.

headline: Inside the List
text: The Kings of Comedy: The director Judd Apatow began interviewing his comedy idols while still in high school. In “Sick in the Head,” No. 17 on the extended hardcover nonfiction list, he compiles almost 30 years of conversations with legends like Mel Brooks, Steve Martin, Jerry Seinfeld and Chris Rock into a master class of the form — of why people come to comedy (Roseanne Barr: “My dad wouldn’t hit me if I got him with humor right between the eyes”) and how to do it well (Amy Schumer: “The stuff you’re copping to and the saddest, worst moments of your life — that’s the stuff people connect to and ­appreciate”).

headline: 1940: Britain Bans Import of Notes
text: LONDON — Great Britain gave the economic screw another twist today by declaring worthless in the home market for the war’s duration the millions of pounds of British currency in non-sterling countries. Persons residing in the United States were given six days in which to cash into dollars whatever British currency they may hold, but the inhabitants of France and other European countries invaded by the Germans or living next door to them were allowed only a twenty-four-hour notice.

headline: Aging Extremist Laments Violence Now Used Against Palestinians
text: OFRA, West Bank — YEHUDA ETZION does not regret, exactly, helping plant bombs in the cars of Palestinian mayors and plotting to blow up the Dome of the Rock in the 1980s, nor does he express remorse. But he has reconsidered the role of violence in the quest for a Messianic kingdom of Israel, particularly as he contemplates a new generation of radicals he sees as bastardizing their shared ideology.

headline: The Very Bad Picture Book
text: Its colors are dull and it teaches an important lesson.

headline: Aggressive Treatment for Early Breast Cancer: Reporter’s Notebook
text: On Tuesday, I got an e-mail from JAMA Oncology, a leading medical journal, saying that it planned to publish a paper and editorial on ductal carcinoma in situ, or D.C.I.S., a condition that has become increasingly controversial over the years. As many as 60,000 women are told each year that they have it: tiny clusters of abnormal breast cells, confined to a milk duct and too small to be felt. It’s often called stage 0 cancer, and it almost never was detected before the early 1980s when mammograms came into widespread use.

headline: The Person Behind Those ‘Bad Lip Reading’ Videos Has a Favorite Politician (No, It’s Not Donald Trump.)
text: For years, an anonymous producer of “Bad Lip Reading,” a popular series of dubbed-over YouTube videos, has added absurdist humor to our already fairly absurd political process.

headline: What’s on This Week Around the World
text: Ruhr Region, Germany

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: ‘Hit Count,’ by Chris Lynch
text: It’s one thing when a novel about a meaningful subject gets published at a time when a media storm surrounding that subject is beginning to brew. But add to the mix an author who can really get the crosswinds blowing and there is truly cause to marvel. That’s the case with Chris Lynch’s “Hit Count,” a powerful story that illuminates both the dangers of head trauma in athletes and the psyche of football players.

headline: ‘What This Story Needs Is a Pig in a Wig,’ and More
text: A children’s books editor once asked me what kind of books were needed most in libraries. My immediate response was, “Beginning readers!” Then I had a question: Why aren’t there more available? The editor’s reply was just as fast: “Because they’re too hard to write.”

headline: ‘Mama’s Nightingale,’ by Edwidge Danticat, and More
text: Picture books have long been concerned with helping children transition to an unfamiliar place. A child’s first day in a new school or a family’s move to a different neighborhood are by now classic subjects. But since the dawn of the 21st century, with the number of immigrants in the United States continuing to increase markedly, children’s authors and publishers have begun to take on a far more challenging task — helping immigrant children settle into a new cultural environment, one that even their parents may find inexplicable. Since the principal obstacle to understanding a culture is, of course, the language that expresses it, language can loom large in these books; and a language divide is a concept difficult to express pictorially. Given all this, a child’s experience of immigration is a subject matter that requires some inventive tactics, as four new books ably demonstrate.

headline: A Gay Baseball Player, in Statistical Perspective
text: Until this week, no active baseball player associated with a Major League Baseball team had ever publicly come out as gay. David Denson, a prospect playing for the Helena Brewers in one of baseball’s rookie leagues, has finally ended that streak.

headline: Kevin Henkes’s ‘Waiting,’ and More
text: As both subjects and protagonists, animals seem to rule the world of children’s books, and it’s easy to see why. They are cute, recognizable and fun to imitate. They play a part in every child’s life, sometimes a big one. But what about the toys and tools children use every day? These make more occasional literary appearances — in, for instance, classics such as “Corduroy,” about a stuffed bear alone in a department store, or even “The Little Engine That Could,” with its dolls and small clown — but they really deserve to be more frequent stars. Children have immediate associations with their treasured belongings in a way they might not with, say, a capybara. Three new books, all by prominent picture book authors, artfully use worldly possessions to approach larger themes, to varying degrees of success.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York City:

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz: Coffee, Sugar and Sex Drive
text: Take the Quiz

headline: Banksy Opens ‘Dismaland’ Theme Park
text: The British graffiti artist Banksy, in collaboration with other artists, has opened what he calls a “bemusement park” near his hometown, Bristol.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: This week’s properties are co-ops in Chelsea, Midtown West and Midwood.

headline: Pyongyang Reacts to South’s Loudspeakers
text: A senior official from North Korea criticized the South’s use of loudspeakers to blare propaganda messages across the demilitarized zone, but the South Korean defense minister defended the broadcasts.

headline: Maggie Thrash’s ‘Honor Girl’
text: At the start of every summer session deep in the Kentucky Appalachians, Camp Bellflower celebrates one camper chosen to be the Honor Girl. She is the female ideal, representing the noble qualities the camp aims to foster in its generations of girls. Fifteen-year-old Maggie Thrash is a Bellflower veteran, an old hand at the hokey traditions of the camp. She doesn’t bat an eye at the candlelit Honor Girl ceremony, or the daily Civil War re-­enactments (which consist of two groups of girls screaming “GRAY!” and BLUE!” at each other). She has her friends, her ankle leash to keep from sleepwalking, her entire pleasantly familiar summer stretching out ahead of her. Until one fateful lice inspection by an older counselor triggers a romantic awakening, in the last location she would have chosen.

headline: Why Jeff Bezos Should Care More for Amazon’s Employees
text: Dear Jeff Bezos,

headline: House Tour | Scholten & Baijings
text: The Amsterdam-based designers Stefan Scholten and Carole Baijings invite T into their colorful home, which they describe as a living still life.

headline: Vague Disclosures by Highflying Mutual Funds May Put Investors in Peril
text: Desperate for richer yields on their portfolios, individual investors have thronged in recent years to mutual funds promising higher-than-usual income. The question is: Do these investors understand the higher-than-usual risks involved?

headline: Holly Holm, a Top Boxer, Will Be Ronda Rousey’s Next Opponent
text: The mixed martial arts superstar Ronda Rousey announced Friday that her next opponent would be Holly Holm on Jan. 2 in Las Vegas.

headline: Scholten & Baijings’s Bright Ideas
text: A husband-and-wife team is brightening up the sober Dutch design world.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
text: This week’s properties include a beach house in New Rochelle, N.Y., and Tudor in Fairfield, Conn.

headline: This Week’s Market Sell-Off May Not Be Such a Bad Thing
text: It has been a frantic week on Wall Street and in other financial centers, with stocks and other risky assets experiencing their worst week in years.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in the New York region:

headline: Review: ‘Becoming Dr. Ruth’ in Stony Point Is a Meditation on Home
text: Five countries, three husbands, four names. The one most people know her by, Dr. Ruth, has become synonymous with frank talk about sex, but in “Becoming Dr. Ruth,” the first-rate Mark St. Germain play now at Penguin Rep in Stony Point, sex is perhaps the least scintillating of the subjects under discussion. This 90-minute, one-woman show, set in 1997, finds our heroine, born Karola Ruth Siegel in 1928, preparing to move from the New York apartment she has shared with Fred Westheimer for 36 years.

headline: How the Social Mission of Ben & Jerry’s Survived Being Gobbled Up
text: Big food companies have an endless appetite for smaller brands that make local, organic and socially responsible products. Over the years, Danone acquired Stonyfield Farm yogurt, General Mills bought Annie’s Homegrown and Campbell Soup swallowed up Plum Organics.

headline: A Reunion Screening of ‘O Brother, Where Art Thou?’ and More at the New York Film Festival
text: All you men of constant sorrow can shed one less tear. The New York Film Festival will present a 15th anniversary screening of the Coen brothers comedy “O Brother, Where Art Thou?,” festival organizers announced today. In addition, the festival unveiled their special events lineup, which includes a screening of new work from Paul Thomas Anderson, the Holocaust drama “Son of Saul,” a documentary about Brian De Palma and a revival screening of his 1981 film “Blow Out.”

headline: On Edge
text: It was Cate Blanchett’s second time climbing the Sydney Harbour Bridge. She couldn’t really say why she wanted to do it, or what it is about heights that appeals to her. She has no interest in skydiving or bungee jumping or parachuting. She’s not especially sporty or athletic. It’s not thrills she likes; it’s control. She once drove her children to the edge of Mount Yasur, an active volcano on the island of Tanna.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
text: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: The ‘Flying Spaghetti Monster’
text: A team of BP drill workers discovered this deep sea creature off the coast of Angola.

headline: Bookshelf: Schooling
text: New picture books include “Music Class Today!” and “Dad’s First Day.”

headline: Carly Rae Jepsen Grows Up
text: With “Emotion,” the singer known best for “Call Me Maybe” embraces a seductive side to her music.

headline: Feeling the Bass Deep in His Body
text: Houzaifa Konditamdé, a native of Burkina Faso, became deaf at age 6, but that did not stop him from dancing. And dancing has helped him begun to carve out a niche since arriving in New York last year.

headline: Big Ticket | 42 West 71st Street
text: A five-story townhouse sold for $18,355,000 was the week’s second-largest residential real estate transaction.

headline: Bookshelf: By the Numbers
text: New picture books include “Two Mice” and “The Great and Mighty Nikko!”

headline: For $28 Million, Another Perch at One57
text: A sprawling aerie on the 67th floor of One57, Extell Development’s glassy-blue skyscraper, where the city’s priciest transaction for a single residence took place earlier this year, sold to an undisclosed buyer for $28,005,375 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Dr. Dre Apologizes to the ‘Women I’ve Hurt’
text: For Dr. Dre, this summer was meant to be a victory lap in a successful career. “Straight Outta Compton,” a biopic about his hip-hop group, N.W.A., topped the box office last week with a $56.1 million opening. “Compton,” his first album in 16 years, debuted at No. 2 on the Billboard chart. Last year, the music company that Dr. Dre helped establish, Beats, was sold to Apple for $3 billion, making him the self-proclaimed “first billionaire in hip-hop.”

headline: Winner Take Less? (In Music)
text: I very much liked Steven Johnson’s piece on the failure of the feared creative apocalypse to materialize. I do have a bone to pick, however: you do not write things like this:

headline: On Assignment: Exploding a Cherry Pie
text: New York Times staff photographer talks about his process photographing an exploding cherry pie for the May 21 cover of the Wealth and Finance section.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘NeuroTribes’
text: This week, Steve Silberman talks about “NeuroTribes” and autism; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Elisabeth Egan discusses “A Window Opens”; questions from readers; Maria Russo talks about the season’s children’s books; and Parul Sehgal has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘NeuroTribes’
text: This week, Steve Silberman, Elisabeth Egan and Maria Russo.

headline: Attracting Young, Diverse Mortgage Bankers
text: The Radius Financial Group, a mortgage lender in Norwell, Mass., recently made a $1 million investment in its future. The outlay wasn’t for technology, marketing or even office space. Rather, the company executives decided the future well-being of Radius depends upon its ability to attract younger employees from more diverse backgrounds.

headline: Track and Field Returns to Center Stage, as Do Doping Concerns
text: BEIJING — In less troubled times, the eve of the world track and field championships would have been all about the return of Usain Bolt and his sport to the Bird’s Nest.

headline: Popcast: Carly Rae Jepsen Grows Up
text: Carly Rae Jepsen arrived in the world like a hailstorm. Her song “Call Me Maybe” invaded from Canada in 2011 and by summer 2012, it had completed its assault on the country, a virus that infected America’s youth, its elderly, its sports teams and even its political leaders.

headline: A Deaf Dancer From Africa Makes a New Life in New York
text: Growing up in the small country of Burkina Faso in West Africa, Houzaifa Konditamdé could not hear. But that did not stop him from dancing.

headline: The Matisse of Mufflers
text: Lenny Prince sculpts objects far more elaborate than the usual stick figures fashioned from car parts that one sees outside some muffler shops.

headline: The Time Is Right to Make Tomato Sauce
text: Tomatoes are now at their ripest and reddest, just right for a batch of fresh tomato sauce.

headline: Into the Teeth of the Storm
text: Walter Baranger, senior editor for news operations, shares photos from his time coordinating The Times’s Hurricane Katrina coverage 10 years ago.

headline: The Companies That May Be the Next 50 Start-Up Unicorns
text: It used to be a rare thing when start-ups were valued at $1 billion or more by their investors. Now it’s become so common that there are at least 131 start-ups boasting such valuations and a term — “unicorns” — to refer to the companies.

headline: 1890: Panic on Wall Street
text: This has been the most exciting day Wall Street has seen since the assassination of President Garfield. The stringency in the money market reached such a degree that it precipitated a panic among borrowers and carried the rate of call loans to nearly 190 per cent, the highest rate on record since the chaos resulting from the tragedy of ’81. The demand for funds at this anomalous rate of per cent per day, in addition to the regular rate of interest, cannot honestly be attributed to mere bear manipulation. The eagerness with which long stock was thrown on the market fully attested to the general need for money that prevails in Wall Street. While Wall Street was howling, stocks were tumbling out of sight. The threatened state of affairs on the Vanderbilt railroad system did not improve matters. Heavy liquidation in the entire group was one of the first conspicuous features of the session. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 22, 1890

headline: Challenging Mayor de Blasio Over Times Square Plazas
text: It was bad enough when the New York City police commissioner, William J. Bratton, reacting to tabloid headlines about topless women and costumed panhandlers in Times Square, suggested digging up the pedestrian plazas. That brought back memories of the 1980s, when New York officials refused to install benches in some city parks because they couldn’t figure out how to manage public space.

headline: A Staten Island Mechanic Turns Tailpipes Into Artwork
text: “No one can teach you to be an artist,” Lenny Prince likes to say. “The mufflers themselves trained me.”

headline: Doctors Behaving Badly
text: What really goes on in an operating room?

headline: Mistrial for Charlotte Police Officer in Death of Unarmed Black Man
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — After nearly four days of jury deliberations, a judge declared a mistrial on Friday in the trial of a white Charlotte police officer who killed an unarmed black man almost two years ago.

headline: In ‘Hombre’ and ‘Kid Blue,’ the Antiheroes Wear Stetsons and Ride Tall on a Rebellion Frontier
text: From the advent of the Cold War to the fall of Saigon, no American movie genre was more relevant than the western, with its allegorical echoes of race, crime, conquest and American exceptionalism.

headline: Restaurant Reviews: Little Drunken Chef in Mount Kisco and Little Mumbai Market in Pleasantville
text: There are already a lot of “Little” restaurants in Mount Kisco, but there was still room for one more.

headline: Usain Bolt vs. Justin Gatlin: Showdowns Await in Sprints
text: For years, one of the few certainties at major international track meets was that Usain Bolt would outsprint everyone.

headline: Groups Press Hillary Clinton on Protecting Social Security
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton pleased progressives this week when she came out in opposition against drilling in the Arctic Ocean. Now they want to hear from her on Social Security.

headline: The Film Fatales Collective Trains a Lens on Gender Inequality
text: Hollywood’s prehistoric attitude toward female directors, the filmmaker Leah Meyerhoff said, was epitomized by the recent “Jurassic World.”

headline: Restaurant Review: Lithos in Darien Is Built on a Greek Tradition
text: Lithos may sound like a Greek island in the Aegean or Ionian seas, or maybe one of the less Trumpian of the gods on Mount Olympus, but not so.

headline: A Hofstra Museum Exhibition Offers Views of the Past Through a Softer Light
text: Even though all the art works in “Enduring Images,” an exhibition at Hofstra University in Hempstead, address themes like war, genocide, oppression and natural disasters, several of the paintings, prints and drawings use pastels or bright colors to illuminate the dark subject matter.

headline: The (Other) Sounds of Summer: Musical Scenes That Make Movies Sizzle
text: Savvy filmmakers know that when their releases are scheduled during the summer, it helps to include a musical sequence or set piece. This year, “Trainwreck” took appropriate precautions, with a cheerleader-dance finale set to a medley that included 2 Unlimited’s “Get Ready for This” (known for its appearance in “Space Jam”) and Billy Joel’s resilient “Uptown Girl.” It’s part of a long tradition — “Are you ready for the summer?” a chorus of excited children once inquired in Ivan Reitman’s sunbaked 1979 masterpiece, “Meatballs.” Here are a few highlights that have helped make hits and cultural milestones of hot-weather fare through the years.

headline: Facts & Figures: Carly Fiorina on Vaccines
text: Last week, Carly Fiorina said that school districts should be able to deny admission to children who haven’t been vaccinated against “highly communicable diseases.” But, she added, “when we’re talking about some of these more esoteric immunizations, then I think absolutely a parent should have a choice and a school district shouldn’t be able to say, ‘sorry, your kid can’t come to school’ for a disease that’s not communicable, that’s not contagious, and where there really isn’t any proof that they’re necessary at this point.”

headline: Fafsa Follies: To Gain a Student, Eliminate a Form
text: Many smart students forgo college in the mistaken belief that they cannot afford it. The financial aid system, which is intended to increase opportunities for low-income students, is largely to blame.

headline: London Theater Journal: Inside, Vodka and Stilettos; Outside, the Revolution
text: LONDON – Is it possible to achieve a contact high from alcohol? If so, I should be reeling. Strong drink is flowing freely – and damagingly – on this city’s stages. The night after I saw the Almeida Theater’s wine-soaked production of Euripides’ “Bakkhai,” I spent an evening at the Donmar Warehouse with four mutually contemptuous women who kept filling shot glasses with undiluted vodka.

headline: A Deadly Sin at the Aldrich, From the Comfort of an Armchair
text: Strollers along Main Street in Ridgefield, Conn., will encounter a curious signpost planted in front of the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum. Each of its prongs is inscribed with one of the seven deadly sins followed by mileage information. Six aim westward: Lust, Gluttony, Greed, Wrath, Envy and Pride. The other points east, directly at the museum. It reads “Sloth 0.01 miles.”

headline: Study Finds Surprising Byproduct of Middle Eastern Conflicts: Cleaner Air
text: Civil unrest and humanitarian crises can now be detected from space — because of, somewhat surprisingly, cleaner air.

headline: Classification Follies
text: The Clinton email “scandal” goes on — still no sign that she broke any rules, no sign that she sent or received anything labeled “classified”, but she may have received and even forwarded items that were later classified or “should” have been classified. By normal human standards this is a big nothing; but Clinton Rules apply, under which malign behavior is the default assumption and where there’s smoke there must be fire even if everyone knows that the usual suspects are operating big smoke machines. How many people still think that there really was a Whitewater scandal, or for that matter that Hillary is the subject of a criminal investigation?

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Caitlin Moran
text: For his new bookshop installation, One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next installment in the series comes from Caitlin Moran, the comedian and author, who shares her picks exclusively with T.

headline: Enthusiastic Crowd Will Greet Donald Trump in Alabama Stadium
text: MOBILE, Ala. – By midday Friday, with the temperature in the high 80s, Keith Quackenbush and Bill Hart decided it was time to buy an $89 pop-up tent from a nearby Walmart. It was how, they said, they were going to endure the wait outside a football stadium ahead of an appearance by Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential candidate.

headline: Silent Beyoncé, a Bloomingdale’s Blunder and Lagerfeld’s Eye
text: Plus, Cookie at Saks, Dolce’s soul searching and more from the week in style.

headline: Tianjin Blasts Expose the Dangerous Proximity of Toxic Chemicals in China
text: The warehouse in Tianjin that exploded was just one of many buildings across China that store toxic chemicals near residential areas.

headline: Rafael Nadal Accepts Another Early Loss, but Looks Ahead
text: MASON, Ohio — It used to be that Rafael Nadal’s crashing out of a tournament in an early round would prompt the biggest headlines in tennis. But in a year in which Nadal has consistently fallen short of the high standard he has set for himself, each subsequent loss seems less newsworthy.

headline: The Writer's Room
text: Under the canopy of a tree, near a closet full of sweets, with the ghost of a famous painter, six authors on the spaces where they work.

headline: Have You Cut the Cable Cord?
text: Friday morning’s editorial on the growing number of Americans who are giving up cable- and satellite-TV service resonated with many readers. A number of them said in comments on the piece and on Facebook and Twitter that they, too, had happily given up cable.

headline: President Erdogan of Turkey to Call for New Election
text: ISTANBUL — President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey said on Friday that he would call a snap election for Nov. 1 to break the impasse among the country’s four main political parties, an impasse that opponents say is partly of his own making.

headline: Pension Advisers Learn the Folly of Trying to Beat the Market
text: CARSON CITY, Nev. — The Carson Nugget casino takes up the better part of a downtown block in this state capital, and a sign on the side beckons bettors with a promise of “Extremely Loose Slots.”

headline: Jacob deGrom, a Met Known for His Hair, May (Gasp!) Cut It
text: Just before each spring training, Jacob deGrom has his hair cut in the kitchen of his parents’ house in DeLand, Fla. His older sister, Jessica, a former hairdresser, styles it. The whole scene has become something of an event for the deGroms. They find it funny to watch a major league pitcher squirm.

headline: Unseen Burdens in Chrome That Can Lead a Mac to Lag
text: Q. I noticed my Mac was acting a little sluggish. When I opened the OS X system monitor to see what was going on, I found all these things called “Google Chrome Helper” listed. Is that a legitimate piece of software?

headline: A Lawyer Quit Her Job to Start a Climate Museum in New York
text: Miranda Massie may not be the most obvious candidate to create a museum in New York City devoted to the subject of climate change. As a child growing up in the Hudson Valley in the 1970s, she rebelled against her father’s early efforts at recycling. Later, after flirting with getting a Ph.D. in history, she became a lawyer specializing in civil rights and took a job in Detroit.

headline: What I Love | John Pizzarelli and Jessica Molaskey
text: The husband and wife cabaret team rehearse their act and record their weekly podcast in an Upper West Side brownstone.

headline: John Pizzarelli and Jessica Molaskey’s Brownstone Rental
text: The couple known to uptown sophisticates as the Nick and Nora of the cabaret world — and to the rest of us as John Pizzarelli and Jessica Molaskey — rent the parlor and garden floors of a brownstone on the Upper West Side.

headline: Trading Barbs, India and Pakistan Seem on Verge of Canceling Talks
text: NEW DELHI — Talks between India and Pakistan, scheduled for next week in New Delhi, appeared on the brink of collapse Friday after the foreign ministries on both sides traded tough statements over Pakistan’s plans to meet with Kashmiri separatist leaders while in India.

headline: Carter, Reagan, and Machiavelli
text: Rex Nutting has a very nice article about the reality of Jimmy Carter’s presidency, which has been distorted out of recognition by the myth of Saint Reagan. As he points out, Carter presided over faster average job growth and lower unemployment than Reagan; unfortunately for Carter, his timing was bad, with vigorous growth for most of his presidency but a recession at the end.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The History of Autism
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Jennifer Senior reviews Steve Silberman’s “NeuroTribes: The Legacy of Autism and the Future of Neurodiversity.” Ms. Senior writes:

headline: Revisiting Issue, Donald Trump Calls Attack on Homeless Man ‘Terrible’
text: Donald J. Trump said on Friday that he “would never condone violence” and that an attack on a homeless Hispanic man in Boston by two men who said they supported him was “terrible.”

headline: Review: Martha Graham’s ‘Embattled Garden,’ Deconstructed
text: In the August heat, Janet Eilber, the artistic director of the Martha Graham Dance Company, apologized for the “breathless and sweaty” conditions in the Martha Graham Studio Theater, a storied spot cooled only by fans. She also joked with the audience that the steamy atmosphere was exactly right for the work being performed on Wednesday evening, Graham’s “Embattled Garden,” from 1958.

headline: Bernie Sanders Speaks at a Rally in S.C.
text: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, who is running for the Democratic presidential nomination, spoke to a large crowd in Greenville, S.C., on Friday, stressing the benefits of his agenda to minorities.

headline: Ex-Heavyweight Champion Riddick Bowe Steps Into a New Arena
text: Three men stood on a street in Harlem, handing out fliers and pointing to a big man sitting alone inside a small restaurant with four tables called Bowe’s. He looked around, eager for company.

headline: Bill Cunningham | It Bag
text: A molded rubber bag is a style mixture of the Birkin and Kelley bag details and a hit of the summer.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
text: Bernie Sanders draws crowds, the Iowa State Fair attracts White House hopefuls, and the president shows his form on the links.

headline: A New Day
text: IT SEEMS ONLY FITTING that an issue kicking off the fall season should be rife with stories about transformation. Yet while it wasn’t actually our intention to thread together features on that theme, neither is it really a coincidence. Change — whether emotional, sartorial, intellectual, artistic or stylistic — is what this magazine seeks to understand and to celebrate. And so, a small sampling of what lies ahead: a renegade collective that is shifting the practice and conception of architecture from a focus on the grandeur of a building to its actual everyday use; an artist who turns the stuff of daily life (which is more compelling than most, as she collects male muses and creates avatars to reproduce her Internet sex chats) into challenging work; a successful garden designer who wanted to bust out of his formal clipped-hedge-and-boxwood box and apprenticed himself at one of England’s most revered flower gardens; a group of avant-garde young designers who are reimagining fashion: luxury and craftsmanship take on a different meaning when they involve slicing and reweaving T-shirts bought in bulk at Kmart; a foreign-born press that is turning artfully designed books of fiction into status symbols.

headline: Bill Cunningham | It Bag
text: A molded rubber bag, designed by Robert Verdi and the Great Bag Co., mixes style details from the Birkin and Kelly bags from Hermès and is a hit of the summer. At $120, the bag is offered in vibrant primary colors, plus black, gray and white. A young man was observed this month on his way to work, carrying the bag in a different color on different days. Another young manwas seen with black and gray versions. Several times, women carrying the same bag stopped to show them off. Other bag news this August: red bags brightening black clothes. Other times, both during the day and evening, the bags were taxicab yellow and gave a new vitality and zip to black clothes.

headline: Ellen Page Confronts Ted Cruz at the Iowa State Fair
text: As he flipped pork on a large grill at the Iowa State Fair, Senator Ted Cruz was engaged in an active discussion over same-sex marriage and gay, bisexual and transgender rights with a hat-and-sunglasses-clad attendee.

headline: Five Mystery Birds Among Audubon’s Paintings
text: Q. I recently saw a TV program that said several of the birds painted by John James Audubon in “The Birds of America” never existed. Could that be true?

headline: ABN Amro Nearly Doubles Earnings
text: ABN Amro, the state-owned Dutch bank that was the poster child of the financial crisis, has almost grown up.

headline: In Questions Over Shaun King’s Race, Activists See Challenge to Black Lives Matter Movement
text: A prominent Black Lives Matter activist who has been accused of lying about his race was forced to discuss deeply personal issues after reporters pointed out that the father named on his birth certificate is white.

headline: Living in the Ring of Fire
text: THE West has been on fire all month, with dream homes falling to a combustive punch, wild horses seared by flame and suffocated by smoke, even a rare “firenado” dancing across a landscape in which seven million acres have been burned this year.

headline: New Condos in Astoria’s Kaufman Arts District
text: A 24-block section of Astoria, Queens, known as the Kaufman Arts District and home to Kaufman Astoria Studios — one of the world’s oldest continuously active movie studios — will soon see the addition of its first major new apartment building in years.

headline: Your Brain, Your Disease, Your Self
text: WHEN does the deterioration of your brain rob you of your identity, and when does it not?

headline: Airstrikes Kill Dozens of Civilians in Yemen, Doctors Without Borders Says
text: Doctors Without Borders said Friday that Saudi-led airstrikes on a residential district in Yemen’s southwestern city of Taiz had killed more than 65 civilians, including 17 people from one family.

headline: Karen Stives, Acclaimed Olympic Equestrian, Dies at 64
text: Karen Stives, a fiercely gifted horsewoman who helped lead the American equestrian team to an Olympic gold medal in the sport known as three-day eventing, barely missing out on an individual gold medal herself, died this month at her home in Dover, Mass. She was 64.

headline: A Day Out in the Boxing Gym With John Leguizamo
text: Accidents happen. Few people know better than John Leguizamo, who was sparring the other day at the Church Street Boxing Gym in Lower Manhattan with his longtime trainer, Jenaro Diaz.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Jazz Age Lawn Party
text: Some of the core participants dressed in the authentic flapper style.

headline: 1965 | A Half Century of Civil Rights Coverage Begins
text: To those who grew up reading The Times’s coverage of civil rights, the byline over the front-page obituary of Julian Bond on Monday was almost as familiar a name as Mr. Bond’s: “By Roy Reed.”

headline: Evening Hours | Jazz Age Lawn Party
text: The tenth annual Jazz Age lawn party on Governor’s Island concluded its two-weekend run. For the first time, it ended in a brief but dramatic thunder shower with many of the more than 20,000 participants taking cover under their picnic blankets. The original event was the idea of Michael Arenella and his Dreamland Orchestra, as part of an effort to popularize the century-old military island after its reopened as a public park.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: How Bentley Meeker, Lighting Designer, Spends His Sundays
text: In 2010, Bentley Meeker left an anonymous note in the temple of the Burning Man festival, concerning his relationship with his son, who is now 15 and lives in California. After the temple burned down — as is the ritual at the annual Nevada event — he found resolution. Grateful, Mr. Meeker, 47, a lighting designer whose regular gigs include White House state dinners, approached festival organizers about contributing his skills to future temples. This summer, he plans to illuminate the “Temple of Promise” in collaboratoration with Scooter Wilson and Adam Crocker. His method: Edison tungsten spots, which he has also installed in the converted warehouse in East Harlem where he lives with his girlfriend, Alicia Boyes, 38, a restaurant consultant.

headline: Airstrike Kills a Deputy to ISIS Leader, U.S. Says
text: WASHINGTON — A deputy to the leader of the Islamic State was killed in an American airstrike in Iraq this week, the White House announced Friday.

headline: Breast Cancer Treatment and D.C.I.S.: Readers React
text: An article Thursday on the results of a study indicating that aggressive surgical treatment of a possible precursor to breast cancer may be unnecessary prompted a wide range of responses from readers, among them anger, sadness and relief.

headline: Summer Berry Buckle
text: Melissa Clark makes a buckle with copious amounts of fruit and just enough batter to bind it together.

headline: The Buckle Makes Great Use of Summer Fruit
text: It’s easy to see how the crumble and the crisp got their names. Just look at their toppings. But for me at least, the buckle was more of a mystery.

headline: 2 American Service Members Foil Gunman in Train Attack
text: PARIS — The two American service members who tackled a suspected terrorist on a high-speed train traveling from Amsterdam to Paris rushed him even though he was fully armed, then grabbed him by the neck and beat him over the head with his own automatic rifle until he was unconscious, one of them said in television interviews here on Saturday.

headline: Social Chatter: Deez Nuts For President
text: The presidential candidate Deez Nuts was surging on Wednesday, polling at 9 percent in North Carolina.  Here are a few of the reactions to his campaign.

headline: Candis Cayne, From Chelsea Drag Queen to Caitlyn Jenner’s Sidekick
text: Long before Laverne Cox made the cover of Time magazine as a “transgender tipping point,” and long before Caitlyn Jenner made global headlines as a former Olympian transitioning from male to female at age 65, there was Candis Cayne.

headline: Ted Cruz Takes Up Iowa Couple’s Cause as He Courts Evangelicals
text: DES MOINES – When Senator Ted Cruz speaks to as many as 2,000 conservatives at a Rally for Religious Liberty on Friday night, he will feature on stage Iowa’s equivalent of the Christian bakers and florists who became cause célèbres by refusing to provide services for same-sex weddings.

headline: Thousands Stop to Smell a Flower (and Hope Not to Gag)
text: DENVER — It felt as if all of Denver was there, clutching their souvenir motion sickness bags and taking selfies as they waited for hours — and hours — for a glimpse and a whiff of this city’s celebrity of the moment: the corpse flower.

headline: Turning Puerto Rico’s Lament Into Hope
text: A photographer and writer return to the island to find both resentment and resilience among the middle class.

headline: N.Y.C. Nature: The Charming Pill Bug
text: As cute as anything found under a log, pill bugs, or roly-polies, are often the first “bugs” a child invites to play. My brother and I spent many hours in Canarsie poking them into little balls and rolling them around at the bottom of bottles, impatiently waiting for them to unfurl. Pill bugs are gentle, completely harmless creatures, and are often a child’s first invitation to nature in the city.

headline: New York Bookshelf: The Last Big Colony and the First Suburb
text: Puerto Rico has been a United States possession for 117 years, or almost as long as the Eastern Seaboard was under British domination until Americans declared independence in 1776.

headline: Women’s Fashion, Fall 2015
text: The latest issue from T celebrates emotional, sartorial, intellectual, artistic and stylistic transformation.

headline: Friday Not Music: Talking New York
text: Somehow not feeling musical this week. But I recently took a relative to the wonderful Tenement Museum, where we listened among other things to a recording of someone who lived in the building just before it was condemned; it was fascinating, but what got my companion going was the accent, which she found hilarious and I found comforting. After all these years, it’s the sound of home:

headline: ‘Cuba: The Conversation Continues’ and ‘Live in Cuba’ Expand a Musical Dialogue
text: As the American flag was raised over the United States Embassy in Cuba last Friday, the pianist and composer Arturo O’Farrill could be found in the immigration area at José Martí International Airport in Havana. Footage of the ceremony, symbolizing the restoration of diplomatic relations severed in 1961, was being piped into the room.

headline: A Russian Solider Story
text: As the tensions between Russian and Ukraine have continued, Pavel Volkov has explored the lives of young Russian conscripts with mixed reactions to the conflict.

headline: Review: On ‘Blunt Talk,’ Patrick Stewart Is Far From Home and Caught With His Pants Down
text: It’s not accurate to say that Patrick Stewart hasn’t done comedy. He was funny playing himself as a poker-faced pervert in an episode of “Extras,” or dancing with Kelsey Grammer and telling him how sexy he looked in a tux on “Frasier.” And he’s lent his plummy voice to a raft of animated shows from “Family Guy” to “Robot Chicken.”

headline: Bobby Jindal Calls for Holding Mayors of Sanctuary Cities Responsible for Crime
text: Not to be outdone by his Republican presidential rivals on immigration, Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana said Friday that he could secure the Southern border within six months of becoming president and called for prosecuting officials in sanctuary cities when their undocumented residents commit crimes.

headline: Season 2 of ‘Survivor’s Remorse’ Handles Touchy Topics
text: Season 2 of the Starz comedy “Survivor’s Remorse” opens the same way Season 1 did: with a joyous family checking out its new digs, laughing and shouting and dancing through the rooms. In the first season, the setting was a lavish penthouse apartment; in the second (which begins Saturday night) the clan has moved on out to an imposing suburban mini-mansion.

headline: ‘¡Cuba, Cuba! 65 Years of Photography’ at the Southampton Arts Center
text: Since the announcement of a thaw with the United States, Cuba seems suspended between potentially very different histories: what was, what is and what’s to be. Of the three, the knowable one is, of course, the past, and a substantial and dramatic part of the record is in the form of photographs. The International Center of Photography has a collection deep enough to tell that visual story, and is doing so, with some outside additions, in “¡Cuba, Cuba! 65 Years of Photography” at the Southampton (N.Y.) Art Center through Sept. 7.

headline: Two Good Reasons to Visit St. Albans, Queens
text: Household names and tastemakers — Fats Waller, Count Basie, Ella Fitzgerald, Lena Horne, John Coltrane, James Brown, Billie Holiday, Jackie Robinson, Joe Louis, Milt Hinton, Cootie Williams, Illinois Jacquet and Brook Benton — all lived at one time or another in Addisleigh Park, a stately enclave just north of Kennedy International Airport. The historic district is part of St. Albans, Queens, a predominantly black, middle-class neighborhood where another sort of nostalgia can be indulged at the MARIA ROSE INTERNATIONAL DOLL HOUSE, which opened in July.

headline: Gunman Kills Guard Then Himself at a Federal Building in Manhattan
text: A New Jersey man walked into a federal building near the SoHo neighborhood of Manhattan on Friday afternoon and fatally shot a security guard before killing himself, the authorities said.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
text: Greece and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Breast Cancer Confusion
text: What should women do with the latest findings that raise doubts about the value of surgery for certain lesions?

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: August 21, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photographs from Greece, the West Bank, Japan and Malaysia.

headline: First Draft Focus: Plenty of Seats, Plenty of Time
text: Supporters of Donald J. Trump waited for a pep rally in Mobile, Ala.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
text: Good evening. Here’s the latest.

headline: In the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Archives, a Magical Past and Present Unite
text: BECKET, Mass. — Jacob’s Pillow, the oldest dance festival in the United States and always eclectic and international in taste, began in the early 1940s. But its founding director, Ted Shawn, had been here since 1931, and when he died in 1972, still at the helm, he left the festival with archival materials that went back to his own early days in dance.

headline: Nearly 51,000 Madewell Sandals Are Recalled
text: Madewell, J. Crew’s smaller but fast-growing hipster brand, is recalling about 50,900 pairs of sandals in the United States and Canada because they may cause wearers to trip and fall.

headline: Native American Artists Display Works in Santa Fe
text: SANTA FE, N.M. — Native American artists converged here this week to sell their work in the Indigenous Fine Art Market, an artist-led initiative that formed last year as an alternative to the Santa Fe Indian Market, produced by the Southwestern Association of Indian Arts.

headline: Jacob Bekenstein, Physicist Who Revolutionized Theory of Black Holes, Dies at 68
text: Jacob Bekenstein, a physicist who prevailed in an argument with Stephen Hawking that revolutionized the study of black holes, and indeed the nature of space-time itself, died on Sunday in Helsinki, Finland, where he was to give a physics lecture. He was 68.

headline: Review: ‘Pericles,’ Lashed by Sorrows, at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival
text: ASHLAND, Ore. — Even among the beleaguered heroes and heroines of Shakespeare’s late romances, the title character of “Pericles” stands out for the weight of strange misfortunes that chase him around the Mediterranean, and more than once dump him in it when the ships he’s traveling aboard founder. (A favorite stage direction: “Enter Pericles, wet.”)

headline: Home Care Workers Prevail in Court
text: A unanimous three-judge panel on the United States Court of Appeals in Washington, D.C. ruled on Friday that for-profit home care agencies must pay their employees at least the minimum wage and time-and-a-half for overtime.

headline: Black Man Shot by Police in St. Louis Died From Bullet to Back
text: An 18-year-old St. Louis man whom the police said they shot after he pointed a gun at officers died from a bullet that entered the middle of his back and lodged near his rib cage, the city’s chief medical examiner said Friday. The shooting, the latest killing of a black man by officers, has raised tensions in the region.

headline: Israel Came Close to Attacking Iran, Ex-Defense Minister Says
text: JERUSALEM — A former Israeli defense minister, Ehud Barak, revealed new details to his biographers about how close Israel came to striking Iran’s military facilities in 2010, 2011 and 2012 and why it did not despite his and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s desire to do so, according to interview excerpts aired on Israeli television Friday night.

headline: Canada’s Leader and His Critics
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Constitutional Question About Innocence as a Defense
text: To the Editor:

headline: John Correnti, Steel Industry Executive, Dies at 68
text: John Correnti, who was a leader in the American steel industry during its heyday and clung to it even as it faded, died on Tuesday in Chicago while on a business trip. He was 68.

headline: Shirtless Bodies in Pointless Times Square War
text: In New York politics, as in Newtonian physics, there is action and reaction and, too often, overreaction.

headline: F.B.I. Releases Documents About 2012 Shooting in Queens
text: In response to Freedom of Information Act requests by The New York Times, the F.B.I. has released three internal federal government reports about a July 2012 incident in Queens in which an off-duty agent shot a man apparently trying to burglarize his car. The F.B.I.’s shooting incident review group deemed the shooting unjustified, making it the first such “bad shoot” in decades in a case involving an intentional shooting of a suspect.

headline: F.B.I. Shooting Incident Reviews, 1993-2013
text: Under the Freedom of Information Act, The New York Times obtained this collection of internal reports by the Federal Bureau of Investigation reviewing shootings by F.B.I. agents. In late 2013, for the first time since at least 1993 and likely longer, this administrative review process deemed an intentional shooting by an agent of a suspect to be a “bad shoot.”

headline: In Rare Case, F.B.I. Tries to Fire Agent Who Shot Queens Suspect
text: WASHINGTON — For the first time in decades, the F.B.I. is trying to fire an agent for intentionally shooting a suspect, after finding that the agent violated bureau policy when he wounded an unarmed man who had apparently helped break into his Lexus outside his home in Queens.

headline: Man Killed and Woman Badly Hurt in Knife Fight on Harlem Sidewalk
text: A man in his 30s was fatally stabbed and a woman he was with was seriously injured when they faced off against two other people in a knife fight on a busy Harlem street on Friday, the police said.

headline: Expanding Web of Scandal in Brazil Threatens Further Upheaval
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — The charges are nothing less than sweeping: Prosecutors say that Eduardo Cunha, the speaker of Brazil’s lower house of Congress, took as much as $40 million in bribes for himself and his allies, plundering Petrobras, the government-controlled oil company, while laundering money through an evangelical megachurch.

headline: Americans Foiled Train Attack
text: Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve spoke after a shooting on a train left three people wounded, saying two United States citizens helped disarm the attacker.

headline: Shatterproof Window Foils Effort to Steal Fake iPhones in a Manhattan Shop
text: The sign on the Upper East Side street looks so realistic, people stop and lean closer.

headline: Decades of Data Fail to Resolve Debate on Treating Tiny Breast Lesions
text: More than 30 years after the widespread use of mammograms set off a surge in the detection of tiny lesions in milk ducts, there is still debate about how — or even whether — to treat them. In an era when there has been so much study of how to treat more advanced cancer, it might seem odd that there is so much uncertainty about these minute sprinklings of abnormal cells, often called Stage 0 cancer, which some say are not cancers at all.

headline: Times Square Painted Ladies Take a Pause
text: On Friday afternoon, John and Kathie Watts of Hanover, Pa., were sitting at one of the tables on the pedestrian plaza on Broadway between 43rd and 44th Streets, drinking a soda and taking in what was the very ordinary tableau of Times Square on a summer day.

headline: U.S. Court Reinstates Home Care Pay Rules
text: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court on Friday reinstated regulations drawn up by the Obama administration to extend minimum wage and overtime protections to almost two million workers who provide home care for the elderly and disabled.

headline: Hillary Clinton Will Interrupt Vacation to Campaign in Midwest
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton had planned to spend the last two weeks of August on vacation, unwinding and fund-raising on the exclusive shores of Long Island. But, as it turns out, this is no time for a vacation.

headline: Advice After Stock Market Drop: Take Some Deep Breaths, and Don’t Do a Thing
text: The impulse when the stock market falls hard for a few days in a row is to do something. Anything. Our life savings are often on the line, after all.

headline: Match Lit at Manhattan School Exploded a Laboratory in Renovation
text: The renovated laboratory was hailed as state of the art. One teacher even said it would be a “crown jewel” of the campus shared by several high schools in Marble Hill, its unveiling so eagerly anticipated that, one mother said, paper had been put up over windows to keep students from peeking inside.

headline: Inequality in Hollywood
text: To the Editor:

headline: Spreading Social Capital to Close the Racial Gap
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Woes Pushing Joe Biden to Reach Out to Those Who Could Back a Campaign
text: WASHINGTON — As Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign struggles with sliding poll numbers, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s exploration of a presidential candidacy is taking on a new seriousness.

headline: Sasha Petraske, 42, Dies; Bar Owner Restored Luster to Cocktail Culture
text: Sasha Petraske, who helped restore lost luster to the venerable cocktail as the founder of the New York cocktail bar Milk & Honey and other polished drinking spots around the world, was found dead on Friday morning at his home in Hudson, N.Y. He was 42.

headline: A Perilous Moment at the Korean Border
text: The enduring, familiar tensions between North and South Korea are usually considered background noise by a world focused on other international crises. That was no longer possible after the two countries traded rocket and artillery fire across their heavily militarized border. Given North Korea’s nuclear weapons arsenal and its erratic leader, Kim Jong-un, any such confrontation must be taken seriously and managed carefully, with the United States and China playing key roles in urging restraint.

headline: Florida Legislators Fail to Agree on Congressional Districts
text: MIAMI — Florida’s House and Senate on Friday failed to agree on a new congressional map mandated by the state’s Supreme Court, bringing to a futile close a legislative special session created to redraw congressional districts the court said were unconstitutionally gerrymandered.

headline: Investigation Lifts a Cloud Over President of Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY — A seven-month conflict-of-interest investigation into the purchase of luxury homes by President Enrique Peña Nieto’s wife and his finance minister from a government contractor found no wrongdoing, Mexico’s comptroller said Friday.

headline: Liz Perle, Writer and Former Publishing Executive, Dies at 59
text: Liz Perle, a writer and former publishing executive who co-founded Common Sense Media, a nonprofit organization dedicated to helping families navigate the complex worlds of entertainment, media and technology, died on Thursday at her home in San Francisco. She was 59.

headline: Daily News Struggles to Find Its Identity After Sale Is Called Off
text: The news at The Daily News — that the owner, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, had done an about-face and decided not to sell — brought consolation to the publication’s newsroom, at least for now. But questions remain about The News’s long-term prospects, and about its place in both the city and the turbulent media world.

headline: Microbeads, the Tiny Orbs Threatening Our Water
text: Plastic is believed to be the main contaminant in the huge garbage gyres that pollute the oceans. Now researchers, led by Sherri Mason of the State University of New York at Fredonia, have found a stunning amount of plastic in the largest freshwater ecosystem on earth, the Great Lakes. And an increasing amount of it consists of the tiny plastic orbs used as abrasives in products like toothpaste and anti-acne lotions.

headline: Prospect of Self-Inspections by Iran Feeds Opposition to Nuclear Deal
text: To the most strident opponents of President Obama’s nuclear deal with Iran, the suspicious behavior at a military base about 12 miles southeast of Tehran has become a rallying call to defeat the accord, especially as it now appears that Iranian officials may be allowed to take their own environmental samples at the site and turn them over to inspectors.

headline: Three Killed in Washington Wildfire Are Mourned
text: CHELAN, Wash. — Tom Zbyszewski, 20, won a poetry-reciting competition but was studying physics at Whitman College, the small liberal arts school in southeastern Washington where he was about to enter his junior year. He also studied Mandarin Chinese and dabbled in theater, and got into firefighting to help pay for school.

headline: For @UKLabour, RT = Endorsement, Apparently
text: Until this week, Grace Coles, a 24-year-old student in Wales, had never heard of Ken Loach, the great English filmmaker born five decades before her, whose social-realist dramas about the struggles of the British working class are more acclaimed at Cannes these days than in the multiplexes of Cardiff.

headline: Jeff Bezos and the Amazon Way
text: The best thing about Jeff Bezos, the founder, chairman, president and chief executive of Amazon, is that he doesn’t give a hoot what anybody else thinks. The worst thing about Jeff Bezos is that he doesn’t give a hoot what anybody else thinks.

headline: Flipping on the Couch
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I had a hard time making up my mind as to whether I liked this puzzle by Barry C. Silk or not. Typically, I really enjoy solving Mr. Silk’s puzzles, but I just wasn’t on his wavelength with this one.

headline: Gay and Marked for Death
text: AS he tried to concentrate on his final college exams, he couldn’t erase the terrifying images in his head, an endless replay of a video he’d seen. It showed two men being killed — their necks noosed, their bodies dragged through the streets and set on fire.

headline: The Trucks Are Killing Us
text: ACCIDENTS like the one that critically injured the comedian Tracy Morgan, killed his friend and fellow comedian James McNair, known as Jimmy Mack, and hurt eight others on the New Jersey Turnpike last year are going to continue to happen unless Congress stops coddling the trucking industry.

headline: Readers Address the Escalating Violence in Cairo
text: For decades Cairo was considered safe for residents and visitors. Not anymore. Nearly two years of escalating bombings in and around Cairo are gradually changing the feel of the city. Neighbors are becoming more suspicious of strangers asking questions, and commuters are getting used to changing their routes to avoid police cordons after each bombing.

headline: The Keys to Trump’s Appeal
text: Donald J. Trump is leading the polls in the Republican presidential race, and he does well with nearly every voter demographic. But pollsters still struggle to define what drives his supporters.

headline: Donald Trump Fails to Fill Alabama Stadium, but Fans’ Zeal Is Undiminished
text: MOBILE, Ala. — Before Donald J. Trump arrived at a college football stadium here on Friday evening, the colorful guessing games that often accompany his campaign were very much in the air.

headline: After a Promise to Keep in Touch, Obama and Modi Get a Hotline
text: When President Obama and Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India hugged and said their goodbyes in January after Mr. Obama’s state visit to India, the two leaders promised to keep in touch.

headline: New Rules on Crowding for the Hamptons Express
text: The track number appeared on the train board at Pennsylvania Station, and the beachgoers wasted no time.

headline: Shaky Defense Creates Familiar Feeling for Jets
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It was still early in the game, a preseason game, the first one at MetLife Stadium this season, but already the boos were building. Already the Jets trailed by two scores. The offense was scuffling; the defense seemed hapless; even the special teams suffered. It looked all too familiar.

headline: Yoenis Cespedes’s Three Homers, One a Grand Slam, Lead the Mets Over the Rockies
text: DENVER — Yoenis Cespedes crossed home plate, mouthed “Wow” and flashed a smile. He had just golfed a low curveball to the opposite field, over the wall in right-center field, and everyone at Coors Field seemed to have the same reaction as him.

headline: Escaping a Meeting With the Indians’ Ace, the Yankees Can’t Take Advantage
text: Masahiro Tanaka is not recognized as a superstitious pitcher. There is no rabbit’s foot or unusual talisman in his locker. Unlike some players, he freely walks on the first-base line when entering and exiting an inning.

headline: Trump Rebukes Obama on Bergdahl
text: At a campaign event in Mobile, Ala., the Republican presidential candidate Donald J. Trump criticized President Obama’s handling of the release of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, who is charged with desertion.

headline: 跟著豬肉了解人民幣
text: 從市場到餐桌，豬肉恰好可以解釋中國貨幣市場正在發生的動盪。

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) DUMB AND DUMBER TO (2014) Jim Carrey and Jeff Daniels reprise their roles as the dimwitted Providence pals Lloyd Christmas and Harry Dunne, who set out once again on a cross-country road trip in their tongue-wagging puppy-mobile — this time to find Harry’s biological daughter. Both Mr. Carrey and Mr. Daniels “have slowed down without cleaning up their act,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this comedy from Peter and Bobby Farrelly, which was a critical flop but a box-office success. “To that end, as it were, this sequel is just, uh, packed, or perhaps smeared, with a whole lot of poop jokes. There are diaper gags, lots of them, mostly pretty funny, and a couple of peekaboo looks at a feline rear end.” But, she added, “the Farrellys are still not much interested in film as a visual medium, and when Lloyd and Harry aren’t smacking each other or dropping their pants, you might as well be listening to a radio play.”

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 22, 2015
text: “I apologize to the women I’ve hurt. I deeply regret what I did and know that it has forever impacted all of our lives.”

headline: Corrections: August 22, 2015
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Turning Point: Mark Kauzlarich
text: Mark Kauzlarich, a New York Times photography intern this summer, has previously worked for Reuters and The Chronicle of Higher Education, and his work has been published by Time. Mr.Kauzlarich, 25, participated in the 2013 Eddie Adams Workshop and the 2015 New York Portfolio Review. His conversation with Elijah Walker has been edited.

headline: South and North Korea Hold Talks to Defuse Border Tensions
text: SEOUL, South Korea — South and North Korea held a high-level meeting on their border on Saturday and agreed to meet again on Sunday, South Korean officials said, apparently easing, at least temporarily, a tense standoff that has prevailed since the countries exchanged artillery fire two days ago.

headline: Who Owns Helen Gurley Brown’s Legacy?
text: From the apartment of Helen Gurley Brown — No. 22D, a turreted quadruplex in the Beresford building on Central Park West — one can glimpse among the sleek modernist skyscrapers in the Manhattan skyline the Norman Foster-designed Hearst Tower directly to the south, a little over a mile away. Famously thrifty, Ms. Brown, the legendary editor of Cosmopolitan magazine, commuted there on the M10 bus well into her 80s.

headline: All In Good Taste
text: After a series of heartbreaks and long distance dating, the couple find they complement each other perfectly.

headline: Valerie Masten and Jon Bonné: Brought Together by a Shared Love of Wine
text: For many years Valerie Masten dated men whose idea of dining out was a burger and milkshake downed in the front seat of a car.

headline: Vaccinations Bring Hope, Bracelets Deliver Reminders
text: Because of the vaccine alliance Gavi, United Nations agencies, the World Bank, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and other donors, immunizations have soared in developing countries over the last 15 years. As a result, an estimated seven million children have survived infancy who before the year 2000 would have died young.

headline: Ted Cruz, Seeking Converts to His Campaign, Rallies Iowa Evangelicals
text: DES MOINES – Senator Ted Cruz on Friday night drew one of the largest crowds in Iowa of any candidate this year: some 2,300 Christian conservatives, who turned out for an unusual program featuring people Mr. Cruz called “victims of government persecution.”

headline: The Week on Instagram
text: Photos posted by @nytimes took followers to a shrinking lake in California, and Rockefeller Plaza in 1944.

headline: Fading Economy and Graft Crackdown Rattle China’s Leaders
text: HONG KONG — The start to the day was hardly unusual for a senior Chinese leader in a country grappling with an economic slowdown. On the morning of July 24, Zhou Benshun attended a meeting to promote one of President Xi Jinping’s signature projects, a plan to boost growth by building a “supercity” that would integrate Beijing with the region around it.

headline: Farhad and Katie’s Week in Tech: Amazon and Ashley Madison Exposed
text: Farhad: Hey, Katie! Mike is off snorkeling in Hawaii, so I’m thrilled that you’re free to help me make sense of this week’s tech news. You have some small shoes to fill!

headline: Hold the Burger Smell, Please
text: The Burger Stench

headline: Judge Increases Pressure on U.S. to Release Migrant Families
text: A federal judge in California has given the Obama administration two months to change its detention practices to ensure the rapid release of children and their parents caught crossing the border illegally.

headline: A Shot, a Glimpse of an AK-47, and U.S. Servicemen Pounced on Gunman on Train to France
text: PARIS — It was 5:45 p.m., a normal Friday afternoon on the sleek high-speed train that takes high-level European diplomats, businesspeople, tourists and ordinary citizens between Amsterdam, Brussels and Paris.

headline: After 70 Years of Men, Some Say It Is ‘High Time’ a Woman Led the U.N.
text: UNITED NATIONS — The bearded diplomat in a striped tie addressed a roomful of his peers the other morning on the subject of how the next United Nations secretary general should be chosen.

headline: Passengers Tell How They Subdued Gunman
text: Two American passengers and a British businessman describe how they subdued a gunman on a high-speed train traveling from Amsterdam to Paris.

headline: Variety: A Starry Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Samuel L. Clemens, who wrote under the nom de plume MARK TWAIN, is one of my favorite fiction authors, and so it was a very pleasant surprise to find a quote from his novel “HUCKLEBERRY FINN” as today’s acrostic.

headline: Why Donald Trump Won’t Fold: Polls and People Speak
text: In the command centers of Republican presidential campaigns, aides have drawn comfort from the belief that Donald J. Trump’s dominance in the polls is a political summer fling, like Herman Cain in 2011 — an unsustainable boomlet dependent on megawatt celebrity, narrow appeal and unreliable surveys of Americans with a spotty record of actually voting in primaries.

headline: Investors Race to Escape Risk in Once-Booming Emerging-Market Bonds
text: The large mutual funds that helped fuel rapid growth in developing countries have begun hastily retreating from those investments, contributing to the recent sharp decline in global markets.

headline: Merl Reagle, January 5, 1950 – August 22, 2015
text: SPECIAL POST — It is with great sadness that we announce the death of über-constructor Merl Reagle on Saturday, August 22, 2015. Mr. Reagle was 65 years old.

headline: Kabul Suicide Bombing Kills 12, Including 3 Americans
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Three foreigners working for the American-led military coalition were among 12 people killed Saturday when their vehicle was targeted by a suicide car bomber, according to Afghan and American military accounts.

headline: Bernie Sanders Courts Black Voters in South Carolina After Criticism on Racial Issues
text: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — After activists with Black Lives Matter disrupted his campaign appearances this summer, Senator Bernie Sanders, the surging if still long-shot candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination, added a new section to his hour-plus stump speech, explicitly addressing racial injustice.

headline: Surprise Star of 2013 U.S. Open Receives No Break in Comeback
text: MASON, Ohio — Though the distribution of wild cards into the United States Open is often scrutinized, rarely have so many agreed that one player was treated unfairly by the United States Tennis Association.

headline: Obama on the Vineyard? Been There, Seen That
text: CHILMARK, Mass. — In 2009, this island buzzed with excitement as President Obama, then still a newcomer to the Oval Office, arrived here for his first presidential summer vacation.

headline: Mark Toro of North American Properties: ‘Who Will Do What by When?’
text: This interview with Mark Toro, managing partner and chairman of North American Properties — Atlanta Ltd., was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Looming Confrontation of Usain Bolt and Justin Gatlin Would Be a Morality Play
text: BEIJING — The 100-meter race billed as a morality play will not come, if it comes, until Sunday night’s final in the Bird’s Nest stadium.

headline: Currency Devaluation Is a Short Step in China’s Long Advance
text: When China’s currency, the renminbi, fell against the dollar on Aug. 11, it set off a furor.

headline: Pirates Slugger Savors a Legacy of Consistency
text: The Pittsburgh Pirates have been so successful lately that the culture change at PNC Park is old news. After breaking a streak of 20 consecutive losing seasons, the Pirates have started a new streak: This will be their third playoff season in a row, barring a collapse down the stretch.

headline: Donal O’Conghaile: Shepherd of Free Samples
text: Donal O’Conghaile, 27, is an online community manager at Social Media Link, a marketing agency in New York.

headline: After a Long Absence, a Return to the Game Can Be Tough
text: It is one of the most famous numbers in sports. Ted Williams had a .406 batting average for the Boston Red Sox in 1941, which was the last time a batter reached the .400 mark for a full season. But technically it was not the last time Williams hit .400. It was not even the highest batting average of his career.

headline: Profile Emerges of Suspect in Attack on Train to Paris
text: LONDON — The young man who emerged from a Thalys train bathroom on Friday with a Kalashnikov assault rifle, pistol and box cutter is believed to be Ayoub El Kahzani, 26, of Moroccan origin, who was known to the Spanish and French security services and is reported to have traveled to Syria last year.

headline: The States Show Up Congress on Road Repairs
text: As the nation’s bridges and roads deteriorate and Congress dawdles over a serious solution, statehouse politicians have been stepping up at a surprising rate to make some difficult choices.

headline: The Push for a Woman to Run the U.N.
text: The United Nations has had eight secretaries general. All have been men. Each has been selected through back-room dealing dominated by the five world powers that hold permanent seats on the Security Council.

headline: The Myth of the New Orleans School Makeover
text: WAS Hurricane Katrina “the best thing that happened to the education system in New Orleans,” as Education Secretary Arne Duncan once said? Nearly 10 years after the disaster, this has become a dominant narrative among a number of school reformers and education scholars.

headline: How Changeable Is Gender?
text: THANKS to Caitlyn Jenner, and the military’s changing policies, transgender people are gaining acceptance — and living in a bigger, more understanding spotlight than at any previous time.

headline: The Ghost House of My Childhood
text: THE distant earth bristles with tiny imitations of houses and roads as I slide through the air in the silver ghost, a miracle of science. Now that my second parent has passed away, all things seem strange. Am I awake or asleep? I am flying back to Memphis, the place of my childhood, to settle the last of my father’s affairs and to see one final time the house where we all lived.

headline: A Look Inside Amazon
text: Readers discuss the demanding, competitive environment promoted by Jeff Bezos.

headline: Ospreys: The Birds of Summer
text: THE other morning, as I sat on the porch having my coffee, an osprey came plummeting down toward me out of a smoky, overcast sky, with a fish caught in his talons. He was screeching, “See, see, seeeee!” over and over. I suppose there must have been another osprey in the neighborhood. The males can be shameless at showing off their catch, but it’s mainly for other birds, not me.

headline: Taking My Parents to College
text: IT was a simple question, but we couldn’t find the answer in any of the paperwork the college had sent. How long was my family supposed to stay for orientation? This was 1999, so Google wasn’t really a verb yet, and we were a low-income family (according to my new school) without regular Internet access.

headline: Target Shooters Bring Mayhem to National Forests
text: Recreational target shooters call it “trigger trash” — tons and tons of refrigerators, car parts, televisions, sofas, bowling pins and other unwanted junk that shooters haul onto pristine federal woodlands and shred with gunfire for sheer enjoyment.

headline: Jonathan Sumption
text: Jonathan Sumption, called by some the “brain of Britain,” is a justice on the British Supreme Court and author of several highly regarded books on medieval history.

headline: Gay Rights and the Race Analogy
text: Now that same-sex couples can marry in all 50 states, controversies are erupting over clerks who don’t want to issue same-sex marriage licenses, bakers who don’t want to bake cakes for same-sex weddings, photographers who don’t want to take our pictures and so on.

headline: Donald Trump Struts in His Own Pageant
text: Washington — SOME blondes have all the fun.

headline: Hybrid-Powered Megayachts Come With Green Bragging Rights
text: In the new arms race of conspicuous environmentalism, the wealthy have been building “green” mansions, driving hybrid supercars and buying carbon offsets for their private jets. But now the eco-conscious rich have reached a new high-water mark: the hybrid megayacht.

headline: In a Data-Driven N.F.L., the Pings May Soon Outstrip the X’s and O’s
text: When 80,000 fans pack MetLife Stadium each time the Giants and the Jets play this season, they are unlikely to notice the 22 new radio receivers placed discreetly around the building. Nor will they see the radio frequency chips embedded in every player’s shoulder pads.

headline: What the Psychic Showed Me
text: LOS ANGELES — When I was 21, I made two promises to my best friend, Julie, who was dying. They were youthful vows, born of deep love and deeper grief. The first was that I would name a child after her, if I ever became a mother. The second was that I would visit a psychic medium after she was gone and attempt to find out how she was.

headline: Migrants Rush Across Border in Macedonia
text: SKOPJE, Macedonia — Hours after several hundred migrants bypassed a line of baton-wielding police officers on Saturday to enter Macedonia from Greece, nearly all those remaining on the Greek side of the border were allowed in, according to video footage and human rights activists at the scene. By Saturday evening, only around 200 people were left behind a fenced area on the line that separates the two countries.

headline: An Internet Mortgage Provider Reaps the Rewards of Lending Boldly
text: You have substantial assets, but your income is erratic and your finances are what in polite company would be called “complex.” Your credit history may contain a smudge or two. Yet you would like to buy one more luxury apartment.

headline: Chaos at the Macedonian Border
text: Hundreds of refugees managed to get past a police cordon set up to prevent them from crossing into the country from Greece.

headline: Dinner and Deception
text: IT’S 4:25 p.m. I make my way through the kitchen, past the prep cooks, up to the locker room on the second floor. Getting dressed takes 10 minutes. That leaves 20 to get “family meal” before the porters break everything down. At 4:55, I’m ready. Lineup is in five minutes — “live at five.” I double-check my uniform, an expensive-looking suit issued by the restaurant, before I join the rest of the wait staff downstairs.

headline: Movement Builds to Honor Greg Louganis on a Wheaties Box
text: When Julie Sondgerath learned from the premiere of the HBO documentary “Greg Louganis: Back on Board” this month that Louganis, the transcendent Olympic diver, had never been on the cover of a Wheaties cereal box, she started a petition drive on Change.org to demand that General Mills correct an omission that has lasted more than 30 years.

headline: A New Racing Star From Nazareth, Pa.

headline: The New Face of IndyCar Racing Has an Audacious Style
text: NAZARETH, Pa. — Past the cornfields and a small industrial plant, past the Brazilian steakhouse and the Latin fusion restaurant, among the rolling hills and quiet streets of this quaint Pennsylvania town, Sage Karam’s racing career took root.

headline: Macedonia’s Border Breached
text: Riot police couldn’t hold back a tide of of refugees and migrants massed at the border with Greece.

headline: A British House Overflowing With Lords Draws Scorn

headline: A Racket Maestro Makes His Yearly Migration
text: Many people who love tennis and play regularly within New York’s five boroughs know Woody Schneider. At one time or another, they need him. And so do their rackets.

headline: 7 Dead as Fighter Jet Crashes Into Highway at British Airshow
text: LONDON — A fighter jet taking part in a British airshow on Saturday crashed into a highway, killing seven people.

headline: Joe Biden, Considering White House Bid, Meets With Elizabeth Warren
