headline: 3 Who Stopped Train Attack Were Boyhood Friends
text: By May, it was decided: Three friends who met as middle-schoolers in California would take a European vacation.

headline: Serving Up New Return, Roger Federer Advances to Final
text: MASON, Ohio — Despite the adage about “old dogs,” Roger Federer is still learning new tricks at 34.

headline: On Day Filled With Yankees Pomp, Luis Severino Earns First Win
text: As a cadre of Yankees greats were being introduced — Bernie Williams, Andy Pettitte, Derek Jeter and so forth — Luis Severino casually jogged in the outfield, occasionally glancing toward the ceremony taking place in front of the pitcher’s mound, which would soon become his stage for the afternoon.

headline: Train Attack in Europe Puts Focus on Vulnerability of U.S. Rail
text: WASHINGTON — The attempted attack by an armed man aboard a high-speed train in Europe has raised new concerns in the United States about the vulnerability of rail passengers and whether current security measures are adequate.

headline: Will Shortz on Merl Reagle
text: SPECIAL POST — I first met Merl at Stamford in March 1979, at Year 2 of the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament. He competed for his only time and finished third, behind Miriam Raphael and Nancy Schuster. Everyone knows how great a constructor Merl was. Who knew he was such a good solver, too?

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Forget a Settlement, Just Make a Ruling

headline: Rand Paul Can Seek Re-Election and White House Run, Kentucky G.O.P. Decides
text: Senator Rand Paul, averting what would have been a blow to his waning presidential hopes, engineered a vote by the Kentucky Republican Party on Saturday to change the state’s presidential nomination contest from a primary to a caucus.

headline: Unraveling of Gunman Began Long Before Killing a Guard and Himself in Manhattan
text: The foundations of Kevin Downing’s life had begun to crumble long before he opened fire at a federal building in Manhattan on Friday.

headline: Yankees Retire Jorge Posada’s No. 20, With a Nod to No. 15
text: It has been 36 years now, Diana Munson said on Saturday, so very long since her world changed forever and the Yankees lost their captain. She is grateful that fans still revere her husband, Thurman, part of a proud line of Yankees catchers with retired numbers and plaques in Monument Park.

headline: Speaker of Pakistan Assembly Is Removed in Election Dispute
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — The speaker of the Pakistani National Assembly, Sardar Ayaz Sadiq, was unseated on Saturday after an election tribunal declared that his victory in the 2013 general election was marred by irregularities. The election tribunal ordered a new election in Mr. Sadiq’s district in the eastern city of Lahore.

headline: Ieng Thirith, Khmer Rouge Minister in Cambodia, Dies at 83
text: Ieng Thirith, the sister-in-law and close collaborator of the genocidal Cambodian leader Pol Pot, died on Saturday in Pailin, Cambodia. She was 83.

headline: Ohio Bill Would Ban Abortion if Down Syndrome Is Reason
text: CLEVELAND — Opening a new front in the abortion wars, abortion opponents are pushing Ohio to make it illegal for a doctor to perform an abortion if a woman is terminating her pregnancy to avoid having a baby with Down syndrome.

headline: One Killed in Explosion at China Chemical Site
text: BEIJING — A fatal explosion at a chemical factory in eastern China on Saturday night has jangled nerves a little more than a week after a series of blasts killed more than 120 people at a chemical storage facility about 200 miles away, Chinese news media reported.

headline: Musical Remixes
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Well, this one kept me humming for quite a while. I do like a musical theme, particularly one as well thought out as this one by Joel Fagliano.

headline: Shabab Bombing Kills at Least 11 at Somali Army Camp
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — At least 11 people were killed, including two attackers, and scores were wounded Saturday in a suicide bombing against a military training camp in Kismayo, about 300 miles south of the Somali capital, Mogadishu, Somali and African Union officials said.

headline: Pakistan Cancels Talks With India, Citing Restrictions
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan announced Saturday that it was pulling out of talks with India scheduled to begin Sunday in New Delhi, saying the conditions set by India for the meeting were not acceptable.

headline: Svetlana Boym, 56, Scholar of Myth and Memory, Dies
text: Svetlana Boym, a scholar and artist whose work illuminated the haunting, quicksilver counterpoint of myth, memory and identity, died on Aug. 5 in Boston. She was 56.

headline: The Strip
text: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Giant Panda Gives Birth to Two Cubs at the National Zoo
text: Panda lovers, rejoice. Mei Xiang, a giant panda at the National Zoo in Washington, gave birth to healthy twin cubs on Saturday, just three days after the zoo’s staff discovered that she was pregnant.

headline: One Year After War, People of Gaza Still Sit Among the Ruins
text: GAZA CITY — The men of Shejaiya still come daily to sit vigil in the desolate ruins of their neighborhood, drinking tea and playing chess. But these days, there are also clusters of construction workers on Shejaiya’s dirt paths, finally pouring a few cement foundations and hammering together wood planks.

headline: Year After Death, Business as Usual at Arizona Gun Range
text: WHITE HILLS, Ariz. — Antonio Nárdiz, a Spanish tourist from Bilbao, said he had chosen a family vacation to America for one specific reason: to fulfill his sons’ dreams of firing real machine guns. In Spain, he noted, 10-year-old Jon and 12-year-old Toni, like all other civilians, are forbidden to use automatic weapons.

headline: Soaring Art Market Attracts a New Breed of Advisers for Collectors
text: Amy Cappellazzo jolted New York’s art world recently when she left her powerful position as chairwoman of Christie’s postwar and contemporary department to become a private art adviser, quickly brokering sales like Christie’s $82 million sale of a Rothko painting this spring.

headline: Mets’ Bats Give Traveling Fans Plenty to Cheer
text: DENVER — More than 1,600 miles from New York, several hundred Mets fans gathered down the left-field line at Coors Field on Saturday night, forming a block of orange. They waved flags and towels and banners, and they chanted, “Let’s go, Mets!” whenever the Mets scored, which was so often it became a chorus of the night.

headline: Mahmoud Abbas to Resign P.L.O. Leadership Position, Officials Say
text: JERUSALEM — Mahmoud Abbas on Saturday declared his intention to resign from his position as head of the executive committee of the Palestine Liberation Organization, according to two members of the committee, in a political maneuver apparently designed to boost his legitimacy within the organization.

headline: Joan Rivers Dies at 81
text: Ms. Rivers, known for a wit that some critics saw as comic genius and others dismissed as downright nasty, died on Thursday.

headline: Giants’ First-String Offense Trips Again
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants are expecting major production from their offense, and from Odell Beckham Jr. in particular, as they try to rebound from last year’s 6-10 record and snap a string of three consecutive seasons without a playoff berth.

text: Elinor Lynn Tarlow, the daughter of Jill Danzig and Eric K. Tarlow of New York, was married Saturday to Michael Scott Mintz, a son of Leslie Berman Mintz and Dr. Fredric J. Mintz of New York. Charles Talley performed the ceremony at the Old Mission Santa Barbara, a Roman Catholic church where he is the pastor. headline: Walking in War’s Path
text: Meet a wounded Israeli soldier, a 5-year-old stuck in Gaza and a 24-year-old in Gaza who finds comfort in horse-jumping. For them and many others, daily life is full of reminders of last year’s Israel-Gaza war.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 23, 2015
text: “Even if he doesn’t win, he’s teaching other politicians to stop being politicians. He comes on strong. He could say it gently. But I think no one would listen.”

headline: Your Weekend Briefing

headline: World Athletics Championship 2015 Opens
text: Beijing celebrated the opening of the World Athletics Championship at the Bird’s Nest stadium on Saturday, Aug. 22.

headline: Community Policing, Tested in Far Rockaway
text: The 101st Precinct, a low-income and former beach resort community wary of police, is one of four city neighborhoods part of a trial of problem-solving-focused police work.

headline: In New York, Testing Grounds for Community Policing
text: Residents on the street rarely return the greetings of the precinct commander. Officers complain that their overtures are usually rebuffed, but they travel even short distances by car and drive down pedestrian paths in housing developments, cruising past staring faces. Many leave the Queens precinct for meals, some crossing into Nassau County for coffee at Starbucks.

headline: From Whitewater to Email: the Clintons’ Dogged Lawyer
text: WASHINGTON — At first, he had to worry about a remote piece of land in Arkansas that no one wanted. Then there were billing records that went missing before mysteriously reappearing in the White House. And of course there was the blue dress.

headline: North Korea Moves Forces Amid Talks With South
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea had deployed twice as many artillery pieces as usual along the border with South Korea on Sunday, and most of its submarines had departed from their bases, as high-level talks between the two Koreas aimed at breaking a tense military standoff stretched into a third day on Monday.

headline: Immigration Crisis Shifts From Border to Courts
text: Wearing Vans shoes and rubber-band bracelets, hair gel and shy smiles, the brothers Brayan and José looked like typical teenagers.

headline: 1940: Vichy Curbs Aperitif Drinking In Law Against Drunkenness
text: VICHY — Drastic measures to suppress alcoholism and drunkenness in France are embodied in a law which will be published in the ‘‘Journal Officiel’’ tomorrow [Aug. 24]. According to the terms of this law, consumption of aperitifs (drinks before meals) containing more than 16 per cent alcohol will henceforth be prohibited. Furthermore, drinking of aperitifs will be limited to four days a week, namely Mondays, Wednesdays, Fridays and Sundays. The sale of these drinks is also forbidden to minors under twenty years of age.

headline: After a Father’s Heart Attack, a Well-Meant Lie Backfires on the Playground
text: When my pilot husband had a heart attack overseas, I lied to our 11-year-old son. At the time, I thought it was the right decision. I was wrong.

headline: Usain Bolt Holds Off Justin Gatlin to Win World 100-Meter Title
text: BEIJING — A night at the world championships that many had feared would become a cautionary tale for track and field turned into a tale of two stumbles instead.

headline: A Basketball Life, Shown From a High School Locker Room
text: “The stage, such as it is” is a phrase that has appeared in connection with at least one of Ed Schmidt’s critically acclaimed shows. It might have stung someone who was less determined, because the theater was his apartment in Brooklyn. For one production, the stage, such as it was, was his kitchen and dining room. For the other, it was his living room.

headline: Much at Stake in Academy’s Hunt for a 2016 Oscars Producer
text: LOS ANGELES — Will the next Academy Awards ceremony be street smart, like the “House Party” movies? Digitally savvy, with a BuzzFeed twist? Or as grandly mainstream as, oh, almost anything Tom Hanks has ever done?

headline: People Sought in Bangkok Bombing May Have Fled Country, Police Say
text: BANGKOK — Thailand’s chief of police said Sunday that those responsible for the deadly attack on a Bangkok shrine last week “may have already fled” the country, apparently trying to lower public expectations that the main person being sought would be caught anytime soon.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
text: 9 P.M. (AMC) FEAR THE WALKING DEAD In this prequel to “The Walking Dead,” a blended family — a tough-love mom (Kim Dickens), a nice-guy stepdad (Cliff Curtis) and their rebellious daughter (Alycia Debnam-Carey) and heroin-addicted son (Frank Dillane) — find themselves outmaneuvering zombies after a flu epidemic in Los Angeles turns out to be so much more, above. But if “The Walking Dead” is one of television’s quietest shows, this one — with the sirens, helicopters, news reports and cellphones of a functioning society — raises the decibels to amp up the suspense. It feels like a crutch, and also “a sign that the show’s creators, who include Robert Kirkman, the impresario of the ‘Walking Dead’ graphic novel and TV franchise, aren’t nearly as sure of their footing this time around,” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. And the domestic-drama tropes — teenage rebellion, the messiness of divorce, dealing with addiction — seem tired in this context, he added. “There’s a point being made about the dissolution of everyday society, but watching it being made is like eating your vegetables — you’d rather skip ahead to the flesh.”

headline: ‘Hannibal’ Recap: Do You See?
text: Season 3, Episode 12: “The Number of the Beast Is 666″

headline: Myanmar Striking Rohingya From Voter Rolls, Activists Say
text: YANGON, Myanmar — As an elected lawmaker and member of Myanmar’s governing party, U Shwe Maung attended dinners with the president and made speeches from the floor of Parliament. But this weekend, the country’s election commission ruled that despite more than four years in office, he was not a citizen and thus was ineligible to run for re-election in landmark voting in November.

headline: 1965: Bubble Gum Blows Into Art World
text: NEW YORK — For those who feel the Theater of the Absurd has had it, there’s a whole new world of absurdities coming up strong in the field of art. Bubble-gum art, for example. Only a few weeks ago, an elaborate announcement extolled its possibilities. Attached to the announcement — and wrapped in hygienic cellophane — were six gaily colored pellets of bubble-gum, not to be chewed and loudly popped, but to be chewed, gingerly removed from the mouth and stuck on a blank canvas.

headline: ‘Compton’ Spends Second Week at Top of Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES — Despite growing dismay that “Straight Outta Compton” glosses over Dr. Dre’s history of physical abuse toward women, that Universal Pictures drama was again the No. 1 movie in North America, easily defeating three R-rated newcomers.

headline: Clashes Break Out During Protests Over Trash Crisis in Lebanon
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Thousands of protesters streamed into downtown Beirut for a second day on Sunday to demand that the government resign over its inability to remove enormous heaps of garbage from the city’s streets. The demonstrations led to clashes with the police, who turned fire hoses and tear gas guns on the crowds.

headline: As Rivals Snipe, Donald Trump Dodges Questions on Details of Immigration Plan
text: Donald J. Trump repeatedly side-stepped questions on Sunday about how he would pay for his new plan to deport undocumented immigrants, and he also faced criticism from several rivals for the Republican presidential nomination about his call to end so-called birthright citizenship for children of those immigrants.

headline: Wiz Khalifa Arrested for Refusing to Get Off Hoverboard
text: The rapper Wiz Khalifa was handcuffed and forced to the ground by law enforcement officers at Los Angeles International Airport on Saturday night for, he said, refusing to get off a hoverboard.

headline: Obama’s Quiet Vacation Will Yield to a Noisy September
text: WASHINGTON — Like April for accountants or December for flying reindeer, September in recent years has become an especially challenging month for presidents and congressional leaders.

headline: New York City Film’s Czar Resigns
text: Cynthia Lopez, the commissioner of the Mayor’s Office of Media and Entertainment in New York City, announced her resignation over the weekend. Ms. Lopez has held the post for 16 months. Luis Castro, the first deputy commissioner of the office, will serve as acing commissioner once she departs in October to “pursue new opportunities in the production industry.”

headline: Stone Speaks on Taking Down Gunman
text: Spencer Stone, a United States airman, recounts how he and his two American friends stopped the gunman on the high-speed train traveling to France.

headline: Americans Resist Hero Label After Foiling Train Attack
text: PARIS — Looking awed by the sumptuous gilded surroundings of the United States ambassador’s residence here, the three young American men who thwarted an attack on a Paris-bound express train appeared at a news conference on Sunday, brushing aside suggestions that they were heroes.

headline: La MaMa to Open New Theater
text: La MaMa, an experimental performing arts space in the East Village, will open a new venue called The Downstairs in November. The Downstairs is La MaMa’s fourth theater, and will be at the same address as the group’s Ellen Stewart Theater.

headline: German Town to Add Security After Anti-Refugee Protests
text: FRANKFURT — The German police planned to step up security measures in a small town outside Dresden on Sunday after two nights of sometimes violent demonstrations by right-wing extremists near a temporary shelter for refugees.

headline: 2 Bodies Found After Fire in a Debris-Filled Home in Far Rockaway
text: Two people were found dead on Sunday afternoon after a fire in a home in Far Rockaway, Queens, that was cluttered with debris, the Fire Department said.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Al Qaeda Fighters Try to Seize Yemeni Military Base in Aden
text: MAHRA, Yemen — Dozens of fighters belonging to Al Qaeda’s Yemeni affiliate briefly tried to seize control of a military base and the presidential palace in the port city of Aden before suddenly withdrawing on Sunday, according to local fighters and a senior military official in the city.

headline: Baffert Makes It Official as American Pharoah Allays Anxiety
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — They take their Midsummer Derby seriously here in this old horse town. So shortly after noon Sunday, when the track announcer Larry Collmus ebulliently said, “Yes, he’s coming — he’ll be here at the Spa,” racegoers knew exactly what he was talking about.

headline: Review: Helen Phillips Tweaks Corporate Culture in ‘The Beautiful Bureaucrat’
text: Helen Phillips’s unusual and deeply interesting third book, “The Beautiful Bureaucrat,” looks at first to be a piercing little satire (it’s just 180 pages) about the horrors of contemporary corporate culture. After a spell of unemployment, a young woman named Josephine Newbury gratefully snaps up the first job she can find: an entry-level, data-input position at a soulless behemoth of a company named AZ (or is it ZA?) in a place that may or may not be Brooklyn.

headline: Roger Federer Beats Novak Djokovic to Win Western & Southern Open
text: MASON, Ohio — As he tries to reach new heights amid the crowded landscape of tennis history, Novak Djokovic keeps finding the same immovable objects blocking his path.

headline: Donald Trump Pays a Visit to His Not-So-Poor Relations
text: Recent days this summer have found Donald J. Trump, the current leader among Republican presidential candidates, drawing crowds of voters in New Hampshire or Iowa, even Alabama or Michigan.

headline: Review: Haydn’s ‘Creation’: The Birth of All, With High Hopes at Mostly Mozart
text: Three angels preside over George Benjamin’s 2012 opera, “Written on Skin,” the highlight of this year’s Mostly Mozart festival at Lincoln Center. And, in a neat bit of symmetry, three angels also serve as narrators in Haydn’s sunny oratorio masterpiece “The Creation,” which closed the monthlong festival on Friday and Saturday at Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: Explosions Rock U.S. Army Storage Depot Near Tokyo
text: WASHINGTON — Explosions of still-undetermined origin rocked a United States Army storage depot early Monday near Tokyo, the Pentagon said. No injuries were reported.

text: Ohio State, the defending national champion, became the first unanimous No. 1 selection in the 65-year history of The Associated Press’s preseason college football poll on Sunday.

headline: China’s Disaster Management
text: Explosions in Tianjin have set off a national debate about the hazards of storing toxic chemicals close to residential areas.

headline: Comedy Festivals in New York That Focus on the Eclectic
text: After a stand-up show a few years ago, the Brooklyn comedians Julian Kiani and Chris Nester hit upon a seemingly obvious question: Is there a Brooklyn Comedy Festival? We realized “there wasn’t, and that there should be,” Mr. Nester said.

headline: Sarah Sze Aims for Precise Randomness in Installing Her Gallery Show
text: It is morning in Manhattan. Most of the art world is still asleep or out of town for an August vacation. But at the Tanya Bonakdar Gallery on West 21st Street in Chelsea, the artist Sarah Sze debates the placement of dried paint strips.

headline: Another Drama in Harper Lee’s Hometown
text: MONROEVILLE, Ala. — It’s been just over a month since the release of “Go Set a Watchman,” the long-awaited second novel from Harper Lee. The book has been the publishing sensation of the year, but the literary world has largely moved on now, focused on new releases for the fall and winter.

headline: Banksy’s ‘Dismaland’ in England: It’s a Strange World, After All
text: WESTON-SUPER-MARE, England — Rain pelted down for much of Sunday afternoon on this drooping beachside resort town where “Dismaland,” the gloomy anti-Disneyland created by the artist Banksy, opened this weekend.

text: Shortly after the clutch left-hander Andy Pettitte saw his No. 46 retired and a plaque dedicated to him at Yankee Stadium’s Monument Park on Sunday, another onetime Yankees ace trudged off the mound toward an uncertain future.

text: In downtown Beirut, Lebanon, the garbage crisis took a violent turn on Sunday when protesters and the police clashed.

text: Sorry about sparsity of posts; on the road for family reasons, with real life getting in the way of digital. But I did see a number of people praising remarks from Charlie Munger declaring himself “flabbergasted” by low interest rates, with a sideswipe at anyone who claims to have had some inkling:

headline: I’ll Defer On This One
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — At first, I thought Lynn Lempel had lost it. That might not be so unusual, considering her prolific constructing record. Spending a lot of time with black and white squares does something to a person.

headline: The ‘Unicorn’ Club, Now Admitting New Members
text: SAN FRANCISCO — One hallmark of the current technology boom is a generation of start-ups valued at $1 billion or more by investors. Now meet the start-ups-in-waiting that may be next to reach that mark, if the white-hot market continues.

headline: 50 Companies That May Be the Next Start-Up Unicorns
text: It used to be a rare thing when start-ups were valued at $1 billion or more by their investors. Now it’s become so common that there are at least 131 start-ups boasting such valuations and a term — “unicorns” — to refer to the companies.

headline: ISIS Blows Up Ancient Temple at Syria’s Palmyra Ruins
text: Militants from the Islamic State set off explosions at a temple in the ancient ruins of Palmyra in Syria, activists and government officials said on Sunday, continuing a pattern of destruction that they have visited upon historical sites across the territory they control there and in Iraq.

headline: Mets Rest Matt Harvey and Get Their Sweep, Too, as Logan Verrett Stands Out
text: DENVER — Matt Harvey looked comfortable sitting near the top of the Mets’ dugout Sunday, wearing a sweatshirt, with sunglasses perched atop his hat, as he leaned over to get a closer look at Logan Verrett striking out Carlos Gonzalez swinging on a nasty slider.

headline: Big Investors Are Finding Ripe Start-Up Targets in Europe
text: Klaus Hommels has invested in some of Europe’s most successful start-ups. That includes Spotify, the music-streaming service, and Klarna, a Swedish online payments company valued at more than $2 billion. He has also backed several American tech giants like Facebook and Airbnb, the vacation-rental site.

headline: 9 Opposition Candidates Barred From Venezuela’s December Ballot
text: SAN DIEGO, Venezuela — When he handily won a primary to run for the National Assembly, Enzo Scarano hoped to be part of a wave carrying the opposition to a legislative majority that would alter the political balance in Venezuela.

text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Europe Facing New Uncertainty in Terrorism Fight
text: PARIS — Two days after a young Moroccan man was thwarted from an apparent plan to cause carnage on a Paris-bound express train, European officials confronted the deepening quandary of what additional steps they could take in the face of such attacks on soft targets, short of paralyzing public spaces or even more intrusive surveillance.

headline: Guatemala President Balks at Calls for Resignation
text: MEXICO CITY — Guatemala’s president, Otto Pérez Molina, angrily rejected calls for his resignation on Sunday, denying any involvement in a far-reaching scheme to defraud the government of customs revenue in exchange for bribes.

headline: Sillerman’s Failed Bid, Debts and Growing Losses Test SFX Investors’ Patience
text: Robert F. X. Sillerman didn’t start the dance-music festival promoter SFX Entertainment out of a love for the music. Instead, he acted with cold logical reasoning backed by demographic marketing.

headline: A Sprawl of Ghost Homes in Aging Tokyo Suburbs
text: YOKOSUKA, Japan — Ever since her elderly neighbor moved a decade ago, Yoriko Haneda has done what she can to keep the empty house she left behind from becoming an eyesore. Ms. Haneda regularly trims its shrubs and clips its narrow strip of grass, maintaining its perfect view of the sea.

headline: Doudou N’diaye Rose, 85, Senegalese Drummer and ‘Human Treasure,’ Dies
text: Doudou N’diaye Rose, a master drummer and bandleader from Senegal who became an emissary of his native culture’s joyous and complex rhythms to the rest of the world, touring with percussion orchestras in Europe, Asia and the United States, died on Wednesday in Dakar, Senegal. He was 85.

headline: Seeking Equality, Not Tips, Topless Marchers Draw a Crowd in Manhattan
text: It was not all that surprising that a march of a few dozen topless women (and fewer men) through Midtown Manhattan on a sunny Sunday afternoon would attract perhaps thousands of gawkers, bemused tourists, leering loafers, journalists and passers-by — every single one, it seemed, carrying a camera.

headline: Rhode Island Church Taking Unusual Step to Illuminate Its Slavery Role
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — One of the darkest chapters of Rhode Island history involved the state’s pre-eminence in the slave trade, beginning in the 1700s. More than half of the slaving voyages from the United States left from ports in Providence, Newport and Bristol — so many, and so contrary to the popular image of slavery as primarily a scourge of the South, that Rhode Island has been called “the Deep North.”

headline: Future Risks of an Iran Nuclear Deal
text: WASHINGTON — As President Obama begins his three-week push to win approval of the Iran nuclear deal, he is confronting this political reality: His strongest argument in favor of passage has also become his greatest vulnerability.

headline: Los Angeles, With New Star, Far Eclipses City F.C.
text: CARSON, Calif. — M.L.S. has long relied on former European club stars to promote its game. Two of them, Steven Gerrard and Frank Lampard, graced the cover of the program in Sunday’s game between the Los Angeles Galaxy and New York City F.C.

headline: Rolling Stone Moves Beyond the Fray
text: Gus Wenner is 25, not much older than his father, Jann S. Wenner, was when he started Rolling Stone in 1967.

headline: As Minimum Wages Rise, Restaurants Say No to Tips, Yes to Higher Prices
text: SEATTLE — Restaurant owners, customers and staff have long railed against the tyranny of tipping, but like a love affair gone bad, it has proved difficult to quit.

headline: Debating Value of Pedestrian Plazas Beyond New York City
text: The open-air malls in Mayor Bill de Blasio’s New York may be filled with an unusual number of aggressive performers — heavily or barely costumed — but he is not the first mayor to wrestle with the consequences of turning streets into pedestrian spaces.

headline: Data on Home Prices and the F.D.A.’s Decision on a Cholesterol-Lowering Drug
text: Several important data points on the United States housing market will be released this week. On Tuesday, a Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller index is likely to show that home prices in 20 cities rose over the year ending in June. Demand for homes is building, pushing up prices. Also on Tuesday, a report from the Commerce Department will probably show that purchases of new homes increased in July after a surprise decrease in June. More good news is expected from the National Association of Realtors on Thursday as the group reports pending sales of existing homes for July. Sales were unexpectedly down in June, but may well have bounced back. —Dionne Searcey

headline: A Plunge in China Rattles Markets Across the Globe
text: Stocks around the world tumbled in volatile trading on Monday, leaving investors to wonder how much government officials can and will do to insulate the global economy from the turmoil.

text: Season 1, Episode 1

headline: In Baseball, the Times Are Changing
text: TRENTON — On the first day that minor league baseball’s new rules to speed up the game went into full effect this season, a home-plate umpire ejected the manager of the Class AA Trenton Thunder for arguing.

headline: Ryan Hunter-Reay Wins at Pocono
text: Before the Belgian Grand Prix in Spa-Francorchamps on Sunday, expectations of chaos were high because of a new rule designed to liven up the track action by giving full technical responsibility over clutch settings to the drivers at the start of the race, instead of having them take precise instructions from their team engineers over the radio. But the start went off practically without a hitch, and the explosive action came in the penultimate lap of the race, when the right rear tire of Sebastian Vettel’s Ferrari blew out while he was in third place. That handed Romain Grosjean and his Lotus team their first podium finish since the 2013 United States Grand Prix.

headline: ‘Masters of Sex’ Recap: With an Ape, the Show Jumps the Shark
text: Season 3, Episode 7, “Monkey Business”

headline: Changing the Pace of a Leisurely Game
text: Minor league stadiums have become a laboratory to examine the effects that clocks have on the speed of play.

headline: Letitia James’s Ease in the Courtroom Informs Her Role as Public Advocate
text: Several months ago, Letitia James, the New York City public advocate, stepped into a dispute between the city and eight low-income tenants threatened with eviction. Her office tried to broach a resolution, but ultimately decided that an escalation of tactics was required: She sued the city’s Department of Finance.

headline: Forest Whitaker Will Make Broadway Debut
text: Forest Whitaker, the Academy Award winning film star, will make his Broadway debut next spring in a revival of “Hughie,” a short play by Eugene O’Neill. Mr. Whitaker, who won an Oscar for playing Idi Amin in “The Last King of Scotland,” will play Erie Smith, a hustler who confides in a hotel night clerk. The play, set in Manhattan in 1928, was written in the 1940s but was not staged on Broadway until 1964, when Jason Robards played Erie Smith; a 1975 revival starred Ben Gazzara and a 1996 revival starred Al Pacino. This new revival will be directed by Michael Grandage, the former artistic director of the Donmar Warehouse in London, who won a 2010 Tony Award for his direction of “Red.” The “Hughie” revival will be produced by Darren Bagert along with the Michael Grandage Company and the Shubert Organization. The producers did not announce a date or theater for the opening, but said it would be next spring at a Shubert theater and would have a limited run.

headline: Member of De Blasio’s Protective Detail Hit by Pellet or BB
text: A member of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s security detail received a minor injury on Sunday night when she was shot in the back by either a pellet or a BB gun, the police said. Two people were detained and were being questioned on Sunday night.

headline: Intel to Invest Heavily in Software That Enhances Cloud-Computing Capabilities
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Intel, the world’s biggest maker of computer chips, has seen its future. There may not be room for some of Intel’s old friends in it.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | conception

headline: What’s On TV Monday
text: 9 P.M. (Cinemax) MAPS TO THE STARS (2015) Havana Segrand (Julianne Moore, above), an actress on the verge of unraveling at any moment, has seen the apparition of her mother — a more famous actress, who died in a fire when she was young — and seeks therapy from a self-help guru (John Cusack). He happens to be the father of Benjie Weiss (Evan Bird), an obnoxious young star, and his older sister, Agatha (Mia Wasikowska), who was banished from the family after setting a fire that may have been intended to kill her brother, and which badly burned her. Eventually Agatha befriends a limo driver (Robert Pattinson) and turns an Internet acquaintanceship with Carrie Fisher into a job as Havana’s personal assistant. “Suavely directed by David Cronenberg from an elegantly waspish script by Bruce Wagner, it belongs to the venerable tradition of movieland self-loathing,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “It takes a perverse effort of will to love ‘Maps to the Stars.’ It’s a little too chilly, and in some places too easy. But you may find yourself drawn back to it, and retracing its route from the familiar to the uncanny, from entertainment to revulsion, from dream to nightmare.”

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 24, 2015
text: “He seemed like he was ready to fight to the end, and so were we.”

headline: A Russian Soldier Story
text: After the Ukrainian revolution and Russia’s annexation of Crimea, Pavel Volkov wondered how young Russian Army conscripts felt about becoming part of the turmoil they — and the rest of the world — saw play out on television and in newspapers. Mr. Volkov traveled for eight months around military bases in Russia, taking photographs and asking questions. The resulting body of work is a portrait of Russian youth with mixed feelings.

headline: Student Crossword | Biomes
text: Test your knowledge of biomes by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: The Case for Teaching Ignorance
text: IN the mid-1980s, a University of Arizona surgery professor, Marlys H. Witte, proposed teaching a class entitled “Introduction to Medical and Other Ignorance.” Her idea was not well received; at one foundation, an official told her he would rather resign than support a class on ignorance.

headline: Ensuring Social Security’s Future
text: To the Editor:

headline: Clashing Views on E-Cigarettes
text: A British government agency has issued a bullish assessment of the value of electronic cigarettes in helping people to quit smoking. It found that e-cigarettes can reduce the health risks of smoking by 95 percent because they deliver nicotine to satisfy an addiction, but far fewer harmful chemicals than regular cigarettes. It also found little evidence that large numbers of consumers who had never smoked were taking up e-cigarettes. That seemed to challenge the notion that e-cigarettes would be a gateway to more dangerous products.

headline: The Workplace Culture That Flying Nannies Won’t Fix
text: A PRIVATE equity firm announces it will pay for both your baby and a nanny to fly with you when you travel for business until the baby’s first birthday. IBM plans to ship home breast milk pumped on a work trip. Facebook and Apple will reimburse the costs for employees who want to freeze their eggs. It seems that businesses are falling over themselves these days to cater to women who want to be or are mothers.

headline: An Opening for Diplomacy in Syria
text: The beheading by Islamic State militants of the Syrian archaeologist Khalid al-Asaad, who gave his life protecting some of Syria’s greatest treasures, was a grisly reminder of how a conflict that has ripped Syria apart for over four years has been greatly complicated — and exploited — by the Islamic State and its savage doctrinal and territorial rampage.

headline: Let Sudan’s President Come to New York. Then Arrest Him.
text: THE fugitive president of Sudan, Omar Hassan al-Bashir, plans to attend a United Nations gathering later this month in New York City on the future of global development. To travel here, he needs a visa. His application for a visa gives President Obama an opportunity to take a landmark stance in the slow evolution of international efforts to prevent genocide.

headline: Cuban Dissidents Buoyed in a New Era
text: Critics of President Obama’s decision to normalize relations with Cuba have accused him of abandoning dissidents on the island, a marginalized group that had been at the heart of American policy toward Havana.

text: Readers defend the singer’s choice to avoid much of the media, wonder whether her silence is beneficial to her brand and express disappointment that she has not taken a stand on certain social justice issues.

text: As perversions go, how’s this? Socks in summer.

headline: ‘Speak,’ by Louisa Hall
text: A less artful title for “Speak,” Louisa Hall’s sidereal novel on artificial (and thus human) intelligence, might be “What We Talk About When We Talk About Computers.” This starfish of a book, five voices waving gracefully around a core of philosophical questions, wants to explore the nature of memory; the borders of personhood; how words can illumine and obscure and hoodwink and rescue.

headline: Sect’s Death Ritual Clashes With Indian Law
text: PUNE, India — All week, people streamed in and out of the handsome bungalow where the Lodha family lives, eager to witness for themselves the amazing event that was occurring there.

headline: ‘The Incarnations,’ by Susan Barker
text: Traveling in China back in the early 1990s, I was waiting for my westbound train to take on water at a lonely halt in the Taklamakan Desert when a young Chinese woman tapped me on the shoulder, asked if I spoke English and, further, if I knew anything of Anthony Trollope. I was quite taken aback. Trollope here? A million miles from anywhere? I mumbled an incredulous, “Yes, I know a bit” — whereupon, in a brisk and businesslike manner, she declared that the train would remain at the oasis for the next, let me see, 27 minutes, and in that time would I kindly answer as many of her questions as possible about plot and character development in “The Eustace Diamonds”?

headline: Inspector Critiques U.S. Spending in Afghanistan, to Dramatic Effect
text: WASHINGTON — When the Special Inspector General for Afghanistan Reconstruction, an American government watchdog, requested information in June about health clinics in that country funded by the United States Agency for International Development, the aid agency handed over a database with the locations of more than 600 facilities.

This year, another Ramadan has passed, Eid al-Fitr is over and the reality on the ground has changed very little.

headline: Koreas Agree on Deal to Defuse Tensions
text: SEOUL, South Korea — In a deal to defuse tensions on the divided Korean Peninsula that were rapidly escalating toward armed conflict, South Korea agreed early on Tuesday to switch off its propaganda loudspeakers on the border, while North Korea agreed to stand down from its “semi-war state,” a high level of military alert.

headline: Today in Politics: A New Character Joins a Rapidly Expanding Storyline
text: Good Monday morning, as President Obama‘s vacation comes to an end and as Donald J. Trump continues to drive the discussion on the trail and on the Sunday talk shows. But, as the August lull winds down, another political intrigue, filled with whispers, speculation and a seemingly significant private meeting, deepens.

headline: No, You Do Not Have to Drink 8 Glasses of Water a Day

headline: The Sidewalk Shed, a Ubiquitous New York Eyesore, Gets a Makeover
text: Zaha Hadid has designed some of the most remarkable buildings of this generation. Whether a striking factory for BMW, daring Olympic venues or museums in Rome, Glasgow and Cincinnati, the work of the Iraqi-born, London-based Ms. Hadid has brought her global renown and a Pritzker Prize, considered architecture’s Nobel Prize.

headline: Black Markets in China Still Driving World’s Tiniest Porpoise to Extinction
text: Here’s a sobering update on efforts in Mexico, Hong Kong and mainland China to stave off the extinction of the vaquita, a critically endangered porpoise inhabiting Mexican waters at the north end of the Gulf of California that is the world’s smallest, and rarest, cetacean.

headline: U.S. Marine Testifies in Killing of Transgender Woman in Philippines
text: MANILA — A United States Marine accused of killing a transgender woman in the Philippines acknowledged on Monday that he had choked her until she was no longer moving, but he stopped short of saying that he had killed her, according to the prosecutor assigned to the case.

headline: If You Want to Be a Famous Fashion Designer, Here Are the Best Colleges
text: It had to happen sooner or later. There’s a ranking for everything these days, after all, and August is a pretty slow news month (At least in fashion terms, hence the desire to create interest with idle speculation such as the “Is Phoebe Philo leaving Céline?” rumors. O.M.G.! O.M.G.! The brand, not surprisingly, says no).

headline: Israeli Villages Near Gaza Rebound Warily Year After the War
text: KIBBUTZ SUFA, Israel — Looking out across the perimeter fence of this small rural community in southern Israel, along the border with Gaza, Eyal Shalev, 23, sees a battlefield.

headline: 1890: Cholera Epidemic Hits Spain
text: MADRID — Reports received to-day from the cholera-infected districts show a heavy increase of the epidemic in Toledo, where there are fifty-one new cases in the city and twenty-seven in the suburbs and in Valencia. In the other provinces the epidemic is stationary. The official record for the 22nd was seventy-one new cases and fifty-one deaths and for the 23rd it was 139 new cases and sixty-six deaths. The total figures for the whole of Spain since the commencement of the epidemic are: Number of cases 2,393, number of deaths 1,203. The fumigation to which travelers arriving at Seville are subjected is so severe that many have been made seriously ill. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 25, 1890

headline: Selfies in Voting Booths Raise Legal Questions on Speech and Secrecy
text: People post selfies with their strawberry daiquiris and their calico kittens, with strangers and friends, with and without clothes. So it was inevitable, perhaps, that some might take photographs inside the voting booth to show off their completed ballots.

headline: College Football Preseason No. 1s Have Gone 10 Years Without a Title
text: Ohio State is the defending national college football champion. The Buckeyes return 15 starters and have such depth at quarterback that the player expected to lead the team last season has been converted to a receiver.

headline: A Reluctant Teenager, a Barbershop Quartet and a Revelation
text: The memory is hazy, but I can’t imagine that I went enthusiastically into a concert hall in Portland, Maine, on May 18, 1974. The groups on the bill were not the kind that most 19-year-olds were flocking to see. Yet my mind was blown just as thoroughly as if I’d seen Kiss or Queen. It was blown by a barbershop quartet named the Gentlemen’s Agreement.

headline: Obama Flies to the Nevada Desert to Promote Solar Energy
text: LAS VEGAS — President Obama flew west into the blistering sun of this desert oasis on Monday not so much to issue a dour warning about the dangers of climate change — moralizing does not become this freewheeling city — but to speak with great hope about solar and other renewable forms of energy.

headline: Italian Neighbors Build a Social Network, First Online, Then Off
text: BOLOGNA, Italy — When Laurell Boyers, 34, and her husband, Federico Bastiani, 37, moved in together in Bologna in 2012, they did not know any of their neighbors. It was a lonely feeling.

headline: Daily Report: Potential Unicorns, Meet a Rough Market
text: Stock markets around the world plunged last week, capped off on Friday when some benchmark indexes had their biggest losses in years, partly from turmoil in China. Tech stocks did not escape the fall, with some companies being hit particularly hard, including Netflix, which tumbled more than 16 percent over the course of the week. Twitter, which has been on a slide for a few weeks, ended the week below its I.P.O. price. The selloff in global markets continued on Monday.

headline: Turkey Announces Anti-ISIS Operation
text: Turkey’s foreign minister, Mevlut Cavusoglu, speaks on a new agreement with the United States to flush Islamic State fighters out of northern Syria.

headline: Jordy Nelson Injury May Not Ruin Packers’ Season
text: When N.F.L. fans watch their favorite team play its exhibition games, they seldom care too much about winning and losing. Instead, they hope to see veterans look sharp and rookies look promising. But most of all, they hope the key players come out unscathed.

headline: Huma Abedin's Lawyer Responds to Suggestions of Conflict
text: The lawyer for Huma Abedin, a longtime confidante of Hillary Rodham Clinton, wrote a letter to the State Department disputing concerns that Senator Charles E. Grassley raised about a possible conflict of interest involving her.
