text: Hard on the heels of his retirement from “The Daily Show,” Jon Stewart hosted World Wrestling Entertainment’s 28th annual SummerSlam on Sunday, and divided wrestling fans by influencing the outcome of a key match.

headline: NASA’s Cassini Takes a Last Look at Saturn’s Moon Dione
text: The spacecraft, in orbit around Saturn since 2004, has two more years of work before it runs out of fuel. Last week it made its final flyby of Dione.

headline: Why the Stock Market Is So Turbulent
text: Last week, global financial markets were churning, but it really only mattered if you were an oil trader, a Chinese bureaucrat or a hedge fund manager.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Donald Trump on Black Lives Matter
text: Asked about the Black Lives Matter movement during a Fox News appearance, Donald Trump responded, “I know nothing about it.” However, he did have some thoughts about Martin O’Malley’s apology for his response to Black Lives Matter demonstrators. “He apologized,” Mr. Trump said, “like a little baby, like a disgusting little weak pathetic baby, and that’s the problem with our country.”

headline: Apple Stock Reacts After Tim Cook Email Praises China Sales
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Last week, Jim Cramer, the boisterous host of CNBC’s “Mad Money,” had a company called Skyworks Solutions on his show. The company, a chip supplier for Apple, said its sales were strong in China, but its stock plummeted afterward anyway, following the global markets into the red.

headline: Ellie Baker and the Seamstress’s Conundrum
text: This week’s puzzle was suggested by Ellie Baker, a freelance computer scientist and artist who beautifully combines the disciplines of sculpture and mathematics to bring us a counter-intuitive 3D challenge. Let’s try our hands at —

headline: 1915: Britain Shells Belgian Coast
text: ROTTERDAM — This morning a British squadron of considerable strength carried out a great bombardment of the German positions on the Belgian coast. The attack was the most important in the number of ships engaged and the fierceness of the fire since the enemy’s occupation of the littoral. It is reported that great damage was done, principally to the military works at Zeebrugge. The thunder of the fleet’s guns was heard all over Zeeland, where the windows of houses at places miles inland rattled. The sound carried distinctly to Flushing. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 25, 1915

headline: Hot Tech Start-Ups May Face a Long and Bumpy Fall
text: SAN FRANCISCO — As stock markets have tumbled, public company shareholders were not the only ones wondering what would become of their portfolios. Venture capitalists also began fretting about whether the plunge — which resulted last week in the worst week for American stocks since 2011 and a renewed sell-off on Monday — would cool the heady market for shares of private companies, especially in Silicon Valley.

headline: Divorcing a Narcissist
text: Is there a narcissist in your life?

headline: Travel Diary: Tokyo
text: Richard Christiansen and Vanessa Holden’s travels in Tokyo.

headline: How Do You Talk to a 3-Year-Old About a Divorce You Don’t Want?
text: In our occasional parenting Quandaries, we pull from the comments, the weekly open thread or email a question that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than one parent. You — the readers — provide the advice. Today’s question comes from a commenter many will recognize as a long-time member of the community—Ramona, from Toronto. If you have advice, and particularly if you’ve been where she is and come through it, please help.

headline: Two Panda Cubs at the National Zoo Present Special Problems
text: Two tiny giant panda cubs, each weighing about as much as a stick of butter, are the focus at the National Zoo in Washington of an intense, round-the-clock effort to keep them alive, but the odds are against them.

headline: Small Food Brands, Big Successes
text: Everyone knows someone who has dreamed of starting a food business. That next-door neighbor who thinks his chocolate chip cookies are better than Tate’s Bake Shop’s. The niece whose friends beg for her homemade hot sauce and who wonders how it would stack up against Trappey’s or Texas Pete.

headline: Inside the Maple Syrup Beat: Reporter’s Notebook
text: While reporting from the Tour de France in July, I encountered a rare reminder of Canada one morning. In the hotel’s breakfast room there was a bottle of Maple Joe Absolutely Pure Maple Syrup. Just as prominent on the label was the English phrase “Produce of Canada” and, presumably to drive home that point, a drawing of broad-shouldered Joe, who has an improbable beard and wears a plaid shirt and red hunter’s cap. It was a vivid reminder of the article I wrote about Quebec maple syrup, a barrel of which is worth more today than a barrel of crude oil.

headline: Videos: How ISIS Recruits Around the World
text: In this series of videos, The New York Times reports on young people in the Middle East, Europe and the United States who have been lured by the group, also known as ISIS or ISIL.

headline: Racially Disparate Views of New Orleans’s Recovery After Hurricane Katrina
text: NEW ORLEANS — As the 10th anniversary approaches of Hurricane Katrina and the catastrophic levee breaches in New Orleans, a new survey finds a stark racial divide in how residents here view the recovery.

headline: As Turkey Targets Militants, War Grips Kurdish Lands Once Again
text: DIYARBAKIR, Turkey — Across the Kurdish lands of southeast Turkey, a bitter war that had long been stilled by a truce has suddenly come roaring back, threatening to undo a hard-won economic turnaround here and adding a new battlefield to a region already consumed by chaos.

headline: Avoid Worrying About a Future That May Never Happen
text: I love spending time in the mountains. So a few weeks ago, I jumped at the opportunity to join a friend, my son and seven of his friends on a trip into the Uinta Mountains. This range sits about an hour east of our home in Park City, Utah.

headline: Palestinian Authority Is Ordered to Post $10 Million Bond in Terror Case
text: In a widely watched terrorism lawsuit that drew the attention of the Obama administration, a federal judge in Manhattan ruled on Monday that the Palestinian Authority would have to post $10 million and an additional $1 million monthly to appeal a huge damages award for its role in six terrorist attacks in Israel that had killed and injured Americans.

headline: Luke Bryan Stays at No. 1, and N.W.A. Enters Top 5
text: The country singer Luke Bryan’s grown-up new album, “Kill the Lights,” notched a second straight week at No. 1 — the first country album to do so in two years, according to Billboard. But what’s happening lower on the chart may be more notable.

headline: Video Shows Palmyra’s Ruins Before ISIS
text: The ruins of the ancient Syrian city of Palmyra are shown in a video from March 2014, before the Islamic State took control.

headline: A New Way to Charge Insider Trading
text: An acquittal in an insider trading case is no longer much of a “man bites dog” story, even when the United States attorney hailed the indictment, proclaiming that “sooner or later, you will be brought to justice.” But the jury verdict last week in Atlanta in favor Steven E. Slawson, co-founder of the hedge fund Titan Capital Management, may be much more important for signaling a new way of charging those who receive tips that may avoid requirements thought necessary to prove insider trading.

headline: New Orleans Residents’ Opinions of Recovery
text: Ten years after Hurricane Katrina, a survey by Louisiana State University found a stark divide among black and white residents over various issues.

headline: Duke Kahanamoku, Legendary Surfer and Swimmer, Gets Google Tribute
text: If you’re one of the billion or so people who use Google.com, you no doubt spotted the tribute to Duke Kahanamoku on what would have been his 125th birthday.

headline: Square Root of Kids’ Math Anxiety: Their Parents’ Help
text: A common impairment with lifelong consequences turns out to be highly contagious between parent and child, a new study shows.

headline: Inside Andrew Paulson and Sean Dougall’s Watts, Los Angeles Home and Studio
text: The furniture designers and artists live and work in a former light bulb factory.

headline: Review: ‘Purity,’ Jonathan Franzen’s Most Intimate Novel Yet
text: In a very funny passage in his dynamic new novel, Jonathan Franzen draws a very funny portrait of a writer struggling to write a novel “that would secure him his place in the modern American canon.” “Once upon a time,” this writer named Charles thinks, “it had sufficed to write ‘The Sound and the Fury’ or ‘The Sun Also Rises.’ But now bigness was essential. Thickness, length.”

headline: Do You Have Math Anxiety?
text: You may not like taking a quiz to measure your math anxiety. But don’t worry. There are no right answers, and you don’t have to show your work.

headline: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch
text: Yes, the summer’s almost over. The upside? Nearly all of the world’s top soccer leagues are now up and running. The downside? There’s an unwatchable number of hours of soccer to watch every week. This week’s highlights:

headline: Man Charged in Pellet Shooting of Officer Outside Gracie Mansion
text: The pop of an air gun came from above as two members of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s security detail stepped from an unmarked Ford Interceptor sedan outside Gracie Mansion at about 7:15 on Sunday evening. A pellet struck one in the back, causing a minor injury.

headline: A Childhood Obsession Leads to a Cereal Bar at Kith
text: New York has its first dedicated cereal bar. A small white-tiled alcove just inside the renovated Kith clothing and sneaker store in Brooklyn has 24 brand-name cold cereal varieties, with toppings. The cereals come packaged in single-serving Mylar bags that fit into small shoe boxes, from which the cereal can be eaten. The boxes are designed by sports figures — Andre Agassi has done the first one. There is no salad-bar-style display because the owner Ronnie Fieg does not like food out in the open. Milk, coffee and cereal-flavored soft-serve are also sold. Mr. Fieg says he has been obsessed with cereals since he was a teenager, mainly because he was not allowed to have sweet ones. Before the store opens, there is an express window to the street for cereal: Cereals from $6 with milk, ice cream from $5.50, Kith Treats, 233 Flatbush Avenue (Bergen Street), Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, 347-889-6114, kithnyc.com.

headline: ‘My Generation Will Never See One Dollar From Social Security’
text: The sense of doom expressed in one younger reader’s comment about the Social Security system opened an intergenerational conversation about the program’s actuarial predicament.

headline: Migrants Race North as Hungary Builds a Border Fence
text: TISZASZIGET, Hungary — Roiling everything in its path, a wave of tens of thousands of migrants and refugees — many fleeing wars in Iraq, Syria and Afghanistan — has worked its way up the length of the Balkans in recent days.

headline: In Watts, Turning an Old Light Bulb Factory Into a Home
text: “We’re making the sprawl work to our favor,” says Andrew Paulson, a self-taught weaver and one half of the Los Angeles-based design duo Dougall Paulson. Paulson and his partner in life and work, the ceramist Sean Dougall, live in Watts, a neighborhood that’s recently begun to show signs of a renaissance 50 years after the 1965 riots, thanks to chefs like Roy Choi and Daniel Patterson, who are opening a new restaurant there later this year, and Frank Gehry, who is set to collaborate on a local community center for the Children’s Institute Inc. “People ask us, ‘Is that the new neighborhood?’” says Dougall, noting the 75 blocks that separate Watts from downtown’s flourishing arts district. “We’re not feeding off of an existing art scene. We’re trying to build our own visual language, on an island.”

headline: Water Parks Add High-Tech Thrills
text: Water parks are getting a technological upgrade. Great Wolf Lodge in the Poconos and the Wet ’n Wild park in Las Vegas have both introduced a ride called Slideboarding, which its inventors describe as “Guitar Hero inside a water slide.”

headline: New Cinema Planned for Lower East Side
text: A new two-screen arthouse cinema, capable of playing 35 millimeter and digital films, is set to open on the Lower East Side of Manhattan early next year, flying in the face of doomsday reports that independent theaters are in steep decline.

headline: How Emotion Hurts Stock Returns
text: As investors watched global stock markets tumble, the behavioral economist Richard Thaler, who is also an occasional contributor to The New York Times, offered the following advice: “Inhale, exhale. Repeat. Then watch ESPN.”

headline: Details Released in Ashley Madison Hack
text: A spokesman for the Toronto Police Service said that the company behind the website Ashley Madison was offering a reward for information leading to the arrest of the site’s hackers.

headline: Mutation Reduces Pregnancy Complications for Africa’s Khoe-San People
text: The Khoe-San people of southern Africa carry a genetic mutation that reduces pregnancy complications, according to a study in the journal PLOS Genetics. The gene variant can alter the formation of the placenta during the early stages of pregnancy, resulting in larger, healthier babies and reducing the likelihood of pre-eclampsia, a disorder that can be fatal. The click-speaking Khoe-San are thought to have broken off from other African groups 100,000 years ago and, like other sub-Saharan populations, have high genetic diversity.

headline: Jet Lag ‘Cures’ Aplenty, but None That Work for All
text: Rita Gunther McGrath, a Columbia Business School professor, is one of those business travelers who do not care about delays, cancellations or navigating a new location. What does concern her is the seeming inability to conquer jet lag, and the accompanying symptoms that leave her groggy, unfocused and feeling, she says, “like a dishrag.”

headline: A Stock Slide That Started in Asia
text: Monday’s wild ride in the markets began in Asia, where indexes opened lower and continued slipping through the day. Shanghai’s composite index closed 8.5 percent lower, erasing all of the gains it had made this year.

headline: Louisiana State Trooper Is Killed in Shooting at a Traffic Stop
text: A Louisiana state trooper died on Monday after being shot in the head a day earlier during a traffic stop, and the authorities said the man charged in the shooting was being investigated in connection with another fatality.

headline: Bigger Hospital Rooms for Bigger Patients
text: When the revamped Parkland Hospital in Dallas opened recently, each of the 862 single-patient rooms in the sprawling new 17-story tower was ready to accommodate the growing number of obese patients that hospitals across the country increasingly care for.

headline: Plan for New Nepal Districts Draws Deadly Protests and Attacks on Police
text: KATHMANDU, Nepal — An angry protest against a draft constitution in Nepal turned deadly on Monday when demonstrators broke a curfew and attacked police officers with knives, spears and sickles.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: After Ashley Madison Hack, Police in Toronto Detail a Global Fallout
text: Canadian officials are bracing for long-term fallout from the unauthorized release of user data from the adultery website Ashley Madison, they said at a news conference on Monday.

headline: New Luxury Cruise Through France
text: The eight-passenger Finesse barge will cruise along France’s River Saône and the Canal du Centre next spring.

headline: A Piece of the Earliest Baboon Ever Found
text: A two-million-year-old skull fragment comes from the earliest baboon ever found, a new study reports. The fossil was found in Malapa, a cave in South Africa and a Unesco World Heritage site where specimens of Australopithecus sediba, an early ancestor of modern humans, were discovered in 2010.

headline: U.S. Army Reopens Criminal Inquiry Into Afghan Civilians’ Deaths
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The United States military has reopened a criminal investigation into a series of at least 17 murders of civilians in 2012 and 2013 for which Afghan officials blamed an Army Special Forces team, a senior Western official here said on Monday.

headline: John Kasich Balances His Blue-Collar Roots and Ties to Wall Street
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — As the people of Ohio already know — and Republican voters elsewhere are just beginning to find out — Gov. John R. Kasich grew up in working-class McKees Rocks, Pa., the son of a postal worker and the grandson of a coal miner. His grandfather was so poor, Mr. Kasich recently told voters in New Hampshire, that he would bring home scraps of his lunch to share with his children.

headline: Heroes Thwart a Train Attack, Yet Europe Remains Vulnerable
text: The four men — three American and one British — who received France’s highest honor, the Legion of Honor, on Monday from President François Hollande richly deserved it. Their courage in tackling an attacker wielding an AK-47 and other weaponry inside a packed high-speed train traveling from Brussels to Paris last Friday prevented a possible blood bath.

headline: Asia Society Names New Museum Director
text: The Asia Society has appointed a new director of its museum to replace Melissa Chiu, who left last year to become director of the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington.

headline: Richard Christiansen and Vanessa Holden’s Travels in Tokyo
text: Richard Christiansen, the founder of Chandelier Creative and Vanessa Holden, former senior vice president of West Elm, document their three-week trip around the world searching for creative inspiration exclusively for T.

headline: A Way to Make Depth-Sensing Cameras Better
text: Depth-sensing cameras can detect how far away a person or object is. Though these cameras have broad applications — in self-driving cars and navigation tools for the blind, for instance — they do not work well in bright sunlight.

headline: White House on Biden’s Potential Run
text: Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, sidestepped questions on Monday about whether President Obama wants Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to enter the 2016 presidential race.

headline: European Leaders React to China’s Slump
text: Government leaders and representatives from Europe expressed optimism about the state of China’s economic health as the country’s stock market plunged on Monday.

headline: From Governor Cuomo: Build a New Rail Tunnel
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Widening World of Hand-Picked Truths
text: Nearly half a century ago, in what passed as outrage in pre-Internet times, people across the country became incensed by the latest edition of Time magazine. In place of the familiar portrait of a world leader — Indira Gandhi, Lyndon B. Johnson, Ho Chi Minh — the cover of the April 8, 1966, issue was emblazoned with three red words against a stark black background: “Is God Dead?”

headline: Southern Company to Pay $12 Billion for AGL Resources
text: Southern Company’s acquisition of AGL Resources could yet find its true north. The power producer is buying its crosstown Atlanta rival for $12 billion, including $4 billion of debt. Although the premium looks rich for the utility sector, there is at least a chance that the price can be justified.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Syria and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: August 24, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photographs from Syria, Serbia, Malaysia and Britain.

headline: Rich in History, Metropolitan Open Will Celebrate a Milestone at Winged Foot
text: The course where the first Metropolitan Open was held in 1905, Fox Hills Golf Club on Staten Island, is long gone. It has been 75 years since the tournament — won by nine players who were eventually inducted into the World Golf Hall of Fame — regularly attracted the sport’s best.

headline: Review: ‘Dancing Through the Bronx’ Allows Local Artists a Moment in the Sun
text: Owen F. Dolen Park in the Bronx is not the sort of public green that would normally warrant a visit by anyone outside the neighborhood. Despite a $5 million renovation in 2013, it’s still just a few plots of grass and trees amid busy streets in the shadow of the elevated No. 6 train. On Friday evening, though, some dancers attempted to spruce up the place a bit.

headline: Scott Walker Joins Growing Chorus in Attacking China
text: With China’s currency devaluation and stock market downturn rattling American markets, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin on Monday called on President Obama to cancel the visit of China’s leader, President Xi Jinping, to Washington next month.

headline: Steroid Shots No Better for Back Pain Than Placebo
text: Steroid shots are commonly used for back pain, but evidence that they work no better than placebos is mounting.

headline: Women’s Project Will Present 2015-16 Season in a New Home
text: The Women’s Project Theater will begin its coming season in a new home, at the McGinn/Cazale Theater on Broadway, at 76th Street. This Off Broadway company dedicated to promoting female artists announced its three-year residency at the theater along with its 2015-16 season, which includes two New York premieres.

headline: Can Data Capture the True Health of the Creative Economy?
text: On Friday, the Future of Music Coalition, a musicians’ advocacy group, published a blog post taking issue with some of the arguments and data from my Aug. 23 cover story in the magazine, “The Creative Apocalypse That Wasn’t.” I take their comments very seriously for several reasons: First, their concerns — that musicians be appropriately compensated in this digital age — are my concerns. Second, they have assembled some important studies of the new economics emerging in the music business, many of which I drew upon in writing the article. And finally, they’re a terrific organization doing important work.

headline: Potential Joe Biden Run Puts White House in a Bind
text: How awkward would it be for President Obama and the White House if Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. challenged Hillary Rodham Clinton for the Democratic nomination?

headline: Book Review: ‘The Butterflies of North America; Titian Peale’s Lost Manuscript’
text: To most of us, butterflies are charming ephemera that flutter in and out of our lives. But for a certain species of 19th-century gentleman, the stalking and archiving of butterflies was the very height of outdoors adventure.

headline: T’s Five to Follow: Monday, Aug. 24
text: Every week, T rounds up five captivating online destinations you should be visiting often.

headline: Joylynn Holder of Brooklyn Forest and Her Steadfast Batter Bowl
text: Joylynn Holder is wandering in the wilderness, or as much wilderness as New York City parks allow. As a founder of Brooklyn Forest, she runs classes for parents and children in the glades of Central and Prospect Parks, going outdoors whatever the weather, with exceptions made for thunder, hurricanes, snowstorms and February.

headline: Rick Perry’s Campaign Takes a Hit With Departure of Iowa Chairman, Sam Clovis
text: Rick Perry’s scuffling presidential bid has suffered another blow.

headline: Atop Medal Table at Worlds, Kenya Is Also Under a Cloud
text: BEIJING — It appeared to be business as usual for Kenya at the world track and field championships Monday night.

headline: Victim’s Family Testifies in Holmes Case
text: Rena Medek, whose daughter Micayla was killed by James E. Holmes at a Colorado movie theater in 2012, described in the sentencing phase for Mr. Holmes how the shooting changed her life.

headline: ‘Fear the Walking Dead’ Premiere Draws Record Viewers
text: AMC’s new spinoff series, “Fear the Walking Dead,” drew 10.1 million viewers on Sunday night, making it the most viewed series premiere in cable TV history. The show also drew 6.3 million viewers in the 18- to-49-year-old demographic, another record.

headline: Review: ‘Drop Dead Perfect,’ Winking Melodrama, Returns to St. Clement’s
text: “Drop Dead Perfect,” which opened at the Theater at St. Clement’s last year, reopened there on Sunday night. Following is Anita Gates’s review, which appeared in The New York Times on July 23, 2014.

headline: A Volcanic Eruption That Reverberates 200 Years Later
text: In April 1815, the most powerful volcanic blast in recorded history shook the planet in a catastrophe so vast that 200 years later, investigators are still struggling to grasp its repercussions. It played a role, they now understand, in icy weather, agricultural collapse and global pandemics — and even gave rise to celebrated monsters.

headline: Style at the Afropunk Festival’s Fancy Ball
text: Revelers turned out for the kick-off night of the 11th annual music festival, featuring a performance by Grace Jones.

headline: Euro Leaders Back Cease-Fire in Ukraine
text: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President François Hollande of France stood alongside President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine to call for greater security on the Ukraine-Russia border.

headline: Scenes From the Afropunk Festival’s Fancy Ball
text: Rules rarely spark a good time. Yet upon entering Commodore Barry Park for the Afropunk Festival’s inaugural Fancy Ball on Friday night — a fundraiser which opened the 11th annual music spectacle in Fort Greene, Brooklyn — attendees were greeted by eight commandments: no sexism, no racism, no ableism, no ageism, no homophobia, no fatphobia, no transphobia, no hatefulness. “It’s like the most polite people I’ve ever met,” said Manzell Glover, a male bartender in a sleeveless vintage dress who identified as a QPOC (Queer Person of Color). “There was a crowd, but when people have their tapestries down or their blankets down, nobody stepped on anyone’s anything. I’ve never heard ‘excuse me’ so many times,” he said. A retail fashion stylist seated on one of those blankets, Ramie Mitchell, said, “It feels like a no-judgment zone.” Amy Van Doran, a professional matchmaker in a Tang-colored wig, was more blunt in her assessment: “Everyone here is super kind because there is less white privilege,” she said. Headliner Grace Jones took the stage a very civilized 10 minutes early, though she did tell the crowd, drolly and with an expletive appended, “Put down your phones and clap your hands. Put it between your legs if you have to.”

headline: European Leaders Make a Show of Support for Ukraine on Its National Day
text: BERLIN — Clinging to a deal on Ukraine that has never been fully enacted, the leaders of Germany, France and Ukraine called on Monday — the 24th anniversary of Ukraine’s independence — for the bloodshed to end.

headline: Louisiana State Police Discuss Shooting
text: The state police said Monday that a Louisiana trooper, Steven J. Vincent, had died after being shot in the head Sunday night during a traffic stop.

headline: Elisabeth Moss on Her Emmy Nomination and How to Follow Success of Peggy Olson
text: Over seven seasons, the character Peggy Olson on “Mad Men” grew from mousy secretary to advertising dynamo. While that AMC show may have started out focusing on the man in the corner office, in the end it was Peggy’s journey that captivated and compelled many viewers. While Don Draper battled inner demons, Peggy battled society, pushing the boundaries of what women could achieve in the work force of the 1960s.

headline: Scene City: A 24-Hour Party at the Guggenheim
text: Downtown artists including Agathe Snow, Dan Colen and Nate Lowman relive a fabled party from 10 years ago.

headline: China, Japan and Europe Are Flashing Economic Warning Signs
text: Even before the recent plunge in commodity and stock markets, the world economy was weak. But recent data from China, Europe, Japan and other countries suggest that growth is slowing more sharply than many analysts had anticipated. That puts the burden on policy makers in these countries to come up with more credible ways to bolster their economies.

headline: Scene City: A 24-hour Party at the Guggenheim
text: Last Thursday, the artist Agathe Snow hosted a 24-hour dance party at the Guggenheim Museum that commemorated an epic party that took place 10 years ago. An electric crowd of artists, fashion insiders, downtown scenesters and teenagers participated.

headline: In Fight for a Stretch of the Rockaways, Surfers and New Residents Collide
text: The growing popularity of surfing in the Rockaways has created a resurgence, attracting large beach crowds, fueling new businesses and generating other economic boosts.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Taking Another Look at the Reconstruction Era
text: BEAUFORT, S.C. — Growing up in Kingstree, S.C., in the 1960s, Michael Allen never knew the town had elected a black mayor in the years after the Civil War. There was no monument dedicated to the man’s memory. He was never mentioned in school.

headline: Review: Edward Burns’s ‘Public Morals’ on TNT
text: Edward Burns’s new series, “Public Morals,” is set in Hell’s Kitchen in the 1960s and filmed in New York, at Silvercup Studios and at locations like the Russian Tea Room, the Park Lane Hotel and Barrow’s Pub in Greenwich Village. It doesn’t seem to take place anywhere in the real world, though. It’s in an imaginary American neighborhood — around the corner from Runyon, down the block from Scorsese, within sight of Mamet — where characters are nicknamed Beantown and Specs and say things like, “I get a one-way ticket to Palookaville.”

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Viewing Copenhagen Bridge’s Construction
text: Time-lapse footage showing construction of the Cirkelbroen (Circle Bridge), which was designed by Olafur Eliasson and opened Monday.

headline: Review: Charlie Parker Jazz Festival Subtly Recalls Its Inspiration
text: The Charlie Parker Jazz Festival comes by its name with a blissfully casual reverence. The festival, whose 22nd edition ran over the weekend, involves free outdoor concerts in Harlem and the East Village, neighborhoods where Parker, the pioneering alto saxophonist and bebop lodestar, once lived. It always falls near his birthday. (Born on Aug. 29, he would have turned 95 this year. He died at 34.)

headline: Son House Inspires a Rochester Blues Festival
text: ROCHESTER — A sign about eight miles east of this city’s storied Corn Hill neighborhood points out a historical landmark, the rail yard where the blues musician Son House worked as a porter in the 1940s. The vowel in House’s nickname (he was born Eddie) is an odd size, rising about a half inch above the letters on either side. An explanation of sorts can be seen in the abrupt curvature at the top of the first O: The original sign misspelled his name as “SUN,” and the U was rounded off after the fact.

headline: New Report of ISIS Using Poison Gas in Syria
text: ISTANBUL — The Islamic State may have used chemical agents in an attack against civilians and rival insurgents in northern Syria late last week, according to local rebels and an international aid group.

headline: Punchless Yanks Squeak By on a Sacrifice Fly
text: The Yankees had gone eight fruitless innings without scoring a run, their swooning offense looking mostly lifeless and unimposing. Then, in the ninth, the Houston Astros called on a familiar face: Oliver Perez.

headline: Wild Cards Remain as Democrats Add Supporters on Iran Deal
text: WASHINGTON — With Senator Harry Reid’s undiluted endorsement Sunday of the Iran nuclear accord, followed by Senator Debbie Stabenow of Michigan on Monday, supporters of the deal are closing in on the number they need to ensure it goes into force.

headline: ‘Puppies’ Unrewarded at Sci-Fi Book Awards
text: This year’s Hugo Awards, given to the best in science fiction, turned into a referendum on the genre’s politics. Two blocks of conservative authors and fans, calling themselves the Sad Puppies and the Rabid Puppies, have argued that the Hugos have become a litmus test of political correctness, valuing the racial and sexual identities of authors over their storytelling skills. This year, the groups used their leverage to fill categories with their own preferred nominees.

headline: The ’60s: In and Out of the Limelight
text: David Hurn’s celebrity photos helped shape popular memories of the 1960s. But he was more drawn to the stuff of daily life.

headline: The Stock Market Loses 5 Percent In a Week: What Happens Next
text: A look at the last five times the stock market lost 5 percent in a week.

headline: Uncertainty in the Market May Imperil Deal-Making
text: Even as stock markets again tumbled across the world, deal makers — among the most optimistic lot on Wall Street — aren’t ready yet to call an end to one of the biggest waves of mergers and initial public offerings in recent memory.

headline: Stupid China Stories
text: So a stock crash in China triggered a big decline around the world, while I was trying to have a personal life (and succeeding, actually). Leaving aside whether this really made sense, why should events in China matter for the rest of us?

headline: Netflix to Add Films and TV Series for Teenagers
text: Netflix is entering the awkward teenage years, at least with its latest programming push.

headline: Reform Chief Questions United States Involvement in FIFA, Defends Sepp Blatter
text: Somebody needs to tell François Carrard, the Swiss lawyer recently named to lead  FIFA’s reform committee, that he should really stop being so annoyingly impartial and tell the public how he really feels.

headline: Analysis Finds Higher Expulsion Rates for Black Students
text: With the Obama administration focused on reducing the number of suspensions, expulsions and arrests in public schools, a new analysis of federal data identifies districts in 13 Southern states where black students are suspended or expelled at rates overwhelmingly higher than white children.

headline: Lebanese Activists Mock ‘Beirut Wall’ Meant to Block Protest
text: Supporters of Lebanon’s “You Stink” protest movement — who were confronted with water cannon and tear gas over the weekend when they took to the streets to demand a solution to the trash crisis in Beirut — ridiculed the authorities online Monday for trying to stifle dissent by erecting a concrete blast wall around the seat of government.

headline: Jeb Bush Talks About Immigration
text: The Republican presidential candidate responded to Donald J. Trump’s immigration proposals, as well as his own use of the term “anchor baby.”

headline: From Venezuela to Iraq to Russia, Oil Price Drops Raise Fears of Unrest
text: Oil, the lifeblood of many countries that produce and sell it, appears to be rapidly turning into an ever-cheaper economic curse.

headline: One Direction Says It Is Taking a Break, but Not Splitting Up
text: After more than 24 hours of fan panic, members of the British boy band One Direction have addressed tabloid chatter that said the group would go on an indefinite hiatus — or worse, break up — next year.

headline: Jeb Bush Takes a Cue From Donald Trump’s Playbook: Punch Back
text: The schoolyard taunts from Donald J. Trump arrive on a daily basis, raining down on Jeb Bush’s sober, careful and policy-minded campaign with growing acerbity.

headline: ISIS Speeds Up Destruction of Antiquities in Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Islamic State militants have razed a fifth-century Roman Catholic monastery and blown up one of the best-preserved first-century temples in Palmyra, the ancient Syrian city that is one of the world’s most important archaeological sites, according to government officials and local activists.

headline: Merl Reagle, Whose Crossword Puzzles Delighted Clued-In Solvers, Dies at 65
text: Merl Reagle, a playfully irreverent crossword puzzle constructor whose clues set off spirited cerebrations from his fans rather than frustrated surrenders to dictionary arcana, died on Saturday in Tampa, Fla. He was 65.

headline: G.O.P. Candidates Take Aim at China as U.S. Markets Tumble
text: Republican presidential candidates began shifting their focus on Monday from the dangers posed by illegal immigrants to a new target: China, whose currency devaluations and stock market plunges are starting to hurt the savings of American investors.

headline: Cynthia Macdonald, Poet Known for Humor and Ability to Shock, Dies at 87
text: Cynthia Macdonald, whose idiosyncratic blend of humor and the grotesque made her a distinctive voice on the American poetry scene, died on Aug. 3 in a nursing home in Logan, Utah. She was 87.

headline: Jordan Spieth Reassesses a Career Path From the Top, Where Time Is Short
text: JERSEY CITY — Four rows of young golfers, all active in local chapters of the First Tee, a youth development group, fidgeted in their seats in the midday sun. Filling out the rows behind them were grown-ups wearing belts and shirts bearing the names of some of the country’s most prestigious courses. On the dais, Paul Fireman — a founder, with his son, Dan, of one such place, Liberty National — was answering a question about personal legacies.

headline: A Warning on China Seems Prescient
text: Kenneth Rogoff has long warned of a potential financial crisis in China.

headline: Ferguson Announces an Amnesty on Warrants
text: The City of Ferguson, Mo., announced Monday that it was withdrawing thousands of arrest warrants for municipal violations and taking steps to prevent the incarceration of people who cannot pay fines and fees, a response to the sharp criticism of its court system that emerged after the killing of Michael Brown last year.

headline: Advisers Work to Calm Fearful Investors
text: Even a pep talk from the chief executive of Apple, the single biggest American company by market value, did little to soothe investors on Monday.

headline: Loved Ones Recount Their Pain at Hearing for Aurora Gunman
text: CENTENNIAL, Colo. — The family members of the people killed and injured by a gunman in an Aurora, Colo., movie theater in 2012 took the stand on Monday to give some of their most emotional testimony yet, approaching a lectern in a courtroom here and delivering searing accounts of the depression and loss they felt after the massacre.

headline: Puerto Ricans Seeking New Lives Put Stamp on Central Florida
text: KISSIMMEE, Fla. — When Manuel Hernandez, a teacher in Puerto Rico, looked at the reasons to stay home or to take a chance on joining the ever-growing Puerto Rican diaspora in Central Florida, it was not a hard call.

headline: Government and Protesters in Lebanon Weigh Next Move in Trash Dispute
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Demonstrators regrouped and the government tried to get a handle on events on Monday in Beirut, where weekend protests over uncollected garbage boiled over into violence that left scores of demonstrators and police officers injured.

headline: A Stock Market Rout in a Month That Hedge Funds Would Sooner Forget
text: From his getaway cabin deep in the woods, an experienced adviser to wealthy hedge fund investors was hopping from one conference call to another to manage clients’ mounting anxiety.

headline: David Wright Quickly Sets Tone in Return to Mets
text: PHILADELPHIA — Imagine if David Wright’s leadership powers worked this way all the time. With his first swing Monday after coming off the disabled list, Wright launched a home run into the second deck of Citizens Bank Park. His teammates followed his example to absurd lengths: They set single-game Mets records for homers and extra-base hits in a 16-7 thrashing of the Philadelphia Phillies.

headline: Bus Slams Into House in Queens, Injuring Six
text: A bus shuttling people from the Resorts World Casino in Queens veered off a busy road in the Rego Park neighborhood on Monday afternoon and slammed into a three-story house, injuring six people and leaving a gaping hole in the building, officials said.

headline: Review: In A. R. Gurney’s ‘Love & Money,’ a Grandson Materializes to Claim His Fortune
text: The money is vividly apparent as soon as the lights go up on “Love & Money,” the slender new play by A. R. Gurney that opened at the Pershing Square Signature Center on Monday. The sumptuous but tasteful set, by Michael Yeargan, depicts the parlor floor of a brownstone on the Upper East Side, stocked with expensive-looking furniture, paintings and books. And one expensive-looking person, Cornelia Cunningham (Maureen Anderman), who owns the townhouse and all those mouthwatering goodies.

headline: The Art of Punning
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — No one — not the constructor John E. Bennett, and certainly not Will Shortz — meant for this to happen, but this was a tough puzzle for me to solve. Not from a solving point of view, but from an emotional one. This is the first crossword I’ve solved since I learned of Merl Reagle’s death, and it haunts me for a couple of reasons.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Campaign Takes Steps to Rein In Spending
text: Jeb Bush’s presidential campaign has asked various divisions to be mindful of their spending, in a reminder that despite his giant “super PAC” bankroll, campaign dollars are ultimately more valuable.

headline: Prosecutors Rebuke Menendez Over Request to Dismiss His Corruption Case
text: Justice Department prosecutors scolded Senator Robert Menendez and his lawyers on Monday, rebuking the indicted lawmaker for what they described as a disingenuous attempt to have corruption charges against him thrown out in federal court.

headline: Ouster of ‘Disruptive’ Book Club From Napa Train Prompts Racial Bias Charge
text: A group of women, almost all of them black, was kicked off a Napa Valley Wine Train over the weekend for making too much noise, in an incident that prompted accusations of racial bias.

headline: Vibrantly Original Style at Afropunk Fest
text: Assorted swarms of students, grandmas and grandpas, designers and musicians, skaters, and bloggers of every stripe gathered to celebrate the diaspora of black music and culture.

headline: British IndyCar Driver Justin Wilson Dies of Injuries From Pocono Crash
text: Justin Wilson, a British racecar driver who was struck by debris from another car during the closing laps of the penultimate race in the IndyCar Series season, died Monday, racing officials said. He was 37.

headline: Jamaican Wins 100 Meters Again
text: Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce won her third straight world title in the women’s 100 meters on Monday at the world championships in Beijing. She finished in 10.76 seconds, followed by Dafne Schippers of the Netherlands and Torie Bowie of the United States.

headline: Stocks Deepen Their Slide After Early Gains Evaporate
text: A sudden reversal in United States stock prices late in trading on Tuesday produced a sixth consecutive session of losses and heightened uncertainty about the challenges facing global markets.

headline: Mets Rout Phillies, Bashing 8 Homers and 15 Extra-Base Hits
text: PHILADELPHIA — David Wright lay flat on his back, on a mat in a hallway outside the Mets’ clubhouse here Monday afternoon, going through a series of stretches. He looked vulnerable as he tried to loosen up his back. But as his teammates and coaches passed him, stopping to chat, they went on laughing from the gut, and Wright’s familiar cackle echoed throughout the clubhouse.

headline: Obama Pushes Clean Energy Plan
text: At a conference in Las Vegas, President Obama called for increased use of renewable energy, in part through a new solar power initiative.

headline: Kentucky Stays Alive in Little League World Series
text: Eli Burwash scored the go-ahead run in the bottom of the fifth inning, then earned the save as Kentucky avoided elimination at the Little League World Series in South Williamsport, Pa., beating South Carolina, 4-3. Kentucky will next face California, which defeated Rhode Island, 10-3.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | paleontology
text: paleontology • \ˌpa-le-ˌän-ˈtä-lə-je, -ən-\ • noun

headline: With Mergers, Concerns Grow About Private Medicare
text: As some of the nation’s largest health insurers plan to merge, a new report raises fresh concern over the lack of competition in the private Medicare market. The analysis, released on Tuesday, concludes “there is little competition anywhere in the nation.”

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
text: 8 P.M. (Cinemax) DALLAS BUYERS CLUB (2013) A fiercely gaunt Matthew McConaughey, in an Oscar-winning role, portrays Ron Woodroof, a Texas electrician and rodeo rider who, after learning in 1985 that he is H.I.V.-positive, decides to treat himself by hunting down medication that is not then legal in the United States. He eventually begins a subscription service, selling contraband medicine for a monthly fee. Jared Leto, in another Oscar-winning performance, plays Rayon, a transgender woman who becomes Ron’s business partner. And Jennifer Garner is the doctor who turns into an ally. What is largely missing from this drama, directed by Jean-Marc Vallée and inspired by real events, “is the sense that Ron’s efforts are part of a larger movement,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Ron’s bravery and determination are entirely credible, thanks to Mr. McConaughey’s disciplined, high-spirited performance and the filmmakers’ interest in the complexity of the character. But his actions unfold in something of a vacuum.”

headline: Corrections: August 25, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: The ’60s: In and Out of the Limelight
text: At this late date, what do we want from a portfolio of photographs calling itself “The 1960s”? Everyone already knows what the period looked like, sounded like, what it meant and what it led to. Especially, we know what pictures of it look like — or are supposed to look like.

headline: Student Crossword | The Seven Wonders of the Ancient World
text: Test your knowledge of the seven wonders of the ancient world by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Prisons, Mental Illness and Excessive Force
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Big Decisions
text: Let’s say you had the chance to become a vampire. With one magical bite you would gain immortality, superhuman strength and a life of glamorous intensity. Your friends who have undergone the transformation say the experience is incredible. They drink animal blood, not human blood, and say everything about their new existence provides them with fun, companionship and meaning.

headline: Jimmy Carter’s Unheralded Legacy
text: WASHINGTON — AS Jimmy Carter moves into the twilight of his life, it is enormously frustrating for those of us who worked closely with him in the White House to witness his presidency caricatured as a failure, and to see how he has been marginalized, even by his fellow Democrats, since he left office in 1981.

headline: How Universities Spend Endowments
text: To the Editor:

headline: Too Many Law Students, Too Few Legal Jobs

headline: The Man Who Got China Right

What sparked his curiosity was the realization that commodity producers had been largely unaffected by the financial crisis; indeed, they had recorded big profits even as other sectors found themselves reeling in the aftermath of the crisis.

headline: ‘Give Us the Ballot,’ by Ari Berman
text: Fifty years ago, when President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Voting Rights Act on Aug. 6, 1965, he felt, his daughter Luci said, “a great sense of victory on one side and a great sense of fear on the other.” According to Ari Berman, a political correspondent for The Nation, he knew the law would transform American politics and democracy more than any other civil rights bill in the 20th century, but he also feared that it would deliver the South to the Republican Party for years to come. Both predictions proved to be accurate. “The revolution of 1965 spawned an equally committed group of counterrevolutionaries,” Berman writes in “Give Us the Ballot.” “Since the V.R.A.’s passage, they have waged a decades-long campaign to restrict voting rights.” Berman argues that these counterrevolutionaries have “in recent years, controlled a majority on the Supreme Court” and “have set their sights on undoing the accomplishments of the 1960s civil rights movement.”

headline: At Afropunk Fest, a Kaleidoscope of Fashion
text: Afropunk encompasses music, sociocultural politics and a kaleidoscopically colorful wardrobe. But to hear it from its earliest champions, it’s way more than that.

text: We often talk about soldiers, firefighters and fictional characters with supernatural powers as heroes. Recently, the news media have used the term to describe three Americans who helped foil an attack on a speeding train in Europe.

headline: 4 State Parties Sign Fund-Raising Pacts With Clinton Campaign

headline: Today in Politics: Obama’s Delicate Spot With Joe Biden as Hillary Clinton Maneuvers
text: Good Tuesday morning. Politics can be tough on friendships, as Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is seeking to put a home-state senator in a tough spot, while President Obama might find himself in a similarly awkward position if his vice president decides to challenge his former secretary of state in a bid to replace him. And to the surprise of some in her party, Hillary Rodham Clinton is proposing joint fund-raising agreements that typically occur after the nomination has been won.

headline: ‘Moment’ Is Having a Moment
text: In normal everyday life, time is a liquid that flows around us all unceasingly — a kind of existential syrup. During election season, this syrup is captured, boiled down, dehydrated and separated into its constituent grains — grains that we like to call, without fail, ‘‘moments.’’ Thus Donald Trump is (according to The New York Times) ‘‘the man of the moment,’’ and although he was briefly ‘‘out-­Foxed’’ (according to The Belfast Telegraph) ‘‘by a Megyn moment’’ (Jim Rutenberg's coinage in this magazine), he went on to recover with a ‘‘big, symbolic moment’’ (according to Mark Halperin on the ‘‘Today’’ show) at the Iowa State Fair. Hillary Clinton, meanwhile, might be having an ‘‘Al Capone moment’’ with regard to the legality of her private email server (The Washington Post), but she still found time to have a ‘‘celebrity moment’’ (The Times again) by taking a selfie with Kim Kardashian and Kanye West. No nexus of events is too large or heterogeneous — no geopolitical weather too swirlingly turbulent — to avoid being reduced to the shorthand of the moment.

headline: Coca-Cola Says It’s Close to Water Replenishment Goal
text: The Coca-Cola Company is years ahead of schedule in its efforts to replace the water that it uses around the world to make its beverages, it announced on Tuesday.

headline: The Meaning of Serena Williams
text: There is no more exuberant winner than Serena Williams. She leaps into the air, she laughs, she grins, she pumps her fist, she points her index finger to the sky, signaling she’s No. 1. Her joy is palpable. It brings me to my feet, and I grin right back at her, as if I’ve won something, too. Perhaps I have.

headline: For History-Minded Tourists, London Marks Blitz Anniversary
text: Beginning in the autumn of 1940, German Luftwaffe pilots bombed London for 57 consecutive nights. It began on Sept. 7, when 348 German bombers and 617 Messerschmitt fighters appeared in the clear skies above the British capital and began to pound the area with explosives. In the months that followed, great numbers of aghast Londoners fled to the countryside. But many more stayed put, through air raids that flattened great swaths of the city and killed 20,000 residents. When the bomb shelters filled up, tens of thousands of Londoners filed into Underground stations, where they slept, packed like sardines, on the concrete platforms.

headline: Waukesha Plan for Lake Michigan Water Raises Worries
text: WAUKESHA, Wis. — This city, once famous for its bubbling natural springs, sits about 17 miles from the shore of Lake Michigan. So when the state and federal authorities began demanding that the city address a growing contamination problem in its aquifer, the answer seemed simple: Get water from the big lake.

headline: Deal Between North and South Korea Defies Their Mutual Disdain
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The agreement that ended a tense military standoff on the Korean Peninsula on Tuesday taught a lesson about North-South dynamics: Though they heap verbal abuse on each other’s leaders, the two sides can still do a deal when it suits their interests.

headline: Morning Agenda: China Cuts Rates After Stocks Plunge
text: CHINA CUTS RATES AFTER SHANGHAI STOCKS PLUNGE | China’s central bank cut interest rates after Shanghai’s stock market went into free fall on Tuesday, closing 7.6 percent lower after an 8.5 percent plunge on Monday, Chris Buckley writes in The New York Times. The move brought interest rates down by 0.25 percent, lowering the one-year lending rate to 4.6 percent. The People’s Bank of China also reduced the reserve rate requirement by 0.5 percent.

headline: Part of the Problem: Stocks Are Expensive
text: The smart advice during a falling stock market is not to panic. Selling out of panic often leads investors to miss out on the market recoveries that typically follow a drop, because it’s all but impossible to predict when such a recovery will begin.

headline: Dear New York, Will We Work Out?

headline: Popcast: ‘Where Are Ü Now’
text: Times music critics discuss Justin Bieber’s collaboration with Skrillex and Diplo.

headline: Popcast: ‘Where Are Ü Now’
text: “Where Are Ü Now,” released last February and a contender for consensual song-of-the-summer status, was a result of a fairly typical songwriting process: piano chord changes and a sung topline, later developed through digital manipulations into a dance track. The singer was Justin Bieber (who developed the core of the song with his collaborator Poo Bear), and the digital manipulators were Skrillex and Diplo, who were putting together their “Jack U” collaboration album.

headline: Bets That the Fed Will Delay Interest Rate Rise Could Be Premature
text: WASHINGTON — As markets quake and stock prices fall, investors increasingly are betting that the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates this year.

headline: The Inside History of ‘Where Are Ü Now’
text: On the radio, where it has been ubiquitous all summer, the million-selling single “Where Are Ü Now” by Skrillex and Diplo with Justin Bieber is four minutes of high-tech bliss: a sweet-voiced mixture of longing and recrimination, a lonely plaint with a dance beat.

headline: Why Vouchers Won’t Fix Vegas Schools
text: LAS VEGAS — FOR the past year, I’ve lived next door to a public elementary school. With my windows open in the morning, I can hear children’s laughter on the playground, and at 9 a.m., the Pledge of Allegiance over the intercom. My afternoon commute takes me past the entrance, where I see a diverse group of parents collecting their children, from white moms in yoga pants to Muslim women in hijab guiding their kids carefully through the crosswalk.

headline: 1890: Kerchief Keeper Called Insane
text: There is good news from Vienna. A man who has devoted himself to collecting ladies’ handkerchiefs has been decided to be insane and has been placed in an asylum. If the collector of handkerchiefs is adjudged to be a lunatic, how can the collector of postage stamps be regarded as sane? Handkerchiefs have an intrinsic value and ladies’ handkerchiefs may be full of poetic and sacred associations, whereas the used postage stamp is valueless, ugly and devoid of any associations worth mentioning. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 26, 1890

headline: The Cost of Lower Standards for Women in Marine Recruitment
text: The recent success of two female officers, both West Point graduates, in passing the Army’s grueling Ranger School has bolstered arguments for the full integration of women into the military’s front-line combat units. In becoming the first women to receive the coveted Ranger tab, the two officers proved that women can handle not just the physical challenges but also the psychological and leadership tests posed by the nine-week course.

headline: Showing Courage on Iran
text: Intense lobbying and heated (often demagogic and hateful) rhetoric has made deciding whether to support the Iran nuclear deal an excruciating process for many members of Congress. None have come under more pressure and scrutiny than Jewish-American lawmakers. And among those, Representative Jerrold Nadler stands out. He represents a district of New York City from the liberal Upper West Side to ultra-Orthodox Borough Park in Brooklyn that is believed to have the largest Jewish population in the country.

headline: U.N. Predicts 3,000 Migrants a Day Will Pass Through Balkans
text: BERLIN — Three thousand migrants a day will pour into the Balkans trying to reach Western Europe in the next few months, the United Nations forecast on Tuesday, a few hours after a suspected arson attack destroyed a sports hall in Germany where some migrants were to be sheltered.

headline: Unnatural Obsessions
text: One enduring constant of the world economy since 2008 is the chorus of sober-sounding people declaring that the Fed must act responsibly and raise rates. A few years back, rising commodity prices and a flood of money into emerging markets were proof that low rates were dangerously inflationary and must be hiked. Now we have plunging commodity prices and a flood of money out of emerging markets; clearly, this shows that the Fed must do the right thing, and raise rates.

headline: Guatemala’s Corruption Investigations Make Swift Strides
text: GUATEMALA CITY — Just about every weekend for months, Jorge Castiglione, a 70-year-old engineer with a thinning ponytail, has gone to the Plaza de la Constitución here to support what has become a ritual in this nation: weekly protests calling for the resignation of the president and an end to political impunity.

headline: 1965: French Find U.S. Worth a Visit
text: PARIS — The French are discovering the United States, and finding it’s something to write home about. Following the ‘‘big’’ year of 1964, when the number of Frenchmen visiting the United States rose by 31.9 percent, and a continuing increase this year, French publishers are rushing travelogues into print. The reports go beyond the traditional observations about Americans putting mayonnaise on fruit salad. Articles and serials, some of them inspired by a Trans World Airlines tour of America for 25 French journalists in May, have appeared in publications throughout the country. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 26, 1965

headline: Pro-Choice Questions, Pro-Life Answers, Part II
text: This the second part of my extended response to Katha Pollitt’s questions for abortion opponents, inspired by the still-ongoing release of Planned Parenthood sting videos; you can find the first half of my response here. If you like you can consider this a strange sort of counterprogramming for the global economy’s current China-driven jitters, and fear not: Full-spectrum Trump coverage will no doubt resume shortly.

headline: Marco Rubio to Take On China in Foreign Policy Address
text: With a financial crisis in China rattling global markets, Senator Marco Rubio plans to deliver a major foreign policy speech on Friday outlining how a Rubio administration would more assertively challenge the Chinese, joining leading Republican rivals in pressing this line of attack.

headline: The Crimes of Palmyra
text: The Islamic State, the ultrafundamentalist group better known as ISIS, has laid a trail of unspeakable horrors in its march through Syria and Iraq — videotaped beheadings, ritualized rape and all manner of grisly torture and murder of anyone who does not subscribe to its extreme version of Islam.

headline: Following the March of Migrants Along the Balkans
text: I set out from my base in Berlin for southern Hungary to write about the wave of tens of thousands of migrants and refugees — many fleeing wars in Iraq, Syria and Afghanistan — that has worked its way up the length of the Balkans in recent days. How, I wondered, even with the skills of our local fixer and translator, Helene Bienvenu, might one expect to find migrants on the move? Or officials willing to talk about the challenges.

headline: London Theater Journal: En Travesti, Both Sides Now
text: LONDON — There’s more than one crafty celebrity television sleuth in disguise on this city’s stages. People are of, course, queuing up to witness Benedict Cumberbatch, who plays the problem-solving title character of the BBC’s “Sherlock,” transform himself into the problem-evading Prince Hamlet at the Barbican.

headline: From the Graphics Archive: Mapping Katrina and Its Aftermath
text: A selection of maps published in The New York Times that shows the storm’s impact.

headline: New Jersey’s Effort to Legalize Sports Betting Is Denied on Appeal
text: New Jersey’s effort to offer legalized sports betting was stopped again on Tuesday by a federal appeals court, leaving legal gambling on professional and college sports to a handful of states — predominantly Nevada — and the booming daily fantasy game industry.

headline: French Train Attack Suspect Viewed Jihadist Video, Official Says
text: PARIS — In the moments before he loaded his gun to shoot up a train full of passengers, the suspect in Friday’s failed attack on the Amsterdam-Paris express, Ayoub El Khazzani, watched a YouTube video exhorting the faithful to commit violent acts in the name of radical Islam, the chief Paris prosecutor said Tuesday.

headline: Donald Trump, the Green Lantern Candidate
text: Why is Donald Trump leading the polls in the G.O.P. presidential race? One explanation is his celebrity and the media attention he attracts. But he has also exploited our vulnerability to pleasing fictions about presidential power.

headline: Regulator Votes to Block Merger of Pepco and Exelon
text: Before Tuesday, Exelon seemed close to sealing its $6.8 billion takeover of a fellow utility operator, Pepco Holdings, having secured support from most of the power regulators it needed to satisfy.

headline: Restaurant Review: The Clocktower in Midtown South
text: If you hope dinner at the Clocktower will get you a backstage view of the ticking cogs at the top of the former Metropolitan Life Tower, forget it. The restaurant is on the second floor of the New York Edition hotel, which opened in the skyscraper at the foot of Madison Avenue in May. Marriott and Ian Schrager, who run the place, brought in the restaurateur Stephen Starr to operate the Clocktower.

headline: New Jersey’s $225 Million Settlement With Exxon Mobil Is Approved
text: New Jersey’s widely debated $225 million settlement of a pollution lawsuit with Exxon Mobil Corporation was approved on Tuesday by a state judge who called the deal fair, reasonable and in the public interest.

headline: Museums Engage in Virtual Collection Swap Via Instagram
text: LONDON — Ten of this city’s leading museums are diving into one another’s collections for an Instagram swap this week.

headline: Anna Kashfi, Actress Who Was Brando’s First Wife, Dies at 80
text: Anna Kashfi, an actress who appeared in several Hollywood films in parts calling for, in the parlance of the day, an exotic beauty, but who became better known for playing a continuing role in a real-life soap opera as Marlon Brando’s first wife, died on Aug. 16 in Woodland, Wash. She was 80.

headline: French Prosecutor Discusses Train Attack
text: On Tuesday, François Molins, a French prosecutor, described an attack on a high-speed train as terrorism and dismissed the suspect’s “fantastical” assertion that he intended it only as a robbery.

headline: Julianne Moore and Film Producer Start Petition to Remove Confederate General From School Name
text: The fight against Confederate symbols nationwide has lined up some Hollywood supporters. Julianne Moore and the film producer Bruce Cohen have started a Change.org petition to rename their high school, J.E.B. Stuart High in Fairfax County, Va. Founded in 1959, the school was named for a Confederate general who befriended Robert E. Lee during their West Point days. The name was chosen, the petition says, as a rebuke against the 1954 Brown v. Board of Education ruling that ended public school segregation.

headline: Russia Gives Ukrainian Filmmaker Oleg Sentsov a 20-Year Sentence
text: MOSCOW — A Russian military court sentenced a Ukrainian filmmaker, Oleg Sentsov, to 20 years in a prison camp on Tuesday after convicting him of terrorism in the Crimean Peninsula after its annexation by Russia last year.

headline: Bold Fall Fashion, Grounded in Boyish Basics
text: Loud prints and colors from the pre-fall collections are subdued by tank tops, jeans and sneakers — and casual enough for everyday.

headline: An Island Compound Off the West Coast of Sweden
text: The property, which dates to 1870 and includes a private beach, a dock and a boathouse, is on the market for $2.44 million.

headline: A Corn Gratin Welcomes Chard Into the Fold
text: A neighbor posted on our shared email list that she had harvested from her garden more chard than she could use. If anybody wanted it, she would leave it on her front porch for pickup.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week 9 | My Jon Stewart Withdrawal Syndrome
text: Week 9 of our Summer Reading Contests delivered so many outstanding entries from students that we had trouble choosing our favorites.

headline: Jeb Bush Falls Into a Trap
text: Jeb Bush went to the border town of McAllen, Tex., on Monday to raise money and to talk about immigration, in English and fluent Spanish. Because the Republican presidential campaign has been so fixated on border security and the immigrant peril — thank you, Donald Trump — it was a chance to see how the supposed expert on this fraught subject handled it.

headline: Sheen Center Announces Lineup for Opening Festival
text: Sacred dance from several traditions, a Hollywood premiere, panels on religion and politics, and “an evening of music and chocolate” are among the events scheduled for the three-week grand opening festival of the Sheen Center for Thought and Culture, a new arts center on Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village run by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

headline: Vaucluse Moves In on the Upper East Side
text: Vaucluse Proof that the Upper East Side is not prepared to abandon elegance in favor of salvaged barn siding comes with this palatial new restaurant from Michael White and Ahmass Fakahany, partners in the Altamarea Group. With well-mannered neutral-toned surroundings and white tablecloths, they have turned to France for inspiration instead of their usual Italy. Mr. Fakahany pointed out that several French restaurants, including Voisin and Le Périgord Park, have anchored the space, and Mr. White has cooked in France with Roger Vergé and Jacques Chibois. “I can now use lavender, thyme and bay, ingredients that I don’t get to use often,” Mr. White said. Though the name refers to a region of Provence, the food is not Provençal. The menu is broad brasserie-style, offering sections devoted to chilled seafood, vegetables, starters, fresh pastas, main courses and a list of daily specials like blanquette de veau (Tuesdays). The executive chef is Jared Gadbaw. The bar area on the mezzanine has been widened, and a stunning vaulted ceiling has been uncovered; the light fixtures suggest Art Deco. The dining room on the upper level is somewhat less formal-looking than the main room and is accented with cushy dark-sea-green leather chairs. (Opens Sept. 2): 100 East 63rd Street, vauclusenyc.com.

headline: Boy Avoids a Fall, but Punches a Hole in a $1.5 Million Painting
text: A 12-year-old in Taiwan lived out many museum-goers’ nightmare (and many parents’) when he tripped and caught his balance by punching a hole in an oil painting that is over 300 years old and valued at $1.5 million.

headline: Joe Biden to Hold Unusual Call With Democratic Party Officials
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. may not be attending the Democratic National Committee’s summer meeting this week, but he’s making his presence felt as he mulls a run for the party’s 2016 presidential nomination against Hillary Rodham Clinton, Bernie Sanders and others who will be speaking at the party gathering.

headline: Test for Donald Trump: Turning Crowds Into Real Voters
text: DUBUQUE, Iowa — Donald J. Trump, it is abundantly clear, is not a conventional candidate. And neither is his approach to recruiting campaign activists.

headline: The Price of Silence on Wall Street
text: What is the price of silence on Wall Street? That is the question confronting Peter Sivere, a 46-year-old soon-to-be former compliance officer at Barclays in New York.

headline: Patty Murray Comes Out in Support of Iran Nuclear Deal
text: Senator Patty Murray of Washington, the only member of the Democratic leadership who had not weighed in on the Iran nuclear deal, broke her silence on Tuesday and threw her weight behind the accord.

headline: Adam Lippes’s Guide to the Berkshires
text: “The Berkshires are so not about fashion,” says the designer Adam Lippes, summing up the appeal of his country escape in the mountains of western Massachusetts. “I love that the spirit of the area is so eclectic and genuine. It’s this non-high-heel lifestyle.”

headline: Curt Schilling Off Little League Broadcasts After ‘Unacceptable’ Tweet
text: Curt Schilling, the ESPN “Sunday Night Baseball” analyst and former major league pitcher, was pulled from calling a Little League World Series game Tuesday night because of a post he shared on his Twitter account that suggested extremist Muslims were comparable to Nazis. The post featured an image of Adolf Hitler.

headline: South Florida’s Construction Boom Heads North
text: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla. — Known for years as little more than a retirement community with a racetrack and a few pastel-hued motels that had seen better days, this small oceanfront town is not the first place that comes to mind when wealthy Brazilians and Russians seek out expensive condominiums.

headline: In Colorado, Bush Explains Asian Comment
text: Jeb Bush, the Republican presidential candidate, responded on Tuesday to a question about his use of the term “anchor babies.”

headline: Israel Begins Releasing African Migrants From Detention Center
text: JERUSALEM — Israel began releasing hundreds of African migrants and asylum seekers from a detention center in the southern Negev desert on Tuesday, in line with a recent Supreme Court ruling that reduced the time they could be held there to 12 months from 20 months.

headline: Math Anxiety? A Reporter Knows the Subject All Too Well
text: I know exactly when my severe math anxiety began: with my third-grade teacher, Miss S. (I am afraid to write her full name because even if she is no longer among the living, her ghost will most certainly come roaring back and thrust more work sheets at me).

headline: The Idea Lab Behind Harry & Ida’s
text: Siblings and their friends take a science-fair approach to food with delicious results.

headline: The Family Spirit of Harry & Ida’s and Ducks Eatery
text: It is possible to wander into Harry & Ida’s Meat and Supply Co., a delicatessen and provisions shop that opened in June in the East Village, with expectations of nothing more than a good pastrami sandwich.

headline: Photos of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
text: As we edited hundreds of images documenting migrants and refugees making their way from Greece through the Balkans into Hungary, we were compelled to do a Pictures of the Day edit today solely on this subject.

headline: August 25, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: As we edited hundreds of images documenting migrants and refugees making their way from Greece through the Balkans into Hungary, we were compelled to do a Pictures of the Day edit today solely on this subject.

headline: Fall of ‘Beirut Wall’ Reminds Some of Berlin, Others of Miley Cyrus
text: Lebanese officials might still be struggling to solve the trash crisis engulfing Beirut, but they seemed to acknowledge on Tuesday that blocking themselves off from protesters enraged by the stench behind a high concrete wall was not helping.

headline: Alibaba’s Stock Still Looks Expensive
text: Alibaba’s stock price still looks expensive despite the recent sell-off. Less than a year after the Chinese web giant’s record $25 billion initial public offering of stock, its shares are near their $68 initial price. Though macroeconomic worries have afflicted all Chinese companies, the company, founded by Jack Ma, is still highly valued when compared with rivals.

headline: On the Road, in Accessories Form
text: “I might have an escape fantasy,” suggests the New York-based accessories designer Adam Davidson of AANDD, speaking to T from a factory in Mexico. “I certainly fixate on modes of travel,” he continues, mentioning that many of the five-year-old brand’s early shapes and detailing relied on nautical references. For his fall 2015 collection — which includes, for the first time, small leather goods — Davidson found himself thinking about the open road. His Accordion Wallet streamlines motorcyclists’ money-holders and the Key Lanyard resembles the hooded fobs once commonly affixed to car keys. The currant, ochre, white and cobalt blue (or “mineral”) of 1970s auto upholstery hold together the line that’s rounded out by AANDD staples, like the Pyramid Pouch, inspired by a knotted bodega bag. “It’s not a noble inspiration, but it has a good attitude that I can reinterpret in my own aesthetic,” Davidson says. “I’m always watching the way people carry things, wherever I am.”

headline: Political Risks May Foil Economic Reform in China
text: Can China pull it off?

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Under Armour Seeks to Do for Maryland What Nike Did for Oregon
text: Within a few years, the midcentury red-brick field house in the center of the University of Maryland campus will be a glassy, sunlit home of medical facilities and classrooms, as well as an athletic conditioning center, a locker room and three football fields — two outdoors and one inside.

headline: Review: ‘Billion-Dollar Ball’ Explores the Economics of College Football’s Top Programs
text: When it is reported that the University of Alabama pays its head coach an annual salary of $6.5 million a year, or that the University of Oregon erected a $42 million academic support center for it players, or that the University of Texas assesses its fans as much as $20,000 in the form of “seat donations” for preferred locations, it is clear that college football is no longer just a game.

headline: Serena Williams, Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi Play Tennis in the Street
text: Tennis greats convened for a U.S.-Open-themed spectacle.

headline: American Coaches Have a Field Day, but for Other Countries
text: BEIJING — Randy Huntington’s laugh boomed through the hallways of the Bird’s Nest stadium after the long jump competition, making him something of a rarity at the world track and field championships on Tuesday: an American with something to celebrate.

headline: Sydney Theater Company Names New Artistic Director
text: After months of speculation, the Sydney Theater Company has appointed a new artistic director to succeed Andrew Upton, who announced his exit from the position in February.

headline: Tennis Greats Convene for a U.S.-Open-Themed Spectacle
text: In 1995, Andre Agassi and Pete Sampras appeared together in a commercial for Nike. In the ad, a taxi pulls up to a bustling New York intersection; the players run onto the street, unfurl a net and begin a game of pick-up tennis. Last night, in honor of its 20th anniversary — and to mark the 2015 U.S. Open, which begins next week — Sampras and Agassi reconvened to restage the ad, taxi and all, in another made-for-TV (and now, publicist-orchestrated) moment: They played a quick round of tennis in front of fans on a pop-up tennis court in the Meatpacking District. They were joined by Serena Williams, Maria Sharapova, Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer — and many more. Photographer Dina Litovsky was on hand to capture the scene.

headline: How Stressful Work Environments Hurt Workers’ Health
text: A lot of people would not work in a place where co-workers smoke. And most people will never be faced with that decision because smoking is typically banned in the workplace on the sensible ground that secondhand smoke is dangerous to everyone.

headline: Chris Christie Pushes Cory Booker to Oppose Iran Deal
text: Gov. Chris Christie stood before an audience on Tuesday as “the leader of our state,” the golden seal of New Jersey adorning the lectern before him, and excoriated President Obama’s nuclear deal with Iran, accusing the president of lying to the American people and putting the entire world in danger.

headline: Rutgers Investigating Football Coach Over Possible N.C.A.A. Violation
text: Rutgers confirmed Tuesday that it was investigating its football coach, Kyle Flood, over an allegation that he improperly contacted a faculty member about the academic status of a top player.

headline: Midwest Gasoline Prices to Normalize After BP Refinery Repair
text: HOUSTON — BP has restarted a large distillation unit at a refinery outside Chicago that broke down on Aug. 8 and caused a jump in gasoline prices across the Midwest.
