They had brought Puccini to the Times Square subway, Rossini to the depths of Union Square and Verdi to Pennsylvania Station, where they found a semicaptive audience among the beer-swilling commuters of the Long Island Railroad.

headline: Arizona: State Ends Deal With Prison Contractor
text: Gov. Doug Ducey said on Wednesday that the state had canceled its contract with a private prison operator over a series of security and training lapses that set the stage for riots at a prison in July. He also ordered the Department of Corrections to assess operations of all private prisons in the state. Mr. Ducey, a Republican, described the riots, at a minimum-security prison operated by the Management and Training Corporation in Kingman, as “frightening, disturbing and completely unacceptable.” The riots, which began on July 1, forced the transfer of 1,100 prisoners from several housing units that were destroyed. Nine corrections officers suffered minor injuries.

headline: Joe Biden Isn’t Sure Family Is Ready for Run
text: In a conference call on Wednesday, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. told Democratic National Committee members that he was uncertain if his family had the “emotional fuel” for another presidential campaign.

headline: China Holds 23 Linked to Fatal Blasts in Tianjin

headline: Appellate Ruling on Issuing Marriage Licenses to Same-Sex Couples

headline: What’s On TV Thursday
text: 1:45 P.M. (IFC) THE BLUES BROTHERS (1980) Jake (John Belushi, above left, with Dan Aykroyd) and Elwood (Mr. Aykroyd) are on a mission from God to come up with $5,000 so that the Chicago orphanage in which they were raised can pay its taxes and avoid closing. They have to get the Blues Brothers Band back together to play shows to raise the money, which leads them through a series of screwball misadventures, with appearances by John Lee Hooker, Aretha Franklin, James Brown, Ray Charles and others. John Landis (“Animal House”) directed this film.

headline: Let Fear Guide Early Stage Breast-Cancer Decisions
text: TWO patients, I’ll call them Sara and Janine, both learned that they had ductal carcinoma in situ (D.C.I.S.), often referred to as Stage 0 breast cancer. Both underwent lumpectomies in their early 50s. Told that worrisome cells were found, both had another surgery. Then a third surgery was recommended.

headline: Rethinking Warren G. Harding
text: THE last year or so has not been kind to Warren G. Harding, who was the 29th president, from 1921 to 1923. Last summer the Library of Congress released his steamy love letters to his neighbor Carrie Phillips. More recently, some of Harding’s descendants had their DNA tested, to see if there was any truth to the claim of Nan Britton, the author of the tell-all book “The President’s Daughter,” that she had borne Harding’s child. They released the results last month. It turns out she had.

headline: Looking Back on Le Corbusier’s Legacy
text: Fifty years after his death, the influence of Charles-Édouard Jeanneret-Gris, known as Le Corbusier, remains omnipresent in the world of architecture and urban planning. As a recent exhibition at the Pompidou Center showed, his buildings, books, and beliefs continue to stoke vigorous debates.

headline: The Lessons of Anwar al-Awlaki
text: Type ‘‘Anwar al-Awlaki’’ into YouTube’s search bar, and you get 40,000 hits. Most of them bring up the earnest, smiling face and placid voice of the first American citizen to be hunted and killed without trial by his own government since the Civil War. Here is Awlaki on what makes a good marriage; on the nature of paradise; on Jesus Christ, considered a prophet by Muslims; on tolerance; on the holy month of Ramadan; and, more quirkily, on ‘‘obesity and overeating in Islam.’’ Here is Awlaki, or Sheikh Anwar, as his many admirers still call him, easily mixing Quranic Arabic with American English in chapters from his 53-CD series on the life of the Prophet Muhammad, once a best seller among English-speaking Muslims.

headline: A Tour of Lake Michigan, My Inland Sea
text: We left to the south and returned from the north. In doing so, we fulfilled the grandest dream of Magellan, the dream of circumnavigation. Our compass was GPS and our logic was simple. If we kept the lake always on our left and traveled continuously, we would eventually reach the place from which we started — Chicago, with its seismic chart of skyscrapers, protracted sunsets and canyon-like streets, closing the circle by visiting every beach and port on the greatest lake of all, Michigan.

headline: Defying Tradition, and Working Out, to Wear Bridal Crop Tops
text: When Cammy Hébert began planning her May wedding to Nick Miller, she knew a froufrougown would not do. Visions of Emilio Pucci danced in her head: specifically, a photo she came across years ago, in which a model wore a tight short-sleeved crop top and a long skirt reminiscent of a bunch of doilies.

text: Ukraine and its main creditors agreed on Thursday to restructure $18 billion of the country’s foreign debt, in a rare deal between bond funds and a wobbly, emerging-market government.

headline: Today in Politics: Ad Portrays Donald Trump and His Rivals as a Single Voice on Immigration
text: Good Thursday morning. Donald J. Trump‘s heated back-and-forth in Iowa on Tuesday with a respected anchor for a Spanish-language station was a clear display of Mr. Trump’s quirks, but it also highlighted the rising tension his statements and policies on immigration have caused in the party. And a group with ties to Hillary Rodham Clinton is about to pounce.

headline: Real Cambodian Cuisine in Siem Reap
text: One of Southeast Asia’s lesser-known cuisines is getting its due in Siem Reap.

headline: The V.C.s of B.C.
text: One morning, just before dawn, an old man named Assur-idi loaded up two black donkeys. Their burden was 147 pounds of tin, along with 30 textiles, known as kutanum, that were of such rare value that a single garment cost as much as a slave. Assur-idi had spent his life’s savings on the items, because he knew that if he could convey them over the Taurus Mountains to Kanesh, 600 miles away, he could sell them for twice what he paid.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Brock Lesnar
text: A World Wrestling Entertainment production tends to be a ridiculous spectacle: a brash, crass, gleefully obnoxious passion play where herculean men scream, threaten and belittle at the tops of their lungs, then work through their interpersonal issues in front of millions of viewers by pretending to pummel one another senseless, all while wearing colorful spandex. It’s hard to take seriously — that is, until Brock Lesnar enters the arena.

headline: In Siem Reap, Cambodia, Local Fare Gets a Chance to Shine
text: On my first visit to Siem Reap a dozen years ago, I ate pizza, bibimbap and chocolate croissants. What I didn’t eat much of was Cambodian food. As the jumping off point for Angkor Wat, Siem Reap (pronounced SEE-ehm REE-uhp) has long catered to international appetites. Yet it’s only relatively recently that visitors keen to explore local dishes have been able to do so beyond street stalls and mediocre buffets.

headline: Scrutiny Falls on a Spanish Mosque After Foiled Train Attack
text: ALGECIRAS, Spain — Before he boarded a Paris-bound train last week, armed with an assault rifle and the intent, the authorities say, to carry out a blood bath, Ayoub El Khazzani had spent the final chapter of his troubled time in Spain in this gritty port city, living in a run-down apartment block with his parents within walking distance of the local mosque.

headline: Bernie Sanders’s Support: Even More Unequal Than U.S. Incomes
text: The supporters of Bernie Sanders keep telling me that I’m wrong about their coalition, which I’ve written is too narrow to succeed. At this rate, Mr. Sanders doesn’t have nearly enough support among moderate, nonwhite and Southern voters to win the Democratic presidential nomination.

headline: Morning Agenda: China Joins the Rebound
text: CHINA JOINS THE REBOUND | Shares in China rose for the first time in a week on Thursday, following on the heels of a Wall Street rebound, Amie Tsang writes in DealBook. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped into negative territory in the last hour of trading, but shot up to close 5.3 percent higher. Trading volumes were heavy during the period — an indication of state intervention.

headline: First Draft Focus: Throwback Thursday — A Stampede, Before the Stampede
text: A herd of elephants marched in procession in Indianapolis to greet the Republican presidential candidate, Gov. Alf Landon of Kansas, in October 1936.

headline: In Genevieve Hulme-Beaman’s ‘Pondling,’ a Girl Who Only Looks Innocent
text: Genevieve Hulme-Beaman’s dark and eerily transfixing play “Pondling,” seen at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe a year ago, is headed to New York as part of the annual Origin’s 1st Irish Festival, which starts next week. The show, written and performed by Ms. Hulme-Beaman, is about a young girl who at first seems innocent enough, but soon her crush on an older boy brings out a darker side.

headline: Review: ‘Narcos’ Follows the Rise and Reign of Pablo Escobar
text: The small screen offers plenty of post-Vietnam, pre-Sept. 11 nostalgia these days, but don’t expect a warm and fuzzy feeling from “Narcos,” an irresistible drama that begins streaming Friday on Netflix. Expect instead a reminder of a time when a few lawless men did a lot of societal damage by spreading cocaine far and wide.

headline: London Theater Journal: Make ‘Em Dream
text: LONDON — When a show talks about dreaming as much as “Bend It Like Beckham: The Musical” does, a theatergoer can start to feel drowsy. This family-friendly hit, which opened at the Phoenix Theater in June, begins with an open-faced young woman named Jess (Natalie Dew) in a soccer jersey looking, well, dreamy as she croons about how people “say that I’m a dreamer” and “that wishing for the moon will never get me anywhere.”

headline: Introducing Film Club: A New Teaching and Discussion Forum About Short Times Documentaries
text: You probably already know that The New York Times is increasingly publishing video to accompany its articles, but you may not know that The Times is also home to hundreds of short films that go well beyond just reporting the news.

headline: After Virginia TV Shooting, Grief and Calls for Stricter Gun Laws
text: ROANOKE, Va. — Colleagues of the journalists slain a day earlier had a grief-filled return to work here on Thursday, clinging to one another for support and unsure if it was safe to venture out, while Democratic politicians and one victim’s father said the shooting showed the need for tougher gun laws.

headline: Grisly Discovery in Migrant Crisis Shocks Europe
text: VIENNA — The legions of desperate migrants fleeing war and mayhem in the Middle East and Africa have long known they were risking harm from unscrupulous smugglers and death at sea to reach the safety of Europe. But it became shockingly clear on Thursday that they now face the same dangers within Europe’s own borders.

headline: Hungarian Fence Doesn’t Deter Migrants
text: Migrants, hoping to reach the security of wealthier European Union nations, scrambled under a barbed-wire barrier Hungary is erecting to protect its southern border with Serbia.

headline: As Economies Gasp Globally, U.S. Growth Quickens
text: Not long ago, the United States was considered the tortoise of the world economy, at least in comparison to emerging powers like China and Brazil.

headline: In L.A., a Cheaply Constructed Pop-Up Bar That’s a Work of Art
text: It’s a hot August afternoon, and four artists-in-residency at the Los Angeles outpost of the Vienna-based MAK Center are surveying the damage to their collaborative art installation. Empty liquor bottles are everywhere, a banquette needs repair and the paintings lining the wall need to be straightened. This Saturday-afternoon assessment is a weekly ritual after the previous night’s debauchery at Los Bar. Their project, built in the garage of the midcentury architect Rudolph Schindler’s 1939 Mackey Apartments, where the artists are housed for six months, is a 0.65:1 scale replica of the famous Loos Bar in Vienna.

headline: Bargemusic’s ‘Here and Now Labor Day Festival’
text: The week leading up to Labor Day is typically the least-scheduled stretch in New York’s classical music season. But the intrepid Bargemusic, Brooklyn’s floating recital hall, always steps into the brink with a gala program. It does so this week with “Here and Now Labor Day Festival,” an ambitious contemporary music program, repeated four times, offering nine works in either world or New York premieres. There are premieres of two pieces by Dalit Warshaw; a solo cello Soliloquy by Andrew Rudin; David Del Tredici’s Duo for Violin and Cello (“To Be Sung on the Water”); Richard Sussman’s Trio for Violin, Piano and Laptop; and David Taylor’s Concertino for Bass Trombone and Trio. Works by Morton Subotnick, John Zorn and Gordon Beeferman receive New York premieres. Among the enticing roster of 11 performers are the pianist Kathleen Supové, the violinist Jennifer Choi and the bassoonist Peter Kolkay. (8 p.m., Wednesday, Friday and Saturday, with a final performance next Sunday at 4 p.m., bargemusic.org.)

headline: Airbnb Appoints Chris Lehane, Former Aide to Bill Clinton, as Head of Policy
text: For years, Chris Lehane has known how to wage political war inside the Beltway. More recently, he’s been focused on fighting political battles from inside of Silicon Valley.

headline: Only Man Who Can Topple Usain Bolt: A Photographer on a Segway
text: BEIJING — American sprinters like Justin Gatlin? Usain Bolt keeps beating them and then beating his chest, as he did in winning his latest gold medal, in the 200 meters at the world track and field championships.

headline: China Sentences 45 in Restive Region of Xinjiang
text: HONG KONG — Courts across Xinjiang, the volatile region of western China, have sentenced 45 people to prison in recent days after convicting them of supporting organizations accused of terror attacks or of helping others flee abroad, Xinhua, the main state news agency, reported on Thursday.

headline: 1965: Marriage Mania in Las Vegas
text: NEW YORK — The beat-the-draft marriage mania that raged over many parts of the nation last night was best illustrated in Las Vegas, Nev., where 171 couples were married in the rush hours before midnight. By plane, bus and hot rod, the young couples poured into Las Vegas — Nevada requires neither blood test nor prewedding waiting period. In the top of their minds was one frantic thought — President Johnson’s order earlier in the day that a marriage after midnight yesterday would not exempt a man from the draft. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 28, 1965

headline: Daily Report: The Ugly and Antisocial Side of Social Media
text: It is passé to say these days, but maybe it bears repeating after Wednesday: Social media is a powerful thing.

headline: From Indie to Franchise in a Single Bound
text: Independent film for decades has been seen as a way for directors to hold the greatest creative control over their projects. They work with meager means to create something close to their hearts, without the crushing pressure for it to be a global financial success. But having little or no cash to make art can be difficult, so many directors see indies as a steppingstone to the mainstream, a calling card to show studios how their intimate ideas could translate to big-budget projects. That may mean making a number of small films, then a climb up the studio ladder.

headline: The High Bridge, a Scenic and Serene Cousin of the High Line
text: FOR as long as New York has been New York, its inhabitants have looked for ways to escape the city’s frenzy. They have sought out breathable air, fresh vistas or a simple patch of greenery.

headline: Exploring ‘Hamilton’ and Hip-Hop Steeped in Heritage
text: In the hit Broadway musical “Hamilton,” Lin-Manuel Miranda tells the story of Alexander Hamilton, once the most overlooked founding father, by seamlessly weaving hip-hop into a musical theater framework. It’s a novel hybridization, but is Mr. Miranda successfully paying tribute to both traditions or somehow weakening one of them? How specific are his references? How skillful is the rapping? Anthony Tommasini, the chief classical music critic of The New York Times and an avowed musical theater enthusiast, spoke with Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The Times, about technical fluency, Stephen Sondheim and Biggie Smalls. These are excerpts from their conversation.

headline: Can You Match These Artists With Their Childhood Works?
text: Prominent contemporary artists shared some of their earliest works with T. Can you match the past with the present?

headline: Planned Parenthood Videos Were Altered, Analysis Finds
text: WASHINGTON — Planned Parenthood on Thursday gave congressional leaders and a committee that is investigating allegations of criminality at its clinics an analysis it commissioned concluding that “manipulation” of undercover videos by abortion opponents make those recordings unreliable for any official inquiry.

headline: Before Obama’s Alaska Trip, Climate Group Charges Hypocrisy
text: President Obama’s environmental critics are using his own words and images against him as they argue that his planned trip to Alaska next week is proof of what they call his “self-defeating hypocrisy” on global warming.

headline: Business Travelers Warming Up to Car-Sharing
text: IN March, William Petz departed from his usual routine of logging on to Travelocity or Orbitz to rent a car from Budget or Hertz while traveling on business.

headline: Francis Sejersted, 79, Dies; Steered Nobel Peace Prize Into Controversy
text: Francis Sejersted, a Norwegian historian who as the chairman of the Nobel Peace Prize committee presided over several controversial awards, including the one shared by the Israeli leaders Shimon Peres and Yitzhak Rabin and the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, died on Tuesday at his home in Oslo. He was 79.

headline: Rising Anxiety That Stocks Are Overpriced
text: Over the five trading days between Aug. 17 and Aug. 24, the United States stock market dropped 10 percent — the official definition of a correction, with similar or greater drops in other countries.

headline: U.S. Open 2015: Who Will Break Out?
text: All the attention will be on Serena Williams this year, but keep an eye on these players. Vanderbilt tennis coach Geoff Macdonald sizes up their chances.

headline: Catholic Exceptions and Catholic Rules
text: It’s been a little while since I’ve written anything about the still-percolating issue of communion for Catholics who divorce and remarry without an annulment — with Pope Francis’s visit to the U.S. in September and the synod the following month, there will be ample opportunity for Catholic argument this fall — but I didn’t want to let this John Allen column slip too far into the past without highlighting its argument.

headline: Williams Sisters Leave an Impact That’s Unmatched
text: For a sizable portion of nearly two transformative decades, one family surname has competitively dominated tennis and continually inundated its news. Think about how an emerging generation of female players has never known a tour without the headlining Williams sisters, Venus and Serena.

headline: Donald Trump’s Critics Aren’t ‘Politically Correct.’ They’re Outraged
text: It came as no surprise this week that Donald Trump put on a mock Chinese accent and spoke in broken English to criticize the leaders of China and (more to the point) President Obama for even talking to them.

headline: ‘The Daily Show’ Gets Ready to Go Viral
text: Though “The Daily Show” is generally consumed as a once-a-day experience, the political offenses and media misdeeds it chronicles are a 24-hour phenomenon, as any glance at your Facebook or Twitter feed will tell you.

headline: Officials on Bodies in Truck Near Vienna
text: Chancellors Werner Faymann of Austria and Angela Merkel of Germany expressed sorrow on Thursday after police discovered at least 20 bodies of presumed migrants piled in a truck east of Vienna.

headline: Former Hewlett-Packard Board Member Praises Carly Fiorina’s Business Leadership
text: A “super PAC” supporting Carly Fiorina is defending her record as chief executive of Hewlett-Packard in a full-page ad in The New York Times that promotes her strength as a leader of the technology company.

headline: Reflections on Virginia Shooting Victims
text: The boyfriend of Alison Parker, who was killed in a shooting on live television on Wednesday, and the husband of a woman who was injured spoke about their loved ones.

headline: The Food Sermon
text: The bright flavors of the Caribbean in Crown Heights, Brooklyn.

headline: At the Food Sermon, Keeping the Faith in Crown Heights
text: The cross-shape sign says, “Jesus Saves,” or almost: The first S has fallen away. All along this stretch of Rogers Avenue in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, battered-looking storefronts speak of miracles and end times. So the Food Sermon, standing on a corner with its windows shining and its name in letters as yellow as the noon sun, may be mistaken at first for a sleeker, more modern place of worship.

headline: Tyler, the Creator Barred From the United Kingdom
text: Tyler, the Creator, a rapper in the hip-hop collective Odd Future, has reportedly been barred from the United Kingdom because of his provocative lyrical content.

headline: Google Rebuts Europe on Antitrust Charges
text: Google on Thursday rejected claims from the European Union’s top antitrust official that the company favored some of its own search results over those of rivals, saying there was significant competition in the region’s online search market and that the company’s services increased choice for local consumers.

headline: Germany Urges Sharing of Migrant Burden
text: While offering aid to Balkan countries hit by the recent wave of migrants, Germany’s foreign minister, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, called on European Union states to cooperate to solve the crisis.

headline: Sinkhole Swallows Five People in China
text: At least four were injured Saturday when a sinkhole suddenly opened at a bus stop in northern China. A surveillance camera at a nearby noodle shop caught the collapse.

headline: Children React to Panda Cub’s Death
text: Children visiting the Smithsonian National Zoo in Washington shared their feelings on the death of one of the twin cubs born to a giant panda named Mei Xiang.

headline: On The Verge: Elizabeth Suzann

headline: Outrage Over Images of TV Shooting on Newspaper Front Pages
text: Was it newsworthy or over the line? News outlets had to confront that question after Vester Lee Flanagan II fatally shot two television journalists in Virginia on Wednesday and then posted a video of the shooting to his Facebook account.

headline: As Trash Piles Up, So Does Contempt for Lebanon’s Government
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Mohammad Rizk sat glumly in his sandwich shop on Wednesday, waiting for customers. The scent of roasting chicken mingled with the fumes of a trash pile just outside. The garbage heap, which seemed to have taken on a life of its own, now dominated the curb where his drive-by clients once idled.

headline: Dark Shades for a Children’s ‘Hamlet’
text: David Habben had one man in mind when he created the eerie artwork for a new production of “Hamlet” at the Utah Children’s Theater in Salt Lake City.

headline: A Basics Line That Strives for Less-Is-More
text: “I started this company to avoid the excess I saw in clothing — to create comfort and inspire confidence through well-made garments that don’t speak louder than the person wearing them,” says Elizabeth Pape, the 25-year-old founder of the Nashville-based direct-to-consumer label Elizabeth Suzann.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Handling of Email Issue Frustrates Democratic Leaders
text: Democratic leaders are increasingly frustrated by Hillary Rodham Clinton’s failure to put to rest questions about her State Department email practices and ease growing doubts among voters about her honesty and trustworthiness.

headline: What to Do This Weekend
text: The Times arts team is here to help.

headline: Dr. James H. Duke Jr., Texas Trauma Surgeon, Dies at 86
text: Dr. James H. Duke Jr., a Houston trauma surgeon who treated Gov. John Connally of Texas on the day of the Kennedy assassination and reached a national audience through his syndicated television reports on medical topics and his frequent appearances on “Today” and the “NBC Nightly News,” died on Tuesday in Houston. He was 86.

headline: U.S. Open Draw Unveils Serena Williams’s Grand Slam Path
text: The first player standing between Serena Williams and a historic U.S. Open title: Vitalia Diatchenko, a Russian ranked 86th.

headline: 1915: Roosevelt Calls Pacifists ‘Sissies’
text: NEW YORK — Colonel Roosevelt, addressing the New York business men who are training as soldiers at the military instruction camp at Plattsburg, N.Y., to-day, declared that America should support the President only if he was right, and denounced ‘‘hyphenated’’ Americans as enemies of their country and humanity. He also held up to scorn the professional pacifists who require other men to defend them, calling them ‘‘college sissies’’ and ‘‘men with mean souls.’’ — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 28, 1915

headline: Carolyn Maloney, New York Representative, Will Oppose Iran Nuclear Deal
text: Representative Carolyn B. Maloney said on Thursday that she would vote against President Obama’s proposed nuclear deal with Iran, joining Senator Chuck Schumer and other New York Democrats in opposing the White House’s top diplomatic priority.

headline: Closing Remarks in St. Paul’s Rape Trial

headline: Insane Things Republicans Say: Bobby Jindal Edition

headline: MSNBC Moves Al Sharpton’s Daily Show to Sundays
text: The Rev. Al Sharpton’s “PoliticsNation” show on MSNBC is moving from its daily 6 p.m. time slot to a weekly broadcast on Sunday mornings at 8 a.m. starting Oct. 4, the cable news network announced late Wednesday.

headline: Junaid Hussain, ISIS Recruiter, Reported Killed in Airstrike
text: LONDON — A 21-year-old hacker from Birmingham, England, who tapped into American military networks and was a central figure in the Islamic State militant group’s online recruitment campaign, has been killed in Syria by an American airstrike, according to three senior American officials.

headline: Money Managers Look for Stock Bargains in Turmoil
text: The steep market sell-off has spared hardly anyone. Even some of the country’s top-performing portfolio managers have been hit. A fund run by William Miller, the Legg Mason Opportunity Trust, gave back all of this year’s gains of 14 percent. Bill Smead, who manages the Smead Value Fund, lost about 10 percent over the last month. Both funds are now roughly flat over the last year.

headline: Stephen King: Can a Novelist Be Too Productive?
text: THERE are many unspoken postulates in literary criticism, one being that the more one writes, the less remarkable one’s work is apt to be. Joyce Carol Oates, the author of more than 50 novels (not counting the 11 written under the pseudonyms Rosamond Smith and Lauren Kelly), understands perfectly how little use critics have for prolific writers. In one of her journals she wrote that she seemed to create “more, certainly, than the literary world allows for a ‘serious’ writer.”

headline: Champions League Draw: Manchester City in Tough Group With Juventus
text: Manchester City, which has weathered difficult Champions League draws in recent years, will have to do so again after being grouped with Juventus, Sevilla and Borussia Mönchengladbach at the draw in Monaco on Thursday.

headline: Dole C.E.O. and Aide Found Liable for $148 Million in Buyout
text: Taking the Dole Company private in 2013 was nothing new to David H. Murdock, the nonagenarian billionaire who first bought out the fruit seller in 2003.

headline: The Slow Process of Countering the Emerald Ash Borer
text: In 2001, ash trees began dying in Detroit, and no one could say why. Then glittering green beetles were discovered crawling out of an ash log.

headline: Carly Fiorina, Gaining in Polls, Moves to Secure Spot in 2nd G.O.P. Debate
text: WASHINGTON — When Carly Fiorina found herself relegated to the “undercard” for the first Republican primary debate this month, she seized the opportunity to stand out. Clad in a bright pink suit, the only woman in a sea of men, she delivered a forceful performance that catapulted her into the national spotlight and generated a bounce in public polls.

headline: Spike Lee, Gena Rowlands, Debbie Reynolds to Receive Honorary Oscars
text: LOS ANGELES—Spike Lee, fiercely independent in both his films and public remarks, will receive an honorary Oscar from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, as he joins the actresses Gena Rowlands and Debbie Reynolds among those to be honored at the group’s Governors Awards on Nov. 14.

headline: No Comment Necessary: “China Is the World’s Biggest Democracy”
text: Those who describe India and the United States as the world’s biggest democracies are missing something, according to Han Zhen, the head of Beijing Foreign Studies University. “We should speak with great confidence that China is the world’s biggest democracy,” he wrote on Thursday in an op-ed in a Chinese state-run newspaper. “If we don’t, it means we have admitted we are a non-democracy.”

headline: Hillary Clinton Likens Republican Views on Women to Those of Terror Groups
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton compared Republican presidential candidates to terrorist groups when it comes to their views on women, arguing that their “extreme” positions are not right for 21st-century America.

headline: At La Garagista, Hybrid Grapes Stand Up to Vermont’s Elements
text: BARNARD, Vt. — Wine is now made in all 50 states, though few suggest much of it is any good. But on a hillside just outside this small town in central Vermont, a little east of the Killington ski resort, Deirdre Heekin makes wines under the label La Garagista that are so soulful and delicious, they challenge crucial assumptions long taken for granted.

headline: No One to Rescue Me From My Drinking
text: “It’s sort of lounge-y in here,” I remarked to my co-worker as I walked past his office late one April afternoon. The room’s fluorescent lights were off, and jazz floated quietly from his computer.

headline: Second City Assesses Losses After Fire
text: A day after a fire ripped through the offices of Second City, the comedy theater and school in Chicago, the theater’s staff members were coming to terms with their loss.

headline: ISIS Suicide Attack Kills 2 Iraqi Generals Near Ramadi
text: BAGHDAD — In a further setback to the faltering American and Iraqi campaign to retake Anbar Province from the Islamic State, two Iraqi generals were killed in a suicide attack by the group Thursday morning outside Ramadi, the provincial capital.

headline: School Lunches Becoming Healthier, Statistics Indicate
text: WASHINGTON — The humble school lunch, that staple of most every American child’s diet, has become healthier.

headline: Joe Biden Has Meeting With Head of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is meeting Thursday with Richard L. Trumka, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., a person briefed on the get-together confirmed.

headline: When a Child Comes Knocking, Selling Candy
text: I am a gay woman who lives near a single mother and her sweet 9-year-old son. The boy goes to a Roman Catholic parochial school. Every other minute he is knocking on my door, trying to sell me something to benefit the school. (This week it was candy for the athletic department.) I like these neighbors, but I have little interest in supporting private schools and even less interest in supporting church schools that take a dim view of my marriage. How can I deal with these neighbors nicely?

headline: Miley Cyrus’s Style
text: The performer’s fashion choices and physique make of her a natural avatar for a post-gender generation.

headline: Local Nets, Not Faraway Markets, Key to New Zealand’s Dolphin Decline
text: In my latest piece on how Chinese appetites for an endangered fish are indirectly driving Mexico’s tiny porpoise, the vaquita, to extinction, I passingly mentioned the world’s other deeply imperiled toothed whale — New Zealand’s Maui’s dolphin. This diminutive marine mammal is a subspecies of that country’s Hector’s dolphin. The subspecies is down to fewer than 50 individuals by some counts, largely because of drownings in towed and anchored fishing nets.

headline: Miley Cyrus’s Style: An Exuberant Sexuality
text: Like dog years, media hours multiply. Although Miley Cyrus is 22, so much of her life has been spent in front of the camera that it seems as if we’ve been studying her image for an exponentially longer period of time, watching her evolve in front of the mechanical lens and in a fast-changing society.

headline: Many Psychology Findings Not as Strong as Claimed, Study Says
text: The past several years have been bruising ones for the credibility of the social sciences. A star social psychologist was caught fabricating data, leading to more than 50 retracted papers. A top journal published a study supporting the existence of ESP that was widely criticized. The journal Science pulled a political science paper on the effect of gay canvassers on voters’ behavior because of concerns about faked data.

headline: A Fake Goldman Sachs Underlines a Real Chinese Strength
text: The Goldman Sachs leasing company in Shenzhen is as genuine as the Apple store in Kunming and the $5 bottle of Château Lafite-Rothschild in Beijing. Wall Street’s best-known investment bank has joined an illustrious list of Chinese fakes that belie a very real Chinese strength.

headline: SoundCloud Sued for Copyright Infringement by PRS for Music
text: SoundCloud, a popular music-streaming website that has previously clashed with the music industry, has been sued in connection with copyright infringement by a British agency that represents songwriters.

headline: Kari Soinio’s “City of Ghosts” Series
text: The photographer manipulates his photos to create a Manhattan that seems, as he says, “both familiar and utterly foreign.”

headline: Untangling the Mysteries of Personal Technology
text: In tech land, it has become commonplace to obsess over every shiny new device — and forget why we buy all this stuff in the first place.

headline: Haunting Images That Make New York Landmarks Feel New Again
text: When he landed in New York City as a first-time tourist in 1990, the Finnish photographer Kari Soinio — like so many visitors before and after him — was struck by the breathtaking sweep of the Manhattan skyline. When he returned to live downtown for an artist residency in 2006, his gaze was again drawn upward. “I was amazed by the canyon of high-rises,” he says, “and the whole idea of the newcomer looking up.” It was with this view in mind that he embarked on an ongoing series, “City of Ghosts,” which combines street and architectural photography. Soinio captures the beauty of the city’s renowned landmarks — the Washington Square Arch, the Flatiron and Woolworth buildings — and pulls them into the foreground, while unwitting passersby become shadowy, anonymous characters in a duet between pedestrian and monument. Shooting with a 4x5-inch camera with no viewfinder, the defocused scene is “both familiar and utterly foreign,” as Soinio puts it, thanks to his manipulation of the images’ depths of field. “In the happy accident of photography, if you really know your camera, you can do so much,” he says. As “City of Ghosts” has continued, Soinio has shifted his attention to the changing urban landscape and the new glass towers that now reach skyward. In an age during which it’s never been more tempting to keep your eyes glued to a screen while traversing the urban landscape, his photos are a welcome reminder: Look up!

headline: A Home’s Story, Told in Dust, Bacteria and Fungi
text: An analysis of dust from 1,200 homes across the continental United States provides new information about the fungal and bacterial communities sharing the great indoors with us.

headline: Fines for College Football Players? Not So Fast
text: In the lead-up to the first college sports season in which players for the nation’s biggest programs will receive stipends worth as much as several thousand dollars per year, recent remarks from two prominent football coaches have revealed that confusion still exists about how to treat athletes who are ostensibly amateurs yet now receive checks from their teams.

headline: Labor Board Ruling Eases Way for Fast-Food Unions’ Efforts
text: WASHINGTON — The National Labor Relations Board, in a long-awaited ruling, made it easier on Thursday for unions to negotiate on behalf of workers at fast-food chains and other companies relying on contractors and franchisees.

headline: Trump Reads The Times at a Rally
text: Donald Trump, the Republican presidential candidate, reacted to an article about himself in The New York Times on Thursday at a campaign rally in Greenville, S.C.

headline: Donald Trump’s Latest Target: The New York Times
text: Theatricality is a staple of Donald J. Trump’s campaign events. On Thursday, during a speech in Greenville, S.C., he deployed a new prop: a copy of The New York Times, from which he read, on and off, for about eight minutes — alternately praising and mocking a front-page article about him. When he was done, Mr. Trump dramatically flung the newspaper into the air, allowing it to slowly descend over the audience.

headline: Pull on My Hair, Donald Trump Says: ‘I Don’t Wear a Toupee’
text: Donald J. Trump brought his free-association presidential campaign to Greenville, S.C., on Thursday, following up a cavalier reference to the “silent majority” that supports him with an annotated reading of a New York Times front-page article about him and then with an invitation to a woman in the crowd to yank his hair (“I don’t wear a toupee — it’s my hair”).

headline: Miley Cyrus on Nicki Minaj and Hosting a ‘Raw’ MTV Video Music Awards
text: LOS ANGELES — This weekend, Miley Cyrus is throwing a rager. Everyone’s invited, and MTV is footing the bill.

headline: Architectural Salvage at a Brooklyn Church
text: A Manhattan salvage business is stripping the interior of the Church of the Redeemer, which was sold to a real estate company last year.

headline: At This Brooklyn Church, Everything Must Go
text: On a recent Saturday morning, dust choked the air, and debris rained inside the Church of the Redeemer in Brooklyn, just south of the Atlantic Terminal transit hub. Shards of stained glass panes had fallen onto remnants of floral floor tiles, near stacks of dirt-covered hymnals and mangled metal ceiling panels. Workers were hammering apart walls and carrying walnut pews, which were to be offered for sale at the Demolition Depot in Manhattan.

headline: The Virginia Shooter Wanted Fame. Let’s Not Give It to Him.
text: A BRUTAL attack takes place on live television; the on-air reporter and cameraman are fatally shot while at work on an early morning story.

headline: The Ultimate Tennis Mom
text: Judy Murray, the British Fed Cup team captain and mother of Andy and Jamie Murray, explains how she “harnessed the talent” of her young boys on and off the tennis court.

And now, a court has banned the release of a film about a building collapse that killed more than 1,100 garment workers in 2013.

headline: Clarence Thomas, a Supreme Court Justice of Few Words, Some Not His Own
text: WASHINGTON — Justice Clarence Thomas has not asked a question from the Supreme Court bench since 2006. His majority opinions tend to be brisk, efficient and dutiful.

headline: A Male Túngara Frog’s Mating Signal
text: A male túngara frog calling within a chorus in Gamboa, Panama, in search of a potential mate.

headline: A Twist to How a Túngara Frog Finds Her Prince
text: Given a choice of two males, female túngara frogs will select the most attractive — those with calls of a low frequency and long duration. But when a third male who is inferior is added to the lineup, researchers have found, females often choose the less attractive of the first two. In a study published in the journal Science, scientists at the University of Texas, Austin, and at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute suggest that when a social situation becomes too complex, obvious decisions become too burdensome for the frogs. A similar effect has been observed in humans, suggesting that irrationality in mate selection may have deep biological roots.

text: THE SECOND MOTHER

headline: Living With Cancer: Collateral Damage
text: When I was invited to attend a prostate cancer group called “Us Too” in my town, its members were meeting in a private room in our public library. About eight men, some accompanied by their wives, had great difficulty communicating their discomfort about urine leaks and diapers. They wanted to know what strategies my gynecological cancer group used to talk about sexual issues. To alleviate their daily problems, the participants needed professional help that I could not furnish.

headline: Review: Recalling Ray Johnson, a Pioneer of Mail Art

headline: A Ruschmeyer’s-Style Lobster Boil, Starring the Sussman Brothers
text: Like many true New Yorkers, Eli and Max Sussman of Brooklyn’s Samesa are spending the summer in Montauk, as executive chefs at Ruschmeyer’s restaurant. “Working closely with Hamptons farms and fishermen has been an incredible experience — both the personal, daily relationships and the ability to obtain the freshest products possible,” Eli tells T. “And living this close to the beautiful beaches is a very solid way to spend the summer.” Here, the Sussmans (who are originally from Detroit) demonstrate how to make a lobster boil, Ruschmeyer’s style. And below, they share a recipe for the perfect starter or side dish, a light ceviche that plays on different flavors, “but fits perfectly into the seafood theme of an East Coast boil.”

headline: Eric Cancel, an Apprentice Jockey at Saratoga, Listens and Learns
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — It was the nightcap, the final race on Monday’s card, and all Eric Cancel had to show for his afternoon was dirty riding pants. His horses had so far managed to beat only two horses in three races. When he got a leg up on his final mount of the day, Confessa, the words of his agent and mentor, Angel Cordero Jr., rattled in his head.

headline: Met Announces Extended Hours for Chinese Fashion Show
text: The long goodbye for “China: Through the Looking Glass” just got a little longer: The Metropolitan Museum of Art is extending hours for the exhibition’s final weekend.

headline: For Some New York Latinos, Enthusiasm for de Blasio Gives Way to Frustration
text: In December 2013, Bill de Blasio, then the mayor-elect, made a series of high-level appointments that heartened many people in the Latino and Hispanic community.

headline: Daniel Barenboim Provokes Backlash Over Iran Concert
text: News that one of the most respected — and outspoken — Israeli musicians in the world, Daniel Barenboim, is hoping to conduct a concert in Iran with the Berlin Staatskapelle drew a furious reaction this week from Israel’s right-wing culture minister.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Hungary and Elsewhere

headline: MTV VMAs 2015: Nominees Offer a Bundle of Contradictions
text: NOWADAYS, music videos are anomalous in MTV’s programming; the debacles of teenage moms and “catfished” romantics claim the airspace once occupied by Britney Spears and Michael Jackson. But the network’s Video Music Awards show — now headed for its 32nd installment — endures as an annual spectacle of theatrical pop performances, salacious onstage antics and reliable scandals. (Bet on that this year, as the reigning V.M.A.s provocateur Miley Cyrus will host.)

headline: Hillary Clinton Reaches Deal With Democratic Party on Fund-Raising
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton and the Democratic National Committee have finalized a joint fund-raising agreement after months of negotiations, opening the door for the party to gain a significant head start on Republicans at roping in big checks from Democratic donors.

headline: August 27, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Hungary, Nigeria, Ukraine and China.

headline: The Role of Décor in Hitler’s Life
text: A new book by the architectural historian Despina Stratigakos, “Hitler at Home” (Yale University Press), arriving next month, details how that dictator showed “an enthusiastic interest in even the smallest detail” of his décor. His favorite interior designer, Gerdy Troost, who died in 2003 at 98, saved her voluminous papers.

headline: Review: In ‘When Animals Dream’ a Teenager’s Secret Is a Revelation Even to Her
text: In American popular culture, lycanthropy has typically been a guy thing. For the hapless Eisenhower-era protagonist of “I Was a Teenage Werewolf” and for the studly Jacob Black in the “Twilight” movies, sprouting fur, fangs and claws was a metaphor for uncontrollable adolescent male rage. But girls are angry, too, and the teenage werewolf in “When Animals Dream,” a spare and smart Danish thriller, comes of age in particularly infuriating circumstances.

headline: Agent Cleared Over 2010 Florida Shooting Inquiry, but Lawyer Lashes Out
text: Four years ago, a Florida state investigator was drawn into a highly contentious case involving a young single mother who was in the process of breaking up with her boyfriend, a St. Johns County deputy sheriff, when she was killed with the officer’s service weapon.

headline: U.S. to Join Inquiry Into Death of New York Prisoner
text: The office of the United States attorney in Manhattan announced on Thursday that it was joining the investigation into the death of Samuel Harrell, a prisoner at the Fishkill Correctional Facility in Beacon, N.Y., who inmate witnesses say was handcuffed and beaten severely this year by a group of corrections officers.

headline: Review: ‘The Sympathizer,’ a Novel About a Soldier, Spy and Film Consultant
text: There’s a great comic interlude in Viet Thanh Nguyen’s novel “The Sympathizer” when the unnamed narrator, a Vietnamese Army captain exiled in Los Angeles, critiques the screenplay of a gung-ho Hollywood movie about America’s heroism in the Vietnam War.

headline: Days of Unrest Turn Deadly in Indian State of Gujarat
text: NEW DELHI — The authorities in the Indian state of Gujarat struggled to restore calm on Thursday after two days of widespread unrest and deadly clashes between residents and the police. Curfews remained in Ahmedabad, the state’s largest city, and a state court ordered an inquiry into allegations of police brutality.

headline: Review: In ‘Z for Zachariah,’ an End-of-Days Love Triangle
text: “Z for Zachariah” may not be the most eventful post-apocalyptic drama, but its grip is strong and sure. Set in a verdant valley (with New Zealand standing in for the American South) that has somehow survived the fallout from an unspecified nuclear catastrophe, this minimalist but deeply affecting morality play slowly tugs you in.

headline: Loving Queens: Reporter’s Notebook

headline: U.S. Open Stars Juggle Preparation With Publicity
text: Nike organized street tennis for Maria Sharapova, Roger Federer and others in the meatpacking district. Tommy Hilfiger opted for strip tennis with Rafael Nadal in Bryant Park. Delta Air Lines held a celebrity karaoke night with Serena Williams near Times Square. And American Express staged what it called a “hydro-interactive tennis experience” featuring Ms. Sharapova along the Hudson River.

headline: Review: ‘Made in the Americas’ Explores Globalism From Way, Way Back
text: BOSTON — One of the great gifts that multiculturalist thinking gave us was final freedom from the tyranny of purity. Simply put, that old ideal was revealed as an illusion. It doesn’t exist, at least not in art. There, in reality, everything is a mix. Wonderfully, the longer and closer we look, the richer the mix becomes. And this has always been true. Globalism, which we take to be so 21st century, with its networks and mash-ups, is as old as the hills.

headline: A New Mexican Restaurant That Doesn’t Skimp on the Spice
text: The restaurateur Dario Wolos began making tacos a decade ago, selling them out of a Volkswagen bus in Mexico. Since then, he’s moved to New York and opened four restaurants, all called Tacombi, around the city, each focusing on a different Mexican regional cuisine. The fifth, Tacombi West Village, opens on the corner of Bleecker and Cornelia streets in September. Wolos and his chef, Jason DeBriere — who honed his kitchen chops at restaurants Washington Park, Barbuto and Peels — traveled throughout the Yucatán, stopping at roadside stands and markets in search of dishes and flavors they could bring back to New York. “We wanted to focus and bring these flavors from the Yucatán, because there wasn’t a lot of representation,” DeBriere says.

headline: Review: ‘Grand Illusions’ Showcases Deceptive Photography
text: “Grand Illusions: Staged Photography From the Met Collection” is a small, choice, concentrated exhibition. Ensconced in modest galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, its 40 works are drawn entirely from that museum’s collection and form a freewheeling introduction to staged photography. This tactic — arranging objects or people for the camera — began with photography’s invention; figured prominently in portraiture, commercial and Surrealist lines of work; and entered mainstream art full throttle in the 1980s, with the arrival of the Pictures Generation and postmodernism.

headline: Review: ‘Endless House’ Expands the Definition of Home
text: If modern architecture has a quintessential building type, it is the apartment block — those functional, rigidly structured urban compressors that made architecture a form of social planning. The single-family home, by contrast, was a more suspicious thing. It stood for individualism, and therefore against progress — or at least the kind of progress envisioned in the grand metropolitan plans of the last century.

headline: When Airlines Looked Cool and Showed It
text: In more ways than one, “Airline Visual Identity, 1945-1975” (Callisto Publishing) is a hefty piece of work, landing at 430 pages, weighing 14 pounds and selling for $400. But the true size of its ambition is how it reveals the optimism of the Jet Age through nearly 400 posters and images from airlines like Pan Am, TWA, and United, evoking a time now seen as the golden age of flying.

headline: Inside the List
text: Proust For The People: Almost 100 years after his death, Marcel Proust has finally cracked the best-seller list. Sort of. The French artist Stéphane Heuet’s illustrated interpretation of “Swann’s Way,” the first volume of Proust’s sprawling semiautobiographical novel “In Search of Lost Time,” is at No. 5 in its seventh week on the graphic novel hardcover list.

headline: New York Captured Between the Day and the Dark
text: These last nights of summer, the dark never quite arrives, not in the city. It lingers in the future, along with the fall harvest and the winter cold, not so much an absence of light as the ink for a page unready to be written yet. It will come, bringing definition and clarity. For now there is just miasma.

By day, watched by gun-toting soldiers, they line up to cross what was once a busy international bridge now under military lockdown, dragging roller suitcases while their children shoulder school backpacks.

headline: What’s On TV Friday
text: 8 P.M. (TCM) CASABLANCA (1942) Casablanca, Morocco, is a refuge from Nazi-occupied Europe during World War II. Rick (Humphrey Bogart) runs a cafe, where, one evening, his ex-lover Ilsa (Ingrid Bergman, above with Bogart) turns up with her husband, Victor (Paul Henreid), and Rick becomes tormented by the memory of his life with Ilsa in Paris. Eventually, the cafe is occupied by Nazis as well, and Rick becomes tangled up with them, Ilsa and Victor. The film won three Academy Awards. “Mr. Bogart is, as usual, the cool, cynical, efficient and super-wise guy who operates his business strictly for profit but has a core of sentiment and idealism inside,” Bosley Crowther wrote in The Times in 1942. “In short, we will say that ‘Casablanca’ is one of the year’s most exciting and trenchant films. It certainly won’t make Vichy happy — but that’s just another point for it.”

headline: Europe Reels From More Migrant Deaths on Land and Sea

Damage to the vehicle’s side raised the possibility that victims had struggled to escape.

headline: Bernie Sanders’s Small-Beer Donors in the Big Money Casino
text: As a measure of democracy, one of the more encouraging statistics of the 2016 presidential race is the fact that the average contribution to the long-shot campaign of Senator Bernie Sanders is $31.30. It would be hard to buy any politician for $31.30. That is exactly the message Mr. Sanders intends, in renouncing fat-cat, super PAC campaigning that is turning American politics into an exercise in plutocracy.

headline: When ISIS Rapists Win
text: The ISIS atrocities have descended like distant nightmares upon the numbed conscience of the world. The first beheadings of Americans had the power to shock, but since then there has been a steady barrage of inhumanity: mass executions of Christians and others, throwing gay men from rooftops, the destruction of ancient archaeological treasures, the routine use of poison gas.

headline: A Refugee Tragedy in Austria
text: European leaders attending a summit meeting Thursday in Vienna had already shifted their focus to Europe’s growing refugee crisis when the terrible news came: the decomposing bodies of more than 70 people, assumed to be refugees smuggled into Europe, were discovered packed in a truck only miles away, apparently abandoned by human traffickers.

headline: How Common Core Can Help in the Battle of Skills vs. Knowledge
text: Washington — STANDARDIZED tests are commonly blamed for narrowing the school curriculum to reading and math. That’s one reason Congress is considering changes in the law that could lead states to put less emphasis on test scores. But even if we abolished standardized tests tomorrow, a majority of elementary schools would continue to pay scant attention to subjects like history and science.

headline: Bill Bryson Fears Humans More Than Bears

text: MASON, Ohio — The last time Mardy Fish played in the U.S. Open, he departed crumpled in anxiety, fear and tears.

headline: ‘Mirror. Memory’
text: Cultural memory often involves a good measure of willed forgetting, an overlooking of some parts of experience in favor of a dominant narrative. In this poem, the precise imagery of faces reflected in a kettle — “misted and revealed” — hints at how these subjects are at once obscured and plainly seen. Here, the memory of people who are often left out of history is set against the imagery of the painting, connected by the single long sentence from which the poem is made.

headline: European Publishers Play Lobbying Role Against Google
text: BERLIN — In private sessions this summer, giant publishers and media companies from Germany, France and elsewhere have met with European officials about proposals to regulate Europe’s digital economy. The discussions have covered a broad range of contentious issues, according to public disclosures and several people who attended or were briefed on the meetings. Central to almost all of them has been limiting the reach of a single American company: Google.

headline: Tirana, Breaking Free From Communist Past, Is a City Transformed
text: You begin to understand Tirana, the capital of Albania, the first time you try to cross the city’s main road, which locals simply refer to as Boulevard. There are zebra-striped crosswalks, and cars stop if they must, but the feat is something akin to stage diving into a free-form automotive ballet. Confidence is the operative word here — coupled with an understanding that Albanians live by a rhythmic, improvisational code: Fill space when it’s free.

headline: The 8.16.15 Issue
text: Readers respond to our 8.16.2015 issue.

headline: Myanmar Democracy Icon Finds Herself Assailed as Authoritarian
text: YANGON, Myanmar — Framed photographs of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel laureate, cover the walls of his small living room, but U Myo Khin, a longtime democracy activist, has harsh words for the woman he idolized for years as a crusader against dictatorship.

headline: Morning Agenda: Investors Seek Signal in the Noise
text: INVESTORS SEEK SIGNAL IN THE NOISE | Asian markets continued to soar on Friday, on the back of a global rebound on Thursday. The fear was palpable just days ago, but by the end of Thursday, the gloom had dissipated, DealBook’s Peter Eavis reports. The Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index had climbed 6 percent from the low of Tuesday’s close by the end of Thursday.

headline: Officials Discuss Austrian Truck Tragedy
text: Three people held in Hungary are being questioned after the bodies of 71 people, believed to be Syrian migrants, were found in a truck near Vienna.

headline: Antonio Banderas Sets a Celebrity Fashion Precedent at Central St. Martins
text: There’s a new name on the roll call of celebrities in the fashion sphere. Joining Victoria Beckham, Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen, Sarah Jessica Parker, John Malkovich and Kanye West is … Antonio Banderas.

headline: Steady Financial Advice, With Friendship as a Bonus
text: CHICAGO — Anxiety-prone investors looking for safety in the stock market have sometimes found it in so-called widows-and-orphans stocks. At their best, they pay dividends for decades and bounce around a bit less when the markets convulse, as they have over the last week. For years, AT&T was the textbook example. Procter & Gamble was another.

headline: Tennessee Williams Short Stories, Now as One-Acts
text: The Acting Company has commissioned evenings like “Desire” before — a program of Chekhov adaptations in the 1980s, when Spalding Gray and Wendy Wasserstein were among the playwrights; in the 1990s, a slate of short plays inspired by Shakespeare’s sonnets, by writers including Tony Kushner and Ntozake Shange.

headline: Play About Incarcerated Women Wins Best of Edinburgh Award
text: EDINBURGH — The real stories and experiences of women in a United Kingdom prison form the basis for “Key Change,” this year’s winner of the annual Carol Tambor Best of Edinburgh Award, to be announced here on Friday. The award is presented each year to a single theater production at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe that has never been presented in New York City, and the winning show is produced the following winter in New York. Past winners of the prize include “The Object Lesson,” written and performed by Geoff Sobelle, and David Greig’s “The Events.”

headline: Video Reviews of  ‘When Animals Dream,’ ‘Queen of Earth,’ and ‘No Escape.’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “When Animals Dream,” “Queen of Earth,” and “No Escape.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Jozef Wesolowski, Ex-Archbishop Accused of Sexual Abuse, Dies at 67
text: ROME — Jozef Wesolowski, a Polish former archbishop who would have been the first high-level cleric to stand before a Vatican tribunal on charges of child sexual abuse, was found dead early Friday, the Vatican said in a statement. He was 67.

headline: About 150 Migrants Feared Dead After Boats Sink Off Libya
text: CAIRO — About 150 people are believed to have drowned off western Libya after a fishing boat and a smaller boat carrying migrants sank in the Mediterranean, Libyan and international relief officials said on Friday.

headline: National Security Adviser Meets With Chinese President Before His U.S. Visit
text: BEIJING — President Obama’s national security adviser, Susan E. Rice, met in Beijing on Friday with several Chinese leaders, including President Xi Jinping and a senior army general, to discuss a number of issues that included areas of tension between the two nations. Her meetings were in preparation for the scheduled state visit next month by the Chinese president to the United States.

headline: No Crying Over Spilled Chicken
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Zombie Factories Stalk the Sputtering Chinese Economy
text: Miao Leijie loses money on each ton of cement his company produces. But stopping production is not an option.

headline: Test Yourself: 5 Questions From an 8th-Grade Math Test
text: This month, New York State reported that just 22 percent of the eighth graders who took this year’s Common Core-aligned math test received a passing mark. How do you compare?

headline: What’s on This Week Around the World
text: Gwangju, South Korea

headline: Regenerative Medicine Researcher Cleared of Scientific Misconduct Charges
text: A prominent researcher in the field of regenerative medicine was cleared on Friday of charges of scientific misconduct by the Karolinska Institute, the Swedish medical university where he had done much of his pioneering work.

headline: The How-on-Earth Garden
text: If there were a competition for tackling decidedly out-of-the-ordinary landscaping projects, David Kelly, a landscape designer, would be on auto-entry.

headline: Mishka Henner Uses Google Earth as Muse
text: “There’s an absurdity to living in an age when everything is photographed,” Mishka Henner, a Belgian-born artist, said recently from his home in Manchester, England, emphasizing, in particular, that every square inch of the earth seems to have been photographed and all of it is accessible online — including some of the world’s most secret places.

headline: A City Rises in Queens for the U.S. Open
text: Every August since 1978, a city within a city has popped up in Flushing Meadows, Queens. In just a few weeks, the corner of an almost 900-acre public park is transformed into the United States Open, along with its six fully staffed restaurants and 60 concessions stands, 20 stocked and staffed stores, five active loading docks, dozens of artfully landscaped tennis courts and strolling areas, a police force the size of a small Montana town, and three stadiums filled with passionate tennis fans, some of whom will probably soon be dancing the “Whip/Nae Nae” for the “spider cam” at Arthur Ashe Stadium. All of this hustle and bustle will help to bring in an estimated $700 million-plus for the New York area.

headline: Rethinking Work
text: HOW satisfied are we with our jobs?

headline: Queens as a Tourist Destination? Readers React
text: An article Wednesday on the rising number of tourists visiting Queens — attributed to the Lonely Planet guidebook’s designating the borough to be the No. 1 travel destination in the country this year — attracted reader responses from along the No. 7 train line and beyond.

headline: Daily Report: From thefacebook.com to One Billion Users in a Single Day
text: Facebook hit quite a milestone on Thursday.

headline: Facing Retirement, but Easing Your Way Out the Door
text: SEVEN years ago, Steve E. Norwitz, who was then a 61-year-old executive at the Baltimore mutual fund group T. Rowe Price, proposed a scaled-down work schedule that would reduce his duties.

headline: 1998 in 2015
text: David Beckworth has a good if possibly over-elaborate discussion of China’s flirtation with crisis. What I find striking is the extent to which China has managed to put itself into something like the situation many of its neighbors faced in the late 1990s. The renminbi “wants” to depreciate, partly because of a slowing economy and monetary easing, partly because of a crisis of confidence and capital flight. But Chinese authorities aren’t willing to let it drop all the way, perhaps because of fears of trade conflict but also perhaps because the private sector and state-owned enterprises now have a lot of foreign-currency debt.

headline: Credit Default Swaps for North America
text: The credit default swaps for North American companies with the biggest one-day change in either tightening (reduced risk) or widening (increased risk).

headline: In Stieg Larsson’s Head, but His Own Man
text: STOCKHOLM — The saga of Lisbeth Salander continues, and David Lagercrantz, who has written the sequel to Stieg Larsson’s wildly popular “Millennium” trilogy, is both proud and deeply anxious over how millions of readers will receive it.

headline: Human Obstacle Surprises Horse, Ends Ireland’s Olympics Bid
text: Ireland’s show jumping team was looking good to qualify for next summer’s Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro. The Olympic medalist Cian O’Connor was perfect through 10 fences.

headline: 1890: France-U.S. Trade Dispute
text: No one denies that if the American pig is addicted to the dissemination of trichinosis and if French wines are unwholesome, France has legally the right to exclude pigs from her territory and the United States has the right to exclude French wines. But is it not rather absurd to exclude pigs and wine and admit tourists? In old days the ocean passage was so long that if a traveler had contracted a contagious or infectious disease before starting, it was certain to be developed before the passage was ended.

headline: Fear of Asymmetry
text: David Roberts has a very nice essay on American politics, framed as an analysis of what nerds don’t get; but it’s not just nerds who seem weirdly blind to the reality here.

headline: Tax-Free Savings Accounts for Disabled Are Expected in 2016
text: SPECIAL savings accounts for people with disabilities are likely to become available in most states next year.

headline: 1940: Color Television to Start Jan. 1
text: A demonstration of television in full color was shown privately to James L. Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, by the Columbia Broadcasting System yesterday in its laboratories at 485 Madison Avenue. Paul W. Kesten, vice-president of C.B.S., said the company expected to be broadcasting color television commercially by Jan. 1. The system used, which was developed by Dr. Peter C. Goldmark, C.B.S. chief television engineer, would not render existing television sets obsolete, Mr. Kesten said. The receiver used in the demonstration was of standard type, adjusted to a minor extent and equipped with a simple attachment which can be produced at comparatively small costs, while other tests proved that standard sets without any adjustment would receive black and white images broadcast by the new method. — New York Herald Tribune, August 30, 1940

headline: Stuff We Liked: TV Show Finales and Timeless Songs
text: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Glenn Ligon
text: For his new bookshop installation, One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next installment in the series comes from the conceptual artist Glenn Ligon, who shares his picks exclusively with T.

headline: Governor Christie’s Gift to Exxon Mobil
text: For years, New Jersey officials have been trying to make Exxon Mobil Corporation pay for their “staggering and unprecedented” pollution of the state’s northeastern wetlands. The price tag for damages and cleanup of more than 1,500 acres in the Linden and Bayonne areas was estimated at $8.9 billion. Gov. Chris Christie settled for a payout of $225 million from Exxon, a paltry sum that won the approval of a state judge earlier this week.

headline: Marco Rubio Lashes Out at Hillary Clinton Over ‘Terrorist’ Remark
text: Senator Marco Rubio hit back at Hillary Rodham Clinton on Friday for comparing Republicans to terrorists when it comes to their views on women.

headline: Virginia Shooting Victims Were Hit in Head, Autopsies Show
text: The Virginia television reporter and cameraman whose murder on live television has renewed a national debate over gun violence both suffered gunshot wounds to the head, the chief medical examiner’s office in Roanoke said Friday.

headline: Inventive Menus at Soho House Berlin’s New Restaurant
text: On a recent Thursday evening in the fashionable neighborhood of Mitte, a crowd of artists and D.J.s descended on a large marble-top table loaded with seasonal dishes: radishes served with freshly churned kefir butter; Dutch oysters flavored with ponzu ginger and chile. Within 20 minutes, the platters were empty. This record release party took place at the Store Kitchen, a new restaurant within a recently opened design emporium called the Store, off the lobby of Soho House.

headline: Obama Says New Orleans Inspires Him
text: President Obama delivered a speech in New Orleans on Thursday at an event commemorating the 10th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina. The president praised the city’s efforts to rebuild.

headline: In Flushing: Upscale Condos and Retail
text: For much of the city’s Asian community, the center of New York City is not in Manhattan, but in downtown Flushing, Queens, the bustling shopping district at the end of the No. 7 subway line. Soon this crowded commercial hub will grow even busier as sales start early next month at Flushing Commons, a mixed-use development that has been in the works for a decade.

headline: Fans in Cary, N.C., Protest as FIFA Scandal Hits Their Little Home Team
text: CARY, N.C. — Before a big match, the scene outside a Carolina RailHawks game is hardly unusual for a soccer team in second-to-last place in a second-tier professional league. At the entrance gate, interns at a folding table distribute discounted tickets bought online.

headline: Reminder: Private Mortgage Insurance Is Temporary
text: Home buyers who can’t put at least 20 percent down usually have to carry private mortgage insurance, often an expensive proposition. One good thing about mortgage insurance, though, is that it doesn’t last forever.

headline: Ashley Madison Chief Steps Down After Data Breach
text: In the last two years, online attacks have led to executive casualties at prominent companies like Sony Pictures Entertainment and Target. Now add to the list the chief executive of the company operating the adultery website Ashley Madison, a lesser known but far more salacious victim.

headline: The Key to Soupe au Pistou: Lots of Vegetables
text: My first experience of soupe au pistou, that vegetable soup from the South of France, was in a freezing cold Paris garret. From a can, in the middle of winter. It remains one of my warmest and most nourishing memories.

headline: U.S. Citizen, Once Held in Egypt’s Crackdown, Becomes Voice for Inmates
text: CAIRO — MOHAMED SOLTAN knew he had one thing going for him when the Egyptian police came to his door: He was a United States citizen, raised primarily in Ohio.

headline: No Retrial for North Carolina Officer Who Killed Unarmed Man
text: DURHAM, N.C. — North Carolina will not retry a white police officer who killed an unarmed black man who had just survived a car crash, state officials said Friday. The officer’s trial ended in a hung jury.

headline: For Parents With Troubled Adult Children, Financial Hurdles Abound
text: IT was the summer between her sophomore and junior year at the University of Wisconsin-Madison when Patti Sacher’s daughter Keisha had a breakdown. She had taken LSD at a Grateful Dead concert one weekend in 1989. When Mrs. Sacher called to check on her that Monday, Keisha wasn’t making sense.

headline: Vatican Envoy Dies While Awaiting Trial
text: A spokesman for the Vatican announced that Jozef Wesolowski, a former Vatican envoy who had been charged with child sex abuse, was found dead in his apartment on Friday morning.

headline: Panda Cares for Surviving Cub
text: The panda Mei Xiang is seen caring for her surviving cub at the Smithsonian National Zoo in Washington. The second of her two cubs died on Wednesday.

headline: Ian Rogers, Apple Music Executive, Is Leaving Company
text: A crucial executive in Apple’s new music streaming service is leaving the company, just two months after Apple introduced the service and began an intense competition with Spotify for dominance of the online music market.

headline: Bush Visits School Rebuilt After Katrina
text: Former President George W. Bush visited Warren Easton Charter High School in New Orleans on the 10th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina.

headline: Just What Do You Mean by ‘Anchor Baby’?
text: “Frankly, it’s more related to Asian people,” Jeb Bush said Monday in defense of his use of the term “anchor baby.” It had to have been one of the least artful clarifications of the 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: A Yiddish Operetta, Once Lost, Will Receive Its Full First Staging in 70 Years
text: “Di Goldene Kale,” a Yiddish-language operetta from the 1920s that was lost to time, will soon receive its first full staging in nearly 70 years.

text: This week’s properties are co-ops in Lenox Hill, the Upper East Side and Park Slope, Brooklyn.

text: How can we expect Wall Street’s me-first culture to change when regulators won’t pursue or even identify the me-firsters who are directly involved?

headline: China’s Vulnerability Is a Test for U.S. Presidential Candidates
text: For two decades, American politicians have been escalating their rhetoric about how to confront a rising China, one that grabs territory in the South China Sea, vacuums up American jobs and mounts cyber attacks on the United States.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Give Us the Ballot’
text: This week, Ari Berman and Simon Winchester.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Give Us the Ballot’
text: This week, Ari Berman talks about “Give Us the Ballot”; Simon Winchester discusses Susan Barker’s “The Incarnations”; and Parul Sehgal has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: For Loyal Guests, Hotels Bring Back the House Call
text: In the hotel industry, customer relationship management has evolved to keeping notes on a regular guest’s favorite foods or room preference. But now some of the country’s most celebrated properties are reviving an old service for an even more personalized connection: the house call.

text: Marc Jacobs’s tee, an Instagram upgrade and Serena the Great.

text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Fed Officials Say a September Rate Increase Is Still on the Table
text: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo. — The Federal Reserve will give serious consideration to raising its benchmark interest rate in mid-September, particularly if volatility subsides in financial markets, a number of Fed officials said Friday.

headline: The Perils of Email Auto-Fill
text: Every new technology is amazing, and every new technology brings its own horrors. For example, there was no such thing as waking up at 30,000 feet on the shoulder of a stranger who is covered in your drool until we invented commercial air flight (and Ambien).

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘Give Us the Ballot’
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Jeffrey Rosen reviews Ari Berman’s “Give Us the Ballot: The Modern Struggle for Voting Rights in America.” Mr. Rosen writes:

headline: Homeland Security’s Peculiar Prosecution of Rentboy
text: The website Rentboy.com is accused of connecting male sex workers with clients, enabling prostitution, which is unlawful virtually everywhere in the country. It operated fairly transparently, giving annual parties, announcing a scholarship contest for escorts and promoting the motto “Money can’t buy you love … but the rest is negotiable.”

headline: Setback for Suit Against N.S.A. on Phone Data
text: WASHINGTON — An appeals court ruled on Friday that the National Security Agency may continue to collect the phone records of millions of Americans, at least until a new law banning the practice goes into effect in November.

headline: Al Arbour, Coach of Islanders’ 1980s Dynasty, Dies at 82
text: Al Arbour, who coached the New York Islanders to four consecutive Stanley Cup championships in the 1980s and finished his career with the second-most coaching wins in National Hockey League history, died on Friday in Sarasota, Fla. He was 82.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Rivals Critical of Democratic Party Politics
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Hillary Rodham Clinton staked her claim on Friday to lead Democrats in 2016 and beyond, delivering a fiery speech to hundreds of party officials in which she attacked Donald J. Trump and other Republicans for “hateful” remarks — “The party of Lincoln has become the party of Trump,” she said acidly — and pledged to rebuild the Democratic political machine to help candidates win races nationwide.
