text: This week’s properties include a waterfront home in Bayville, N.Y., and a carriage house in Highlands, N.J.

headline: Eric Betzig’s Life Over the Microscope
text: In October 2014, the Nobel Prize in Chemistry went to three scientists for their work developing a new class of microscopes that may well transform biological research by permitting researchers to observe cellular processes as they happen.

headline: The Birkenstock Doctor
text: To track the rise of Birkenstocks, one might look to their reinterpretation in Céline’s Spring/Summer 2013 collection, peep under the tables of any Brooklyn coffee shop, or read Vogue’s seal of approval (“Pretty Ugly: Why Vogue Girls Have Fallen for Birkenstocks”). Alternatively, one could simply call Tom Lonergan. The sixty-something retiree living in Ohio doesn’t know a thing about couture (“Selena? Selena who?” he responded when asked about the Céline tipping point), values comfort in attire above all else and has never paid any attention to the strange, mercurial shifts in fashion. But two years ago, Lonergan’s mail order Birkenstock’s repair business doubled in orders overnight. For years, orders had come from Vermont, Maine, New Hampshire and Florida, but suddenly, return labels increasingly sported ZIP codes in New York and California. Women sent in pairs they’d worn at college in the ’90s and wanted to refurbish; millennials mailed damaged, rare styles they’d found on eBay.

headline: Upper East Side Penthouse for $37.94 Million
text: A three-apartment penthouse combination, spanning the top four floors of the Charles condominium at 1355 First Avenue, sold for $37.94 million and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Tomato Sandwiches
text: This sandwich pairs slightly overripe tomato slices with the essence of pan con tomate.

headline: The Tomato Sandwich Perfected
text: When tomatoes are in season, you can’t do better than a simple tomato sandwich.

headline: An App Connects Users With Start-Ups That Are Hiring
text: We have come to expect our smartphone apps to accomplish any simple task we ask of them: order food, get from here to there, read the news and maybe buy tickets to a movie or a concert. But when they offer to do complex tasks, it’s best to remain skeptical.

headline: Syrian Refugees on Their Journeys
text: Record numbers of people have arrived in Europe this year to seek asylum, many of them fleeing the war in Syria. Some of those refugees described their experiences.

headline: Popcast: The Weeknd, No Longer a Mysterious Internet Presence
text: Abel Tesfaye is the Weeknd, a revelatory R&B singer and a narrative conceit, a persona with a high and lovely ballad-voice about his self-absorbed hedonism. He started in 2010 through a mysterious Internet presence, then some mixtapes, and finally a career: negotiating with record labels, getting onstage, going on the road.

headline: Days Before Kidney Transplant, Aries Merritt Wins Bronze in Hurdles
text: BEIJING — There are the hurdles on the track, all of which Aries Merritt cleared on Friday night on his way to a bronze medal at the world track and field championships.

headline: Mississippi’s Recovery After Katrina Holds Lessons for Policy Makers
text: GULFPORT, Miss. — Hurricane Katrina did not directly hit New Orleans, which flooded because of levee failures. Mississippi, it walloped.

headline: Rudolph Giuliani’s Outrage on Homelessness, and Richard Gere’s
text: If the offenses of Donald J. Trump weren’t getting played out by the hour at the volume of a jackhammer in competition with a Nascar event, then recent comments by another New Yorker synonymous with unchecked expressiveness, and also touched by the pixie dust of presidential aspiration, might be generating more outrage. In an interview with NBC’s local news channel in New York, former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani explained, with both glee and self-regard, that not long ago he had paid a visit to the 19th Precinct station house on the Upper East Side to complain about a homeless man who had taken up residence on his block.

headline: Scott Walker Vows to Defeat ISIS and Assails Democrats
text: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin struck an aggressive posture in a foreign policy speech on Friday, taking aim equally at America’s enemies in the Middle East and Mr. Walker’s political rivals in both parties.

headline: What I Love | Frederique van der Wal
text: A model whose résumé includes Victoria’s Secret spends weekends in an 18th-century house near Rhinebeck, N.Y.

headline: Popcast: The Weeknd
text: Times critics discuss The Weeknd’s music and new album, “Beauty Behind the Madness.”

headline: NASA’s Next Horizon in Space
text: Since New Horizons beamed back photos of Pluto, the question has loomed: What’s next? More than 1,600 Times readers shared their ideas.

headline: Owen Labrie of St. Paul’s School Is Found Not Guilty of Main Rape Charge
text: CONCORD, N.H. — The prep school graduate accused of raping a younger student at the elite St. Paul’s School dropped his head and sobbed for the first time since the start of his trial: He had been found not guilty on Friday of felony sexual assault charges, but was convicted of having sex with a girl who was below the age of consent.

headline: A Victoria’s Secret Model on Her Permanent Fixer-Upper
text: Frederique van der Wal decided to buy a weekend house 15 years ago, when she was pregnant with Scyler, her daughter with the screenwriter Nicholas Klein.

headline: Death of Knut the Polar Bear Is Explained at Last
text: HEIDELBERG, Germany — Scientists have solved the zoological mystery of what killed Knut, the Berlin Zoo’s famous polar bear, more than four years after he drowned in his enclosure as horrified visitors watched.

headline: India and Pakistan Accuse Each Other in Deaths of Civilians
text: ISLAMABAD — Pakistan and India on Friday accused each other of targeting civilians in the latest deadly exchange of cross-border fire, as relations continued to worsen just days after talks between top security officials of both countries were canceled.

headline: Three Popular Psychology Studies That Didn't Hold Up
text: Researchers re-did 100 published psychology studies, and many did not check out. These are three of the studies, and some possible explanations for why they couldn’t be replicated.

headline: Seeing Freedom in Their Future, Psychics Reveal All: ‘It’s a Scam, Sir’
text: Is it real? Or a bunch of baloney? It’s a question New Yorkers and visitors to the city may ask themselves when they pass any of the seemingly countless storefront fortunetellers.

headline: Marco Rubio Urges a More Aggressive Approach Toward China
text: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida issued a sharp critique of China’s behavior on Friday, using a speech in South Carolina and an opinion piece in The Wall Street Journal to fault Beijing on such issues as military expansionism, cybertheft, human rights abuses and “economic misconduct.”

headline: José Serrano, New York Democrat in Congress, Adds His Support to Iran Nuclear Deal
text: Representative José E. Serrano said on Friday that he would vote in support of President Obama’s nuclear deal with Iran, adding to the thin ranks of New York City Democrats who have backed the contested arms-control agreement.

headline: A Grand Tour of a Great Lake
text: A tour of Lake Michigan reveals striking topography, time-worn communities and the reassuring permanence of an unchanging lake.

headline: Bitcoin Technology Piques Interest on Wall St.
text: Most people still think of Bitcoin as the virtual currency used by drug dealers and shadowy hackers looking to evade the authorities.

headline: South Africa’s Majority-Female Anti-Poaching Squad
text: The Black Mambas patrol the Balule Nature Reserve, near South Africa’s Kruger National Park.

headline: On Patrol With the Black Mambas
text: For the past two years, the majority-female Black Mamba Anti-Poaching Unit has patrolled the Balule Nature Reserve, a private wildlife reserve in northern South Africa. The Balule has an open border with Kruger National Park, an Israel-size reserve that has in recent years been besieged by poachers in pursuit of the park’s famed wildlife — particularly its rhinoceroses, whose horns are now worth hundreds of thousands of dollars on the international black market.

headline: The History of the Sweeney Building in Brooklyn
text: Q. Many years ago, when I was still Mrs. Sweeney, our three boys in Brooklyn Heights never had to ask us, “Where did we come from?” because the answer was plain to see: the Sweeney Manufacturing Company, just to the right of the Brooklyn Bridge. Alas, the sign is gone. What happened?

headline: Florida Governor Discusses Storm
text: Gov. Rick Scott of Florida discussed the preparations the state was making for a tropical storm on Friday. The storm is expected to hit the state on Monday.

headline: Illinois Fires Coach Tim Beckman One Week Before Season Opener
text: The University of Illinois fired its head football coach on Friday, saying in a statement that he had inappropriately influenced medical decisions and encouraged players to compete despite injuries.

headline: ‘A Labyrinth From Which I Might Never Emerge’: Readers Weigh In on the Fafsa
text: To mention the Free Application for Federal Student Aid is to inspire a collective shudder among many students and parents trying to pay for a college education, though some have found simplified ways to deal with the process.

headline: Harsh Odor Wafts Over Staten Island, Baffling Residents
text: Cataloging the city’s summertime smells — taxis’ exhaust, perfumes and bodega flowers, to name a few — can nearly be considered a New Yorker’s pastime. On Friday, residents all over Staten Island were trying to determine the origins of a fouler smell.

headline: Superiority Burger, a Vegetarian Ode to White Castle in the East Village
text: Is there such a thing as vegetarian food for carnivores? Superiority Burger, which opened near Tompkins Square in June, is a shoebox-size, white-tiled ode to White Castle, with a chef who comes from the tonier, meat-oriented Del Posto. The new restaurant’s name alone would seem likely to deter the quinoa-faithful.

headline: Labor Board Ruling on Joint Employers Leaves Some Companies Scratching Their Heads
text: A National Labor Relations Board ruling that could significantly change the relationship between companies and their subcontractors and between franchise operators and their franchisees has businesses in those industries scrambling to understand the ramifications.

headline: The Trick to Acting Heroically
text: WHAT causes people to risk their lives to help strangers?

headline: How Heather McGhee, President of Demos, an Advocacy Group, Spends Her Sundays
text: Heather McGhee, the president of the left-leaning research and advocacy group Demos, often begins her Sundays by giving her mother something to talk about. “She’s the person who has a lot of opinions about my appearance,” said Ms. McGhee, 35, a frequent guest on morning talk shows and on MSNBC. Besides doing on-camera stints, she likes a day without meetings, conferences or fund-raising talks, instead pursuing culture with friends. She lives in Greenwich Village with two cats.

headline: Hillary Clinton Blasts G.O.P. as ‘Party of Trump,’ Not Lincoln
text: MINNEAPOLIS – Facing Democrats who have concerns about her presidential candidacy, Hillary Rodham Clinton galvanized them on Friday with a searing attack on Republicans, saying “the party of Lincoln has become the party of Trump” as a result of Republicans’ reluctance to repudiate Donald J. Trump and his divisive remarks about immigrants, women and others.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, Aug. 30 to Sept. 6, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, Aug. 30 to Sept. 6, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, Aug. 30 to Sept. 6, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Things to Do on Long Island, Aug. 30 to Sept. 6, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: George W. Bush, Visiting New Orleans, Praises School Progress Since Katrina
text: NEW ORLEANS — Returning here Friday 10 years after this city was inundated, former President George W. Bush painted a rosy picture of the recovery since Hurricane Katrina, saying that the devastation had “sparked a decade of reform” in public schools and declaring, “New Orleans is back, and better than ever.”

headline: 1959-75 | The Rise and Fall of the West (Side)
text: A recently installed sign in a West End Avenue park has answered the mystery of the runic stones visible from West 64th Street. They once served as an embankment for the Hudson River Railroad tracks.

headline: Rape Acquittal in Prep School Trial
text: Owen Labrie, the prep school graduate accused of raping a younger student at St. Paul’s School, was found not guilty on the main sexual assault charge. He was convicted of lesser charges.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Hungary and Elsewhere
text: Hungary and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: 6 Great Things About the Great New York State Fair
text: Organizers claim it is the oldest state fair in the United States, dating back at least to 1841. Big names like Melissa Etheridge and Snoop Dogg are scheduled to perform this year, but there are smaller reasons why the fair still matters.

headline: The Drunk Man in the Park
text: Unaccustomed to people drinking alcohol in public, a group of Syrian refugees is bemused by a Belgrade resident who is helpful, but drunk.

headline: Miley Cyrus’s Tongue Launches a Thousand Selfies
text: On Sunday night, two icons of commercialized youth rebellion will come together: the MTV Video Music Awards and Miley Cyrus’s tongue.

headline: Robyn, the Space-Age Disco Queen With a Dark Bent
text: Robyn, the 36-year-old Swedish pop star, was in Los Angeles recently, decked out in a pale blue bustier and lying on a bed, as part of the video shoot for her latest single, “Love Is Free.”

headline: India Virtually Eliminates Tetanus as a Killer
text: The country sees success in its 15-year campaign against lockjaw, in part by providing incentives for mothers to give birth in clean conditions

headline: Review: Martha Graham Dancers in an Eclectic Menu at Jacob’s Pillow
text: BECKET, Mass. — The ghost of Ted Shawn, who turned a farm here into the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival and worked tirelessly to present dancing as a manly activity, might have been pleased to see a burly guy chopping wood on Thursday on the barnlike stage of the Ted Shawn Theater. Shawn might have been tickled, too, to learn that the man wielding the ax was a member of the dance troupe of his old student and partner Martha Graham.

headline: Review: ‘Fireface’ Explores Incest, Jealousy and Pyromania
text: There are rules about shouting “Fire!” in a crowded theater. But it’s almost unbearably tempting to yell it during Third Space’s production of “Fireface,” particularly when a Zippo-wielding sociopath begins splashing what is ostensibly gasoline across the narrow stage floor of the Brick, near enough to spray your sandals.

headline: New York Theater Ballet Announces Season
text: A blend of family-friendly fairy tales and revivals of dances by Merce Cunningham and Pam Tanowitz are in store for New York Theater Ballet’s coming season.

headline: The Battle for the Soul of the Hamptons
text: More than 150 years ago, Manifest Destiny drove American pioneers westward. A horde of speculators and moguls staked claim to everything before them as they pressed onward to the Pacific, their mission being to “overspread the continent allotted by Providence for the free development of our yearly multiplying millions,” as the journalist John L. O’Sullivan wrote in 1845.

headline: New Jersey Barbecue Joints Find Their Secret in the Smoke
text: What sensation the word barbecue evokes depends on the region you have in mind. Texas barbecue summons the smell of mesquite smoke, the brawn of beef. Think North Carolina and get a whiff of vinegar, the crackle of a pig on a spit. The meat may be fine in Georgia, but what I remember is those bags of sliced white bread. Now close your eyes and consider what the following phrase conjures: New Jersey barbecue.

headline: Protecting Your Mac From Malware and Viruses
text: Q. I thought Macs were supposed to be protected from malware, but I’ve gotten those fake tech support pop-ups and ads in Safari. I have to force the browser to quit to get away from them. Could my Mac be infected?

headline: Review: ‘Dumbo,’ With Glitter and Lap Dances, Takes Flight at Jack
text: No matter how much distance there is between yourself and seventh grade, that outcast feeling never really disappears: Dumbo lives inside us all.

headline: Injured ‘Wicked’ Actress Seeks Evidence in Court
text: A 35-year-old actress who fell from a rope during a performance of “Wicked” has asked a court in Manhattan to order the show to preserve evidence of what happened to her.

headline: Review: ‘A Delicate Ship’ Plumbs the What-ifs of Love and Heartbreak
text: Snowflakes drift lazily down, a view of a cityscape looms through the blurry night, and the crisp scent of a freshly cut Christmas tree fills the air as the lights go up on “A Delicate Ship,” a lovely drama by the newly (and justly) hot playwright Anna Ziegler. But the serenity evoked by this atmosphere soon gives way to storms of philosophical debate and emotional turbulence in this memory play about the fragile dynamics of young relationships, and the mysterious workings of time.

headline: Erdogan Approves Caretaker Government in Turkey
text: ISTANBUL — The short-term interim government approved Friday by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey allowed pro-Kurdish party lawmakers to take up ministerial posts for the first time in the country’s history. But the two ministers who were appointed are not expected to survive this fall’s election.

headline: New Jersey Festivals Offer Jazz, Bluegrass and a Chance to Do the Twist Again
text: For fans of live music, the end of summer signals the tapering off of festival season, not to mention barbecues and beach trips. But in New Jersey, September is shaping up to be as robust a month for outdoor multi-act concerts as June or July.

headline: August 28, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Hungary, Libya, India and South Africa.

headline: Review: ‘Pearl’ Visits the Many Worlds of ‘The Good Earth’ Author
text: Before seeing the new dance play “Pearl,” the chief questions in my head were: “Why tell the life of the writer Pearl S. Buck in dance? And how?” But this production at the David H. Koch Theater, directed and choreographed by Daniel Ezralow, answers those quickly, repeatedly and variously.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: A Great Night for Hurling
text: Whether it is a low-level match on a rural field in County Galway or the intercounty final at Croke Park in Dublin, hurling is an amateur endeavor that sparks Ireland’s passions.

headline: A Passion for Hurling, the All-Ireland Game
text: KINVARA, Ireland — Thirty men battle on a deep-green field, each one wielding what looks like a field hockey stick moonlighting as a broken oar. They chase a ball that fits snug in the hand, sometimes balancing it on their sticks as they run, sometimes swinging the sticks in midsprint to arc the ball toward a goal’s uprights.

headline: Europe’s Halting Response to Migrant Crisis Draws Criticism as Toll Mounts
text: LONDON — The daily toll among refugees and migrants desperately trying to reach Europe — 71 suffocated in a truck in Austria and 150 drowned off Libya this week — has dramatically underscored the European Union’s scattered, halting response to increasing waves of asylum seekers.

headline: The Week in Political Pictures
text: The 10th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, campaign barbecue and an outstanding teenager in New Hampshire in this week’s political pictures.

headline: Restaurant Review: Lost & Found in Long Beach Has a Chef Who Goes for the Flavor Bomb
text: Lost & Found, a culinary hideaway tucked among the rowdy bars of Long Beach’s West End, can be hard to find. During the day, the blinds are drawn, the phone goes unanswered and the only sign of life is a discreet stenciled logo on the front window.

headline: Review: Majorca, a Hartford Restaurant Where the Tastes of Spain Shine
text: I recall the island of Majorca in Spain from a long-ago visit — blaring azure vistas, vertiginous roads and vaguely racy-sounding villages (Fornalutx) where tiny cafes served exciting food: raw and peppery sobrasada, eggplant ratatouille, roast suckling pig and lots of olives, almonds and garlic.

headline: Rebekah Brooks Said to Be Returning to News Corp. in Britain
text: Rebekah Brooks, the editor and publishing executive who four years ago became embroiled in a phone-hacking scandal in Britain, is set to return to Rupert Murdoch’s media empire in a senior role, an executive with knowledge of the company’s plans said on Friday.

headline: Antiterrorism Laws Prompt British Library to Distance Itself From Taliban Project
text: LONDON — A decision by the British Library not to host a huge collection of Taliban-related documents, despite years of close involvement with the project, has added to concerns that Britain’s sweeping body of antiterrorism legislation is impinging on academic freedom.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
text: The 10th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, campaign barbecue and an outstanding teenager in New Hampshire in this week’s political pictures.

headline: At Wave Hill, Photos of New York’s Trees, ‘Living Archives’ of the City
text: The first image visitors see when exploring “New York City of Trees,” an exhibition of 10 photographs by Benjamin Swett at Wave Hill, in Riverdale, the Bronx, is bound to leave the wrong impression.

headline: Martin O’Malley Rails at Democrats for Debate Schedule ‘Rigged’ to Aid Hillary Clinton
text: MINNEAPOLIS – Martin O’Malley had one clear chance to make waves within the Democratic National Committee, and he seized it, delivering a fiery speech Friday that condemned his party’s leadership for what he called a process “rigged” to help Hillary Rodham Clinton — namely, curtailing the number of presidential primary debates.

headline: U.N. Official to Visit Central African Republic Amid Scrutiny Over Peacekeepers
text: UNITED NATIONS — The way the United Nations has handled sexual abuse allegations against peacekeepers in the Central African Republic has come under sharp scrutiny, including on the high commissioner for human rights, Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein.

headline: Art Show Captures the Wrenching Effects of Closing a School
text: PHILADELPHIA — A school may be made of bricks and mortar, but when one closes, the loss can feel like a death in the family.

headline: Bernie Sanders Warns Democrats They May Not Win in 2016 Without Him
text: MINNEAPOLIS – Taking his outsider message into the heart of the Democratic establishment, Senator Bernie Sanders, the Vermont independent, challenged hundreds of the party’s leaders on Friday to embrace his candidacy, warning that the huge crowds of supporters he has drawn may not vote for Democratic candidates in 2016 unless he is at the top of the ticket.

headline: Beatles and Abba Items to Be Auctioned
text: Money can’t buy you love, but enough of it can buy the rare Beatles memorabilia being auctioned this weekend in Liverpool.

headline: Restaurant Review: The Diversity of Indian Cuisine Is at RaaSa in Elmsford
text: In 1998, when Peter Beck was the chef at the Indian restaurant Chola in Manhattan, Ruth Reichl, then The New York Times’s restaurant critic, regarded it highly enough to give it two stars.

headline: Precious Objects From Vanishing Estates on Long Island
text: Did Otto Hermann Kahn, a banker, financier and arts patron, have a rival Long Island estate on his mind as he built his own palatial house, Oheka, in Huntington in 1917?

headline: Georgia Engel, a ‘Mary Tyler Moore Show’ Sidekick, Takes a Star Turn
text: On the closing night of Annie Baker’s adaptation of “Uncle Vanya” at Soho Rep three years ago, Ms. Baker took the actress Georgia Engel aside and whispered in her ear: “I’m writing a play for you.”

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Uber Hires Two Engineers Who Showed Cars Could Be Hacked
text: Uber is continuing its hiring spree of top technical talent by recruiting two respected computer security engineers, Charlie Miller and Chris Valasek.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Garden Party
text: Newport coaching weekend, where hats added to the festivities.

headline: Edinburgh Festival Fringe Offers Stories That Are More Personal, Less Political
text: EDINBURGH — Despite loathing audience participation, there I stood onstage in a small black box performance space here recently, gyrating my hips and spinning a hula hoop before a packed house. Nearby, a couple of people were clumsily attempting to spin plates on sticks, and others in the audience were trying the same with anything suitable they could find in pockets or handbags.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Garden Party
text: A highlight of the Newport coaching weekend was a luncheon given by Eaddo and Peter Kiernan (No. 1) at their home, where the Frederick Law Olmsted gardens have been restored to their original splendor. A tent for 200 guests was set among the gardens that overlook Narragansett Bay. The 11 coaches from the morning drive were parked on the lawn that sweeps down to the bay. Hats added to the festivities.

headline: Evening Hours | Newport Coaching Weekend
text: Newport coaching weekend included a white-tie dinner dance for coach drivers at the Breakers, the former home of Cornelius Vanderbilt II.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Yale Students Campaign for All That Jazz
text: Michael Hoot and his compatriots value their hard-won seats in the Yale Jazz Ensemble, a Yale University-sponsored big band. So it did not sit well when Thomas C. Duffy, who as university director of bands had led the ensemble for 34 years, suspended its operations for the coming year — and possibly beyond — citing a loss of rehearsal space and a lack of qualified brass players.

headline: Iran and Israel United in Opposition to Daniel Barenboim Concert
text: Cultural diplomacy can be as knotty as any other kind. The conductor Daniel Barenboim’s efforts to lead the Berlin Staatskapelle at a concert in Tehran drew criticism this week from the Israeli culture minister, who called the performance anti-Israel, and a rebuff from Iranian officials, who said on Friday that they would block the concert because of Mr. Barenboim’s Israeli citizenship.

headline: Oil Prices Jump 17 Percent in Two Days, Despite Glut
text: HOUSTON — Oil prices jumped for a second day on Friday, sending the United States benchmark past $45 a barrel, a gain of 17 percent in only two days.

headline: Pilot Killed in Crash of Home-Built Plane at Stewart International Airport
text: A small plane crashed shortly after takeoff at Stewart International Airport in Newburgh, N.Y., on Friday afternoon, killing the pilot.

headline: Poetic Connections: Nice View; Rough Delivery
text: There’s a tendency to think of the Hamptons as a municipal collective of elegant perfection, the sort of place where lovers meet at just-so garden parties or sneak away to moonlit beaches where nothing can go wrong. But at least according to the following poems, the posh East End communities are as plagued by erotic mischance, romantic awkwardness and the plain old fumblings of love as anywhere. The poems were “found” last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are reprinted verbatim with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are their subject headings.

headline: Ruth Sivard, Economist Who Scrutinized Military Spending, Dies at 99
text: Ruth Sivard, an economist who for more than three decades drew attention to the disparity between social and military spending around the globe, even after the Pentagon objected to her making that comparison for a federal agency, died on Aug. 21 at her home in Washington. She was 99.

headline: Obama Tries to Soothe Divided Jewish Community on Iran Deal
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama appealed to a divided and troubled Jewish community on Friday, defending his nuclear accord with Iran as in the security interest of both the United States and Israel, and calling for a more civil debate with a congressional vote just weeks away.

headline: Child Goddesses in Nepal
text: Among the Newar people of Nepal’s Kathmandu Valley, some girls are worshiped as living goddesses, or Kumaris.

headline: Consumer Anxiety in China Undermines Government’s Economic Plans
text: BEIJING — In recent days, an advice column has circulated widely on China’s most popular social media phone app. Titled “Guide on Safe Passage Through the Economic Crisis,” it is aimed at young Chinese urban professionals. Its nuggets of wisdom include: “Work hard at your job so you are the last to be laid off” and “In an economic crisis, liquidity is the number one priority.”

headline: Countries Under the Most Strain in the European Migration Crisis
text: European Union officials struggle to cope with the growing crisis.

headline: American Pharoah Awes Saratoga Springs on Eve of Travers
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — They have come here from Boston and Los Angeles, Atlanta and Cincinnati, and places in between, all to see the Big Horse, a title long thrown around lightly but now deservedly worn by American Pharoah. He is the sport’s 12th Triple Crown champion, the winner of eight straight races, each punctuated with a performance more impressive than the last.

headline: Psychologists Welcome Analysis Casting Doubt on Their Work
text: The field of psychology sustained a damaging blow Thursday: A new analysis found that only 36 percent of findings from almost 100 studies in the top three psychology journals held up when the original experiments were rigorously redone.

headline: Bystander Shot by Undercover Police Officer Dies
text: A bystander accidentally shot by an undercover New York City police officer on Friday afternoon during an illegal firearms sting gone awry has died, the Police Department said on Saturday.

headline: Tony Finau’s Unorthodox Path to Tour Success
text: EDISON, N.J. — Tony Finau finished a television interview Friday as Scott Piercy was making his way to the nearby 10th tee for the start of his second round at the Barclays. Piercy slowed to bump the fist of Finau, whose one-under-par 69 at Plainfield Country Club had moved him into a tie for the early Friday lead in the first event of the FedEx Cup playoffs.

headline: Now Playing Around the World, the ‘Trump Show’
text: It is no secret that Donald J. Trump, who has dominated the race for the Republican presidential nomination for the past month, has become  a reviled figure in Latin America for his inflammatory remarks about Hispanic immigrants. His statements have won him plaudits from nativists at home, but his showy candidacy has not gone unnoticed in other parts of the global village.

headline: Man Is Fatally Shot and 3 Others Are Injured at Brooklyn Hookah Bar
text: The first bullets hit Chrispine Phillips in the chest, arm and head. As he fell fatally injured inside a crowded hookah bar in Brooklyn on Friday morning, the assailant ran for the door, shooting as he went.

headline: Ruling Limits Protests Outside Supreme Court
text: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court on Friday upheld 65-year-old limits on protesters’ First Amendment rights to gather and wave signs on the grand plaza in front of the Supreme Court, reversing a district court ruling that had found the restrictions “plainly unconstitutional.”

headline: Friday Night Music: Courtney Barnett, Avant Gardener
text: In honor of my coming visit to Australia. Saw her at SXSW; a bit rawer than my usual taste, but very good.

headline: Rethinking Mass Transit in the New York Region
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mets Set Team Home Run Records in an August to Remember
text: Terry Collins studied the itinerary for the Mets’ last road trip and noticed a common theme. The Mets would be playing at Camden Yards in Baltimore, Coors Field in Denver and Citizens Bank Park in Philadelphia. All are home run havens.

headline: NASA’s New Horizons Spacecraft Has Next Mission After Pluto
text: The next destination for NASA’s Pluto probe is to be a much smaller ice ball in the outer solar system, the space agency announced on Friday.

headline: Grim Findings in Austria and at Sea Push Migrant Crisis Into Public View
text: VIENNA — They were the lucky ones. Packed into a small white truck, 34 migrants, 10 of them children, had made the hourslong drive from Serbia, begging for air in broiling summer temperatures. According to the police, the three people smuggling this human cargo into Austria refused to stop.

headline: Ban Abortion for Down Syndrome?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Arizona: Lawyer Paid to End Suit Against Homeland Security
text: The Department of Homeland Security has reached a settlement with the top lawyer in the Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency in Arizona, who sued the department in 2014 claiming discrimination. The lawyer, Patricia M. Vroom, said she was bullied and harassed by officials in Washington because she raised concerns about an Obama administration policy applying prosecutorial discretion to spare some immigrants from deportation. Ms. Vroom will be paid $399,999 to end the suit, and a recent annual performance rating will be revised upward to “achieved excellence.” She had said top legal officials lowered her rating after she moved cautiously to allow the release of some undocumented immigrants with criminal records, a rebuke she said amounted to age and sex discrimination. Her lawyer said that as part of the agreement, Ms. Vroom would retire on Oct. 1 after 30 years working for the federal government. Homeland Security officials did not admit wrongdoing.

headline: Dementia and the Breakdown of Moral Judgment
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Ruling With a Bonus for Fast-Food Workers
text: The “Fight for $15” campaign is about more than higher pay for fast-food workers. It is also about fighting for the right of workers to form strong unions without retaliation. That goal looks much more achievable this week after a National Labor Relations Board ruling that may force corporate parents, like McDonald’s or Yum Brands, to take responsibility for workers at franchises.

headline: A Break in the Khobar Towers Case
text: The 1996 terrorist attack on Khobar Towers in Saudi Arabia that killed 19 United States airmen was among the defining events of America’s recent experience in the Middle East. But there has been no judicial accountability. With the reported arrest of the man accused of masterminding the crime, a resolution of the case may be closer.

headline: In Alaska, Obama Will Be in Middle of Oil and Climate Change Battle
text: ANCHORAGE, Alaska — Gov. Bill Walker ticks down the things he wants President Obama to see in visiting this vast northern state starting on Monday, and glorious glacial vistas are not at the top of the list.

headline: Show Some Spine, Federal Reserve
text: THE financial markets and the Federal Reserve Board have been playing out a tragicomedy in three acts. Here’s how it works: Initially, a flurry of news stories appear about how, a few months hence, the Fed intends to raise short-term interest rates for the first time in years. Second, the predictable market swoon, as Wall Street traders ponder the fact that the morphine drip of free money that they have been enjoying since the aftermath of the 2008 financial crisis might be pulled out of their arms. Finally, the Fed backs away from its much-overdue policy change, causing traders to rejoice and the artificially stimulated bull market in both stocks and bonds to continue. The curtain comes down, and the audience roars its approval.

headline: How to Halt the Violence
Marks of Derision
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — The people who write to me to say that they would never dare attempt to solve a Saturday New York Times crossword puzzle should really try this one by Evan Birnholz.

headline: Buying Sex Should Not Be Legal
text: DUBLIN — HERE in my city, earlier this month, Amnesty International’s international council endorsed a new policy calling for the decriminalization of the global sex trade. Its proponents argue that decriminalizing prostitution is the best way of protecting “the human rights of sex workers,” though the policy would apply equally to pimps, brothel-keepers and johns.

headline: U.S. Open Qualifiers Brave a Gantlet Into the Main Draw
text: For some, the qualifying draw of the United States Open is a launching pad. For others, it is a place to land, comfortably or not, after enjoying greater heights in tennis. For 16 men and 16 women, it was a gantlet to reach the main draw.

headline: The Tesla Cheerleader
text: Do you remember when Henry Blodget first became famous?

headline: Jets’ New Practice Drill Leads to a Few Dings. Of a Bell.
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Walking out to the Jets’ first padded practice of training camp, Nick Mangold spotted a contraption that left him stumped. From a distance it resembles a cherry picker without a bucket: A long, adjustable arm sprouts from a post, and at the end of it hangs a bell, and below that a speed bag dangling about seven feet above the ground like pugilistic mistletoe.

headline: U.N. Urges the Netherlands to Stop Portrayals of ‘Black Pete’ Character
text: UNITED NATIONS — A United Nations committee has urged the Netherlands to get rid of Black Pete, a popular children’s character who has long been portrayed in early winter by white people in blackface makeup, usually with exaggerated red lips and gold hoops in his ears.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,348 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: With Two Big Bats Out of Lineup, Yanks Still Feast on Subpar Pitching
text: ATLANTA — The slumping Yankees staggered south without their two most threatening bats in the lineup, one because there is no place for a designated hitter in a National League park and the other because his troublesome shin showed no sign of getting better.

headline: Texas: Sheriff’s Deputy Is Fatally Shot at Gas Station
text: A uniformed Harris County sheriff’s deputy was fatally shot at a gas station in suburban Houston late Friday. The deputy, a 10-year veteran, was pumping gas when he was shot multiple times by an unknown assailant who approached him from behind, said Ryan Sullivan, a spokesman for the Harris County Sheriff’s Office. The sheriff’s office later identified the deputy as Darren Goforth. The shooting took place around 9 p.m. at a busy intersection in unincorporated Harris County. Other law enforcement agencies joined the sheriff’s office in an intensive search for the gunman late Friday night. “We’re currently working to ascertain the physical description or identity of the suspect,” Mr. Sullivan said shortly before midnight.

headline: Inside-the-Park Homer Brings Mets’ 7-Game Winning Streak to an End
text: Tucked in the lower-right-hand corner of the giant video board in center field at Citi Field, a new graphic appeared Friday. It promoted a matchup that is still more than a month away, when the Washington Nationals visit on Oct. 2, the final weekend of the regular season.

headline: What’s On TV Saturday
text: 2 P.M. (Showtime 2) AMERICAN GRAFFITI (1973) It’s the last night of summer in 1962, and a group of recent high school graduates prepares for college, Vietnam and the rest of life in this film by George Lucas. They hang out at Mel’s Drive-In, cruise up and down the main strip of town while listening to Wolfman Jack and attend one last school dance. A young Harrison Ford drives a black Chevrolet. “American Graffiti exists not so much in its individual stories as in its orchestration of many stories, its sense of time and place,” Roger Greenspun wrote in The New York Times. “Although it is full of the material of fashionable nostalgia, it never exploits nostalgia.” He continued, “It is a very good movie, funny, tough, unsentimental.” The film also stars Ron Howard and Cindy Williams (together above), Richard Dreyfuss and Charles Martin Smith.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “It’s a scam, sir.”

headline: Corrections: August 29, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Falling for an Adventurous Soul
text: My Luu and Dave Ventresca married Aug. 7 in Galloway, N.J. The bride’s family escaped Vietnam; the groom had a more traditional American upbringing.

headline: My Luu and Dave Ventresca: No Mountain High Enough
text: There he was in Bhutan, one of the world’s most remote locations, fighting a combination of an infection and altitude sickness — which, considering where Dave Ventresca was laying his head at that moment, did not seem all that unusual to him.

headline: Antigovernment Protesters Gather in Malaysia, Defying Police Orders
text: BANGKOK — Tens of thousands of demonstrators in Malaysia defied police orders on Saturday, massing in the capital in a display of anger at the government of Prime Minister Najib Razak, who has been accused of corruption involving hundreds of millions of dollars.

headline: Exhibition on China and Fashion Proves Golden for Met
text: The talk of Wall Street over the last week may have been Shanghai’s plunging stock market, but many blocks farther uptown, where commuter traffic gives way to verdant sidewalks, a different set of numbers related to China was making news. As it entered its final week, the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s spring Costume Institute show, “China: Through the Looking Glass,” was attaining blockbuster status.

headline: Young Hands in Mexico Feed Growing U.S. Demand for Heroin
text: EL CALVARIO, Mexico — With her nimble hands, tiny feet and low center of gravity, Angelica Guerrero Ortega makes an excellent opium harvester.

headline: The Week on Instagram
text: Photos posted by @nytimes took Instagram followers from a refugee processing center in Serbia to a hotel room in Tokyo.

headline: Thai Police Announce Arrest in Bangkok Shrine Bombing
text: BANGKOK — Thai security forces raided an apartment building in a Bangkok suburb just before dawn on Saturday and arrested a foreign man the authorities believe was involved in the deadly bombing of a Bangkok shrine nearly two weeks ago.

headline: Al Jazeera Journalists Sentenced to 3 Years in Prison in Egypt
text: CAIRO — An Egyptian judge on Saturday handed down an unexpectedly harsh verdict in the trial of three journalists from the Al Jazeera English news channel, sentencing them to three years in prison on charges that legal experts said were unfounded and politically motivated.

headline: Hiking and Biking in Tasmania
text: Tasmanian Tour Ride & Seek, an Australian outfitter offering trips in a dozen countries, has added a destination close to home: an eight-day hiking and biking trip through Tasmania, the rugged island state off Australia’s south coast.

headline: Once a Pariah, Now a Judge: The Early Transgender Journey of Phyllis Frye
text: HOUSTON — Nearly four decades before Caitlyn Jenner introduced herself to the world, Phyllis Randolph Frye came out as a transgender woman in a far less glamorous way. No Diane Sawyer, no Vanity Fair.

headline: Outfit Check Before the Hamptons
text: The stylish Hamptons hordes gather like clockwork wherever the Jitneys depart.

headline: Dear Landlord: Where’s Our Building Canopy?
text: Punishment by Canopy

headline: Outfit Check Before the Hamptons
text: As the weekend approaches, the summer Hamptons hordes gather like clockwork wherever the Jitneys depart. On a recent Thursday, Hamptons regulars, grateful houseguests and enterprising workers formed a single file at East 69th Street and Lexington Avenue, with their beach gear in tow. Here are the photos.

headline: Before Trump or Fiorina, There Was Wendell Willkie
text: If either Donald Trump or Carly Fiorina receives the 2016 Republication presidential nomination, it will be a rare achievement. Only once in American history has a major political party granted its prize to someone whose principal qualification was to have served as a corporate chief executive. That was in 1940, when Wendell Willkie was the Republican candidate against President Franklin Roosevelt, who was seeking a third term.

headline: Artificial Unintelligence
text: In the early stages of the Lesser Depression, those of us who knew a bit about the macroeconomic debates of the 1930s, and realized how relevant the hard-won insights of Keynes and Hicks were to the post-financial crisis world, often felt a sense of despair. Everywhere you looked, people who imagined themselves sophisticated and possessed of deep understanding were resurrecting 75-year-old fallacies and presenting them as deep insights.

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Facebook Assistant
text: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the industry.

headline: ‘Narcos’ Episode 3 Recap: Pablo the Politician
text: Read all of our “Narcos” recaps.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Campaign Makes Appeal Amid Fund-Raising Woes
text: Jeb Bush’s presidential campaign, which to date has raised significantly more than his Republican rivals’, is encountering difficulties maintaining its torrid pace as Mr. Bush slips in the polls and top party donors continue to withhold their commitments.

headline: Prison Vendors See Continued Signs of a Captive Market
text: Is there anything that cannot be turned into a weapon? Walk around the exhibitors’ hall at the conference of the American Correctional Association, held in Indianapolis in early August, and at some point the question will answer itself. Apparently, with enough malign intent and the right tools — a lighter, for instance — even disposable plates can be transformed into shivs.

headline: Texas Rangers Rise After a Trip to the Woodshed
text: The bold summer revival of the Texas Rangers began immediately after they hit bottom. On July 28, three days before the nonwaiver trading deadline, the Rangers scored five runs in the first inning against the Yankees. Then they gave up the next 21 runs of the game, without getting a hit.

headline: The Week in Political Pictures
text: The 10th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, campaign barbecue and an outstanding teenager in New Hampshire in this week’s political pictures.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Give Us the Ballot’
text: This week, Ari Berman and Simon Winchester.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Give Us the Ballot’
text: This week, Ari Berman talks about “Give Us the Ballot”; Simon Winchester discusses Susan Barker’s “The Incarnations”; and Parul Sehgal has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — In June, Will Shortz announced that he was going to start alternating Mel Taub’s Puns and Anagrams byline with other constructors’ and today’s offering is by the veteran crossword constructor Joe DiPietro.

headline: Swansea City’s Garry Monk Rises in Premier League
text: SWANSEA, Wales — In a quiet moment during the Premier League’s annual preseason meeting of head coaches a few weeks ago, Louis van Gaal of Manchester United shook hands with Garry Monk of Swansea City.

headline: The Strip
text: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: A New Race for the Arctic
text: The warming climate has transformed a region once largely bound by ice, now sought after for territory, transit routes and natural resources.

headline: U.S. Is Playing Catch-Up With Russia in Scramble for the Arctic
text: ABOARD COAST GUARD CUTTER ALEX HALEY, in the Chukchi Sea — With warming seas creating new opportunities at the top of the world, nations are scrambling over the Arctic — its territorial waters, transit routes and especially its natural resources — in a rivalry some already call a new Cold War.

headline: Owned by Union, Amalgamated Bank Gives Lift to the Left
text: When Ready for Hillary, a pro-Hillary Rodham Clinton “super PAC,” wanted to take out a million-dollar loan five months before it planned to go out of business, it turned to a bank that was founded to guard the savings of New York City garment workers.

headline: Greg Schott of MuleSoft: Beware the Threats to a Positive Workplace
text: This interview with Greg Schott, chief executive of MuleSoft, a software company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Lebanese Protesters Aim for Rare Unity Against Gridlocked Government
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Thousands of Lebanese demonstrators gathered on Saturday evening to protest towering garbage piles, corruption and political dysfunction, infusing new momentum into a campaign for better governance that seeks to unite citizens often divided by religion and politics.

headline: Mets Find Lineup Solutions in a Single, Mysterious Chart
text: Before every series, Mets Manager Terry Collins receives a three-ring binder full of scouting reports, charts and numbers. Collins combs through the information, wearing his glasses, highlighting things as he goes, making notes in pencil. He uses the binder to help fill out his lineup each day, a task that has become much more complex lately.

headline: Rousting the Book Pirates From Google
text: The Haggler will now don his professorial tweeds because he starts this episode in teacher mode. All of the action below revolves around the Google Play store, an online destination that may be unfamiliar to Apple fans. So a brief explanation. You know iBooks, iTunes and the App Store? Well, Google Play is all of those rolled together, for anyone using devices with the Android operating system.

headline: Ashton Eaton’s Record Moment for U.S. Is Tempered by Error in 4x100 Relay
text: BEIJING — With his own decathlon world record in reach but with 1,500 meters still to run, Ashton Eaton did anything but stay in the moment.

headline: In Sharing Baseball’s Joys, Mourning Something Lost
text: With our road trip just days away, I was having second thoughts. Was this going to be too much baseball? I asked my son. “No such thing as too much baseball!” he answered. I smiled. We were ready.

headline: Michelle DeFeo of Laurent-Perrier: A Toast to France in a Queens Loft
text: Michelle DeFeo is the president of Laurent-Perrier U.S.

headline: Galloping Away to a Place Beyond Words
text: On Thursday at noon, I ditch the San Francisco courthouse where I work as a Spanish interpreter and high-tail it home to swap my conservative suit for breeches and dusty paddock boots. I arm myself with allergy pills, nasal spray and a puff from an asthma inhaler. Patches on my windbreaker and baseball cap identify me as a National Park Service volunteer.

headline: Fly Riffs on Air Strings
text: Contestants from around the globe plucked imaginary strings, competing for the title of Air Guitar World Champion 2015.

headline: Players’ Names Spawn a Mouthful of Errors
text: With a stadium bearing his name at the United States Open, an obvious link binds the jazz legend Louis Armstrong to tennis. But one of Armstrong’s recordings with Ella Fitzgerald, “Let’s Call the Whole Thing Off,” at times encapsulates a subtle feature of matches.

headline: Any Plans for New Year’s Eve? The College Football Playoff Has Some
text: Forget about the big ball in Times Square. Select a Champagne that pairs well with Buffalo wings. Make sure your New Year’s Eve date likes college football as much as you do.

headline: Turkey Launches Its First Airstrikes of ISIS Campaign
text: ISTANBUL — Turkey has launched its first wave of airstrikes as part of the United States-led coalition to fight the Islamic State, the Foreign Ministry said in a statement Saturday.

headline: Prominent Afghan Officials Are Killed by Taliban in 3 Attacks in South
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban insurgents killed three prominent local government officials and at least nine other people in three separate attacks in southern Afghanistan on Saturday.

headline: The Summer That Never Was
text: I NEVER went to Iceland. I suppose I should say I didn’t go to Iceland this summer — never sounds a little melodramatic, possibly terminal. It’s not as if I’ve died and all hope of ever having gone to Iceland is obviated. But for some reason this missed opportunity is causing me more than the usual, near-toxic level of regret. I’ve had a free apartment in Reykjavik on offer for several years, and somehow I’ve never made it there. The owner of the apartment sends me photos of the aurora borealis that break my heart.

headline: Casey Harris
text: Casey Harris is the keyboard player for the indie rock band X Ambassadors, whose song “Renegades” has been No. 1 on Billboard’s Alternative chart for the past 11 weeks.

headline: Diet Advice That Ignores Hunger
text: TOWARD the end of the Second World War, researchers at the University of Minnesota began a legendary experiment on the psychology and physiology of human starvation — and, thus, on hunger. The subjects were 36 conscientious objectors, some lean, some not. For 24 weeks, these men were semi-starved, fed not quite 1,600 calories a day of foods chosen to represent the fare of European famine areas: “whole-wheat bread, potatoes, cereals and considerable amounts of turnips and cabbage” with “token amounts” of meat and dairy.

headline: The Real Threat to Hillary Clinton
text: THE predicted Republican front-runner flails. The actual Republican front-runner rails, peddling insults instead of ideas. And the story line caroms from misogyny to xenophobia to a tussle over tresses: toupee or not toupee?

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Keep Baseball Timeless

headline: This Land Is Our Land
text: THE other day, my teenage daughter and I were idly browsing real estate porn, a monument to American inequality: a private island in the Bahamas selling for $17.9 million; a 900-acre retreat in Washington State for $11 million; and an 83-acre estate in Colorado for a cool $100 million.

headline: In Case You Missed It: Top Articles of the Week
text: Catch up with the most-read sports stories in The New York Times from Aug. 21 to Aug. 27.

headline: 3 Children Among Migrants Found Crammed in Van Are Hospitalized in Austria
text: VIENNA — Three small children found crammed into a small van with 23 other migrants were hospitalized with severe dehydration in northern Austria, narrowly averting another fatal tragedy for refugees fleeing the Middle East and risking their lives with smugglers, the police said Saturday.

headline: Raging as My Sister’s Light Dims
text: Don’t let anyone try to soft-pedal what is going on, use metaphors and literary allusions to turn my sister’s cancer into a great meeting with the blessings of life.

headline: Donald Trump, Traitor to His Class
text: THE Donald Trump phenomenon is a great gift to pundits because it can be analyzed and criticized in so many different ways. But two shorthands seem particularly useful. First, Trump is essentially using the Republican primary to run a third-party campaign, not a right-wing insurgency. Second, Trump’s appeal is oddly like that of Franklin Roosevelt, in the sense that he’s a rich, well-connected figure — a rich New Yorker, at that — who’s campaigning as a traitor to his class.

headline: Bush and Clinton Dynasties Hit Trump Bump
text: Washington — PITY Poppy.

headline: Tea With the Queen? In Their Dreams
text: LONDON — QUEEN ELIZABETH II, at 89, is a very old lady. By day, her subjects see less of her than they used to. But by night, it’s different. Then she and her family visit millions of households up and down the kingdom. Up to a third of Britons have dreams about Her Majesty and the royals.

headline: Optimistic About Inflation, Stanley Fischer Suggests That Fed Will Stick to Plan on Rates
text: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo. — The Federal Reserve’s vice chairman, Stanley Fischer, said on Saturday that he saw “good reason” to expect that inflation would rebound to a healthier pace as the American economy continued to grow.

headline: The Battle for Biomedical Supremacy
text: States from coast to coast are using public funds to help their medical schools recruit scientific stars from other states or to prevent their own stars from being lured away by lucrative offers. There have long been recruitment battles among academic institutions, but today we’re in the midst of what The Chronicle of Higher Education calls a “boom in academic poaching.”

headline: As the Stock Market Swings
text: By the close of the stock market on Friday, the recent ups and downs in share prices had worked out to a mild correction. In all, the market was down 6.6 percent from its all-time high in May.

headline: A Peace Plea for South Sudan
text: It would be satisfying to celebrate the peace deal signed in South Sudan as an end to the warfare that has been the lot of the land’s 12 million people for most of the past 60 years, including the extraordinarily cruel civil conflict that has ravaged the country since independence in July 2011. But at least eight cease-fires have collapsed since civil war erupted in December 2013, some within hours of being signed, and both sides have already accused each other of continuing attacks. Only continued pressure by the United Nations and the United States on the South Sudanese leaders will give the peace any chance.

headline: The Water Receded. The Anger’s Still Here.
text: New Orleans — WHY are we still so angry? Even sympathetic newcomers can’t quite figure out why we New Orleanians are not over it a decade later.

headline: Texas Deputy Killed ‘Because He Wore a Uniform,’ Sheriff Says
text: HOUSTON — A 30-year-old Houston man was arrested Saturday in the fatal shooting the night before of a sheriff’s deputy who was filling the gas tank of his patrol car.

headline: Europe to Bolster Railway Security After Thwarted Train Attack
text: PARIS — European countries have agreed to increase security checks in railway stations and on trains, and are calling for improved cooperation among intelligence services, France’s interior minister said Saturday after an emergency meeting of European officials in Paris.

headline: The Art of the Presidential Exit
text: Washington — OVER dry martinis and drawn-out dinners with artists, authors, tech billionaires and Hollywood moguls, President Obama has begun to contemplate life after the White House.

headline: Topless Women in Times Square
text: The X-rated establishments of days past have given way to almost naked painted women and Elmos seeking tips from tourists.

headline: A Decade After Katrina, New Orleans Is Partying Again, and Still Rebuilding
text: NEW ORLEANS — “Today is ceiling drywall,” said Dani Babon, a 24-year-old site supervisor for the St. Bernard Project, a volunteer group that was started the year after Hurricane Katrina.

headline: With Ruble’s Decline, Russian Tourists Gain Appreciation for the Motherland
text: VYATSKOYE, Russia — The tourists streamed out of the tall white bus onto an asphalt parking lot in the middle of this spruced-up village. Wearing sun hats and wielding cameras, they peered into the gardens of brightly painted houses and listened to a tour guide talk about enterprising peasants.

headline: New Alternatives to Statins Add to a Quandary on Cholesterol
text: ROCHESTER, Minn. — Doctors have long faced a conundrum in prescribing statins to lower cholesterol and heart attack risk: The drugs are cheap and effective for most people, and large, rigorous clinical trials have found minimal side effects. But as many as 25 percent  of those who try them complain of muscle pain. Others stop taking the drugs because, they say, they cause a hazy memory or sleep problems, among other side effects not documented in studies.

headline: California Death Penalty, Struck Down Over Delays, Faces Next Test
text: Whether California’s application of the death penalty is so drawn out and arbitrary that it amounts to cruel and unusual punishment will be argued on Monday before a federal appeals court in Pasadena.

headline: American Pharoah Is Calm Amid the Saratoga Storm
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — It was 3 p.m. Friday and the Triple Crown winner American Pharoah was taking a stroll near Barn 25, where he was stabled ahead of Saturday’s Travers Stakes at Saratoga Race Course. He stopped to pose for members of the news media and his adoring fans at each end of the wooden green barn, where security barricades had been set up since his arrival Wednesday.

headline: In a Venezuelan Border Town, a State of Emergency Is Barely Perceptible
text: SAN ANTONIO DEL TÁCHIRA, Venezuela — President Nicolás Maduro has declared a state of emergency in this Venezuelan border town in what he says is nothing less than a fight for national survival. More than 1,000 Colombian immigrants have been deported and some basic guarantees, like the right to hold most public gatherings, have been suspended.

headline: As Homicide Rate Rises, Washington Mayor Pledges Action
text: The police in Washington on Saturday were investigating the fatal shootings of two men the night before, the latest in a city that has seen a sharp increase in homicides this year.

headline: A High Point on the Appalachian Trail
text: The storied Appalachian Trail, which begins 2,190 miles away in Georgia, ends with a final scramble up Mount Katahdin, Maine’s highest peak.

headline: As Hikers Celebrate on Appalachian Trail, Some Ask: Where Will It End?
text: MOUNT KATAHDIN, Me. — The storied Appalachian Trail, which begins 2,190 miles away in Georgia, ends here, with a final scramble up Maine’s highest peak — some of it nearly vertical, much of it blocked by boulders. For those who have trekked five or six months, Katahdin’s iconic summit is an exhausting challenge with a rewarding end.

headline: Keen Ice Defeats American Pharoah at Travers Stakes
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — They were fully aware of this historic racetrack’s reputation for felling iconic horses like Gallant Fox and Affirmed, as well as immortal ones, like the great Secretariat. They also knew of its charms, how racehorses are not only loved here but revered and how the people who follow them believe this is truly Valhalla.

headline: Venezuelan Border Town Remains Active Despite President’s Order
text: A state of emergency at San Antonio del Táchira, which shares a border with Colombia, has spurred little change in daily public activity.

headline: Conflicting Advice
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — There is a concept in psychology called the “backfire effect,” and basically it explains why no one will ever win an argument on the Internet.

headline: Paul Royle, Who Fled Nazis in a ‘Great Escape,’ Dies at 101
text: Paul Royle, whose escape from a German prisoner of war camp in 1944 with 75 other Allied soldiers inspired the 1963 Steve McQueen movie “The Great Escape,” died on Aug. 23 in Perth, Australia. He was 101.

headline: Johan Renvall, American Ballet Theater Principal, Dies at 55
text: Johan Renvall, a principal dancer at American Ballet Theater whose range there from 1978 to 1996 could stun audiences with spectacular classical technique and — in dramatic ballets — powerful intensity, died on Monday in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 55 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: The Jordanian Aid Worker
text: A veteran aid worker finished a stint in South Sudan and then decided to tour the Balkans. He came to Belgrade, saw refugees in the parks and soon discovered Refugee Aid Serbia, a donation center.

headline: George Cleve, Conductor Who Interpreted Mozart, Dies at 79
text: George Cleve, a conductor known to New York audiences for his guest appearances with the Mostly Mozart Festival and the New York City Ballet, died on Thursday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 79.

headline: Bystander’s Death Shows Risks in Gun-Buy Stings
text: In a dangerous profession, it is among the most dangerous of jobs. The police officers who go undercover to arrest illegal firearms dealers can quickly find themselves at the mercy of their targets, conducting big-money transactions in close quarters with jumpy, suspicious criminals quick to draw guns.

headline: Torpor Overtakes the Mets in a Second Straight Loss at Home
text: After a rollicking trip in homer-happy parks like Baltimore, Colorado and Philadelphia, the Mets were as confident as they had been in years when they returned to Citi Field on Friday. But so far, in two games back home, their offense has crash-landed with a pronounced thud.

headline: Ryan Palmer Plays On Despite a Painful Loss
text: EDISON, N.J. — Fathers and sons go together in golf like tee boxes and drivers. Where you find one, the other typically follows. For many of the top players, their fathers were the ones who breathed life into their golf dreams. That was certainly the case for Ryan Palmer, a Texan who was 9 when his father, Butch, introduced him to the game.

headline: Andrelton Simmons and Didi Gregorius Share Journey: Small Island to Big Leagues
text: ATLANTA — The first time Andrelton Simmons set eyes on Didi Gregorius, what he noticed was not Gregorius’s strong throwing arm, his fleet feet or anything he did with a bat in his hands. They were, after all, only 5 years old.

headline: Kyle Jean-Baptiste, Actor in ‘Les Misérables,’ Dies at 21
text: Kyle Jean-Baptiste, the first African-American actor to play the lead role of Jean Valjean in the popular Broadway musical “Les Misérables,” died on Friday after falling from a fire escape in Brooklyn. He was 21.

text: Read all of our “Narcos” recaps.

headline: Met Extends Show on China’s Fashion Influence
text: The Metropolitan Museum of Art’s “China: Through the Looking Glass” is attaining blockbuster status, Vanessa Friedman writes. It’s proven so popular, including with Chinese visitors, that it will be extended through Sept. 7, Randy Kennedy reports. Read more »

headline: Ryan Fitzpatrick Finds Rhythm as Jets’ Offense Shows a Pulse
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Every day, Ryan Fitzpatrick says, his connection with the Jets’ receivers gets a little better. Their timing improves, their relationships blossom, and their tendencies become more and more familiar to one another.

headline: Luis Severino’s Strong Outing Carries Yankees to Victory
text: ATLANTA — Luis Severino pitched six shutout innings, and Didi Gregorius and Brian McCann delivered key hits for the second consecutive game as the Yankees beat the Atlanta Braves, 3-1, on Saturday.

headline: Giants Have Rough Night but See a Sliver of Hope
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Saturday did not begin well for the Giants. When a team’s extensive injury list lengthens during a leisurely pregame warm-up, it figures to be a long day.

headline: Fan Dies After Falling From Upper Deck at Atlanta’s Turner Field
text: ATLANTA — A man in his early 60s died Saturday night after falling more than 40 feet from the upper deck at Turner Field during the seventh inning of the Yankees’ 3-1 win over the Atlanta Braves.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 30, 2015
text: “The fault is not with those who cultivate the opium. It’s with the idiots who consume it.”

headline: Janna Burke, Gregory Spock

Fitzgerald performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary, Our Lady of the Isle, in Nantucket, Mass.

headline: Julie Griffith,  Leo Goodman

text: Nicola Odessa Albano and Dr. Dominic Peter Rachiele were married Saturday at the Church of St. Rita in Staten Island. Cardinal Orlando Beltran Quevedo, the Roman Catholic archbishop of Cotabato, the Philippines, and an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.

Rabbi Daniel A. Sklar, a cousin of the groom, is to officiate at Riverside on the Potomac, in Leesburg, Va.

text: Dr. Irina Lisker and Michael Joseph Weil are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Ronald Roth at the Estate at the Florentine Gardens, a party space in River Vale, N.J.

headline: Genevieve Kimberlin,  Devon Jarvis
text: Genevieve Steele Kimberlin, a daughter of Joni S. Kimberlin and Kevin B. Kimberlin of Greenwich, Conn., was married Saturday to Devon Michael Jarvis, a son of Carol A. Jarvis and Jackson M. Jarvis of Fairfield, Iowa. The Rev. Jack Davidson, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich.

headline: Merrill West, Ryan Hardy
text: Merrill Elizabeth West and Ryan Wayne Hardy are to be married Sunday at Cherry Hill in Central Park. The Rev. Dr. R. Scott Colglazier, a Congregationalist minister and a friend of the bride’s family, is to officiate.

Lemanski, also of Hazlet. The Rev. Daniel Kirk, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Benedict Catholic Church in Holmdel, N.J.

headline: Jayne Kang, Phillip Kim
text: Jayne Kang, a daughter of Junghee Kang and Byung Jae Kang of Austin, Tex., was married Saturday to Phillip Kim, the son of Grace Kim of Blue Bell, Pa., and the late Sang Kwon. The Rev. Gerald Donnelly officiated at the Bermuda Run Country Club in Winston-Salem, N.C.

headline: Kathleen McCarthy, Brendan Kelleher
text: Kathleen Anne McCarthy and Brendan William Kelleher were married Saturday at Our Lady of Victories Catholic Church in Boston. The Very Rev. Brian R. Kiely, an uncle of the groom, performed the ceremony.

headline: Puerto Rico Postpones Debt Plan
text: Citing time lost to a tropical storm, the government of Puerto Rico on Saturday postponed by one week a plan for a “negotiated moratorium” on $72 billion of debt.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
text: 11 A.M. (BBC America) THE MATRIX (1999) The Wachowskis wrote and directed this sci-fi thriller, which won four Oscars. Neo (Keanu Reeves, above), a hacker, learns from Morpheus (Laurence Fishburne) that life is really a computer-generated fiction called the Matrix, imposed on humans by robotic overlords who harvest their energy. They must protect the last real human city, Zion, while battling the machines and the evil Agent Smith (Hugo Weaving). “With enough visual bravado to sustain a steady element of surprise (even when the film’s most important Oracle turns out to be a grandmotherly type who bakes cookies and has magnets on her refrigerator), ‘The Matrix’ makes particular virtues out of eerily inhuman lighting effects, lightning-fast virtual scene changes (as when Neo wishes for guns and thousands of them suddenly appear) and the martial arts stunts that are its single strongest selling point,” Janet Maslin wrote in The Times. “As supervised by Yuen Wo Ping, these airborne sequences bring Hong Kong action style home to audiences in a mainstream American adventure with big prospects as a cult classic and with the future very much in mind.”

text: METROPOLITAN

headline: Oliver Sacks, Casting Light on the Interconnectedness of Life
text: It’s no coincidence that so many of the qualities that made Oliver Sacks such a brilliant writer are the same qualities that made him an ideal doctor: keen powers of observation and a devotion to detail, deep reservoirs of sympathy, and an intuitive understanding of the fathomless mysteries of the human brain and the intricate connections between the body and the mind.

headline: Dr. Oliver Sacks, Explorer of the Brain
text: Dr. Oliver Sacks was a neurologist and best-selling author who explored the brain’s strangest pathways. His work touched Hollywood, theater, even opera, and his legacy lasts in the stories he told.

headline: Oliver Sacks, Neurologist Who Wrote About the Brain’s Quirks, Dies at 82
text: Oliver Sacks, the neurologist and acclaimed author who explored some of the brain’s strangest pathways in best-selling case histories like “The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat,” using his patients’ disorders as starting points for eloquent meditations on consciousness and the human condition, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.

headline: Defection of Perry Aide to Trump Camp Has Iowans Fearing for Image
text: DES MOINES — Is Iowa for sale?

headline: Behind Deadly Tianjin Blast, Shortcuts and Lax Rules
text: TIANJIN, China — One partner was the son of a local police chief, the other an executive at a state-run chemicals firm. After meeting at a dinner party, they started a company here to handle the export of the most dangerous chemicals made in China, promising “outstanding service” and “good results.”

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know to start your week.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
text: Here are the week’s top stories.

headline: Apps to Bring Math and Science Skills Back After Summer’s Slide
text: After a summer of fun, the shift back into schoolwork can be tough for kids. Feeling out-of-practice when it comes to math facts, logical thinking or even, for younger kids, the alphabet can make the transition even harder. It’s time for a little review, but that review will go over much more sweetly if it seems more like fun than work.

headline: Tianjin Explosion Reveals Company That Exploited Weak Governance
text: More than two weeks after explosions at its warehouses killed 145 people, Rui Hai International Logistics has become a symbol of the high cost of rapid industrialization in a closed political system rife with corruption.

headline: Oil, Oligarchs, Climate and Obama’s Arctic-Focused Alaska Trip
text: The Arctic seems hot these days, and not just because of rising temperatures and retreating ice, or because President Obama plans to speak at an Arctic policy meeting and visit an Arctic community on an Alaska tour starting Monday.

headline: Defying Expectations, Mayor Ras Baraka Is Praised in All Corners of Newark
text: NEWARK — Mayor Ras J. Baraka came into office last summer practically taunting his doubters.
