text: In Iowa, when J. Ann Selzer talks, people listen.

headline: Jason Rezaian’s Status Unclear After Iran Sentences 2
text: TEHRAN — Iran’s judiciary sentenced two people to 10 years in prison on Sunday for spying for the United States and Israel, but their names were not released, local media reported.

headline: ‘The Witches of Venice’ by Philip Glass to Have American Premiere
text: Philip Glass’s “The Witches of Venice,” an opera-ballet for children first performed two decades ago at La Scala in Milan, will be given its American premiere next summer during Opera Saratoga’s 2016 Summer Festival in upstate New York, the festival announced Sunday.

headline: The Time an 11-Year-Old Took Down Nadal
text: “So, about Nadal,” Estee Ackerman said in her unassuming way, about to relive the summer of 2013 serve by serve, volley by volley, point by point.

headline: ‘Straight Outta Compton’ Is No. 1 for Third Week at Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES – With the return to school preoccupying a major chunk of the movie-going audience, and Hollywood holding back significant new releases as a result, theaters in North America were relatively uninhabited over the weekend.

headline: 1965: Dr. King’s Children Enroll in White School
text: ATLANTA — The Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. and his top assistant in the civil rights movement today enrolled five of their children in a previously all-white elementary school as classes began. Dr. King’s wife Coretta brought two of her children, and Mrs. Ralph Abernathy, whose husband is vice president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, enrolled three of her children in the Spring Street school.

headline: Republican Candidates Address Donald Trump and Volatility in Polls
text: As the summer of Donald J. Trump winds down, some of the real estate mogul’s rivals took to the Sunday political talk shows, discussing plans for emerging from Mr. Trump’s shadow in the Republican field.

headline: Obama’s Alaska Visit Puts Climate, Not Energy, in Forefront
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will travel to Alaska on Monday to call for urgent and aggressive action to tackle climate change, capitalizing on a poignant tableau of melting glaciers, crumbling permafrost and rising sea levels to illustrate the immediacy of an issue he hopes to make a central element of his legacy.

headline: Big Apple Circus to Focus on Early Travel in 38th Season
text: The Big Apple Circus’s new show, “The Grand Tour!,” will arrive at Lincoln Center in October. The production is a tribute to early-20th-century travel, and will feature performers from every continent, except Antarctica.

headline: Food Trucks Divide a Missouri Town Looking for Sizzle
text: NORTH KANSAS CITY, Mo. — This region for years has prized its trendy and innovative side — from the shiny, modern performing arts center that resembles a seashell to the custom homes that look more Malibu than Midwest to the streetcar that is near completion.

headline: 1940: Arab World ‘Sitting on Fence’ As War Nears Its Threshold
text: CAIRO — As the British Middle East concentrates its attention on preparing to resist the expected Italian drive from the Libyan Desert eastward into Egypt, the Arab world, which in some of its parts flamed into revolt against the Ottoman power during the World War and seldom has been entirely peaceful since, remains curiously quiet.

headline: VMAs 2015: Moments to Watch
text: “Enough of the finger pointing and the slut shaming,” Jon Caramanica wrote in 2013 in response to the moral panic that gripped the nation over Miley Cyrus’s twerk-filled, tongue-wagging MTV Video Music Awards performance. The haters haven’t gone away, but Ms. Cyrus rolls on, ready to court controversy, as she teased in an interview with The Times last week. There will be skits, “psychedelic” and “raw” elements, and thousands of Twitter fingers ready to critique her every move. “I didn’t want this V.M.A.s to be like they’ve been in the past,” she said. Since it’s the Viacom executive Van Toffler’s last year, anything goes: It’s one big party, and MTV is footing the bill. (The show starts at 9 p.m. on MTV.)

headline: Hillary Clinton Secures Backing of Senator Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire
text: Senator Jeanne Shaheen, the popular Democrat from New Hampshire and the first woman to be elected senator and governor in the state, will publicly endorse Hillary Rodham Clinton next Saturday, Mrs. Clinton’s campaign said.

headline: Protesters Demand Restoration of Mephistopheles Sculpture in St. Petersburg
text: MOSCOW — Hundreds of St. Petersburg residents and cultural preservationists gathered on Sunday to protest the destruction of a bas-relief sculpture of Mephistopheles that was removed from a historic 1910 apartment building last week and demand that it be restored.

headline: To Jar North, South Korea Used a Pop-Music Barrage
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Chirpy bubble-gum harmonies bop across the desolate Demilitarized Zone. “Look at me, I’m your genie, your dream, your genie,” the K-pop band Girls’ Generation beckons as grim-faced soldiers patrol the border.

headline: After American Pharoah Is Dethroned, Baffert Has Plan to Cement His Place
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — Neither American Pharoah nor his trainer, Bob Baffert, looked worn out or deflated the morning after the colt was run down by Keen Ice in the final strides of the 146th running of the Travers Stakes. The white-haired Baffert smiled as he led his big bay colt outside his barn here, stopping to let a little girl feed him carrots.

headline: Battling Arm Injuries, a Tennis Player Changes ... Hands
text: My forehand sailed deep — not just behind-the-baseline deep, but over-the-fence deep. I’ve played tennis for more than four decades, yet I was staring at my right hand as if it had never swung a racket, which was sort of true.

headline: Soul-Searching in TV Land Over the Challenges of a New Golden Age
text: John Landgraf’s comments arrived like a thunderbolt.

headline: Egypt Defends Ruling Against Two Al Jazeera Journalists
text: CAIRO — The Egyptian Foreign Ministry said Sunday that it had summoned the British ambassador to object to his comments on a recent court ruling to jail two journalists, escalating the government’s defense of its crackdown on dissent.

headline: 4x400 Relay Offers Bright Moment, but U.S. No Longer Dazzles
text: BEIJING — The last gold medal went to the United States as the veteran LaShawn Merritt ran another poised and powerful anchor leg to clinch victory in a tight 4x400-meter relay.

headline: Mets Hang On to Edge the Red Sox
text: A familiar sound, a nervous murmuring, emanated from the crowd during the seventh inning as Manager Terry Collins hurried out of the Mets’ dugout toward the mound.

headline: On China’s Economy
text: Economic fears about China culminated last week in a global market rout.

headline: Mount McKinley Will Again Be Called Denali
text: President Obama announced on Sunday that Mount McKinley was being renamed Denali, using his executive power to restore an Alaska Native name with deep cultural significance to the tallest mountain in North America.

headline: Tennis Players Are Helped by Products (at Least They Think So)
text: In recent years there has been a proliferation of so-called smart rackets and other high-tech gadgets, including Sony’s Smart Tennis Sensor and Babolat’s Play racket, that compile data on strokes. This fall, Babolat will introduce POP, a wristband that will provide similar analysis when used with any racket.

headline: The Phone Charger Situation
text: A group of Syrian refugees gathered around a single power strip to charge their phones.

headline: A New Look for the Wadsworth Atheneum
text: Photos of the renovated museum in downtown Hartford.

headline: The Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford Puts Final Touches on a Comeback
text: HARTFORD — At the Wadsworth Atheneum, they called it the Leak Tour, and sometimes the Horror Tour.

headline: Review: ‘Todrick,’ on the YouTube Star Todrick Hall’s Relentless Pursuit of Fame
text: “Todrick” is a television show about the making of YouTube videos by a singer who once tried to become famous by performing on TV and failed. Which is to say that either the performer has changed, music has changed, or TV has.

headline: Review: Martha Graham Dancers Explore Myth and Machismo at Jacob’s Pillow
text: BECKET, Mass. — The ghost of Ted Shawn, who turned a farm here into the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival and worked tirelessly to present dancing as a manly activity, might have been pleased to see a burly guy chopping wood on Thursday on the barnlike stage of the Ted Shawn Theater. Shawn might have been tickled, too, to learn that the man wielding the ax was a member of the dance troupe of his old student and partner Martha Graham.

headline: Zhang Huoding of Peking Opera Takes a Turn in the United States
text: BEIJING — When “The Legend of the White Snake” opens Wednesday at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center, an American audience will get its first glimpse of Zhang Huoding, one of China’s biggest Peking Opera stars, as she makes her United States debut.

headline: Review: LoftOpera Brings Mischief, and a Crowd, to Berlioz and Mahler
text: I’ll admit, with a certain degree of shame, that my predominant feeling on Friday night when I entered the Muse, a warehouse deep in Bushwick, Brooklyn, usually used as a circus school, was surprise, even shock. I hadn’t trusted that 10 love songs by Berlioz and Mahler had much power to draw a crowd; after all, lieder has long been opera’s poor relation, and even opera, some say, today struggles to find an audience.

headline: Review: Choosing a Husband or a Lover in Dell’Arte Opera Ensemble’s ‘Rosina’
text: Did you hear? Rosina has a baby. From Cherubino! They’ve moved to Madrid. He paints — mostly her — but that doesn’t pay the rent. Rumor has it that Count Almaviva is looking for Rosina, but nobody knows if he’s out to kill her for her infidelity or beg forgiveness for his own string of escapades, which helped push her into the arms of his young page.

headline: Review: At Indian Dance Festival, Subtleties in the Sway of a Torso
text: Since India has many languages, it would take a true polyglot to comprehend all its poetry. On Friday, when the Erasing Borders Festival of Indian Dance held an indoor program enticingly called “An Evening of ‘Poetry, Danced’ ” at Pace University’s Schimmel Center, the audience was given words in five different languages. If we accept Frost’s theory that poetry is “what is lost in translation,” probably most of those present lost a great deal. Much, however, remained.

headline: The Stress of the Slam
text: In the days leading up to the 1969 United States Open, pressure was mounting on Rod Laver. He had won the Australian Open in grueling fashion and followed it up with victories at the French Open and Wimbledon.

headline: In Lorde’s Wake, a Groundswell of Female Rebels in Pop
text: From a distance, this seems like a great moment for female friendship in pop. Look at Taylor Swift’s current tour, which includes appearances from people she admires, often women: Serena Williams, Selena Gomez, Mary J. Blige, Ellen DeGeneres, Lisa Kudrow (hmmm), Joan Baez (what?).

headline: Supplanting CBS and Tennis Channel, ESPN Empire Will Show All U.S. Open Matches
text: Serena Williams’s quest to complete the Grand Slam at the U.S. Open will be a production of the ESPN empire, viewable only on ESPN, ESPN2 and ESPN3.

headline: Review: ‘The End of Tsarist Russia’ by Dominic Lieven
text: Dominic Lieven’s stated reason for this contribution to the centenary literature on World War I is to place Russia “where it belongs, at the very center” of the war’s history. Certainly the war proved to be at the center of Russian history, leading to revolution, dictatorship, repression and more war.

headline: What’s New at the U.S. Open? Start at the Top
text: The most visible change at the U.S. Open this year is hard to miss. Long before fans get to the U.S.T.A. Billie Jean King National Tennis Center by road or by rail, they will notice the new shape of Arthur Ashe Stadium.

headline: M’s and N’s
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — Who knew there were three different ways to invite us into the pool?

headline: Review: ‘Phantom,’ on the Trail of Mumbai Terrorists
text: Daniyal (Saif Ali Khan) and Nawaz (Katrina Kaif), the hapless secret agent heroes of Kabir Khan’s revenge thriller “Phantom,” could have used some pointers before being sent into the field.

headline: Susan Rice, Obama’s Security Adviser, Urges Pakistan to Do More Against Militants
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — President Obama’s national security adviser, Susan E. Rice, urged Pakistani civilian and military leaders on Sunday to do more to stop militants from using Pakistani territory to stage attacks in neighboring countries.

headline: Review: ‘Magic Trick,’ the Tale of a Breakup in the World of Burlesque
text: A relationship dramedy set in the world of burlesque, Mariah MacCarthy’s “Magic Trick” lives low to the ground. This is partly by necessity: The play’s main character is a young woman who uses a wheelchair, and much of the action occurs as she and others are sitting or lying down.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Aug. 31
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Kanye West to Perform an ‘808s’ Concert
text: Kanye West will perform a one-off concert celebrating his 2008 album, “808s & Heartbreak,” at the Hollywood Bowl next month. That album, which featured heavy use of auto-tune and synthesizers, did not receive universal acclaim upon release but now is regarded as a pivotal influence on current hip-hop and R&B stars, including Drake, the Weeknd and Future. “  ‘808s & Heartbreak’ sounds like none of his other albums, nor any rap album of note,” Jon Caramanica wrote in his review for The Times. “At best, it is a rough sketch for a great album.” Mr. West later described it as “the first black new wave album” in an interview with Mr. Caramanica. The concert will take place on Sept. 25. Tickets go on sale Friday.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Authorizes Emergency Measure to Aid Homeless People
text: With few beds available in New York City’s homeless shelters, Mayor Bill de Blasio has authorized another emergency measure to provide rental assistance to people facing homelessness.

headline: Captain’s Death Rattles a Marina in New Jersey
text: BELFORD, N.J. — He was a retired construction worker who turned his fishing hobby into a low-pressure business, taking a delight in almost anything he brought back.

headline: Manchester United Sputters as Wayne Rooney Struggles to Ignite

headline: As Police Investigate Deaths in Truck, Migrants and Smugglers Appear to Shift Tactics
text: NICKELSDORF, Austria — Investigators continued to work their way on Sunday through a truck that carried 71 migrants to their deaths last week, removing articles of clothing and bagging and labeling them as possible evidence in an inquiry against the smuggling operation believed to be responsible.

headline: An Archipelago’s Gulag
text: Russians clash over how best to memorialize those killed at a monastery used as a Soviet prison camp.

headline: Maria Sharapova Withdraws From the U.S. Open
text: Maria Sharapova, the 2006 U.S. Open champion, withdrew from the Open on Sunday, citing a leg injury.

headline: In Marriage, Andy Murray Finds an Escape From Tennis
text: For the fourth consecutive year, Andy Murray, the 2012 United States Open champion, will speak to The New York Times during his run at the Open about topics relating to tennis and his life.

headline: Covering Serena Williams Through the Years
text: The New York Times has followed Serena Williams’s career since 1990, when she was an 8-year-old in Compton, Calif. Here are excerpts from The Times’s coverage of some of her significant moments at Grand Slam events.

headline: A Tug of War Over Gulag History in Russia’s North
text: SOLOVETSKY ISLANDS, Russia — Yuri Brodsky, who has dedicated his life to exposing the dark secrets of the ancient Solovetsky Monastery, pointed at a small, dirty courtyard window blocked by a crooked red brick wall.

headline: Grand Slam Dominance: Serena Williams, in Three Charts
text: In her service game, her ability to bounce back after losing a first set and her hold on the top ranking, Williams stands apart.

headline: Ahead of I.P.O., Univision Faces Bigger Rival Than Trump: Shifting TV Habits

headline: Lonely Feeling for 86th-Ranked Tennis Player Selected to Face Serena Williams
text: Vitalia Diatchenko, a 25-year-old from Sochi, Russia, traveled to New York alone, without a coach or her family.

headline: Gary Keys, Filmmaker Who Documented Duke Ellington, Dies at 81
text: Gary Keys, a filmmaker whose documentaries captured some of the most important figures in jazz from the 1960s through the 1980s — notably Duke Ellington, the subject of three of his films — died on Aug. 9 in Manhattan. He was 81.

text: Read all of our “Narcos” recaps.

headline: ISIS Damages Temple of Baal in Palmyra
text: A week after reports of destruction by Islamic State militants in the ancient city of Palmyra in Syria, fighters severely damaged the Temple of Baal there, one of the oldest and culturally significant in the region, according to activists.

headline: Car Sales, Samsung’s New Smartwatch, and the Jobs Report
text: Major automakers are expected on Tuesday to report healthy August sales of new vehicles in the United States, despite posting an overall decline from the same month last year, which included the Labor Day weekend. Industry analysts project that year-over-year sales will drop slightly, but will still exceed 1.5 million vehicles for the month. So far this year, consumers have flooded vehicle showrooms to buy pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles, while sales of passenger cars have declined. The trend has benefited the Detroit automakers, which are expected to report sales increases in August. Analysts do not expect the recent stock market fluctuations to have had much effect on the auto industry. —Bill Vlasic

headline: Fernando Valenzuela Quietly Affirms His Status as a U.S. Citizen
text: LOS ANGELES — Fernando Valenzuela recently held his right hand over his heart and clutched an American flag in his left hand, the same one that used to fire screwballs past major league batters.

headline: Indian Scholar Who Criticized Worship of Idols Is Killed
text: NEW DELHI — An Indian scholar whose criticism of idol worship had angered religious groups was fatally shot Sunday, the police said.

headline: Growing Migrant Crisis Prompts Call for Urgent Meeting of E.U. Officials
text: LONDON — With increasing public consternation about the flow of migrants and asylum seekers to Europe and the dangers of their passage, Germany, France and Britain made a joint call on Sunday for an urgent meeting of European Union interior and justice ministers to find “concrete” measures to cope with the escalating crisis.

headline: Challenged on Left and Right, the Fed Faces a Decision on Rates
text: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo. — Conservative activists who want the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates distributed chocolate coins in golden wrappers at the local airport last week as Fed officials arrived for their annual policy retreat.

headline: Banking Ties Could Hurt Joe Biden in Race With Populist Overtone
text: During a meeting with consumer advocates in Washington in July 2010, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. lauded the Obama administration’s progress on reforms it had long sought while offering pointed words about the practices of lenders and banks.

headline: Caste Quotas in India Come Under Attack
text: AHMEDABAD, India — The resentment built slowly in Hardik Patel. It took root when he watched his younger sister lose out on a college scholarship because of India’s version of affirmative action, a system of strict quotas that reserves nearly half of government jobs and public college slots for those who come from disadvantaged castes or tribes.

headline: It’s Hard to Foretell a Brady Ruling, if There Is One
text: Trying to figure out how judges will rule is a fool’s errand, but that has not stopped prognosticators from wondering what Judge Richard M. Berman of Federal District Court in Manhattan will do in the showdown between Tom Brady and the N.F.L.

headline: Tom Coughlin Has Sober Appraisal of Giants’ Readiness
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — A day after the Giants’ stumbling preseason performance against the Jets, there were no encouraging updates about the team’s many injured stars nor were there any uplifting assessments of the team’s progress. The season opens in roughly two weeks.

headline: Wall St. Policy Poses a Challenge for Presidential Candidates
text: Even seven years after the financial crisis, Wall Street has lost none of its ability to stir partisan rancor.

headline: University of Texas at Austin Moves Confederate Statue
text: A statue of Jefferson Davis, the president of the Confederacy during the Civil War, was taken down from its pedestal outside the clock tower on the University of Texas at Austin campus on Sunday, after a legal appeal to keep the memorial in place was rejected.

headline: Jets’ Leonard Williams Expected for Opener After Test Reveals a Strain
text: Leonard Williams, who left the Jets’ preseason game Saturday against the Giants with a knee injury, appears to have avoided a long-term absence.

headline: James L. Flanagan, Who Helped Make Computers Talk, Dies at 89
text: James L. Flanagan, whom we can thank for articulate digital assistants like Siri and intelligible subway loudspeakers and blame for the disembodied voices that inform frustrated telephone callers to listen carefully because their bank’s, airline’s or insurance company’s automated customer care options have changed, died on Tuesday at his home in Warren Township, N.J. He was 89 and would have turned 90 the next day.

headline: Braves Honor Fan Who Died in Fall
text: ATLANTA — Gregory K. Murrey was a small-business owner, father and grandfather who enjoyed seeing a local blues band and the Atlanta Braves, for whom he had been a season-ticket holder for 23 years. His passion for his hometown baseball team was evident Saturday night as Murrey, 60, wearing a Braves cap, sat with two companions in the second row of the upper deck at Turner Field.

headline: At Least 13 Reported Dead in Yemen Strikes

Renamed the AR-15, this semiautomatic assault rifle has come to haunt society in the hands of criminals and the deranged, who regularly kill innocent people in high-powered mass shootings.

headline: What’s on TV Monday
text: 1:35 P.M. (MAX) THE GRAND BUDAPEST HOTEL (2014) In this Wes Anderson film, Zero Moustafa (F. Murray Abraham) tells an author (Jude Law) the story of how he came to own the Grand Budapest Hotel. The film flashes back to 1932, detailing the friendship between the young Zero (Tony Revolori, center, with Tom Wilkinson, left, and and Owen Wilson) and the hotel concierge, Gustave H. (Ralph Fiennes). Gustave is framed for the murder of an aristocrat (Tilda Swinton) and flees with Zero. They are pursued by her family and henchmen (Adrien Brody, Willem Dafoe) while trying to protect a prized painting. Zero, meanwhile, deals with romance. “There is no doubt that Mr. Anderson possesses a distinctive sensibility and a consistent visual style, and that instead of striking out in new directions, he tends to embroider and elaborate on familiar themes and pictorial habits,” A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. “You will see many of them here: static, densely packed, fussily composed frames; traveling shots in which the camera glides alongside the characters like a low-flying bird; action sequences that refuse the usual digital hocus-pocus in favor of the older, artisanal magic of stop-motion animation, matte paintings and rear projection. You will also meet eccentric characters possessed by a kind of madcap melancholy, soulful and silly in equal measure.”

headline: Wes Craven, Whose Slasher Films Terrified Millions, Dies at 76
text: Wes Craven, a master of horror cinema and a proponent of the slasher genre who was best known for creating the “Nightmare on Elm Street” and “Scream” franchises, died on Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 76.

headline: A Heckuva Job
text: There are many things we should remember about the events of late August and early September 2005, and the political fallout shouldn’t be near the top of the list. Still, the disaster in New Orleans did the Bush administration a great deal of damage — and conservatives have never stopped trying to take their revenge. Every time something has gone wrong on President Obama’s watch, critics have been quick to declare the event “Obama’s Katrina.” How many Katrinas has Mr. Obama had so far? By one count, 23.

headline: Let Consumers Use Better, Cheaper Cable Boxes
text: Of all the electronic devices in American homes, the cable box is one of the hardest to use and probably one of the most expensive. A recent survey by two Democratic senators found that consumers spend on average about $231 a year to rent them.

headline: When Bad Doctors Happen to Good Patients
text: ONLY in Albany can a bill pass the Assembly with overwhelming bipartisan support, be sponsored by a majority of the State Senate, be endorsed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, and yet never come up for a final vote. That happened to Lavern’s Law, a bill that would have helped grievously injured victims of medical malpractice have their day in court. This summer, the Senate majority leader, John J. Flanagan, a Republican, wouldn’t allow the bill to be voted on, effectively killing it.

headline: At MTV V.M.A.s, Celebrity Feuds, Miley Cyrus and Also Some Music

Two years ago, performing on the show, she ignited a thousand think pieces with her antics, and since then, she’s become perhaps our most unfiltered pop star, for better and often for worse. She is a reliable generator of controversy, and a reliable generator of memes.

headline: The Selfie-Drone: Invasion of the Vacation Snatchers
text: It was a blistering hot Sunday in Provence. The painted shutters of the houses in Arles were closed. Visitors were scarce. In the Roman amphitheater, built to hold some 20,000 spectators, I sat among empty bleachers, above homes with orange tile roofs, looking past ancient arcades and terraces to the blue horizon. Was this the sort of stillness van Gogh experienced when he was in Arles on this same June day in 1888? I began to entertain the thought but was distracted by a soft whirring; a faint electric hum. Something was drawing near. I looked around and saw nothing — until it and I were eye to eye.

headline: Can We Improve?
text: Human beings have made progress in various areas, though it is often fitful, double-edged and reversible. But are we capable of substantial moral improvement? Could we someday be much better ethically than we are now? Is it likely that members of our species could become, on average, more generous or more honest, less self-deceptive or less self-interested? I have known individual people who have improved morally in various ways (and many who have made the opposite journey) but I’m not sure that as a species as a whole we are any better than we were 100 or even 10,000 years ago.

headline: What We Don’t Talk About When We Talk About Alcohol: Binge Drinking
text: As a parent, you’ve probably talked to your young children about alcohol (“See this drink I’m having? It’s not for you”) and to teenagers about drinking (“Don’t do it, and if you do don’t drive, and did I ever do it? Ooh, look, a woodpecker!”). But have you talked to your children, particularly your high schoolers and soon-to-be college students, about drinking the way it’s often done at that age — hard, fast, and with the intent of getting drunk?

text: GARDEN CITY, Ga. — In the kitchen of her double-wide trailer, Dora Charles sets spare ribs kissed with flour into a deep fryer and sautés yesterday’s collard greens with rice and onions. Her cooking is practiced and deliberate, learned at the hand of her father and her grandmother Hattie Smith, who showed her that seasoning something well and cooking it slowly encouraged flavors to bloom.

text: A federal judge will rule this week on whether to lift or uphold New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady’s four-game suspension by the N.F.L. after Brady and the league failed to reach an agreement to their seven-month standoff.

headline: One Thing You Can Do With Your Portfolio Right Now
text: When the markets get scary, there’s an overwhelming temptation to do something, anything really, with our portfolios. But we know better. We all know on an intellectual level that selling during a dip is a bad idea, and the data confirms that successfully timing the market is, at the very least, highly unlikely. Yet it feels crazy to just sit in front of what feels like an oncoming train.

headline: A Dream Parisian Cafe, Brought to Life
text: In the early 1970s, George Whitman, the late owner of the legendary Shakespeare & Company bookshop in Paris, had visitors make sketches of his dream cafe, which he intended to open in the adjacent building, if he ever managed to take it over. Unearthed after his death by his daughter, the current co-owner Sylvia Whitman, the drawings depicted a convivial meeting place with outdoor seating and books aplenty. Now, after more than 50 years of vacancy, the space next door has undergone a massive overhaul (the retro floor tiles were one of the few things preserved), complete with large windows through which the bookish set will be able to gaze at Notre Dame while snacking on literary treats such as Proustian madeleines and Salinger-inspired ‘‘Love and Squalor’’ pie.

headline: You Can Reduce Your Blind Spot, a Study Says
text: The human eye has a blind spot, though few of us realize it. Now, a new study suggests that it is possible to reduce the spot with training.

headline: Where to Eat and Drink in Evanston
text: The urban suburb north of Chicago has a downtown area that is picking up steam with the recent openings of farm-to-table restaurants and world-class distilleries and breweries.

headline: Breaking the Grip of the Gaokao, China’s SAT
text: The notorious Gaokao, (高考, or “High Test”) is China’s SAT on steroids, with a score on the nine-hour test being the sole criterion for admission to Chinese universities. Preparing for the test is a years-long obsession for both students and parents. (In case you missed it: Brook Larmer’s Inside a Chinese Test-Prep Factory.) And for many, the unfortunate consequence is that the lengthy preparation destroys, rather than enhances, academic ability. Student enthusiasm and curiosity are crushed.

headline: Angela Merkel Calls for European Unity to Address Migrant Influx
text: BERLIN — Faced with a humanitarian crisis that shows no signs of letting up, Chancellor Angela Merkel gave her fellow Germans and other Europeans a pep talk on Monday, praising those assisting the thousands seeking asylum here but warning that the Continent’s open-border policy was at risk unless all European countries showed an equal willingness to help.

headline: Kathy YL Chan and Her Coveted Tea, Never to Be Brewed
text: A year ago, a member of a private tea society in Shanghai presented Kathy YL Chan with a small box as slender as a cigarette case. Inside were four tiles of highly prized pu-erh tea, conjoined like a chocolate bar and almost black, twined with green and ocher.

headline: A Tour of Jayma Cardoso’s Airy Montauk Home and Office
text: The Surf Lodge owner has filled her home with artworks and objects from friends.

headline: A Montauk Home Where the Windows Are Always Open
text: The hotelier and nightlife entrepreneur Jayma Cardoso has been involved in a handful of high-profile Manhattan projects: SoHo’s GoldBar, Lavo in Midtown. But none is unmistakably hers as the Surf Lodge, the Montauk mainstay now wrapping up its sold-out eighth season: like the hotel, Cardoso is unfussy and welcoming, with an accent left over from her native Brazil and a throaty laugh she deploys often.

headline: Denali’s Name Change Upsets a Senator
text: I know it’s a tricky thing to expect consistency from politicians, but I was struck by Senator Rob Portman’s indignation at President Obama’s decision to change the name of Mount McKinley in Alaska back to Denali, which is the name that local Native Americans gave it.

headline: The Long, Winding Interview With Miley Cyrus
text: Last night, after hosting the MTV Video Music Awards in a typical polarizing performance, Miley Cyrus surprise-released a free, 23-track new album, “Miley Cyrus & Her Dead Petz,” written and recorded largely at her home with members of the Flaming Lips. In a five-hour interview the previous weekend, Ms. Cyrus, 22, discussed the experimental project, which you can read about here. But along the way, she also touched on her budding friendship with Caitlyn Jenner, learning about herself through drugs, and how she’s learned to handle the media.

headline: Ben Carson Ties Donald Trump in Iowa Poll

headline: Relationships, and Sex Lives, Benefit When Men Share Child Care

headline: 1965: Russia Rejects U.S. Proposal
text: GENEVA — The Soviet Union formally rejected today [Aug. 31] the American-proposed disarmament treaty which was designed to try to halt the spread of nuclear weapons. Soviet delegate Semyon K. Tsarapkin told the 17-nation disarmament conference the U.S. treaty draft presented Aug. 17 was unacceptable even as a basis for discussion. He described the draft as a cynical Western attempt to admit West Germany to the nuclear club by the back door. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 1, 1965

headline: Oliver Sacks: Diverse Elements in Harmony
text: In 2001, shortly after his book, “Uncle Tungsten: Memories of a Chemical Boyhood,” was published, I asked Dr. Oliver Sacks which of the chemical elements he had written about was his favorite.

headline: Challah and Brisket, Rethought for Rosh Hashana
text: Most challah is made from wheat flour. But rye, barley, spelt and oats may also be used according to Jewish law. This year, in time for Rosh Hashana, Breads Bakery is using a mixture of spelt and wheat to make a handsome and tasty round loaf. It is not kosher. The gluten- and dairy-free By the Way Bakery is making challah primarily from oat flour, under rabbinical supervision, so it’s kosher and pareve. It is baked in a ring shape and is dense and thickly studded with raisins for a bread that’s earthy and sweet: Spelt challah, $8.50, beginning Friday at Breads Bakery, 18 East 16th Street, and Breads Bakery kiosk in Bryant Park, breadsbakery.com; oat challah, $12, Sept. 11, 13, 18, 21 and 22 from By the Way Bakery, 2442 Broadway (90th Street); 574 Warburton Avenue, Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., BTWBakery.com.

headline: Rick Perry’s Woes Continue as Iowa Staff Is Cut to One Person
text: Former Gov. Rick Perry’s campaign continues to retrench.

headline: Carrie Brownstein’s Book Tour to Kick Off in Brooklyn
text: From “Portlandia” to Portland, Ore., and Brooklyn, too, Carrie Brownstein will be traveling to 11 cities across the United States this fall to promote her memoir, “Hunger Makes Me a Modern Girl” (Riverhead Books), due in October.

headline: The Eerie Realism of ‘Mr. Robot’
text: In the first episode of “Mr. Robot,” a drama that is nearing the end of its first season on the USA Network, Elliot — the show’s main character, played by Rami Malek — delivers a memorable monologue about his disillusionment with society. Elliot’s Margaret Keane-size eyes go blank as he describes feelings of isolation and disconnection from popular culture.

headline: Tracking People Like Packages: Republicans’ Inhumane Immigration Ideas
text: The Republican presidential candidates just can’t help themselves on immigration. That subject is a rhetorical sinkhole that, like Donald Trump’s mouth, just seems to keep getting bigger, swallowing candidates left and right.

headline: A New Place to Sleep in Old Barcelona
text: Despite not being particularly known for its contemporary art scene or flashy architectural projects, Barcelona is one of those rare cities that somehow always feels up to date. The same, however, can’t be said for its hotels, which are either Old World-stodgy or genera-minimalist. But the affordable new Casa Bonay, located in a stately, sun-washed 1869 building in the city’s central, semi-industrial Dreta de l’Eixample neighborhood, is changing that. The co-owner Inés Miró-Sans, who worked with the Brooklyn-based design firm Studio Tack to restore the space without destroying its 19th-century charms, preserved as many details as she could, from old fireplaces to the mosaic floors, while keeping the feeling super simple.

headline: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch
text: Most of the world’s top leagues have the week off for the international break, but the world’s top players, as usual, will get no rest. The Times’s soccer editor, Andrew Das, an unapologetic Ajax fan, suggests what to watch on television.

headline: Third World Trade Center Parachutist Is Sentenced
text: The last of three sky divers convicted on misdemeanor charges for parachuting off 1 World Trade Center two years ago was sentenced on Monday to 300 hours of community service and a $2,000 fine.

headline: Monsters Unleashed
text: Twyla Tharp is writing about rehearsing, touring and creating new work, 50 years after her first dance concert.

headline: London Theater Journal: Discipline, Punish and Put on a Play
text: LONDON – Plays about putting on plays – including knockabout farces like “Noises Off” – almost invariably raise a lump in the throat of the sentimental theatergoer. But even those resistant to this sub-genre’s charms may well mist up during a certain scene in Timberlake Wertenbaker’s “Our Country’s Good,” which has been given a big, handsome and somewhat literal-minded revival at the National Theater here.

headline: Born in Chiapas
text: A look at the traditional midwife in southern Mexico, and at modern inroads into childbirth

headline: Training Midwives to Save Expectant Mothers in Chiapas
text: Chiapas, the southernmost state in Mexico, is a mix of wonder and sadness. It is home to rain forests, Mayan ruins, waterfalls, rugged highlands — and some of the country’s highest death rates among women in childbirth.

headline: Reformist Iranian Politician Is Said to Be Held
text: TEHRAN — Iranian security forces arrested a prominent reformist politician on Monday, hours after he held a news conference thanking President Hassan Rouhani for a more open political atmosphere, several Iranian news agencies reported.

headline: Slowing Growth Exposes Chinese Banks’ Debt Debris
text: China’s economic slowdown is exposing the debt debris in its banking sector. Shaky credits on the balance sheets of the country’s four biggest lenders jumped by 28 percent to 592 billion renminbi ($92.8 billion) in the first half of the year. Further deterioration would send earnings growth into reverse.

headline: A Kugel to Savor for Rosh Hashana
text: This savory kugel is from my 102-year-old mother, Pearl, who in 1950 put the recipe in a spiral-bound cookbook to raise money for her temple. Rather than raisins and sugar, it calls for onions and garlic, with what were then considered secret ingredients, Worcestershire and Tabasco.

headline: Favorite to Lead Britain’s Labour Party Is Criticized for Bin Laden Comments
text: LONDON — The effort to undermine Jeremy Corbyn, the consensus front-runner for the leadership of Britain’s opposition Labour Party, continued on Monday with reports that Mr. Corbyn called the death of Osama bin Laden “a tragedy” in a 2011 interview just after the event.

headline: A Complicated Love Story
text: This story begins with two couples living in Seattle. The men are in a band. When one of the women gets into the City University of New York School of Law, everyone moves to New York together.

headline: From Seattle With Love: A Tale of 4 Friends and One Band
text: This is a complicated summer love story. It involves four people and one band that plays trippy surf music with elements of punk. It starts in Seattle and ends in Brooklyn. The tale is highbrow (Walt Whitman) and lowbrow (Pabst Blue Ribbon). It has a soundtrack that might be confusing.

headline: A Warhol-Worthy Watch
text: Andy Warhol’s prediction of a future in which everyone would be ‘‘world-famous for 15 minutes’’ has largely come true. And yet, nearly 30 years after his death, his own fame lives on: Maison Piaget’s Black Tie Vintage Inspiration watch, with a spare black onyx face framed in white gold, is an updated version of a 1973 model from the artist’s own collection.

headline: Eating on the Move May Lead to Later Overindulging
text: Eating on the go may be worse than eating in front of the television, a new study reports, and may lead people to overindulge later.

headline: Supplements Don’t Fight Cognitive Decline, N.I.H. Study Says
text: Omega-3 fatty acids and antioxidants are often marketed to promote brain health. But one study to test these supplements has found no evidence that the pills stave off cognitive decline in older people.

headline: Amid Attacks over Mountain Names and Arctic Oil Leases, Obama Seeks Alaska Survival Tips from Bear Grylls
text: Kicking off his Alaska tour, President Obama is scheduled to talk about climate change, oil and the Arctic later tonight at an ambitiously titled Anchorage event — the Conference on Global Leadership in the Arctic: Cooperation, Innovation, Engagement and Resilience.

headline: S.E.C.’s In-House Judges Not Too Tough, a Review Shows
text: The Dodd-Frank Act allowed the Securities and Exchange Commission to bring almost any claim that it can file in a federal court before its own administrative law judges. The agency has since taken up this power against a panoply of inside traders and others accused of securities fraud.

headline: The Most Prized (and Totally Random) Possessions of Nine Famous People
text: Each weekend, T hands over the keys of its Instagram account to a single editor to post pictures of whatever he or she is feeling at the moment. The most recent curations have been all-summer-everything: T’s deputy editor Hanya Yanagihara and senior online editor Isabel Wilkinson each posted images of remote places in which to take a dip (hotel pools and swimming holes, respectively); art director Shawn Carney celebrated the dog days with a survey of seasonal album covers; and features associate Lauren Poggi honored summer’s finest elements through the lenses of art and photography.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: When Your Sex Life Doesn’t Follow the Script
text: If someone had told me 10 years ago that I would one day announce in The New York Times how old I was when I lost my virginity, I would have died of embarrassment.

headline: Judge Allows Moral, Not Just Religious, Contraception Exemptions
text: WASHINGTON — Employers do not need to provide insurance coverage for contraception even if their objections are moral rather than religious, a federal judge here ruled on Monday.

headline: D.A. Recounts Shooting of Police Officer
text: Devon Anderson, the district attorney for Harris County, Tex., described the fatal shooting of Deputy Darren Goforth. Shannon J. Miles has been charged with murder.

headline: ‘On the Town’ Takes Box Office Leap Thanks to Misty Copeland
text: The nation’s most famous ballerina has now conquered Broadway too.

headline: Prosecutors Say Shannon Miles Shot Texas Deputy 15 Times
text: HOUSTON — The man charged with killing a sheriff’s deputy at a suburban gas station Friday emptied his 15-round handgun into the back and the back of the head of the deputy, as witnesses watched in horror and surveillance cameras captured the shooting, prosecutors said Monday.

headline: Mediator on Failed Brady Talks
text: Jay Feely of the N.F.L. Players Association spoke to reporters, and the N.F.L. commissioner, Roger Goodell, and the New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady left court after settlement talks failed.

headline: Afghanistan’s Electoral Reform Plan Is Met With Skepticism
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Months late, Afghanistan’s electoral reform commission has delivered a list of proposals, in a critical step to holding overdue parliamentary elections.

headline: Faking Doctors’ Notes to Escape Gaza War Zone
text: GAZA — The medical report details some worrying conditions: chronic dyspnea — a shortage of breath that could be a sign of heart or lung disease — and bronchial asthma. It says the patient, a 28-year-old woman from Gaza City, relies on “continuous medication” and an inhaler.

headline: Amal Clooney Discusses Al Jazeera Case
text: Amal Clooney, a lawyer representing the Canadian journalist Mohamed Fahmy of Al Jazeera during his trial in Egypt, reiterated her call for the Canadian prime minister to intervene.

headline: India’s Supreme Court Suspends Ban on Starvation Ritual
text: NEW DELHI — India’s Supreme Court on Monday suspended a state-level court’s ban on a religious practice called santhara, a fast to the death most often undertaken by the sick and aged.

headline: ‘The Cost of Cable Is Preposterous’: Readers Sound Off on Set-Top Boxes
text: Our editorial this morning calling on the Federal Communications Commission to make it easier for people to buy their own cable boxes attracted hundreds of comments from readers. Not surprisingly, most of the people writing in were unhappy with cable and satellite companies, which generate nearly $20 billion in revenue from renting out boxes to their customers.

headline: Can a Computer Tell Whether Something Was Written by a Man or a Woman?
text: Q. Can a computer tell from published documents whether the author is a man or a woman?

headline: Ponchos Are the New Frontier
text: Five styles for the modern pioneer. (Go West, young man.)

headline: MTV’s V.M.A.s Dominated Social Media, but Had Fewer Viewers
text: MTV’s Video Music Awards drew 9.8 million viewers on Sunday, about a half a million viewers fewer than watched last year’s show, according to Nielsen.

headline: ‘SpongeBob’ Musical Will Open in Chicago, With Sights on Broadway
text: He might live in a pineapple under the sea, but next year SpongeBob SquarePants hopes to make his home onstage on Broadway. First: Chicago.

headline: Wes Craven, a Filmmaker Who Invaded Your Dreams
text: When Wes Craven started making horror movies, he had hardly seen any. “I didn’t even know what a horror film was,” he told me several years ago. “I kind of made it up as I went along.”

headline: White Supremacist Convicted of Killing 3 at Kansas Jewish Centers
text: OLATHE, Kan. — A white supremacist was convicted of capital murder on Monday in the shooting deaths of three people a year ago at a Jewish community center and an assisted living facility in suburban Kansas City.

headline: Review: ‘Puffin Rock’ Joins Parade of Shows Aimed at Youngest Viewers
text: The newest Netflix series, “Puffin Rock,” arrives on Tuesday full of action, suspense and topicality. A valuable cargo is hauled across a beach under a ticking deadline. The story’s heroine disappears, and her father sets out to find her. The whole cast gathers to take in the supermoon.

headline: In Topping Charts, Disturbed Accomplishes a Rare Feat
text: The metal band Disturbed has the No. 1 album this week with “Immortalized” (Reprise), which sold 93,000 copies and had just over three million streams, according to Nielsen. It is the band’s fifth consecutive release to open in the top slot, a rare chart feat — Metallica and the Dave Matthews Band are the only other groups to have done it, Billboard reported.

headline: Mourning Kyle Jean-Baptiste, ‘Les Misérables’ Actor Who Plunged to His Death
text: Several hundred people gathered at the Bethesda Fountain in Central Park on Monday afternoon to celebrate the life of Kyle Jean-Baptiste, the 21-year old actor who died last week in a fall from a fire escape in Brooklyn. Mr. Jean-Baptiste was the first African-American to play the role of Jean Valjean in “Les Misérables” on Broadway, as well as the youngest.

headline: Strict Enforcement of FIFA Rules Sidelines Young Players Abroad
text: Ben Lederman still gets up early for school every morning so he can be finished in time for soccer training. He still practices, every day, at La Masia, the famed youth academy of F.C. Barcelona. He still spends much of his time at a place where he occasionally crosses paths with stars like Lionel Messi.

headline: Transgender Inmate Who Sued Georgia Gets Unexpected Parole
text: Ashley Diamond, the transgender inmate who sued Georgia in February for access to hormone therapy and protection against prison rape, was unexpectedly paroled on Monday after serving less than a third of a 12-year sentence for burglary.

headline: Review: ‘Atomic Orbital’ and ‘Midway Avenue,’ Examining Electrons and Memories
text: Choreography may not be quite as perplexing as quantum mechanics, but it is a mysterious art. “Atomic Orbital,” Laura Peterson’s contribution to a shared program at Here this past weekend, is an abstract dance whose clean lines, attention to detail and complex sense of stage space recall the work of Merce Cunningham. And yet something is missing, the something that makes such abstraction dramatically absorbing. It’s hard to say exactly what that something is.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: Locrian Chamber Players, With Music Wrapped in Temporary Mystery
text: Two rules govern concerts by the Locrian Chamber Players: The music cannot be older than 10 years, and program notes are provided only after the event, at the exit.

headline: Review: Madboots Dance Ignores Gender Boundaries
text: BECKET, Mass. — In the final week of this year’s Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival, much of the warmest applause was directed at the woman giving the preshow speeches: Ella Baff, who is moving on after 17 years as the festival’s executive and artistic director. Her closing round of introductions addressed America’s oldest dance troupe, the Martha Graham Dance Company, and one of its youngest, Madboots Dance.

headline: Michigan Lawmakers Misused Aides to Cover Up Affair, Report Finds
text: Two Michigan legislators forced their aides to do political and personal work on state time, including helping cover up their affair, and then lied repeatedly about their actions, according to an investigation by the State House of Representatives, whose findings were released Monday.

headline: Tennis Fans Excited for U.S. Open
text: Tennis fans lining up outside Arthur Ashe Stadium in New York, excited to see their favorite players, including Serena Williams, in this year’s U.S. Open.

headline: T-Mobile Says It Will Ban Abusers of Unlimited Data Plan
text: T-Mobile USA, one of the few phone carriers to still offer an unlimited data plan, has run into a classic Homer Simpson problem: The company says it will get rid of abusers of its all-you-can-eat data privileges, similar to when Homer was thrown out of a restaurant for eating too much seafood at an all-you-can-eat buffet.

headline: Review: From Taka Kigawa, a Class on Resonance at Le Poisson Rouge
text: Summer school has been in session in New York piano recitals. Recently, at the Kaplan Penthouse at Lincoln Center, Pierre-Laurent Aimard gave a lesson in canons and fugues, a prelude to his performance of George Benjamin’s combination of those two forms in “Shadowlines.” And on Aug. 24 at another intimate space, Le Poisson Rouge, Taka Kigawa held a class on reverberation and resonance.

headline: Review: In ‘Make Me,’ Lee Child Adds Another Layer to Jack Reacher
text: “Grain, meet the railroad” Jack Reacher tells himself, after he’s picked the latest sinister little Nowheresville in which to spend a book’s length of time. He appears to have gotten off a train in the middle of wheat country, for no better reasons than he liked the cryptic name of the town, Mother’s Rest, and that he’s got foolproof instincts for sniffing out trouble. Lee Child’s Reacher series has hit Book No. 20 with a resounding peal of wisecracking glee (“Are you going to be a problem?” “I’m already a problem. The question is, what are you going to do about it?”). Everything about it, starting with Reacher’s nose for bad news, is as strong as ever.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Ukraine and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: August 31, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Ukraine, Greece, Russia and Nepal.

headline: An Outpouring of Reader Reflection After the Death of Oliver Sacks
text: When Oliver Sacks died at age 82 on Sunday, readers flocked to his obituary to pay their respects. Many wrote of their connections to the neurologist as patients, mentees and, largely, as readers. In his essay last February “My Own Life,” Dr. Sacks acknowledged the impact his readers had had on his life, writing, “I have had an intercourse with the world, the special intercourse of writers and readers.”

headline: In Vienna, Trains Packed With Refugees Are Welcomed and Ushered On
text: VIENNA — Six trains packed with migrants arrived on Monday at the Westbahnhof rail station in Vienna from Budapest and Hegyeshalom, a Hungarian village near the border with Austria.

headline: Jorge Ramos Is Not Walter Cronkite
text: Shortly after Donald Trump’s bodyguard forcibly removed him from a press conference in Dubuque, Iowa, the Univision news anchor Jorge Ramos declared that the ejection had caught him by surprise. As he told George Stephanopoulos on “Good Morning America,” “Never in my life, and I’ve been a journalist more than 30 years, have I been thrown out of a press conference.” Technically, Ramos’s statement is true. But anyone who has read his books knows that he has tangled with bodyguards before, even if they weren’t at a press conference.

headline: Obama Makes Urgent Appeal in Alaska for Climate Change Action
text: ANCHORAGE — President Obama on Monday issued a global call for urgent action to address climate change, declaring that the United States was partly to blame for what he called the defining challenge of the century and would rally the world to counter it.

headline: Why Students With Smallest Debts Have the Larger Problem
text: Politicians who complain about college costs frequently cite two numbers: one trillion and seven million. Student borrowers owe more than $1 trillion, and seven million borrowers are in default, according to the latest Department of Education data.

headline: At Manhattan Marriage Bureau, a Union of Matrimony and Bureaucracy
text: The brides wore white, temporarily, retrieving ticket No. C685 from a kiosk inside the Manhattan marriage bureau — that great municipal deli of matrimony — and waiting to be served.

headline: A Day at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau
text: Two changes have helped fuel greater use of the bureau: the legalization of same-sex marriage and an effort by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to make it a premiere wedding destination.

headline: Greenlight Capital Down 14% for Year; David Einhorn Surveys Investors
text: David Einhorn has earned a reputation as one of the savviest stock pickers on Wall Street. But the recent market turmoil has not spared him, and this year is shaping up to be one of the worst in his big hedge fund firm’s two-decade history.

headline: Iran Nuclear Deal Gains Momentum With Endorsements of Four House Democrats
text: Three House Democrats from New York and a House Democrat from Florida who is running for a Senate seat endorsed President Obama’s nuclear deal with Iran on Monday, lending fresh momentum to the pact from political quarters that once appeared most leery of it.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Takes to Twitter for a Lunchtime Chat
text: The message went out just before 1 p.m., lurching into the social media wilderness of lunchtime on a late summer Monday.

headline: Calling the Midwife, in Chiapas
text: In Chiapas, Mexico, a midwife may be the only person there to help a woman when she gives birth.

headline: Teenage Motherhood in France
text: Vivane Dalles labored to find the money — and outside interest — to pursue an intensive project on teenage mothers in France.
